Q44_1:
This year was another exciting year of art for students at PS 15, as we continue to expand our programs and partners (adding Puppetry this year). In addition, through implementation of the School-wide Enrichment Model, the faculty and staff have played an integral part in providing sustainable arts programming based on student-interest in clusters such as “Art for Change,” “Photography,” “Making Music” and “Trash to Treasure”. 
We continued residency programs with organizations such as The Children's Museum of Art, Mark DeGarmo Dance and Third Street Music, in which kindergarten through fifth grade students learned through the Orff Shulwerk approach. Students explored basic rhythms/melodies using various instruments. 
All our students visited arts museums, films and performances to supplement and extend arts learning objectives grown out of classroom curriculum. We continued our nine-year relationship with Arts for All, Inc, providing our kindergarten through second grade students with opportunities to integrate theater and visual art into literacy. Our students have many opportunities to express themselves through dance, music, and theater with our partnerships with Mark DeGarmo Dance, Rosie’s Broadway Kids, puppetry with Arts Connection and creative storytelling with Story Pirates. Lastly, through our Technology Arts class, students study mentor artists, learn coding, graphic design, and animation. We expect to have many submissions to this year’s District 1 Arts Fair and close the year on a high note for Arts at PS 15!
Q46_2: Arts Education Liaison and Schoolwide Enrichment Coordinator

Q44_1: We strongly believe that the arts should be an important part of a school's academic program. We have participated in and developed a wide variety of educational programs and activities to support the inclusion of the arts (music, art, movement and drama) in the daily curriculum offerings to our students. Many community agencies support us including Third Street Music School, Rosie's Broadway Kids and the Beacon after school program. Visitors to PS 19 often comment on the extent to which the students are engaged with their work. We are particularly proud of our school's warm and sociable tone and productive learning environment.

Every student at PS 20 is engaged in the arts in a variety of ways. Our current partnerships have allowed us to provide dance and movement instruction to all of our students in grades 2-5. Turtle Bay Music School continues to provide ORFF and world music classes to our students in grades PK-2 as well as a chorus for our 3rd graders. Our classroom teachers, cluster teachers, and our partners work closely to integrate the arts into our units of study. In addition to our many partnerships, we have a school based visual arts teacher and music teacher who meet with most of the classes once a week. Both arts teachers try to coordinate their curriculum with the literacy and social studies curriculum. Another partnership we are very proud of is our that with American BaLLET Theater, our 5th graders get too learn ballet and theater. The students get an opportunity to perform at the Metropolitan Opera House at the end of the year. Our Fourth graders dance all year with teachers from the National Dance Institute and have 2 performances for Families and school. In addition, our 5th graders get to be part of Rosie's Broadway Kids, this program gives them the opportunity to go to a Broadway show. They also have weekly dance classes for half of the school year. Our Art teacher and Music teacher are active all year teaching all our students to play instruments and different fine arts techniques. This year they will have a Arts festival day where they will present to the student.We are always looking for new ways to expand our programming

Our school currently offers music instruction by a certified full-time music teacher. The CCLS aligned curriculum taught is primarily string instruments. Students perform in a winter and spring concert. Our school partners with two community based organizations that provide visual arts and music instruction. We continue to partner with Rosie's Kids theater program.

Our school is dedicated to exposing students to the many opportunities New York City has to offer in the arts. Every semester we offer ballroom dancing through our physical education classes. Lincoln Center visits every semester to work with our students on a small theatrical performance. Our after school program allows students to explore museums across the city and attend Broadway shows. We offer choir, modern dance, drama and visual arts after school and they perform several times throughout the year. Our goal is to continue our partnerships and allow our students the opportunity to learn about American culture and living through the arts. Additionally we partner with Magic Box, Abrons Center for the Arts Henry Street Settlement, and Ballet Hispanico. From 2016 through 2020 we will be in a partnership with Exploring the Arts.

At P.S. 63, our commitment to the arts is always growing. Since the 2010-2011 school year full-time music and visual arts instruction by certified arts teachers has been offered to all grades. In visual art classes students explore a variety of 2 dimensional and 3 dimensional media and techniques. Additionally, they are exposed to a wide variety artists both contemporary and from art history as well as careers in the arts. In music, all students kindergarten through 5th grade, are given keyboard instruction, as well as instruction in reading music and singing. As students move into the upper grades they learn additional instruments such as the tin whistle and bucket drums. To enhance our arts program we continue our partnership with the dance education organization Notes in Motion and theater partnership with Script to Stage-Young Storytellers in 5th grade.

The P.S. 64 Arts program makes constant efforts to provide a range of artistic and cultural experiences throughout grade levels. The Students receive focused visual arts lessons from a certified fine art education teacher who also holds a masters degree in fine arts. The students receive instruction one to three times a week through the entire school year. The art facilities are well suited for a wide range of medium; Painting, Sculpture, printmaking, life drawing, and collage are all part of the curriculum. The classroom teacher and visual arts teacher integrate curriculum to foster richer learning. The art curriculum also focuses on the benchmarks set through the blueprint for the arts. Theater, music and dance are also provided to the students by outside cultural organizations. Professionals from within the fields of music, dance, and theater, provide direct instruction to students in these content areas.

The students, staff and parents are fully committed to the integration of all art forms across all grades. Our licensed Dance teacher collaborates with teachers to align her program with the science and social studies curriculum. Our licensed music teacher integrates her work with developing social emotional growth of our students. The Studio-In-A-School artist- in-residence works closely with classroom teachers to guide our students toward rich explorations of visual art as an extension of mathematical and analytical thinking.

P.S. 140's goals for our schools' art programs focus on coordinating the planning between the classroom teachers, the music teacher, part-time visual arts teacher and visiting artists in order to integrate the arts and curriculum to have a more positive impact on student learning. We look forward to building on the addition of the visual arts program through the Arts Matters initiative this past year. We expect that this initiative will inspire and encourage students to gain skills and confidence through art and galleries. In addition, we will continue to enhance our school environment and culture by encouraging performances and displays that not only celebrate the talents of our students but also create more of a connection and understanding of the various units of study in different curriculum areas. We currently and consistently have student work on display throughout our school building. This enables students to support each other and gain respect for each others work and skills. In addition, we have a middle school art gallery and photography wall which showcases the art work and photography created by our middle school students in collaboration with our community based arts organizations.
Q45_1: We did not receive 21st Century Grant, as we had for the past 14 years, that supported the arts program at M140.  Budget does not allow for M140 to sustain many, and possibly all partnerships with Arts organizations.

Q44_1: PS 142 is known for its arts programs, including sequential art and music during the school day. A comprehensive extended-day arts program in partnership with the Educational Alliance takes place from 2:40-5:30 PM daily. This program includes musical theater, tap dance, art, photography, filmmaking, mask making and storytelling. The program culminates in two showcases and an annual original school musical. Third Street Music School Settlement brought recorder and african drumming to all students in grades 3-5. 3rd grades studied songwriting with Broadway Playhouse (Kaufman Center), including attending 3 performances. Rosie's Kids provided musical theater for students in grade 5. Studio in a school brought visual art to grades Pre-K and K and Story Pirates brought theater and storytelling to grades K, 2, 3, and 4. In art classes, students studied artists, techniques and processes, elements and principles of art and major works of the different periods of art history. In addition to Music and the Brain keyboard classes and pre-school Orff, students can elect to participate in chorus after school.

Shuang Wen School has always prided itself on academics --mathematics, literacy, science and the arts. We provide music, dance, and visual arts instruction for all elementary and most middle school students. In addition to classroom instruction, students visit various cultural and community organizations throughout the year. Within the school year, all elementary and middle school students perform and exhibit their work for their parents, teachers and our school. This year, thanks to PTA's support, 3rd Street Music Center provided music program to our students from grades Pre-k to 3rd grade. For the upcoming 2017-2018school year, Shuang Wen plans to hire an in-house music teacher to provide music program with language acquisition integrated curriculum.

Q42_R1_C1: Learning through an Expanded Arts Program
Q44_1:
PS/MS 188 - The Island School, is dedicated to implementing a rigorous academic program and to identifying and nurturing each student's talents. To accomplish this, we strive to secure funding for arts resources and opportunities for our Pre-K, Elementary and Middle School students.   Our 2016-17 CBO arts partners include Studio in a School, LEAP, Marquis Studios, Rosie's Theatre Kids, Disney Musicals in School, SEA, and more! 

We believe that the arts provide a unique entry point into academics.  With this in  mind, we collaborate with these CBOs to implement arts-infused curricula in core subject areas, as well as to provide skills-based arts instruction.   PS/MS 188 is designated a NYC DOE  Showcase School.  Our Technology/Media Arts program has been highlighted at our regularly held Open Houses for NYC DOE educators and administrators, and commended by Chancellor Farina.  

We believe that the arts provide meaningful pathways for success to and in high school, and beyond. Using Renzulli's School-wide Enrichment/Talent Development Model, we provide students with a comprehensive range of experiences in the Arts:  Type I (Exposure & Exploration); Type II (Skills Development); Type III (Application of Skills to Real-Life Situations).  The arts at PS/MS 188 greatly enrich our student's lives, and provide inspiration and pathways for our students when they move on to secondary school.   As importantly, the arts contribute greatly to our vibrant school culture.
Q45_1:
Our school enrollment is approximately 97% Title 1 eligible, with disproportionately 
high representation of student groups most at risk:  47% of our students live in temporary housing (2nd highest percent across NYC public schools); 33% are classified as Students with Disabilities; 28% are English Language Learners; 66% are Latino and 32% are African American.  

The arts play a vital role in engaging our students both during the regular school day and in extended day programming, and contribute dramatically to our vibrant school culture.

Q42_R1_C1: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
Q44_1: In 2016-2017 TASS provided arts instruction in visual arts, and video/film. All students received four periods per week of visual arts, and 6th and seventh grade received introduction to video making in their tech classes which were given twice per week.  Furthermore, we are a Lincoln Center Institute partner school. Our teachers receive professional development through Lincoln Center. LCI provides teaching artists who work with the students throughout the school year. All students receive at least one session with Lincoln Center where they spend 3 hours prepping to see an arts event (being steeped in the art genre as it is integrated into a content area) and then another 3 hours post event, debriefing and completing a project based upon the art show; thus receiving an integrated, comprehensive art experience.
Q45_1: A register loss has had a significant impact on our budget and has limited our ability to provide a vast array of art experiences.

Q44_1:
Art Studio: Students are introduced to a variety of art materials and techniques. The focus is on creating art, observing art, talking about art and writing about art. Students become familiar with various artists and art movements from around the world and throughout history. Students work independently and in groups to create art projects that incorporate a wide array of artistic concepts and materials. Students work on projects that deepen their knowledge of the elements of art (line, shape, form, color, value, texture, and space) while they develop their own artistic style/voice. Projects are often tied to social studies curricula.

Dance Studio: Students are introduced to a variety of dance styles/techniques and work to create their own choreography. They work individually and in pairs and groups to create dance routines. Dance techniques are taught across the grades and are age and developmentally appropriate. Dance genres are often tied to social studies curricula.

Theater Program: Teacher works in classrooms with teachers to support social studies work through drama.  

Music Program:  Students are introduced to a variety of ways of making music - vocals, instrumental, and percussive.  Students become familiar with various artists, styles of music, and genres of music from around the world and various time periods.  Students work together and alone to both create new pieces of music as well as to perform music of a variety of genres both chorally and with instruments.

Q37_4: They participate in fundraising to provide students art enrichment.
Q44_1:
Our arts curriculum is purposefully integrated and scheduled into our school day as an integral part of our social studies core curriculum.
It therefore becomes inclusive of all students and addresses each child's intellectual, physical and emotional development.  Our arts program provides opportunities for our students to explore and express their creativity through learning activites in music, movement, and visual arts.  As a small school with limited funding, we depend on the engagement and financial support of our parent body and community-based organizations.  Together we are able to provide a rich and essential arts program that helps our students thrive in a rich creative environment and achieve academic success.

Q33_6: Blueprint for Moving Image and Ticket for 2
Q44_1:
Art is integral to the experience of each child at the Neighborhood School.  Throughout their time at the Neighborhood School, students take part in visual art, music, and theater programs.  At our school, students experience art for its own sake--partnering with Studio in the School and other cultural organizations to learn discipline-specific skills and to explore new forms of expression.  Through these vital programs, students have a chance to collaborate with professional artists in residency-based programs. 

Field trips are integral to our work and curriculum at the Neighborhood School.  Teachers work closely with educators and teaching artists at a range of museums and cultural institutions throughout NYC.  Teachers plan trips connected with studies in all academic and artistic areas.  Throughout their time at TNS, students will likely visit the Whitney, Museum of the City of New York, the NY Historical Society, MOMA, the Met, Studio Museum, NMAI, and many more.  We are a partnership school with the New Victory Theater.

Curriculum at The Neighborhood School is multi-disciplinary and project-based.  Students have a chance to collaborate on arts-based culminating projects.  Additionally, all students take part in Project Time in their classrooms or in the Makers' Space multiple times per week.  Project Time is a time in which students choose, design, plan, and execute a project of their own design.  Examples include projects in film, animation, robotics, painting, printmaking, wood-working, sewing, blocks, and more.

Our mission at the Earth School to support our students inherent love of learning through a curriculum that is engaging, playful, socially-conscious and rigorous. We are committed to knowing each student through his or her individual strengths and to nurturing the development of the whole child. To this end, students receive arts instruction that is integrated into the main curriculum of their classroom, as well as stand-alone arts instruction in visual arts, dance, music, and theater.

Q42_R1_C1: Society of 3rd Street Music School Settlement
Q44_1:
At MS 131 we have three ARTS programs which the students can select one of, for their three-year specialization. 
MUSIC: The Music Program focuses on instrumental music. Students
explore the elements of music – rhythm, melody and harmony through the study of piano. Critical listening skills are developed through exposure to a variety of musical styles including classical, jazz, rock and world music.  Music Majors choose a string instrument – violin, viola, cello or guitar to deepen their study of music at a higher level and give live performances in and out of school.
The Visual Arts program at MS 131 serves a diverse student body comprised of SPED, ELL, and GenEd students in a 3-year, a sequential curriculum designed to prepare students for entrance into specialized arts high schools throughout New York City. Throughout the 3-year art program, students visit art galleries and show their own work in semi-annual art gallery shows, as well as throughout the year in classrooms, hallways and even the MoMA and The Metropolitan Museum of Art, this year. 
Dance Education Program is dedicated to developing dancers that are interested in developing exceptional dance artists. The dance curriculum is designed to create strong technical dancers where skill and confidence are acquired along with a passion for the performing arts. Students develop as professional dance artists, critical thinkers, problem solvers, choreographers, teachers, leaders, and individuals. Literacy and technology are used to research and create dance.

The school currently has a full time visual arts teacher. All 6th grade students take art at least twice a week. We have a partnership with Lincoln Center and they provide professional development to support teachers with integrating the arts across content areas. Lincoln Center also provides in school performance and Spoken Word residency.

UNHS believes in exposing students to diverse forms of fine arts, media arts, dance, music, and theater. During the school day, every student takes at least one dance, music, and/or visual arts course each semester. Our visual arts program fosters students’ creativity and addresses their social and emotional needs while encouraging thoughtful application of the formal and conceptual aspects of art and art making. Through collaboration on projects such as mural painting and art installations, our students develop artistic and interpersonal skills as they play an active role in beautifying our school and community. Our music program offers music literacy through keyboarding for all students and infuses technology through beat making; jazz and rock bands allow for student choice. Students also take dance courses as a part of their regular coursework, studying various forms of cultural dances and examine the technique, history, influence, and aesthetics of each. For 2017-18, we wish to begin tracking students through sequential arts concentrations and maintain a collaborative community partnership with Abrons Arts Center/Henry Street Settlement.
Q45_1: 2017-2018 School year will be the first school year we are building sequential arts programming. We will be offering arts tracks in dance, music, and visual arts to interested and talented students.

Q44_1: We strive to expose our students to a variety of arts options in order to expand their horizons and make them more well rounded individuals. Students express themselves in a myriad of ways and thus we work on providing them with a variety of opportunities. We currently provide our students Visual Arts, Digital Photography, Dance, Guitar, Composing music beats and spoken word, film, rock band, and theater. Students have the opportunity to try 2 different types of arts classes each year from 6-12th grade four days a week plus after school classes and clubs. Each year we strive to strengthen the programs currently in place and to expand the variety of choices by doing outreach to outside organizations.

Forsyth Satellite Academy is an alternative, transfer high school created to work with young adults who have been unsuccessful in large, traditional high school settings. Our mission is to provide students who have opted out of larger, traditional high schools an opportunity to complete their education in a smaller, student-centered learning community. We believe in the power of knowledge,words, art, relationships and non-violence. We nurture self-determination, hope and confidence in our students. Our 208 students enroll in classes that are designed to awaken their love of learning and to foster a sense of community. The curriculum, which includes the arts, encourages students to make connections between what they encounter on their academic journey and what they experience in the world. Currently, we offer courses in visual and media arts. These courses are specifically designed for our students by teachers who collaborate with arts professionals from Downtown Community Television.

Q42_R1_C10: The organization came out of the 21st Century Grant which is scheduled to end this year.
Q44_1: Marta Valle High School believes in the importance of enhancing and educating every student through Music, Art and Dance, in addition to all academic core areas. All students have the opportunity to take courses in Required Visual Art and Required Music which meets five days a week. The required classes are prerequisites for the advance classes offered in the arts which include: Advanced visual art, painting and drawing, Music Audio Engineering, Piano I , Piano II. Through the 21st Century Grant, after school Dance classes, Art Club and Music Club are offered to the students. There are two major music performance events. Also, included in our concerts are group/or solo pianists. Both the Winter Show and the Spring Show involve mostly all the students involved in the arts. There is usually a cast of 25-40 performers. Non performing students take the roles of producer, set designer, program designer, lighting controller, sound mixer/audio, and stage manager. In this coming year,a new expansion of facilities in the MVHS Recording Studio,has begun. All arts instruction is aligned to the New York State Blueprints for Teaching and Learning in the arts and offers a pathway for excellence and engagement in the arts for all students. *Please view samples of past and present performances at our school website: https://sites.google.com/a/martavalle.org/mr-rizzo-s-music-program/
Q45_1: https://sites.google.com/a/martavalle.org/mr-rizzo-s-music-program/

Q44_1: NEST+m is a city-wide K-12 G&T screened school. We are a STEM school that is committed to meeting the needs of all learners. This committment means that we value the arts AND the sciences. To do this, we take every opportunity to promote the arts. We supplement in-school programs and courses with after school arts programming. In SY 16-17 we added new residencies for 4th, 5th, and 6th grades to provide additional arts exposure. We look forward to continuing on this mission.

Students who apply and are accepted into our transfer high school will be provided with the necessary arts courses to satisfy New York State Department of Education requirements for high school graduation. Additionally, to assist with college and career readiness and enhance the critical thinking abilities of our children, we provide arts courses in the following areas: Studio Art, Photography, and Multi-Media Laboratory.  In addition, arts programs are contracted with the school to provide on-site programs in dance and theater.
Q45_1:
Cascades High School was established in 1999 as an Alternative, Transfer high school for “at risk and over age / under credited” students between the ages of 17 and 20 who have at least 15 credits. It is located on the third and fourth floor of a building situated on the Lower East Side of Manhattan adjacent to the Chinatown community. Our diverse student body is drawn from students who have chosen to attend Cascades High School after having experienced difficulty adjusting to the traditional learning environment found in other New York City Comprehensive High Schools. The shared commonality for all of our students is that they are over age and under-credited and want to complete requirements for a high school diploma.
The student body is served by 21 full time professionals and support staff, including one (1) principal, (1) assistant principal, (12) teachers, (1) guidance counselor, (1) secretary, (1) computer technician, (1) parent coordinator and (3) school aides. Of the 12 teachers on staff, 42% have more than 5 years teaching experience, and 75% hold a Master’s Degree. Three of the teachers are in their first year of teaching.

We have a very diverse student body -- in terms of ethnicity and economics. It is an early college, so the students tend to be highly motivated, but often feel too busy/stressed for full arts participation.

Q44_1: Tompkins Square fosters every student's potential in multiple art disciplines.  We continue to supplement our PE program with dance. Through an arts continuum grant we are partnering with Third Street Music Settlement to provide music education to our 6th grade with the goal of expanding to other grades. We will be expanding our theater program to a larger classroom fitted out with lighting and a sound system. As much as 20% of our graduating 8th graders go on to art-related high schools.

This year we have hired a full time Visual Arts teacher to provide courses to students at all grade levels.  Curriculum is developed with the Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in Visual Arts. Units are currently:

Unit :0 Sketchbooks/Elements of Art and Principles of Design
Unit 1A: Drawing/Graffiti/Street Art
Unit 1B: Drawing Observational
Unit 2A:Painting/Color Theory
Unit 2B: Painting Observational
Unit 3A: Collage elements of Art
Unit 3B: Puppets/Shadow
Unit 4A: Sewing/Sample patters
Unit 4B: Sewing Animals
Unit 5A: Paper Making practice
Unit 5B: Paper puppets/Sculptures
Unit 6A Sculpture Intro
Unit 6B Sculpture forms, newspaper, clay.

As a supplement, our school has applied for and received a 5 year Extended School Day/School Violence Prevention grant that is used to fund our partnership with Groundswell and Harmony.  Groundswell Groundswell brings together artists, youth, and community organizations through to use art as a tool for social change and beautify our school space. Harmony allows us to provide music instruction to our students through trained teachers that guide students from beginner group instruction to orchestral performance.

Q42_R1_C1: Young People's Chorus of New York
Q44_1: Our current arts programs are embedded into our school curriculum and content studies. We ensure that every child has the opportunity to be involved in the arts program as a musician, singer, artist, director, stage hand, script writer, ballerina, or choreographer. Our goal is to expose our children to all arts forms as they continue to grow as learners at P.S. 1 and become well -rounded citizens in society.

P.S. 2 believes in the importance of arts education as part of our rigorous and well rounded curriculum.  Visual arts, music and theatre classes engage students in a wide range of learning.  Our visual arts curriculum includes exploration of different art forms while incorporating a study of famous artists.  The music curriculum includes instruction in instrumental performance (keyboard, xylophone and recorder) as well as instruction in reading music. Our theatre arts program provides students with experience in acting and play writing. Enrichment periods are scheduled to provide additional opportunities in arts learning.  To prepare students for 21st century learning, our students use their individual ipad apps to create iMovies, keynote for presentations as well as pages for poster presentations.  These are integrated into all content areas of the curriculum - reading, writing, social studies and science.  This is our second year with the Abrons Art Center at Henry Street Settlement.  This year's focus has been on theatre and dance for our students, prek through 1st grade.  National Dance Institute continues their 30 year history at P.S. 2 teaching our 5th graders. At P.S.2, we recognize the significant impact of art learning: promoting academic learning, developing important skills, and building positive self-esteem.  It is our goal that our students receive the highest quality arts learning.

There is exceptionally strong school community support for the arts. An integral part of the school's mission is to integrate the arts with the academic curriculum. Many classroom teachers have professional backgrounds or serious amateur involvement in one or more of the arts, and many of our families have professional involvement in the arts as well. We offer visual arts, movement, technology and music programs supported by a combination of Department of Education and PTA funding, as well as a grant from the Rudin Foundation. Our children have in-house movement classes twice a week and in-house art once a week. Our clay and music programs provide extra time in the arts each week. The PTA also funds "artist and scientist in residence" mini-grants to classroom teachers. These permit teachers to partner with outside arts and cultural organizations to support student learning through the arts within the classroom. We take full advantage of local arts organizations, museums, and theaters through residencies and field trips.
Q45_1: Our school has many in house art teachers, music, singing, studio arts, media, clay and two movement teachers. We have multiple performances by the children for the children in dance music, theater and studio art. This is in addition to the many field trips, artists in residence and outside arts groups who work with our kids.

Q44_1: Our young artists are active and exuberant explorers who become increasingly curious about the art world around them. They will discover that ideas can be interpreted in a variety of ways and that creating art supports the development of a variety of skills and a sense of self as an artist. Our students will recognize the cultural, societal, and historical significance of art, connect the visual arts to other disciplines, and apply the skills and knowledge learned in visual arts to interpreting the world. We look forward to working with children and observing their ongoing development as artists in our school community.

Q37_4: Parents lead young artist program during lunch
Q44_1: We are an arts-based school with full-time, certified teachers in the following disciplines: art, dance, music and theater.  Every grade partners with an outside organization focused on theater or dance; third, fourth and fifth graders have two artists in residency partnerships throughout the school year.  Our dance, music and theater teacher also collaborate in designing three various productions, one each for second, third and fifth grade, with students from other grades helping with sound management and stage direction.

Q37_4: Parent Led Gallery Tours of Chelsea: after school Fridays once a month - open to all students and parents/caregivers
Q44_1:
The art program at PS 33 Chelsea Prep inspires students to explore the different ways that they can visually express themselves in a supportive classroom studio environment. Art lessons are developmentally appropriate experiences that encourage children to reflect and communicate about themselves and the world around them.  
The philosophy of our visual arts program, emphasizes that all our students are potential artists who view the world from their own unique perspectives.  Their experiences of living in the world are communicated through explorations with different arts materials in drawing, painting, collage, printmaking, and sculpture. Our program inspires students to explore a variety of processes and techniques for self expression and communication. Children are encouraged to work independently as well as in collaborative group settings at all grade levels.   
All art lessons are aligned with the NYC Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts at each benchmark level, the New York State Learning Standards for the Arts and the National Visual Arts Standards. Projects and themes are structured to support the philosophies and perspectives of other disciplines such as math, literacy, science, social studies, language arts and technology.
Q45_1:
PS 33 has students in grades PK-5 and is proud to host a diverse community of learners. We work collaboratively to maintain the remarkable achievement that has become the norm for our students. It is home to a rich, standards based curriculum that fosters analytical thinking, creativity, and independence. We use a wide range of resources to provide an holistic and challenging academic program while fostering a welcoming school community. As evidenced through the data here, the school strives to make many and varied connections for all our students by utilizing the vast array of out of school arts and cultural organizations available to public school students in NYC.
Student artwork, art reproductions, picture books and technology are incorporated to assist in achieving the goals of the art program at our school. The artistic development of each child is a blueprint for how we approach the growth of the individual in the classroom experience.  
The art classroom studio provides children a rare and valuable opportunity to express visually their unique feelings, thoughts, and perspectives. Extended time in a studio environment allows for experiences where students can take the time to experiment and create at a developmentally appropriate pace to their needs.  Children learn best when their learning matters to them – when it’s connected to their lives and experiences – and filled with wonder, joy and fun!

Q44_1: PS 40 is committed to developing a high quality arts program. As a school, the integration of the arts into our classroom curriculum is essential. Our full time art and music teachers provide our students with an outstanding and comprehensive program that ranges from multi-media use to choral and instrumental music. Outside organizations, such as National Dance Institute and Marquis Studios, supplement and enrich our in-house art studies. After-school opportunities in the arts are also available to students. Children celebrate their work through performances and exhibitions.

Located in the heart of historic Greenwich Village, PS41 both reflects the rich cultural diversity of our neighborhood, and dynamically incorporates the resources of our neighborhood into our studies. The arts are integrated into all curriculum areas. Our building is a vibrant testimony to the creative pulse of our community. We ahve partnerships with: National Dance Institute, the Highline, the Whitney Museum and Lincoln Center.

Through immersion and our collaborations with various cultural programs, our students will develop talent and skill in different areas of the arts. The arts are integrated into our interdisciplinary curriculum with a focus on the development of literacy, non-cultural appreciation and integration of the curriculum. The programs of study actively engage children in experiencing the arts, using them and communicating about and through them. We have collaborations with organizations including Chen Dance Center, The Drawing Center, The Guggenheim Museum “Learning through the Arts”, Dancing Classrooms, Audubon Society, Center of Architecture Foundation, Midori and Friends (Jason Poole, Mexico Beyond Mariachi, Chen Tao, Forest Drums), Faces of Wonder, New Victory Theater, YMCA, The New York Historical Society. All of these organizations provide residencies including professional development for participating staff in addition to parental participation. The cultural arts programs are selected because they are aligned to the core curriculum and support the classroom instruction taking place.

"47" American Sign Language and English High School offers courses, clubs and community opportunities in several arts disciplines.  Arts courses include: Visual Arts Courses, Theater Courses and Dance Courses.   Our American Sign Language Courses also integrate the Arts.   In addition to our courses, we have Arts and Illustration Clubs,  Dance and Step Clubs as well as Music, Photography and Theater Clubs.   Our school provides enrichment trips focused on the Arts, these include trips to various New York City Art Venues, Broadway Plays, Musicals and Dance Performances.

P.S. 51 currently offers a well-rounded, standards-driven arts program that combines the elements of visual art, music, movement, dance, and theater to enhance the overall educational experience of our students. Through extensive horizontal and vertical collaboration among arts and classroom teachers, students are provided with multiple opportunities to share their skills and creative talents with the entire school community through arts shows, instrumental and vocal concerts, and dance performances. Our arts teachers have designed a unique program including special clubs and classes like fashion design, Chorus, Orff Ensemble, Recorder Ensembles, guitar and ukulele classes, violin and cello classes, and music theater in addition to the scaffolded curriculum offered in weekly arts classes. We strive to provide a safe and nurturing environment where students are encouraged to transcend emotional boundaries and explore their creative energies.
Q45_1: Our music and art teachers taught weekly dance classes to all of our PreK and Kindergarten classes this school year.

Q44_1: The PS59 community strives continuously to provide a comprehensive arts experience for every student. We continue to focus, as part of an ongoing SLT wellness initiative focused on social emotional learning, increasing student confidence, coordination, skill, and appreciation for the arts by maximizing opportunities for movement and creative expression throughout the day. Each year, teachers and resident artists collaborate and reflect to make purposeful decisions about the arts programs being provided to students. We have been fortunate to expand our offerings to include even more hours devoted to theater and dance while maintaining the breadth and quality of our long term music and studio arts programs. It is quite rewarding to celebrate our eager and talented learners each year through the arts. We are thrilled with our current Arts Partners, including Creative Stages, City Center, Lincoln Center, the NY Philharmonic, and Arts Connection. We will continue to rely on the generous support and commitment of our PTA and the City Council as we face anticipated budgetary challenges.

In grades K-5, the Lower Lab School boasts a full calendar of family-friendly arts events, including those related to academic achievement (Music Concerts, Sotheby"s Art  Show). The art specialists follow the NYS Arts Curriculum that includes hands-on investigation of the visual arts. The music specialist follows an exploration of music that involves learning, listening and performing music using violins, cellos and, recorders.

PS 89 is committed to providing an enriched art education program to all students. Children participate in weekly classes in dance, music and visual arts. The arts programs are integrated in the classroom curriculum. Collaboration occurs regularly among the classroom teachers and arts teachers which enriches the units of study for children. We believe that providing children with a well-rounded education includes regular participation in a variety of arts programs. Whenever possible we augment our programs by bringing in arts organizations that represent the rich variety of disciplines within the arts in New York City.

Students study visual arts in grade 6 & 7 with an array of contexts offered (calligraphy, pastels, stills, puppets, water paint, mosaics, etc.). Connections are made to their social studies curriculum such as study of and replication of folk art, weaving, etc. The ceramics class has students creating a variety of both functional and decorative pieces with an after school component that allows students to use a potter's wheel. Orchestral music is offered in all grades to students who select this option. Drama is also offered to grades 6 & 7. There is a full length musical production at the end of the year. All 8th grade students select their electives allowing them to "major" in the arts of their choice.

Currently P.S. 111 has a full time music teacher and art teacher for grades Pre-K through 5.  This year we have four outside organizations that provide arts programming to our students.  They are Studio in the Schools (Pre-K), Marquis Studios (Grades K-1), Alvin Ailey Dance (Grade 4), Young Storyteller's Theater Program (Grade 5) and Orchestra of St. Lukes (Grades 2-5) which is an after school program that services about 15 students.

As a school, our goal is to have a grade specific arts program provided by outside arts organizations, in addition to our full time music and art teachers.  However, this is all contingent on funding.

All students in our school take three arts periods a week of either visual art, theater or dance.  In addition to their three periods of arts, all of our 8th grade students take one semester of ballroom dancing and all of our 7th grade students take one semester of Art History.
Each Thursday afternoon, we have an extended Electives period where students can chose from a wide variety of arts classes that are created by both teachers and students.  Examples include Sculpting, Fashion Design, Sketching at the Met.
Our school partners with the Classic Stage Company. In addition to providing a theater teacher, the CSC also gives our students  opportunities to see CSC productions and participate in talk backs with the actors and the directors of these plays.
All of our 8th graders participate in a Shakespeare unit, in which they study a play in depth and work with MFA students from the CSC to stage scenes from these plays, directed and acted by our students.
We partner with Jazz at Lincoln Center so that our 8th graders see three jazz performances and participate in curriculum developed by Jazz at Lincoln Center.

P.S. 116 has been committed to aesthetic education, whereby
students learn about the arts by focusing on works of art, including dance, music, theater, and visual arts. The focus is on students'
perceptions of a particular artwork, guided by a line of inquiry. Rather than teaching skills in service of creating a final art product, students explore the artistic/aesthetic process of the artist.

Q37_4: Chaperoning theatre club trip to Junior Theater Festival in Atlanta, GA and other arts field trips
Q44_1: PS 124 views the arts (visual arts, music, theater and dance) as integral components of a well-rounded curriculum for all elementary students. Arts programs at PS 124 also support and enrich academic learning in order for students to develop reading, writing and oral language skills. Appreciation for various art forms is encouraged as students visit different cultural institutions, as well as participate in hands-on activities taught by New York State certified arts teachers and teaching artists from partner organizations. Meaningful arts education at PS 124 is supported by professional development in order for productive teaching and learning to take place in the classroom. The arts teachers use the various art disciplines to help children develop appreciation for the arts as well as provide them with other avenues to express their understanding of themselves and their world. In addition, the teachers will use their discipline as another means to develop literacy skills. The arts teachers will plan and work with classroom teachers, incorporating the arts into the class curriculum. Parents support the arts at PS 124 by attending student performances at our school and chaperoning numerous arts experiences throughout New York City.

Our school provides a very strong enrichment program in arts education. The arts program is a crucial factor in attracting an ever increasing number of applicants to our middle school. At least 80% of our students applying to specialized arts schools are accepted. It is our goal to increase partnership with visiting artists and cultural institutes so that our students can learn from the professionals and gain insight into the art profession as a career choice. This year we were the proud recipient of a grant from the Center of Art Education which provide our elementary school students with much needed professional in-school dance and theatre instructions.
Q45_1: no response

Q44_1: We believe that the arts play a vital role in helping to improve our students' academic performance and achievement by providing a variety of venues for them to develop the necessary language and social skills, self-confidence and poise needed to succeed. Students enjoy coming to school so our attendance rate is among the highest in the city. Our comprehensive program includes our in-house music and art programs and an arts residency program for every child from Pre-K through Grade 5. Many of our arts partnership programs offer scholarships to students who show a particular interest or talent in a discipline and also provide opportunities for them to continue after they leave PS 130. In addition to our day school offerings, we also have many free school-sponsored after school programs such as a competitive fife and drum corps, a school chorus, a ballroom dance club, and a Chinese lion dance club. Parents actively support our many programs by volunteering and raising funds to pay for partnerships with Community Based Organizations, musical instruments, and equipment.
Q45_1: All of the arts programs listed in the survey have been made possible by the generosity of our parents and our Parents Association. We are a Title I school with a majority of children coming from homes that speak a language other than English. Because the parents see the value and the positive impact that the arts have had on their children's academic performance, they have been tremendously supportive in helping us to raise the funds necessary to continue the programs. As a result, our school has consistently ranked as one of the higher performing schools in New York City.

Q44_1:
At Mather, our Arts program in the classroom consists of Decorative Finishing in the Building Arts.  Decorative Arts introduces students to the materials and methods of historic architectural surface finishes, including decorative plaster, painted decorative finishes, and gilding.  Students receive hands-on instruction in the techniques of common historic finishes, as well as in their history, context, preservation, and present-day applications.  Units include Introduction to Paint, Color Theory and Application, Surface Preparation and Drawing/Transfer, Faux Finishes, Troweled Plaster Finishes and Gilding.

Outside of the classroom, our arts program consists of after school clubs including the performing/improv arts club, the musical club "The Matherizers," a singing group, and a visual arts club.

We also have offer summer opportunities for mural painting and craftsmship in carpentry.

At PS 150 we are proud of our long-standing commitment to the arts, and our recent development of theater offerings. The arts play a significant role in daily instruction at PS 150. Students receive stand alone instruction as well as arts instruction integrated into our in-depth science and social studies themes. Each year, all our work comes together in our annual arts festival. The arts festival includes a visual arts exhibit with work from every student in the school and an original theater piece that incorporates dance, music, theater and content study artwork. The theater piece is performed on the main stage of the Tribeca Performing Arts Center for our families as well as students from neighboring schools.

Our Specialty classes are taught by full-time YCS Specialty teachers, certified in their practice. Our specials include visual arts, dance music, band and chorus programs. Students receive one–two periods a week of each Specially class. Our monthly “Specials” news, included in our newsletter, provides you with information regarding what children are learning in each class and how families can support at home. In addition to our Specialty classes, we offer enrichment opportunities which are provided by Community Based Organizations, (CBO’s). These programs provide our students with the unique opportunities to further promote excellence, self-confidence, creativity, and the development of strong-will, expanding on our students' learning in ways that bring new concepts to light or by using old concepts in new ways.  Our goal is to provide all of our students with opportunities to learn more about themselves, their skills, and strengths.

We are proud of the varied arts programs that our students participate in throughout the school year. With the generous assistance of the Parents' Association and the participation of our Arts Committees (comprised of parents and teachers) we hope to be able to continue to offer these wonderful programs in the upcoming school year. PS 158 is committed to providing diverse instruction in the arts.

Wagner Middle School offers visual arts, theater arts, band, and chorus. These programs provide much needed art opportunities for
students to participate in exhibits, performances, and trips to many arts-based institutions. Band members participate in band five times a
week. Additionally, band students participate in concerts as well as borough-wide band shows and performances at Carnegie Hall. This year, the senior band visited the Coast Guard Academy in New London, CT, attended their concert and had lessons or "clinic" with the Coast Guard band members and their conductor. A
number of students, from 6th to 8th grade, have auditioned and been accepted into Manhattan Borough-Wide Band and Inter-City Band as well as the National Children's Chorus. Non-band students
participate in a rotating program of theatre and visual arts. The visual and theatre arts students follow the NYC Blueprint for the Arts and an alignment to the Common Core Standards. Activities in the theatre and visual arts program include but are not limited to art studio,drama club, museum club, dance performances, digital photography, winter and spring concerts, and a school-wide celebration of learning. Some of our students have been accepted into summer art intensives at Frank Sinatra School for the Arts. 
Wagner proudly puts on a musical for our entire school as well as evening performances for the Wagner community. At Wagner, we feel every student should be equally exposed to the arts as they are to other core subjects to create a well-rounded student.

Yorkville East Middle School offers a variety of arts programs both during the school day and after school hours. During the day, students take visual art and participate in a drumming residency program through Marquis Studios. We also offer focused courses during our Cerebral Diversity classes such as observational drawing,comic book making, fashion design, and MakerEd. After school, we work with Manhattan Youth to provide additional classes in dance, chorus, graphic design, theater and anime to ensure our students have access to a well-rounded arts program.

We believe in integrating the arts to extend student learning. We nurture both the hearts and minds of our students through rich arts-based opportunities. From music, including chorus and band, to visual arts, dance, and theater, students develop an understanding of the principles of art and music while deepening their expressive and critical thinking skills and cultivating their imaginations. We have a wonderful core group of art studio and music family volunteers. This partnership is vital to our arts program and allows us to accomplish our goals and display student work throughout our school building. We connect our arts to our local community by participating in exhibitions, visiting museums, observing outside performances and performing in our own concerts to share what our students have learned.

Leadership and Public Service High School offers one of the top Chorus and Visual Arts programs of any non-specialized high school in New York City. Our strongest partnerships are with the Metropolitan Opera Guild, DIFFA, Trinity Church Wall Street and The New Museum. We are also continuing to expand our outside partnerships and affiliations. The Leadership Chorus was chosen to perform at the New York Daily News, the New York State Capitol on two occassions, Hunter College, Gotham Hall, Times Square, and we were selected by NBC/iTheatrics for the NBC SMASH Make-a-Musical program.  Our students have opportunities to work in Arts based internships at The MoMA and the New Museum as well as participate in competitive scholarships with the Broadway League, Stella Adler, and The Roundabout Theater Company, to name a few. Our arts faculty is highly trained from top conservatories and universities in the US. Each member of our faculty has many years teaching and professional performance experience.

Our current arts program provides exposure to and participation in the multiple arts disciplines to strengthen a child’s academic, social, emotional growth and development as an individual. Whenever possible, the arts curriculum is integrated with the academic curriculum.

Q37_4: assisting in architectural design and grant-writing
Q44_1: At the end of the 8th grade year, all students at Salk will have engaged in a rich art experience by making art, reflecting on the process of making art and understanding the cultural and historical significance of art. We aim to fully utilize our rich cultural institutions, parent community, and teaching artists to enhance the arts experience for our students. Both our theatre and visual art teachers (as well as our extracurricular music, dance, and media teachers) aim to expose students to as many various art media as possible and connect their curricula across subjects by planning with core classroom teachers to provide a rich learning environment that allows students to apply concepts across classes while drawing upon real-life experiences.

The goals of the art program is for children to use art using original ideas while developing art skills and techniques.  They will be familiar with a variety of visual art forms and can describe them using the vocabulary of visual arts media .  We expect that they will develop an awareness of the expression and communicative power of visual art and express thoughts through a combined use of the visual and performing arts.  They will showcase their learning by using various medias (drawing, painting, sculpture, collage, etc) to create art work with some of the principals of design.

Q37_4: hotographing and filming events, publicizing arts events in community papers and blogs, updating PTA and school website with images and videos of art work and arts events, FUNDRAISING specifically for arts enrichment,  helping to display students work by framing, mounting, hanging work
Q44_1:
As our student body has increased, so has our commitment to the arts.  This year, for the first time in many, we have a full time certified art teacher,and a certified full time music teacher. New this year was 3 rotations of Middle School arts clubs (based on student choice) which included film appreciation, 3D art, and band. Our long term (14 weeks and more) residency programs included Salvadori for Urban Design (MS) Landmarks, Memorials and Monuments, Music Together for PreK&K, Studio in A School for G4, Musical Theater from Wingspan & Main Street Theater for Grades 4&5, and African Dance from Main Street Theater for G3. Other grades participated in Hip Hop, Yoga/Movement, Ballroom Dance, Greek Architecture and Studio classes.  Additionally, we celebrated the arts with 3 Family Art Sat. and evening Workshops.
Unique to our building is our partnership with Cornell Tech Graduate School that has provided and supported arts learning through a year long residency program in computer science, that included several hack-a-thons for animation and game design and maker space events for a variety of design and arts projects. We continue our collaboration with the Main Street Theater and Dance Alliance, our own Roosevelt Island local arts community center.
We provided art for 10 G levels with 2 residency programs per
grade plus visual arts instruction and music through certified staff this year, hopefully, funding from our school budget and our parents through the PTA will enable us to do so again for 2017/2018 school year.
Q45_1:
We are a PreK to 8 grade school on Roosevelt Island.
We are a diverse community of learners who speak over 17 different languages from over 30 countries who are in general education, special education and gifted and talented classrooms.  We have a very active PTA who is committed to providing funding for arts enrichment for all students across the school.

Q44_1: The Ella Baker School is rich in arts education. The curriculum is project and materials based so that children become comfortable and familiar with various art mediums. All children receive instruction in dance, theater, visual arts, multi-media. Children in K-5 have music instruction and children in 6-8 have the opportunity to continue with music instruction if interested. All classes participate in ongoing visits to a wide variety of arts and cultural institutions available in New York City. Our teachers participate in ongoing professional development opportunities throughout the year to strengthen their understanding of arts education. Arts materials and education in an integral part of interdisciplinary units developed by teachers.

Arts instruction is a rich and vibrant part of students' learning at PS 234. We offer a full array of vocal music classes (K-3rd grade), as well as instrumental music starting in the fourth grade. Our most significant partnerships with arts cultural organizations in New York City are with National Dance Institute, which works with our fifth graders weekly, and Center for Arts Education, which provides music instruction to our K-3rd grade students. Classroom teachers instruct students in visual art, music and theatrical arts experiences throughout our rich social studies curriculum. Our visual arts teacher, music teachers,  and dance teacher collaborate throughout the school year to create amazingly well-crafted arts learning and culminating performances for our students. PS 234 has a long and rich history of valuing the arts in children's learning. This is completely evident as you walk through our school.
We offer performing arts and visual arts to our 6th-8th graders. 9th graders take visual arts, 10th grade photography and then 11th and 12th grade IB film.
All students at East Side Elementary School receive visual arts instruction twice a week. They also have music once a week.

Grades K-3 artists learn art techniques and art history through a workshop model. Grades 4-8 artists are learning how to maneuver through a Choice-based art class. Our students take trips to several museums - MoMA, Whitney, Cloisters, the Rubin and the Met. This is the 4th year that our studio art teachers have created the school yearbook with 8th grade students. 
We have a rich music program with 2 full time music teachers. All students have music each week. K-2 learn general music using Solfege, and Orff instruments.  In grade 3 students learn the recorder. In fourth grade, all students learn an instrument for band. In grades 5-8 students have a choice of band or chorus.  8th graders also have a general music history class in which they also learn to compose using Garage Band and Finale. 
We partner with several organizations for drama. Our K students work with a teaching artist from the Creative Arts Team for interactive story telling. Students in grades 5-8 partner with Lincoln Center Education for theater workshops.  Fourth and fifth graders work with Kids Empowerment Academy on public speaking.

We currently have a full-time music teacher as well as a weekly visiting visual arts educator through the organization Studio in a School. Students learn how to play keyboard on instruments provided through a grant from Music and the Brain. Through the music program, students also learn to sing and play other classroom instruments such as drums and xylophone.

UA Maker offers courses in Theater and Visual Art where students will engage in both making and critical thinking. The first unit of Visual Art, “Art Begins With a Mystery", provides students with experiences uncovering and expressing ideas through visual imagery. In Theater, students begin by learning about storytelling, uncovering the deep connections between design thinking and artistic creativity. Visual Art offers students the opportunity to develop strategies and techniques for making 2D visual art; including proficiency with line and weight, shape and form, value, color, and perspective. In the later half of the class students will practice and refine these skills in independent works, and explore the social and historical context of various artistic expressions. Theater encourages students to extend their expressive and interpersonal skills, building their work in other classes by developing their confidence and comfort presenting to an audience of their peers. Throughout the latter half of the class, students will explore more sophisticated areas of performance, with options ranging from clowning and comedy to the writing, performance, and analysis of Hip Hop poetry. Students will engage with art and art making both in and out of the classroom. They will be expected to produce exhibitions of their own work as well as portfolios of their growth. They will engage artists, art makers, and art spaces in public and community settings in order to explore careers in the arts.
We currently offer music to all of our seniors and many of our underclassmen. We offer courses in chorus and instrumental. We have a culminating performance.

At I.S.289, the arts program is both embedded in the project based curriculum, and as part of a stand alone comprehensive visual arts and music program.  

Within the project based curriculum of each core class, students use the digital and visual arts to engage in the culture and texts of the content, as well as to demonstrate understanding of the content. 

Within the Visual Arts and Music curriculum, the five strands include the various types of art and music making, developing art and music literacy, making connections to the world and to other disciplines through music and the visual arts, exploring careers in music and the arts, and learning about community and cultural resources.

We try to provide each grade with the opportunity to experience live performances in various genres of music. We provide a rich visual arts program using community resources such as museums and a full-time art teacher. The Wingspan Theater company works with every class to experience creating theater through improv, theater games, creating characters and writing plays. Our fourth graders participate in the National Dance Institute program culminating in a dance concert at the end of the school year and our first grade students participated in a New York City Ballet program. We provide the fourth and fifth grade students with musical instrument instruction from our full-time music teacher and  teaching assistant. In third grade, the students learn to play the recorder and perform in a concert at the end of the school year at Carnegie Hall. A variety of performances are scheduled throughout the year for each of the grades and we incorporate the visual arts into our daily curriculum.

The Urban Assembly Academy of Government and Law offers students a range of elective courses and arts related programming throughout their high school career. All students take visual arts in their sophomore and senior years. This course introduces students to a variety of art mediums and allows for the exploration of both two-dimensional and three-dimensional art processes.  This course is also supplemented by an extensive after school program, including an art club.

Essex Street Academy offers 3 electives for students in the Art Department: visual art, theater and music. In the visual arts program students learn the basics in art and theory. Students are asked to create a series of work that reflect growth. In the theater program students learn memorization skills, performance tactics and are asked to perform major scenes from a variety of theatrical genres. The after school music program at ESA is a performance-based curriculum that focuses on building foundational skills and nurturing a life-long relationship to music. The students learn and practice vocal and beat-making skills. Students are then asked to perform and demonstrate growth by participating in talent shows and an end-of-year art expo. These courses are offered to the entire 11th grade class and end in a Performance Based Assessment Task. All three modes of art are offered to students in all four grades.

Presently, 10th graders in our school receive Studio Art 1 and 2 for 1 credit each. The courses are designed to meet the required benchmarks and performance indicators for the NYC Blueprint for the Visual Arts. Additionally, our 9th grade students receive one semester of Graphic Design in the technology lab for 1 credit. Students have the opportunity to complete a portfolio to submit for Advanced Placement Studio Art in 2-D Design, and they can also participate in the following extra-curricular clubs and activities: acrylic painting and drama. We also visit a number of cultural institutions each year, and we assist our students with applying to arts programs at various cultural institutions throughout NYC.

This year we've expanded our Arts teaching staff from one two artists in residence and 1 certified teacher to two artists in residence and 2 certified teachers.  As a result, w were able to expand our offerings.  Freshman and sophomores at SDC have the opportunity to take a design seminar. In this class, students learn the elements of design, utilize design thinking, practice drafting, and utilize spatial reasoning while building scale models. Students visit key architectural spots around the city, and many see design themes integrated into their subject classes. Past projects have included skyscrapers, museums, schools, and bridges. Freshman and sophomore students also have entry level classes in visual arts in mixed media. Juniors and seniors had the option to remain in design classes as well as take advanced elective visual arts classes during the spring semester. This year we offered two periods of dance classes with visiting artist to about 40 students from all grade levels. We also offered two periods of a sculpture elective with one of our Art teachers this year.

At FHS, there is strong collaboration with Urban Arts Partnership. Academic teachers, a DOE certified visual art teacher and Urban Arts teaching artists co-plan curricula that integrate art, poetry, photography, music, and drama- all to deepen students’ understanding and provide multiple forms of expression in the classroom. The goals for the Arts Education Program are as follows: Provide all students with an inquiry-based, student-centered, and constructivist approach to arts learning; Provide all students with arts-integrated lessons and theme-based art studios. Our seniors participate in our annual Choosing to Participate exhibit which combines intense research on a social justice issue and the creation of an art activism piece displayed at the end of the year celebration. Our partnership has provided opportunity and access for all of our students both academically and artistically.

Q42_R1_C1: Learning through an Expanded Arts Program
Q44_1: LoMA is dedicated to nurturing the artist in all students. Students take survey classes in music, dance, drama and visual art before committing to a 3 year major in one of the disciplines. The students receive in-house arts instruction and are also exposed to a wide variety of cultural institutions and community partnerships within the arts. In addition to full time certified arts teachers, LoMA students work with a wide variety of teaching artists in their arts and academic classes. Students at LoMA regularly attend theater, music and dance performances as well as visit museums and cultural institutions. Our students have numerous opportunities to perform, direct and choreograph including events such as our fall drama, spring musical, talent-show and majors' performance. Students at LoMA have a wide range of arts experiences incorporated into their daily academic classes. LoMA students also have a wide range of extracurricular arts opportunities from which to choose.

NYC Lab Middle School for Collaborative Studies works to provide a comprehensive arts experience connected to all subject areas and in arts specific courses of study. In sixth grade students participate in a year-long introduction to visual arts with a focus on drawing, stop-motion animation and visual communication through art. In seventh grade students take drama. Students engage in playwriting, learn acting techniques and have opportunities to perform. The seventh grade course is designed in collaboration with a partnership at The New Victory Theater. In eighth grade students study visual arts through a survey of fine arts. A partnership with The Whitney Museum helps support this work. Students in eighth grade visit the museum multiple times throughout the year. A museum educator also works with students at the school site. The students also showcase art work at a culminating show in the museum. Arts is integral to the student experience at NYC Lab Middle School for Collaborative Studies. We have prioritized arts education - providing nearly double the required amount to our students. We believe that when students are allowed to engage in art making and learning about art they grow as learners and human beings.

The James Baldwin School infuses the arts into classes of many disciplines, like "Baldwin's Art and Soul." Although we have not had a school play this year, in all previous years our theater class has produced a school play, often one that is written by the students. In addition, we offer after school opportunities in the arts ranging from visual arts to spoken word. In addition, many of our students participate in programs in the arts with other organizations across the city (like the Possibilty Project, the MoMa, etc).

Our school arts program this year included a focus on Music, Songwriting, Arts Technology and Film classes. Our goal this year has been to provide students with introductory knowledge and appreciation for the arts and the different aspects of Music and Film. Our long-term objective is that these classes will provide them a foundation upon which to build a career interest in Music or Film.

At PS 340 we encourage and support arts education in numerous ways. We employ a full time music teacher who provides music and keyboard instruction through the Music and the Brain program to students in pre-k to 2nd grade. We have a full time Dance teacher who provides dance instruction in our large dance studio to all of the children in our school. pre-k to 2nd grade. Our kindergarten and 1st/2nd grade students receive visual arts instruction from our in-house, part-time art teacher, and pre-k students receive art instruction from their classroom teachers. We have a partnership with the Joyce Theater that involves a residency and visits to a dance performance. Take Two film company works with our 2nd grader in a 10 week residency program in our school to create documentaries. Learning by Design, an architecture company, provides a 10 week program for our kindergarteners. Additionally, we regularly go on visits to museums (Whitney and the Rubin), and offer art instruction within the regular classroom.

Peck Slip students receive theater and instrumental music instruction with resident artists from cultural organizations, and general music and visual arts instruction from school-based certified arts teachers. The arts are also incorporated into the classroom curriculum, used both as a tool for learning social studies and science content and for demonstrating what they have learned. For example, kindergarten students produce up to four drafts of realistic drawings of moths and butterflies to sharpen their ability to observe these insects and note their distinct features, and third graders build a model of a Lenape village to demonstrate their knowledge of this culture.

PS 347 has been very fortunate to receive two grants this year that have enabled us to support an art and dance program for our students on a weekly basis, and an after school Theater program (in partnership with Town Hall) for students in grades 4-8. Through a generous donation from parents, CMA provided 8 weeks of art to our K-5 students. Our teachers are also very active in exposing our K-5 students to theater on a monthly basis.

Gramercy Arts High School (GAHS) is a dual-mission auditioned program for students who are committed to developing their skills in the visual and performing arts. Gramercy Arts High School provides students with a strong academic background combined with one of the best visual fine arts and theater programs in New York City. In addition to emphasizing excellence in all subject areas, students are encouraged by teachers and school community partners to develop long and short term goals for success.
We have a full-time visual arts teacher, who is implementing a visual arts curriculum with our 10th grade students.
Q45_1: We have a visual arts teacher who is new to teaching this year, so she has been learning how to implement an engaging curriculum.

Q44_1: Emma Lazarus High School is a transfer school that serves over-aged, and under-credited ENL students.  Our student body is comprised of new arrivals to the United States, with limited English.  We offer stand-alone ENL courses through an English immersion model.  Our students have limited time to learn English and pass Regents; however, we ensure that students meet the city and state requirements for the arts and when possible expose them to additional cultural opportunities throughout New York City.  Students have visited museums, attended Broadway shows and visited other cultural institutions.  We have solicited the professional services of arts organizations such as the Lincoln Center’s LEAD program, the New York City Horticultural Society, and TADA!.  We believe that students learn best through experiential, hands-on and project-based instruction.   Moreover, we believe that arts integration is an effective method for students to learn and acquire a new language; therefore, we make the arts a priority at our school.

As a growing school, we maintain a commitment to the arts. Our students are currently exposed to a range of arts experiences, including the launch of our full-time music program. As we grow, we will preserve an arts program that supports both immersion and emerging expertise - breadth and depth. We maintain our commitment to community partners and arts organizations who can help make this work even more robust.

Our school (student population of approximately 400 students) has one full-time visual arts teacher and 1 split program English/theater teachers.  We have a dedicated classroom/studio for visual arts and offer a range of courses within the visual arts field, including but not limited to drawing, digital design, and sculpture.

The High School for Environmental Studies provides students with opportunities to engage in the arts for all four years. As a theme-based school which focuses on developing environmental stewards, we are proud to be able to provide our students with a Common Core-aligned, well-rounded education that places a strong value on an arts education. In addition to offering our students beginning and advanced courses in chorus, orchestra, band and theater, we also offer ceramics, painting and drawing, as well as dance courses through a partnership with Alvin Ailey. HSES is a culturally rich community that enjoys a great deal of student involvement in our arts program. Our teachers are dedicated to providing our students with meaningful experiences and to exposing them to a wide array of art forms, including environmentally-themed arts projects.

The Institute for Collaborative Education (I.C.E.) Arts Education Program is a critical component of our school's curricular vertical planning along the 6th - 12th grade arc. Our students are offered multiple arts opportunities at each grade level including music, theater, dance, visual, graphic, and mixed media arts in their school day program and through after school activity offerings. All students in each grade participate in at least one arts course each semester. Our focus is on the whole student, and we believe that cognitive, social, and emotional development are each positively impacted by continuing exposure to new experiences in which students are enabled to construct their own knowledge and exercise their higher order thinking skills.
