The I.C.E. Arts Program is an excellent arena in which this work is undertaken, and I.C.E. students and families have been historically very invested in this aspect of the curriculum.

The mission of PPAS is to provide professional performing arts instruction to all students in grades 6 – 12 in a variety of disciplines, while also providing them with a rigorous academic curriculum that will lead to exceptional higher education choices that include, but are not limited to, top performing arts colleges and conservatories. The performing arts curriculum offers students in grades six through twelve a unique opportunity to study the arts in a professional environment. Professional artists offer training to meet the performing arts learning needs of students who are passionate about the arts and committed to the study of the arts. High School students major in professional studios in dance, drama, musical theater, and vocal music. Middle School students participate in a variety of performing arts classes to increase their exposure to performance elements. These classes include acting, dance, singing and music appreciation. PPAS has a unique programming structure where the school partners with professional arts organizations that provide top quality instruction in professional settings. Student take classes in site-specific high caliber studios, which include off-Broadway theaters, concert halls, and ballet and tap dance studios. Students present concerts, plays, and other productions throughout the school year, both in-house and in premier performance spaces across New York City.

All students take a full year (2 credits) of visual arts in 10th grade, where they explore different mediums, including collage, drawing, painting and murals. They study contemporary artists and explore the issues of identity and self. Students have the option to apply for Honors Art in 11th and 12th grade, where they develop a portfolio for post-secondary arts programs. With a partnership with Manhattan Class Company Theater, students explore drama integrated into all English classes, from grades 9-12, with reinterpretations of Shakespeare, spoken word poetry, dramatic interpretation of American novels, and rhetoric. There is also an after school drama program, which puts on our annual school play. We have a partnership with American Composers Orchestra, who works with 9th grade English classes to examine tone and music. There is an after school rock music club and an after school dance club.

Our Goals for the Arts Program remain the same as past years: It is our goal that all Lab students will be exposed to a variety of art experiences that will allow them to interact with art in a meaningful way and to cultivate a life-long relationship and appreciation for art. To nurture independent, creative thinking, the development of content knowledge, and a deeper appreciation of the visual arts, the art department uses a variety of instructional methods including the development of a studio-like environment, careful observation and writing about specific works of art, making inferences and interpretations, material explorations, class discussions, creative problem solving, the keeping of journals and sketchbooks, and the exposure of students to a wide variety of visual arts resources available in New York City. With regards to music, the curriculum is designed so that students can derive a meaningful learning experience regardless of prior knowledge and experience in music.

School of the Future has expanded over the last few years to include a full time Visual Arts teacher, two F-status Drama teachers, a part time music and dance/yoga teacher. Students in both the middle and high school receive arts instruction one to two times per week throughout the school year. Our 9th through 12th  graders choose their Electives while the middle schoolers have assigned arts classes.

The Museum School offers a 4-year studio art sequence aligned with the New York State Blueprint for the Arts standards. All art courses are interdisciplinary and taught by a fully licensed and certified art teacher. Unique to our school are the "museum module" courses, which allow students to take specialized museum-based courses every week that correlate with in-school Regents-based courses. Our goal is to provide students with as rich an arts education as possible while reinforcing the connections between the arts and the core disciplines. Students frequently visit the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Japan Society, the Rubin Museum, the Museum of Natural History, the Paley Center for Media, and more! The arts are a highly valued part of the Museum School experience.

A college preparatory, liberal arts program, Eleanor Roosevelt High School provides diverse opportunities for students of all levels, interests, and prior experiences in the arts. In the freshman and sophomore years, students elect from introductory courses in media and technology, music, and visual arts. In the junior and senior years, students have the option to study artistic disciplines in depth in small seminars and advanced placement courses. 2016-2017 offerings included Animation, AP Art History, AP Music Theory, Art and the Environment, Ceramics, Concert/Symphonic Band, Digital Photography, Film Lab, Guitar, and Visual Art. Extra-curricular opportunities included Canstruction, Chamber Music Society, Choir, Drama Club, Film Club, Jazz Ensemble, Jazz Club.

Millennium High School aims to provide every single student with the skills needed to become visually literate members of society. By providing a rigorous 9th and 10th grade curriculum for every single student we feel confident that we are laying the ground work for continued art research and and learning. Our upper house electives allow students to continue to investigate specific areas of art. Electives offered during the 2016-2017 school year included full-year courses in AP Studio Art, Mixed Media, Graphic Design, and Photography.

Visual art and music programs are offered to all students in compliance with NYS graduation requirements. The visual art program includes studio art and art history, with an introduction to artists and artwork from a global perspective. Students experience creativity as a means of expression through an understanding of the Elements and Principles of Art with culminating exhibitions. The music program offers students an education in basic music theory. The course covers music notation of rhythm, melody and harmony. Students apply what they have learned to the piano keyboard and have a chance to perform as a group in percussion ensembles. In addition, HPHS offers classes in theater, dance and medical illustration. Our staff is committed to offering students a variety of experiences in the arts, and off-site visits to museums, events and shows are ongoing throughout the year. Student and staff theater productions and events are developed and produced in-house during the school year. Also available to students are courses in the arts at the college level for college credit through the College Now and College Board programs.

Manhattan Academy for Arts and Language opened in 2010 welcoming all categories of English Language Learners. At Manhattan Academy for Arts and Language we believe that students excel when given a strong academic education and meaningful support to develop the student entirely which includes art's education. Every student at Manhattan Academy for Arts and Language has an opportunity to take either a music class or an art class during their time in High School. Students that excel in music  are able to continue developing their music skills throughout their HS education.

Q42_R1_C1: Learning through an Expanded Arts Program
Q44_1:
Our Studio Arts teacher works with our students on a variety of highly engaging projects. He has been able to create student-centered projects that allow the students to express personal thoughts and feelings about important social topics, as well as express their own individuality and creative visions. In addition, in the past two years we created several new art history classes, centering around the history of street art, the history of music, and the use of imagery in politics and media. 

To supplement our Studio Arts program, we engaged with LEAP, an outside arts organization, to bring in a professional artist two days a week into our school. As such, all art students participated in a series of painting and printmaking projects that introduced to them the broader professional art world. 

Additionally, our subject teams are committed to exposing students to art in a variety of avenues, and we bring our students to many plays, movies, and museums throughout the year taking advantage of our location in midtown Manhattan. Many of our students take more than the minimum two credits in the arts and our goal is continuous exposure to arts as a vital part of a well rounded education.

As a school exclusively for newcomer English language learners, our goal is to provide all students with an equal opportunity to access the
arts. Therefore, all of our students take drama in grades 9-10, and visual art in grades 9-11. Each year, students participate in the creation, display, and critique of their art work. All students are required to include an art project that includes a written component in English in their portfolios each year and for graduation.
Q45_1: While our high school is one of NYC’s many public high schools that are operated under the NYC DOE, we remain a unique and specialized school who caters to teaching a student body made entirely of English language learners. Our students come from over 40 different countries, speak over 20 different home languages, and practice a variety of religious faiths. 88% of our students are eligible for free school meals, 60% are overage for their grade level, and 35% are Students with Interrupted Formal Education (SIFE), who by definition have had gaps of two or more years in formal schooling. In addition to coming to us from all corners of the world, our students commute from all five boroughs to our school.

Q44_1: We have a band and music classes.
Q45_1: We are servicing Black and Latino students from all over the city. Approximately 75 percent qualify for free or reduced meal.

Q44_1: Ballet Tech's students are enrolled in a full-time pre-professional classical ballet school. Its primary goal is to develop new generations of professional dancers. Students' daily dance classes are in the tradition of classical ballet. In addition, students take pointe, modern, character, gymnastics, and repertory. Through their studies, students develop a strong understanding of the principles of classical ballet and dance, as well as developing a personal and sophisticated relationship to their artistry (or art). They leave the school armed with the necessary skills to pursue careers in the dance field, or to further their dance studies.

Q42_R1_C1: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
Q44_1: The arts program at Vanguard High School is a comprehensive approach to visual arts. Vanguard currently has one art instructor, who teaches several sections of painting, sculpture, furniture design and digital photography. The teacher also offers a class called "Philosophy in Art" that provides strong support to the Social Studies department at our school. Additionally, the art teacher works with advanced art students in terms of preparing their portfolios for admissions into art colleges.

The Manhattan International High School is committed to providing a variety of opportunities in the arts to enrich each and every student's educational experience. We have, and will continue to integrate the arts into our curriculum with the strong belief that the arts enhance language development which is critical for our students. Students also have the opportunity to expand their involvement in the arts through elective classes and multiple after-school programs.  New learners of English develop linguistic, cognitive and cultural skills for informed participation in NYC diverse and creative society.

Schooling in the arts is an important part of a Stuyvesant student's well rounded education. Our music curriculum emphasizes performances with nearly 30% of our students participating in music ensembles. There are 3 concert bands, a beginning band, a jazz band, 3-string orchestras and 2 choruses. Those students who do not participate in a performance ensemble are required to take Music Appreciation. 

In addition to the 3 public concerts the music department presents annually, there are 3 theatre productions (including a fall "musical" and spring play) and the annual "Sing" production.  For the past several years members of our orchestra, through a highly competitive selection process, have performed for the Lincoln Center Chamber Music Society Young Ensembles program.  Other students have won positions in the Inter-Borough Orchestra (ISO), All City bands & orchestra, and the All State bands, orchestras, & chorus.  The choruses recently performed for the Invitational High School Choral Festival at Hunter College, sponsored by the National Chorale of New York City, and the Distinguished Concerts International New York at Carnegie Hall and Lincoln Center.

Our fine arts program consists of art appreciation, water color, acrylic painting, Advanced Placement in Art History, and Studio Mixed Art. Our technology education department offers courses in computer graphics, photography, video production, web design, drafting, advanced auto CAD, ceramics, interior design, & architecture.
Q46_2: Assistant Principal Supervision of Music, Art & Technology

Q44_1: UA Gateway is dedicated to providing a focused and relevant arts program tailored to our students’ individual curiosity. Students are surveyed at the beginning of each year to determine interests, informing our programming and partnership decision making. In addition to required art courses, UAG students are exposed to art through our digital arts track and enrichment programs. As a school for technology with a focus on digital design and animation, we are particularly committed to the use of technology in the arts as well as the development of art within technology fields. This year we will continue the collaboration between our technology department and the art department to provide a grounding in digital design and art/illustration to support the student's choice of Technology Pathway at the end of 9th grade (Digital Design and Animation, IT & Systems or Software Engineering). We also have weekly drawing, animation and photography clubs.

Talent Unlimited High School's arts program seeks to educate, empower, and prepare students for work in the professional world of the arts and beyond. As a Career and Technical Education (CTE) School, students are provided with a sequential and scaffolded series of knowledge, skills, and internship experiences. These work-based learning tools are designed to train students in the discipline of the artist while equipping them with a vast array of analytical and creative skills which cross over into the professional world of work. Talent Unlimited High School believes the goal of training students in the arts transcends the art form itself: we endeavor to prepare our students for the rigors of any professional work environment through disciplined arts training coupled with an uncompromising academic education. Our students  work closely with various arts organizations and industry professionals including the American Folk Art Museum, Ballet Hispanico, Circle in the Square, Classic Stage Company, Exploring the Arts, Martha Graham Dance Center, Metropolitan Opera, NYPOPS, Park Avenue Armory, Pentacle, Paul Taylor American Modern Dance Company, Theater Development Fund, and Western Wind Vocal Ensemble.

The PS 527 visual arts program focuses on experimenting and creating artwork in a wide range of media including painting, drawing, sculpture and printmaking, which aligns to the NYC Blueprint for the Arts. Students are exposed to a variety of materials, techniques, artists and cultures. We use sketchbooks for planning, work with peers to give and receive feedback, and share work during frequent class gallery walks. While we value the experience of creating artwork the most, we also celebrate the learning and final product during our elaborate Spring Art Show. 

The music program at PS 527 provides engaging experiences that are appropriately aligned to NYC Blueprints for the Arts to teach the fundamentals of music. In weekly music classes, children are creating, singing, and performing on instruments. Classes also function as choral ensembles that rehearse for and perform multiple concerts annually. Many third-fifth grade students elect to be in the band program, which consists of keyboards, guitars, woodwind, brass and percussion and performs a repertoire that spans from Latin jazz to contemporary pop. Students in grades 2-5 receive music technology training in which they learn to compose and record music using digital audio workstations and notation software. 

In addition to music and visual arts, all students perform in end-of-year theatrical performances, and Grades 1 and 4 learn Dance from NYC Ballet and 92Y.  Many arts-based field trips occur throughout the school year for all grades.

As a Title 1 business focus school, we strive to ensure that our students receive quality arts instruction and authentic arts experiences that can fully develop the whole student and prepare him/her for success in college and beyond. We see these arts-based skills as transferable and necessary for our students to compete in today's world. We believe that the arts are an excellent platform for our students to explore and gain an understanding of the world around them and a means for them to become active participants in it.They explore personal, global, political, and social perspectives. Students have used the arts as a lens to examine gender issues, social justice, violence against women, climate change, GMO’s, water and food security, identity and personal expression. Students train as lighting designers, sound designers, and stage managers for school productions and as a paid internship for our theater rentals. We've expanded arts residencies in English, History and Spanish classes. Our dance program continues to thrive.

Repertory's immersive theatre curriculum is built to cultivate the complete theatre artist and ends with students taking the New York City Comprehensive Examination in Theatre and graduating with an Arts Endorsed Diploma. Located in the heart of Times Square, we offer a small, nurturing environment where students become college-ready lifelong learners. Coupled with our comprehensive theatre arts curriculum is a full, rigorous academic course load. Completion of our academic program prepares students for graduation with an Advanced Regents diploma. Our students do not declare majors in any one arts field but are encouraged to explore each aspect in the arts from performance, design, technical theatre, vocal, visual, instrumental and dance. Repertory offers all of our students classes in music, dance, and drama as part of a theatre arts sequence. We believe that each artistic discipline and academic subject informs the others. By exposing our students to these diverse experiences, we are able to help our students emerge ready for college, a career in the arts or any other path they may choose to pursue. All of our students perform multiple times throughout the year in at least one of our many school productions. These include one main stage play, one main stage musical, Winter & Spring Arts Festivals, Assembly Performances, Student Produced Talent Shows, New Play Festival, Freshmen Class Productions, Monologue Competitions and Senior Distinction Projects.
Q46_2: Dean of Students / Arts Education Liaison

Q44_1: U.S.A. continues to be committed to providing a rich experience for all students in the arts. With a full-time music teacher, and the investment of an electric piano keyboard lab, 10th-grade students were immersed in a comprehensive arts curriculum based on units and lessons designed around NYC Blueprint for the Arts/Music and Common Core Standards. Music Making, Music Literacy, Music History, Cultural Connections and Life-Long Careers in the Arts were the major themes of study this year. Students had the opportunity and responsibility to become educated readers, writers, performers and appropriate audience members, able to give and receive constructive feedback to each other. The highlights/performances held this year included: A Winter Musical Theater Production of CINDERELLA, The Musical, followed by a  Multi-Cultural Holiday Assembly (December); A Respect for All Arts Assembly (February); Culminating Piano Recital (June). All Performing Arts Disciplines were supported and encouraged by U.S.A's Arts Partners and Performing Arts Club. In addition, students attended:  GVO Orchestra monthly concerts held on Sunday afternoons;  Two Vineyard Theatre Plays (Fall and Spring Terms); Battery Dance 41st Spring Opening at Pace University, as well as had the opportunity to participate in a 25 Hour Dance and Choreography program known as DANCING TO CONNECT for two weeks in May.  The arts nourish and enrich the lives of students at Union Square Academy For Health Sciences.
Q45_1: Union Square Academy For Health Sciences High School is a CTE high school in which students study either Pharmacy or Dental courses for all four years of their high school career.  Their course-load is heavy and their assessments are difficult. While the arts are not the the main feature at our school, we are fortunate to have a student body, teaching staff and administrators who are completely supportive of the arts!

Q44_1: We are a small school with a mission of every student learning a musical instrument.  To that end, we organize for each student to take a music sequence, selecting Guitar, Piano or Band in their first two years, with frequent opportunities for concerts and performances.  Students may elect to additionally study Glee Club, Beats, Studio Arts, Filmmaking, Theater Dance and Dance Choreography, as well as other embedded arts options during our week-long Intensive.  The arts are a rich and vital part of Harvest's liberal arts education program, creating compelling experiences for inquiry into topics of "moral or aesthetic significance."

New Design is a design education focused high school which includes design courses offered in 10th - 12th grades. Courses offered include 10th Grade Foundations to Design, Fashion Design and Advance Fashion Design, Graphic Design and Entrepreneurial Design. Students can also enroll in Art Portfolio classes to assist them in applying to Art and Design colleges and programs.

Our visual arts program offers students comprehensive art experiences with detailed explorations in the classics such as painting, drawing, printmaking, sculpture, graphic design, and crafts. In addition to gaining confidence and proficiency working with a variety of mediums, students will learn about the history, analysis, and interpretation of art. Our goal is to have students learn from hands on projects, as well as taking trips to various cultural institutions around the New York City area.

AFSE offers an extensive Music program where students learn and practice using a variety of musical instruments including guitar, piano, and drums. Music classes at AFSE offer fundamental music theory, learning and playing instruments, and composing music. Students participate in extracurricular sessions practicing various instruments for Talent Shows and recitals. 

AFSE also offers a Tech and Design computer technology course where students design and print using the 3D printer. Students have an opportunity to focus on visual arts using technology.

Our goal is to provide our students with a range of arts courses. Our students are English language learners, thus the arts provide a medium of expression and language acquisition. The methods and strategies used to teach the arts support student learning.

This school year, we have two full-time arts teachers on staff providing direct instruction to 9th grade students during the regular school day, and to all grades through after-school programming.  

Both the visual arts and music teacher are teaching one semester long fundamentals courses to the 9th grade body.  Due to space constraints, the teachers must share the same room, which simultaneously creates restrictions on materials but also creates a central arts space.  

In music, students learn to play guitar, drums, & keyboard while writing their own music as well as researching music genres. In art, students are learning the fundamentals of drawing, color theory, watercolor paint, and oil pastels while learning about some arts movements and artists.

After school, the music club meets once a week, and students forms small groups or work on individual skills.  With our school being a PROSE school, the visual arts teacher was able to shift her schedule to include an after school art program as part of her regular day three times a week, where students have worked on individual skill, and creating artwork for a summer exhibit.  Once a week, a documentary film maker works with a group of students after school through the CASA grant received in cooperation with South Street Seaport Museum, ending in a screening in June.
Q45_1: New York Harbor School is a public high school for the Maritime and Environmental trades on Governors Island.  Our students travel from all over the five boroughs to the ferry, which is the only way on and off the island.  Our students hail from a variety of socioeconomic situations, and represent a wide range of ethnicites.  We are bound to a strict ferry schedule, which sometimes falls prey to weather conditions and other harbor disruptions, such as when the President comes into New York City.

Q44_1:
Urban Academy's art's program spans the visual arts (painting, drawing, sculpture, digital and black and white photography, and film) to creative writing (plays and playwriting, poetry, and fiction) to performance (acting, spoken word, singing and dancing).  Most of our arts classes are taught by full time staff, some by professional artists, and a few by students.

We take the arts very seriously, and two of our graduation requirements are arts based -- Creative Arts (in which students must develop a portfolio of work over time which is presented to the school), and Art Criticism, in which students must choose a work of art to research (including interviewing professionals in the field) and present to a classroom of students.

Q30_6: External organizations offering arts professional development
Q44_1: Satellite Academy has initiated an ambitious arts program for the 2016-2017 academic year. Utilizing a part time F-Status art teacher, who was awarded to us through the F-Status Arts Teacher Pilot, students are participating in classes focusing on yoga, drawing, knitting, song-writing, singing and band.
Q45_1: Satellite Academy High School serves New York City's most at-risk population. Music and art are vehicles that motivate and engage our students in all subject area classes. They also help to build a strong community and positive school culture. Satellite Academy struggles to maintain our arts program every year due to budget limitations.

Q44_1: RRGHST offers Studio Art 1, an introductory course to the Visual Arts focusing on various mediums in the art world to develop imagination, self- expression, and using art as a form of communication. Aligned with the Common Core Standards and the NYC Blue Print for the Arts, this course focuses on team building skills, critical thinking, complex problem solving, writing, self-confidence, literacy, decision-making, school achievement. This course supports intellectual and educational development along with personal and social development. Students will have the opportunity to participate in school-wide art exhibitions. Art History is also incorporated in our curriculum as an elective.

We currently offer visual arts classes.  Students are also encouraged to attend arts programming after school hosted by our partner community based organization, Hetrick Martin Institute.  In addition, we partner with TDF and are often provided opportunities to attend the Public Theater.

We provide a four year program in art that will explore both fine art techniques along with art history and the application of these skills in various art related industries. Our students all learn photography, darkroom techniques, digital photography and study the business of the arts. Students create portfolios over the four year experience including artists' statements and related essays. We aim to provide as varied a program as possible in terms of the many subjects in the arts including design, illustration, gallery and curatorial techniques. Our close connection with the business, industry and post-secondary education communities ensures that the standards, knowledge and expectations are continually updated and reassessed. This connection also allows for students to have access to unique internship opportunities, special enrichment and on-the-job training opportunities

The High School of Art and Design has been a commercial art high school since 1936.All the arts based curricula are developed with our industry partners and Post-Secondary educational partners. We prepare students for college and careers in the arts. Our students receive two periods of art instruction daily for all 4 years they attend our school. Most programs are NYS approved CTE programs. Included are architectural design, cartooning, animation, graphic design, illustration, digital photography, film and video, and fashion design. Students learn the Adobe and AutoCAD software programs and become certified in both programs. Our facilities mirror the state of the art equipment used in industry and students participate in internships available through industry partners and various arts organizations. They compete in art competitions and display their artwork both in school and in outside venues. Graduating students are accepted into major colleges and universities throughout the country. All our majors have their own gallery Shows in the Kenny Gallery throughout the year. We also invite industry professionals to address our students and share their expertise with our students during career day and in their studios. Our culminating Spring Arts Festival thoroughly highlights student achievement in the arts and is well-attended by the public and students' families. In addition, our fashion students present a fashion show and the film students showcase their work in their Film Festival.
Q45_1: Students who wish to attend the High School of Art and Design participate in the audition process where they share their portfolios with us and take the audition assessment. Students meet and discuss their portfolios with an art educator during their audition. Acceptance is based on students' talent and commitment to the arts. Our acceptance criteria are posted on our web site for parents and students to review. We do not discriminate based on race or ethnicity. We pride ourselves on sustaining a warm and nurturing environment for young emerging artists where they can explore various art-forms whilst developing their own voice through their art.

Q44_1: Over their three years in middle school at LMC our goal is to provide students with a basic orientation of multiple art forms and establish deeper facility and competence in a single art form of their choosing. As 6th graders our students participate in an arts wheel through which they take 8 weeks of instruction in each of the following art forms: dance, music, digital arts, and visual arts. At the conclusion of their 6th grade year, students participate in a series of auditions and select one of these art forms in which they will specialize over the next two years. Through their three years of middle school our students have multiple opportunities to showcase their art work. 6th graders demonstrate their work four times through the year during morning art exhibitions that are open to families. Our 7th and 8th graders share their work twice a year in evening art showcase and performance exhibitions. In all three years of our arts program students perform multiple times for peers, the school community and the public. Performance is a skill and experience that we believe to be a key component of arts instruction in our school.

City Knoll Middle School's instructional approach embeds the arts throughout all content areas, as part of our vision. The school offers a visual arts and an instrumental music program this year to the sixth, seventh and eighth grade with two full time arts teacher. Four units of study have been created in collaboration with content area teachers resulting in interdisciplinary work. Experts and field work support student learning. Our partnerships with the Museum of Modern Art, Morgan Book Arts Project, and Inside Broadway have enhanced our arts program.

Our objective is to foster an environment where maximum artistic creativity can take place through school instruction by certified arts teachers. Whenever possible, the arts are utilized to reinforce the academic curriculum. Cultural institutions are utilized to enrich and expand musical and visual literacy. Students experience the arts using a variety of materials and techniques. Family participation during trips, attendance at school performances and exhibitions is an essential part of our school culture. Active participation of the Parent Association and Learning Leaders help us to fund raise for the arts, write grants and display art. Parents often share their talents in performances for students. Parent involvement is integral to our success. "Family Art Night" is a culminating event. Parents, students and staff design activities and place art displays representing every child in the PS 9 community for all to celebrate.

Q42_R1_C1: Learning through an Expanded Arts Program
Q44_1: During the day, instruction in arts will be provided by classroom teachers so that students in grades K - 5 will have studied a minimum of 4 artists and integrate social studies content in curriculum taught by certified arts teacher in collaboration with classroom teachers. Students in grades 6 - 8 will receive art instruction from a certified art teacher during the school day twice a week. Within their social studies curriculum, students in grades 6 - 8 will work with the LEAP arts organization to study Social Injustice and create art as related to the matter.A culminating activity will be to create a design based on the topic on a cafeteria table and have it showcased in the park with media coverage. Students in grades 2 - 5 will have a school residency with the Philharmonic Music Orchestra. Third grade had a residency through Artworks.

Our visual arts program has always been focused on strengthening K-5 curriculum units. We engage in ongoing collaboration to strengthen the Blueprints Strands in culturally connection to our students lives. We also seek to broaden our students creative problem solving minds through integrated concepts and high interest lessons aligned t strengthening reading informational text, writing with a point of view, and deepening their thinking by justifying their thoughts and ideas about their artistic creations. Our professional experiences by using visual art as the seed for developing ideas, and expanding reading, writing,listening and speaking about visual art in a more profound way. This is also evident written artists' statements and connections students make between classroom and art learning experiences. Our students also develop leadership skills as active participants performances that engage the entire school community.

Public School 76, Asa Philip Randolph School for the Humanities, is located in the historic South Central Harlem section of Manhattan, New York. Our Pre-K-8 school serves a population of approximately 531 students from culturally diverse backgrounds. The community is home to many families from different countries like Dominican Republic, the Caribbean Islands, Ghana and other countries in Africa. The school plays a vital role for many students and the families within the community. The arts are essential in enriching the cultural lives of our students. The goal of our arts program is to extend students' learning beyond the classroom through the use of all available resources within and outside the community to expose and engage our students in all forms of arts education thus enriching their lives academically and culturally.

The arts program at Dual Language Middle School focuses upon developing students’ literacy in the visual and performing arts. Within the three-year sequence of studio arts classes students participate in the process of art-making through the exploration of artistic history and the various media, subject matter, and symbolism therein. Students respond critically to a variety of works in the arts and make connections between the art and other subjects as a result of their studies. Students develop understanding of and appreciation for the reasons people and cultures construct works of art, both visual and performance, and how the arts shape the diverse cultures of past and present society. During the three-year dance sequence, students explore not only the steps, but also the history and symbolism within dances from a variety of cultures and time periods including Bharatanatyam, traditional African dance, Salsa, Hip-Hop, Jazz, and ballroom dance styles to name a few.

PS 84, Lillian Weber School for the Arts, prides itself on providing a high quality arts education for all students. Students leave our school with the ability to read music, count rhythms and play at least one instrument. Our students perform and produce artistic and interpretive programs with the finest artists. They film and edit there own multi media productions with animation, photography and live action. Our photography program takes our students outdoors to capture the world using a new and different lens and perspective. With the implementation of the NYC Blueprints for the Arts our student are exposed to a variety of art genres and create their own magic. In addition, our school families understand the value of a rich arts education that is integrated into contact learning, transferable to all disciplines and open ended enough to allow children to collaborate, create and problem solve through performance. The arts allow children to opportunity to excel and experience success using skills that might otherwise go untapped.

Q37_4: Grant team, art show committee, drama production volunteers, musical performance volunteers, dance performance volunteers

Q44_1: Our school views student engagement as the key to raising achievement. All students are challenged to stretch above their current comfort and ability levels.

Sojourner Truth School students receive weekly instruction in the visual arts in grades K-8 as a part of their instructional program. Students also participate in Alvin Ailey Dance residencies to study different dance genres with resident dance artists. Students in grades 3-8 participate in the Young People's Chorus and have the opportunity to sing in citywide honors choir performances.Students in grade PreK -1 also participate in our Sing & Learn program which integrate music instruction with our social students curriculum.

PS 163 has an arts program that includes weekly classes throughout the year for grades pre-Kindergarten, Kindergarten, 1st, and 2nd and for half the year for grades 3rd, 4th, and 5th with full-time dedicated and certified art and music teachers. In addition, there is a choral group – The Voices of 163 – of mixed grades (2nd – 5th) that presents two concerts during the year for the school and an evening performance for the parents. Also, there are lessons on the recorder for all third grade students with a performance. There is, as well, a percussion group which practices and performs during school performances. This year, all students in grades 3rd and 4th partnered with Lincoln Center Film Society Kids. There is a full year of dance for the 4th and 5th grades through the National Dance Institute. The 3rd grade does dance with several New York cultural organizations offering Chinese and African dance for ten weeks followed by a performance for the school. Kindergarten students prepare and perform in their classroom for individual programs for other students and parents.

Q37_4: Setting up, and filming/video taping & photographing performances, volunteering for weekend theatre productions, helping with props and costumes, volunteering with school and outside school arts fairs.
Q44_1: P.S.166, The Richard Rodgers School of the Arts & Technology, provides students with a robust arts program that enriches their depth of knowledge and appreciation for the arts. Our school is dedicated to developing the whole child through a rigorous and enriching program that incorporates music, dance, theater and the visual arts. In music students explore, create, and experience the power of music by investigating historical, social and cultural themes. Our dance program teaches students to build technical and expressive skills while developing experiences in creating and performing dance, rooted in the understanding of historical dance styles across cultures. Students participate in annual dance and musical performances with opportunities to express themselves in set design, choreography and lyrical writing presented to our community and their families. Students explore a wide-variety of artists and art movements through hands-on creations of projects throughout the year culminating in a school-wide art show. They are provided with multiple opportunities with art making, literacy in the visual arts, and making connections to community and culture. Students discover that ideas can be interpreted in a myriad of ways and we celebrate imagination and growth through the appreciation of the arts. Our comprehensive arts program is engaging as it incorporates the Common Core Learning Standards and the Blueprint for the Arts, providing students with opportunities to engage in learning outside the walls of the classroom.

Q45_1: Our school is committed to providing our students with a rich and diverse arts experience. This experience includes exposure to all arts disciplines, integration of art into the instructional program and exposure to all of our city's art rich cultural institutions and resources. Our students learn to appreciate art in their environment and they understand how art contributes to their lives. Our teachers are also committed to art learning through ongoing professional development offered throughout the year. They integrate visual arts into all subject areas and help students explore their creative talents in a variety of disciplines including visual arts, drama, music, dance and technology. We have great arts partnerships that help us to provide students with rich experience in all of the above. We provide music exposure and learning to all of our early childhood students and we offer instrumental music instruction in woodwinds, percussion and violin to students in third through eighth grade. Our goal moving forward is to grow our art program so that there is cumulative learning in visual arts and music in pre-kindergarten through eighth grade and to integrate theater arts into the middle school curriculum so that there is alignment to content area learning. We also seek additional funds for instruction in  visual arts on every grade.  "Excellence, Engagement and Enrichment" is our mission statement and we are committed to offering our students a well rounded arts experience utilizing our school and city resources.

Q44_1: P.S 185 Early Childhood Discovery and Design Magnet School (ECDD) is committed to providing a high quality arts education to every student. We provide our students with vocal music, piano keyboard, Orff, dance, and visual arts instruction as part of the regular curriculum. In addition, we partner with community arts organizations to expose children to a wide range of performance and visual arts. At ECDD, a strong foundation in arts literacy prepares our students for a lifetime of arts appreciation as well as providing them with rich contexts for problem solving, creativity, collaboration and communication of thoughts and ideas.

The PS 191 Community believes that the arts enhances the lives of our students. We work hard to prioritize music, dance, visual arts, film and performing arts at our school, both during the school day and after school. Our students in the lower school have dance and music every week, and our upper school students participate in a comprehensive performing arts program. Through those classes our students are exposed to the arts during the school day, but we find that they want and need more, so we have also expanded our arts programs after school. We offer choir, dance, theater, visual arts and film through our after school program, and our students are so engaged in this work. We continue to look for opportunities to expand our arts program so that we can immerse our students in the arts and tap into their many talents.  Every year, more and more of our students are applying and being accepted into high schools that have a focus in the arts such as LaGuardia, Talent Unlimited, PPAS, and Grammercy Arts.
Q45_1: Our dance and performing arts teachers are continuously making connections with outside organizations to bring arts programming to our students.  Additionally, the arts are offered to our students in grades 2-8 through an after school program.

Q44_1:
The MS 421 arts program has supported a three year sequential music and dance program to develop a full scale marching band. In the school year of 2016-2017 students in 6th grade began the sequential music program, that included general music, instrumental music, dance, brass, and rhythm. All curricula follows the principles articulated in the NYC Blueprint for the Arts and instills the 8 habits of studio thinking in our children's' lives. Moreover, integrating the arts with our schools magnet theme, "Youth Voice through Youth Media," will engage our students in more authentic 21st century learning experiences. By 8th grade students have been exposed to various art forms and built a repertoire of skills that encapsulates these experiences at MS 421. Each year the marching band participates in several performances on site and off site, such as parades, district performances, and competitions in the city.

Our sequential visual arts program has also begun this year.  Students study and apply various mediums, throughout the year and develop a strong foundation in drawing, color, value, and composition starting in 6th grade.  All curricula follows the principles articulated in the NYC Blueprint for the Arts and instills the 8 habits of studio thinking in our children's' lives.

Our school hosts at least two showcases each year to highlight the work we are doing within the visual arts and music classes.

Our students are exposed to a variety of arts education programs over the course of their elementary education, through partnerships with Lincoln Center Institute, Wingspan Theatre,NY Historical Society, the New York Philharmonic and National Dance Institute. The students also have weekly classes with highly-qualified, school-based studio art and music teachers. We are happy to take advantage of the many opportunities available to us to visit museum exhibits and attend live performances.

During the 2016-17 school year our school started a partnership with Inside Broadway where all classes will be participating in our first musical theater production. This culminating performance which is held in May alongside our yearly arts exhibition where students showcase their best works this school year. We continue to participate in the District 3 Arts Festival where students will be performing and showing art work. This year one of our students Josef Thompson’s artwork was selected to be part of the Manhattan Borough Arts Festival where his painting entitled Nature will be exhibited at the MOMA along with other students in the city. We also have an after school rich in arts related activities such as our first Art Club that includes 4th and 5th grade students who meet once a week after school to work on special projects relating to school events, mural painting, and student choice activities. We also provided our students with a dance program through a residency with Pure Elements that works with our girls to put on a dance performance based of the musical Annie.
Q45_1: At the Alain L. Locke Magnet School for Environmental Stewardship, our staff is committed to the personal, social and academic development of all our students. We believe all students can succeed-NO EXCEPTIONS! Our school community continuously work together in developing the best ways to meet the needs of every child and encourage them to strive for GREATNESS and nothing less.

Q42_R1_C1: Learning through an Expanded Arts Program
Q44_1: The STEM Institute of Manhattan will continue to provide visual arts and music instuction through art residencies provided by LEAP. In collaboration with The leadership Program, STEM students receive regular instruction in visual arts and theatre. Our classroom teachers will continue to integrate art through the content areas so our students will continue to explore, design and showcase their work in our corridors and classrooms.

Our school provides integrated instruction to students in all grades. Therefore, the students are required to create art projects that are aligned to their units of study. All 4-6 week long units include two project based homework assignments that include some form of art. Additionally, our Art teacher aligns the art instruction to the units being studied in class. All projects are assessed through the use of rubrics. They are also provided with constructive feedback from their peers and teachers. Student work and efforts are acknowledged at the end of every school year by hosting an art gala. Families and local community members are invited to enjoy the beautiful artwork.

Our arts program consisted of: 1) 3 years of continuous visual arts classes for all students; 2) teaching artists collaborations with all ELA classes. 3) weekly STEAM classes for all 6th and 7th graders 4) theater, music and dance immersions via collaboration with Lincoln Center Education 5) American Composer Orchestra for all 6th and 7th graders; 6) Ballroom Basix dance instruction for all 8th graders; 7)afterschool arts program fully funded via partnership with Manhattan Youth and supplemented with PA funding

West Side Collaborative Middle School values the arts and incorporates arts into content area curriculum through interdisciplinary projects. We also offer courses in specific art forms. Students are provided with arts experiences that allow them to be creators and performers. Students explore a wide range of arts disciplines including visual, film, music, digital, dance and theater arts. In content area and arts courses, students respond to and analyze works of arts. These experiences are enhanced by long term partnerships with art museums and performing arts organizations that broaden our students' awareness of the importance of the arts and their value to society. We are pleased to continue relationships with organizations such as the Whitney Museum of American Art, Wingspan Arts, and The Center For Arts Education to enrich our arts curricula at West Side Collaborative Middle School.

West End Secondary School is committed to providing a comprehensive arts program for all students inclusive of visual arts, dance, and music.  Multiple partnerships will enhance our commitment to the arts.

The High School for Arts, Imagination and Inquiry is a learning community in which deep engagement with works of art is integrated across the curriculum, which enhances the intellectual rigor expected of all students. This work is based on the philosophy of the late Maxine Greene, former Philosopher-in-Residence at Lincoln Center Education (LCE), and the exploration of the LCE Capacities for Imaginative Learning which comprise our academic language used to support student success.

Through interdisciplinary coursework and media classes, UAM students develop the self-reflective practices and critical and analytical skills necessary for future success in college and beyond. At UAM, ‘media’ is defined as the way in which ideas and information are expressed and communicated. Media classes expose students to the various communicative manifestations of media and equip them with the tools to critically evaluate and access this varied information, including both digital and fine art, dance and theatre journalism and the Spanish language. Students develop a portfolio that embodies their ability to effectively use and analyze media which documents their development as critical thinkers equipped with an understanding of the forces that shape communication. They gain an appreciation for the crucial role of media in contemporary culture and society. All students participate in media presentations, where they present and defend their work from their media classes at the end of each quarter.

At the Manhattan School for Children, we believe that the arts are vital to our children's education, and that the exploration of the arts nurtures their creativity, imagination and ability to see other points of view as they make personal connections to the world they live in. To foster this vision, the school community has developed a dynamic and well-organized arts program across arts disciplines that is inclusive of our children's backgrounds and of the world's cultures. We are committed to a vision of the school as a community of learners, who are empowered to create their work and share their process. We achieve this vision by the integration of the arts experiences within classroom curriculum and the broad exposure to the arts through our collaborations with neighborhood cultural institutions. Our school is currently in a vertical grade research project with Lincoln Center Institute with the goal of understanding how to implement the capacities for imaginative learning across cohorts. In addition, we have embarked making our vision for an MSC Music Department a reality with an all-school sequential music program and have hired a music director for our MSC chorus classes and a percussion teacher. We have also added four music electives to our elective roster: Band, Percussion, Chorus and MSC Glee

Our goal is to expose our students to as many genres of art as possible, and engage them in critical conversations about their experiences with art. We have a visual arts teacher that works with our students in Ceramics, and her work is supported by our writing teachers who engage our students in thinking about how their work communicates their intentions.

This school year 5 GLC students partnered with the Theater program at The Brandeis Campus. Students from all school met every week for 3 hours to rehearse a play. The play will be presented in the auditorium in June 2017 and all students and staff from the campus will be invited.

Innovation Diploma Plus (IDP) High School offers art courses in Theatre, Mixed Media, and Digital Media. Our courses focus on using an inter-disciplinary approach to shaping critical art spaces that allow students to explore connections between notions of self and community. Within that process, students are able to re-contextualize both narrative and story through their own use of multi-media and performance as well as use art to explore critical issues that are important to them. Each course has three specific performance challenges and one culminating capstone that function as part of a student’s ongoing portfolio. In addition, teachers at IDP collaborate with outside cultural organizations to offer after school programs in Theatre, Spoken Word, Creative Writing, and Video Production. During the 2016-7 school year, IDP produced two full theatre productions and one Spoken Word Performance.  In addition, students were given opportunities  to attend cultural arts events, such as the Metropolitan Museum of Art and Broadway shows. IDP is a member of the Brandeis Arts Collective, which provides after school arts programs, including music, dance, theatre, and fine art,  to students from attending schools on the Brandeis Campus.

Wadleigh Secondary School for The Performing and Visual Arts offers a comprehensive Performing and Visual Arts education program to students in grades 6 through 12. Wadleigh Performing Arts program offers classes in Drama, Vocal Music, Piano and Instrumental music. The Dance program includes tap, modern, jazz, African and other cultural dance forms. The Visual Arts program offers general and advanced classes in painting, drawing and digital photography including computer graphics. We have added a culinary arts program and a film/ video oral history program in partnership with The Apollo Theater Foundation. The school's vision is to emphasize the well balanced student. We have adopted the Habits of Heart, Habits of Mind and Habits of Work. We strive to become the premier arts school in the Harlem community. At Wadleigh, students engage in a rigorous academic curriculum inclusive of advance placement courses, honor classes and college credit courses infused with a strong Performing and Visual Arts program designed to ignite our scholars' imagination, nurture their intellectual curiosity and develop their creative spirit within and beyond our school walls.

Q42_R1_C1: Learning through an Expanded Arts Program
Q44_1: Frank McCourt High School provides all students with a two-year introduction to visual art and dance.  Our 9th and 10th grade Media curriculum provides students with an understanding of visual art techniques and building blocks that can be expanded upon in elective courses and applied in media work throughout the disciplines.  Dance is introduced through our Physical Education program- including movement and choreography- to all students and interested students can elect to take specific dance courses in 11th and 12th grades.  In addition, we have a robust opt-in arts program that includes visual art, dance, theater and music.  Community arts organizations and campus teachers work with our teachers to provide opportunities and instruction to all interested students.  We celebrate the arts at our school annually in an Art Show that includes gallery and performance displays.

PS 452 aims to provide opportunities to leave the classroom for exploratory purposes to museums, landmarks, parks, neighborhoods and cultural institution. We utilize group projects that require the children to plan, research, organize and share. Our goal-oriented units use technology, art, drama and movement to express ideas. Currently we engage our Primary grade students in the exploration of the foundations of music and begin to foster their visual artist-self through many mediums. Upper grade students begin to diversify their learning through choral work, differentiated instrumentation, art history, art making, art critique, and advanced visual artistic creation. We believe the arts to be an inclusive and engaging experience for all students, instilling an appreciation for all art forms while fostering their journey to become life-long fine arts appreciators. During the 2016-2017 school year we engaged residency programs with National Dance Institute and Salvadori. We work in collaboration with cultural institutions such as The American Museum of Natural History, New York Historical Society, and various other museums and artistic institutions throughout New York City.

Our school enjoys an international reputation as the first and foremost high school dedicated to nurturing students gifted in the arts. Part of our mission is to provide an opportunity for students to pursue conservatory style training. Our state-of-the-art building at Lincoln Center was designed especially for the arts and features world-class facilities including a 1,150-seat concert hall, art, dance, music, recording and theater studios, and an art gallery.

Our school has a passion for the arts and academics.  We are dedicated to nuturing students creative talents.  Part of our mission is to provide our students with a solid foundation in the arts through a sequence of academic courses, career exploration opportunities and inspiring interactions with fellow students, faculty and professional artists. Students will receive an introduction to fundamental concepts of art.  Students will explore Elements of Art and Principles of Design through studio lessons using problem solving skills in a variety of 2D and 3D media: drawing, painting, printmaking, collage, cardboard and clay.  Students will build a foundation of media and technique through lessons engaging observation and imagination. Our art program will expose students to a variety of artists, art styles, and art vocabulary building dialogue to critically analyze their work and the work of others. Students will be exposed to the visual arts through trips to museums and from our resident artist through our partnership with City Arts.

The High School of Arts and Technology at the MLK Campus is a small school with approximately 600 students. At Arts and Tech HS we use arts and technology as tools to teach, learn and drive the educational process. Students have access to visual art, theatre, drama, general music, art history and graphic arts on computers. Our school has its own student art hallway gallery.

We could not continue to offer dance classes this year before, during, and after school. We were only able to afford music and visual arts. Our goals are to expose students to art forms that they have not experienced yet as well as to help them discover or develop their talents in these areas.

The arts program at MHSHS uses project-based learning to educate students about visual media, culture, history, and mathematics. Educators infuse their curricula with multidisciplinary lessons that offer practical applications for their expressive and creative talents. Our students transform themselves into active participants of their culture. In visual art students learn a broad range of disciplines including but not limited to sculpture, modeling, drawing, painting, scenic design and a multitude of others. Students receive a broad education in the history of the arts featuring notable artists and their styles. In the performing arts students explore animation, audio sound and sound design, film and TV study, acting, directing, stage combat and theater technology. Our acting and musical units address diction, projection and performance techniques to instill confidence and ownership in our students.

The mission of Kaufman Music Center's Special Music School High School (SMS) is to develop students who have the skills, competencies and knowledge necessary for successful 21st-century music careers. The 21st-century musician can analyze, compose, and perform music at the highest level; has a strong sense of his/her own artistic “voice,” and is fluent in current music technologies. The 21st-century musician possesses the academic knowledge, skills, and habits that are keys to success in a rapidly changing world; he/she is also community-minded, inventive, and resourceful.

Founded in 1996 and inspired by the “spetsshkola” system of the former Soviet Union, Special Music School is a unique partnership between the New York City Department of Education and Kaufman Music Center, a not-for-profit cultural organization.

Q42_R1_C1: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
Q44_1: FDA II is a Lincoln Center Education focus school. Here, we value art education and deem it important for each of our scholars to be exposed to dance, music, film/media and the visual arts. Our lessons are aligned to the BluePrint and Common Core standards. At FDA II scholars perceive the arts through the capacities of aesthetic education as defined by Lincoln Center Education. Scholars explore the arts with the assistance and knowledge of our teachers, visiting artists and getting involved, learning for themselves with hands-on performance tasks.

Mott Hall II considers the arts to be a critical part of our curriculum.  All scholars at Mott Hall II take music for three years.  The music curriculum is anchored by "Music and the Brain."  Additionally, 7th and 8th scholars receive dance instruction from a certified dance teacher.  Mott Hall II collaborates with Studio In A School to provide visual arts as part of our after school program.  The Society for Educational Arts (SEA) also works with Mott Hall II to provide 100-hour theater residency that ends with the performance of our annual school musical.  Finally, Mott Hall II has a school choir and rock band scholars can audition for.

At PS/MS 7, our academic program is challenging, rigorous and enriched by integrating the arts.We have 'Education Through Music,' which serves the entire student population with general music, choir and, this year, concert band. We also have the 'I Have A Dream' Foundation , as an after-school program for the 2nd graders that help children with homework, provides instructional support, implements art projects,and take our students on trips. 'Edible School Yard' is a creative garden project that involves our entire school, grades pre-kindergarten to 8. We are in the process of building a roof-top garden, where each student will plant, maintain tools, create signs and grow healthy fruits and vegetables. In addition, we have a classroom dedicated to being a kitchen for healthy food preperation. It's an exciting year! The National Dance Institute works with our forth and fifth grade students once a week and culminates with a gala dance performance for the students in the school and their parents.

Q37_4: helping to create partnerships with cultural organizations
Q44_1:
TAG has been devoted to providing well-rounded Arts education for its students. All of our students, Kindergarten through Eighth Grade receive consistent, high-quality instruction in Music and Visual Arts. We have a dedicated Kindergarten through 3rd Grade music teacher. In 4th grade students transition to instrumental music through the recorder. By 5th grade, students choose a band instrument and begin their performance instruction. All Kindergarten through 8th Grade students perform for their classmates as well as parents, during formal concerts, multiple times per year. In addition to our music program that takes place during our regular school day, we have an afternoon Latin Jazz Ensemble that rehearses twice a week, after school. They perform multiple times per year, both in school and at community events throughout New York City. 
Our Visual Arts program is continuing to grow and develop. All of our students, Kindergarten through 8th Grade receive Art instruction at least 1 time per week. They work in various mediums. Pieces have been displayed at Art Shows both in the school and online, through Artsonia. Our art teacher also does an "Art Lunch," where students can work on projects during their lunch.

At River East, we provide a comprehensive arts education program. We partner with several community based organizations to enhance student opportunities in the arts. With this support, we are able to offer full time visual arts instruction, pottery, violin, dance, and chorus as well as a music program in which students participate in a series of interactive concerts that introduce music from various parts of the world.

Roberto Clemente's art program consists of monthly projects.  Each unit includes pre and post-assessments. Content specific vocabulary is a big part of each unit. These projects further the understanding of all students with different modalities and individual needs. There are many assemblies that showcase student achievements in music and dance. There is a school wide multicultural day where our students explore the culture of various countries and showcase their learning through food, song or dance. Our upper class man work closely with artists from the Guggenheim to explore other visual art techniques and take field trips to the museum as part of the program.  We have a full time visual arts teacher who is certified in the arts teaching art history along with art methods and vocabulary.  She also identify connections to science through the arts as well.  While teachers are not available for dance, theater and music at PS 38, scholars are exposed to a variety  of art form through different resources and programs.

School’s Arts Program Description 2016-2017
(To be published in Arts Report)


 
  


The PS/MS 57 Arts program includes visual, music, theater and dance components. All students receive arts enrichment in these areas. Prekindergarten has music, role-play, poetry and movement as integral components of everyday. K-8th grades infuse poetry, music & art into CCLS-based lessons which are developed by the teachers and instructional teams. In addition to embedded school-based visual arts instruction, we have an Arts partnership with the 92nd Street 'Y' that provides stimulating student experiences through choral training that culminates in a district-wide showcase with several participating schools. 92nd St. Y also engaged students in visual arts, Hip Hop and musical introduction. This year the 'Dancing in the Classrooms' served 5th grade and 'Ballroom Basics' company serves our middle school population. These dance programs culminate in the school's participation in a citywide competition. After-school programs such as the YMCA, Roads to Success, and City Year provide arts exposure via varied dance genres such as hip hop and tap; while the staff enhances support of the arts initiative via after-school chorus, flag corps, step squad and classical music appreciation for K-8th grade students.

We currently work with three major community based organizations, Turtle Bay Music School, Midori & Friends, and El Museo del Barrio. They provide enriching opportunities to our students in music, theatre, and fine arts education.

Our goal at PS/MS 96 is to provide our students with a complete and comprehensive Arts Program for next year. This will be enriching to our current curriculum via our teachers and also be supported by many cultural organizations which will partner with us in the future. Our goal for next year is to include 3 Arts Disciplines; Visual Arts, Dance and Music as well as continuing to provide Technology. Our students will work with their art teachers who will align projects to their core subjects, as well as promoting art outcomes including shows, digital displays, concerts and performances for our greater community. We also look forward to offering Arts Workshops for parents and their children broadening our scope as a community school. Through the connection to the arts we look ahead to positive and tangible improvements in learning across all educational disciplines.  We also hope to provide our Middle school students can connect arts to relevant cultural and career opportunities.  Our Middle school students will have opportunities for portfolio specials going forward into the new year.

The art department of the High School for Law and Public Service views all students as artists and embraces a vision of art education as an integral part of a student's core education. We therefore provide students with rich opportunities to express themselves artistically through a variety of media or performances, to explore career opportunities available in the art world, to learn about art history and the role that art plays in cultures throughout the world, and to develop an understanding of how art is related to all forms of expression and is connected to other subjects of study. At HSLPS, students can choose to fulfill the minimum credit requirement within a rich studio and graphics arts curriculum or follow an advanced art track culminating in an arts endorsed diploma. A theater elective course also offers students the possibility of following a performance track in the arts.

P.S. 102 is committed to educating the whole child. This is done through the use of different disciplines that appeal to many needs of our students. Students will gain and extend knowledge of art media and art compositional elements. Students will have the opportunity to explore through the use of different materials and techniques. Our Arts program will focus on the students' prior experiences and align to the scope and sequence of each grade level to enhance learning for all students. Teachers will be encouraged to create student-directed activities that encourage investigation and thought. Teachers will use the Art Blueprint from Studio in a School to help formulate units of study and lessons that are developmentally appropriate for our children.  Children will engage in graphic arts, programing for animation, painting, drawing, and collage.

Q42_R1_C1: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts

Q44_1: The arts are considered a vital part of the mission of PS 112. It is our goal to provide all of our students with a high quality standards based arts education. We want our students to discover the lifelong enjoyment and wonder of dance, visual arts and drama. Our arts programs provide students with rich learning experiences that strengthen their academic skills, creativity and positively impacts student achievement in reading, writing, math, science and social studies. The arts program at PS 112 creates a culture of mutual respect and enhances self esteem.
Q45_1: We have a drama teacher from the Actor's fund who provides drama to all of our students. She works at PS 112 four days a week.

Q44_1: Our students and teachers experience professional arts concerts and events at 92Y and PS146. Through our partnership, students have been able to take advantage of further arts instruction at 92Y and have been offered scholarships at 92Y. Our vision for this partnership is to build a course of study consisting of arts disciplines that are related sequentially and make meaningful connections to the Common Core Standards and Blueprint for the Arts. Through this partnership we are able reach our goal to make sure that reach every child in the school has access to the arts. We consider the arts crucial to the development of our students, both academically and personally, recognizing that effective arts education addresses the diverse ways in which students learn. We are committed to fostering collaborations between classroom teachers and teaching artists using common language and curriculum goals. 92Y also provides professional development to our classroom teachers and assessment and evaluation of our arts programs. This year, we extending our programs through June through an arts extension grant. The students will use what they learned in their art classes to create and produce a school-wide performance combing all art disciplines and classes K-5.

We are currently partnered with Arts Connection to provide theatre and visual arts to all students in grades Pre-K- 5th grade. Students are provided an inter curriculum approach to art through Social Studies and Science.

PS/IS 171 believes that integration of the arts into all aspects of the school community is essential to promoting the goals of the Common Core Learning Standards and revised common core aligned curriculum implemented within all classrooms, Pre-K to Grade 8, in our school. As visitors travel through the hallways of our building, they view the beautiful artwork created by our students. Classroom teachers work collaboratively with our arts providers to design units of study and motivating projects that will enrich student achievement while working to foster student appreciation of the arts. Working with the various arts provider, classroom teachers and specialists are able to infuse music, movement, art and dance into literacy, mathematics, social studies, science and foreign language.  Our long term partnerships with cultural and artistic organizations including Studio in a School and the Horticulture Society of New York support and enhance our efforts to promote the arts.
We are proud to share that on March 24, 2017, sixteen of our sixth, seventh and eighth grade students participated in the New York State School Music Association (NYSSMA) Festival at Celia Cruz High School in the Bronx.  Nine of the students received a score of 'Outstanding' and seven students received a score of 'Excellent' for their solo or ensemble pieces.

The Bilingual Bicultural Mini School promotes the Arts. We currently have one full time music teacher who participates in Music in the Brain. This opportunity allows students to cognitively develop skills through the concept of listening to music, playing the keyboard and composing notes. We have established partnerships with the Society of Educational Arts and CMA. Currently, we have a visual arts program where students engage in the process of creating graphics using videos and others engage in mask making. The learning includes learning the history behind specific cultures and the meaning of masks for each particular culture. Students learn how to create masks and develop a sense of understanding for each unique culture. The Children's Museum of Arts works with our fourth grade students. Visual arts is infuse in the social studies curriculum. The artist worked hand-in-hand with teachers to integrate the arts in classrooms, using project-based learning to creatively bridge disciplines. Story Pirates provides our students with theatre experience. The idea is that students are engaged in creative writing by planning and visualizing. The actors collect written works from students and adapt these stories for the stage. Kid-written work is then performed by professional actors in a sketch comedy venue.

This school year we added a dance program which is led by the Society of Educational Arts. The dance program provides an opportunity for students to learn technique and dance history.

Our school's arts program is comprised of in-house initiatives in which music and theater are incorporated into the daily instructional program by arts cluster teachers and music and movement by a non-arts cluster teacher. This year we have a licensed music teacher and theater arts teacher. In addition, we contract consultants such as Dancing in the Classroom. This year we will continue to participate in a grant with the Salvation Army that allows us to foster the love of music by having the children play in an orchestra. Extended day programs in music and visual arts are provided through after school enrichment clubs and arts programs in which students receive instruction in playing the clarinet and drama. We have a variety of clubs in drama, dance, and music taught by in-house staff. Our students have participated in city-wide dance competitions and have won second place for the various genres of ballroom dances. As a school we have a strong commitment and vision for the arts.
