We currently have school-day 6-12 sequences for Music, Visual Art and Dance. We prioritize access for all learners, and emphasize performance at venues throughout the city. Our music program is currently focused on ensemble playing, and we are excited to have the only string orchestra in District 4. Scholars learn music theory and composition as well as performance technique. Directed by Grammy Award winner/Teacher, we also offer Latin American Jazz ensemble as a class and after program. Additionally, through our partnerships, the students participated in Opera Performance with the Martina Arroyo Foundation, and attended performances and installations at the Park Avenue Armory. Our Visual Arts program is a 6-12 sequence focused on developing the fundamentals of visual art, developing scholar talent, and exploring different forms of visual art. Instructed by award winning Art Teacher, we also offer Film Production as an introductory course this year. We also offer pottery in our after-school program through the 21st Century Community Learning Centers grant. Our Dance department is also a 6-12 sequence focused on developing the fundamentals of dance in different genres from ballet to jazz and hip-hop. The scholars compose and perform their own works throughout the year while making connections with other arts and disciplines outside the arts. We also have cooperative learning set up with Alvin Ailey, 92nd street-Y and NYC ballet, as well as 2 after-school dance troupes through The Leadership Program and 21st CCLC grant.

Mosaic's school based art program consists of a visual arts teacher and a dance teacher. The classroom teachers teach the other disciplines of art in the classroom. In addition, students are exposed to the arts through art based performances both in school and out of school. Also, students take various trips throughout the year to visit museums, theaters, cultural institutions and art based organizations. Mosaic Preparatory Academy studied the various forms of art/artists throughout the 2015-2016 school year: September - Swing, Big Band, Artist Focus John Sloan October - Ballroom Dance, Classical Music, Artist Focus Georgia O'Keefe November - Square Dancing, Folk Music, Artist Focus Henri Mattise December - Country Dance, Country Music, Artist Focus Wassily Kadinsky January - Modern Ballet, Symphony, Artist Pablo Picasso February - Disco Dance, Disco Music, Artist Paul Cezanne March - Modern Dance, Soul Music, Artist Mark Rothko April - Hip-Hop Dance, Funk Music, Artist Betye Saar May - Salsa Dance, Latin Music, Artist Salvador Dali June - Tap Dance, Blues Music, and Artist John White. 
As a culminating activity at the end of the school year, all scholars learn Langston Hughes poems and perform them through dance, song and theater.

Renaissance School of the Arts' (RSA) core belief is that education adds immeasurable value to our human existence. It empowers us to dream, enlightens us to our potential, and liberates us to take hold of the unknown. RSA provides students of all learning styles a stimulating and rigorous middle school educational program intertwined with the performing arts as they strive toward academic excellence. During their three years at Renaissance School of the Arts students receive intensive training in their chosen arts field. Upon graduation, our students are ready to audition for performing arts high schools and will have a strong foundation, not only in their specific art form, but in all of the arts. Through our partnerships with Lincoln Center Institute, the 92nd Street Y, Roundabout Theater, Shubert Theater Broadway Junior, and Muralopolis work together to provide core content instruction infused with Common Core Learning Standards and citywide expectations of exposure in the arts

We aim to provide arts through partnerships with organizations, as well as by providing music, dance, and visual arts to each student. Because we are a technology-based school, students have the opportunity to create music and film on their computers and utilize online resources to enhance their arts education. Our school is also partnered with Broadway Jr. to help produce a school musical in the spring.

Coalition will continue to offer visual Arts and chorus programs during the course of our day. We will continue to enhance the education of students with the attendance at out of school performances and Museum trips. In 2017-2018 we will look to continue our work with 21st Century Learning,  Partnership with Children, the Young People's Chorus, the Art of Stepping, and TDF.

Manhattan Center for Science and Mathematics High School offers a robust arts curriculum. We offer both visual arts and music, including an introduction to music theory. Additionally, we offer both Technical Drawing and Photography. The visual art program explores arts through the ages. It explores artistic techniques for drawing, painting, sculpting, etc. We offer many oportunities for students to create their own art. Our technical drawing program introduces students to composing plans that visually communicate how something functions or is to be constructed. We work with Shakespeareforum.org to provide free after-school drama lessons, culminating in an end of year performance.

At Park East, we offer both introductory level visual arts classes and an advanced level portfolio class for students who are considering college study or careers in visual art. We have also offered electives in the the arts including theatre, performance poetry, choir and introduction to music.

Central Park East High School offers both studio art, Photoshop and yearbook to students during the school day. We complete the NY State graduation requirements with this program and offer students who excel in the arts many opportunities beyond the mandated credit requirements. We also offer students the opportunity to join the school newspaper, The Madison Times, where students gain valuable experience in learning design layout techniques with the In-Design software program. In addition to the art classes offered during the regular school day, Central Park East High School works with Young Audiences New York through a CASA grant to offer dance and improv theater residences to students as an extracurricular opportunity. Students who seek admission to colleges that focus on the arts receive assistance with developing portfolios for admission and are offered access to many supplemental after school and summer programs to increase their exposure to the arts.  And finally, new for this year we have collaborated with Urban Arts Partnership and two other nearby high schools to offer chorus, dance, theater and a dj club as additional after-school choices for our students.

The comprehensive visual arts and music programs consist of Standards and Blueprint Based curricula that enrich student learning and offer a generous platform in providing college and personal development. The additional courses, partnerships, museum, film and theater programs add incomparable enrichment to broaden the academic, creative and professional perspective. These programs enable each girl to make connections between cultural, historical and social aspects of the world through their uniquely creative imagery and expressive languages. This year all arts related courses broadened to include more technology and now use state of the art equipment to enrich the learning experiences. Both the formal arts departments of Art and Music Education and enrichment curricula, are designed to expand the developing student's capacity to relate to the world of increasing complexity, connection and enjoyment. A variety of career directions are explored, developed and nurtured.

Currently 1/3 of the school if offered Art Year One, Art Year Two and AP Art in mixed grade classes. These courses focus on introducing students to learning to think visually, and develop their ideas from concept to completion through scaffolded projects. The projects develop students ability to work out problems in line, color and 3-d media such as clay, plaster, paper mache & mixed media. The work students produce individual and group projects, exhibited around the building continuously through the school year, in an annual in-school arts exhibition, as well as entered in exhibitions locally and nationally. Lessons are coordinated across school curricula. Students are encouraged to build a portfolio with school projects, personal work done at home and apply to after school programs as well as summer museum and arts internships. 
Music in also offered to 1/3 of the students in mixed grade classes through three courses: beginners, intermediate and Band. the band preforms at school events and the basketball games. Students are also provided with individual instruction after school through a 'go fund me' program created by the Music teacher, to bring in musicians to teach.
After school workshops are offered to students in Visual Arts & Photography, Step & Latin Dancing, Film & Music Production through ELO-Teachers College, Columbia University. Students attend 1 hour classes twice a week over the full academic year. Their work is showcased in in-school exhibitions & two end of the semester talent shows.

Isaac Newton Middle School for Math and Science has a full time visual arts teacher and a drama teacher who does cycles of theatre for the sixth grade students. Students interested in applying for Visual Arts High Schools are given assistance and instruction on preparing their portfolios.

PS30 partners with the following cultural arts organizations to enhance and support arts education -

*  Time In Children's Arts Initiative - Year round program for Kindergarten to 5th grade students provide a hand-on arts with specialization in 20th and 21th century visual arts.  Program includes in-school, in-studio, and gallery/museum visits.
*  92nd Street Y's Musical Introduction Series Program for selected classes provide first hand concert performance experiences in different genre of music and culture, in-school visits from a teaching artist, and professional development for classroom teachers.
*  Opus 118 provides violin instruction each week for students from first to fifth grade.  Each group receives individualized attention from two experienced OPUS violin instructors  
*  Carnegie Hall Musical Explorers and Link Up programs for classes in first, second, third, and fifth grades.  Program provides concert experiences to students and professional development to educators.
*  LEAP Works work with ENL/SWD students exploring Social Studies themes through Project based learning.
*  Leadership Program for first and second grade afterschool students engaging in dance, movement, and healthy eating.  
*  Performing arts visits from Los Pleneros, Young Audiences, and Making Books Sing

PS30 is committed to continue and to support art education to broaden and deepen students' exposure and deepen their appreciation of the arts aligned with the Arts and Music Blueprint Standards as well as the Common Core Standards.

This school year we were fortunate to have Inside Broadway and Inside Voices where the artists worked with our fourth and fifth grade students as they created a play on immigration and wrote their screen plays.

In addition, students in grades kindergarten through fifth received art classes with an intern from TC throughout the school year.

Our four Pre K classes enjoyed a small Studio in the school grant for three months where the teachers received profession development and an artist worked with the teachers and students.

At The Arthur Tappan School - PS/MS 46, we believe that Arts education helps to form the basis of a well-rounded student. We continue to foster partnerships, with recognized art institutions, to build an appreciation for the different media, in addition to hiring and retaining art educators who bring the disciplines to life for our students. Through the Arts, we hope to foster in our students an appreciation for the varied forms.

This year we continued with our goal to expose our students to as many aspects of the arts as possible as this is paramount to their holistic development. Understanding and participating with the different art forms (dance, music, visual art) will facilitate and engender understanding and hopefully tolerance of their own and other cultures. The integration of the arts in our curriculum will help to develop their creativity in response to the other content areas. Students will gain awareness of the variety of careers available in the arts and this will broaden their career scope, especially for those who demonstrate an affinity for these areas. In addition, the introduction to the arts will allow them to develop an appreciation of them as a source of personal enjoyment and lifelong learning.

PS/MS 123 is committed to providing quality arts educational programs for our students. We strongly believe that our students' gifts and talents should be nurtured to their fullest potential. It is our intention to provide art integrated experiences to enable our students to participate in various multiple art forms. Emphasis is placed on developing creative and critical thinking skills to address the challenges of the twenty-first century. Our goal is to design and facilitate student interest and appreciation for the arts. Staff and parents will be provided professional development workshop opportunities to improve and enhance their understanding of the arts. Parents will be provided multiple opportunities to take part in various art form celebrations with their children and etachers.  We recognize the importance and therapeutic value of the arts in the lives of our students by permitting them to express their feelings through various art themes. We will continue to select highly-qualified art teachers to provide a standards-based arts curriculum.

In our progressive approach, we believe that education must not be a race for the accumulation of facts, but should be an enriching end in itself. We also believe that education is a joint venture among students, parents/caregivers and teachers. We see the individual child’s curiosity, abilities and learning styles as integral factors in designing, individualizing and assessing each student’s learning. We believe that the arts are an essential part of the curriculum and that it is important for students to express themselves creatively and to use their imaginations freely. We believe that the uniqueness of children is revealed in their very existence and that it is the school’s responsibility to foster their innate sense of the mystery and joy of life. We encourage children to follow their interests, pursue problems in a way that makes sense to them and defend their conclusion by explaining their thinking a variety of ways. We understand that there are many kinds of intelligence and the traditional academic, cognitive area is one. Other important areas of intelligence are intuition, imagination, artistic creativity, physical expression and performance, sensitivity to others, and self-understanding. To neglect any of these areas is to limit students in the development of their full human potential. We engage students with hands-¬on investigations, projects and design challenges across the grades and subject areas inspiring greater interest, depth and understanding.
Q45_1:
Ralph Bunche School Students…						 
Think Creatively
• Explore, take intellectual risks and think divergently
• Know how to learn from their experiences and a myriad of sources
• Apply a variety of learned techniques for effective problem solving
• Balance determination, perseverance and flexibility to strengthen resilience
• Understand constructive dissent as a way to question the status quo
• Recognize their unique learning strengths

Actively Engaged
• Solving problems or creating solutions
• Developing questioning, research and communication skills
• Collaborating within and beyond the classroom
• Tackling real-world questions, issues and controversies
• Participating in the public creation and improvement of ideas and knowledge
• Developing deep understanding of content knowledge

Learn Deeply
• Engage as inquisitive, thoughtful, active learners
• Possess broad skills for the design, collection, analysis and application of quantitative and qualitative research
• Think critically to connect and interpret complex information
• Develop technological competency
• Learn equally from failures, setbacks,  mistakes, wonderings and successes
• Find intrinsic satisfaction through development and mastery of essential academic competencies

Act Compassionately
• Learn to make thoughtful, informed decisions both individually and collaboratively
• Embrace diversity and inclusiveness
• Have a developed responsibility to work for what they believe is important
• Act with agency
• Use empathy to understand a variety of perspectives

Q44_1: At New Design Middle School we believe in the idea of making the city our classroom. With so many cultural institutions at our fingerprints we have designed much of our curriculum around rich local experiences. Below are some examples of how our students have experienced NYC. In our 8th grade Design for Life course, many of our students will be visiting the African Dance workshop at BAM. The workshop will allow our students to learn about the Afro-Brazilian style of dance and music. Our 7th grade DFL class has reached out to Harlem Stage. Theater instructors from Harlem Stage worked with our students to create interpretations of excerpts from the Autobiography of Malcolm X. Our 6th grade social studies classes spent this year visiting the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Our students were able to view works of art and historical artifacts that aligned with the early civilizations of the 6th grade curriculum (Egypt, Mesopotamia, Greece, and Rome). During this past school year we partnered with the New York Historical Society and took part in a program called Teen Thursdays. A number of our 7th and 8th grade students experienced the historical society each week and worked with different primary sources that reflected the role of New York in the context of American history. This past month our students working with the Broadway Jr. program performed songs from Aladdin on a Broadway

Q42_R1_C1: Learning through an Expanded Arts Program

Q44_1: Our partnerships with Brooklyn Steppers, Arts Connection and Sheltering Arms have provided our scholars with the opportunity to explore the both music, theater, and visual arts in order to engage in a variety of projects and performances. Both our music and theater programs have added key enrichment opportunities for the young men of Eagle Harlem both during and after the school day.

We are an elementary PK-5 school located in central Harlem.  We believe that the arts are essential in enriching the academic, social and cultural lives of our students.  We are unable to provide a rich arts program which includes music and dance, due to our limited resources. We currently have a full-time visual arts teacher who provides direct instruction to students in K-5.  Students in PK receive arts instruction from the classroom teacher.  The goals of the art program will be to use all available resources within the community to expose and engage our students in all forms of arts education to extend their learning beyond the classroom, thus enriching their academic and cultural experiences. In order to ensure that our students become literate in the arts, we have established ongoing partnerships with various cultural institutions, including the Apollo Theater, The American Ballet Theater and Broadway Beats, to name a few.  Our partnership with these organizations enable our students and staff to fully engage in various art forms which taps students' unidentified talents and interests.  Full arts Integration will enrich students learning. Our goal continues to be in increasing our school-based arts teachers to expand learning opportunities for our students.
Q45_1: We are an elementary school in central Harlem, located near several rich cultural institutions, The Apollo Theater, Studio Museum of Harlem, to name a few. In previous years we were able to provide our students with a rich arts program that included music, dance and visual arts.  Due to funding cuts and staff turnover, we have had to reduce arts programming to students during the instructional day. This has also limited our ability to provide arts programming in our extra-curricular activities.

Q44_1: Our school adheres to the New York State Education Department mandates for all high school diplomas that require students to earn a half unit of study in art and another half unit of study in music. All middle school students and upperclassmen in high school earn their art and music appreciation credits through seminar style courses that culminate in a term project, after meeting the necessary amount of classroom hours. In addition, this year we have increased our participation in the Arts Matter Program by hiring full time the Visual Arts licensed teacher. All 6-8 students are programmed to recieve art five times a week. The coursework followed the Blueprint for the Arts provided by NYC DOE. We have also an Arthuir Miller Fellow-Theather/Drama licensed teacher providing paly wrtiing and acting classes to high scholers.

We currently have a UASGC Robotics team. We also offer AutoDESK (Photoshop, AutoCAD). We also have the Apollo, and Caribbean Cultural Center come and visit the students after school and provide one on one instruction.
Q45_1: We have 242 students enrolled in UASGC.

Q44_1: PS 161 has a small group of excellent full time fine arts teachers. Our two music teachers, Lindsay Brown and Delia Alexander, teach general music and music technology as well as ensembles in strings, chorus and guitar, serving all 9 grades in our K-8 schools. We put on two major music performances: a Winter and Spring concert. Our art teacher teaches 2nd-8th grade. We have a full-time Drama and Dance teacher, Wendy Rojas, who works with grades K-4 as well as our after school middle school drama club.  Our students do theater in collaboration with our City College theater partnership. The highlight is our annual middle school fall musical, which has become a cherished tradition. Our fall production of Beauty and the Beast featured 40 students performers, elaborate design, and a packed house of 400 community members.  Our drama club attended a performance of Holiday Inn on Broadway.  We participate in dance with several dance residencies including NDI and Reach Educational Solutions, and host an annual ballroom dancing competition. Our elective model for the arts in the middle school has been transformative to our arts culture. For the last 3 years, 1 in 10 of our 8th graders has gone on to matriculate at a selective fine arts high school. Our middle school debate team was named one of the top 5 middle school debate programs in New York City.

Following our school's motto of Mind,Body Success, the P.S. 175 arts program focuses on teaching to the whole child by incorporating multiple intelligences within the arts instruction. The goal of the arts program at P.S. 175 is to provide an interdisciplinary standards-based arts program through which our students will be provided ample exposure to dance, music production (instrumental and choral), visual arts, and theatre. Engagement in these art disciplines will enhance cultural awareness, promote positive socialization skills, boost self-esteem and positively impact students' capacity in areas such as math, literacy, science, etc. Through participation in these arts programs, students will recognize and engage in the vibrant historical and artistic community of Harlem.  They will also learn about cultural diversity through exposure to music and dances from around the world.  Students will have an opportunity to create their own projects within the music and dance studios.  Consequently, students will think and behave like artists.

Q42_R1_C1: Learning through an Expanded Arts Program
Q44_1: P.S. 194M scholars participate in the following arts programs:  Visual Arts and Integrated Arts. Both of the aforementioned programs are aligned with The Blueprints for Teaching and Learning in the Arts: PreK-12 to provide a standards-based, rigorous approach to teaching the arts, as well as the Common Core and NYS Standards, as applicable.  Our Visual Arts program takes a holistic approach to developing the whole artist where scholars are exposed to Art History and the technical skills to develop their artistry.  Integrated Arts incorporates music, dance, and theater, which afford scholars the opportunity to develop each discipline in a unique way. Additionally, our scholars’ learning is enhanced by field trips, interdisciplinary projects, and service learning activities.  Scholars participate in whole-school and grade-level performances where they showcase their creative talents in music, dance, and theater, as well as feature their work in art exhibitions.  Our Arts Programs help foster a wide range of discovery and critical thinking activities, and is designed to promote and foster scholars’ creativity, discovery, exploration, and expression.

The Teachers College Community School's (TCCS) overall arts goal is to provide all of our students with a well rounded, high quality arts education which includes dance, drama, visual arts, and music. We are proud to note that our school's arts program encompasses all grades, including pre-kindergarten. Our school has forged strong collaborations with Teachers College, Columbia University, as well as renown cultural institutions such as 92nd Street Y. Our students have performed in music recitals and school-wide concerts, their artwork curated for exhibit on-site, and displayed at Teachers College. Visiting artists have performed at our school. All children deserve to explore the stimulating and exciting world of the arts, and to see the world through a different lens. TCCS has made a strong commitment to provide a diverse and valuable arts education for our students.

At PS 197M, Art in an integral part of our instructional program. Students in all grades from Pre-Kindergarten through Grade 5 receive an assortment of art instruction. One of the highlights of our Art program is our partnership with Time-In Art. Students in Kindergarten, Second, Third, and Fourth Grade receive direct instruction each week for both interpreting the visual arts of others, as well as how to create their own works of art with emphasis on techniques. Through this program, students have had the opportunity to attend various art galas, operas, and culturally themed events in many of New York City's esteemed museums. For the 2017-2018 school year, we intend to increase our performance arts offerings for our students. One highlight will be our new ballet program in which grades 2-4 students will have a unique opportunity to develop their potential with formal instruction

Q37_4: PD by Studio in the School
Q44_1: Our school had the privilege of continuing our visual arts partnership with the Studio In A School program. This partnership provides visual arts instruction for our students and professional development for our teachers. As a result, we have an abundance of art displayed throughout the school, with an increased love and respect for visual arts by students, staff and the entire school community. For the year 2017-2018, it is our hope to provide dance, music and theater instruction via community based organizations and/or licensed full time staff arts instructors.

Q42_R1_C1: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
Q44_1: For the 2016-2017 school year we will partner with Lincoln Center Arts Education program and African Voices. Our students ELA and Social studies classes will be enriched with abundant art experiences from these two world renowned cultural arts institutions. We also have a partnership with the Shubert Arts Theater Foundation which allows our students to explore performing arts practices while supporting their content knowledge as classes are infused with elements from ELA and social studies. We will have a full time visual arts teacher that will support our project based learning model in addition to providing instruction in sculpture, painting, drawing, print making and fashion design. We firmly believe in showcasing our students work. Each year we have a student produced talent show, an Art Expo and student performances embedded into our quarterly award ceremonies.

The Mott Hall High School school community will exhaust all available resources to accomplish the goals of providing our students the most enriching arts program possible. The school will continue to integrate the core values of our mission statement and school goals, and instructional focus aligned with the Danielson framework. The arts program will continue to implement the Common Core music curriculum and the blueprints for teaching and Learning in the Arts. MHHS community will ensure students are exposed to and use a variety of media subjects, symbols and themes in order to ensure students create works of art. Mott Hall High School Arts program recognizes an effective and high-quality arts education can be a powerful catalyst for a successful education. Students will utilize the principles of art to create their own personal styles and express their ideas through various means. The arts will allow students to find various ways to express themselves. Students will develop techniques that will reflect their personal styles to illustrate and inform different opinions. Students will recognize the social, cultural, and historical significance of art. Mott Hall High School will provide students opportunities to work individually, as well as in groups, the building schools and community organizations to develop students'with art appreciation. Mott Hall High School will forge partnerships with local institutions, such as the Schoenberg Library, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and others to bring art enrichment to the students.

Our goal is to foster an environment where artistic creativity is nurtured and developed.It is our goal for students to recognize the cultural, societal and the significance of the arts. Thus becoming lifelong learners and advocates of the arts.Through our arts program students are allowed to see themselves as true artists and performers.We believe our arts programs help students to develop critical thinking skills which allows them to view the world through multiple lenses. As a school community we visit the cultural institutions of NYC. Our arts infused program is aligned with the NYS Common Core Standards.

We offer students a full compliment of Visual Arts and through partnerships with Community based Organizations are able to offer decorative Arts as well. We strive to provide opportunities in web design and audio engineering.

The Urban Assembly School for the Performing Arts (UASPA) sustains a challenging college preparatory curriculum that infuses the performing arts into all aspects of the academic experience. We know that instruction in the arts enhances the academic performance of many hard to reach students. We present our students with a conservatory level of study and weigh offerings in the performing arts equally with our academics. During freshman year, students gain instruction in four areas of the performing arts: dance, theater, technical theater and vocal arts. During students' freshman year, they declare a pre-major in which they study daily during freshmen and sophomore year. At the end of sophomore year, students declare and audition for a performing arts major which remains their focus as upperclassmen. During that time students have daily double periods of conservatory study in their major as well as an internship or apprenticeship with a professional artists/arts organization.

The Digital Media and the Arts Program encompasses the music, dance, visual arts, theater, and digital media course offerings at Frederick Douglass Academy. DMAP also oversees specialized 4-year programs in Harlem Samba and Digital Media. Classes incorporate technology, collaboration and engaging high level discussion and continued implementation of the Blueprint for the Arts standards. Dr. Monteiro serves as program director of Harlem Samba featured on TED Talks: The Education Revolution on PBS and live on Globo TV an international network in celebration of 100 years of Samba https://globoplay.globo.com/v/5472973/
He was also honored as a 2016 Big Apple Teacher and Lincoln Center Arts Teacher of the Year at https://Vimeo.com/172588398 
Led by Ms. Luz Ceballos and Advanced Digital Media students, "Hello FDA" enjoyed its 2nd season and one of our students, Daniella Rodriguez, FDA Class of 2017 was honored by Sade Baderinwa's GET REEL WITH YOUR DREAMS with a $10,000 scholarship for her PSA "Don't Litter" at https://vimeo.com/206235990
Harlem Vocal Ensemble students have performed around the country and in this year's Harlem SING! We expect to complete our modern chorus facility in 2018 and further develop the program with Mr. Darius Kennebrew, Program Director. Our Visual Arts and Dance programs include 2-year sequences.  We continued our partnerships with Aquila Theater, Sports and Arts in Schools Foundation, Spanish Dance Arts and Apollo Education at https://vimeo.com/216767798
See more at https://vimeo.com/205641783

Q42_R1_C1: Young People's Chorus of New York
Q44_1: Thurgood Marshall Academy offers music courses and visual arts courses to students in grades 6-12 taught by licensed teachers. In addition, Broadway Jrs. and the Young Peoples Chorus of NY provides theater, dance and choral instruction.

Q33_6: Applied web-based tools to develop a digital photography class
Q44_1: Music education at HSMSE includes a core music class for all sophomores and music elective classes such as guitar and chorus. Visual arts education at HSMSE includes a project based drafting class and art electives that require students to participate in school beautification projects. Also, students in the drafting classes accompanied their instructors to the CCNY School of Architecture to view various exhibits. Additional performance arts education includes a spring and winter talent show for students to share their various artistic talents.

Our renewed vision for the entire Duke Ellington School community  is to create an enduring and creative platform for all scholars to become visionary leaders that foster Ellington P.R.I.D.E by way of the performance arts. By modeling and teaching positivity, respect, integrity, determination and excellence via the performance arts platform, we as a school community aspire to provide opportunities for students to participate in a myriad of artistic endeavors so that they may become well rounded individuals who have an appreciation and a love for the arts. Our partnerships with Turn 2 Us, Midori & Friends, Vivid Imagination Program and the Shubert Theatre/Arts Connections grant, allow us to expand the minds of the children and connect the arts with their education. Furthermore The award winning Ellington Poet Society Spoken Word club at the school has become a staple in the community for theater performance arts.

P.S. 5: The Ellen Lurie School is the winner of the prestigious Leonore Annenberg School Fund for Children grant. In partnership with the Center for Arts Education, the grant allows for the planning and implementation of extensive music-integrated curricula for all students in grades PreK-5. Our goal is to encourage our students to use their imaginations to solve problems by nourishing their creative skills. We believe the arts provide entry points into Common Core Learning Standards-aligned curriculum for students and are a vehicle for students to build self-confidence by feeling successful in the classroom and can be a catalyst for increased student motivation and achievement. We are committed to hiring certified arts teachers to lead our arts programming, with a focus on visual arts. We strive to meet the NYS instructional time requirements. In order to allow learning within all four arts disciplines, we partner with cultural organizations, including the Center for Arts Education, Shen Wei Dance Arts, and Studio in a School. Through these partnerships, students not only reap the benefits of an enriched curriculum, but teachers also have the opportunity to grow professionally through planning and delivering instruction in cooperation with teaching artists, thereby expanding their capacity to integrate the arts throughout the school day for our students. P.S. 5 expands our arts offerings after school, through two select choral groups, xylophone ensemble, ELL visual arts / science program and a family arts program.

P.S. 8M aims to make arts education a significant part of our students’ experience alongside rigorous academic standards and instruction.  P.S. 8M encourages its students to participate in arts education through its programming in music and dance, and classroom art projects.  We offer dance, general music, instrumental music, and vocal music instruction to students at all levels in grades pre-K through 5th.  We produce a fully staged and costumed musical theater production with 3rd-5th graders each year.  Beginning in the fall of 2017, we will house a state-of-the art auditorium with new lights, curtains, sound, and A/V thanks to the DOE Arts & Special Projects Arts Space Grant we received this 2016-17 school year.  After school activities include modern band in which we explore a wide range of musical genres, including Latin jazz, punk rock, salsa, and popular music.  

We maintain instrument grant-based programming and equipment through Music and the Brain and Little Kids Rock.  In-house performances include monthly interactive jazz combos with The Jazz Foundation of America, and yearly interactive classical performances with the American Classical Orchestra.  Dance and movement are an important part of our arts curriculum with support from the Arnhold Organization in partnership with Together in Dance.

Q45_1: Our Middle school students engage in Urban Arts for visual arts aligned to Literacy units of study. Middle school students work with a resident artist with a focus on Social studies and Literacy. SEA theater works with our middle school after school program in writing and showcasing performances.

Q30_6: Music in the Brain (42nd street foundation)
Q44_1: Our goal at The Wright Brothers School is to provide well-rounded arts instruction to our students. To accomplish our goal, we have created a diverse arts program that serves as a creative forum for our students to support their individuality and cultures. Students participate in our visual arts instructional program and our Music and the Brain music literacy program. Our partnerships include The Guggenheim Museum, The Society of Educational Arts and the Sugar Hill Museum. We extend our students' appreciation of the arts through trips to MoMA, and New Victory Theater. Our annual multicultural celebration in June will highlight the various cultures represented in our school community, through research projects, exhibits and performances. Parents participate in art workshops and collaborate with their children in creating a masterpiece and dance classes.

In visual arts students are exposed to a curriculum-based program that helps them understand how material, technique and process are used to create works of art. Students understand how art has a variety of functions within historical and cultural contexts. Resources at the school, like iPads with museum Apps, help students become familiar with all kinds of art forms and hone their ability to observe and discuss their own artworks and the works of art of others. The program is enhanced with museum visits and a year-round calendar of exhibitions showcasing students' work. In theater, pre-k and kindergarten students activate and use their imagination through creative drama activities with storytelling components. First graders explore ensemble acting and memorization techniques through participatory stories that include folktales from different cultures. Second graders develop the actor’s instruments: voice, body and mind, while participating in play productions. Third and fourth graders engage in complex acting settings such as full-length rehearsals or scene work to explore theater making processes through various roles: the actor, the director, the designer, the spectator and the critic. Dual language students in fourth grade are trained in Jacques Lecoq’s Pantomime for Actors Technique which prepare them for the experimental theater course in fifth grade. Other fifth grade classes focus on acting or playwriting, and a specific theme or historic period such as Elizabethan Theater, Ancient Greek Theater and Musical Theater.
Q45_1:
PS 48M's Arts Education Mission Statement

Arts education at PS 48M plays a fundamental role in the individual and social-emotional developmental stages of children. We believe the arts develop self-expression; expand a child’s imagination, creativity, critical thinking, awareness and sensibility for other subjects, disciplines, traditions and cultures; foster global capacities; and improve academic achievement. Our arts education sequential learning focuses on a four-stage cycle: experiencing and understanding art-making processes, developing art-making skills as well as key character values, creating art works, and reflecting and responding to artists, their own work, and  the work of others. Through our program, led and taught by qualified arts teachers and supported by long-lasting partnerships with arts and cultural organizations, we strive to enrich the school environment by embedding arts and culture into the core curriculum.

Q44_1: I.S. 52 offers programs in music and art. Students receive three periods of art per week in their concentrated art area. This includes band, guitar, recorder class, African drumming, and fine art. Students participate in several performance venues around New York City as well as several performances throughout the school year within the school and local community. Presently we have the only marching band in District 06 Manhattan.
Q46_2: Technology Coordinator / Data Specialist / Art Liaison

Q44_1: We continue working with Little Kids Rock where students learn to play instruments and express thoughts and feelings on social issues through songs and poetry. Although we were not able to work with Urban Voices this year, it is our intention to work with them again during the 2017-2018 school year. Our affiliation with Rosie’s Theater Kids will continue next year. This program is a fusion of music and dance education for our fifth grade students. The students have the opportunity to attend a Broadway show, and participate in a culminating performance. The students also have the opportunity to attend a Broadway show, and participate in a culminating performance.

Q37_4: Assisting with preparation of arts events
Q44_1: There are three components to Dos Puentes Arts program: visual art, music and dance. Visual art is provided by Studio in a School and serves all our students weekly. Children work with a teaching artist in Spanish to learn sculpture, drawing, painting, and printing. This is extended into the classroom during our daily Exploration period. Children also receive music weekly. They learn to sing, drum, and use other percussion instruments. Second graders learn ukulele and third graders learned recorder. There are at least two musical/ dance performances a year. We have a full-time dance teacher who serves all our students 2xs a week. Students learn creative movement, cultural dances and how to collaborate around a presentation in Spanish. As a dual language Spanish/English school, language and culture are reinforced through the arts both in the classroom and in these specialty areas. All classrooms also participate in our New Victory Theater partnership seeing performances at the midtown theater. We are also fortunate that are after school program provides other enrichment opportunities through Chorus, “Just Dance”, Latin Dance, Zumba, and Capoeira.

Q42_R1_C2: The Conservatory of Music of Washington Heights
Q44_1: At PS 115, the vision and the goal of our arts program is to promote a positive learning environment for our students so that they can develop a life-long commitment to the arts. We encourage students and parents to view themselves as life-long-learners who are inspired by the arts and act as creative participants in our school community.  We have a curriculum aligned to our national common core standards which includes giving students opportunities to develop as artists and develop curiosity, critical and creative thinking skills as well as communicate effectively. We provide our students with experiences that strengthen their creative voices and that allow them to take risks and work both individually and in collaborative groups. In our program our students can embrace global awareness, personal responsibility, and artistic integrity. We use arts education to develop their imagination and to prepare our students to participate in meaningful ways in their own future communities, jobs and families. In an effort to enhance our learning environment and to provide our students with more opportunities, we have partnered up with The Washington Heights Music Conservatory. For next year, we are looking forward to continue expanding our music program and to include other arts disciplines as well.

The P. S. 128M arts program consists of a visual arts, dance, and music teacher, all of whom are licensed and provide critical insights for our students. Students are taught to make social, cultural, and historical connections through dance and art. They learn to connect creatively to other disciplines and to technology. They become life-long learners and advocates for the arts. Students are actively engaged with institutions, schools, community-based organizations, libraries, and artists that contribute to the cultural and economic strength of New York City. Students learn to apply knowledge and skills they learn in art class to assist them in interpreting the world around them.

The goal of P.S. 132's arts program is to integrate the arts into all content areas as well as to develop appreciation for the various art forms. We have partnered with the Music and the Brain program as a means of exposing our students to music theory starting at the kindergarten level. Currently our kindergarten through second grade students receive two periods of keyboard instruction each week. This practice has helped to develop the students' musical abilities as well as their fine motor skills. Our students in 3rd - 5th grade receive one period of music instruction per week. Starting in third grade, the instruction in music is connected to the content being covered in the units of studies by the classroom teachers. The other forms of art are addressed by the classroom teachers, visual arts teacher and cultural arts organizations, during the school day and after school.

Our 2016-2017 school's arts curriculum is based on the NYCDOE Blueprint for the Arts. We provide an Arts Literacy Proggram (ALP) that offers our students an intra-curricular arts based program that is instructed by the general arts specialist, social studies and English teachers. It is a biannual rotating program which affords our students the opportunity to study arts history and compare and analyze different world cultures.
We have classes in visual art, dance, instrumental and digital music.
Our goal is to continue providing our students with the utmost arts education through different modalities of the arts.

Q42_R1_C10: we have to reapply and be selecteed.
Q44_1: This year we worked with the Morgan Library Project to provide bookmaking workshops to our 5th graders. We partnered with Dancing Classrooms to provide Ballroom Dancing to 5th grade students. Students danced twice a week for a total of 18 sessions.  3rd grade students participated in Capoeira, a unique dance experience that incorporates martial arts, music and dance. Students danced once a week for a period of 10 weeks. In addition, we hired a part time music teacher and our PA has continued to provide funding for this program. All our students receive art instruction from our full-time arts teacher. We have a strong commitment to the arts and we believe that the arts are an integral part of a well-rounded education. We feel that developing arts’ literacy, vocabulary, and skills support learning across the curriculum. We hope to instill in our students a lifelong appreciation for the arts.

Art programming in its various forms at PS/IS 187 is a year-round process that promotes and fosters creativity, individuality while showcasing their talents and abilities.  Our students embrace the opportunity to learn and become well-rounded individuals by learning from not only our skilled faculty but from many outside providers such as City Kids, YANY, and Art Hoppers as well.

As we look towards the upcoming school year, we look to focus on the following goals: 

Instrumental Music: Continue increasing ability to play instruments by teaching the students music theory, appreciation, and presentation.  Students in grades 5-6 will show their growth by performing for an audience of their peers and parents/guardians, while students in grades 7-8 may chose to perform in the annual talent show. 

Vocal Music: Continue to create unique and original content that aligns to curriculum and addresses the social and emotional needs of students in grades K-4.  Students in the Elementary School will have the opportunity to perform  Students in grades 5-8 may continue to build their vocal abilities by participating in the Intermediate School Choir.    

Visual Art: Continue to introduce Art to students in grades K-8 by allowing them to express themselves through painting, sculpting and collage building.  Through a series of cycles, students in grades K-4 continue to build on their knowledge and skill set by working with outside providers.  Students in grades 5-8 will continue to work in tandem as they focus on digital media.

In order to provide our students with a strong foundation in the arts all students participate in music and art instruction. Together, these two programs support and enhance the classroom's learning environment by aligning the New York State Music and Art Standards, New York City BluePrint for Teaching and Learning in music and visual arts to the Common Core. We believe that music and art enriches and enhances individual learning, and promotes school-wide progress in the basic skills of thinking, listening, speaking, reading, and writing while supporting our students' social-emotional growth. Our arts program has several culminating performances/events each year such as the Winter Concert, Spring Concert, and Multicultural assembly. We provide our fifth grade students opportunity for special programming where students choose a specialty such as music, art, theater, dance, and sports. Our music program offers instruction in general music, steel drum band, string ensemble, recorder ensemble, and chorus. Our visual arts program integrates  Common Core content, enriching concept and knowledge, and exposing students to various forms of art forms and experimentation. This year we have extended our after school sketch club for grades third through fifth.The focus is to enhance student's observation skills and develop their drawing abilities.
Q45_1: Due to significant register loss our ability to fund and extend our arts programs was greatly impacted.

Q44_1:
Varied mediums of arts instruction, (Music, Dance, Theater, and Visual Arts), are introduced to our Pre-Kindergarten students and is taught by the Pre-K classroom teachers.  This year, students in one of our Pre-K classes Kindergarten and second grade students were provided with direct instruction in the area of visual arts through residency programs (The Sugar Hill Children's Museum for Pre-K; CAW for 2nd grade). PK - 5 students are also provided with general music instruction by the school based music teacher.  In PK-5 general music classes, accuracy, facility and clarity of sound are the primary indicators of the musical progress that students demonstrate at this stage of their music education.  
The following competencies are expected of all Jacob H. Schiff PS 192 students as a manifestation of their participation in general music: • Performance: singing and playing instruments (primarily keyboards) • Improvising and creating songs and accompaniments • Reading and writing simple rhythms and the musical alphabet • Listening and describing timbres, melody, rhythm, form and style • Understanding music in relation to history and culture.
All PK-5 students also have the opportunities and experiences to perform (singing, instrumentals) in our school-wide Winter and Spring Concerts.

The arts hold a prominent place at Hamilton Grange Middle School and for that reason we are committed to making the visual and digital arts, as well as music, dance and theater part of our regular school day and after school programming. Our commitment to the arts is twofold. One, we want students to find their passion while here at Hamilton Grange, and through it build the discipline and work ethic necessary to be successful in whatever endeavor they choose. Two, we know that training in the arts is beneficial to the whole child. For instance: sustained learning in music and theater correlates strongly with higher achievement in both math and reading, art studies and activities help keep high-risk dropout students to stay in school, new brain research shows that not only does music improve skills in math and reading, but it promotes creativity, social development, personality adjustment, and self-worth; and students who study art are 4 times more likely to be recognized for academic achievement and 3 times more likely to be awarded for school attendance. We look forward to working with you!

PI/IS 210, The Twenty-First Century Academy for Community Leadership, offers a rich and dynamic arts program that emphasizes music, visual art, and theater/dance. Students in grades PK-8 have weekly visual arts, music, and theater/dance classes. Middle school students have additional opportunities for arts instruction during elective periods. The school maintains relationships with the Theater Development Fund, the Museum of Modern Art, the Cloisters Museum, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and the Whitney Museum. Music offerings include piano ensemble, drumming ensemble, recorder ensemble, xylophone ensemble, and chorus. Art offerings include drawing, painting, clay (with a kiln in the school art department), and other media. Theater students study play-writing, acting, dance, technical theater, and present productions. Field trips to museums and other cultural organizations frequently supplement classroom instruction. Many opportunities for sharing arts products with the school community exist, such as concerts, graduation ceremonies and art displays in the school's hallways and display cases.
Q45_1: We are a dual language PK-8 school.

Q44_1: We launched our Arts program this year with the support of the F status Arts Teacher grant. Our inaugural program in Theater allowed us to integrate the arts into our students' school experience giving them ways not only to express themselves creatively, but also to explore technology in the arts as additional career options. In just a few months, our wonderful Theater teacher, Ms. May, was able to capitalize on students' intrinsic motivation and willingness to work hard in order to stage two performances for our school community.

Q37_4: Teaching enrichment group of first and second graders (School Wide Enrichment Model)
Q44_1: The Arts are prominently featured at The Paula Hedbavny School- PS/MS 278.  Through visual arts classes, students study fine art and basic elements of art. Our general music program offers keyboard, recorder and guitar instruction using curricula and methodology from Music and the Brain, Little Kids Rock and Carnegie Hall's Link Up! Program.  4th -8th graders can join the school band, 3rd graders -5th graders can join the violin ensemble and  4th-8th graders may join the chorus.  Through our partnership with the 92nd street Y we have creative dance classes for grades K-4 and a music series for grades 1,2, and 3.  Four of our classes partner with the Salvadori Center which enables students to learn about core subjects through the study of architecture.  Our school has a School-wide Enrichment Model program.  Students join faculty-led enrichment clusters, which meet weekly during the school day.  Many of our enrichment clusters have artistic components to them, such as musical theater, vocal training and fashion design.

All students in grades 6-12 have access to the arts. Grade 6 students take 5 periods of arts instruction each week. Grade 7 students are programmed for 5 periods of music per week. Students in grade 8 are programmed for either art or music. Students in grade 9 take either photography or drawing as their first college course through our partnership with City College of New York,CUNY. 10 grade student take FIWQS, a CCNY college course that links a writing class with either music, dance or visual art. Students in 10 grade may also choose to continue taking drawing or photography. Students who take courses at CCNY may also select courses such as: theater arts, stage combat, ballet, tai Chi. Also at the high school level, students may opt to take Capoiera as a physical education class.

The M.S. 319 Arts Program offers visual art and drama.The visual arts program is a sequential, three-year art curriculum (including drawing, painting, mixed-media and architecture) that is materials-based and developmentally appropriate. In response to Common Core Learning Standards, students are offered art classes that are geared towards preparing them for arts-related careers. Classes culminate with an art exhibition at the end of the year.  musical notation, the study of musical genres and history. 

Drama classes for 6th, 7th and 8th grade students covered ensemble building, improvisation, pantomime, scene study, Spoken Word, Shakespeare and his influence, and musical theatre. Each grade also visits Broadway as audience members. The year culminates with several classes participating in a school-wide performance for students and parents.

At the High School for Health Careers and Sciences, we offer a rigorous arts program. Currently we offer both Studio in Arts and Graphic Design as well as introductory music and theatre classes to students in grades 9-12. In our Studio Arts Class, students are given a foundation in the elements and principles of art. Students view, discuss and create paintings, drawings and mixed media art works. In Graphic Design, students are exposed to a Adobe System programs: PS6 and illustrator, as well as IMovie. In the music classes, students are provided opportunities to learn foundational skills in instrumental music including piano, guitar and drums. In the theatre class, students receive a literacy-based program where they are able to be exposed to and write their own original theatrical material and perform the pieces. In addition, students are given the opportunity to explore the arts in museums, view Broadway shows and to visit colleges with art programs.

Q42_R1_C10: We have music, dance and theatre with this program
Q44_1: Middle School 322 believes that a well rounded, educated student has exposure to the arts as well as academic courses. Through our partnership with groups like Urban Arts, students have been exposed to theater performances and dance recitals around New York City. Furthermore, our own in- school visual arts teacher, Anthony Vitale, has provided our students with unique arts experiences in the classroom, as well as exposing them to the many benefits of being an artist in New York City.

MS 324 provides a rigorous, Common Core State Standards based arts curriculum. It contains strong studio strands where students paint, draw, sing, act, dance, and play, as well as aesthetic education experiences that include learning about the art form in its context and in the world. Guided by the New York City Department of Education Curriculum Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts, students receive the unique arts experience of their New York City community. The curriculum focuses on five strands of instruction: Arts Making, Literacy in the Arts, Making Connections, Community and Cultural Resources and Careers and Lifelong Learning. Our goal is to give each student the opportunity to explore his or her creativity while integrating the arts across the content areas. For example, in our visual art curriculum, students make connections to math as they learn about spatial relationships in an artwork and the relationship of the elements of art to the work's creation.

Our students receive Arts instruction in all the disciplines. We stage several performances every year. Our Art teachers work with students during the regular school day and during after school programs. Our children go out to see Broadway shows, movies and visit the area museums. We also work with community organizations to provide Arts instruction.

During the current school year, we offered more visual arts programming and hired a teacher who is completing his certification in arts education.  The teacher taught arts classes three days/week.  We also continued to schedule theater arts sharing a part time theater teacher with another local middle school.  In addition, we began a relationship with the Alvin Ailey Dance Theater who ran an after school program two times/week.  Next year, in 2017-2016, we plan to continue these initiatives and to strengthen the visual arts component of our curriculum.  Another goal is for us to continue to strengthen the three year sequence of arts classes.  Finally, we will build "rigor" in the arts by developing more comprehensive arts assessments such as rubrics, peer assessments, timely teacher feedback to students, and performances.
Q45_1: Currently, CMSP 328 has 258 students enrolled including 80 students with disabilities and 140 ELL students.

Q44_1: PS 369's walls are decorated with an array of student artwork, showing the variety of artistic modalities learned and interpreted by our students. This year's partnership with Education Through Music and our various after school partners have enabled us to offer a more comprehensive arts program. We remain committed to offering all students both visual arts and music instruction during the school day. Our fifth grade students were provided the opportunity to study a instrument for a year through our new band program. This spring, the school will host both an art show and spring concert to showcase and celebrate our students' artistic expression. As part of our after school programming, our students are offered a wide array of enriching opportunities in the arts, including: theater, film-making, percussions, dance, capoeira and architecture. Our returning partners: Studio in a School and CCCADI, ensure that our students receive comprehensive arts instruction through our extended day programming.

Washington Heights Expeditionary Learning School (WHEELS) prepares all students for success in college and careers. WHEELS serves Pre-K through 2nd grade and 6th-12th grade students, and the arts play an integral role in the school curriculum. WHEELS offers classes as well as after-school programs in dance, theater, visual art, and music. The school has three bands spanning grades 6-12, general music classes for all students in 1st, 2nd, 6th and 7th grades, visual art classes for all students in 6th, 7th, 10th and 12th grades, movement classes for all Pre-K through 2nd grade students, and drama and musical theater club for high school students.
Q45_1: Our partnership with Manhattan School of Music involves band students (approximately 55) receiving weekly group lessons for about 20 weeks out of the school year. Additionally, Manhattan School of Music performed a concert and a musical theater production for 300 of our students. On average, our students had about 4 contact hours with Manhattan School of Music, with some students having as many as 21 hours and others having as little as 1 hour.

Q44_1: Our students in grades 6-8 receive fine arts instruction one period per week provided by a certified arts teacher on our staff. These same students participate 2 hours per week in a theater arts class provided by artists in residence of the People's Theatre Project during the SONYC (School's Out NYC) after school program. Every 8th grade student receives 10 hours per year of ballroom dance instruction from an artist in residence of the American Ballroom Dance Theater and 12 students continue regular ballroom dance practice as a competing dance team. In addition, 1/3 to 1/2 of our students select arts programs as part of our regular enrichment period curricula one period a week for the entire year. In these enrichment clubs, students are learning guitar, computer-based song-writing, visual arts and theater arts.
Q45_1: We serve the second highest percentage of low-income ELLs of all NYCDOE schools (K-12) and have a very high need for additional funding and support in the Arts.

Q44_1:
At the Hamilton Heights School (HHS), each year and every year in grades K - 5, all students study music two times a week and dance two times a week throughout the entire school year with full-time Certified Arts Teachers. Select classes study dance or music three times a week. The music program has a long standing relationship with Little Kids Rock and Carnegie Hall’s “Link Up” program and offers classroom instruction in recorder, guitar, keyboard, drums, auxiliary percussion, music appreciation, beginning sight-reading and vocals in a variety of genres. School-wide weekly sing-a-longs build community and offer opportunities to feature select students. The dance program offers students a creative movement curriculum where students learn dance concepts and are expected to use these concepts to create their own dance phrases. Additionally, students study various genres such as modern and ballroom dance. There are multiple opportunities for students to perform dance throughout the school year. HHS is a recipient of the  

2016-17 ArtsSpace Grant which provides sprung-wood floors,mirrors and barres. In 2015-16, dance students were selected to perform at the Manhattan Borough Arts Festival

At The High School for Excellence and Innovation  we offer a variety of art programs from Studio Art to Advanced Art to our students that are aligned with the New York State standards. Students that are interested in pursing an art career beyond High School have the opportunity to create a portfolio for college entry.

The 2016-2017 school year we partnered with Lincoln Center Educate and students were engaged in Arts through the content-area classes. For instance, the LCE teaching artist worked collaboratively with my Bilingual teachers, ICT teachers and Visual Art Teacher. During the series of in class teaching of the Arts students were expected to attend a LCE field trip. The partnership with LCE provided 2 Family Night performances where LCE artist comes to the school and perform for our families.

We have a full time Music Band teachers that works with my incoming sixth grade and the 7th and 8th grade that had band in 6th grade.

We also have Visual Arts being provided for students two times a week.

We also provide our students with digital arts classes once a week.
Q45_1:
We have a full time Music Band teachers that works with my incoming sixth grade and the 7th and 8th grade that had band in 6th grade.

We also have Visual Arts being provided for students two times a week.

We also provide our students with digital arts classes once a week.

Q44_1: The College Academy elevates students creatively and intellectually to express their ideas in visual and musical form and to perceive not only historical contexts but also how it relates to the dynamics of culture in community based art. The College Academy’s visual art courses range from art foundations to advanced level studio art. In art foundations, students learn how to draw from observation and apply basic level drawing and design skills from a large scope of art genres. If students have taken art foundations and wish to further expand their technique, they can take advanced level studio art. They will not only start to communicate personal ideas through their artwork but will participate in group critiques in which they discuss the artwork of their classmates and apply it to art history and culture. The goal in advanced art is to prepare students work professionally for future study of art after high school. Students will create a portfolio that requires them to think independently and develop their own artistic voice that will be presented at their final thesis show.
