Q37_4: participating in classroom based music workshops with students
Q44_1: Our goals remain as stated in the description 2015-2016. The music program continues the membership to the Little Kids Rock organization and monthly professional development sessions are attended by the music teacher. This organization has also added a drum set and additional PA equipment for use in the music room. Grades PreK-3 attended one in-house dance performance JMTW modern Dance company.  Two music concerts have been staged in the evening, a off site collaboration in a new musical performance is planned with El Taller Latino Workshop and two in house  art exhibitions during conference evenings.  Both Art and Music teachers continue to support the work of Inquiry based Project Time in the classroom.
Q45_1: We are co located in a building where shared space is difficult to come by for large school arts events such as the gym and auditorium.  Our School is a dual language school (spanish/English) and all classes are integrated special ed.

Q44_1: Our school's mission is to prepare our students to become life-long learners by providing an enriched environment that promotes academic rigor through a standards-based curriculum, while fostering a love, respect, and an appreciation for the arts. All of our students actively participate in a visual arts and dance program during the school day. In addition, there are numerous opportunities to participate in dance, music, and the arts during our after school hours through our rich collaborations with the Alvin Ailey Dance Theatre and Urban Arts Partnership.

We offer the music and art courses that are required for graduation. We also augment our arts programming through our after school
programs. Sound Business Institute is our CBO, and they run after school dance and step clubs at our school. This year Harlem Swings
donated their time to offer 2 hour, weekly classes to our students.

Gregorio Luperón High School for Science and Mathematics opened in 1994 as the first school in Washington Heights to serve newly arrived immigrant Latino students.  GLHS provides the avenue that enables students to explore the fields of science, technology, engineering and mathematics throughout four years of high school.  We prepare our students to achieve high standards of scholarship and equip them with the necessary skills to be successful in their college and professional careers.  We enforce strong community ties that allow our students to become successful leaders with integrity, solidarity and excellence.  Our music teacher is part of a community based organization called The Washington Heights Community Conservatory of Fine Arts which prepares children from the community to become masters of arts.
Q45_1:
Our music teacher is part of a community based organization called The Washington Heights Community Conservatory of Fine Arts which prepares our students to become masters of instruments and be part of an orchestra.  

Our art assistant is a volunteer worker from the community that prepares our students to become master artists and create unique pieces of art work.

We have two dance volunteers that teach our students choreography and Mambo classes.  

Our computer technician is developing a GEEK SQUAD of students to become knowledgeable in the audio/visual components of computers.

Q44_1: Our school offers arts education in four main areas: dance, drama, music, and visual arts. As in previous years, we have continued to expand our arts programs, thus increasing the number of students participating and being serviced at our school. We also expanded our parent program to include a dance class provided by our dance teacher, and our music teacher now has a Big Kids Rock Program where she instructs parents and students in playing guitar. We have also expanded our Bronx Arts Ensemble (BAE) program to include two additional performance where our students perform with professional musicians at the school and once in Van Courtlandt Park.

We offer a rigorous art program designed after top NYC arts schools. The students participate in a studio arts type curriculum based strongly on NYC common core standards as well as state and the NYC DOE's BluePrint arts criteria. The arts curriculum provided not only by the arts teachers, but also by the classroom teachers, helps provide a solid arts foundation. We promote the integration of the arts into our curriculum in all subject areas including math and science. Our students are exposed to various arts genres during classroom activities, residencies, and through the incorporation of trips to various cultural organizations. We are a school focused on college readiness and our arts program reflects our expectations as well goals for our students' futures.

Q42_R1_C1: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts

Q44_1: During the 2016-2017 school year, all students had the opportunity to engage in music education as an arts discipline.  Students arts experience were integrated with other disciplines and demonstrated through student learning outcomes in their performances and projects.

In order to educate the whole child, we offer a rigorous arts program, in addition to an academic one. We believe that arts instruction should build, within our students, an appreciation for arts in all form and encourage their creative mind. Our arts curricula is embedded into our academic instruction, incorporating music, visual arts, theater, and dance, via the lens of social studies. In every grade, pre-kindergarten through grade eight, students receive instrumental/vocal music, visual arts instruction, and/or dance instruction. We have two full-time visual art teachers, one full-time instrumental/vocal music teacher, and one full-time dance teacher. In order to even further deepen the exposure our students have to the arts in all forms, we partner with cultural organizations and use our amazing City of New York as a resource. As a school community, arts instruction is an extension of our belief in providing our students with a well-balanced educational experience in which they are exposed to the best we can offer.

The Wilton School continues to engage students and integrate the arts into the content areas. Our Arts Program consists of a Glee Club, upper-grades Dance Group and African Drumming. We also partner with Victory, Evoke and Galley in the performing arts, theater and dance to support our English language learners. Students are able to cultivate a deeper understanding of different cultures as they explore world music and other expressions of performing arts. We believe the Arts to be at the Core of our Curriculum, enhancing the potential of contiguous exploration of various mediums of self expression. As a school community our staff bans together in support of the arts. Due to budget constraints, several teachers volunteer of their time to man various art programs before and after school. We look forward in securing any grant monies available to expand our current art program to include visual art and musical programs for all students. We believe that the Arts help students to make basic connections between curriculum and practical text-to-self applications.We partnered with the Morgan Museum and Library’s Morgan Book Project. This project involves our upper grade students in the production of their own personal narratives in the literary genre of the illuminated manuscripts. The partnership involved guided tours to the Morgan where students learn how primary colors for the manuscripts were obtained, maintained such as in ink gardens and how we can duplicate similar methods today to obtain our own colors for illustrating.
Q45_1: In continuance of our embrace and provision of arts related programs and services to our student body we have formed a partnership with Manhattan’s Victory Theater, Galley Theater, The Morgan Museum and Evoke Arts LLC serving all grades. We also have teachers trained and implementing the Visual Thinking Strategies program. PS 30 continues to engage the entire student body via during a weekly Club Hour program featuring Visual Arts, Glee, Performing Arts, Book Making, Photography, Cheerleading and Dance programs. Teachers on every grade also prepare programs for monthly thematic assemblies via musical, choral and dramatic performances. The Arts continue to be at the center of our core curriculum. We will continue to form partnerships with cultural and community organizations that specialize in bringing the arts in their varying forms to all of our students as well as securing private funding to ensure the continuation of many of our programs.

Q42_R1_C1: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
Q44_1: PS 179 is a Prekindergarten to Grade 5 school. Our goal for our arts program is to provide all students with a variety of arts experiences. These experiences will help students to recognize how the arts play an integral part in their daily lives. All students visit museums to study exhibits connected to their visual arts curriculum, attend theater, learn about and perform music and choreograph and perform their own dances that are aligned with the social studies curriculum

Q42_R1_C1: Learning through an Expanded Arts Program
Q44_1: It is the goal of PS/MS 31 to integrate Arts into daily life of all students.  We presently have a visual arts and music class and moving into next year we plan on integrating the Arts through Technology program to further enhance the cultural lives of our students.  A sustained arts program is clearly tied into the success of a school and we strive through the arts to enhance the cultural lives of our students.

Our goal for the 2016-17 school year is to help our students become critical thinkers by using the arts in their academic and daily lives, making them college and career ready for the 21st century. The arts integrate and support all the core subject areas such as math, reading, social studies and science. We also used the arts to improve student motivation, self - esteem, cognitive skills and verbal skills through the different programs that we have in our school such as the Education Through Music, Anne Frank Center, and through our teachers who follow the Blueprint for the Arts. We have added to our repertoire of art programs, The Visual Thinking Strategies. This program is designed to expose students to different art work. The students connect to the art work and express their opinions and build social awareness. Our quest for the upcoming school year is to enhance and support our students' and teachers' knowledge of the arts.

P.S. 49 is committed to providing a well rounded, quality education and increased rigor for all students. The arts are an integral part of accomplishing that mission. A comprehensive education draws upon the expertise of both arts specialists and classroom teachers. It is our belief that the integration of arts throughout the curriculum areas serves to enhance and reinforce student learning as well as support the Common Core State Standards. It enables students to better organize, retain and explain information as well as understand the relationship between concepts and skills across curriculum areas. P.S. 49 is using standards-based curriculum to provide a comprehensive approach in educating students to critically evaluate the world and reflect on the common bonds between literature, the arts and sciences

Our school's arts program is aligned with the requirements dictated by the Blueprint for the Arts, Danielson’s Framework for Teaching, English Language Arts, and the Mathematical Common Core Standards. Our goals are to create high standards for each student in our school and create a school environment that strongly supports the arts as an essential substance for child development. Our goal is to provide rigorous standard-based arts instruction that will contribute to our students’ college readiness. Our students are introduced to and given all the tools necessary to perform on a keyboard, reading musical notes, learn about the history of music in America and around the World. Students’ performance culminates with our concerts and recitals throughout the school year. Students are encouraged to perform in multiple forms of art such as theater and dance. We will continue working closely with our nonprofit organization partners, Music and the Brain and the Afro Latin Jazz Academy.

At M.S. 151, the students will: develop an appreciation of, and confidence in, creative self-expression; have an awareness of global cultures and an exposure to diverse art forms; develop an understanding of the effects and use of technology in the field of visual arts, music and film; be given the opportunity to participate/engage in meaningful art experiences; be able to analyze and interpret artistic images using the appropriate language/vocabulary; create works of art on an appropriate level of artistic proficiency; become cognizant of career opportunities that are art-related. All these are in keeping with all the Learning Standards for the Arts in the intermediate level and the NYC Blueprints for Teaching and Learning in the Arts that provide a standards-based, rigorous approach to teaching the arts. The school's art program is also in alignment to The National Core Arts Standards to enable the arts providers to establish best practices across the education field that will best serve students while complementing national and state standards for education. They are also in alignment with one of the school's goals, which is to integrate literacy into all disciplines, including the arts, and integrate the arts into literacy instruction.
Q45_1: MS 151 has a population of 253 students, 23% of which are ENLs and 20% of which are students with special needs. The Arts serve as an effective entry into having communication skills and building self-esteem. Our school's participation and partnerships in the Arts are based on our instructional focus in communication (writing, more specifically) and the idea that teachers of all subjects can use artistic works/performances as springboards for discussing big ideas and concepts that make lasting impressions on students, teaching them life-long skills for arts appreciation.

Q44_1: The art department at P.S. 154x currently consists of a full-time visual arts teacher and a full-time dance teacher. Both teachers are certified and teach a full program. This year our Visual Arts teacher participated in the Astor Educator Fellowship with the Metropolitan Museum of Art.  She worked closely with a third grade class throughout the year.  The class engaged with art works through an intense questioning technique that explored Observations, Evidence, Inference and Interpretation.  Our arts program works together to provide two performances a year which incorporate set design, dance and/or theater. One of these performances is always a musical theatre production. We always have overwhelming attendance by the parents in our community. This year's musical was an elaborate production of The Wizard of OZ. P.S. 154 is entering its third year of a four year grant with Studio in a School. The Expanding the Frame (ETF) program serviced our 4th graders during the 2015 - 2016 school year and will service both 4th and 5th grade during the 2016 - 2017 school year. Through this collaboration, the students receive additional instruction through integration in their regular classroom instruction.  Studio in a School also holds 'Community Arts Nights' that engage our parents and community in art making.  For the third year in a row, Choate Rosemary Hall visited our school to engage selected classes in vocal/orchestral music.  The residency ended with a performance by the students for the entire school.

The art program at P.S.157 is based on the New York City Department of Education's Blueprint for Curricula in the Arts. Along with a determination to provide every child with a strong academic foundation, it is our belief that students should be nurtured in the visual and performing arts. Therefore, we offer our students art appreciation programs in music as well as visual art. We are convinced that our commitment, sincerity of purpose and dedication to the needs and interest of children, which includes the visual and performing arts, will enable us to provide an atmosphere saturated with enrichment and achievement that will prepare our students for the next steps in their educational and cultural journeys. In 2016-2017, our arts program emphasizes enrichment in music education for the early grades (PK-2), and in visual arts for the grade 3, 4, and 5. Most of the classroom teachers include visual art in their regular curriculum. We offer pull-out instructions for strings and Little Kids Rock (5th Grade rock band), and after school programs for chorus, tap dancing,ballet and visual arts in addition to other programs such as Oratory (Circle of Gold), Fitness Club, Basketball team, and Soccer.
Q45_1: In spite of budget cutbacks and other obstacles we at PS 157X believe that exposure to the arts is extremely important for all students and at all cost we continue to keep and provide our students with music, art and dance even though sometimes it is quite difficult due to the fact that we are not funded by any CBO and/or Arts Program.  We do this all ourselves because of our belief in our children's need for that exposure.

Q44_1:
Hiring a music teacher this year who had been an Arts Education Liaison for 7 years gave P.S. 161X not only a seasoned arts instructor but also one who was privy to the panoply of programs and grants offered by the Office of Arts and Special Programs and local community-based partnerships.  Our principal created space for arts professional development and interdepartmental inquiries to determine what resources were needed to bolster student learning and encourage student creativity.  

This year our school was awarded a grant to renovate our auditorium stage.  With new lighting and sound systems, students with cognitive, auditory, visual, and locomotor deficits will have new pathways to gain agency over their decision-making and have greater access to performances that would previously have been unavailable to them. 

In line with the school-wide instructional focus on reading this year, students in the music room have focused on music-making, particularly around literacy.  Using the Blueprint for the Arts and the Danielson Framework, this was implemented through student-led discussion, group ensemble playing, and language acquisition within reading music notation.  Experiential objectives have also been prioritized through arts field trips and in-house performances.

Next year we will be build an inquiry team with Lincoln Center Education to look into how the arts can bolster language acquisition among English Language Learning students.

South Bronx Preparatory (SBP) art program has an interdisciplinary focus geared toward self discovery and promoting identity awareness. This year the focus has included implementing common core as we continue to build literacy through the arts. This year SBP partnered with Lincoln Center Education to increase our arts in the middle school. The results were phenomenal! The partnership helped us: boost parental involvement, provide Family Nights at SBP with live performances, boost critical thinking skills and intellectual struggle inside the classrooms, implement a Capacity for Imaginative Thinking Focus: Notice Deeply, celebrate student work by showcasing student work in the hallway strategically and transition arts into the History classrooms.

The Laboratory School of Finance and Technology provides quality arts instruction for all of our student body. We expose our students to at least three art disciplines: orchestra and band for 6th grade, theater for 7th grade and visual art or dance for 8th grade. Our teachers continually strive to reinforce literacy skills as well as a true appreciation for the arts. We believe that the arts create a path to expression that might not have been an option to every student in our community. To create greater pride in their work, we have art celebrations, such as gallery showings, and culminating performances in music, dance and theater. We are proud to put on an annual production through Broadway Jr. and offer arts programming during expanded day and the summer. We also go out to attend performances and bring in performers to create young consumers of art.
Q45_1: We have an extensive summer program that is privately funded that is based on the arts.  Each student gets four hours of arts for 100 hours which is more than most schools provide in a year.  Music, dance, theater, visual arts, and media are all represented.  And we love our support from the DOE!

Q44_1:
Our school has a robust arts program we are always trying to improve.  We have full time visual arts teacher and a full time music teacher. Additionally we hire a dance consultant to work with each grade intensively for 6 week intervals.  We also have technology teacher that has a mixed media visual arts club in which students create a newspaper, documentaries and public service announcements.  

The sixth grade participates in visual arts for one semester and music for one semester, then they choose a major that they continue with for seventh and eighth grade. Our artists use pencil, charcoal, paints, paper sculpture and clay to create amazing artwork.   Our musicians learn keyboards and or guitar in addition to using their voice an instrument in chorus.  Our chorus was selected as a finalist to sing the National Anthem at Madison Square Garden. We also created our one school school borrowing the beat from an established song, but rewriting the words.    This is sung at every assembly.  

Understanding the need for our students to move more, we brought a dancer in to teach our students the magic of motion.  They using Body Action, Space, Time and Energy (BASTE) to choreograph their own dances.

HERO High School offers students a comprehensive range of arts electives: visual arts, music, and dance , which incorporate the NYS Learning Standards for the Arts, as well as support the socio-emotional growth of our students. After school programs include a visual art club, chorus, and The Cypher Hip Hop and Spoken Word Club.  Ninth grade students wrote and performed an original play at the NYC Student Shakespeare Festival.  This endeavor was assisted by the Creative Arts Team (CAT) workshops, comprised of ninth and tenth grade students, which meet twice a week after school at HERO.

M.S. 343 (7X343) has partnered with Creative Connections to provide a comprehensive arts program both during the school day and two days a week after school. The program consists of music, visual art, and dance. All three disciplines are taught by professional artists hired by Creative Connections. Two of the artists have worked with the school for over eight years building a strong rapport with both staff and students. Each student will receive a full year in each of the three disciplines, meaning that by the time they graduate from 8th grade they would have completed three comprehensive arts programs. The goal for this is to create awareness in different disciplines so that our students can make informed decisions about the arts in the future. The arts program is connected to the work being done in the other core classes to enhance both the enjoyment and their understanding of needed concepts and ideas.

The PS 277 school community is continuing to provide our students with arts instruction in a variety of ways. Through the generosity of the Change for Kids organization, our Pre K and Kindergarten students are still receiving music and movement instruction. We have an artist-in residence- program with Studio in a School, which  provides visual arts instruction to our students.  Different grades have worked with different medium, such as paint, clay/sculpture and collage. Additionally, our after school program offers multiple arts-based classes. Some of these classes have been funded with a grant from the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. We will continue to find ways to infuse the arts into our students' school lives, as we believe that arts instruction is an integral part of a child's primary education.
Q45_1:
Some of the arts-based activities that we would like to include here are ones that are offered to our students during after school.  These would be:
-African dance with a teaching artist from the Brooklyn Arts Council
-Theater with a teaching artist from the Brooklyn Arts Council
-Music/Band  provided by the Afro Latin Jazz Academy of Music
-Music/Band provided by an artist from Education Through  Music
-Choir provided by our school Music teacher
-Digital Photography- provided by a school staff member
-Stop Motion Photography provided by a school staff member
-Studio in a School also does an after school program with us.

Q44_1: We currently have two teachers for the arts.  A music teacher and a visual arts teacher.  Both are full time staff.

At the South Bronx Academy for Applied Media (SBAAM).  We strive to ensure that all scholars in grade 6-8 receive arts instruction annually. During the 2016-2017 academic year our arts program consisted of the following: Grade 6 scholars receive Visual Arts and Theater for the entire school year. Grade 7 scholars receive Visual Arts and Theater for the entire school year. Grade 8 scholars receive Visual Arts half of the school year and Theater the other half. As previously indicated, we also have partnerships with various cultural organizations who provided arts instruction during Extended Learning Time (ELS). Finally, scholars receive arts instruction during Elective periods 2 times per week.

With limited funding and resources, the Academy of Public Relations has implemented the following arts programs: Spoken Word,Hip-Hop/Step Dance, Video Journalism, and Visual Arts. Our after school programs included Mural Painting, African and Latin Dance and Drama. Through creative budgeting, we were able to provide Visual Arts and Theater to all of our students throughout the school year for the first time in 4 years. All subject area teachers are encouraged to incorporate art into their assignments and/or projects when applicable, as the school has purchased the necessary art supplies to support this. The students' artwork is proudly displayed throughout the hallways during the school year.

At International Community High School, the arts present an additional opportunity for recent immigrant teens to further develop social and academic English language skills. We partner with Bronx Arts Ensemble to provide the following classes twice a week: Ballroom Dance, Hip Hop, Yoga, Capoeira, and Karate. Yoga and Capoeira are also offered as after school activities. The dance and martial arts classes perform twice a year in December and May during a school-wide assembly in which we invite families and members of our community at large. Our 9th and 10th graders also participate in a studio art and theater classes during the school week. Advance studio arts students meet four times a week and participate in special arts events and trips throughout New York City. A few select students also attend our BLAST class, a weekly Saturday music program, offered in conjunction with ASPIRA of New York.

At CVES our goal is for scholars to gain knowledge of visual art concepts and design. Scholars will be able to identify principles of design in a range of visual disciplines. Additionally, scholars will be encouraged to discuss works of art and design using the content specific vocabulary of the discipline.

Our Overall Objective:
Our visual arts program is a critical and dynamic part of CVES and it encompasses an important role in our school culture. We strongly believe in exposing our children to the artists as well as to the artwork. We want our scholars to know what inspired the artist to create because we hope that it inspires our scholars to create as well.

We are making plans to apply for the ARTS grant and couple our efforts with a community ARTS provider in an effort to bring artistic diversity to our students in forms that are culturally relevant. As part of an initiative to expose our students to 21st century forms of ART, it is crucial to provide many forms of Digital ARTS opportunities related to Film, Desktop publishing and other forms of cyber art forms.

The visual arts program explores numerous dimensions of the visual arts, examines cultural, historical and personal reasons for making art and seeks ways in which the visual arts can be applied to and bring about positive outcomes in the realm of social justice. Students develop skills and techniques relevant to the visual arts and learn how to use a variety of methods and materials. Students learn to discuss, analyze and critique art in historical, cultural and personal contexts. CSSJ has a strong theatre collaboration with Manhattan Theatre Club (MTC) in which our theatre teacher co-plans and co-teaches a playwriting unit with a theatre educator from MTC. In addition to learning about acting, improvisation and studying plays of different genres, students in this program see a current Broadway show and write their own one-act plays which are performed by professional actors from MTC.

The art program at Mott Haven Village Preparatory High School incorporates movements in art history, famous artists from those movements, elements of art, and principles of design. Throughout the units of study, the students determine the importance in readings and complete numerous writing assignments including interpreting and analyzing artworks. The students participate in gallery walk activities and self/peer critiques. Our students produce work in areas such as but not limited to drawing, painting, and sculpture. Students produce a portfolio of completed work. They reflect on the progress made throughout the semester.

All students take music in 10th grade and are able to take an elective course in advanced music. In addition, students are offered painting, drawing and graphic art classes through CUNY. Students are also offered multiple opportunities to attend Broadway plays and musical concerts. There are a minimum of 6 performances for our school including 2 music concerts, 2 theatre performances and one spoken word performance. We provide interdisciplinary courses that include art and literacy (Yearbook and What is Art?). As a performance-based assessment school, most core classes also include an art component in the curriculum to ensure that students have various venues of expression and creativity.

Q37_4: attended a theater event with their children
Q44_1: As a 6th-12th grade secondary early college school, our arts program focuses on the visual and theater arts. We have an extensive, award-winning creative writing program that we use to fuel our drama program. We have many outside agencies providing arts support through in-school and after-school programs. In addition, our students take college classes in the arts. The emphasis is on pushing students to explore and reach beyond their preconceived limitations.
We currently offer blueprint reading and writing for students enrolled in our construction trades, and have an extensive architecture program for students enrolled in our Architecture program.

The Visual and Performing Arts Department at BLA II allows students the opportunity to express themselves creatively. Students enrolled in our visual arts classes are producing a diverse range of products: ceramics, graphic design, murals, and multi-media sculptures. Students can participate in at least one performance-based show before the end of each school year. These works of art and the stage performance are celebrated by students, their peers, and their families at our school's Annual Talent Show, Awards Night (BLA II Bonanza), and project specific exhibitions. Students may additionally participate in our after school session provided by our visual arts teacher in photography and pottery.

NEHS provides programs in Music, Visual Arts and Dance that cultivate our students' abilities to express their ideas, engage their community and create solutions through original artistic expression.  Students can begin to study an instrument or learn to speak more fluently with an instrument they already play.  Students have the opportunity to improvise with a variety of visual media and tools, and possibly use one genre of visual art to create a portfolio of work.  Our students also have the opportunity to create art and tell a story with their bodies as dancers and choreographers.  Our facility supports the growth of our students as artists with state of the art performance and practice spaces.

At the Urban Assembly School for Careers in Sports, all of our 9th Graders are required to take a visual art class. This class is taught by Mr. Alago - students do paintings, sketches and masks. Our students, 9-12, also have the opportunity to participate in other art related activities such as theatre presentations, spoken word evenings, as well as script and novel writing.

We offer visual art, dance, musical theater, dramatic theater, and mixed media courses to students in grades 6-12. Our arts sequence includes both introductory and advanced courses. Students in our arts courses exhibit their work in art shows, perform in dance and music concerts, host and contribute to gallery exhibitions, publish written works in our literary magazine, and perform in a full theater productions each year.

We have a certified Graphic arts program in our school. Additionally all 9th grade students take an art class. We offer dance, video making, and music production in after school programs through the 21st century grant

Q42_R1_C1: Learning through an Expanded Arts Program
Q44_1:
Health Opportunities High School provides students with the opportunity to take dance and art elective classes in their regular schedule. Theater is incorporated in the English classes and is taught by a LEAP guest artist teacher with rehearsals done after school. Students write and produce ten minutes plays and ten plays are selected and produce in school while the first place play is performed on Broadway where students as well as parents are given the opportunity to watch these performances. Liberty Partnership, a community based organization, works with the school to provide our students with the opportunity to participate in Digital Photography, Art Therapy and band.Students work are presented at an Art Exhibition at Hostos Community College as well as in our school's lobby area. 

Students have the opportunity to participate in music by joining the school choir who sings at school functions as well as off site functions.Each year the school hosts its annual fashion, talent and lip sync shows, which have students participating in modeling, dancing,poetry, drama and music. This year students had the opportunity to participate in fashion textile by creating and designing different outfits and accessories such as handbags , hats etc. Students participated in patchwork creation, embroidery, knitting, painting, drawing and designing. We are committed to developing students academically and giving them a solid foundation in art education which will prepare them for college and career and creating a well rounded individual.
Q45_1:
Our students are not expose to the arts in their home environment. Therefore it is our responsibility to provide them with the opportunity to experience the different forms of art and to encourage,  promote and foster a healthy art culture for our students. 

We do not have sufficient funds to provide a comprehensive art experience for our students. We would appreciate special funding that is designated only for the arts. However, we do try to provide art exposure for our students with the budget that we are given annually.

Q42_R1_C1: Learning through an Expanded Arts Program
Q44_1:
Senator John D. Calandra School’s arts programming is limited, due to budget constraints. In 2016-2017, the full time visual arts certified teacher taught 25 classes in grades K to 5 for 45 minutes once a week. Grade 3 received music through ArtsConnection. Leap provided theater, dance, music and visual arts for students in grades 1. 4th grade students studied dance with Dancing Classrooms. 5th grade students received theater instruction through Inside Broadway. Students attended trips that related to music, theater, visual arts and media. Our goal for the future is to increase our arts programming to create a more well-rounded arts education, if budgeting allows.

Spell Check

The arts teachers collaborated with classroom teachers to develop and to prepare performance programs based on curricular themes. Grade 5 wrote and performed an original drama from A Long Walk to Water. With the fable, The Fox, Grade 4 retold the story four ways, in ballad, drama, mime and movie. K shared Mother Goose classics. Grade 1 performed a musical about earth day. Grade 2 is preparing a poetry cafe and Grade 3 will stage a travel tour through the monthly cultures. Two students were featured in the Bronx Borough Festival exhibition. About 50% of the students have posted artwork to the Artsonio website, an online portfolio. In collaboration with the two ESL teachers, the art teacher organized a weekly after school club for ELL students. Through a grant, P.S.36 hired a teaching artist from the Bronx Dance Theatre for an after school dance program for grades K-5. Grades K and 1 follow the Music and the Brain keyboard curriculum. The fourth and fifth grade choruses performed in concert for their parents and peers. The art and music teachers served as facilitators in the planning and facilitating of meetings of professional learning in their respective mediums.

Our goal is to provide a safe haven where budding artists can explore their creativity in the various art forms in a creative and innovative environment. We have a band program for fifth graders and chorus for 4th and 5th grade. From kindergarten through fifth, every student receives complete music education, while visual arts education is provided for a portion of the population including Pre-kindergarten.  Our music program has ben nationally recognized.  Our music teacher, Ms. Melissa Salguero has been a semi-finalist for the Grammy music educator award and she was named one the 25 Bronx Influential Women.

The three art programs at our school are funded through the 21st Century grant. These programs include Ballet Hispanico, LEAP, and Stella Adler. Each of the programs are used to support the classes during the day to involve the students in different artistic expressions. Ballet Hispanico teaches the students dancing techniques, Stella Adler teaches the students to perform through voice and language control, and LEAP teaches support through acting and script writing. Ballet Hispanico is paired with Spanish classes at our school to maximize the efforts and goals for artistic projects that the students work on through the duration of the course. The LEAP and Stella Adler programs are paired with our English courses to support the students with their reading and writing. LEAP and Stella Adler also help the students maximize the efforts and goals for artistic project they have throughout the course. In each program the projects are decided and presented in collaboration with the teacher and the teaching artist in order to achieve the highest performance. The students work cooperatively to produce an artistic expression in the agreed upon style demonstrating their understanding of the art form. The use of these teaching programs strategies help students that are at different levels of English. Ballet Hispanico is helping students further Spanish Culture through the use of Dance. Stella Adler and the LEAP programs are supporting English and Art through written and oral presentations.

During the 2016-2017 school year, we provided two Visual Arts Cluster teachers so that all Pre-K -5 students could participate in Visual Arts. The students produced weekly projects.  The Visual Arts Teachers worked in collaboration with the classroom teachers to support the Core Knowledge and Expeditionary Curriculums. In addition to working with the classroom teachers, the Visual Arts teachers supported the Artist In Resident STARRS Program, and the Lincoln Center Residence Program. The students produced mosaics, watercolors, finger painting, scenery and customs for the Final Performances. 
Monthly Award Assemblies were held and 701 students had the opportunity to perform for their peers, teachers and parents during the school year. The First Graders worked with their classroom teachers and STARRS Artist In Residence on writing  original class plays, and presenting them.  The Second Grade worked with Lincoln Center Artists. Students had the opportunity to present their original plays and view the Nutcracker at Lincoln Center on 11/30 as a culminating activity. In addition, the students viewed "How the Turtle Got His Shell" by Shadow Box Performers.  During our yearly Spring Fling, all buddy classes a total of 555 students had the opportunity to participate in Mask Making, Moving to the Music, Yoga, Clay Making.  Instant Circus by Music for the Many performed for 701 students. Teacher, Parents, and Students viewed the P.S. 62 Art Museum were collections of student art work PK-5 was displayed.

Q42_R1_C1: Learning through an Expanded Arts Program
Q44_1: We provide arts integration within the Pre K - 5 curriculum. Both classroom teachers and certified art teacher provide experiences for students to use the arts as a catalyst for learning. Through collaboration and articulation, teachers create performance tasks cumulating in involving the multiple content disciplines. New opportunities from grant writing has allowed art to be a content area of learning in the after school program with Bronx Dance Theater. Students learn the dance steps for both ballet and jazz. Our many partnerships with other organization has helped us strengthen and maintain our focus on the arts. Organizations include: American Ballroom Dancing, NY Botanical Garden, Young People's Chorus, LEAP, Bronx Arts Ensemble and Ballet Hispanico.

Our school currently has one part time art teacher servicing students from K-5. Our students work on projects that are aligned with the CCLS in collaboration with classroom teachers. Our students have also had music integrated into the school curriculum through the Education through Music Program (ETM). Students in grades K-5 receive general music instruction. Grade 5 students have the option to participate in small group instrumental lessons and a school band. Grade 4 and 5 students can participate in a school chorus. The goal of ETM is to provide students with the opportunity to have music in school as it helps develop a well-rounded student. Grades 4 students participate in Dancing Classrooms where they learn social etiquette and the following dances: fox trot, tango, swing, salsa, merengue. Working in partnership with the OST afterschool program, Inside Broadway coordinates a theater program with an artist in residence.

Our school has teachers in music, visual arts and drama. All arts are taught through literacy. PK-5 are scheduled for visual arts. Music is provided K-4 by a dedicated music teacher. Our school participates in cultural arts field trips and programs such as Disney on Broadway and Lehman College Art Gallery. Our goal is to improve participation, technical knowledge and appreciation for the arts in every grade level. Our classroom teachers and residence artists complement arts education by including the arts in special projects and performances throughout the year. Our teachers' lessons are based on the standards set forth by the Blueprint for the Arts and the Common Core Standards. Funding is key in order to maintain and expand these programs. To this effect PS 75, the School for Research and Discovery will continue its fund raising efforts to support our students' exposure to field trips and the arts outside of our school.

Arts program is offered to all of our students.  Many different periods of Art History are covered as well as famous artists and their works.  West African Art has been incorporated with a literacy component.

At the Isaac Clason School, we recognize the importance of integrating arts instruction into all curricular areas in order to motivate students to take greater ownership of their learning. Many of our students participate in our winter musical and our spring choral concert. This year, we continued to participate in Little Kids Rock program which donated instruments to play modern band music. We also were granted with CASA/ Inside Broadway which allowed many children to perform and learn from an artist-in-residence. It also provided the school two opportunities to visit Broadway.

Q42_R1_C1: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts

Q44_1: We provide programs in Dance, Photography, film Production, Digital Arts, Cartooning, Guitar and Sound engineering (a new course).  One goal for Film Production and Sound Engineering is to prepare students to pass industry certifications exams.
Children receive art and music instruction.

Students of Mott Hall Community School are exposed to both Visual Arts and Instrumental Music as part of their weekly schedule. Most classes have art twice a week, and music twice a week. The courses focus on the NYC standards for the art, blueprint arts, and the Common Core Learning Standards. These include art and music making, literacy in the arts and careers and lifelong learning in the arts. Several times a year students visit cultural institutions and go on hands-on trips to broaden their culture in the arts. Student work is exhibited throughout the school year, and there are several musical performances each year, including talent shows, and performances for "Little Kids Rock." Students are taken on trips to visit arts high schools in seventh grade and are encouraged to audition form arts high schools. This year 2016-2017, 4 of our students made Arts High Schools. Our Exposure after school program meets daily from 3-6 pm and provides art enrichment to those who join. They work with film editing, music producing, dance, theater, graphic design, and visual arts as well.

P.S. 119's goal is to provide arts instruction that facilitates self-expression and builds community spirit. Students are offered opportunities in all of the arts during our regular school day, weekday after school program, Next Jump, and our Literacy Through the Arts Saturday Program. One full-time visual art teacher, Resident Artist in Dance, Music, and Visual Arts, Project Boost, field trips to art institutions provided opportunities to all students at PS 119. Smartboards enable teachers to integrate the arts and technology. Students take virtual tours of world-renowned museums, attend performances, and study great works of art in the classroom and through outside field trips. We celebrate our diverse cultures through the performing and visual arts with annual festivities such as Fall, Winter and Spring concerts, special Mother's Day musical celebration, and Father/Daughter Dance. Social studies instruction includes an appreciation of the arts in each of the civilizations and cultures studied. Our Science Fair showcases student work demonstrating a rigorous integration of science, technology, social studies and visual arts. This years science fair theme was New York City based. Relationships with Dancing Classrooms, Smartworks, Music for Many, and New-York Historical Society have evolved over the years to permeate teaching practices. In the coming year we will expand the Arts Program to include Theatre Arts,and Choral Music during the day and/or after school programs.

The music teacher did not return to P.S.119 this year to pursue his professional performance career. At the same time, the actual student enrollment was lower than projected and the budget did not support hiring a music teacher at that point.

The theater arts teacher returned the classroom to teaching 3rd grade. She was able to offer theater arts in our after-school program.

In years past, we had received grants from Studio in a School. This year however, we did not receive this financial support.

Q42_R1_C1: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts

Q44_1: Henry Hudson Intermediate School 125’s Visual Arts Course is designed to introduce the students to the basic elements and principles of design. Students will have an opportunity to develop their own creative potential through thoughtfully designed projects.They will be given art history and cultural instruction, including demonstrations and projects using various media to enhance aesthetic growth. The projects students undertake will provide a comprehensive series of experiences aimed at developing technical skills, fortifying an understanding of design, developing appropriate and fundamental art vocabulary and encouraging individual artistic expression. The goal for each art student is to create their best work and develop a true appreciation for the arts. When creating the interdisciplinary lessons, along with following the NYS Art Standards and the NYC DOE Arts Education Blueprint, ELA and Math CCLS were incorporated into the units to provide support to these departments.

The "Arts" contribute to our quality education.  It is an instrumental component that enriches the schools academic curriculum.  Here at P.S. 130 "Art" experiences are embedded into lessons presented by all our educators(Art and Non-Art).  Our Visual Arts Teacher regularly services 22 classes and on occasion three additional classes.  Our intention for next years "Arts" program is to continue the work paved this year and expand by collaborating with In-House Cultural partnerships and organizations.  Additionally, we would like to further encourage and expose our students and extended families to our cities great resources in the "Arts"- Visual, Music, Theater, and Dance.
Q45_1: We are a Title One school in the Bronx, New York, part of the public school system of the New York City Department of Education. Our students respond well to the four major art groups- Visual Arts, Theater, Music and Dance. It is found to be an awarding motivator stimulating our students imagination, intellect and interests, enabling the blend of academics and the Arts. We would like to broaden our outreach for donations and volunteers for success.  Our intention is to expand our Arts programs in the school. We welcome and thank our school family and the communities assistance in this endeavor.

Q44_1:
At IS 131, we have continued with our vision for the arts. We have established our three year program for our arts majors: Dance, Instrumental, and Fine Arts. All students select an arts major as 6th Graders and continue with their chosen major through the 8th Grade. Our students are offered an intensive program that develops their art skills, introduces them to art history and fosters a lifelong appreciation for the arts throughout each discipline.  Our staff members are available to work with any student who decides to apply to a high school that specializes in the arts by offering assistance with auditions and portfolios. Our halls are festooned with the artwork of our students and we conduct concerts throughout the year celebrating our dance and instrumental programs. 

At Albert Einstein Intermediate School 131, "WE CELEBRATE THE ARTS!!!

We have in class art lessons which art is incorporated across the curriculum. We presently are working with the Society of Educational Arts. We have had different assemblies programs that address different art disciplines. Grade performance that are done in the school.

The art experience @ P.S.140 is designed to enable each child to understand, appreciate and enjoy art in a non-threatening environment. Using the Blueprint For Teaching and Learning in Visual Arts as a guide for standards-based rigorous approach to nurturing interventions, we are constantly encouraging our students to take risks in order to reach their full potential.  Being cognizant that success is multi-faceted, we are always exposing our students to our ‘artist in resident’, museum trips,  ‘bringing the gallery to students’ and inviting parents to participate in in-house Art Exhibitions and Theatrical Performances. Our students also take ownership of our art endeavors by playing significant roles in decorating and advertising for celebrations and special events, and assist in curating in-house exhibitions.

We believe that our holistic approach will not only help to highlight the various art-related career opportunities available, but also to fosters a lasting appreciation for the arts, whether it be an artist, future audience, or a patron.

Visual art is integrated with literacy, social studies, and science for grades Pre-k-5 aligned with the Common Core Standards. Grades 4 and 5 students wrote poetry which helped to improve their writing and gave them a voice and builded their self-esteem. Fourth and fifth graders participated in poetry competition among schools in poetry slams and open mike at Lehman College. Grades K-3 and grades 3-5 special education students received dance and integrated it with theatre. For the fall and spring grades Pre-K-5 participated in a dance theatre performance.

Q42_R1_C1: Learning through an Expanded Arts Program
Q44_1: The Evergreen School's arts program is an integrated curriculum component in the daily life of our students. The curriculum is broken down into units by grade level. These units are based on the standards and benchmarks provided within the New York City Blueprint for the Arts. Additionally, all arts teachers are integrating the Core Curriculum Standards as well as New York State Arts Standards. Band is taught by a certified-band teachers. We value the arts in our school and believe that we are privileged to have these wonderful programs. We 're also blessed to have a very significant visual-arts program provided by Leap..that services the entirety of the school.

The school strives to provide high quality, comprehensive, sequential skills-based direct instruction to all K-5 students in the arts that enhances students' academic growth and general development. The school's arts programs address the five strands of arts learning: Arts Making; Literacy in the Arts; Making Connections; Community and Cultural Resources and Careers and Lifelong Learning. Instructional content is grade-specific and developmentally appropriate. The school has long lasting relationships with external arts organizations who help support the school's goal to provide students with a wide and deep arts education. Students are provided with multiple opportunities to perform and display their artistic talents for the school community during the school year.

This school year we were able to continue our music instruction on a full time basis. The goal for the 2017-2018 school year is to re-introduce the Music Unites Guitar and Choir Program.

Renaissance High School offers courses in vocal music, instrumental music, theater and visual art. RHS produces a variety of shows from straight plays to cabaret shows to fully staged musicals. RHS has a beginning and advanced band as well as a beginning and advanced choir. All of these performing arts classes perform at the Winter and Spring Concerts as well as many events throughout the local community and the greater New York City area.

Q44_1: Dunbar Middle School has a full time visual arts teacher, and teaching artists in other art disciplines provided by Lincoln Center Arts Education

At MS x302 the goal is to provide students with an art program during the regular school hours and that continues during the after-school hours. We have strengthened the work that the community based organizations provide in order to enrich the art programs.  This year's goals were to expose all seventh grade students to a percussion and keyboard program, and coding for students to create computer software applications.

Our school continues to provide visual arts to students in grades K-2 by a licensed fine arts teacher. Students in grades 3-5 get a variety of arts applications via our SEM Renzulli Cluster program. Music, dance and theater are offered to students by classroom teachers who have an interest or hobby related to the arts. Inside Broadway is a professional theater company that works with grades PreK-5. Each grade performs a culminating production based on a Broadway theme. Students learn the elements of theater (choreography, voice, acting) to give them a good foundation of how a Broadway production is put together. Next year we plan to expand this program to grades K-5. Also K-2 students receive instruction in percussion, music theory and note taking from a NYC Teaching Artist. Finally all our classroom teachers involve their students in the arts through monthly grade-wide assembly performances. Culminating projects often include visual, musical or video share- outs related to the topic of study. Students and teachers proudly display their work on bulletin boards throughout the building.

PS 392 the Bronx Delta School is a growing school of 210 students that provides the ARTS to all our students. The 2016-2017 school year was composed of PK, K, 1 and 2. The full time Gym teacher provides a gym period and a dance/movement period for all students each week. The students receive a full period of visual arts class and an art infused social/emotional class every week. The school has Education Through Music come in once a week and provides a full class of music for grades K-2. This year we had Town Hall complete 2 - 11 week residencies with the Kindergarten in Dance.
Studio in a school provided a 12 week residency with the first and second grade in visual arts. Studio in a school also completed a 8 week residency with kindergarten. New York Historical Society completed a 12 week residency with our PK focusing on Art History.
As a school community, we have a Winter Arts Festival and a Spring Arts Festival that showcases music, dance/movement, and visual arts. Town Hall presented dance to families as well as performances by Marquis Studio, Bronx Arts Ensemble, and a .
Students go on at least 6 field trips a year that are ARTS based. 
Marquis Studio completed a theater based residency with percussion for our first and second grade students in an after school setting. Marquis Studio completed a 6 week residency with our kindergarten students in theater in an after school setting. 
Bronx Arts Ensemble provided a theater and music based residency for 15 weeks for our first and second graders in an after school setting.
Q45_1: Bronx Delta School is a Schoolwide Enrichment Model school that offers Enrichment Clusters to students. In the 2016-2017 school year, we began the program with our first and second graders.

Q44_1: Pablo Neruda Academy is committed to providing students with the social, academic, and cultural currency required to be a productive citizen. Through the dedicated work of two full-time art teachers, a full-time media arts teacher, and partnerships with two Community Based Organizations (The Leadership Program and Educational Alchemy), we are able to provide all of our students with experiences in the arts, in and outside of the classroom.

Q44_1: MILLENNIUM ART ACADEMY HIGH SCHOOL OFFERS REQUIRED ART STUDIO IN BOTH THE 9TH AND 10TH GRADE. THE STUDIO COURSES FOLLOW A SEQUENCE, BEGINNING WITH FOUNDATION. OUR STUDENTS ATTEND ARTS PROGRAMS OUTSIDE THE BUILDING AS WELL, STUDYING PHOTOGRAPHY, FILM AND OTHER ART FORMS.  OUR STUDENTS RECEIVE SCHOLARSHIPS TO ATTEND SUCH PROGRAMS.
