Q44_1: We have a robust arts program that includes a plethora of courses and opportunities in all arts disciplines.

Pelham Lab High School offers an interdisciplinary program in the arts with an emphasis on theater and the visual arts. Visual Arts is connected with the ELA curriculum and includes focused courses as well as regular collaborations with arts organizations and visiting artists who push into the ELA classes. Additionally, our visual arts classes include an emphasis on painting and drawing with a focus on self-expression and thematic expression.

The arts program at HLR provides student with an overview of the visual arts, including the: concepts, techniques, history, materials, and understanding of how artist and society have used art to express ideas, opinions and experiences. Students also gain an understanding of their own artworks, reviewing works by their peers and understanding historical cultural and social movements. Students will use both digital (computer, cameras) and traditional art making methods (painting, drawing, sculpture).

PS 333 2016/2017 arts program was aligned to the principal's writing goals. Exhibitions included the science fair, student set design for performances and class bulletin boards. Students brought learning to life via student performances such as Black History month, Holiday Cultural Show and Student Pep Rally for the state tests. Museum Night was not implemented this year as the school's annual exhibition. Visual arts instruction was also aligned to student math & ELA standards to support students during the state test. During parent engagement the art teacher offered workshops for parents and students. The arts program received the $1,000 from the city funding. For next year 2017/2018 arts program if federal and city funding is provided then we might consider using Mindup.org a behavior intervention plan can be used to support student emotional and behavioral growth through self reflection & meditation. We can have student performances by theme or month with a live band and residency to accompany the student's performance. We will continue to hold parent workshops during parent engagement. There might be performances during open school night. We might hold a career day and have 3-5 interview presenters. We could hold a large whole school exhibition by theme in  both courtyards.
Q45_1: We are a title 1 school in Hunts Point in the Bronx. It is one of the poorest boroughs in NYC but students are within one of the most culturally diverse environment where the arts are abundant. The Bronx is a beacon of the arts such as music innovations which have brightened the world. Our school is consolidating and will become one school. PS 333 & PS 335 will become The Longwood Academy of Discovery for the 2017/2018 school yard. We have also  will also have Hard of Hearing and Deaf students from HES in District 75.  We have many ELL students of various languages which benefit from our arts program. Since we are consolidating the federal and city funds could be combined and used to bring our students more exposure to the arts via field trips, assemblies, residencies, onsite collaborations with arts organizations and student performances/exhibitions.

Q44_1: The Arts Program at P.S. 335 is driven and inspired by the New York City Social Studies Passport Curriculum and Common Core Learning Standards. We employ a full time visual arts teacher who integrates Pre-Kindergarten-5th grade social studies content into all lessons and art activities. We also maintain relationships with arts organizations that allow our students to express themselves as performers. Our goal is to provide students with a sequential projects-based art education that incorporates the Visual Arts Benchmarks and Standards from the New York City Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts. Through the arts, our students are learning to be self-motivated workers and creative thinkers.

Schuylerville Preparatory High School hired a second Visual Arts teacher in order to offer more art classes, as well as electives. Electives in the arts that were offered were graphic design (using an online program), mixed media, art history and drama. The art history class was focused to help reinforce the global history content. Students also took a vital row in beautifying their school by creating murals after school, on the weekends and over breaks.

Students are exposed to ballroom dancing in the 6th grade and Latin dancing in the 7th grade (for a quarter, as part of their physical education). Students in 9th grade also spend one quarter with Latin dance as part of their physical education program. We have a Cheer Stunt Team and an after-school dance club provided through our Dance teacher.  Through an Arts Matters Grant we were able to bring on a Theater and Dance teacher shared with another school so that we could offer all 4 Arts disciplines.  Students spend 1 quarter in each of the 4 Arts disciplines (Art, Music, Dance and Theater)in the 6th grade.  This year we allowed our 7th and 8th graders to choose one Arts discipline for the fall term and our HS students were offered choices in the spring term.  Due to constraints of the grant regarding scheduling we will not be able to offer choices among the 4 but will instead be able to provide a mini course of 2 each in 7th and 8th grade and a mini course of 2 each in the 10th and 12th grades

During their middle school years scholars will have a host of opportunities in the Arts.  All sixth graders will receive a full year of Visual Arts and will work with such outside partners as LeAp and Lincoln Center.  Seventh graders will receive music and theater instruction and learn to ballroom dance in the spring through a partnership with Dancing Classrooms.  In the 8th grade scholars will continue their theater instruction and be able to take Art electives such as Web Design, Computer Programming, Visual Arts, and can learn how to DJ.  Additionally, we have an after school theatre program which allows scholars the opportunity to experience all aspects of theater from acting, to set design, to lighting, costumes and music

Our school has 1 teacher that teaches Visual Arts to all students in our school. One day per week we plan to have a F-status Visual Arts teacher that provides direct Arts instruction to students one day per week. Community based organizations offer dance and STEP.

All students at Bronx Community High School are required to take two arts classes during the course of their high school education to graduate. The courses focus on the NYC Standards, the Blueprint for the Arts and CCLS. In the Visual Arts, these include art making, the historical/cultural context of the arts, literacy in the arts and career and lifelong learning in the arts. There is an emphasis on art making and the exploration of materials in each class. During class students work towards mastery of media and a strong conceptual base for the value of arts in education and as a vehicle for student voice in a community. In Dance, these courses include dance making, developing dance literacy, making connections, working with community and cultural resources, and exploring careers and lifelong learning. Several times per year students are provided the opportunity to visit cultural organizations around the city and, when possible, outside artists/professionals are brought in to classes to teach and discuss about careers in the arts. We offer our students a variety of courses such as Urban Art, Design it Yourself (DIY), Printmaking, 3-Design, Art & Design, Art for Change, etc.

The Hunts Point School, in alignment with district 8 goals of providing access and equity to our young people, has established an Art program giving students choices to develop and showcase their creativity. The school currently offers, music, dance, visual arts, graphic design and theater through regularly schedule classes, after school programs and partnerships.

Students are exposed to a visual arts curriculum that is aligned with ELA and Global History. The students create artworks using multiple medias and techniques. The program has allowed for students to display their work in the school and a more formal display during parent-teacher conferences. Students have created murals to beautify and engage the community.

The arts program here at Soundview Academy for Culture and Scholarship is one of the most unique and comprehensive arts programs in the entire city of New York. With courses in theater, visual art, dance and music, our students are being exposed to contemporary art forms that enhance their academic, social, and cultural evolutions. Every art challenge the students are given will ask them to express their thoughts, feelings, and personal experiences in response to a larger idea. Students are currently being engaged in our program with activities that will allow them to discover things about themselves, their classmates, and master artists

We partner with Educational Alchemy to provide an hour a day of arts to our 9th graders, with a multi- disciplinary approach. Our 10th-12th graders create a semester long art project in conjunction with their semester long internship project.
Q45_1: Our school is an internship based school; our students participate in internships two days a week, and build an internship project around their experience.

Q44_1: The only arts that are currently at this school is a visual arts drawing and painting class. In addition we have an after-school program with Educational Alchemy who provides dance and spoken word to students once a week.

Our school offers beginner and advanced Art, photography, web design, digital and mixed media, audio engineering. Our visual arts courses require students to paint, draw, sketch sculpt, and take artistic risks. Students participate in two art shows where their parents were invited to attend. In addition students art work is entered into contest and local art festivals. The goal of the art program is to provide students with an introduction to art materials and vocabulary, exposure to art history and an understanding how to "read" an artwork. Students interested in pursuing a career in the arts are provided assistance in portfolio development. During the 2017-18 school year, we will offer an Advanced Placement course is Art Studio 2-D.

Our art program is in the budding stage. We brought on a new art teacher and she has been able to infuse visual arts across the disciplines and has created some amazing art projects with students. One project was featured at the Bronx Museum of the Arts!

The Westchester Square Academy Arts track has been created to give our students a well-rounded education that allow them the room to express themselves through movement and visual arts. Students will be afforded the opportunity to accrue credits toward graduation and develop a professional resume in dance or visual arts.
This year freshman and seniors took a full year of art

Our arts program aims to give students exposure to dance and the visual arts through student interest-based concentrations. We aim for students to experience a multi-year program in the various genres of dance and diverse styles of visual arts. This includes experience through direct instruction in their concentration area, performance and observation in various venues. Students present their work three times per year during our Intersession Presentations. In addition, they create portfolios that showcase their development in their selected concentration area over three years.
Q45_1: We have been part of the Arts Matter Program for visual arts over the past 3 years. We will exit that program next year and no longer receive program resources. Being part of the program has helped us to initiate our visual arts program, which students have excitedly participated in through scheduled classes and our after school art club. We have had students show their work in the Borough Arts Festival over the past 2 years. We intended to also offer dance instruction, but have been unable to hire a dance teacher. We would love to continue the program for dance and seek additional support in growing our arts program.

Q33_6: Pre K Create Office of Early Childhood Education
Q44_1: PS/MS 4 is committed to create a culture of self reflective scholars who use learning opportunities to develop a global awareness of the world to include the arts. The mission of PS/MS 4 is to devise and implement a comprehensive educational program to encompass the arts in order to provide a holistic educational experience that teaches the whole child.

Our School Art’s Program for the fiscal year 2016-2017 comprises of the following:  

Teachers & Writers
During a T&W writing program, students come to think of themselves as writers. Most T&W workshops begin with students reading and discussing the work of contemporary and classic writers. Through these activities, students learn literary elements and techniques that they are then asked to use in their own creative writing—guided by a writing prompt assigned by the T&W writer. At the end of most T&W programs, students work with the writer to revise their work, which T&W publishes in an anthology and culminates at a celebrating event.

Studio in a School
The Studio in a School Residency Program is another program that is partners with us again this year. This community-based organizations offers customized art instruction for our students and caters for their particular needs. Residencies help our second through fourth grade students to build their foundational art skills and develop 21st century skills of communication and problem solving.

Creative Arts Team (CAT)

This is a Literacy through Drama (LTD) program which is new to us this year. Through this program, our students are exposed to drama.  In doing so, our participants are provided opportunities to explore social and academic literacy.

Q42_R1_C1: Learning through an Expanded Arts Program
Q44_1:
Jordan L. Mott Junior High School (09X022) believes that the arts are an important component of adolescent development. Two additional
arts teachers to create a continuum of experiences for all students. Our 6th graders have Theater Arts 2 times per week. Our 7th graders have Visual Arts 2 times per week and our 8th graders receive intruction in digital and multi-media arts 2 times per week. These experiences give students exposure to different media and better equip them to choose electives, before and after school arts clubs, and high schools. Our school marching band includes multiple instrumental sections and a color guard. Our visual arts teacher has transformed the visual landscape of our building and prepared our 8th graders for high school auditions. We partner with Learning through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP) who provides job-embedded professional development to our content faculty on strategies to infuse the arts into content area disciplines. LEAP also engages our students in after-school activities such as fashion, violin,
hip hop dance, drumming, and spoken word.

C.I.S 303 offers 45 minute art classes on a daily basis to 6th, 7th, and 8th grade students, for the duration of one marking period per year.  The art program follows the Blueprint for the Visual Arts Benchmarks outlined for specific grades and the Danielson's Framework for Teaching. Classes are designed to develop drawing, observation and analytical skills using varied media and the application of the Elements of Art. Units begin with classwork based on practice activities and progress to applications of techniques in hands-on projects. Works by renowned artists are introduced and end projects include the creation of original artwork. The goal of the art program is to teach skills that enable students to make connections across content areas and engage in self-expression. Students who demonstrate strong artistic potential and interest, are encouraged to pursue portfolio preparation for specialized high schools auditions. In addition after-school programs such as City Year help reinforce participation in the Visual Arts.

Our school is committed to providing students with a CCLS aligned, rigorous approach to teaching the arts both through a school based visual arts teacher as well as through cultural partnerships. We hope to enrich all of our students experiences in the arts including our students with special needs as well as our English Language Learners (ELLs). Students with special needs should be stimulated artistically, intellectually and imaginatively, as should all students. We hope to further support our ELL students by using the same effective instructional commopents employed within our learning environments such as clear objectives, scaffolded learning,differentiated instruction and opportunites for problem solving and expressive responses. These strategies would be appropriate for all students, reinforcing content and learing as well as provide opportunities for collaboration.

P.S.35X is a staunch supporter and proponent of arts instruction. We believe "The arts have a power to deepen and extend our understanding of ourselves and the world"(Carr 2005). Educational research indicates studying the arts cultivates essential qualities students need to succeed in the 21st century. The arts promote creativity, cooperation, communication, cultural understanding and problem-solving. Learning in the arts nurtures active engagement, disciplined and sustained attention, persistence and risk taking. Arts education also increases attendance and educational aspirations. Our commitment to college and career readiness includes instruction in the arts disciplines: dance, theatre, music, art, and visual/graphic art (technology). Students in grades K-2 receive arts instruction across all areas and specialize in 3rd, 4th and 5th grades. Culminating projects are the expectation to show what students have learned.

Our goal is to provide all children with a well-rounded education. That entitlement requires introduction to, understanding of, and appreciation for the arts. The arts are an avenue to understanding our history and ourselves. Our goal is to increase the exposure of our students to the arts, giving students performance opportunities which will lead to increased listening, speaking, and motor skills. Additionally, by providing students with these experiences, they are also given the opportunity to find a talent within themselves.

PS 204X partners with cultural organizations to provide standards-based instruction in the arts. Dancing Classrooms provides instruction in ballroom dancing to students in grades 4 and 5. A full time music teacher provides music instruction to all of the students in the school. Students sing, dance, move, and play along with traditional songs from many cultures. The program integrates instruction on a variety of instruments (guitar, piano, drums, recorders, etc.) Studio-in-a-School provides visual arts instruction for all students. Residencies include instruction in two and three dimensional explorations using various art media. Art exhibitions allow students to present their work to the public. A Disney Musical Grant offers students the opportunity to participate in producing a Disney musical theater program. This year, the students performed Willy Wonka. Marquis Studios provides a parent child programs for students in the primary grades. Students learned the art of circus performance. book making, and the art of collage. Students regularly participate in field trips to New York's world-renowned museums.
The following are the arts programs in out schol: Bronx Children's Museum- Visual Arts, SCAN of New York- Dance and Visual Arts, New York Pops- Vocal and Drama, and Disney Musicals.
Q45_1: We want to make our arts programs strong. The challenge is always finding qualified and highly effective arts teachers to work in our school.

Q44_1: We believe in the arts across the curriculum at Public School 58. Our students have the opportunity to participate in visual, dance theater and vocal music. We believe in finding the talents of the whole child and celebrating the arts in performance, art shows, and competitions. We collaborate with The New York Twirling Organization, SEA, Bronx Arts and MOMA to support our students.

One of the biggest goals of the visual art program at our school is to make connections between the visual arts and other academic areas for interdisciplinary learning. In addition, we strive to give students the knowledge and skills they need to use art as a way to interpret and portray the world around them. We launched a music program this year. We provide sequential music instruction with students working towards music literacy. We have established a pattern of 2 concerts per term for students with additional opportunity for performances at special events and assemblies. This year we began beginning guitar instruction with a goal of working towards offering modern band instruction.
Q45_1: We are on a cluster schedule. In this schedule, each student receives daily instruction in Art and in Music for approximately six weeks, one time per year (sometimes the duration of the cycle varies.) We also cycle with Math enrichment, Technology, Physical Education, and Science Enrichment. Six-week sessions present some advantages as well as some challenges. The learning curve is quite high for students receiving instruction on consecutive days; this schedule is conducive to project-based learning. Challenges include being able to track student progress over the duration of an entire school year.

Q44_1: Involvement in the arts is associated with gains in academics. Arts learning can also improve motivation, concentration, confidence, and teamwork. Our Bronx Arts Education program enables our children to have a more level playing field with children who have had enrichment experiences in the Arts. Comprehensive, innovative arts initiatives continue to take root in our school. P.S. 73 fosters the use of the arts as a learning tool by incorporating arts into our daily programs, creating a school environment rich in arts and culture and hands-on arts instruction. Through various grants, our students have been afforded the opportunity to learn how to play the Recorder and Guitar. Our third year music instructor continues to flourish us with new innovative ideas to strengthen and increase the growth of music education. The After-School program, SCAN has supported us in financing to establish a Drama Club. The revitalized ‘state of the Art’ auditorium has been put to good use re-establishing school concerts. for example we partnered with Jazz at Lincoln Center and had three concerts for our students through there jazz for young people program. We also took a group of students to two live performances at Jazz at Lincoln Center in Manhattan. Our parents continue to be pleasantly surprised at the talent we have discovered since improving our Arts programs. We will continue to grow and strengthen our Visual and Music Arts Program next year and in the years to come.

Our goal is to involve our students in a variety of creative, artistic, and imaginative experiences which will enhance self-esteem, problem-solving skills, aptitude, concentration, and listening skills. We try to develop in our students an understanding and appreciation of an art form through participation in an art residency program. We provide the instrument for the integration of the arts with the core curriculum.

PS109 believes it is important to cultivate students' interests and talents in the arts. Therefore, with two full-time visual arts teacher, and collaborations with Disney Musicals  students are immersed in the artistic process. Furthermore, PS109x hired a full time theater teacher this year to provide students with more exposure to performing arts.   This year PS109 will have its annual art show with 100% student participation.There will be an evening showing for parents and local community members. We have also hosted an anti-bullying performance.  Students in grades 2-5, danced, sang, and acted out various scenes and songs that demonstrate the importance of being an up-stander.  The art teachers at PS109 have been involved in several professional development workshops this year including inquiry work that explores how formative assessment increases learning in the arts. This year PS 109 will perform our fourth school musical, Annie,  that is the culmination of weeks of intensive instruction in musical theater and set design.

Our art appreciation program addresses the arts standards aligned with New York State performance indicators. Units of study are developed and implemented using the Department of Education's Blueprints. Classroom teachers focus on providing a well-balanced art program using a variety of media. This program enhances content area initiatives, especially in the reading and writing programs, through grade level unit planning. A music teacher supports both vocal and instrumental music programs for all students. The art teacher provides both art history and visual art programs for all students. Art, dance and music clubs provide enrichment opportunities for our students. Theater programs allow students to express themselves in the form of drama in their classrooms and in monthly assemblies. Readers Theater enhances our literacy curriculum.
This year we added a full-time Dance teacher to incorporate movement and physical performance arts into our curriculum. We are also planning Fashion/Talent shows to showcase our students' abilities.

At P.S. 114. we are proud to say that the learning extends far beyond the borders of the classroom. P.S.114X envisions providing the students, parents and staff with opportunities to participate in drama, music, art and cultural activities that are age and grade appropriate. We hope to continue getting the services of outside professional artists who will conduct hands-on class workshops and on stage performances for the students. Finances have become a huge barrier to our goals. We hope that our goals become reality with funding for the Arts. We envision having celebrations in which the community is invited, showing the visual and performing arts, such as stage performances and arts fairs. The students can display their creativity through video, computer, musical and artistic displays. We would like to encourage and bring out the talent within our students and love for the Arts. This year we were successful in having more parent engagement activities which brought our families together to celebrate the Arts. Next year we hope to extend this more and bring more members of our community into our school.
Q45_1: Our school is an inner city Title 1 school where almost all of our learners receive free lunches. New York City is our community and the Arts bring out the opportunity for the learners to experience this and bring out their talents.

Q44_1:
The Joseph H. Wade arts program consists of opportunities for instruction in dance and visual arts for all grades (6-8 including
ELLs and SWDs). The dance program is led by Ms. Lyndel Bernard and the visual arts program  is led by My. Lowell Wynn. Every effort is made for all students to participate in all programs prior to graduation. We have partnered with ENACT, that provides additional
support to our students in theater performances on and off site. The entire school community gets the opportunity to witness fine dance work through culminating performances during the Back to School Showcase for parents and students, as well as Christmas holiday, February, May and June performances.

The arts program at PS 126 provides instruction in visual arts and music (specifically keyboard). Additional extra-curricular activities
include school wide chorus, Keys2success, holiday presentations, and spring concert.

Our school has studied and implemented the Schoolwide Enrichment Model for the past seven years, sending teachers to study the model at professional development sessions during the year and at the summer Confratute session sponsored by the University of Connecticut. As part of our implementation of this model, our students and teachers have enrichment clusters incorporated into their weekly program. These enrichment clusters are organized into cycles that rotate every 10-12 weeks throughout the year, and all of our students have the opportunity to register for the cluster of their choice. Our enrichment clusters are devoted to skills such as culinary arts, theater, chorus, rock band, recorder music, and website design. In addition to our co-curricular enrichment clusters, our students also have opportunities to participate in arts programs after school. These offerings include MH3 Rock Band, Dance Team, Chorus, and various sports.

Q42_R1_C1: Learning through an Expanded Arts Program
Q44_1: We seek to provide students with a foundation in the arts that will spark an interest that can be nurtured in the junior and senior years of their educational career. We endeavor to expose our students to the rich cultural offerings of New York City as we foster their creativity. We leverage their natural love for dance to expose them to other dance forms. We are sure that with these in and out of school experiences the love for and of the arts will be rooted in our students' hearts

At P.S. 163 we continue to implement the Blueprint for the Arts Curriculum for visual arts. We are also very fortunate to have a continued residency with Arts for All INC., where the students are exposed to theater, visual arts, and dance. This year we will spend a day at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where the students will view, discuss and analyze several paintings and sculptures. We also went to a performace of Jack vs. Rapunzel both sponsored by Arts for All. This continues to be of great impact in the lives of our students because it allows them to experience the Arts outside the constraints of the classroom.

PS 170X is proud to say that we have been able to offer our students access to exceptional instruction in all arts disciplines through a combination of school-based arts educators and a partnership with Marquis Studios. All of our students' arts learning is comprised of both skills-based instruction and a connection to the discipline's cultural background and vocabulary. Instruction across all disciplines is aligned with or surpasses benchmarks outlined in the NYC Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts. Students have additional access to arts programs provided by our school's arts specialists in a variety of arts-based after-school programs (not discussed in this survey) It is our goal that our students continue to find success and grow both as performers and artists and pursue the arts well after they leave our school as artists, advocates, or appreciators. We hope to provide these opportunities through the continuation of our current programs in the upcoming school year.
Q45_1: We are a K-2 Early Childhood School in the South Bronx.  It has been our goal to provide all of our students in every grade rigorous instruction in all 4 art forms.  We have worked extremely hard to source outside funding in support of this goal.

Q37_4: Parents donate time to decorate and support any and all events. They even go on trips for our Little Friends of Highbridge program
Q44_1:
We have revised our plan to expand the Arts Education in the Shakespeare School. To realize the plan’s goals, each teacher was  asked to incorporate the arts into their day-to-day culture. This shift spans five years and is divided into two achievable phases, although access to the arts will be evident immediately. Equitable arts opportunities for students will be realized increasingly, as the culture of the Shakespeare School is strengthened and supported school wide.  
This strategic plan is based on a continuum for implementation , with an emphasis in three focus areas that are essential to its success. Its projected outcomes hope to spark policy, future action plans and budget recommendations for implementing a sequential and standards - based curriculum in the arts outlined at every grade level (not only 2nd and 5th as identified in the Blueprint for the Arts).   
This process has fostered further community awareness and hopes to provide the structure and catalyst for sustainable relationships between the Shakespeare School and key arts stakeholders. This concept is founded in the idea that every member of the community has an important piece of the larger puzzle, offering valuable resources that will contribute to the greater good - the future art education, awareness and experience of the scholars at the Shakespeare School!
Q45_1: We continue to produce Disney Musical in Schools production, absorbing full costs of the program. We chose to invest in sustaining the Musicals in our school because of the profound impact it has with all of our students, especially our English Language Learners and Students with Disabilities. This year we selected The Little Mermaid Jr. A musical that is normally conducted at the middle school level. Our directors took on the challenge to provide our students with more enrichment time and activity with the arts. We continue to employ Dimitri Saari of The Society of the Educational Arts liaison to help design and build our set from recyclable materials.  Our students are dedicated, talented and professional, and this is a direct reflection of the commitment our teachers have toward exposing our students to multiple facets of arts instruction through theater.

Q44_1: We provide visual arts and music to students in grades K-8. The teachers are bilingual and instructs in both English and Spanish to align the NYCDOE curriculum and our mission as a Dual Language School. In addition, the classroom teachers provide art and music instruction during the day.

We offer a two semester sequence in Introduction to Visual Art with lessons based on The Blueprint for Art and Common Core. Students express themselves in 2-D, 3-D, and media projects using a variety of different art mediums and computers. Juniors and Seniors can apply for our College Now Program that offers college-level arts classes through participating colleges. Other school enrichment programs, led by outside cultural organizations, include music, dance, cosmetology, and journalism. Students and staff perform in a Winter and Spring Talent Showcase. Other extra-curricular opportunities include clubs and enrichment classes led by our teachers and staff which have incorporated aspects of the arts such as photography, fashion, cartooning, knitting crafts, culinary arts, and poetry. We create a student-designed yearbook in the 12th grade, and participate in a cultural exchange program in Amsterdam.

Q45_1: The Eagle Academy for Young men (09x231) is an all male school in the Bronx. The school is grades 6-12 and has 522 young men. We have many diverse scholars and aim to ensure they are expressing their cultural pride through the arts.

Q44_1: Our goal for arts education at PS 236 is to provide a wide range of experiences that will expose our young learners to the many ways to enjoy the arts. Through our in- house music program we develop appreciation for many genres of music and provide opportunities for our students to perform and showcase their developing talent. All classes receive instruction in vocal music and many begin to explore instrumental music through the use of recorders. Our choir and African drum band meet after school and perform in many venues throughout the city. We host several artist residencies throughout the year that provide experiences in the visual and performing arts. Children have opportunities to experiment with different artistic media and to express themselves through drama and storytelling. Classroom teachers integrate visual arts into all areas of the curriculum, using the Blueprint for the Arts to guide their selection of materials and artistic method. Early exposure develops a lifelong appreciation for art

Our arts program is an integral part of our students' academic program. During the school day, all students enroll in arts-based electives including instrumental music, visual arts, computer design, and woodworking. After school, there are a series of arts-based programs open to all students including dance, visual arts, and music. During the summer, we run "Camp AMS", an all-day program combining academics and arts. This camp is open to all middle school students, including those mandated for summer school. Throughout the year, all of our arts programs include performances and displays, and students invite the community to share in and celebrate their acquired artistic skills.

Our 3-Dimensional design is an advanced course in which students will explore and create a wide variety of sculpture projects while utilizing various materials and resources such as plaster, clay, and paper. Students will be introduced to relevant contemporary and historical artists and art styles and will learn to compare, analyze, evaluate and discuss their own work as well as the work of others. Students will develop the ability to adapt and apply learned skills to other areas of their lives and will recognize the important influence of the arts on our daily lives. During each course, continuing education and career opportunities involving the arts will be addressed. Drawing and Painting is an entry-level art course in which students will learn basic drawing and painting techniques. Students will receive an introduction to the study of Art History and will learn to compare, analyze, evaluate works of art, as well as their own work, and the works of others. Students will use their art making skills, life experiences, and observations to create art. Students will learn to recognize the important influence of the arts on our daily lives. Continuing education and career opportunities involving the arts will be emphasized. Theater/Theater Production is an entry-level course in which students will learn the basics of performance, and technical theater.

The visual arts program at Mott Hall Bronx High School is designed to prepare students for the International Baccalaureate program. Students are engaged in creating an art exhibition in their senior year that is a culmination of their work over their time in the program. 

We also offer BEAT Global after school for students interested in music production, beat-making, rapping, and/or poetry. BEAT teaches music production skills using iPads and beat-making software.  Students create beats, write lyrics, and put together tracks. All of the instructors are real artists who are passionate about teaching students.

The High School for Violin and Dance's mission is to "give students the opportunity to perform and shine in the classroom, on stage, and in life. We want to prepare students to be caring leaders in society. At HSVD, students and staff work together to provide opportunities that meet the needs of every learner. One of the major ways in which our school has grown in regards to the arts has been through continued expansion of our offerings to students. Our music department offers a full orchestra program where students have a choice of violin, viola, cello, or string bass. Some of the music department's goals for next year include having our music students perform both solo and in ensembles at the New York State School Music Association competition. This year we were fortunate enough to add a visual arts component and it is very exciting as many students have learned sublimation and heat transfer with vinyl. This skill has led to many HS for Violin & Dance creations such as shirts, pants, sweaters, mugs, plaques and other items as well. We also plan on building more relationships with cultural organizations and continue the ones we connected with this year (Alvin Ailey, Carnegie Hall & Dance Theater of Harlem). Project I.AM continues to grow and be a important part of our school where students create and deliver individual and group performances before a live panel of judges who provide feedback based on a school-wide performance rubric. Students receive the feedback and are then expected to revise their performances.

The BCSM theatre department currently offers two levels of theatre: introduction to theater and theatre performance. The work in these courses requires personal motivation, passion for exploration, risk-taking, and most importantly, an openness to new ideas, thoughts, and feelings. Students will enhance and develop performance skills in improvisation, theatre games, spoken word, physical theatre and vocal work. We will increase our abilities as imaginative and analytical actors by interpreting the texts of dramatic works. Additionally, we will gain new performance skills needed to help build characer in monologues and scenes. These classes will prove an enjoyable outlet for self-expression, group interaction, and an opportunity to explore personal meaning and identity. After school, the department produces two full scale musical theatre productions each year. Students audition and are chosen to sing, dance and act among their fellow ensemble members. Technical theatre work is also offered, where students may help design, build and paint the sets. Every fall and spring, the theatre department partners with the Theatre Development Fund's Stage Doors Program. Through this program, students collaborate with a TDF teaching artist and attend a Broadway show for free.
Q45_1: BCSM is a title 1 school located in the South Bronx. The majority of students have never taken an arts class before or been to a live performance event. BCSM shares a building with another school and so our common spaces such as the auditorium and cafeteria and not solely ours.

Q44_1: Students were exposed to the arts through clubs and will have a culminating event in June to perform their talents. Students were also exposed to a drama class, digitial art class and and art in action class that combined activism with the arts. Additionally we have been trying to secure Insideout.org to have all of our students particpate in an art project in June, pending DOE approval

The Art program at LIHS is focusing on performing arts this school year. A growing music program that allows students to explore a variety of instruments and performance opportunities. In addition, students are developing skills in acting, directing and scene design. Students are using art textbooks for ideas and are developing their own scripts, as well as studying classic published playwrights. Students are expected to have a culminating performance project each semester. We have a collaboration with The Leadership Program,Inc., which works with students during the school day and after school. They provide visiting artists who collaborate with our teachers and students. Through this program our students are able to engage in visual arts, theater, dance, music and poetry.

For the 2016-2017 school year, PS 294's goal was to integrate art into the regular school day. Through community arts partnerships, every student at our school was able to experience the arts and the thrill of performing for their peers and family. Teachers received professional development in art, music, dance, and theater so that they can support the work of our arts partners, as well as adopt practices to implement into their own daily lessons. Parents have also been able to participate in arts-related family activities coordinated by our parent coordinator in collaboration with our community arts partners. Our partnership with Ballroom Dancing allows direct instruction to our students.
Our school's goal is to focus on project based learning and arts projects that go through panels and round-tables where students defend their work and then prepare it for public presentation.

Visual arts is in its second year of implementation. We recognize the need to expose students to the arts as it addresses the whole child. Through Arts Matter we were able to hire a visual arts teacher who has been an asset to this school. He has showcased student work throughout the year. Students have used a variety of mediums to express art.

Our primary goal within our Arts Education curriculum is to enhance our students overall educational experience. We at CMSP 327 want our students to perform well academically and actively participate in all aspects of our school environment. We are keenly aware of how music, art, dance, and film impact the educational and personal growth of each of our students. We have worked with the Arts Matter program for the past few years to increase our Arts offerings, we have a full time dance teacher, and one of our own English teachers acheieved certification in theatre. We continue to grow our Arts program and are looking for a certified visual arts teacher.

Students in middle and high school grades were able to take one to two semesters of visual arts. Students worked on standards-aligned visual arts assignments to build their secondary school arts portfolios. Year III or more students are able to design independent study courses in visual arts according to interest and school capacity. Students in middle and high school also received a semester of music - both instrumental and vocal. They performed at four school assemblies and for some external partners.
Q45_1: We are New York's only transfer high school with middle school grades. We use the arts and interest in artistic talent development to "re-interest" disconnected youth into coming back to school - regularly (defined as at least four times a week). Our 6th to 11th graders range 13 to 21 years of age.

Q44_1: ur mission is to ensure that students are equipped with the academic and socio-emotional skills necessary to enter competitive high schools. Arts education will develop our students' academic and socio-emotional skill set by providing them a means of expression. Currently, we offer our students daily access to physical education, and the ability to participate in one of the following enrichment activities: dance, visual arts ( computer-based or painting/drawing ) and theater. Our goal is to bring a full-time arts person on board to help implement arts during the periods 1-7, and not just through our community based organization partner, WHEDco.

We have a full time certified music teacher. Students also have the opportunity to major in Media and Communications which will allow them to experiment and create with digital art resources. Our students continue visiting museums and attending art related productions such as movies and theater. These experiences support their learning and appreciation for the arts.
Our Program provides students with dance, visual arts, African drumming, photography, spoken word and video.
We have an arts integration system. We infuse the arts into all subjects

In 2016-2017 we partnered with SASF for enrichment programs in music and visual art. Additionally, students continue to be engaged in art projects and participate in periodic art exhibits for parents and the school community.

At the Family School we believe in advancement of the arts through collaborative learning and artistic practice within a diverse, intellectual, and social environment. Underlying all our work is the commitment to the arts and use of community and educational resources as a vital and fundamental cultural force necessary to the functioning of a democratic society and to the education of our students.

Grant Avenue Elementary School is committed to the arts as a critical way in which our students learn more about the world and more about themselves. Our students experience quality visual arts, and music instruction throughout the school year with our specialty teachers. Students receive additional arts instruction from cultural organizations across the city including Studio in a School, Story Pirates, and Third Street Music School Settlement thanks in large part to our partnership with Change for Kids. We pride ourselves on engaging with parents through the arts and, together, we celebrate our talented students and showcase their work at annual musical performance events (concerts and a 5th grade musical) and one major art exhibition each year.

At The Bronx School for Law, Government and Justice, we believe in the importance of the arts for our students. We also believe in tapping into students' interests, creativity and abilities. In support of these beliefs, in addition to our school themed electives, we offer arts focused after school programs. Each year, our students choose from a range of electives in the arts based on their interests. Because art is both product and performance based, students participating in arts courses share their talent and learning by performing in and out of school.

9th grade scholars at FDA III all participate in visual arts classes for at least one semester and in some cases two semesters. The school provides visual arts classes for continuing visual arts scholars in the 10th and 11th grades who wish to develop a portfolio and take the arts exit exams in June after accumulating six or more credits. 9th through 12th grade scholars may take classes in music and music appreciation and join the band. Theater classes have been introduced to the high school scholars this year and also meet during our after school program hours.

The overall goal of our visual arts program is to provide a comprehensive program where students are engaged in the art making process as well as critical analysis of works of art. Students are engaged in rich discussion about works of art focusing on the identification of the elements of design as well as the principles of art.Through these discussions the goal is to enrich student's visual arts vocabulary and cultural awareness. Our art program utilizes the NYC blueprint for teaching and assess our instruction. 

Our dance program also utilizes the NYC blueprint for dance to guide and assess our dance program. Our program works collaboratively with dance residence Alvin Ailey. The goal of our dance program is to provide student with an understanding of various genres of dance while building and developing student's dance vocabulary. We also aim to develop student's fine motor, gross motor and memory through learning age appropriate Choreography. All students participate in an annual school wide performance.

In partnership with the Internationals Network for Public Schools, Claremont International High School opened in the fall of 2012 to service English Langauge Learners in the South Bronx. Our school has a strong commitment towards integrating the arts into all classes. We believe that the arts are an integral vehicle for students, especially newly arrived ELLs, to confidently express and communicate their ideas, feelings and sharing of prior knowledge. The arts are considered a core class that all 9th/10th grade students take. We employ 2 full time arts teachers (theatre arts and visual arts), who each serve on an interdisciplinary team. Students are required to complete portfolios for a selected art discipline to graduate.

Students are exposed to the arts in a variety of ways at PS/MS 3. They participate in developmentally appropriate arts instruction in areas including, but not limited to, the following: dance, music, theatre and visual arts. Our grades 5-8 students receive additional instruction and support in the arts through SOBRO, our CBO. We look forward to increasing student participation in the arts for the 2016-2017 school year.

P.S. 7 is a school of excellence in the arts. We integrate the arts to align with the curriculum. We partner with a number of community organizations to develop the intellectual and social/emotional growth of our children. P.S. 7 is a community that embodies our core values of achievement, collaboration, equity, growth, integrity and meaningful work. The staff and students work together to ensure that all people in the school are actively engaged in learning and reaching their potential.

Our current arts program is comprised of music appreciation and visual arts for all students in Grades K-5. For the 2017-2018 school year, our goal is to enrich our arts programs by collaborating with outside organizations to include residencies that offer theater and dance.

Q45_1:
The arts department had a fun year of collaboration with a production of Swan Lake In the Bronx. It was rewritten by our dance teacher, Ms. Alden. Choreographed by students and had cameo appearances by our staff members this show was one that brought delight and laughter to it's audience. The music teacher prepared songs and instruments and The visual art teacher guided the students in transform into the front  of the auditorium into a painted forest.  
The dance teacher and music teacher both have multy grade groups in their respective clubs which are very instrumental in each production at our school. Next year the visual arts department will seek to provide this opportunity to students in grades 3-5. All departments will engage in community involvement through presentation and field trips.

Q44_1: The goal of PS/MS 15 is to expose, nurture and enhance the cultural experiences for all students through a variety of art disciplines. Additionally, we offer a variety of club  activities for middle school students to further enhance their arts education experiences. Menu items include dance, visual arts, film, chorus, knitting and cooking

PS/MS 20 has a junior chorus for students interested in learning performance and vocal techniques. The students will exhibit these techniques in concerts. Additionally, interested students will have the opportunity to learn how to use instruments such as violin, recorder, xylophone and keyboard. Early elementary students will learn and experience playing percussion instruments and keyboard. Additionally, the school will seek out Cultural Arts Organizations to identify programs that can be brought to students in school.

We have two full time ARTS teachers, one in Dance and one in Visual Arts. The Visual Arts teacher works with the lower grades - PreKindergarten through Second Grade. The Dance teacher works with Third through Fifth Grade. Both teachers have been teaching at this school for more than ten years. They do various individual and collaborative projects. They design and implement curriculum that is based on the New York City Blueprint for the Arts Standards, but also include the Common Core Curriculum, ELA, and Social Studies Standards.  Both teachers have attended the Teacher Effectiveness in the Arts three day series.  The dance teacher also has facilitated this program for the last two years.

Q42_R1_C1: Philharmonic Symphony Society of New York

Q44_1: We currently have an Arts Leadership Team comprised of students, teachers, and administrators. The team works towards our Arts Mission Statement and goals set early in the year. They organize programs, events and opportunities for both students and teachers around the arts. We highlight teacher strengths in the arts even if they are not certified as an arts teacher. Teachers take these strengths and create programs during and after-school in addition to sharing in teacher teams to build capacity in the arts. Our school environment consists of an arts gallery, "The Belmont Art Gallery," located in a hallway/bridge where all grades and programs are represented. Hallways, bulletin boards, and classrooms also come alive with arts. We have developed strong collaborations with our arts partners, particularly DreamYard, who have assisted in deepening the work around the arts disciplines.

We provide Visual Arts instruction in grades K-5, and grade 7.  We provide Drama instruction to grades K-5.  We dance and sing in our classrooms and at assemblies, shows and our dance festival.  We expose our students to cultural events outside our school including plays, recitals, art museums, and films.

in the 2016-17 school year, we have a visual arts teacher servicing mostly our 6th/7th grade students include SWD and ENL students,
in addition, we work with DreamYard for after school dance as well as marquis studio for in house student work - architecture via technology.
2 of our 8th grade teachers are involved with Lincoln center and the victory theatre providing our student with access to a teaching artist and then the cultural event. 
we would love more of the arts, i.e. dance, however with decreased budgets it is very difficult to fund during the school day without grants.

PS 46, The Edgar Allan Poe Literacy Development School houses student’s grades kindergarten to fifth grade.  All students receive arts instruction integrated into the literacy block.  Arts instruction is implemented in the classroom daily by certified classroom teachers.  In addition, PS 46 has two full-time certified art teachers.  One teacher is certified to teach fine arts and services students located at our MS 45 annex.  The second art teacher is certified in the performing arts (drama), and services students in grades kindergarten through fourth grade and is housed in the main building.  Our schools belief is rooted in the idea of developing the whole child, therefore art residencies are also conducted annually with a resident instructor.  Currently our residences are run through the following organizations Arts Horizon, Dream Yard, and Marquis Studio.  Residencies last anywhere from 10-14 weeks in duration and are being conducted in the discipline of architecture, dance (ballroom, world and Afro-Brazilian), recorders, storytelling, drumming and poetry.  As a result student’s educational experiences are enhanced and enriched.  Each class participates in a culminating event that strengthens the home-school connection.

Fine Arts Mission Statement 2016-2017. At the Bronx New School, the fine arts are a vital part of the comprehensive education plan for every student here. We believe that every student should have access to quality materials and instruction in all fine arts areas: music, theatre, dance, visual art and poetry. Our students learn skills in each of the arts areas in accordance to the New York City Blueprint for the Arts and New York State arts standards. Students learn how to make connections between the arts, academic subjects, and technology; building their creative and critical thinking skills, responsibility and self esteem. Students are also exposed to the many arts experiences that New York City has to offer by taking field trips several times a year to see live performances, art museums, and cultural centers. Students have the opportunity to display their work through performances and exhibitions for our school community in a number of celebrations through out the school year.

PS 54 provides visual arts, theater, poetry, music and dance instruction to all of our students. We celebrate this every year with visual arts exhibitions, dance recitals, poetry slams, and theatrical performances with our entire school community. This year we increased our opportunities to work with the Dream Yards Project with the focus on visual arts and dance.   Visiting artists have been working directly with selected classes and with parent groups as part of community outreach in the arts and have also be conducting after school programs. The early childhood education students received additional visual arts instruction through Studio in a School.  Our students have exhibited work at the New York Botanical Gardens and will be exhibiting art work in the 2017 Bronx Borough Annual Visual Arts Festival and the Dream Yards Visual Arts Festival at Lehman College where they will exhibit art work and perform in a dance recital. We have a second grade teacher who provides music instruction as he also orchestrates a student rock band and he also is directing a theatrical performance in the spring.  Connections are continuously made with the common core subjects to support learning through the arts.
Q45_1: Public School 54 is a strong school community that celebrates our diversity through various modalities of student achievement.  We pride ourselves on setting high expectations for all students with the belief that all of our students are capable of achieving academic success in their various forms of intelligences and learning styles.  Classroom teachers are enhancing their teaching practices through Teachers College as a source of professional development and professional application in the classroom.  We also provide workshops for our parents in the community to extend the learning beyond the classroom.

Q44_1: All students in grades 1 and 2 learn to play the recorder. All students in grades 3,4 and 5 participate in a choral program through The Metropolitan Opera Guild/Urban Voices. All students in grades 3, 4 and 5 learn to play the violin. Instrumental instruction in grades 3, 4 and 5 are given by resident artist through the Bronx Arts Ensemble. Students participate in visual arts , theater and dance in the classroom instructed by a classroom teacher.

Students will receive dance and music through various programs, trips and before and after school groups. All lessons taught are aligned with the New York State and NYC Blue Print Standards as well as incorporating ELA common core, math, science and social studies as interdisciplinary lessons. Students are able to express themselves and learn visually and vocally to enhance their skills and self- esteem as young students.

In the 2016-2017 school year, PS 77 was able to provide music instruction to all students from Pk to 2nd grade thanks to the hiring of a full time music teacher. In addition to this, students and their families participates in cycles of Saturday arts workshops from January to May. 
These sessions were very popular and successful, for this reason, we hope to be able to offer it again next year to a larger population.

We believe that the arts are integral an component to our students' academic and social-emotional development. Through the arts our students develop 21st century skills such as, problem solving, collaboration, creative thinking, perseverance, and communication skills. We currently offer a comprehensive arts program comprised of visual arts, music, and theater. Our daytime arts program is complimented with a large selection of after school arts activities. We have partnered with community based organizations to provide both the students and community at large with heightened arts experiences. Our students take part in a minimum of 3 arts performances per year. These events allow students to display their talents and engage our parents, families and community members. In the coming year(s) we are looking to expand our arts through technology. This will include music/sound engineering, computer graphics, web design, robotics, and 3D design. These offering will provide students with skills to prepare them for college and the current/projected career landscape. We are committed to holistic development of our students and the arts is one of the critical components.

Our school offers a sequential arts program for high school students. In grades 6-8 each student has the opportunity to take both visual arts and music. At the close of 9th grade high school students select either a visual arts track or a music track. In grades 10-12 visual arts students take elective courses in creative craft, 2-D and -3-D design and have the opportunity to take Advanced Placement Studio Art in their senior year. 10-12 grade music students take survey courses including vocal training, percussion, guitar and keyboard. We have increased our arts programming with the Lehman College Art Gallery and a variety of Arts institutions throughout the city. Our vision is to continue to grow our arts program and provide students not only with traditional hands on arts opportunities but with critical thinking skills in the arts that will prepare them for the global 21st century.

Public School 85 is a community committed to integrating diverse art forms across the curriculum to enable its members to reach their full potential. Through the arts, our community will foster life-long learners with a sense of pride and self motivation. The arts will be a vehicle to further our understanding of ourselves and the world around us.

Q42_R1_C1: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts

Q44_1: The goal of the P.S.86 Visual Arts and Performing Arts program is to provide students with the tools to understand and internalize the premise that the elements of art inhabit every aspect of our lives. Recognition of the elements of art gives students freedom to acquire self-esteem and self-mastery, and the momentum to pursue creativity. Through direct involvement in an integrated arts curriculum students make connections between art and their own lives, i.e., math and art, science and art, history and art. Self-direction within art classes allows students to express themselves while building problem-solving skills as well as as developing techniques used in making art: descriptive language (describing), analysis of purpose (analyzing), interpretive feelings (interpreting), evaluation of the art project (evaluating). Collaboration with the New York City cultural organizations in music, dance, theater, and visual arts provides a superlative opportunity for students to build a global arts foundation. For example, P.S. 86 has worked with the Guggenheim "Learning Through Art" for over twenty years with admiration and awe from students, teachers, and parents. (LTA is a 20 week program, October-May, with students'work exhibited in the Museum in May.) The 86 vendors'lists reflects the "quality vendors" who make connections between the arts, daily lives, and life styles of students, teachers and parents. Parents, families, and friends are enthusiastic supporters of 86' student concerts and performances.
Q45_1:
This year P.S. 86 art teachers, on one of the extended days, explored techniques used in assessing art in the classroom to further develop students' skill levels, their interpretive sensibilities, their use of materials as well as assessing individual and group progress.                                           
PS 86 has also implemented a new program for Special Education students called "Fly High". The program is based on acquiring self-esteem and mastery not only in the classroom, but in alternative spaces, such as gallery studio workshops and museums. Th arts residencies are coordinated with the 86 school curriculum. Professionals in the Special Needs spectrum have been invited to observe and conduct art classes for the students. Staff Development for the Special Education staff is included in the program.        (All arts lesson plans are developed in accordance with the Common Core Standards: ELA and History, the National Standards and the New York State Standards.)

Q44_1:
P.S. 91 has two certified music teachers, who provide choral and general music instruction. All students in grades kindergarten through fifth, receive music instruction at least one period per week. We have two visual arts teachers (one who is certified) who provide visual art education for all students’ in grades kindergarten through fifth for at least one period per week.  Additionally, we have staff members from "Materials for the Arts" who work with classroom teachers and students on ‘end of unit’ projects teaching Art through Social Studies content to students in grades K-5. We also have weekly Music/Orchestra, Visual Arts and Dance programs which take place after school.

Finally, we have a Saturday Arts program where students can participate in Music, Drama, and Art. This program runs from November to May, ending with a theatrical performance. The school has two culminating assemblies, once in the winter and the other in the late spring where students perform in each of their respective disciplines. Also, twice a year we have an "ART Gallery" display on our first floor where students showcase their visual arts pieces. The displays are received well by parents, teachers and students. Teachers in all grades have a fifteen minute dance/movement/ theater break every day.
Q45_1: Due to a clerical error within the STARS System, class 2-942 has appeared on this survey. This class is a nonexistent class at P.S. 91 which is why it received zero arts instruction this year. We apologize for any inconvenience this may have caused.

Q44_1: During the 2016-2017 school year, we at PS 94 believe we are giving our students another way of learning and expressing themselves, allowing them to explore new ideas and develop their imagination through arts education. We have seen the programs in the arts at PS 94 provide our students with skills in cooperative decision-making and leadership. It has also helped in the social and emotional development of the child, which can lead to an increase in academic achievement as well as overall school success. We have a variety of arts partners (Arts Horizons, Lehman College Art Gallery, Studio in a School) that supplement our arts program with residencies designed to expose our children to music, theater, dance and the visual arts. It is our obligation as educators to support our students by every means possible. We will continue our arts partnerships and engage all our learners through the arts.

P.S. 205 will continue to implement the Common Core Learning Standards and the NYC Blueprint for the Arts, integrating them across the curriculum. Our interdisciplinary approach promotes student progress, improves instructional practices and leads to teacher sustainability in the arts. In addition to our Fine Arts Curriculum (K-5), we have an additional full time cluster speciality art teacher to service our students.  Our ongoing partnership with Young Audiences/NY enriches and deepens our instructional program. They provide quality professional development for staff through in-class modeling and workshops by teaching artists.

M.S 118 is still able to offer many opportunities for the arts but have some difficulty maintaining music and dance classes due to staffing issues.  We are looking forward to resolving this for Sept. 2017 as well as offering students more electives choices. Art teachers are currently applying for an Art+Family Engagement Grant.

The RKA 10x141 Arts department has worked hard to strike a balanced approach in our middle school Arts curriculum. As students move from sixth grade to seventh, we encourage them to commit to a two-year sequence in one of the arts; that is a two-year sequence in either Visual Arts or Band or Chorus during grades 7-8. Yet, as sixth graders, they experience two half-year arts classes so that they can make a more informed choice about the longer commitment. We are blessed with truly gifted arts teachers who provide rich classroom instruction; these teachers also provide authentic performance experiences at our Winterfest Arts Festival and our Springfest Arts Festival. In high school there are opportunities for advanced work in clay, as well, in our AP Ceramics class, in addition to high school core art classes. We are proud of the array of arts experiences available to our students in grades 6-12.

We, at Public School 159, believe that teaching art is an integral part of the teaching and learning process. Art enables students to express their personal experiences in ways that are concrete and compelling, even when they are unable to articulate the events in words. Children love to make direct physical contact with their universe. Teaching and learning about art allows children to develop cognitive and psychomotor skills and an appreciation for art. Our integration of the arts has offered our students different didactic art opportunities and learning experiences. We have also created an arts Integration teacher who reinforces content areas through the use of visual arts.

We strive to offer a wide array of artistic opportunities to our students. We believe arts education to be an integral part of the middle school experience because of the opportunities it provides to expand student engagement and encourage creativity in expression. Currently, our arts programming offers instruction in band, choir, dance, piano, strings, theater, and visual arts. To offer this range of artistic options, we actively seek to bring in cultural organizations to supplement and expand our own in-school offerings. One of our greatest partnerships is with the Park Avenue Armory which, through its residency programs, student and teacher workshops, and programming, have afforded our students an extraordinary level of enrichment. All our work around the arts culminates in large-scale school performances held three times a year. These performances bring together all our artistic disciplines in a celebration of the arts. A poignant performance held each February is in honor of Black History Month where our school community is able to see the fullest integration of the arts and core subjects such as ELA and social studies. As a school community dedicated to increasing the exposure and learning our students gain from the arts, we look forward to future expansion and opportunities for our students to connect to and through the arts.

The school has a drumming music program that runs during the school day.

The school has a ballroom dancing program that runs during the school day.

The school provides art instruction during the school day.

The school has a music/dance program that runs during the school day.

Q37_4: Parents would like more involvement with the arts.
Q44_1:
Teachers incorporate art in their daily lesson plans, in addition all children receive at least one class of art per week by a licensed art teacher. Student art work is exhibited throughout the building.
Children receive at least one period of music per week by a licensed music teacher. Students perform two concerts for the school community and parents.
Students use photography and slide shows to memorialize special events throughout the year. In order to increase the visibility of art in our school we have initiated an enrichment program to create murals around our school and make art more accessible to all our students.
Q45_1: This year we have new administration in our building.  As a result new initiatives have been put in place for this year. Teachers are receiving targeted professional development and technology is being upgraded school wide. The building is being reorganized so that the arts and technology can be highlighted in a localized areas of the building. Staff are writing grants to partner with outside resources to increase dance, theater and other arts opportunities for the next school building.

Q42_R1_C1: Learning through an Expanded Arts Program
Q44_1: The students at P.S. 209 are exposed to various artists and mediums that are aligned to the NYC DOE Blueprint for the Arts. Our students also have opportunities to participate in visual art exhibits, as well as take part in dance, music, and theater productions during our fall, winter, and spring performances. Our students receive art instruction in visual arts, dance, theater and music from outside artists as well as their classroom teachers. Theses art residencies were initiated to provide students with additional opportunities to further their artistic capabilities. P.S. 209’s Project Arts Committee also plans school-wide and grade specific field trips to cultural institutions including museums, botanical gardens and zoos throughout New York City to enable students to make meaningful connections.

While IN-Tech Academy is known as a technology school and as a school offering many Advanced Placement courses, we are also a school that is proud of our arts programs. We have a high school drama production in the fall and a middle school musical in the spring. We have visual art displays in our courtyard and in the hallway leading to the auditorium, which is visible from the street outside our building. We have band performances in the winter and spring. Our facilities include three kilns, several pottery wheels, a band room and a room designed as a dance studio. We also take students on trips to see Broadway shows and the STREB Lab for Action Mechanics.

More could be added, but suffice it to say that the arts are as much a consideration at IN-Tech Academy as technology and AP courses. We work with the whole scholar.

At PS 246 we are cognizant that a balanced and sequential arts education program fosters students’ perception of both their real and imagined worlds. Through structured course work which includes knowledge of artists, art principles and educated critique our students are exposed to various cultures around the world. Our art program enables each student to develop positive attitudes toward self, others and the environment through creative experiences. It empowers students to experience the arts as a constructive expression of human emotions and as an unique intellectual discipline. Through the integration of problem solving and creative learning in our arts program we encourage students to relate visual and auditory knowledge to other content areas and to respond with originality, appreciation, flexibility and imagination. We measure our students' growth as artists through assessments focused on individual achievement related to each student’s stage of growth and development.

As a school of technology and engineering, our students explore creativity through the use of technology. Within our core subjects, we increase cultural exposure to the arts within the general curricula. Our core subjects have incorporated field trips to museums, theaters, and concerts. This year, Bronx Engineering and Technology was able to offer Art and Creative Writing as electives. Lastly, all BETA students explore the arts through their engineering courses supported by the Project Lead The Way curriculum. Additionally, sixty-five students are in the Academy of Computer Science and explore the arts through graphic design and computer languages

Q44_1: DANCE: Students develop creativity, strength, as they learn principles of modern dance, ballet and composition. Students develop their own unique voice as choreographers. DRAMA: Students learn acting technique, scene study, voice and diction, movement, singing, theatre history, auditioning, digital resume building, script analysis, directing, lighting design, and stagecraft as well as acting technique for classical, modern, musical theatre productions and smaller studio settings. VISUAL ARTS: Students develop their artistic skills through still life drawing, perspective drawing, portraiture, figure drawing, and abstract compositions using a variety of drawing, painting, and digital design media. Students develop self-confidence as they build valuable artistic, literacy and technical skills in photography and video production while building skills for meaning and application in college and beyond. JAZZ PIANO. Students learn general appreciation and listening, history, theory, basic to advanced songs chord structures & progressions, improvisation, solo & ensemble performance, styles, and aesthetics. CHORUS. Middle and High School. TAPCo students have consistently placed in Arts competitions, garnered roles in major motion pictures, and represented the Arts at various public functions throughout New York City.
