Q42_R1_C1: Learning through an Expanded Arts Program
Q44_1: P.S. 226X - The Nadia J. Pagan School. We are a school where children come first! Our focus is building future leaders who encompass college and career readiness, a well rounded education through the arts, and a strong foundation of 21st century skills. We are most proud of our arts programs where students are exposed to music, art, and dance. We offer a variety of programs to culture our students that include Chinese dance, salsa, ballroom dancing, yoga, and other programs that broaden the horizons of our children. In conjunction with our partnership organizations, we house our own enrichment programs such as student council, peer-to-peer, gardening, chess, basketball, photography, cooking, ballet dance, and DJ spin club of which was exhibited on News 12 just last year. Parents are so supportive of our school initiatives that are in place and our attendance rates truly exhibit the love that students have for coming to school.

Jonas Bronck Academy's philosophy is to build up the entire scholar.  Students have been  challenged to take their education to a metacognitive level.  The Arts is a major part of that vision implementing the Blue Print Strands in Dance and in Art.  We now have a full-time dance program in place along with Dancing Classroom (8th Graders only). Ms. Powers vision is to prepare our scholars in all facets of dance, building movement and vocabulary skills as well as creating, performing and responding to dance.  The program was further enriched by a Dance Theatre of Harlem partnership. Which played an intricate part of the implementation the connection of the arts to a vision of college and career readiness path for the scholars. This was made possible with the assist of the Arnhold New Dance Teacher Program.  
     The arts curricula will continue to build on itself as the foundation of Fine Arts are explored.  Making connections in art and it's practices to many master fine artist through modern art movements to the newly developed Warwick House movement of Street Art.  
     LEAP is still a valuable part of the extra-curriculum vein of the school.  They add multi-media, cosmetology, robotics, fashion, arts & crafts and even cooking.  Many scholars are venturing into their own creativity and making life long connections.  Next year's goals include a theatre component which will add to the already rich opportunities we offer our scholars.
Q45_1: Jonas Bronck Academy is fortunate enough to be working in partnership with LEAP, through Mrs. Carmen Farina's vision.  This Community Based Organization provides our scholars with an enormous variety of activities in the after school programs. Including supplemental arts programs and many physical activities are offered. They allow our scholars to venture into cooking, web-designing, photography and/or photoshop, all kinds of sports and even Robotics. None of our scholars are without some excuse when it comes to being stimulated creatively or kinetically.  They offer over 24 different clubs and skill building sessions.  Our mission is to open the doors of creativity and the power of knowledge to every scholar that walks through our doors.

Q44_1:
Art and design play an increasingly important role in BASE's curriculum. In 10th graders all students take a year-long fine arts course that includes theory as well as drawing, painting and multi-media work. The course also includes a full unit on digital design using state of the art design software. 
 
Design work also plays an important role in the software engineering work students do at BASE. They learn to use Design Thinking to solve complex problems, a process multi-step that includes thinking like a designer to ensure solutions are creative and targeted to users' needs.

Kingsbridge International High School has an expanding arts program, including a new ceramics program. With two brand new kilns, students are able to create works of art using ceramics as a medium, using their knowledge of proportion, three-dimensions, and color.

Our arts programs have been designed to create an arts culture in our school where every child receives the opportunity to express themselves, both artistically and socially, through all subjects, including the arts. Our aim is to work with the resources (time, personnel, and money) our school possesses so that we may give our students the best possible arts education with the end goal of enriching our students lives and their artistic and academic futures

PS/MS 280 is a K-8 school with a total student population of 910. We have a full time cetified Art teacher for grades 3-8. We have a second full time teacher to teach art and music to our K-2 students. We also have 3 teachers who each teach art part-time to our grade 3-8 students. As it is our goal for all students to be enriched in the arts as much as possible, classroom teachers' support includes all aspects of arts, dance, theater, music and visual arts in their lessons by creating thematic units. Throughout the school year, all grades go on several field trips to enhance this art curriculum and some arts providers are brought into the school directly.

Our school collaborated with our neighboring small school to provide Visual Arts and Music classes to students through the support of the High School Arts Matters funding.  Students were exposed to music theory concepts and visual arts open studio activities that offered them exposure to techniques.

Bronx Arts Ensemble runs dance and visual art classes, in addition to the film, arts, and art history classes we already have. Additionally, our students saw Hamilton on Broadway, and also see other Spanish-language performances. This year we also started an Arts club, and we have students participating in photography for free at the School of Visual Arts.  Additionally, Manhattan School of Music has been visiting our school and doing performances for our students.

Our visual art, and music teachers offer sequential art instruction to all students in Grades K-5. Students are also given in-school art residencies in visual arts, creative dance, ballroom dancing and African drums. We offer interdisciplinary connections to help build on the students learning inside the classroom. Our visual arts teacher develops integrated art units that are designed to enhance the Common Core Learning Standards. Through creating, performing, responding and connecting, students are able to develop their art skills and imaginations. Students learn to understand how others express themselves through music, dance and visual arts. Our students learn to share ideas and emotions and how to turn those into images, sounds, and actions. As our students create artistically through the arts they become more imaginative and strengthen their problem-solving skills.

Q37_4: Participating in Saturday Family Art Workshops
Q44_1: 307's goal remains to infuse the 4 art strands into core subjects and to instill an appreciation for the arts throughout our school community.  Our arts program continues to be enriched by a CASA Grant thanks to Councilman Cabrera. This grant gave ALL of our students an opportunity to work with teaching artists from The Town Hall. K-3rd graders participated in dance residencies. K students learned jazz, 1st graders learned tap and 2nd and 3rd graders expanded their tap dance expertise. 4th and 5th graders worked with a theater teaching artist and created their own scripts. All residencies culminated with performances for families. For the 4th year, we had a Musical Theater Review. The enseblem consisted of 4th and 5th graders who auditioned for this residency. They worked with both a theater and music teaching artist. The residency culminated with 3 performances(2 for their peers and 1 for their families). For the 8th year, we held a Fall and Spring Saturday Family Arts Institutes. K-2nd grade families participated in a theater/visual arts institute and 3rd-5th grade families participated in a visual arts(cartooning) institute. Our Family Art Institutes continues to be a tremendous success with many families repeating the experience. Last year, we were awarded a 3 year SPARK Educational Grant from The New Victory Theater. Our 3rd graders attended 3 performances at The New Victory Theater, worked with 2 of their teaching artists, and 3rd grade teachers participated in 3 sessions of arts professional development.
Q45_1: 307 is not a DOE building which sometimes tends to hinder us in programing.  Our gym is the only room available for dance and theater arts.  We now have a certified gym teacher and it is extremely difficult scheduling both the gym program and dance residencies which require gym space.

Q44_1: Our mission at the Bronx Dance Academy is to provide a comprehensive and nurturing learning environment where students excel. Dancing and the Visual Arts are of great importance in this effort. Staff and parents will work collaboratively to improve the quality of standards-based instruction while respecting the diversity of our school community.

P.S. 310's goal is to provide an arts curriculm aligned with the Blue Print for the Arts, and supports the Common Core Learning Standards We believe arts instruction enhance academic performance. Teachers are aware of the value of the integration of dance, music and visual arts in the content area.
Q45_1: P.S. 310 is divided into four academies. It is performed for the school and community.

Q44_1: Students at the Lab School will demonstrate independence and develop content knowledge through creative expression in the arts. This will be measured by assessing growth in music composition and performance and dance choreography and performance. •Twice a week, students in grades K-8 will be offered dance and music instruction by a full-time certified dance teacher and music teacher. •Students will be provided with a dance and music curriculum that is aligned with New York State Standards and the New York City Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts by a full-time certified dance teacher and music teacher •	Weekly 45 -minute small group instruction in dance and music for selected students. Twice weekly, selected students in grades 5-8 will have the opportunity to participate in the after-school enrichment program for dance and music. At least 6 performance opportunities: Book-a-ween, Spring Dance Fest, two Cultural Arts Presentations, Kindergarten and 8th grade Graduation.

KAPPA International High School provides a challenging and engaging arts curriculum. Our scholars are performers, composers, musicians and actors. Visual arts, music, and theater are offered grades 9-12. Beginner and advanced band are offered in addition to drawing, painting, and advanced art. Upperclassmen can also take International Baccalaureate Art, Music or Theatre Arts, each of which offers a rigorous, college-preparatory curriculum. Seniors have created visual arts portfolios for the purposes of college applications; graduates have received up to 6 college credits for IB coursework undertaken in IB Theatre Arts alone. KAPPA also partners with Theatre Development Fund's Open Doors program, wherein eight students are selected to attend six on and off Broadway shows over the academic year with mentor (and world famous producer) Thomas Schumacher. Rock band is offered as an extracurricular option.

The arts program exposes young people to the many facets of the arts. it is our goal that all of our students will stimulate their creative thinking and use the knowledge and skills to enhance their problem solving abilities.  It is our intention that this exposure will provide enrichment and a lifetime of arts enjoyment and appreciation.

We believe in providing arts opportunities throughout the school day to expose all students to many art forms.  We also believe in offering many after school activities for students who are interested to expand their opportunities to experience the arts. We offer many extra-curricular arts opportunities, in our ArtsXL program, including music, visual arts, theater, digital media and dance. Students have an opportunity to work with artists in residence and also attend many arts related field trips.

P.S. 340 continues to provide quality visual arts instruction to our students. This year the visual arts teacher supported the content area curriculum through the arts. A current focus and new initiative is the cross curriculum of social studies and art. Both the art teacher and social studies teacher regularly attend workshops to professionally grow and develop the aligning curriculums. Our goal is to continue providing positive rewarding experiences through the arts that will provide students with the skill and knowledge they need to be well rounded individuals who make sound, aesthetic choices. We will also continue our relationship with American Ballroom Dancing: Dancing Classrooms uses a curriculum-based teaching approach to achieve social awareness and build self-esteem. Theatre Moves provided our students with the skills necessary to create their dynamic performance which are the same skills students utilize in learning situations. Working with Marquis Studios has provided our students the opportunity to learn about different fields in the arts department.  This program has helped to incorporate our community and parents.  Parents were encouraged to participate with their children.

his year the school provided a variety of opportunities to engage students in the arts. Students across the middle school and high school were offered dance in our physical education program. In addition, students were offered an opportunity to participate in school- wide plays, dance performances, and talent shows as part of our after school program. In the middle school, there is a full time art teacher. The middle school art teacher also runs an after school art club where students draw. In the high school two art courses were offered to students in 10th through 12th grade, as well as an AP art class. 

Two field trips in partnership with the Jewish Museum were organized for high school students to watch films. Three field trips were conducted to the MET museum for all middle and high school students. 

The school has several artists in residency offering Flamenco, Zumba, and theater. This is our first year in putting together a school band.

We continued our partnership with Inside Broadway, including "Creating the Magic" experiences at Broadway shows ("Cats" and "Chicago") and musical theater performances by students across all grades.  We started a new collaboration with Alvin Ailey Dance in grades 2-5, including African and Jazz dancing.  AmPark provided art and music to students at every grade level. We have a music room equipped with instruments, and an art room equipped with arts materials. Our after-school drama program was offered to every grade, and culminated in 2 musical productions. Many students have attended dramatic performances. Our art program allows children to work with a large range of materials and media, and develop skills and knowledge of art concepts. Much of the work is in collaboration with classroom teachers, and expands on the themes being learned in students' classrooms. In music, children learn an expansive repertoire of songs. They explore notation, beat, and rhythm using their voices as well as instruments. There are several presentations throughout the year for families.

An art/math program that teaches mathematical concepts to children through visual arts.  Where possible, the students use vocabulary and expressions related to mathematics.  The children use art materials and resources and they analyze art.  They explore how artists are inspired and how culture influences art.

In 2016-2017, MS 363 will offer a visual arts program to all 6th grade students and a music program to all 7th grade students. 8th grade students will receive music and art. The focus of each program will be for students to use the arts to relate to everyday problem solving and to make connections to the social and emotional issues they are faced with. Students will use different expressive techniques to become better learners and leaders.

Art education offers students a fundamental study of aesthetics, art criticism, art history, as well as art production. Art is provided to all grades K-5 weekly. The art environment at PS 382 brings the art world into the classroom with the use of various art materials, media and to promote creativity within each lesson. Students attended trips to art museums throughout New York City.

we will again offer ceramics, fine arts, band and general music.  we will offer sculpture and creating course sequences in the arts and music.  we will be offering marching band and modern band. we will continue working with the theatre development fund.
During the 2016-2017 school year we had a certified arts teacher in house.  We also partnered with Bronx Arts Ensemble where our students had residencies in Musical Theatre and Violins.

We presently offer visual arts and Orchestra. It is our plan to offer digital arts  and dance for the 2017-2018 school year.  

Our Arts program continues to allow students to develop creatively and challenge their knowledge of style, artists and cultural contributions to the world of the Arts. We support the individual talents that students posses in music performance, music theory and visual arts. Q44_1: We continue to work closely with our art teacher to ensure that he has the resources to develop student skills and to engage them in projects that challenge their abilities in the realm of visual arts. This program allows students to continue working on various class projects after school or to engage themselves in a special project designed for the group by our art teacher. An integral part of our educational vision, the arts program at PS 396 provides a comprehensive, learner-centered approach to instruction in music, theater and the fine arts. Our goal is to provide an equitable and accessible arts education for all students. We believe in the importance of recognizing, honoring and supporting students’ different learning styles and in developing questioning and decision-making skills that inspire them to embrace their own authentic voice. Conceptual, critical and creative thinking, social skills and cultural awareness are all aspects of art and music making that are nurtured and encouraged at PS 396. The music, art and theater teachers, along with resident artists, collaborate with classroom teachers to support our inter-disciplinary curriculum and celebrate school events. In addition to our designated program, we enrich the arts experience for our students with parent and child art workshops, arts residencies, after school enrichment programs, cultural partnerships and museum visits.
Q45_1: The social-emotional support we offer our students is fundamentally nurtured by the arts program here at PS 396. In a world that is not always welcoming or sustaining, we offer our students a safe place to fund their caring, confidence and build their inner resiliency in a way no other discipline or subject matter can be as successful as the arts.

Q42_R1_C10: they will be providing services after school
Q44_1: The Bronx Arts Ensemble provides a variety of arts experiences to our students in visual arts, dance and music. Students meet with Bronx Arts Ensemble teachers weekly to learn various arts forms and perform or showcase their work at the end of each semester.
Students in grades 9-12 receive visual arts instruction in Required Art and Painting courses.

Our school's arts program includes a visual and creative arts elements which focuses on sketch art, pottery, mannequin and marionette making and mural design and painting. Tenth, eleventh, and twelfth grade students have the opportunity to enroll in elective drama, modern art appreciation, and music appreciation and film classes. Additionally, ninth grade English language learners receive dramatic instruction through Lincoln Center Project LEAD. Tenth grade students participate, with an artist in residence, the August Wilson LeAp program which provides them the opportunity to perform at the annual August Wilson Monologue competition. Extra-curricular activities include guitar club, photography club and digital editing. PM school College Now courses include photo and digital music composition as well as a graphic arts classes in conjunction with Bronx community College. Additionally, New Beginnings Performing Arts Studio provides ninth graders with a residency program in dance. We continue to partner with Theater for a New Audience.  Furthermore, this year we have expanded the variety of field trips to include trips to the Metropolitan Museum of Art for ALL 9th graders as well as continued trips to BAM for the annual poetry presentation.

Our music department offers a diverse and challenging course of study in music. From performance fundamentals studied freshman year, to conducting, writing, and reading all levels and styles of music, we continue to offer quality music education to each and every student in our school. Included are sequential programs in string orchestra, band, piano, and choir, with multiple ensembles to suit every ability level.

The Drama, Music and Art departments have enjoyed another great year. It is our mission to provide our students with opportunities for interdisciplinary experiences that combine the unique mix of fine arts, arts, music and drama. Our students have a regular opportunity to perform. Our Mandarin language students performed original songs at NYU in a contest and won two awards. At Science, we enjoyed a high-caliber winter concert and spring concert featuring our Concert Band, Jazz Band, Chorus and Orchestra. These groups are preparing for the spring concert. Our fall play: "The Importance of Being Earnest" was a big hit and our spring musical: "Fiddler on the Roof" is in rehearsal for a late May performance. S!NG gave a smashing performance of hysterical spoofs written and performed by its many members. Our students have participated in our annual Mask creation contest, Japanese singing contest and were winners in the NYU "Rock that Movie" contest. Many of our artists have been recognized in myriad contests around the city, especially in photography.

Q42_R1_C1: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
Q44_1:
We are the grateful recipients of Lincoln Center Education Arts in the Middle Initiative. Through Lincoln Center we are providing our students with experiences in dance, music, theater, visual arts and mixed media. We are integrating the arts through our social studies curriculum. Our teachers have weekly planning sessions with the teaching artists. These meetings ensure clear and meaningful student outcomes and support that our students clearly understand the purpose of each activity and the learning outcomes. Our students visited the Metropolitian Museum of Art and The Studio Museum to view the collections relevant to our social studies units with the Lincoln Center Teaching Artists. Students have also seen performances both in school and at Lincoln Center in the above mentioned genres. The entire school had the opportunity to attend performances at Lincoln Center. Our arts Committee has planned and implemented a family arts event for our community. The goal of our school is to ensure that the arts are a rountine for students, parents and our entire school community.
In addition to Lincoln Center Education, our school has a growing orchestra program.  Sixth graders receive orchestra instruction during the day and we have an elective afterschool Orchestra Club.  Members of the club will be going to NYSSMA and will perform three pieces that they have learned.  Our orchestra will perform Pomp and Circumstance as well as the Star Spangled Banner at Graduation.

East Fordham Academy for the Arts provides all students with the opportunity to select from a menu of visual arts, music, theater, and/or dance as an Arts elective, and study their chosen art form for three years. 

Our comprehensive Arts programs gives students the opportunity to develop their talents in a variety of dance genres such as, jazz, cultural, ballroom, and performance dance. Students can also practice chorus, vocals, concert band, sculpting, sketching, painting, set design and mural design. 

In addition, we have partnerships with various cultural organizations, including Bronx Arts Ensemble, Broadway Jr., Doing Art Together!, and Dancing Classrooms. Through these partnerships, we are able to provide students with direct Arts education with experts in various fields.

Our Arts goal for the 2016-2017 school year is for students to express themselves in various art forms through performances, develop leadership skills by sharing performance and classroom responsibilities, articulate connections between the Arts and their own emerging identities as artists, and become informed about the live performances they will attend. Our ultimate goal is to become the model Middle School for the Arts in New York City.

Our school has a fifteen year relationship with the DreamYard Project. Through year-long residencies, DY artists meet to plan sessions and teach with Marble Hill teacher in a two hour block weekly class.  All 9th and 10th grade students take a DY class of their choice for the year: theater, visual art, dance, film or music production. One of the 10th grade choices for their art class is a film class that is taught by a classroom teacher who was trained by a DY teacher for five years. DY also provides after-school arts opportunities off-site such as Saturday arts classes at their DY Center in the Bronx and Poetry Exchange group that includes elementary, middle and high schools in the Bronx, Japan and South Korea. Additionally DreamYard had included us in an ILearn project with Morocco where students and teachers from schools in Morocco do virtual exchange with our school.  Another long-standing partnership is with Lincoln Center (Open Stages).    Through this program, our entire 10th grade sees 1-2 live theater events each year. This year we also received an Arts for ELL grant from the DOE. We added on two additional dance classes that meet 2 times a week as well as two  digital photography classes that meet once a week. Lastly, we have a NYC Photo elective taught by a Marble Hill teacher.

Q44_1: The Arts program at Bronx Theatre High School provides students with a well-rounded exposure to various forms of the arts. Students at Bronx Theatre High School are encouraged early on to work with each other as an ensemble, and this is conveyed through various forms of artistic expression such as performance, set & costume design and visual arts. As students progress through grade levels, they are given numerous opportunities to work with content teachers and Roundabout Theatre Teaching Artists to explore various aspects of the arts including set design, costume design, dance and acting. Students who express interest in dance work with our in-house Dance Company and choreograph performances.  All graduating seniors have the opportunity to "walk" on a Roundabout Theatre Broadway stage. Advanced, and dedicated thespians, who earn 10 or more art/theatre credits (including Advanced Placement Studio Art & Photography/Videography) are eligible to sit for the Comprehensive Theatre Regents examination in their senior year - they have an opportunity for an Arts Endorsed Regents upon graduation. Roundabout Theatre Company has been our partnering organization since the opening of the school in 2003 and continues to provide services to our students through in-class residencies and pre/post-show workshops. Studio art and Advanced Placement Studio Art are new offering at the school in which students complete a sequence of coursework and generate a portfolio of various works including Pop Art, Abstract Drip Art and multi-media collage.

Discovery integrates the arts throughout its Social Studies curriculum.  In particular, Discovery offers its students an US Art History and Appreciation course as a compliment to the US History course offered at the eleventh-grade level.  This course enables students to develop a basic understanding of how to examine art as well as an appreciation for the ways in which historical and cultural periods of American history were manifested in the art that they produced.  Students leave the course with a deeper understanding for history and a greater appreciation for the visual arts.

Our School Arts Program offers differentiated access for all students through visual art during the academic day, a guitar club and an after school Theater Program. After two visual art courses, our students are offered a variety of art electives to strengthen their perception. We aim to add an Art Club after school. There is guitar instruction during the lunch period daily and we offer The Parents’ Association family art-making events. We aim to nurture a reflective school culture that is supported by commitment to our students’ creativity and their reflective participation in the community. This year, two of our students attended the seven hour Saturday Program of The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art. One of our students had work selected for the Bronx Borough Art Exhibition at Lehman College. Our school is invested to bring equity to every child through the arts. Our principal is one of a select group of school leaders who has supported district initiatives to advance Action Research by hosting “Arts Monday” Professional Development on campus. Our art teacher has been a facilitator for Secondary Visual Art teachers for "Arts Mondays" for the past two years. Our administration supports the Chancellor’s Vision to build effective systems for evaluating teacher inquiry for Action Research that advances academic growth and student revision with optimal cognition. Our goals include establishing a partnerships for arts program. We plan to gain support for this from the Foundations Center.

Our arts program has a number of important goals. We seek, as part of our focus on American studies, to expose students to the careful study of art and music history. We also provide students with the skills necessary to create meaningful works of art on their own. Finally, we place great emphasis on inculcating in our students an interest in seeing and thinking about gallery and museum exhibits, plays, operas, musicals, and other theatrical performances, contemporary film, and modern and classical dance.

Public School 16 provides arts programs in the four disciplines of dance, music, theater and visual arts for students in pre-kindergarten through 5th grades. Arts instruction is provided by teaching artists from our established partnerships with the cultural organizations of Bronx Arts Ensemble and the New York Historical Society. These programs are supported, in part, by public funds from the NYC Department of Cultural Affairs in partnership with the City Council. To support and maintain school-wide arts instruction aligned to the Blueprint for the Arts, the teaching artists collaborate and plan with teachers in addition to providing professional development for classroom and cluster teachers during the school day. City Council funding also supports our after school African Dance and Drums program. We also offer arts workshops and provide opportunities for parents to visit arts institutions city-wide with their children during school trips and other parent engagement activities.
Q45_1: The school budget does not allow for an in-house arts teacher.  Therefore we rely on City Council funding for most arts partnerships.  Where is the "fair" in fair student funding?

Q44_1: PS 19 has a certified art teacher providing art services to students in grades K-6. For the past 14 years PS 19 has partnered with Bronx Arts Ensemble to deliver art, music and dance instruction to all our students in grades K-8. PS 19's facilities are limited due to overcrowding but we strive to provide as much arts education as possible. Students who participate in dance and music through programs not offered within our school are given the opportunity to display their talents in our school concerts and shows

We are a very comprehensive Arts education program.  Ms. Manning prepares all of her lessons according to the NYC Common Core Visual Arts Standards, NYC Visual Arts Scope and Sequence, and The NYS Arts Standards.  She uses art rubrics for each project.  Mrs. Manning has worked on teaching our students the 7 elements of art.  She taught them basic art concepts: How to sketch/draw, How to....., color (How to use a coloring rubric), use scissors, how to paint and painting tips.  The students work in groups and independently to complete  specific tasks.  Our student's art work is exhibited throughout the school building.  
This school year Mrs. Manning produced a Tribute to Black History Month in Song and Dance for Black History Show: A Tribute to Africa, Bob Marley, A Tribute to Motown-Song & Dance, A Tribute to Hip Hop Music from the 70's to the present, A Tribute to Martin Luther King Jr. and The March from Selma to Montgomery
This school year we participated in the CUNY/Creative Arts Team CASA After school Program.  The program took place after school  at P.S. 21 from 2:30-4:40 every Monday for 12 sessions.  It began on Monday, January 30, 2017 and the last session  was May 1, 2017.  The program supported our boys and girls social and emotional learning through the arts.

We provide music and dance education through our relationship with the 92nd Street Y. We also offer after school enrichment programs in which students can develop their talents in dance, music, drama, technical and visual arts. We produce an annual student talent show, display student art work throughout the building and expose our students to culturally diversified field trips

This is PS 68's 19th year of collaboration with Education Through Music, Inc. ETM provides a teaching artist for our pull out string orchestra. The artist provides instruction twice weekly during and after school hours. Our grade 4 and grade 5 string orchestras are made up of approximately 50 students per grade who receive instruction on their string instrument of choice. Our music program is comprised of general music, recorder, violin, viola, cello, and bass. General music instruction is provided one to two times weekly for 50 minutes for Pre K-5th grades. We also have a grade 3-5 chorus that meets weekly after school. All students perform in at least one concert each semester as well as at festivals, presentations, and graduations. Additionally, after school services in music (drumming), dance (hip-hop), and the visual arts are provided by the Phipps Community Development Corporation, which provides instruction to 100 of our students.

For the 2016-2017 school years we partnered with Notes in Motion providing dance instruction to identified students on grades two through five. Over the past ten years we have experienced great success through our partnership with Notes in Motion, each year the cooperating teachers and the dance instructors meet to determine the focus for the year, this allows the teaching artists to connect their lessons to an academic focus area. In addition, this year we have expanded the program to include a two part Parent and Child Workshop, where families can come in to watch a performance by the Amanda Selwyn Dancers and also to participate in a dance lesson where parents can learn about some of the things that their children have been experiencing. 

Our second partnership has been with Inside Broadway for a theater residency with identified fourth and fifth grade students. Here students are given the opportunity to create and perform in their very own musical. This residency helps to bolster our students’ confidence level as they perform for their audience.  Students and parents are excited about this wonderful opportunity and show their full support at our culminating performance. 

In addition, four of our students were awarded dance scholarships through Ballet Tech. This year, we hosted three seasonal performances and two performances for our dance and theater residencies. These performances provide our parents, teachers and students with an opportunity to watch our students as they showcase their talents and the skills.

Our collaboration with Education Through Music continues to enhance our string instrumental program. The school orchestra has grown from 42 students in its first year to 92 students in our third year! This year the orchestra collaborated with One World Middle School in a holiday and Spring to the delight of students seeking admission to the school in sixth grade. P.S. 87 will join several schools across the City in an annual performance at Lehman College.  Our long term partnership with Studio in a School creates a vibrant visual arts environment.  Parents and students have also completed their second mural.  This mural, supported by a generous NYC Family Engagement grant, will be permanently installed in the lobby of our school. Our dance program is made possible by Music for Many and it was expanded this year to include Mary Poppins in Grade 2, Oliver in Grade 3 and Hip Hop in Grade 4. Grade 1 performance of Lion King World has become a school tradition.  Our Grade 3 chorus meets at 7 a.m. in the morning and the Grade 4 and 5 chorus meets during their lunch period once a week.  Music For Many has extended their support of our kindergarten students for the 2017-18 school year.

Q37_4: parent/student after school workshops and parent arts nights
Q44_1: Public School 96, The Richard Rodgers School, is a diverse school community committed to creating an educational environment of excellence for all participants. Our goal is to have all of our students take an active role in their arts education through hands on activities and explorations.  PS 96 offers arts education in the fields of visual arts, music, dance and theater through granted programs, programs through cultural organizations, and in class instruction. We are proud of the programs that are available to our students including The Little Orchestra, chorus, band, and Dancing Classrooms. Our students receive weekly arts and music education. Many are able to take part in an abundance of after school arts programs including Little Orchestra and a variety of programs through the 21st Century Leadership Grant in dancing, theater and music. Parents and families are connected to their student's arts education through our interactive online art gallery featured on artsonia.com. Parents have also connected to their child's art education through after school engagement opportunities such as work shops and paint nights!

P.S. 97's goal has been to provide instruction in the arts and to integrate it into the curriculum through a variety of instructional initiatives according to the Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts for both visual art and music.  Our students have participated in giving musical choral concerts for award ceremonies, school assemblies, and senior centers.  The students participate in after school enrichment activities which include cheerleading, music, and arts-n-crafts.   Many students choose to join a club which meets during their recess time.    These students can be apart of chorus, recorder group, or a visual arts club.  The visual arts club creates inspirational posters for the school, dance festival posters for each class in the school, and decorations for school awards assemblies.   All students participate in the annual dance festival.  Each grade creates a choreographed dance which is performed for the school,   parents, and community.   In addition to the events that take place during school hours, families participate in Family Art Night. These events take place twice a year and over 200 people have enjoyed spending time painting and creating art.

The goals of the visual arts and music program are to allow students to experience a robust rewarding and challenging curriculum. Students are introduced to various art forms and music education. Through exploration, students improve in other academic areas and our main goal is to enrich their arts experiences on a day to day basis by allowing them to form connections, make choices, and converse with each other about their work. Building upon and scaffolding with their other subjects in school makes a more rewarding learning experience for our students.

Public School 105 continues to be dedicated to providing our students with exposure to a variety of disciplines in the Arts. We employ two full-time Music teachers, a full-time Drama teacher, and a full-time visual arts teacher. We also have a number of affiliations with outside organizations, such as: National Dance Institute, Bronx Dance Theater, Guggenheim Museum, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Carnegie Hall and Lincoln Center. Additionally, members of the drama club, chorus and art club attend a yearly trip to Broadway, and have seen such shows as Stomp, Annie, Wicked, and this year, the Lion King. Specific highlights our Arts programs include: - Third Grade students participate in the Bronx Dance Theater working toward a culminating activity which is performed for our school community. - The National Dance Institute (NDI)provides themed expressive dance workshops for grade 4, also with a culminating activity/performance that takes place in June. - SWAT is an after school dance program offered through NDI, that provides dance enrichment for selected students of various grade levels. - The school chorus and band, under the direction of our Music teacher performs both on and off site concerts throughout the year. This year the chorus has performed at Riker's Island, the Bronx VA Hospital and various tree lighting ceremonies throughout the Bronx. - The school drama performs various shows throughout the year for our school community. - The school Art club creates the setting and backdrops for our school performances.

The PS 106 school community continues to strengthen in our ongoing effort to provide a well-rounded arts education program. Our teachers are passionate about education and our belief in arts education as a key component in every child's learning. Collaboration among students, staff and parents is the foundation for supporting student learning in all areas. Our common goal is to escalate student participation, heighten best practices in teaching and include parents and community in our partnership for an exemplary arts education program. We also work in collaboration with available artist residency programs to expose our students to as much culture and experience in the arts as possible. This year our residency programs included Studio in a School, Dancing Classrooms, Park Avenue Armory, and Disney Kids. Each of these experiences allows students to make connections between the arts while applying depth of knowledge in core subjects, including Language Arts, Math and Social Studies.Together, our teachers are working to help our students to grow creatively and intellectually, while having positive experiences for self-expression.

Our school art program will focus more on visual arts, Dance and Music in the upcoming school year.  We are excited with our past partnerships with Notes In Motion and Inside Broadway and will extend these through next year.

Q42_R1_C10: Some of the artists did not provide satisfactory services
Q44_1: At P.S. 121 we believe in combining the arts with academic instruction. We have two visual arts teachers who service grades Pre-K - 5. All of our students receive visual arts instruction on a weekly basis. Our fifth grade students receive ballroom dancing lessons.  Every year several students are picked to compete in ballroom dancing competitions in the city.  We have been in partnership with the organization, Dancing Classrooms for several years. Currently we have one certified music teacher.  He provides music instruction to students in grades 3-5.  He also provides individual music lessons to those students who are part of the fifth grade band.   The fifth grade band meets after school three days a week. During the school year the students perform in winter and spring concerts.  For the last three years we have been in partnership with the organization, Music for Many.  The teaching artists have worked with students in grades K-3 to provide instruction in music and dance.  These artist in residency programs  have been a successful part of our arts curriculum.

We offer students a choice of arts electives 3-4 times per week. This year’s arts elective class choices are visual arts and music/theater. Our visual arts class is taught by a full-time arts certified teacher and our music/theater class is taught by a full-time music teacher. We continue to utilize Musica De Camera as one of the finest arts organizations NYC has in classical music. We have increased student involvement in music through a partnership with Musica De Camara teaching violin to our students after school. Our music program is budding every year with performances showcasing the best MS 127 has to offer. Our partnership with our after school program, Sports and Arts in Schools continues to further offer students with additional instruction and exposure in the arts. Some classes offered this year include African drumming, vocal music, piano, step, Hip-Hop dance, water color painting, sculpture and sewing.

Q42_R1_C1: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
Q44_1: JHS 144 has a tradition of providing students with educational opportunities in the arts. The students at J.H.S. 144 are offered music, visual art and theater. The school employs a full time music and art teacher along with a part time theater teacher. This year the students have been awarded scholarships to arts summer camps, as well as acceptances to many of New York City's arts high schools. Music instruction centers around the J.H.S. 144 Band program where there is an emphasis placed upon instrumental performance and music literacy. The visual art program focuses on art making and is project based. The Arts Department produces two shows a year where the students perform or exhibit work. For the past four school years, J.H.S. 144 has partnered with Lincoln Center Education as part of the "Arts in the Middle" grant. This year, the students traveled to Lincoln Center to attend two performances as well as to art museums to study works with a Lincoln Center teaching artist. Lincoln Center Education also produced 5 performances in the J.H.S. 144 auditorium. These performances were used as the basis for units of study with Lincoln Center teaching artists.

Studio Art I will consist of a basic, yet thorough, overview and application of many different artistic styles and mediums.  Through introductory units that focus on the Elements and Principles of Design, student will have an overall understanding of the fundamentals of the visual/fine arts.  Elements of design represent the general visual aspects of how to make art (line, shape, color, etc), while Principles of Design show students how to apply the Elements in creative/abstract ways (Balance, Proportion, Movement, etc).  These Elements and Principles of Design are essential for both the novice and advanced artist to create striking works of art that convey powerful personal ideas/emotions from the person creating them.

After students have a solid foundation of the Elements and Principles of design, they will then utilize those lessons in different mediums within units such as Sculpture and Graffiti.  With each additional unit, follow up interim assessments will be given to the students in order to see how well the Element and Principle lessons are being enacted when drawing/sculpting further assignments.

In the end, the students will eventually move into a Life Drawing unit, which contains lessons that focus heavily on technical drawing, rather than creative drawing.  These life drawing lessons are somewhat complex, and will culminate in the students drawing themselves in a detailed picture that brings together all previous skills they have learned in prior lessons.

P.S. 153 has a full time music teacher who teaches key boarding to Grades K-2 students using Music in the Brain curriculum.  In grade 3, students engage in a recorder curriculum, and in grades 4-5 students are invited to participate in band or chorus which meet afterschool. We also have a visual arts teacher who teaches classes in Grades K-5. In addition, we have cultural organizations such as ballroom dancing, and the Bronx Arts Ensemble that provide dance programs. Bronx Arts Ensemble also provides African drumming lessons, instrument lessons and dance lessons. Bronx Opera provides theater/music opportunities for students in grades 4 and 5. Classroom teachers are encouraged to use the Blueprints for Arts to incorporate the arts into the content areas. Teachers also plan educational trips to various cultural organizations to expose students to other arts programs.

Our schools' arts program provides a variety of opportunities for all members of the school community to be exposed to, appreciate, and participate in the arts. Our arts program continues to show exemplary results year after year. These talents are showcased with several themed concerts (vocal and instrumental) and assemblies throughout the school year. Our annual Art Expo which is held in May highlights outstanding student art work, from K-8. It is an integral part of the school culture, as shown in displays, throughout the building. Literacy competencies are also embedded within the arts curriculum to support our students’ growth in the area of English language arts.

Because the mission of PS 160 is to provide a standards-based education through high expectations and creativity, it is the goal of the school’s art program to follow NCCAS, NY State, and NYC Blueprint standards in providing sequential music and visual arts instruction from PK to Grade 5. Also, it is the school’s goal to expose the students, over the course of their years at PS 160, to the other branches of the arts – dance and theater. Furthermore, PS 160 is moving toward a model of education that aligns the curriculum to Social Studies and the Arts across all grades. In this way, PS 160 maintains a tradition of education that reaches back to ancient Greece in molding the mind, body, and spirit of the learner.
Q45_1: PS 160 is a PK-grade 5 barrier free school located in Section 5 of Co-op City in the Bronx. Two other schools are housed on the PS 160 campus, a charter middle school, and a district 75 program. PS 160 is working toward the goal of becoming a STEAM school. The Arts are a key component in this process.

Q44_1: PS 178X is committed to providing a well rounded arts education. The arts are alive, well, and celebrated at PS 178X. All students, K-5, participate in grade-wide assembly presentations. Classroom teachers, with the support of our arts teachers, produce and direct student performances that tap each arts discipline. Art work for the stage is created to set the scene for each assembly and further enhance the audience's experience. Teachers also integrate the arts into other curriculum areas. For example, it is quite common to hear poems being sung, and see math concepts creatively displayed, as well as stories or historical events being acted out. In addition, students create posters for events such as Respect for All and NY Recycles. Furthermore, our end-term celebrations highlight our arts education program and include music, singing, dance, and public speaking. Our goal is to continue to further develop the teaching and learning of music, visual art, theatre, and dance.

Middle School 181 is dedicated to the development of appreciation of the Arts in all students. The Arts program endeavors to provide a rigorous standards based approach to the teaching of music, drama, and fine arts. We strive to have all students develop an appreciation for the arts as well as foster an understanding of cultural perspectives and contributions. Students explore the arts through constructive critiques, performances, projects and activities. Middle School 181 is committed to expand its music and arts program to better prepare students for opportunities in high school and beyond.

The school's art program seeks to engage students in the visual arts through an interdisciplinary lens that incorporates the school's Health Theme and the Common Core Literacy Standards. For example, elective courses such as the human body support both the visual arts as well as writing across the content areas.

The Bronx High School for Writing and Communication Arts offers a wide variety of courses and programs for students in the arts. From creative writing, journalism, and playwriting to drawing, painting, sculpture, film and photography we provide opportunities for students to be involved in the arts in and out of the classroom. We partner with Epic Theatre Ensemble, Exploring the Arts Foundation, Open Door, Community Word Project,The Morgan Library Museum, and the Art Deco Society to provide arts enrichment in drama, film, writing,visual arts, dance, and stagecraft.  Our award-winning lead partner Epic Theatre Ensemble works with us to engage our students in contemporary social justice issues through acting and playwriting. Our ETA grant expands the Epic program with a dynamic film program. Community Word Project teaching artists work with our students to create and perform poetry and design and paint murals in our school. Our students proudly produce poetry anthologies, short films, a school newspaper and a literary magazine. Through our Morgan Library Book Project grant, our students visited the museum and received training in illumination and bookmaking in our school by Morgan book artists, creating their own books. Five of our students won awards this year for their Morgan books. Our student's art was exhibited in the Bronx Borough Art Fair at the Bronx Museum. Additionally, we are expanding our partnership with Open Door to bring dance, film and teaching artists into our classrooms.

Bronx Lab Arts Program Synopsis 2016-2017

Bronx Lab students will have the opportunity to explore the arts through dance instruction, provided during their lunch hour.  

Students will learn Hip Hop and International dance styles while the history, culture and contribution of hip hop music and dance which instills messages of strength, self-confidence and positivity. 

The students will be introduced to the art of storytelling using their dancing to communicate their ideas and feelings to their audience.  Through international dance workshops, students will gain a familiarity with, and appreciation of, foreign traditions and cultural diversity. 

Programs introduce students to the geographic areas where different dance and musical styles evolved, and the ways in which these styles have influenced other international styles.  Students will build their knowledge and skills during the course of the semester, culminating in a dance performance at a Town Hall gathering.

About Arts Horizons
For almost 38 years, Arts Horizons has impacted the lives of more than 9 million children and adults through the power of the arts. They are committed to making the performing, visual, literary and media arts and artistic expression equitable and accessible to diverse people of all ages and abilities. We believe that the arts are fundamental to a child's education, stimulating learning, enriching the teaching process and providing lifelong learning.
Arts Horizons is a NYC Department of Education Approved Vendor.

Currently our students participate in our visual art program periods per week. We also have 1 section of theatre, taught by one of our ELA teachers. Each year we have an art show, showcasing art pieces created by our students and we also have multiple plays occurring throughout the academic year.

The theme of our school is health careers; therefore, most of our students take their electives in science and health career courses. Students take art in grades 10, 11, and 12. Since there is very little space in the students' schedule to provide additional classes in the arts, we allow students to have a dance club which is student run. Students then perform in talent shows, Latino celebration, Black History Month shows, and during our multicultural shows. When the budget and programming allows, students are offered a video-making course in grade 11 where the students make their own short videos.  Our students take trips to museums and watch films in an art class which supports our history classes. Our students in the Art Class created tee-shirts and canvas bags with artistic designs and quotes.  Due to a grant, Community Word Project has worked with our special eduction, ENL, and general eduction students to create an anthology which was published and related art work.  During a parent presentation, students read their poems and displayed their accompanying art work.  During the spring semester, Community Word Project is working with an art class to paint a mural which is based on themes from their anthologies on a wall within the school.

We have added an AP art to the curriculum. In addition, we added painting courses to our art curriculum and have incoporated the Common Core Standards into our lessons. We continue to offer studio art and introduction to art courses as well.

Through our partnership with Education through Music, every student participates in a weekly General Music Class. Approximately 20 students receive additional instruction through an after-school Select Choir. Students also receive band lessons twice per week during the school day, and one day per week after school.

At Young Voices Academy of the Bronx we know the importance the arts play in the academic success of students. For this reason we decided to partner with Education Through Music. All of our students receive music instruction weekly by a certified music teacher. Students exhibit what they have learned twice a year through a winter and spring concert. It is a great celebration of their talents and musical growth. We look forward to continued musical development at our school for all of our students and teachers.
Currently, All students in grades 6-8 are programmed for visual arts instruction for the entire school year. Each class is programmed for two periods of art instruction per week.

The Matilda Avenue School is in the 2nd year of existence, servicing approximately 78 students in Kindergarten & First Grade.  Our arts curriculum includes a partnership with Education Through Music, which provides general music instruction to all of our Kindergarten and First Grade students for 45 minutes a week.  Students in First Grade had the opportunity to work with a teaching artist from Alvin Ailey Dance in a ten week residency that culminated in a dance performance.  Students in both Kindergarten and First Grade also received a unit of dance instruction provided by a cluster teacher 45 minutes three times a week for six weeks during their gym classes.  Students also receive visual arts instruction 45 minutes one time a week provided by a cluster teacher.  Classroom teachers incorporate theater into their literacy curriculum within the classroom.  As we continue to grow, we hope to be able to offer additional arts instruction.

Bronxdale High School's arts line-up includes a school-specific dance program with a designated dance room that was inaugurated last year. Our dance sequence can lead to an arts endorsement on a diploma. Partnerships with Alvin Ailey and Ballet Hispanico give students an opportunity to learn about, practice, and see dance performances in varied genres. 

Through Campus collaboration, students have an opportunity to participate in the campus-wide music program via membership in the Campus band. 

Bronxdale has built up a Culinary Academy in an industrial kitchen space so that stduents may have an opportunity to learn about the culinary arts through a hands-on class that leads to a CTE designation. The program includes work-based learning experience. 

Bronx a visual arts program that includes graphic/media arts. The arts program begins with an introduction to visual arts and builds up for students who are interested in pursuing visual and graphic arts through opportunities to creat public art, participate in arts activities and competitions outside of school, and display artwork throughout the school.

Theater is offered throughout ELA and ESL classes, while film is an option as an elective course. Partnerships with cultural organizations and community based organizations have allowed us to provide students with opportunities to learn about film, drama, arts, and dance in the arts-specific classes as well as across content areas.

We currently have two full-time visual arts teachers who teach drawing, photography, graphic design, and painting.  We have a theater teaching artist who works in collaboration with our 105th grade ELA teachers and does an in-class residency with our students.  We have after-school and Saturday dance, guitar, and drumming programs offered through Bronx Arts Ensemble.  Also have a partnership with the Morgan Library and Museum that provides a book-making curriculum, teacher professional development, and trips to our 9th graders.

Students are provided with foundational courses in the arts to enrich their experiences and knowledge pertaining to the disciplines. In addition, pending budgetary availability, we look to offer enrichments clubs pertaining to the arts, like dance, drama and/or chorus.

This marks another year of working with Education Through Music. It continues to be a great success and end of year shows continue to demonstrate great growth in our students.  This year, we were accepted into the Broadway Junior Program and we were able to produce our very first musical. This musical allowed all of our students to play a vital role( set design, costume design, dancers, singers, actors, lighting crew, stage crew, stage managers, etc)  This opportunity really exposed our students to new endeavors. Also Dancing Classrooms came and visited our school for the first time.  Our students were able to be apart of an actual competition as well. They met with each of our 8th grade classes for 45 minutes once a week for 20 weeks.  Awesome experience. I believe they will be returning next year.

During the 2016-2017 school year, the arts program at Baychester Middle School aims to expose 6th-grade and 7th-grade students to elements of dance and film. The arts program will focus on creative expression using dramatic stage expression. Students are encouraged to investigate various artistic movements and theater presentations. Baychester's program will investigate the history of theater while getting hands-on opportunities of self-expression.
Q45_1: I invite you to check out our school musical on 6/8/17.  It is without a doubt one of the best programs in the city.

Q44_1:
The arts program at Pelham Preparatory Academy focuses on visual arts, and music arts. The visuals arts program is charged with producing the majority of the art work displayed throughout the building including sculptures, murals, and other artistic pieces. The music department exposes students to many levels of the arts including music appreciation classes, and vocal and instrumental classes. Students are also given the opportunity to participate in various campus-wide bands including the beginners, intermediate, and Latin-Jazz bands. These bands perform at sporting events, graduations, concerts, and other campus and community events.
In addition, our partnership with Lincoln Center has provided multiple opportunities for our students to explore the performing arts
Q45_1: n/a

Q44_1: BAHS works with a variety of educational consultants to provide students with access to a myriad of art forms: dancing, singing and acting. Art programs are created based on student interest during and after the school day. Art programs are designed to include all learners through the lens of character development.

Bronx Park has an interdisciplinary curriculum with a focus on arts inclusion. The arts inclusion means that all summative projects have required elements of the arts blended into the performance. These performances are evaluated by teachers, peers, and individual students based on rubric criteria. There are roughly 5 major interdisciplinary performances each year. Students have completed two integrated theater projects and three visual arts projects. Students are offered an array of arts electives to choose from, including fashion, drama and theater, visual arts, capoeira, step, digital media, which include movie making and editing, digital graphic design and culinary arts. These electives are extra curricular, run for 20 week semesters, and students receive 120–180 minutes of the arts each week. Within the regular school day students also recieve instrumental music, visual arts, and digital arts enrichment courses that run in 10 week cycles. As we grow, our goals are to add licensed staff to expand the arts that we can offer.

Next year we plan on extending our contract with Education Through Music to include band for our 5th graders. We continue to work with Ballet Tech. This year we included a collaboration with Inside Broadway for our Pre-K and K students. They enjoy singing, dancing and performing. The 4th graders went to Broadway to see CATS. We are hoping to hire a licensed Arts teacher next year for fine arts and media development.

Public School 6X strives to provide all of our students with an opportunity to realize their talents in the arts. Through engagement in the arts, students can discover their passion, as well as discover the practical applications of the arts as they move from elementary school to secondary school, and then to college. We intend to meet these goals by aligning our arts curriculum with the Blueprint for the Arts, and the Common Core Learning Standards in all core subjects.  Our vision is to 'be our best,' 'love learning,' and 'inspire the world.'

Classroom teachers provide music, dance, drama and visual arts for grades K-5. Interdisciplinary thematic units of study, provide opportunities for students to engage in projects that includes art, music and dance. A grant funded a residency program from Flamenco Vivo where our scholars were exposed to Flamenco dancing and the history and culture associated with the dance form for ten weeks that resulted in a culminating performance.

There are several goals that are incorporated into the arts program at P.S. 47: Goal 1-to provide a variety of art disciplines and create a continuum from k to 5 that will allow children to explore and discover their talents/ Goal 2-to develop a life-long love and appreciation for the arts/ Goal 3-to infuse the arts into all content areas, allowing teachers to provide differentiation based on individual student modalities and talents. P.S. 47 has adopted the Reggio Emelia philosophy which originated in Southern Italy. This philosophy is basically a "projects approach" to literacy and content area studies. Through the Reggio Emelia philosophy, children work cooperatively to develop art projects and culminating activities that include researching, writing and oral presentations. Goal 4-to align the arts with the New York State Standards for the Arts; creating and performing in the arts; knowing and using arts materials and resources; responding to and analyzing works of art.

C.S. 67's arts program consists of instruction within both the arts classroom and all general education classrooms. We strive to incorporate the arts into daily lesson plans through the use of "move to improve" and "visual thinking strategies". Within the visual arts classroom, scholars engage in painting, sculpting, drawing, print-making and explore various tools, mediums and techniques. Scholars have gained knowledge on different artists, analyzed various forms of artwork and cultural differences through the history of art. Scholars are encouraged to reflect on their own artwork and provide peer feedback through the use of rubrics and checklists. Teachers also provide specific feedback through a "glow", "grow" and "how to" which is collected in their art portfolios. C.S. 67 has also partnered with an outside organization that provides after-school programs such as dance and mask making. We have also provided opportunities for parental engagement in the Arts such as our "Parent Paint Night". Lastly, scholars are provided many opportunities to engage in school shows, and dances. Our Arts Program uses the K-5 blue prints, and the Common Core Standards to drive instruction.

Q42_R1_C2: Sports and Arts in Schools Foundation
Q44_1: I.S. 98 Arts Program is designed to expose our students to many different artistic materials and processes. We encourage our students to try their best in order to help promote self confidence and positive attitudes. Our arts program also guides our students through a wide variety of self exploration. We teach our students to change from being a passive observer to an active participant in all aspect of their lives.

Q42_R1_C1: Learning through an Expanded Arts Program
Q44_1: Every student in grades 6, 7, and 8 are provided with instruction in music and visual arts aligned with the New York State Standards and the New York City Blueprint for the Arts. In our visual arts program, students learn to use a variety of art media and techniques, along with studying many artists and their work. Students learn to critique their own work and the work of other students. Students who are interested in applying to art high schools participate in a rigorous after school program designed to improve their portfolios, teach them how to interview and present their work. In our general music program, students learn about key moments in music history, and a basic knowledge of music theory and notation. Students also have opportunities to compose music using technology. They learn how to play the guitar in the guitar lab. Our music teacher works with 8th graders during their lunch or advisory period to help them prepare for auditions to high schools for music. We collaborate with our school-based organization, Learning through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP), for several after school arts programs. Our music teacher runs a modern band program, including guitar, bass, drums, keyboards and vocals. This guitar ensemble has performed at district events and most school events. Two of our paraprofessionals conduct the drama program through LEAP and have performed plays for the parents, staff, and students. Dance and visual arts is also offered through LEAP.

The goals for the CS 150 Arts Program is to increase the number of programs offered. The Art Program will also work in conjunction with outside organizations to support and enhanced our students cognitive skills, and develop a collaborative environment for our students through the program.  The Art Program will facilitate students to use problem solving skills to find to find solutions to adverse issues in the arts and also in their lives.  Students will be able to exhibit a mean of self expression through the arts and share those skills with the school community.  With the aide of the New York Blue Print for the Arts, students will be able to meet the standards by exploring the essential elements needed for monitoring their learning experience.  This can be done through formative assessment strategies and set criteria to improve students achievement/learning goals.  Clear criteria will be implemented where students will be using language specific for the blueprints for learning. Students will use these standards to connect to the common core standards and develop various components to complete projects and become lifelong learners in the world.

P.S 195 has a fine arts and music program. Students learn the elements that make up each of these disciplines and are exposed to various forms of visual art and music  performances. Higher order thinking skills are supported through these project based disciplines.

The Literacy and Arts School continues to strive for an arts program that will expose all students to as many different genres of the arts as possible. Our visual arts program additionally attempts to infuse the arts into all other curricula areas, including supporting the new Common Core Standards. The connection among math, literacy, social studies, and science and art is exemplified by the projects produced by our students. In addtion to our visual arts program, dance has become a key element for enthusiasm for our fourth and fifth graders. Ballroom and Latin dancing have become an integral part of our arts program. Now, for a fifth year, we have been fortunate to collaborate with Inside Broadway, a not-for-profit organization to provide experiences and learning opportunities in theatre and dance.

CS 211 believes strongly in the transformative effect that art has on children’s lives. As you walk through the halls of our school, you are greeted by beautiful student art. We offer a comprehensive visual arts curriculum Prek-8th grade. Students at CS 211 participate in a variety of performing arts residencies. Grades K-2 participate in an early childhood movement residency where students learn about music and dance. In the 3rd and 5th grades, students engage in Alvin Ailey& Flamenco workshops, Not only do the students learn the dance form but also go watch professional dance performances. In the 5th and 8th grades, students participate in a long in-depth ballroom dance residency culminating with a dance gala. Our dance team has won several dance awards. Our Bilingual students, take part in a musical theater residency. Students learn the music & dance from a current theater production and then create and perform their own original theater pieces. CS 211 middle school has an active marching band. The band practices often and participates in various parades in New York City and neighboring towns. CS 211 offers a free after-school art program for our Ell’s to increase language acquisition. CS 211 hosts several family art workshops for students and parents to learn together. CS 211 holds an annual visual art show representing all PreK-8 students. The art show is not only a display of exemplary work but also an opportunity for families to make art together.
Q45_1:
CS 211 is a pre-K-8 school serving 622 students located in the Tremont section of the Bronx 60 % of our families live below the poverty level, and 70 % of families receive some form of public assistance.  Our student population is comprised of 27% English language learners and 24% Students with Disabilities. 

We hope to be able to increase our arts offering by adding another art teacher to our faculty next year.

Q42_R1_C1: Caribbean Cultural Center - Visual Arts/Visual Arts Research & Res Ctr.
Q44_1: We have made huge strides in restoring the performing arts to the School of Performing Arts. For this school year, there is a full-time dance teacher and chorus teacher. Through our partnerships we have been able to bring in West African Dance, Hip-Hop Dance,Drumming with the congas, and band (trumpet, trombone,saxophone,guitar) during portions of the school day, after school, and on Saturdays. Even more is planned for the year to come.

At Explorations we will like to increase our students’ exposure to the Arts. We want provide our students with opportunities for exposure to Concerts, Dance Performance, Films, Theater Performance and Artwork Exhibits. We hired a music teacher for next year and plan to create an after school music program music.  We would like to enhance our students’ education by offering multiple clubs such as: music, step dance class, playwriting drama and poetry. In addition, we will incorporate three in school performance for the year that include music, theater and dance. We will continue to provide our students exposure the different arts programs such as “El Repertorio Espanol,” Lincoln Center Institute and Roundabout Theater. By doing this, we will provide instruction infused with Common Core Learning Standards and citywide expectations in the arts.
Q45_1: Our school core belief is that the arts program adds immense value to our students lives. We are committed to offering different arts exposure to all our students. For this school year, our greatest obstacle to offer arts program in our school has been the lack of funding and budget. Although we did not have and art teacher this year, we conducted several field trips and after school clubs such as poetry and dance. This year our 11th graders conducted a class project that culminated with a field trip to see the musical Hamilton at the Richard Rogers Theater. Our ENL students attended “El Repertorio Espanol” to see the play “El Quijotel. Our 9th graders attended the Jewish Museum to learn about the Holocaust, as part of class project called, “Make Empathy Great Again.” Our 10th graders attended the Hairy Ape sponsored by Park Avenue Armory. In addition to attending the performance, students received pre- and post-show workshops to discuss and debrief the play with teaching artist from Park Avenue Armory

Q44_1: Bronx Latin's vision is for a comprehensive music program in which students cultivate a knowledge and appreciation of music. We believe that an arts education is fundamental to the development of each individual and that the arts provide unique opportunities for cultural exchange and community understanding. Students will learn to read sheet music and play a range of percussion, brass, string and woodwind instruments, including keyboard, full drum-set, Congo drums, flute, recorder, trumpet, trombone, tuba, guitar (electric and acoustic) and voice and others. To enhance the arts program in the coming year, students will engage in a technology course incorporating elements of fine arts and photo editing in order to support artistic expression and 21st Century skills. Students also engage in a visual arts program in 8th, 10th, and 12th grades where students have different projects every year, culminating in final projects.

Q45_1: Fannie Lou Hamer Middle School provides the arts in conjunction with Marquis Studios, Music for many , Chineese Theather Works and Children's Aid Society. We are dedicated to using the arts to differentiate instruction. Therefore, visual arts are a key component to daily instruction. All three grades participate in both music and theater classes. The sixth and seventh grade integrate visual arts into their curriculum and host monthly dramatic performances by students. Students interested in pursuing art, music and dance are able to attend Children's Aid after school for small group workshops

Q44_1: Our goal at Community School 300 is to provide students with a balanced education of academic learning and fine arts instruction. Students are provided with performance and artistic opportunities in music, theater and visual arts education. Students' artistic talents are cultivated and celebrated at school wide events such as assembly programs, multicultural celebrations and theatrical performances. Evidence of our students' artistic talents can be seen through student work displayed in and around our school community.
