We showcase our students artistic talents each year during our annual talent and fashion shows also during our SISTAH Program for girls.

Q42_R1_C10: Not eligible for ELL/SWD grant for next year
Q44_1: The Arts Program here at The Fairmont Neighborhood School, has devoted serious dedication towards bringing in outside resources to our students this school year. We have continued partnerships with existing cultural arts organizations, as well as formed new relationships and partnerships with other arts' grants, to enhance both arts' instructional time for students, and professional development for designated arts' teachers in our building. Students have continued their studies with music, visual arts, and musical theater. Incorporating, storytelling, acting, and choreography, has been a significant element that has now been added to our arts curriculum. Because of this added components, students have another means to express themselves through various performance activities that musical theater can include. Overall, students have arts' engagements that consist of singing, dancing, acting, instrument-playing, and creating art through the use and application of critical skills and tools.
We are currently offering theatre to 7th and 8th grade students, Music to 6th and 7th grade, Drumming to 6th grade and visual arts to all students.

Students in grade 6 receive music three to four periods per week for the entire school year.

Students in grade 7 receive STEAM Design three to four periods per week for the entire school year.
Q45_1: Students in grade 8 received a French (foreign language)  in place of music and STEAM Design.

Q44_1:
Graphic Art:

The course has multiple components and is designed to learn art concepts based on typography and other types of textual design forms. It is also a course to expand the learner’s knowledge of art by contributing ideas, creating art hands-on and the development of one’s own sense and understanding of its meaning.


Art & Design:

This will exemplify an art studio setting where the learner will be responsible for developing their art projects and the processes involved. Art ideas and concepts will be explored but with the learner designing their own ideas and determining the outcome.

 

Visual Art:

This will be based on learning how to develop art as an art-making community. Explorations of art- making will be independent but group based. In this course the learner will learn concepts of art that focuses on learning about what it means to develop art and create art as a network of artists.

 

 

Grading will be based on the following criteria:

● Class work /Class projects(Product/Project-Based, Independent, collaborative) 

● In-class projects done individually and/or with peers if project requires it.

● Written reflection or written assignment which aligns with project requirement.

● Portfolio Development 

● Discussion & Presentation

Bronx Arts Ensemble provided Spoken Word and Visual Art courses to our student population. After School African Drumming and Dance was provided by consultant Roland Guerrero visiting artist.
Q45_1: We are a Transfer HS with over-aged under credited students who have previously attended several different schools. It is a challenge to offer only visual art courses. we would like to have a mixture of dance, theatre, fine art and film to provide students through curriculum provided to schools (that may be taught by teachers who are not certified in art) as well as the opportunity to have part time teachers (ex. a part time visual arts teacher and a part time music teacher).

Q44_1: The students at Urban Assembly School for Wildlife Conservation are able to explore a variety of art forms, materials and techniques, and sources for inspiration such as observation, memory, and imagination. Students look at, discuss and write about art from different perspectives, as well as their own art and art of peers. The students are able create their interpretation of the world through art,dance and music.

Currently at PAIHS Monroe we have an interdisciplinary Visual Arts program. The art teacher works closely with major discipline teachers to plan curricula that is project-based to support ELLs in learning English and major concepts they are studying in Social Studies, English, Native Language Arts, Math and Science. Students get experience using a wide variety of media, including pencil, charcoal, watercolor, acrylic, and digital art, while learning major content.


Next year we hope to include more museum field trips and community art partnerships. In addition, the visual arts teacher is helping more students each year apply to after-school, weekend and summer programs in the arts.
Q45_1: Our school serves recently arrived immigrant and refugee high school students, many of whom are from low-income families. They are Spanish-speaking students from different Latin American cultures who are adjusting to a new culture, a large city, and a new school environment, all while learning a new language.

Q44_1: As a alternative transfer high school Arturo A. Schomburg Satellite Academy tries to provide as many academic and artistic opportunities for our students to meet their graduation requirements and become well rounded citizens in society. Though our funding may make it challenging to provide as much arts as we would like, we have been able to work with consultants and our teachers to provide art programs. This year we have been able to offer improvisational theater classes after school, Ceramics and visual art classes during the school day, and a dance program after school as well. It is our hope to continue these programs and add more opportunities depending on funding.

Students attend art and music class three times a week with experienced and dedicated arts teachers. Students also learn weekly songs which are sung at the school's sing alongs on Monday mornings. Students participate in capoeira with Abada capoeira and through center times, students work in dramatic play, theatre and other art forms into their play. Students attend bi-weekly field trips to various cultural institutions to enrich their understanding of the world around them and the content in which they are studying.
Q45_1: We are a growing school currently in PK-2.

Q42_R1_C1: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
Q44_1: Currently we have a certified visual arts teacher who services the students in our school. She helps the teachers connect visual art to all of the content areas and assists the students with projects. In addition, she facilitates parent workshops twice a month, showing them how visual art connects to what their children are learning in school. We also have a partnership with Visual Thinking Strategies; six of our teachers have been trained thus far. One of our goals is to have four more teachers trained during the next school year. This is our fourth year having school-wide enrichment clubs once a week. Every Tuesday, students participate in clubs that are arts based. In addition, our students in grades 3-5 are provided with dance, theater and chorus after school for three days a week.

We are the first and only high school in the nation to offer all students a four year curriculum in narrative filmmaking. The goal of our film program is to prepare students for success in competitive colleges and aspirational 21st century careers. Our curriculum focuses on the habits of the mind of filmmakers, including visual thinking, critical literacy, storytelling, and collaboration, which is the synthesis of all skills (technical, artistic, business) into creating something original and representative of the creator's unique perspective

The Art Program at Bronx Career and College Preparatory High School was developed based on student's skill sets and interest. The students in grade 10 are given an introductory course to learn basic techniques. Students in their junior year are provided with a course that refines previously learned artistry techniques. Senior year students are selected by the art teacher as demonstrating interest in continuing to develop as artists. These students have developed an art portfolio for entry into college and/or possible career path. Additionally, a film course has been developed in conjunction with the humanities department to support the Global History Curriculum.

Bronx Regional High School is a transfer school that offers studio art and ceramics classes for students seeking to obtain their arts and/ or elective credits needed for graduation. But at its core, the program gives students so much more than just credentials. Students develop and build self-esteem and self-efficacy as they learn and master new skills. This is evidenced in the pride that students express as they speak about their work in class critiques and as they offer constructive feedback to their peers. A strong focus on literacy allows students to speak to each other using the language of art as they discuss both their work and the work of others. Further, students can carry their knowledge and engage in the language of art as they move beyond the classroom walls. The vast cultural mecca that is our beloved New York City offers students a wealth of resources to enrich their arts education experiences and support personal growth beyond the scope of the classroom. Students that are identified as having a special love for the visual arts will be encouraged to seek such additional educational and career opportunities. Our goal is to further develop this program so that we can continue to offer students a high quality arts enrichment environment that meets graduation requirements, and more importantly, encourages personal growth in the art room and beyond.

Bronx Envision Academy embraces the arts throughout the curriculum. Students have the opportunity to take up to two arts courses each semester, and we encourage students to explore an arts discipline in depth to prepare for the New York City Commencement Level Arts Examinations. One quarter of graduates from our first two classes graduated with an arts endorsed diploma. Elective offerings include visual art, theater, dance, music, chorus, and creative writing. We also offer summer honors arts courses in visual art and theater and a new course in AP Studio Art 2D Design. Students participate in artist residencies with arts organizations Community Word-Project, and Hawley Hussey Arts. We are also proud partners with the Park Avenue Armory, providing access to high quality arts performances and exhibitions for beginning and advanced students and paid internships for advanced students. Teachers are trained in Visual Thinking Strategies, and students discuss works of art on a regular basis. Because the arts are central to Bronx Envision's core beliefs about how students learn best, BEA has recruited accomplished faculty with strong arts backgrounds. As a result, we offer many arts clubs during and after school. Current offerings include mural-making, anime, comic book club, musical theater, dance company, art, music production and DJing.

Students learn to use iMac software in courses that combine literacy, mathematical reasoning and Art. Our course offerings are: 1. Digital Storytelling 2. Graphic Design and Media Marketing 3. Videography and the Arts

Fannie Lou Hamer Freedom High School has a long standing partnership with art educators.  The collaboration with the arts introduces a variety of visual art experience to students, enables interdisciplinary exhibitions and encourages educators to use the arts as a tool for learning.

Visual arts are woven into curriculum in the school and enables 200 9th/10th graders to create artwork that demonstrates their learning and allows them creative expression of their thinking and learning to demonstrate with a larger community.

A dance club that will provide students with a combination of African, ballet, jazz, and hip hop. Students will be able to use this club to express themselves through the art of movement. In addition, students will be prepared to audition and prepare for various competitions.

Currently we have one full-time Music teacher on our budget. Students from Pre k-5th Grade participate in Music classes at least one day each week. We currently have a partnership with the Studio In a School and Dancing Classrooms. We also have a Theater program that has 60 participants from grades 2nd-5th. Students in grades 2 and 3rd grade put together a theater sampler.  Students in grades 4 and 5 put on a full show.  Students meet throughout the day and after school to work on scripts, dance, vocals, and scenery.

The school offered four distinct arts courses during the 2016-2017 school year.

Painting
Studio Art
Music Survey
Piano Keyboarding

We are committed to providing all of our students with sequential standards-based arts education and have earned a well-deserved reputation in NYC for effectively doing that over many years. In addition to full-time staff arts teachers in four strands (Dance, Music, Theater, and Visual Arts), and teaching artists provided by long-standing partnerships with cultural organizations, we have a part-time arts coordinator. All classroom teachers and other curricula specialists also provide arts experiences for students. Weekly Town Hall performances provide opportunities for all students to participate in and experience the performing arts. Classes schedule trips to museums, music and theater performances and dance concerts. Annual student performances commemorate The Day of the African Child and Juneteenth. We have an annual musical theater performance, exhibit student art at MoCADA, are home to The Shadowbox Theatre (which provides free performances for our students and NYSCA-funded puppetry workshops), were an Arts Achieve School and have music and visual arts after school programs. One visual arts after school program is a City Council-funded Creative After School Adventure (CASA) with the Museum of Contemporary African Diasporan Arts (MoCADA).

The lower school (K-5) has full-time teachers for music, visual art, dance and theater; each teacher sees five of the six grades; there are also multiple school-based extra-curricular options for music (concert band, Glee Club), theater (play, musical) and visual arts. The upper school (6-8) has part-time teachers for music, dance and theater; school-based extra-curricular options include a school-wide musical and rock band.

Our School's Arts Program is multi-layered, multi-disciplined and provides our students with the abilities to be competitive with their peers throughout NYC. Each year it is our goal to align all of our subject areas in an effort to provide our students with seamless learning and inquiry. Our students are exposed to varied forms of art; including visual arts, theater, dance, and music.  Our in-house art teachers, along with our art consultants are innovative and seek to stay current with the trends and new discoveries within their disciplines. We take much thought and pride in how we align each grade with the arts. Each of our grades is assigned an art form according to their social studies curriculum. Our artists and classroom teachers collaboratively study the units and decide what the essential question and year's focus would be for the students across each grade.  We provide our students with authentic art instruction which allows them to truly understand the art form that is being studied. Our students are provided with many opportunities to engage in trips which enhance their art awareness and make their learning real and alive. Our students are also provided with many opportunities to study the varied forms of arts, collaborate with their peers and their teachers, and then present their Type III products. They engage in varied in-house art exhibitions, as well as exhibitions outside of the school on stage, in museums, and at dance competitions. We tap into our students' talents and teach them to be confident artists.
Q45_1: Our school is a diverse elementary school that represents the cultural and ethnic blending of New York City.  Our families represent cultures from all around the world and we take pride in helping our students discover who they are as artists, and share this wonderful discovery among each other. We believe in servicing the Whole Child, and we are the only nationally recognized Whole Child school through ASCD within NYC. We believe in tapping the talents of each student in an effort to create confident learners and artist in each of the disciplines. We are no longer a Title 1 school; therefore our parents are forced to raise all of the funding that is needed to support our strong Arts Program. Our parents are dedicated to the arts and share my belief that each child needs a balance between academics and the arts.  We are passionate about the arts and ensure that our students are aware of what it takes to be an artist. We discover many art talents among our diverse student population and we ensure that they are fostered and nurtured. Our school believes in S.T.E.A. M since it not only promotes science, technology, engineering and mathematics, but it also includes and pushes the arts.

Q44_1: Our arts program goals are as follows: to enhance use of ongoing authentic assessment (including projects, observations, student portfolios, exhibitions and performance); to provide meaningful feedback to track student progress in the arts; to expose more students to art museums, concerts and theatrical performances throughout the school year and to continue to enhance our end of year curriculum showcases, which incorporate the arts and all content areas.

The Clinton Hill School strives to provide each student with an arts education that will develop creative ability and nurture a life long appreciation for the various art forms. Teachers engage students in project based educational experiences that integrate the arts across all subject areas and disciplines while addressing the academic and social needs of our diverse student population. Through our partnerships with many cultural organizations, the students are exposed to a variety of art forms, artists and techniques. These various art forms help students develop motor skills, gain exposure to music/theatre using imagination, learning audience skills, movement skills and cooperation. Students showcase their art through concerts, performances, galleries and displays in local businesses.

Society of the Educational Arts, Inc.(SEA)is a bilingual arts-in-education organization and bilingual theater for young audiences. SEA provides our students with rich learning experiences of dance, theater, and cultural performances that are specially designed for our school community. Individualized programs address students' academic needs, strengthen the Arts curriculum, and provide cultural experiences. Students work with SEA's professional Dance Teaching Artist to learn the history of Salsa Hip-Hop and African dances, as they craft their skills in perfecting partner dance work. Our students present their routines during school-wide cultural performances for their peers, school staff and parents to enjoy. Material for the Arts (MFTA) is an in-school residence program which places teaching artists into our classrooms. This program fosters creative ways to reuse materials to enhance environmental awareness and incorporate their visual arts and performing arts in all content areas. Instructional Music: in grades 4-5 children play the flute, clarinet, saxophone, trumpet, and trombone. They receive instruction once a week and perform year round. School-Wide Chorus: Grades K-5 students learn basic chorus techniques. Small groups of children help research and choose music that the chorus performs. Music selected, teaches students social studies, history, math and science through the study of music.

The Arts are a vital part of P.S. 46K. Infused throughout the curriculum, the arts provide opportunities for differentiated instruction within various learning modalities. As a neighborhood school within Brooklyn's newly designated "Tech Triangle" we offer an innovative STEAM program, with the Arts and Design front and center, informing and energizing science and math.  Moving forward with an applied learning approach the arts support and reinforce learning in the Common Core Subjects while developing skills and understandings in the individual arts disciplines. Grade-appropriate lessons are designed to enhance vocabulary and critical thinking skills necessary to prepare students for college and beyond. In addition to an experiential curriculum. Students demonstrate mastery of concepts and content as well as processes.  We utilize the rich cultural resources of New York City as an extension of classroom activities  through trips and assemblies. Collaboration with cultural partners such as the New York Philharmonic provides opportunities for direct instruction to students as well as professional development for classroom teachers. This enhances music, dance and drama instruction.
Q45_1: We have developed ann innovative STEAM curriculum within an Applied Learning context.  Through our federal magnet grant our staff has been trained in an innovative integrated instructional modality designed to support creative thought.

Q44_1: Children learn to perceive and respond to works of art. Children also involve themselves in looking, touching, and analyzing the visual aspects of their environment. Art education is primarily connected with visual experiences. Kindergarten thru Grade 5 students are capable of creating, perceiving and discussing the visual arts.
Q45_1: 90% of our Arts programming has come from the Extended School Day/Violence Prevention Program. Extended School Day/Violence Prevention Program was awarded during the 2016/2017 school year.

Q44_1: PS 56 emphasized the education of the whole child, with a specific emphasis on creating engaging and creative arts experiences.  Our school promotes experiences in a variety of genres, such as dance, visual arts, music and theater.  We have been able this year to initiate partnerships with organizations, such as Little Orchestra Society, Bronx Arts Ensemble, Dancing Classrooms, and Studio in a School to ensure that all of our students experience dance, visual arts, music instruction, and performance throughout the year.  Additionally, our full time dance instructor has introduced our students to a variety of genres, such as modern dance, traditional dance, tap, and others.  Not only do our students experience these themselves, but often through these partnerships they are able to see professional artists and musicians perform at such institutions as the Metropolitan Museum, Brooklyn Academy of Music, Brooklyn Museum, and Kaye Playhouse at Hunter College.  We strongly feel that these experiences enhance the students educational experience overall and improves their progress not only in arts classes but other academic areas as well.

John Ericsson Middle School 126 School for Environmental Engineering offers a robust and diverse arts education program. Visual Arts teachers continue to find a variety of ways to align their instruction to the Common Core Learning Standards that  focus on active learning and higher level thinking. Along with our teaching residencies, we support our students with music, visual arts, and theater development. During our 2016-2017 school year, our students refined their abilities to develop their artistic side by performing in an original adaptation of a classic drama. JEMS offers advanced Visual Arts classes that challenge students 
to develop skills in drawing, painting, collage, and sculpture while exploring the history and analysis of art through various cultural contexts. As a Leader in Me School, our students work diligently and use synergy to showcase their talents to bring our school community together.

The Charles A. Dorsey School provides comprehensive Common Core Aligned cultural arts experiences for our scholars. Through the arts, students acquire tools to engage with a range of source materials and learn to draw on research to investigate their own families and cultural traditions in order to express ideas about the world through the arts.
We continue to participate in the Noel Pointer Violin Program, Disney Musical in Schools and we have our own Woodshop Program.

The Academy of Performing Arts (APA) provides the opportunity for students to pursue training in dance: classical ballet and contemporary dance, and vocal music. The Academy places special emphasis on preparing the young artist for high schools that offer specialized performing arts programs. APA has partnered with several arts groups, organizations and foundations such as Mark Morris Dance Group, Arts Alive, Dance Africa, American Ballet Theater and Creative Outlet, as well as individual artists such as ballet dancer Misty Copeland and Alvin Ailey dancer Jeroboam Bozeman. Students are featured in our annual Winterfest and Springfest concerts, which showcase all of the art disciplines. Our vocal students have performed at several events hosted by local politicians over the years. The School of Fine Arts and Design (FAD) integrates technology into the arts through the graphic design course in Grade 8 and those students participate in the production of the school yearbook.

P.S. 133 is committed to quality education in the performing and visual arts. Every student from pre-kindergarten to 5th grade receives a diverse education in the arts based on New York State standards and the NYC Blueprint for the Arts. Through our music program, students are able to differentiate, interpret and analyze musical experiences and make valuable links to language, math and history. Students are able to analyze musical, concepts, genres and performers. They also learn to play several instruments including the violin and piano. In our drama program, students develop social and emotion skills, as well as creative thinking skills. They develop performance skills focused on using the body, voice and imagination. They have the opportunity to perform already published work as well as create their own original work. The STUDIO visual arts program is a dedicated art studio where the students are encouraged to experiment and classroom teachers learn how to extend art into their classroom. Drawing, painting, printmaking, collage, sculpture, 2-D applied design, and media tech are linked to other classroom subjects. Our cultural partners provide new and exciting ways for our students to express themselves, and also provide opportunities to connect with artists and arts venues in our community.
Q45_1: The student population of our school has continued to grow over the past few years. In order to provide quality arts instruction for all, we added many more arts residencies to our program this year. We also offer before and after school opportunities that many students and families take part in.

Q44_1: Our arts program is a four year sequence in the high school designed to incorporate state standards (CCSS) as well as components of the Blueprint to aid in the structuring of curriculum, activities, and the exposure to various art forms, festivals, adjudications, and the many resources that NYC offers to supplement arts classroom instruction. The Middle school students receive arts instruction weekly with the state mandated time requirements. During such times, the student as six graders are afforded the opportunity to change discipline by grade 7 to ensure that the student has made an informed decision. Our ultimate goal is to engage our students in a rigorous arts curriculum that prepares them academically and socially for success in college and the world of work and develops their civic engagement at both the school and community level.

Q42_R1_C1: Learning through an Expanded Arts Program
Q44_1: At P.S. 270 we believe the arts are a critical and essential part of education for all students. We endeavor to engage our students in an education occurring both in and outside of the classroom. Our current arts program seeks to provide a comprehensive arts education that draws upon the expertise of art specialists/consultants, classroom teachers, as well as our community's cultural resources. The visual arts program, provides students with the chance to explore various media such as painting, drawing, collage, recycling, and pottery. Our students participate in monthly and holiday assemblies that help to develop their knowledge and skills in the areas of acting and playwriting. The Move-To-Improve program engages students and enhancing their skills and techniques of dance and movement.

We are strongly committed to the arts and will work to strengthen the arts at our school for all students in grades pre-kindergarten to 8th grade. We intend to build upon existing partnerships such as LEAP, Music Kafando, and Thrive Collective to fulfill our goal of meeting the creative needs of all students.

All of UAMA’s arts programs are built around core outcomes. At UAMA, every student will: • Build a functioning arts vocabulary • Understand the historical development of the arts • Value the arts as a mode of personal expression • Produce art that explores bigger social issues and themes • Defend their work both written and verbally • Connect with career and higher education opportunities in the field UAMA integrates visual, literary and musical arts into the academic school day. While we have full-time music and visual arts teachers, there are plenty of opportunities to allow for students to engage with the creative arts in other content specifc classrooms with arts integrated units. Students also participate in Extended Studio art classes taught by professional artists once a week in an extended school day. Students have the opportunity to connect with professional internships and undertake independent projects under the guidance of an Extended Studio Teacher and art teacher. Students share their work in class critiques and share-outs and around the school in displays. Field trips, events, and visiting artists further enrich students’ experience and allow them to consider how their academic and arts experiences can translate into a careers and life-long interests. UAMA also provides enrichment and internship programs that extend beyond the school day. These take place both at UAMA (through our Extended Studio after-school program) and offsite, through our partnerships.

Every BCAM student takes Studio Art in their 9th grade year, Photography in 10th Grade Filmmaking in their 11th grade year, and in 12th grade students complete a year-long competitive art college portfolio course.  Additionally, students are required to take a variety of elective arts seminars in all grades, and we offer seven rigorous semester-long after-school arts academies that are enrolled by student application/audition: Printmaking, Fashion Design, Photography, Theater, Filmmaking, Mural Painting, Modern Dance, and Music Production.BCAM’s goals and priorities for meeting the New York State Education Department (NYSED) instructional requirements for the arts include expanding our curricular offerings to include a four-year visual art scope and sequence for our students. This will increase our ability to provide rigorous instruction that meets NYSED visual arts commencement standards 1c (demonstrate an increasing level of competence in using the elements and principles of art to create art works for public exhibition), 2c (take advantage of community opportunities and cultural institutions to learn from professional artists, look at original art, and increase their understanding of art), and 2d (understand the variety of careers related to the visual arts and the skills necessary to pursue some of them). Specifically, our priority is providing differentiated lessons in rigorous art classes that emphasize skill-building, artifact production, and presentation and exhibition of artwork

Q37_4: Donating food or snack for school events
Q44_1: The arts program at Science Skills is designed to provide all students with exposure to all aspects of the arts to develop their appreciation, knowledge and skills in the arts.

Regarding performance arts, we run fifteen performance based music courses, including chorus, band, and orchestra. The students in our music courses compete in city-wide programs. Our arts courses include visual and digital arts. Our entire freshman class is enrolled in a visual arts/pre-engineering course. Mastery in the subject translates to college accreditation through Project Lead The Way at The Rochester Institute of Technology. Students perform one drama and one musical production in the auditorium for a large audience open to all each school year.

The Brooklyn International High School values the arts as an important part of the curriculum, in that the arts provide additional modes of expression. All of our students take courses in media arts, visual art, and dance. We emphasize the incorporation of technology into the arts as knowledge of technology is invaluable to our students as they move beyond high school into college and careers. Our students have many opportunities, across disciplines, to create art; all of the art that is created is celebrated in our end of the year, three-days arts festival.

Studio Art is an introduction to the different ideas, principles and materials used in the visual arts. As a working artist, I have a strong knowledge of the skills and techniques your child needs to learn to make anything from a drawing to a wire sculpture. In Studio Art your child will research many different kinds of art making, as well as look at all kinds of art, from prehistoric to contemporary.  My teaching is focused on the process of art making and on fostering creativity. My classroom is an enriching and safe environment for students to discover their artistic abilities. For students interested in pursuing a career in the arts, I will help them put together a portfolio for college or art high schools. 

The guitar program at PSC will change the way your student hears music and possibly the world. We foster a growth mindset by teaching students how and why to practice and that practice makes progress. Our guitar program is designed to give students the opportunity to be college ready musicians, as well as to be hobbyists. Students learn to read standard music notation, chord charts and tablature. They learn to use picks and to use the fingers of the right hand independently. Students play a variety of styles of music, however if they continue they often eventually focus on Classical, Jazz or a combination of the two as they are the styles most commonly studied at the university level. Students also have the opportunity to prepare for college level music theory, and ear training.
Q45_1: Because Park Slope Collegiate is a relatively small school we are only able to offer one visual arts program and Glee and Guitar classes. Students sometimes come to Park Slope Collegiate overage and under credited and accumulate credit at a slower than ideal rate. This increased need for remediation can limit opportunities for those students to take electives. Similarly, students who are entitled to extra services such as ELL or SETTS are often scheduled for those during periods which might otherwise be used for arts electives and thus have reduced opportunity to take those classes. We do not have the flexibility of budget and programming that is afforded by a population of thousands, instead we maintain a small community where, “the needs of all students are targeted at an intensely granular level.” (quality review 2009-2010)

Q44_1: At SLJ, we believe that a rigorous education includes the arts. Through a variety of arts experiences and partnership opportunities, we make the arts a powerful partner in learning. In 10th and 12th grade, students are exposed to a variety of arts through connections made in content classes and outside arts partnerships. In 9th and 11th grade, students are given exposure to over 20 arts providers for after school and enrichment opportunities. Approximately 50 students across the school participate in off-site enrichment programming in the arts.
Q45_1: As a title I high school, we have very limited access to the necessary funding for arts programming.

Q42_R1_C1: BRIC Arts Media Bklyn Inc.Brooklyn Information & Culture ROTUNDA
Q44_1:
The art department at Arts and Letters is committed to cultivating creative confidence in our students through a rich program in visual arts, movement, creative writing, music and theater. From K- 8 students experience an in depth investigation in the arts. Students create art through inquiry, with a strong focus on revision and reflection. Two times a year students exhibit and perform their work in our bi-annual Art Expo, it is an event drawing hundreds of people and a chance for students to present their work publicly. We believe giving students a rigorous arts education allows students to learn their own interests, develop their voice and expand their critical thinking skills. The arts are a vital part of children’s growth, not only as learners, but as whole people. 
What is a Culture of Creative Confidence? 
• A belief in ones abilities and ideas and the abilities and ideas of those around them. 
• A growth mindset (rather than fixed) that allows for development, evolution, improvement and advancement. 
• A personal outlook that includes an understanding of the importance of creative thinking and the process of making. 
• An ability to receive and give critique without complaint or insecurity.

Students are offered visual arts during the school day. In visual arts classes, students used digital and other art mediums, which include written descriptions and student-produced art. Each unit culminates with the students' presenting their work, including an explanation of their artistic choices. All students provide feedback to their peers throughout the year, both written and verbal. Students are given additional opportunities to participate in arts-related classwork and field trips. Students in senior English classes benefit from working with teaching artists from TDF who provide instruction in theater and performance art and accompany students on trips to see plays studied in class. Our freshman, will continue to participate in theatrical spoken word through the Brooklyn Arts Museum (BAM). Next year, we would like to offer music production/chorus and dance.
Q45_1: Due to budgetary constraints we were not able to house a full time art teacher during this school year.

Q44_1: The goal of our arts programming at UAI is to provide students with exposure to a wide variety of art forms and depth of understanding through visual art, based on the NYC Blueprint for the Arts. Furthermore, our program works with core content teachers to develop units that complement each other. Unfortunately, we do not have the funds for more arts like dance and music at our school.

The Visual Arts program at Brooklyn Academy High School is focused on encouraging creativity and personal expression, developing decision-making and critical thinking skills, and increasing communication and listening skills. 
Through Studio Art and Art History classes, students find their voices to express meaning from experiences in their everyday lives. Students regularly participate in discussions about art in a social context, thus allowing for a dialogue that inspires visual awareness. The use of collaborative and cooperative work provides experiences to express ideas and problem solving skills that lead to a well rounded student.
Q45_1: Brooklyn Academy High School is a Transfer School serving a majority of students who, for various reasons, are in need of catching up in their credit accumulation. Our focus is on academic, social and emotional supports to help students overcome the obstacles that have hindered their credit accumulation in the past.

Q44_1: The arts program at Bedford-Stuyvesant Preparatory High School is primarily a visual arts program that meets during the school day between the hours of 8:12 AM and 2:32 PM. We try to enhance our arts program by accessing various art resources throughout the New York City area. Our students attend different Broadway shows such as Lion King, Aladdin, Wicked, and Color Purple. They also attend museums like the Museum of Modern Art and concerts. At Bed-Stuy Prep, we believe in the inherent value of an arts education and we strive to expose our students to various forms of the arts.

Westinghouse High School will continue to provide various and engaging arts opportunities to our students and their families, such as Jazz HipHop classes, theatrical events, spoken word and drama workshops. Our goal for the 2016-2017 school year is to increase and enhance our current arts program by providing a variety of artistic opportunities to engage the whole school community.
Q45_1: We are a career and technical high school, so our students must take an additional 10 credits of technology.  This makes it difficult to incoproate art classes, other than the required credits necessary to graduate, into their schedule.

Q44_1: Brooklyn High School for Leadership and Community Service is a transfer school, and as such, a large part of our mission is to re-engage students. This year we continue to use the arts as an effective re-engagement tool and have a full time visual arts teacher, as well as a part-time art therapist and a student teacher from Columbia who has co-taught our visual arts courses. Additionally, students have had the opportunity to participate in our film program that includes an artist in residence from Education Video Center who team-teaches our Documentary Film class throughout the year. Through our student teacher program, our students’ work is currently being showcased at Macy Gallery at Teachers College Columbia University, and as our film program and partnership with EVC continues to flourish, our students will be afforded the opportunity to have their student films viewed at the Youth Powered Video Film Festival at the AMC Loews Theater in June. We also collaborated with the arts organization Dance Theater Etcetera in April, and held a three day school wide Poetry Slam with professional poets, who also facilitated poetry workshops with all of our students to celebrate poetry month. All in all, we offered many opportunities to engage students through the arts. Looking ahead to the 2017-2018 school year, we will continue to utilize the arts to inspire students as we hope to expand upon our arts programming.

City Poly HS scholars can discover their artistic selves through a range of academic and recreational arts programs including – visual arts, dance, performing arts, and music. Our arts programs provide an opportunity for students to explore and develop new and existing skills, to develop an appreciation for the arts and to cultivate their imagination.

This year our goal was build upon our strong theater programs. We maintained the Bric visual arts and film opportunities and dance program within our after school programming. We offer and intensive Shakespeare study to all students once a year in partnership with Lincoln Center Theater and all students have the opportunity to view the play. Through our partnership with the Strike Anywhere, we expanded our theater programming to include an additional Shakespeare study to our grade 7 students, which included an original performance conducted by them at a local theater space.
Q45_1: We are extremely limited in space.  It has been difficult to maintain any type of dance, theater, and/or music program long term because the we are only allocated a small number of regular classrooms and no storage space.  Storing instruments is challenging and clearing desks to create performance spaces is challenging and wastes precious instructional time.  Because of our space challenges, it is extremely difficult to recruit top talent who can apply to other schools with much better spaces.  As a result, we have only been able to maintain a fine arts program.  We do have a dedicated art room that is appropriately appointed. The art room is used to house other classes as well.

Q44_1:
This year we did not win any grants for art an our budget doesn't allow us to hire an artist. 

Our music teacher puts on show with students 3 times a year. All students receive music class 2 to 3 periods a week.

Arts education is a very important component of the curriculum at PS 17.  Our music and art teachers work with every student Pre-K through Grade5 all year providing valuable enrichment to the lives of each child attending our school.  The Williamsburg Movement and Art Center provides dance and creative movement classes to every class in our school.  Our students are encouraged to visit locations where art and music are celebrated through class trips and classroom experiences.  We hope to see more arts providers coming to PS 17 for the 2017-2018 school year.

The arts program at PS 18 consists of visual arts and drama/vocal music for all students in Pre K-5th grades.  Students are also exposed to cultural trips and performances throughout the year.  For afterschool, students in grades 3-5 have the opportunity to participate in the Afro Latin Jazz program.  In that program 30 students choose one of five instruments to play.  Students also learn to read music.  Hosh Kids also provide Hip Hop Dance and yoga to all students in Pre K-5th grades during the school day.  P.S. 18 is in the process of building relationships with other cultural institutions to increase our students' exposure to the arts.

At PS23 we are committed to providing our students access to a wide variety of arts programming. This year we focused on dance, theater and visual arts. Through a grant through from the Walentas Foundation we were able to provide all students in pre-K kindergarten first grade and every single special education class the opportunity to learn dance. Students in second and third grade were engaged in a music series and students in fourth and fifth grade learned engineering through the use of digital design. This partnership was with the 92nd St. Y and supported our vision to provide students with STEAM education. Furthermore, we were able to partner with BRI C where students in second and third grade were involved in visual arts and students in fourth and fifth grade learned videography and made a short film. Finally, students in grades two through five were involved in a guitar club which took place after school. Our arts classroom is equipped to provide visual art instruction to all classes. It is our goal to continue these programs obviously pending the funding.

This year, our PTA actively engaged ongoing fund raising throughout the year to support the Arts at PS 31. This enabled us to expand our arts program. Other grants provided partial funding for a full time resident artist provided by Studio In A School, early childhood dance and movement, ballroom dance programs, a resident artist from the 92nd St.Y, PreK Little Kids Rock, assemblies and an early childhood theater program. The Common Core Standards were infused throughout the various art programs. The students also went on a vast array of field trips exploring the arts.

P.S. 34 provides a rich art education to all its students. Students in grades K-5 participate in weekly art classes. They study various art media as well as the history of art. In addition, we have partnerships with BRIC and Eckford Street Studio to supplement instruction in the visual arts. Our schoolwide Art Show is held at the Brooklyn Expo Center,a local event space. In addition,students participate in an Art Parade where they present projects based on artists studied that year.  P.S. 34 is currently in the third year of a Disney grant. This year, the students will be performing Sleeping Beauty. Second and third grade students present one act plays under the guidance of Kevin Ray from Everybody Act.  
Grade 5 students participate in Dancing Classrooms,a ballroom dancing program. For dance, Grades 1-5 work with the Williamsburg Movement and Art Center.
P.S. 34 is currently in their 12th year of a partnership with Brooklyn Conservatory of Music. All students in Kindergarten through fourth grades receive music instruction through this program.

(To be published in Arts Report)


 
  


We have an extensive arts program at MS 50 that combines in-school arts curricula, provided by to itinerant Middle School Arts Matters teachers (visual arts and music, our Integrated Arts Program (IAP) that partners Community School teaching artists with content area teachers (ELA, Social Studies, ENL) to integrate theater, visual arts, music and dance into our content area curricula, diverse arts programming as part of our Expanded Learning Time (ELT), and an inter-disciplinary mural project. El Puente’s IAP includes a codified professional development/training curriculum to support teachers to work with teaching artists to create integrated lesson plans and theme-based projects that will enrich the math curriculum. MS 50 has also partnered wtih El Puente to engage its resident mural group, Los Muralistas de El Puente, to create community murals on MS50’s large exterior wall on Roebling St. as well as on several interior school walls. Los Muralistas will not just to create the mural for the school, but will facilitate an interdisciplinary mural painting initiative. Students will gather oral histories in social studies, design mural proposals in ELA, study scaling in math, and analyze effects of erosion on different paints/surfaces in science. Our community mural painting project, for example, will have an important math application as students will be asked to use transferring, graphing, and scaling to in bringing the mural from design to larger than life reality.
The school currently does not have a licensed full time Arts teacher.

Q42_R1_C1: BRIC Arts Media Bklyn Inc.Brooklyn Information & Culture ROTUNDA
Q44_1: Our school offers a challenging arts program to students in grades 6-12. Students in all grades receive the opportunity for arts instruction in instrumental music, Theater Arts, Animation and/or Visual Arts. Students in grades 6 and 7 take one semester of each arts course before settling on an area of focus for 8th grade to expose them to all of the art forms. High School students are provided with a choice regarding their arts program and are able to choose from a variety of disciplines.  Within their major, students dive deep into different forms of coursework and are expected to be a part of our school's performances, concerts, gallery exhibitions, and arts-based internships. Partnerships with BRIC, NYU Steinhardt, Little Kids Rock and NURTUREart provide students with professional arts opportunities.

PS 84's arts program is a very comprehensive one, following the Blueprint for the Arts. The arts are integrated in all the content areas using a variety of media and techniques. We are very fortunate to be a part of a community that is enriched with a variety of artists, galleries and studios. Our continuous collaboration with various arts residencies have enriched the arts educations of all our students.

In our dedication and pursuit of "Growing Hearts and Minds," our students' participation in and exploration of multiple art forms bring us closer to fulfilling our mission. Students at PS 110 experience all four art disciplines by the time they graduate from fifth grade: visual arts, music, theater and dance. Our visual arts teacher works with grades pre-kindergarten through fifth to create art pieces incorporating techniques in drawing, painting, printmaking, collage, and sculpture. Learning music through song and keyboard,  begins in the early childhood grades. Resident artists provide opportunities for our students to explore their creative talents and abilities through cultural dance, musical theatre and movement, ballroom dancing, and production of Shakespearean plays. In addition to practical educational applications, experiencing the arts allows our children to grow socially, emotionally, and physically.

PS 120 has been fortunate enough this year to have become the Magnet School of Architecture, Engineering and Design. Through the arts, within our building, the students will all engage in a rigorous, rich and exciting hands on curriculum centered around architecture, engineering and design while fostering a love of education.  PS 120 has many residency programs focusing on various arts disciplines.  Throughout our school year each grade focuses on a country.  In June we have a culminating festival where the students display all their work.  In the art room, using the Blueprint for the Arts as our guide, the children study artists and their works, indigenous crafts, native clothing as well as sites and architecture associated with those countries.  Trips at PS 120 are curriculum based to enhance the subject area about which the students are learning.  Our new Magnet grant will afford our students new learning experiences with art and technology to think outside the box and to become global citizens.  The learning comes alive through visual arts, music, theater, dance and design.  Step into PS 120 at any time and a warm and visually inviting atmosphere will welcome you.

We believe that instruction in the arts is integral to the education of every child. We have a fully equipped art studio with a full-time visual arts teacher. There is a fully equipped music studio with keyboards. A full time music teacher facilitates Music and the Brain curriculum to grades PreK-3. Selected second – fifth grade students participate in our school band. We have a brand new sprung dance floor in our Performing Arts space. All students receive dance instruction once a week which includes a 12 week grade specific residency. All teachers are trained in teaching the Blueprint for the Arts. Each grade attends arts related field trips throughout the year. Grades pre-kindergarten – fifth are involved with 2 or more arts based residencies in Theater, Dance and Music. Students have performed Latin dance, African dance, hip-hop, ballet and ballroom dancing. This year we will launch our Art + Design studio where students will have an architecture residency with the Salvadori Center.

At PS 147, the arts support other subjects, such as literacy, science, social studies, and math. We have a full-time certified music teacher on staff and have recently secured a full time art teacher to provide visual arts instruction to students in prekindergarten through fifth grade. In addition to our music program and in-school teaching artist residencies, students attend numerous off-site field trips which provide authentic arts learning experiences in all genres of the arts. Community Arts Partnerships have been steadily growing. All classroom teachers have been trained in Visual Thinking Strategies. Arts instruction is aligned with New York State Arts Standards, as well as the New York City Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts.

At PS 196 we strive to make the arts a daily experience for our students. Our students are exposed to all art forms and media. We hold an annual arts festival where students display their art work as well. We have a theater club and are performing a musical. we have weekly enrichment clubs where students are involved in art, music, drama and photography. We have a dance, music and theatre teacher partime as well. We have been fortunate to receive Magnet funding in November 2016 and secured residencies with Rosie's Theatre Kids, Salvadori and Hosh Kids. These programs have far exceeded our expectations.

Q30_6: State and National Conferences and Clinics
Q44_1:
The performing arts department at PROGRESS is one of the biggest and best in NYC. We have four full concert bands, two jazz bands, two choral ensembles, and numerous chamber groups such as guitar ensemble (modern band) and clarinet choir. Students have the option of majoring in music, which involves taking Music Theory. The instrumental, choral and modern band programs draw from all three schools in the campus and allow students to perform at their ability level regardless of age or experience. All musical ensembles compete annually at the NYSSMA festival where they have received Gold and Gold with Distinction awards. 

Our visual arts department offers students instruction in the foundations of drawing and painting, stage design, graphic arts and sculpture. Advanced students may move on to studio art classes, and A.P. studio art. 

The Campus is host to the All City High School Marching Band and the All City High School Concert Band, in which many Grand Street Campus Students Participate. The campus also hosts the Brooklyn Wind Symphony, Grand Street Community Band and Kings County Concert Band whose performances are free to students and their families.
Q45_1: 4 Music teachers and 3 Visual Arts teachers are shared between the three schools on the campus.

Q44_1: Our goal at Public School 250 is to continue to have a comprehensive arts education program that is interdisciplinary and aligned to the Blueprint for the Arts. Our Magnet theme of Communications and Multimedia Arts will continue to be embedded throughout the school curriculum. We recognize the importance that the arts plays in developing students who are creative, critical thinkers and students who can solve real world problems in order to express themselves in different ways. At PS 250, the arts disciplines are incorporated into the school curriculum as a means to encourage cultural sensitivity diversity, and community involvement.  We pride ourselves in keeping the arts at the forefront of our students' educational experiences.

We are very proud of Arts Programs at P.S. 257.  Our goal is to continue to provide our children with the best Arts Programs we can afford.  We strongly believe in the connection between Arts instruction and brain development.  We know that Arts instruction contributes to higher order thinking skills, problem solving, and overall success in the future. 

 Our ultimate goal is to increase the Arts instruction hours for our children each and every year. It is our hope that by providing more Arts instruction our children can become successful, well-rounded citizens who will contribute to the improvement of our society and our world.

We offer a broad range of arts experiences as part of our comprehenisve curriculum. We currently offer courses in concert band, jazz band, guitar, modern dance, theater, songwriting, photography,sound engineering, digital film, ceramics and visual arts.

For the school year 2016-2017, The School for Legal Studies offers Music, Dance, and Percussion courses for all students. 
The Grand Street Campus collaboratively provides the music program  for all three schools. Its music program is one of the finest not only on the city level but the State level as well. The program consists of 4 full concert bands, 2 jazz bands, as well as classes in guitar and music appreciation. Students may take a 3 year major in music which includes AP Music Theory. The Grand Street bands have won awards on both the city and state level. In addition, the school, in collaboration with the Urban Arts Partnership, provides dance and percussion classes for all students. Urban Arts Partnership advances the intellectual, social and artistic development of under-served public school students through arts-integrated education.

PS 380 implements visual arts and music and movement programs that incorporates activities aligned to the NYCDOE Blueprint for the Arts and the New York State Learning standards. Our visual arts teacher introduces students to a variety of techniques and modalities, and encourages all students to enjoy and appreciate fine arts. Students' artwork decorates the corridors of our school, enriching and enhancing our learning community. Art is also integrated within many curricula areas across all grades by integrating and investigating various art forms. The music and movement program is designed to support the social studies curriculum by highlighting the rhythms and songs of particular cultures and geographical areas. Our children participate in a winter and spring music gala and other cultural celebrations that showcase their vocal and dance talents.

At Brooklyn Arbor Elementary, we infuse art and music into the curriculum wherever possible. We believe that the arts play an integral role in child development and foster the creativity and critical thinking skills necessary for a happy and productive life. Our school offers instruction with both a full time licensed art and music teacher, as well as a plethora of enrichment activities pertaining to the visual and performing arts. Next year we plan on expanding musical performance opportunities for our students. Classroom teachers often include music and movement in their activities, and also engage students in visual arts projects pertaining to their units of study. We also have a unique parent-led initiative, the Materials Depot. In the Depot we organize recyclables as well as donated items. Throughout the day, teachers can browse through the meticulously organized bins and load up on inspiration and supplies. This system promotes our school's mission of environmental consciousness and sustainability.

Art History I and II are one-semester full-time courses, required in Class IV & III (9th and 10th grades). They provide an understanding of the formal and contextual methods of analyzing works in art history. They chronologically introduce discipuli to major themes, movements, and issues in art history from prehistoric times through abstract expressionism. Assessments include Socratic Seminar, analyzing works of art, short and extended essays. 

IB Visual Arts is a two-year full-time course, offered in Class II and I (11th and 12th grades). Discipuli investigate and analyze works of art by various artists while developing a portfolio. Discipuli utilize a visual arts journal to explore and develop ideas. Assessments throughout the year include interviews in which students present their portfolio and visual arts journal. 

IB Theatre is a two-year full-time course, which began in the 2015-2016 school year, is offered to Class II and I (11th and 12th grades). Discipuli explore theatre history, theory and practice through the lens of a scholar, a historian, an audience member and a practitioner. Assessments include Socratic Seminar, intensive process journals, directors notebooks, research presentations, and collaborative projects. 

After school, students engage in studio arts, photography, Stoked, theatre, music and dance enrichment programs at Brooklyn Latin. Public performances are exhibited at least twice a year for these programs.
Q45_1:
odeled after the prestigious Boston Latin School and founded in 2006, The Brooklyn Latin School (TBLS) provides a classical liberal arts education, including the study of Latin, in a discip curriculum provides the groundwork for an understanding of the foundation of our society, while also developing the leadership capacity of our students to become leaders in their communit based on the New York City SHSAT (specialized high school admissions test).
The Brooklyn Latin School offers an all “honors” curriculum taught by an accomplished staff. All courses presented on the student’s transcript represent challenging academic experiences t courses offered at other schools. All students are required to adhere to our core curriculum, with four years of Latin, English, history, mathematics, science, and at least two years of a world students can expect a strong—and continuing—emphasis on structured writing and public speaking, as well as an overarching practice of the kind of analytical thinking that will ensure all T the rigors of college work.
The Brooklyn Latin School is an International Baccalaureate (IB) School. Under the IB Diploma Programme, all 11th and 12th grade TBLS students engage in a rigorous two­year course of eligible to receive an IB diploma, which is widely recognized and respected by prestigious universities.

Q44_1: The Green School provides students with arts based opportunities, both in and outside of the classroom. We firmly believe that arts education provides students with an opportunity to think critically, and to also find a voice to express themselves. With strategic planning and partnerships, we have a visual arts teacher and theatre teacher available to our students. We also have fostered partnerships with community based organizations, that have provided our students with drama opportunities, as well as opportunities to create art within the greater Williamsburg community.

The performing arts department at EBT is one of the biggest and best in NYC. We have four full concert bands, two jazz bands, two choral ensembles, and numerous chamber groups such as guitar ensemble and clarinet choir. Students have the option of majoring in music, which involves taking Music Theory. The instrumental, choral and general music programs draw from all three schools in the campus and allow students to perform at their ability level regardless of age or experience. All musical ensembles compete annually at the NYSSMA festival where they have received Gold and Gold with Distinction awards. In addition to our performing groups, students may take classes in technical theater, which prepares students for jobs in the entertainment industry, focusing on stage direction, lighting and sound. 

Our visual arts department offers students instruction in the foundations of drawing and painting. Advanced students may move on to studio art classes, and AP art history.

Q42_R1_C10: We would love to participate again but may not be selected.
Q44_1: The Brooklyn Preparatory High School Arts Program offers students a variety of courses to explore their interest in art and develop skills in the area of their choice. During the first semester of 9th grade, students choose to take an introductory course in either Multimedia Arts or Music Appreciation. Each subsequent semester, students may elect to take additional art courses, such as Comic Illustration, Fine Arts, Photography, Printmaking, Latin Dance, Chorus, Keyboard, Hip Hop & Spoken Word and Band & Drums. Students who wish to delve deeper in a particular area may apply to take Photography 2, Advanced Fine Arts, Masters of Music, and AP Studio Art.

The Williamsburg High School for Architecture and Design is a 9-12 college preparatory school committed to developing students as imaginative critical thinkers. Our curricula builds a foundation of visual knowledge, skills and literacy for creative problem solving, as students are exposed to design and architecture in stand-alone courses as well as having these studies infused into their core academic courses. The environment at Williamsburg High School for Architecture and Design promotes academic achievement through the integration of a student’s career interests and aptitude while establishing connections between classroom learning and the world in which we live.

Partnered with the World Monuments Fund and the Park Avenue Armory, the Williamsburg High School for Architecture and Design (WHSAD for short) offers students a unique and engaging four-year course sequence with a focus in architectural drafting, design principles, and historic preservation. Our inter-disciplinary and hands-on approach to architecture, design, and the visual arts integrates internship experiences and skills training throughout core academic content areas. WHSAD students can earn a Career & Technical Education (CTE) endorsed diploma in Architectural Drafting & Design, and up to 6 college credits upon graduation from our program.

All of our students are given the opportunity to participate in paid internships with industry partners.

Middle School 577 has provided direct arts instruction to the entire student population. All students receive instruction in a variety of disciplines including visual arts, dance and music. Our goal is provide students with the opportunity to engage in and seek out their talents and interests in the field of arts. All students are provided with a three year sequence in music and visual arts. We also offer students the opportunity to engage in “clubs” specializing in music, dance and art. Our 8th grade students engage in a ten week residency with the American Ballroom theatre.  During the program students are taught the art of ballroom dancing by a licensed dance instructor.  Due to limited funding we cannot provide students advanced courses in the arts disciplines. We are fortunate to have dedicated staff members who are able to use their resources to provide our students with a high level of arts education. Moving forward, we hope to seek new opportunities for our students to engage in.

In an effort to have students learn to express themselves visually, many projects are designed to be reflective of each student. Projects are aimed to allow students to be reflective and express who they are as individuals.  Students use the elements of art and the principles of design to build upon their understanding of art, as well as the artistic process.  In order to gain a deeper understanding of successful works of art, each project will highlight a particular principle and/or element.

Automotive High School is currently developing a Career Technical Education track where students will receive a endorsement after successfully psssijg the Adobe Photoshop assessment. Students will participate in a four year sequence including the required Art classes as mandated by the Department of Education.

El Puente Academy for Peace and Justice strives to provide all students with rich and inspiring engagement in the performing and visual arts. Classes include visual arts, Latin percussion, dance, drama, vocal music, instrumental music, theater tech/production, and quilting classes taught by our staff artists and teaching artists from our community arts partner. Teaching artists also partner with classroom teachers to integrate the arts into academic classes and in support of ELL students.  We schedule regular cultural celebrations that allow our students to collaborate with their peers in producing culturally relevant explorations and expressions. We provide our students with on-going opportunities and mentoring in the arts that allow them to develop mastery over their 4 years at the Academy.

This year at our school we have added new staff members to enhance our arts program.  Our arts program is a strong component of our cluster program.Our program consist of one dance teacher, two visual arts teachers, two music teachers and two theater teachers. Our staff of the arts are well experienced and make-up a wonderful arts team.  As an arts team we share the common goal to serve and create programs that meet the needs of our title one students with a large population of Ells, as well as our ICT and special needs classes on every grade level, as we follow the blueprints in each of the arts.We collaborate with each other as well as with our class room teachers.We all attended Arts Monday PD.  Most/all our students are receiving two or more of the arts.  Students demonstrate excitement and enthusiasm in each of the programs.  Our students are also offered after school arts programs and clubs such as,Community Word Project,where students work with an actor and a writer creating an original performance.  We have a fourth and fifth grade drama club. A program with Brooklyn Chorus, which work with second and third grade.  Our visual arts teachers enter many of our students work in exhibits and contests.  The arts at P.S.1K give our students many opportunities to develop and flourish in a creative and expressive forum, as well as preparing them  for a college and career future.

It is our goal to educate the whole child, and it is for that reason that we have full-time art and music teachers. We have also pursued and received grants that support the arts in our school. Through collaborations with teaching artists and partnerships with art institutions like the Metropolitan Opera Guild, every child experiences a variety of music/theater-based arts activities. All students, including those with special needs, are exposed to opera, Broadway musicals, and visual arts projects. They also have an opportunity to participate in initiatives afforded us by cultural organizations like Carnegie Hall.

Q42_R1_C1: Learning through an Expanded Arts Program
Q44_1: The 6th grade Visual Art classes with Mrs. Chiemezie are beginning two new units! A self-portrait painting unit which explores personal expression and color theory. Students choose a color scheme based on their study of the color wheel to use for their painting. Concurrently 6th grade Visual Art students will be engaged in their last clay project which combines architectute and community building. This opportunity is part of the Continuum Grant which partners with PS172 and Abron's Art Center. Students will learn the techniques of pinching, slab building and coil building. The unit will include two field trips to Abron's Art Center to glaze their pieces and see the firing process first hand.

The arts are alive and flourishing at PS 15. The many arts residencies, direct art instruction by school staff to students and professional development afforded to staff members has transformed the school. The hallways are covered with beautiful art, music can be heard throughout the building,and parents are continuously invited to attend performances that showcase the children's talents. In addition, after school art activities are offered.

This school year we saw students become more involved with the arts. New this year was our affiliation with the Metropolitan Opera Guild which enabled our fifth grade classes to see 2 operas.  We also contracted Studio In A School to work with PreK and 2 Kindergarten teachers and classes on collage, paint, and sculpture with wood and clay.  This year we won a Disney Musicals in Schools grant which enabled us to perform the Lion King and perform a number from the show in a Broadway theater.  The cast was invited to see Aladdin on Broadway.  Arts Connection provided music to kindergarten, puppetry to first grade, and dance to second grade classes aligned with current instructional units.  Students in kindergarten, first, second, third and fourth grades worked with teaching artists from New Victory Theater, integrating theater into classrooms, and they also attended performances. Continuing our collaboration with Brooklyn Arts Exchange, an artist worked with pre kindergarten, 2nd, and 5th grades, incorporating poetry and movement. S'Cool Sounds provided music instruction to PreK, second, third and fourth grades. Students attended 2 performances to the American Ballet Theater. Thanks to funding from our Councilmember, we were able to have Brooklyn Arts Council work with 60 students afterschool on puppetry, dance, and theater.  We look forward to continuing and increasing the arts available to our students in all of the disciplines.

Our active PTA arts committee oversees arts events in our school and in collaboration with the PS29 Administration helps identify, research and make recommendations for arts collaborations with world-class cultural organizations. This past year our collaborations included: Brooklyn/Queens Conservatory of Music (BQCM)optional band for 4th and 5th grade students, American Ballroom Theater’s Dancing Classrooms, Brooklyn Academy of Music, African Dance and Music residency, Construction Kids, STREB, and  educational partnership with the Salvadori Center, Bent on Learning, Yoga and Let's Play Chess. Our goal as an arts committee and school is for all students at PS 29 to have a well-rounded arts education. The PTA has made the arts a priority in their annual budget which will allow the school to participate in these various programs for the 2016-2017 school year.

P.S. 32 provides each student with an arts education that will develop creative ability and nurture a life long appreciation for the various art forms. We create connections across all curriculum areas while addressing the academic and social needs of our diverse student population. P.S. 32 will continue to offer a challenging visual arts and creative dance program as well as an in depth keyboarding, ukulele, and choral music program. P.S. 32 plans to continue the relationship with all current cultural arts partners (Rioult, Arts Connection, and others) and has begun new collaborations with community based art programs such as Artichoke Dance Company and Brooklyn Arts Exchange.  Students from Pre-K through 5th Grade make connections between what they learn in school and the cultural world around them by attending arts events around the city.

Our goal at P.S. 38 is to infuse the arts into everyday curriculum. Students receive instruction in the arts at every grade level. From keyboard instruction to dance, students have exposure to every type of art form. Our focus continues to be various dance forms, steel pan, violin, percussions and piano instruction. Our STEM lab has now been open for a year! This has enabled our staff to enhance our visual and audio arts program. Our STEM team works hard to connect technology to the visual arts!  We have an extensive steel pan orchestra. Students in grades 3-5 pride themselves with mastering different arrangements, which can be quite complex! Our hallways come alive with music. At P.S.38 we feel the arts are essential to learning. Studying the arts gives students a window into the rich and interesting world around them, teaching them about their own history and culture, as well as that of other people. It cultivates self-expression, imagination and creativity as well as critical-thinking and problem solving skills.

Our school continues to have a full time visual arts teacher who works weekly with all students in grades PK-5. All of our students receive additional arts education through extensive arts in school residencies in music, dance, and theater. Arts education is further supported through field trips.

The arts at PS 58 provide a rich and diverse experience for all students. Students receive instruction from highly qualified arts teachers in music, visual arts and drama. While there is no dance teacher employed full time the curriculum is enriched by collaborations with cultural institutions such as Dancing Classrooms and The New York City Ballet. The lower grade music program is built upon instruction of percussion, visual work and beginning notation. In the upper grades the music curriculum centers around students in grades three through five learning to read musical notation and playing a string instrument of their choice. In the visual arts - exploration of media, visualization and problem solving skills are developed over the six years that students receive instruction. The visual arts program relies heavily on visiting artists, contemporary designs, interdisciplinary learning and technology in the arts. Each year, all PS58 students showcase a piece of their artwork during the weeklong Annual Art Show. The Drama program uses scripted work and improvisation to teach students about the theatre. Classes put on small productions throughout the year. The fifth grade class culminates their program with a major performance.
