The Arts continue to be a stronghold in our school supported and loved by all students, teachers, school leaders, families and the entire community.

Q45_1: We are developing our  art program to include a number of electives  that will culminate in an Art Regents exam. This will allow students the opportunity to graduate with an Advanced Regents Diploma and a portfolio which students can use if applying to an arts college program. Students in the visual art program learn skills in creating works of art through sculpture, painting, drawing, printmaking, and collage. Students also have the opportunity to explore other art forms such as dance and theater through our partnerships with many outside arts organizations:  Opening Act Theatre Company, The Brooklyn Historical Society and the Creative Arts Team. Additionally, one of our physical education offerings is dance. Our students perform in the annual CUNY Shakespeare Festival. Students are exposed to the multiple cultural offerings of their community and the city through an annual Culture Day trip where students in all grades visit the many museums and art programs that New York City has to offer.

Q44_1: PS107 has a rich and varied arts program that includes weekly instruction with highly effective Visual Arts and Music teachers and many PTA-funded arts residencies.  We feel strongly that arts education is essential for all children and provides many opportunities for high levels of critical thinking and discourse.  With PTA support, each grade participates in multiple arts-related field trips, such as performances at the New Victory Theater, Brooklyn Academy of Music, and Dance Africa.  These experiences, in addition to our arts programming and residencies, provide students with valuable creative outlets.  They not only allow students to develop a deeper understanding of these arts disciplines, they also foster rich connections to literacy, math, social studies and science.

PS130 is a diverse multicultural community dedicated to academic excellence as well as artistic development and expression.  Our multicultural and linguistic diversity enriches students experiences, nurturing students abilities and talents.  The collaboration efforts with our arts partners Arts Connection, Music and the Brain and Carnegie Hall promote and support artistic abilities in all of our students.

PS 131 has always been dedicated to including the arts in the education of our children. Our goal is to provide each child a means to express their creative side in the various art medias. We strongly feel this will provide a well rounded education needed to be college ready.

Q37_4: Volunteer to chaperone Arts based trips
Q44_1: At Charles O. Dewey, students have their normal Common Core curriculum infused with technology , career readiness and the 7 Habits from the "Leader in Me" program. We are very successful with several shows through out the year, where we showcase mutlimedia artwork and performances created from our student body, and through our partnerships that was formed with NurtureArt, Aperture, RUSH Philanthropic in-house Gallery, Residency Unlimited, Hudson Valley Arts Council, NYSSAA, Brooklyn Arts Council, Diversity Lens Project, Open Source, Leader in Me Foundation, and our in-house CBO Center for Family Life. Through these collaborations, students have participated in artist studio tours, art internships, art seminars, and workshops that connect them to artists in their community. Students show their work at Gala events in Chelsea, Downtown Brooklyn, Williamsburg, Park Slope and Sunset Park. Opportunities for creativity are limitless through a wide range of extracurricular activities and project-based learning in all content areas using STREAM (sci, tech, reading, engineering, art, math).

Q37_4: working on arts projects with students and teaching artist
Q44_1: Arts is embedded into the curriculum at Brooklyn New School PS 146. Students receive classes with a certified music and art teacher and instruction provided by teaching artists from the Brooklyn Arts Exchange. As well, third grade students participate in an African dance residency through the Brooklyn Academy of Music.   In addition, both the visual arts and performance arts are developed through the social studies curriculum within the classroom. In our third fourth and fifth grades students participate in arts workshops where they create models of crafts from other cultures. Open ended inquiry allows students to use the arts for exploration. In this way, students apply the skills learned in the art, music and theater classes to develop their own creations, whether these be skits, shadow puppet theatre, models of buildings, or other visual and musical expressions.

The Sunset Park School is a large Title I elementary school with 1587 students that offers its growing artists daily opportunities to partake in all art forms: music, theater, visual art and dance. Our largely ELL population, enjoy the arts regularly with our eight in-house art specialists, exposing them on a daily to a robust Blueprint based arts program. Students regularly engage in inquiry based sequential CCSS aligned projects. Students' exemplary work is showcased in exhibits and in-house displays and in citywide festivals. Students are challenged and empowered through productive struggle and gain autonomy to produce creative individual and group projects. Students also share multiple opportunities to engage in a robust enrichment after-school programs. Students grades K-5 participate in a vast after-school program that meets once or twice a week for two hours each. These clubs offer: chorus, art and music, animation, violin, band, drama and more. In addition, students participate in an annual musical theater production and attend in-house shows and exhibits. Students frequently go on trips to cultural institutions to special performances, concerts and exhibits. Through the arts, we immerse our students in countless opportunities to engage in the arts as a solid foundation and a means of communication that empowers students to cultivate and appreciate the value of the arts.

P.S. 172 offers a comprehensive foundation in the arts. In dance class, students learn creative movement, cultural, and traditional dance technique. They work with the elements of dance, improvising, choreographing, performing, and critiquing as their skills grow. Through their time in dance class, students learn historic and current dances from around the world and hone their ability to create their own choreographic work and be discerning audience members. Art class begins with a visual or tactile exploration for motivation or the introduction of an artist or skill technique. Students partake in a wide range of art-making processes and experiment with various media and techniques as they learn about art and artists from an historical and contemporary perspective. In music class, students experience a wide variety of musical genres, instruments, songs, and composers. They develop musical skills and concepts needed to succeed in any general music setting. Instruction draws on musical learning methods including the Orff Shulwork, Kodaly, and Dalcroze methods in order to allow students to explore their voices, strengthen ear training, and develop the confidence they need to succeed in any musical setting. Through their studies in all arts disciplines, students learn problem-solving, expression, vocabulary, social skills, self-confidence and creativity. Social studies and classroom vocabulary curriculum are integrated into arts lessons to further support student learning.
Q45_1: Our students are majority from low-income families and immigrant families.  We have many high-needs students.

Q44_1:
Our school has over 1200 students. They all receive visual arts at least once a week. Many also receive music and dance. We have 3 visual arts teachers, 1 dance and 1 music. We provide many arts residencies. Each winter we perform the Nutcracker where over 100 children from 3rd to 5th grade perform, design sets, make costumes, perform as stage and lighting technical theater and design the program. The Nutcracker also has many of our special needs children performing in the show.This project has not only created a bonding with students in multiple grades and abilities, but with the teachers also. They pitch in to help with everything, especially performance night! 
The arts is very helpful as a vocabulary builder for our large ESL population. We have 26 languages represented in our school. The arts gives children the confidence needed to tackle academic subjects, and gives beauty to their lives through the visual arts, music and drama and dance.
Parents often ask "what is the value of an arts education?" We tell them that the arts is the only subject where the correct answer is not in the back of the book. You learn that the world is not just black and white and that your answer to an artistic solution is just as valid as everyone else.
They learn about their own culture and others' through art projects.
Q45_1:
We have many ICT and special ed classes where the development of their fine motor skills is paramount.
They also benefit from making connections through the arts and connecting them to the social studies and math terms they use. Vocabulary words such as symmetry, radial, parallel etc are words that transfer between disciplines. It helps them to visualize these concepts.

Q44_1: These are the types of arts experiences that should be available for all PS 261 students in each grade, every year: 1. Core Arts discipline instruction in visual Art, music, dance and theater every year for every student with a full-time certified teacher providing a year-long curriculum. 2. Arts integration experiences that bring in interdisciplinary arts across the curriculum in connection with learning in all subject areas. 3. Arts enrichment classes, performances, or residencies that add to or supplement instruction in the arts and arts integration. 4. City, community, and/or neighborhood-based arts experiences like field trips and other real world experiences outside of school.

PS 295 is a community that embraces diversity by nurturing strengths and talents of every child. We strive to educate the whole child while supporting them to be successful both socially and academically. In recognizing that all children learn in different ways, we believe that an arts integrated curriculum cultivates a more meaningful discovery of self, while enhancing prior knowledge and supporting content and language development. It is our hope to encourage a strong respect and appreciation for the arts. Our professional development program provides ongoing learning and leadership opportunities for all members, while offering students an exemplar for becoming lifelong learners and leaders of the future

Q42_R1_C1: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
Q42_R1_C10: There was a high amount of paperwork, and other hoops staff had to jump through to make students eligible for the Hamilton trip.
Q44_1: The visual arts program involved 80% of the school population and culminated in many student gallery shows in diverse media within the school. These have included digital photography, watercolor painting and clay sculpture. Creative self-expression and developing technical skills are emphasized.  The music program continues to emphasize student composition through it's Songwriting course. For the first time this year an afterschool club offered students the opportunity to learn to play trumpet. Groundswell Community Mural program worked with the visual arts teacher and a group of 20 students to design and paint a large mural in the school focused on the themes of safety and community.

All entering freshman choose between two four-year tracks: Digital Arts or Cinema Production. The curriculum has been developed to be sequential and comprehensive to meet our programs’ desired end goals. Both curricula have been crafted to immerse students in the technical and conceptual sides of art making, while helping them understand their place within art and cinema history and developing their distinct creative voices. The respective programs have developed partnerships enabling seniors to participate in internships before graduation. All students will graduate with a minimum of 8 credits in the arts. They additionally have the opportunity to take AP Art History as upperclassmen.

Q42_R1_C1: BRIC Arts Media Bklyn Inc.Brooklyn Information & Culture ROTUNDA
Q44_1: The Secondary School for Journalism offers a digital arts program that includes the following courses: Studio Art, Introduction to Graphic Design, and Digital Media. Through our partnerships, students participated in various arts activities: Midori & Friends provided choral instruction; Urban Arts  and LEAP provided theater instruction; BRIC provided video and photography instruction.

Our in school arts program for 2016-2017 will include a certified music teacher, in addition to our current certified visual arts teacher.  We will offer arts electives, including 3D visual arts, photography/graphic design, vocal music, instrumental music and theater.  We will continue to integrate technology into our arts programs.  Students will learn the basics of composition in music.  We also will include a pottery program in our after school arts choices.   This will be in addition to the after school theater arts, visual art and instrumental music offerings we currently have.
Q45_1: MS 442 is a 100% inclusion middle school serving neighborhoods within District 15.  We have an ASD nest program.  We also offer Regents courses and a full catalog of after school programs in academics, theater, sports and other areas.

Q44_1: Since its inception, the school has offered electives and concentrated instruction in the arts disciplines of visual art, dance, instrumental music, theatre, and graphic arts/technology component. Our unique vision is to allow our students to excel both artistically and academically in a positive, nurturing, and literate environment. We provide an arts education that develops the creative potential of each student. Our arts program is designed to not only develop the talent and knowledge of our students but to also ignite their artistic passions. We believe that children who study and practice the arts enhance their intellect, learn self-discipline and realize the global implications of creativity and culture

In dance students study of Anatomy, Jazz, Contemporary Choreographers, African American Choreographers, World Dance, and Group Choreography Projects. Students will learn and demonstrate choreography as well as choreograph in groups with their peers. In music students learn to play an orchestral instrument (violin, viola, cello, double bass, trumpet, trombone, French horn, euphonium, tuba, clarinet, saxophone, flute, or percussion), and begin to work together in small and large ensembles. Students study music notation, music theory, music history, composition, improvisation, and a wide variety of musical genres from around the world. In theater students engage in improvisation, scene study, monologue study, playwriting, and play making, and design, and will read and perform the works of contemporary and classic playwrights. In visual art students use art elements, skills, techniques, and processes to structure visual art works in the mediums of drawing, painting, sculpture, printmaking, photography, illustration, and design with an emphasis on developing well-rounded visual art portfolios. Students will use processes of critical analysis to support personal judgments of visual art works to better understand the range of artistic traditions of different cultures, time periods and art movements.

John Jay School for Law continues to provide high quality arts instruction in both dance and visual art offered at all grade levels. Several of the scheduled dance sections also participated in a theater partnership with Midori and Friends as an extension of their learning throughout the school year. The students performed two highly successful musical performances (Hairspray and High School Musical) through the combined efforts of our dance teacher and a visiting artist specializing in theater. Students also had the opportunity after the school day to join forces with Groundswell Community Mural Project to create a school mural. We continue to focus our efforts on exposure to the arts in all capacities school-wide, and therefore have maintained a strong literacy initiative throughout the two arts disciplines.  Arts instructors have gone beyond attending meaningful performances and visiting museums, and have intertwined themes that will strengthen the students understanding of the world in which they live. We have a commitment to building critical and analytical thinking strategies through learning about the arts. By infusing meaningful reading and writing content as a focus for these specialized areas of instruction we are able to create connections to other areas of academic study. Students continue to produce and perform in a student centered learning environment which challenges them to ask questions and participate in problem solving activities daily. We strive to offer an exciting and rigorous arts program for all.

We currently have one full time Dance and Visual Arts teachers. In the high school we have a Culinary Arts CTE program. We are looking to hire a full time Design teacher for the 2017-18 school year. We have applied for federal grants to ensure a balanced arts education is provided for all of our students. We have partnerships with multiple organizations that bring music, theater and visual arts to our students after-school and will continue to make strategic budget decisions and fundraising efforts to ensure sustainability.

Arts is a vehicle for expression of ideas that serves to enhance educational, academic, and social experience of children at the school. Children benefit from regular and structured arts programs, each and every day. Art develops intelligence, competencies, and skills that have a direct link to academic performance. Our goal is to allow students to experience a rich and diverse arts program. As we grow to scale, we envision regular participation in all art disciplines for all students. Currently, we have a full time visual arts provider to deliver art lessons in school. Theater skills are incorporated in our SELF (Social Emotional Learning Foundation) program. Students also have opportunities to visit cultural organizations and arts venues on school trips to experience the arts outside of school. In addition, we currently have a partnership Creative Music Program to ensure our students receive music instruction, and we will continue this partnership next school year. Our third graders are working with a teaching artist to create a permanent installation in our school building. To enrich the lives of our families, we worked with Center for Arts Education to provide two family programs. We had an after school puppetry program and a dance program for parents and children. Next year, we intend to further enhance arts learning for all students by partnering with cultural organizations to provide additional residency programs in dance and/or theater.

West Brooklyn Community High School aspires to engage and motivate overage under-credited high school aged youth. All our programming, including our arts program, is designed with our student population in mind. 

We plan on continuing our current offerings as well as continuing to survey our students throughout the year and enhancing what we already offer. 

Mission: _________________________________________________
We are a community of educators working together collaboratively to provide quality instruction and social emotional support to overage, under-credited , formerly-truant students in order to prepare them for high school graduation, and ultimately, for college and/or career. 

West Brooklyn Community High School, a partnership between the NYC Department of Education and Good Shepherd Services provides an accelerated, rigorous learning environment. At West Brooklyn Community High School students, their families, and staff work in collaboration to create a physically, emotionally, and socially safe community. 

At West Brooklyn Community High School, young people recommit to improve their attendance, accumulate credits, develop a life after West Brooklyn plan, and graduate with concrete next steps.

Vision: __________________________________________
We continually co-create a community filled with intellectual curiosity, high engagement, laughter, and camaraderie.  
 
Our students experience academic success in all forms, high expectations in the classrooms, excitement for lear

We currently provide visual arts and dance through doe personnel. We also provide drama and theater through one outside organization, Enact Inc., which provide in-classroom workshops to our students on weekly basis.  
In addition our students are invited to films and performances a number of times during the year to enhance art instruction and exposure. Our students are excelling in visual arts as for three years in a row we will have a representative in the annual Borough of Brooklyn Festival of the Arts. The dance teacher has created an Advance Dance Group which performs around the City and she just received a grant to provide dance instruction throughout this summer.
Q45_1:
Our ENL and SWD subgroups populations continue to grow significantly.
They are arriving mainly from Yemen and so we feel the need to provide more art forms that represent their Arab culture.

Q44_1: The Brooklyn High School of the Arts, now a district 15 school in downtown Brooklyn, boasts one of the most accomplished performing and fine arts programs in the City of New York. Our vocal/instrumental music program ranks among the finest in New York, and achieve top scores at state and city-wide competition annually. Our fine art program routinely wins major competitions, and has been featured in galleries across the country. It is a pipeline to major art universities here in New York and nationally. Our dance program, featured on Fox News is enjoying an energy that has our dance students accomplishing tremendous levels of performance. The spring dance concerts have become highlights of our school year. Our drama department, in its seventh year, featured a wonderful musical theater production of, "Once on this Island". Our Drama Department also starred in "Almost Maine". The performance was award winning, and we were one of only 4 schools featured in the Schubert Theatre on Broadway. The performance was also recognized by the Chancellor. " We are one of ten "Exploring the Arts/Tony Bennett" partner schools. ETA provides us with many opportunities for real world internships in the Arts for our students. In short, if you are interested in studying the arts in high school, and preparing for beyond, Brooklyn Arts is the school!

Students are taking a full three year 6 credit sequence in the arts that includes visual arts, dance, instrumental music and multi-media art. Students in the after school program can audition for visual arts, dance, choral and theater troupes as well as photography club.

Currently PS 676 does not have an Arts program.  We have found  over the  years that both students and families have a great interest in art instruction.  We were .  The consultant assigned to our school was able to work with our 2nd grade  classes.  The work that was generated from our youngest students was outstanding.  We also found that some of our challenging students were the most creative and the structure that the program provided helped to foster their creativity.

Q42_R1_C1: BRIC Arts Media Bklyn Inc.Brooklyn Information & Culture ROTUNDA
Q44_1: This year our arts program included Visual Arts I and II, Theater I and II, Photography, and Portfolio Arts.  Our Theatre Arts teacher facilitated several successful community-building events, including two musicals and improv shows. All 9th grade students took a required visual arts course in which they acquired academic vocabulary for analyzing historic works of art, their peers' and their own art. They used a range of media, including mixed-media drawing/painting/collage, digital photography, and stop-motion animation to create visually and conceptually compelling works of art that fulfill aesthetic, expressive, narrative, and/or political art purposes. Students had the opportunity to engage in supplementary arts experiences through our after-school program, which includes Dance, Music and Comic Arts Clubs. Students participated in Animation and Film programs through BRIC arts residencies funded by the CASA grant. Our John Jay Campus hosted its second annual Sing program, through which students from all schools collaborated to write, choreograph and produce an original musical. We hope to be able to offer more rigorous arts electives moving forward in a greater range of media, including graphic design, music production, and film editing. Student photography was exhibited in a Gowanus Arts Studio, and at a coffee shop in Park Slope, and we will be showcasing senior art at a gallery in SoHo in June.
All students have an exposure to Music and Movement, Dance and Visual Arts through NYS certified teachers or through a partnership with Together in Dance teaching artists.

In 6th Grade Visual Arts we focus on content and form, approaching the elements of design with hands on projects. Through research and presentations the students receive an introduction to art history by learning, understanding and recognizing the work and styles of at least fifty classical and contemporary artists. 7th Grade drama.: Through the study of playwriting, acting, and improvisation, students build theatrical skills applicable to everyday life. They are exposed to a variety of theatrical genres including musical theatre, straight plays, Renaissance theatre, and even American rhetoric as they sharpen their analytical and performance skills. Movement is also explored through Tab Dancing. 8th graders music: 8th graders spend time doing analytical and comparative listening to music of various eras/genres and learn about group singing, arrangement and rehearsal technique, songwriting, piano, and music technology. After school activities include choir, rock band, and in collaboration with the drama department, a staged musical.

Public School 5 is a title 1 school.  We have a 90% fee lunch population and 30% of our population lives in transitional housing situations.  Due to our reducing register, our budget will not allow for paidyearlong residencies.  We have hired a great dance teacher who services all of grades at a very reduced salary.  We have received grants from Brooklyn Arts Council and Materials for the Arts to provide Music and Visual Arts.  Werely on grants to provide the arts due to our budget.  we have received many educational arts programs from our community congresswomen and assemblymen.  Our staff is very creative.  They have talents that provide for instruction during culminating events, such as projects and our themed presentations.  We rely on the wealth of the skills of our staff to provide that enrichment for our students.

The Crispus Attucks Young, Gifted & Talented arts studio is dedicated to developing observation skills, technical ability and creating finished art work to encourage self-confidence, knowledge, and enthusiasm. Our program is designed to enrich students through the visual and performance arts. The arts curriculum is directly aligned with the Common Core learning standards for visual and performance arts. Our goal for this year was to spark students’ thinking and creativity by providing a comprehensive and engaging program. Students learn a variety of techniques along with a firm foundation in the basic elements of art. They explore the important role the elements play in the creation of artwork throughout history. Students are inspired using a comprehensive range of visual works of art which reflect how the elements of line, shape, value, color, texture, etc. work together to make art. Through drawing, painting, collage and other mediums students were able to understand all of the components that produce art in its many forms. Students equally understand how the arts contribute to the community in which they live, which in turn enables them to discover new ways to express themselves.

Public School 25 - The Eubie Blake School offers a rigorous and varied Arts program to all our students Pre-k -5th grade, including students with disabilities and English Language Learners. A variety of sections are offered to engage our students in dance, visual arts, performing arts, music, monthly grade assemblies, drumming and trips to cultural organizations. These programs are provided on-site and off-site by cultural organizations such as YAFFA, LeAp, Music for Many, Shadow Box Theater, Morgan Library, Band for Today, as well as a certified full-time Visual Arts teacher and a full-time Music teacher. Our program uses a collaborative interdisciplinary approach which is aligned to New York State standards the Common Core and the Blueprint for the Arts.  Because of our commitment to engaging our students in a sustained rigorous Arts curriculum outside of the traditional reading, writing and math curriculum we have maintained a full-time Music teacher and a full time Visual Arts teacher and have partnered with various cultural Arts organization to enrich the lives of our students and engage them in a love for the aesthetic. The Goal of our Arts program is to celebrate the Arts, enhance our students’ ability to explore non-traditional ways of learning and express themselves in creative and differentiated ways.
Q45_1: Our school also celebrates with our families and community members the various cultures represented in our school through our annual Multi-cultural celebration. Our students are taught various cultural dances, music and study the visual art and artifacts from various countries represented in our school community.  Our staff members and parents from various and diverse cultural backgrounds teach and demonstrate these for our students.  Our school engages students in  monthly performance assemblies where students are given the additional time and opportunities to express themselves in various art forms. Our regular Talent shows allow our students to express their talents and skills in dance, singing, pantomime, drumming, drama and art.  In our early grades students are engaged in expressing their thinking through dramatic play along with the other art forms. Additionally, our school do enrichment clubs which provides our students with increased opportunities to express themselves through drama, visual arts, crafts, drumming and poetic expressions.

Q44_1: PS 26k aims to engage every student in quality visual arts and performing arts instruction. This past year, every student in our school has received visual arts instruction on a weekly basis, provided by our NY State certified K-12 visual art teacher, based on the NYC Blueprint for the Arts. This past year, our students have worked in following artistic media: painting, mixed media, sculpture/3-D, drawing, collage, printmaking, fiber arts, photography, 2-D poster design, puppet-making and performance. A focus on literacy during art classes means that students are either discussing, reading, or writing about art during every lesson. Students engage in meaningful artmaking, analyze their own work and the work of their peers, as well as works by well known artists. Ample opportunities for exploration of materials are provided during lessons and also during periodic "Art Center Choice" studios. Arts instruction this past school year has put a focus on interdisciplinary projects, incorporating Science, Social Studies, Math, ELA, and Social-Emotional development into the visual art, music, and dance curricula. An additional focus of the Jesse Owens art program this past year was to increase parent involvement in the arts program through in-house parent arts workshops which were planned and facilitated by our Visual Art teacher with the help and support of our school's PTA. In addition, students have participated in a number of arts-based field trips and school assembly performances.

Q45_1: The goal of the music and integrated arts program at Warren prep academy is to provide high quality arts education and rigorous instruction in the areas of music, dance, drama and visual arts to foster social emotional, cognitive growth and academic succeas. The music and the brain keyboard program helps to foster cognitive and musical fluency within our school.

Q44_1: Stephen Decatur Middle School 35 Arts Program for the 2016-2017 school year has been advanced by the wonderful work of our committed educators in the disciplines of Visual Arts and Dance. Jasmine Jones and Amiyr Barclift have worked diligently in collaboration with Jean St.Hill to provide an enriched arts program that consists of a plethora of art masterpieces and dance routines. In addition, for two consecutive years we have added our very own "Poet's Chair", which consists of the creation of our students poems. The Arts program displays their talents twice a year with our "The Arts in Learning Performances". Talents are displayed in the Fall and Spring of each academic year. During the 2015-2016 school year we embarked upon a dance residency with Purelements that focused on the genre of African dance. Our 6th grade students (Howard University) participated in this residency in both the Fall and Spring. Finally, the New York City Department of Transportation Safety Education Department in collaboration with Mr. Amiyr Barlcift, Visual Arts Educator conducted a residency program that afforded our student the opportunity to observe banner and sign making. Our students banner on safety will be displayed throughout our community upon completion. Stephen Decatur Middle School 35 is one of the five middle schools selected citywide to participate in this program.

The current arts program at Public School 40 is comprised of a weekly enrichment period that in which every child in P-KG to 5th grade engages in teacher-led arts activities spanning across genres of music, dance, theater, and visual arts. We also build on our existing program by offering dance to all of our students through a collaboration with a local art program, as we understand that a strong arts program will enhance our children's academic abilities.

We are a school dedicated to bringing out the artist that exists in every student. We offer our students a diverse arts education that includes, dance, visual and theater. Students who have an interest in attending an arts high school;also have the opportunity to engage in mastery classes with a dedicated advisor. Students throughout their three years at our school engage in several arts experiences including visits to cultural organizations, attending Broadway shows and mentoring with a resident artist.

At P.S. 309 our arts program include Sports and Arts in School's Foundation, an after school program that facilitates the students' exploration and creativity in visual arts, sports and cooking. Student work is celebrated and prominently displayed throughout the building. All students from pre-kindergarten through fifth grade receive music, and we've worked with Town Hall for drama, Carnegie Hall musical partnership for 1st grade music, Ball Room Dance, Studio in A School for PreK and K, African Drumming and BAM Dance Africa. Students learn to become creative thinkers and support their ideas with authentic illustrations.  Students learn the craft of performance and presentation. Students will develop the skills and courage to present to an audience that expands schoolwide and includes parents and teachers.

Thaddeus Stevens PS 81 supports the arts because it improves individual well-being, unifies communities, improves academic performance, sparks creativity and innovation and helps keep children in school. With these reasons in mind, we collaborate with Community Based Organizations to help us finance our Arts program.  One of our biggest supporters in "Change For Kids".  This organization (CBO) has brought visual art residency, theater residency to our scholars, teachers and parents.  As a result of this collaboration, our students are more confident when making their thinking visible in and outside of the classroom. Through the work of another community based organization, "Inspire Corp", Yoga, African dance, song writing and visuals arts are also offered to students based on their choice.  We would love to have a residency that supports theatre.  However, teachers use literacy periods to incorporate the art of speaking and acting. We are a Title 1 school in good standing.  Many of our  students come from shelters, single family homes or foster care.  Nevertheless, we understand that access and exposure can make a difference in the lives of all students.  With this in mind, we are determined, that budgetary constraints will not hinder our students from receiving 21st century skills that support learning in other core subjects, "The Arts".

Q44_1: Our arts program includes: Collaboration with teachers (classroom and cluster) to create theme-based projects and trips; increase in the amount of trips to cultural institutions based on grade curriculum and arts instruction. We will continue our partnership with Arts For All and Ballet Tech. We will continue working with our grant opportunities with Green Weeksville Project. Visual Arts instruction for all grades at least once a week will continue.

We provide music instruction through the Noel Pointer Strings Program. We have also partnered with LEAP, Neighborhood Music and Arts, and the Brooklyn Arts Council to provide visual media and the arts to our literacy instruction. Students view and participate in monthly assembly programs written and produced by the teachers. Students in music programs participate in musical concerts as well. We have a parent volunteer who provides classroom art instruction to students in grades K-5. Art sales/exhibits were held three times this year.

Q44_1: Foundation classes in Visual Art are offered to grades PreK through 8th grade. Foundation classes in Music are offered to students in PreK through 5th grade. P.S. 308 students are exposed to a wide range of arts focused education in class instruction, enrichment programs and after school initiatives. We also offer learning through the arts programs to K-8, provided by local cultural organizations. In addition some of our specialized offerings are Steel Pan Band, Instrumental Music, Hip-Hop Dance, Theater arts performances, Interpretive dance, and Art and Design classes.
Art Matters provides students with skills to conduct performances and develop skills in Dance
