Q44_1: Theater and the Visual Arts

At Brooklyn High School for Law and Technology we are trying to include the arts in the 2 strands of our school, law and technology.
Right now we are working to develop a technological based art program for students who wants this strand, we are doing digital art, digital design and digital video to include students that are interested in technology. For the students who are interested in the Law program we are using a more traditional approach, teaching basic arts, arts fundamentals and studio art, as well including technical drama and dance.
At this time we are able to have several art classes that keep our students in touch with the demands of the new technologies in the creation of digital media, as well as using traditional classes for the students who are interested in painting and drawing as expression.
Q45_1:
We obtained a grant that is helping us to develop the technology arts program in our school, with the resources that DOE provides is difficult to have a strong arts program as we need to be able to have more that 2 art semesters.
 Our students population, don't have the opportunity to explore in the arts as they are growing up and for some High School is the only place that allows them to explore creativity outside of the regular school day. We are developing more and more students that find a purpose in the Arts while they never really thought about it. Most of out students look for a more traditional education and are surprised when they start developing skills that will allow them to participate in the arts world as professionals some of this are: filming, video art, graphic design, web design. 
We are discovering that younger generations have a tendency to move toward the digital world more an more and schools are not providing support on this new technologies, keeping the majority  of art programs very basic or traditional.

Q37_4: Parent and Family guided visits to area museums and galleries.
Q44_1:
Gotham Professional Arts Academy requires all students complete a graduation project in the arts in order to meet our school's performance assessment graduation requirements.  All students take a required arts foundation course in the 9th grade, then select one of three arts tracks to focus on (visual arts, acting, or art criticism).  Students then must pass five sequential art classes in their chosen area of focus.  When they are in their fifth (or more) art class, they are eligible to complete the graduation task, which we assess using an arts pbat rubric we have developed.  This system encourages rigorous and sustained training in the arts for all our students.

Through two grants received this past year (an ESD/SVP grant and an Expanding the Arts grant from the Tony Bennett Foundation), we have expanded our school's arts offerings to include after school classes in dance, music, visual arts, and fashion, and have created a new theater arts track in theater production.

Through an ongoing partnership with the Whitney Museum, all our staff received professional development in visual arts criticism from the museum educators at the Whitney Museum.
Q45_1: We are a limited non-screened community high school in a high-needs neighborhood (we are in District 16 in Bed Stuy Brooklyn and are a SWP Title I program).  Arts has been an essential ingredient of our school's mission and vision since we opened our doors in 2007.  We are also a member of the NY Performance Standards Consortium (the schools across NYS that have a regents waiver), which allows us to innovate performance based graduation tasks like our art requirement.  We firmly believe that our arts opportunities provide an essential engagement tool for our at-risk population.  We would highlight that our emphasis on the arts is woven into the fabric of our school and is vital to our identity and mission and success.  However, as a limited non-screened district community school, we do not receive any additional funding to support the arts, which means this extremely important aspect of our school community is something we have to fund entirely with regular school funds.  The grants we received last year do not contribute to the in-school arts instruction we provide all our students.  The principal teaches one art class each year to provide the necessary seats for our arts students, but that is not a sustainable long term plan.  As a school that can point to concrete benefits of having robust arts programming in a high-needs district, we hope to see increased funding for the arts as part of the City's commitment to equity in education.

Q44_1: The Brooklyn Brownstone School offers both music and visual art to all of its students, two to three times a week. The goals of our arts program promotes serious artistic study, while also making inter-disciplinary connections to core subjects. We have aligned our instructional goals with the Common Core Standards and the Blueprint for the Arts. Art education includes working with various kinds of materials, art history, and an after school art club fro qualified students.  The music program includes choral music, music history, music theory and instrumental music. We participate in Little Kids Rock, creating student bands, giving meaningful experience to careers in music and team building. We participate in Music in the Brain for Pre-K to 2nd grade,learning how to play keyboard, music theory for beginners,experiencing variety of musical styles, composing and improvising. Opportunities to see students artistic talent are available throughout the year. Student art is continually posted on the walls of our school. We host art exhibitions and visit NYC galleries as well as participate in art exhibitions held in our district. There are two in-school music performances during the year, as well as monthly musical performances aligned with our character building curriculum "Heartwood". Musicians and artists visit from the community to provide instruction and information about careers in music. All projects and activities reinforce our commitment to produce critical thinkers and life-long learners.

Madiba's Prep Arts Program includes dance, theater and visual and media arts. Our program includes two certified teachers. Madiba currently has a dance partnership with another middle school that provides the students a chance to perform and reflect on their performance with students of their age group. On Saturdays students accompany their Dance teacher to special performances around the city. 
Our Dance program offer a variety of styles such as jazz, ballet, hip hop and tap. Our 6th graders learn introductory dance steps. Our 7th and 8th  graders who have already mastered the basic dance steps learn more challenging steps to enhance their skills and technique.  
Our Visual Arts program offers our scholars an opportunity to learn new techniques or mediums. The teacher provides our scholars the necessary foundation of skills that will assist them in progress to use color or more advanced drawing techniques. Our painting classes introduce them  to color and its variety of forms such as acrylic, watercolor and traditional oils to conte, pencil crayon and pastels.

Students are enrolled in a dance course to earn credits towards graduation. Our students are required to earn either two art or two music credits towards graduation. Each semester this year students are eligible to enroll in a dance class where they earn one or a half credit per semester. The pedagogue grades them on assignment completion and also on the students' portfolios being gathered all semester. Students also may participate in 'YRAP: Youth Recording Apprenticeship Program' afterschool music program. During this program, students write, produce and record songs.

The Parkside Preparatory Academy marching band participated in a number of events including school graduation, Winter Wonderland Annual Program, articulation sessions and the opening of the La Sante Community Health Center. The Parkside Preparatory Academy Visual Arts Program is a Discipline Based Art Education (DBAE) Program that integrates the areas of aethetics, art criticism, art history and art production. All Visual Arts students were given a rigorous standards-based training in the arts. Students in these classes studied the elements and principles of art through text; video, careers and everyday experience in order to assist them in understanding how to look at art and the world around them in the eyes of an artist. Students participated in art critiques, which required them to pose questions and find answers. As they learned and practiced the various artistic skills and obtained new knowledge, this year prepared them for future art classes. In addition, English Language Arts, Math, Science, Social Studies and the Performing Arts was integrated into the curriculum. Students were given the opportunity to recognize and appreciate the connections that exist between Art, Dance, Music and Theatre. Art students displayed their work in their year-long Student Art Gallery, end of the year display and created props and stage settings for the drama production. Drama students produced a play, Midsummers Nights Dream. The Dance students put on the annual Dance Recital.





 
 


 The Pa

Foundation classes in visual art are offered to grades K through 5. The visual arts curriculum is aligned to the NYC Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts. Through exploration of painting, drawing, printmaking, collage, sculpture, 2D-design students develop an understanding of the Elements of Art & the Principles of Design and the 5 strands of Arts Learning. We also offer learning through theater arts programing connecting historical and cultural concepts covered in the classroom and expressed through performance. In addition, we offer specialized Violin and Recorder instruction to our kindergarten and 1st grade students. Our 3rd, 4th and 5th grade students travel within the community to take Ballet and Hip Hop dance classes in partnership with the Cynthia King Dance Studio.  Further investigations of dance, theater arts performances, art and design exploration are incorporated throughout the P.S. 6 Arts philosophy. Our goal is to continue to grow the P.S. 6 arts program each year adding by another discipline in order to deepen the imaginative and creative capacities of our students.  Our goal is to educate the whole child; the arts are a large contributor to this philosophy.

P.S. 12 continues to try to provide every student with a variety of arts experiences whether they take place on or off site during the school day, after school, or on the weekend or school holiday. Our goal is to provide every PS 12 student with a broad sense of the arts. Many of our students do not leave the community. Therefore, it is imperative to us that every student attends concerts, goes to museums and experiences live theater. It is also important to us that our students be able to create their own art through hands on experiential sessions and working with actual artists so that they can share their experiences with our students. PS 12's administration and teachers believe that the more enrichment we can bring to our students, the more we follow our vision of educating the whole child. We want our students to experience the world beyond their community, yet realize the possibilities the arts can bring to their world within their homes and their lives.

Q42_R1_C10: Grant has to be renewed annually
Q44_1: Middle School 61 staff, students and community all appreciate the arts! Our art consists of grades 6-8 Music, Dance, Theatre, and Visual Arts. We are the only middle school in District 17 that offers accelerated Visual Arts for students in the 8th grade. We also offer outside arts programs to enhance our curricula. We feature the M.S. 61 Children's Theatre Ensemble which has performed for community organizations, Chancellor Farina and live on Broadway. Students are given the opportunity to showcase their talent in school-wide assemblies and student created exhibits to display talents in music, dance, theatre and visual arts.

This year our school used the services of two  cultural organizations to provide music and art instruction to our Pre-K to 5 students. Our classroom teachers include music, dance, theater, as well as visual arts in their lesson plans. Our students participate in many exciting school based performances, contests, and competitions. In order to address the Common Core Learning Standards, our students are engaged in developing their oral and written skills by incorporating puppetry, theater, music, visual arts or electronic media to enhance their performance skills, creative thinking and expression. Our goal for all our students at P.S.91 is to provide continued exposure to all art forms and to instill an understanding and lifelong appreciation of the arts.

Public School 92 offers direct instruction in the genres of visual arts and music as provided by the two experienced teachers. This is complimented by attendance at off-site cultural institutions (e.g. Brooklyn Museum, Brooklyn College Center for the performing Arts etc.) and in-house student performances. Also, this year we were privy to secure a grant from our District elected official and NYCDOE arts department to work with an external partner to enhance the students'  passion for African Dance. Our goal is to increase opportunities for our students to be participants in and as viewers of various visual arts form and performance venues. We also strive to incorporate the arts in our regular core content areas, particularly literacy and social studies. For the lower grades(e.g. Pre-K & K), the activities are infused in their daily routines and used to enhance their learning experiences. Our teachers provide opportunities for arts related projects, as we maintain a "gallery" type exhibits throughout the school building. This is accentuated during certain time of the year with the special events such as "Black History or Women's History Month." There is an emphasis on experiencing the arts at community museums and integrating it into the various units of study. At PS 92, we believe that the arts is an extension and essential component of a child's education experience which enhance their learning and overall development.

Q45_1: The Visual art program at P.S. 138 helps students develop confidence, creativity and literacy througgh creative projects.The curriculum is align with the standards and benchmarks set forth by NYC DOE blueprint for Visual Art.PS 138, art program goal is to make art the starting point with art making.By connecting art to every subject in the school's curriculum, and by interconnecting a multidisciplinary art program, students not only benefit from the structure of each class, but also from their diversity.The art program is intergrating between every subject in other to give student a rich ,well varied, and all-emcompas art education. Throught the expolration of a variety media- drawings, collage, painting, and now theater, Ps 138 is helping students develop an understanding of the principal of art and the elements of design. Students are able to use academic art language to discuss artworks and always cite "visual evidence" to support inferences, claim, and arguments made about a work of art. Goal 1: To increase student's awareness of Visual arts. 1)Introcuce different artist, art element, principles of design, and art forms to students.Goal 2: To demonstrade and develop Arts methods that support students achievement. Goal 3:To educate students about art, as well as celebrate students's creativity.This year,PS 138 partner with The New Victory theater to enhance art instruction in the middle school. Our Visual art program strives to give all students a well rounded art experience, and encourage them to create a work of art.

Q44_1: We have an in school arts residencies for each grade which included creative movement, collages, puppetry, self-portaits, and ballroom dancing. After school enrichment programs included African dance, contemporary dance, steel pan, violin, and band.

This year PS 181 hired a full-time music program to provide music instruction to those students in grades k-5. Students were introduced to the 'recorder' during the instructional day and have begun to learn how to read music. We currently offer an after-school music program for students in grades 6-8. Middle school students are currently learning how play the clarinet and are part of our middle school ensemble.

In 2017-2018, PS 181 will be looking to include a full-time musical instructor for students in grades 6-8. Our school wide musical program will include brass and string instruments and provide students the opportunity to attain mastery on the instrument of their choice.

In addition to regular art classes, our more talented students participate in after school arts activities in theater, music, dance and the use of instruments. Our students also further their appreciation of arts through field trips to museums, theaters and other cultural organizations.

Q30_6: Museum professional development, specifically the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Design Museum
Q44_1:
Our school offers a one year visual arts class that follows the NYC Blue Print in Arts curriculum exposing students to many forms of art making (drawing, painting, printmaking, and digital media). Students explore masterworks of art focusing on particular artists and art historical periods as a way to learn a medium and/or art making skill. All units include skills based exercises and terminate in a final project in which students can show their creativity and mastery of the material which is peer critiqued. At the end of the year, student create a portfolio of their work and reflect on the skills that they have mastered.

Students from 10th-12th grade are welcome to enroll in the AP Art History class which follows the College Board curriculum and can sit for the AP Art History exam in the spring in order to gain potential college credit. The year long course covers the length and breadth of the Western Tradition in art from prehistory to contemporary art and includes indigenous art from the globe, including; African, Central Asia, Southeast and East Asia, the Pacific, and the Americas.
Q45_1: Our high school is a science oriented school. Our distinguishing feature is the field studies program that all incoming 9th graders take in tandem with the Living Environment class. We are partnered with the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, and within this partnership, students spend one afternoon every week in BBG or Prospect Park learning environmental science and biology, hands on, in the great outdoors. Most of our elective classes are geared towards environmental science and the sciences (sustainable agriculture, science research classes, AP Biology, etc.). As for our student body, our school is made up of mostly African-American students of Caribbean descent, with an additional small group of Southeast Asia and Sub-Saharan African students. We service a large percentage of students with IEPS and use an inclusion model of instruction partnering Special Education teachers with the content teachers in the same classroom.
Q46_2: BASE Visual Art Teacher/ Arts Liaison

Q44_1: Our school is committed to providing a diverse, integrated arts program for all students. This is achieved through shows, exhibits, performances and many trips. Our focus is in the areas of music, dance, and vocal. We will strive to create a love of the arts for all students. Instruction will be standard based and integrated through subject areas.

The Arts are an essential component of the curriculum at PS 241. Our children are exposed to a number of art activities and experiences throughout the year. They learn how to play various instruments such as chimes, keyboard and the recorder. Students visit museums, attend concerts, participate in dance performances, and help curate our annual art exhibit. Our Principal for a Day, Peter L. Malkin, a former student, has been playing a significant role in the education of our students by providing funds to support educational and cultural activities such as our collaboration with Carnegie Hall, Lincoln Performing Arts Center, Art Works, Young Audiences of New York City, etc. Resident teaching artists from Lincoln Center work in collaboration with our music teacher to provide our students with direct music instruction.  Students also attend two performances by Lincoln Center that take place in our school auditorium. Through our collaboration with Behind the Book, also sponsored by Peter L. Malkin, our students work with professional artists to illustrate and edit their own stories prior to publication. Three times per year, our contract with Young Audiences of NY. exposes our children to interactive dance/theater performances.  The annual dance festival, our most popular event, is held every June, over a 2-day period, and brings visitors from the entire community. Indeed, The Arts play a substantial role in the education of the students at P. S. 241.

Our program consist of a full-time full time visual arts teacher. A separate room is dedicated to the art program.The goal of our school is to provide each student access to the program as required by NYSDOE/NYCDOE

P.S. 249 strives to enrich student learning by aligning the arts curriculum with the Common Core Learning Standards, supporting student independence, content knowledge and the ability to think and speak critically. The young artists at P.S. 249 are encouraged to engage fully in the art-making process, taking creative risks and developing their own voices. Throughout the school year, students have multiple opportunities to display and perform their work as well as share in artful experiences with their families and community. The Arts Teacher Team continues to work collaboratively to make sure lessons are supported by the NYC Blueprints for the Arts and to stand behind the mission of P.S. 249 which is to nurture students as they become college and career ready.

The arts at John Bowne High School afford students the opportunity to meet both the N.Y.S. Arts standards, as well as the common core learning standards. Explicit connections are made between the arts and history and literacy is reinforced in all arts courses. Courses include photography, ceramics, studio art, fashion design, graphics, band, chorus, guitar, piano, and strings. John Bowne is proud of its state of the art piano lab. Students participate in both a winter and spring art exhibit and concert and in our second SING performance.  John Bowne has a continued partnership with the Queens College Jazz Residency. Our students have the opportunity to perform in the Spring Jazz culminating concert at Queens College and receive feedback from the Queens College music staff. We look forward to a visual arts sequence next school year.  After completion of the first year Studio Art foundation course, students will have the opportunity to select the two-dimensional or three-dimensional track.  The visual arts sequence will culminate in the NYC Department of Education commencement exam and successful completion of the sequence will result in a Chancellor's endorsed diploma in the arts.

At The George V. Brower School we believe that all students are uniquely gifted.  Our core belief has led us to engage students in multifaceted curricula that fosters creativity in drama and performing and visual arts.  We work collaboratively with parents, community organizations and faculty members to design rich and engaging learning opportunities in music, art, drama and dance.  Our teachers utilize the Blueprint for the Arts as a guide to create rigorous lessons that are intellectually challenging.

As a multi-cultural school with students from more than twenty counties, we construct projects that expose students to many cultures.   We believe that exposure to multi-culturalism will lead to respect and artistic appreciation of contributions other cultures have made to the global community.  Our school conducts cultural celebrations every semester.  Students create artistic presentations through visual art, music, dance and drama.

The George V. Brower administrative team and faculty members believe that engaging students in the arts promotes self-esteem and academic achievement.  Our interdisciplinary approach to teaching enables our students to analyze, synthesize and construct their own ideas and work products structured by content based learning.  Moreover, our instructional approach in the arts supports student learning with engagement through multiple learning styles.  Finally, all students regardless of disability or economic status have the opportunity to excel in the arts.

Q30_6: CUNY CAT and CWP And Alvin Ailey
Q44_1: P.S. 316 continues to offer a comprehensive visual art and music program. We continue to build upon the previous years learning to extend and nurture deeper artistic expression. We have a full time theater teacher who is able to broaden the students' knowledge and experience in dramatic endeavors, including exposure to Shakespeare in the 5th grade. We have added a permanent fourth grade Shakespeare project through CUNY CAT. We were able to link the art's curriculum with common core standards, classroom thematic units, as well as follow the Department of Education for New York City's Blueprint for the Art's. We have broadened our music program to include not only Music in the Brain keyboard program for grades K-5, but also a violin program for grades K-2 and a cello program for grades 3-5 through the Noel Pointer Foundation. We have partnered with CASYM, a Brooklyn Based steel pan group to teach our students and we are also working with Brooklyn Steppers, a drumming teaching organization. We have hired an additional teacher who provides instruction in percussion, guitar, and acapella singing as well as working with our school wide-chorus. We have continued to partner with cultural organizations as well as bring in artists for assemblies and engage in field trips.

Q42_R1_C1: BRIC Arts Media Bklyn Inc.Brooklyn Information & Culture ROTUNDA
Q44_1: Seventh and eighth graders are taught how to play the B-flat clarinet. They play music by reading musical notation. Many of our eight grade students were accepted into performing arts high schools.  Some of our students also were accepted into the Borough Wide Concert Band. All students are taught Visual Arts by a licensed Art Teacher. Students studied the elements of arts and the work of famous artists, replicating techniques to demonstrate understanding, knowledge, and appreciation. In addition, all students participating in the Extended Learning Program are given the opportunity to participate in visual art, dance, step, and theater. All of which are taught by teaching artists.  By June 2017, more than 85% of the students will achieve a score of 80% as measured by the New York City Blueprint for the Arts.

At PS/MS 394, we will strive to expose our youngsters to the work of various artists, and support their own creative development in the arts. We encourage our students to perform at the highest levels, sharing their achievements not only with the school community, but by providing opportunities to arouse and foster a confident spirit within them and help them to develop pleasurable experiences outside of the realm of school life. They are thrilled by the support provided by their parents and other adult members of the school community via participation in on site workshops; serving as chaperones for school excursions as well as attendance at school performances. We invite them to bring cultural agencies with which they are affiliated to demonstrate their programs, and support parents in their endeavours in the development of these talents. Our partnerships with Lincoln Center for the Arts and The new Victory Theater has really served to scaffold the Arts experiences at our school. We encourage the students to hone their skills in the arts and to demonstrate their ability within and beyond the school setting.

Our arts program offers students the opportunity to pursue at least one arts-related talent during each school year. Programmed instruction in visual art is offered in grades six-eight. Residences are offered opportunities in music, art and theatre for grades 6-8. Students in all grades can participate in an after-school and Saturday program that includes enrichment in music and dance. Trips are offered to cultural arts events based our arts program. As a result, all students meet NYSED arts requirements by graduation in the eighth grade.

Currently, our arts program consists of music for 6th and 8th graders, theatre for 6th and 7th graders, dance for 7th and 8th graders. All these programs are offered as part of our regular school curriculum. The music program entails an introduction to music course. Both 6th and 8th grades receive instruction in the keyboard, the recorder, drums , guitars and the clarinet. They are trained in vocals. Additionally 6th graders receive instruction in theatre, and literacy connection to that art form, making connections with social, cultural and historical contexts, community resources in the theatre and careers and lifelong learning in that discipline. In the area of dance, students are taught by a certified dance teacher who teaches dance in pop and hip hop dance genres.  We also have a thriving steel band after school program for all students and the students have performed at several functions both in and out of school.

This year the Music and the Brain program has been our main contributor to the arts program in our school. We have had the opportunity to work with a group which focuses on Theater Arts. The MATB program has extended to the 4th grade to ensure the upper school gets to continue the the development of this skill. The school provided several field trips to a variety of different places including the museums, the zoos, science exhibitions and the circus

Q45_1:
The goal of our program is to introduce our students to varied art forms and techniques, affecting their everyday life and stimulating their creativity. 

Introduce students to the concepts of art and design that include the visual arts. Students identify the principles of design in a wide range of visual disciplines.

Through music, students have an outlet to express their feelings and thoughts.  Providing students with the access and opportunity to music,  promoting their mental development and providing an outlet for emotional expression.   Through experience and practice, we hope to inspire and introduce students to appreciate the many genres of music. 

The Arts in our school community will encourage students to reach out to each other to solve real life problems and share knowledge while building on their collaborative skills.

Q44_1: The High School for Public Service offers classes in the visual arts, music and drama. Students in the visual arts participate in Foundations, Studio and Painting classes and have the opportunity to explore a wide variety of media. Music students can explore music through Intro to Music (including keyboard and music technology), Chorus and Band. Drama is also offered during the school day as well as after school opportunities. Our goal at HSPS is to continue to expand both student and parent involvement with all art forms so that students graduate with a greater understanding, appreciation and passion for the arts. We continue to expand out partnerships with community based organizations for both instructional and performance opportunities for out students.

Our goal is to continue to expose our students to different art forms. Since we do not have a full time Art teacher, so we brought in several art residencies from Marquis Studio and Music for Many to work with our k-5th grade students. The Residency with Marquis Studio was funded by Council Member of the 40th district, Matthew Eugene. This program funded an after-school art program for our 1at and 2nd grade students.  Music for Many provide residencies foo grade k-5 in Music, Dance and arts.

Arts are embedded in the academic curriculum. Children illustrate their writing, and build modes for science and social studies. For this school year 2016-2017 PS398 has a visual art cluster teacher who serviced students from pre-kindergarten through Fifth Grade. Students analyze areas genre of art. There is a focus on analyzing, interpreting, and creating narratives to reflect on particular art pieces. In addition, selected classes participate in "Studio in a School" program, whereby, they bring information from units of study. For this school year 2016 - 2017, a theme studied was on "Art and Nutrition." Students learned the benefits of eating healthy fruits and vegetables. Students drew and painted pictures of fruits and vegetables using different media such as water colors. Children's art work was displayed in the hallway for all to enjoy and appreciate.

Art 1 This course is an introduction to the basic elements of art and principals of design. There is an emphasis on line, color theory, and composition used in two-dimensional art. This is a basic foundation course that will fulfill the graduation requirements recommended by the New York State Board of Regents. Students are exposed to a wide variety of studio experiences in drawing, painting, design and three-dimensional work. Art 2 This course is the second part of a one year sequence that satisfies the graduation requirements recommended by the New York State Board of Regents. This course is an introduction to art history, art criticism, aesthetics, and art production, with emphasis on the understanding and use of the elements and principles of design through a variety of media, processes, and visual resources. Students will do drawing, painting and sculpture to learn the ideas, language, and techniques of the visual artist. Students will study examples of work by well-known artists through slides and videos. Students will continue to develop art skills through a series of related assignments about the elements of art, the principles of composition, drawing techniques, color theory, art history, and criticism which will be evaluated to determine level of mastery. Drama Students will earned elective credit in drama and theater.
Q45_1: We also offer a Culinary Artsd program where students express their creativity through food.

Q44_1: Through a partnership with the New York City WEB Center students learn how to write and record music in our recording studio and the skills associated with television production in our television production studio.

Q42_R1_C1: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
Q44_1: At the International HS @ Prospect Heights, we believe that education in the arts is essential to a well-rounded education. In addition, we believe that it is in the arts where many students experience joy in school. Students at The International High School @ Prospect Heights receive arts education every year. Our school has a full-time visual arts teacher and a full-time music teacher. In addition, through our partnerships with the Theater Development Fund and Lincoln Center, all 10th and 11th graders receive instruction from resident artists in drama, theater and playwriting. Though our program is small, it has had many successes, particularly, in the visual arts. This year, we added choral music to our programming.

Q37_4: We have Parent Arts Nights in which the parents learn Art/Music/Dance skills.
Q44_1: All students at New Bridges express their creative spirit through Art, Music or Dance class each day. These classes operate on a rotation, to make sure student time spent in each area is equally distributed and not overly affected by the school calendar. In addition to daily classes in the arts, children come together each morning for a community circle called "Bright Start" that infuses music and movement and allows us to begin each day as a whole school community. This year we hosted both a Winter and Spring Arts Festival which drew in hundreds of family members for a night of performance and student artwork on display in our gymnasium, converted for the evening into a gallery. We hosted our second annual "Putting Art on the Map" Visual Arts and Multicultural Celebration. In addition, for our Family Art Night, parents and teachers were invited to explore their own imagination and talents. We believe that the creative spirit of our children cannot only be nurtured during arts as "specials," but should be infused and integrated throughout the school day in each classroom.

Our school provides a comprehensive approach to the arts during our school day and after school. Our programs include: theatre, dance, spoken word, chorus, visual arts, arts therapy, photography, videography, storytelling, music, music production. Our music program is entirely performance based.
Students at YCD have had their work displayed in galleries, government and corporate offices. We also participate in the annual Shakespeare Festival at the Lucy Lortel theatre.
Q45_1: Most of our students are coming from feeder middle schools in D17. Many of our students have not been exposed to a rich arts program. They possess raw talent that needs cultivation.

Q44_1: STAR Early College School is 6-12 school that partners with Brooklyn College through the Early College Inititative. We currently have a full-time music teacher, a full-time art teacher. Students participate in band, art club, anime visual arts club, and semi-annual concerts and exhibitions. We also have partnered (for the last six years) with the CUNY Creative Arts Team (CAT). CAT uses drama and the arts to help students navigate through the pitfalls of teen life (bullying, dating and relationships, goal setting and college and career readiness). Also students in the upper grades also have the opportunity to interact with the arts because they take college level courses in theater and music on the Brooklyn College Campus. Finally, around 90 students in grades 6-8 benefit from the BCCP Afterschool Arts and Education program. Students benefit from residency instruction in Media Arts/ Film, Visual Arts, Performing Arts, Dance, Photgraphy and Fashion Design.

We offer a variety of music and theatre programs for students. We have sequences in chorus and theatre and technical theatre. In addition, we have a very rigorous theatre program and have worked very hard on our CTE status this year. Students are doing the NOCTI multiple choice exam and the performance based test as well. In addition we have a very rigorous dance program at the center of the school that is highly competitive. We have incorporated some studios work and have been working with Breaking the Cycle doing public service announcements and film regarding current social injustice happening presently in our society and community.  Our theatre department competes in the August Wilson Monologue competition and every year at least two of our student win on the school level to represent us at the city-wide competition.

Q42_R1_C1: BRIC Arts Media Bklyn Inc.Brooklyn Information & Culture ROTUNDA
Q44_1: Brownsville Academy High School (BAHS) is a specialized transfer high school that serves over aged and under credited scholars. The arts program includes dance and the visual arts including, but not limited to, ceramics, applied arts and crafts, drawing, painting, printmaking and sculpture. The goal of the arts department is to provide scholars with a well-rounded program that allows scholars to gain artistic skills and develop an appreciation for the arts. To this end, we have an art gallery where scholar products are always on exhibit in addition to a professional dance studio within our school building. As a result, many of our scholars excel in the arts and some pursue careers in the arts.

Q37_4: Participating in the arts activities for parents conducted by our visual arts and dance teachers
Q44_1:
Medgar Evers College Preparatory School’s Fine and Performing Arts Department offers a diversified curriculum providing the performing and visual artist in-depth knowledge on refining technique, while discovering the artistry that lies within everyone. The program encourages individuality and creativity, to help students become well rounded, culturally aware and sensitive to the arts. The program encompasses classes in art, dance, drama and music.
OUR MISSION: The mission of the Medgar Evers College Preparatory School Fine and Performing Arts Department is to provide our students with appreciation and experience in the visual and performing arts, offering them an opportunity to learn and advance their skills while developing an understanding of the role of the arts in our society.
OUR VISION: The Fine and Performing Arts Department at MECPS is a high quality educational program for students in grades 6-12 that develops the whole person through a curriculum that integrates the performing arts and college preparatory academics. We aim to develop the students academically, artistically and socially so that they leave the school as independent, cooperative, responsible and creative young adults with a lifelong interest and ability in learning and the arts. We believe that these skills and qualities will prepare our students to pursue further educational goals and allow them to contribute to the life and well-being of society as a whole.
Q45_1:
MECPS is a school where students are challenged academically.  However, in order to educate the whole child, we believe that our students must use art as an outlet to express their creativity.  
Our vision includes the belief that:
• A strong academic program unlocks and supports the artistic potential of our students.
• The best discipline comes from a commitment to shared goals.
• The fine and performing arts encourage each individual to work in a creative, cooperative and collaborative manner while promoting independent thinking.
• Students learn best in a Our vision includes the belief that:
• A strong academic program unlocks and supports the artistic potential of our students.
• The best discipline comes from a commitment to shared goals.
• The fine and performing arts encourage each individual to work in a creative, cooperative and collaborative manner while promoting independent thinking.
• Students learn best in a participative and creative environment placed within a firm framework of high standards in teaching and learning.
• Our program graduates students who will then have the option to pursue further studies in either the arts and/or academics at four-year institutions of higher learning.

Q44_1: Clara Barton's arts programs include courses in visual Arts, graphics, ceramics, and music.  All Clara Barton students are encouraged and programmed to take one term of Required Art and one term of music.  Students are then encouraged to take arts classes such as Ceramics, Graphic Arts, Drawing, or ArtStudio.  Students artwork is posted throughout the building and in display cases.  This year several topics in different discipliners were used and posted to reinforce both the art and the specific topic of a different discipline.  Students work is celebrated and displayed during special assemblies.  Some of our students work is submitted to competitions or exhibitions.

In Art Expressions, students participate in the process of art-making through the exploration of various media (both two and three-dimensional), subject matter, and symbolism. Students will be able to respond critically to a variety of works in the arts and make connections between art and other subjects and social issues as a result of their studies. In addition to the classroom experiences, students attend field trips to the Whitney Museum, Museum of Moving Images,among others to establish further connections. NHMS participates in NYC’s Broadway Junior Performing Arts Program which combines art, music, dance and acting as well as fosters sense of community. In addition, NHMS has students research the history of several types of dances.  A Fall and Spring Dance production is performed for the entire school community.   After school visual and performing arts opportunities are also available as students will be able to participate in various clubs including art club, step, dance club and photography club.

Q42_R1_C1: BRIC Arts Media Bklyn Inc.Brooklyn Information & Culture ROTUNDA
Q44_1:
Brooklyn Institute for Liberal Arts now has a strong Arts program. We have a full-time art, music and theater teacher and our students are thriving.  Because of the continued support from Exploring the Arts (ETA), we were able to expand our arts program and bring in a vocal coach, a guitar coach, a percussionist and a graphic artist to work with the students. This year, we offered visual art classes to all of our students in grades 9-12. Students were exposed to a variety of art media and processes: creating 2D and 3D artworks to express ideas and feelings; developing a proficiency in terminology and techniques related to areas of art; developing the ability to understand and use the elements and principles of art and recognizing art as a means of communication. Students created numerous pieces of art, including self-portraits, which we put on display throughout the school. Our visual arts programs now include graphic design, print-making, and Photoshop. 
In music classes, students in all grades learned to play a variety of instruments and formed a school band. This band performs at our school concerts and other activities. We also have a chorus and a music production class for students who are interested in creating beats and writing music using technology.  We were finally able to get our Steel Pan Band up and running.  We were also able to offer theater classes to all 10th and 11th grade classes, and hired an organization called STEM for Dance to enable us to offer an even wider variety of classes to our students.
All 9th grade students receive a full year of art. Students work on interdisciplinary projects that integrate science, social studies, English, mathematics and health science.

At PS 770, we embed the Arts in many different ways. All of our students participate in residencies in visual or performing arts with either Marquis Studios (yoga, drumming, and dance), Studio in a School (visual arts), or the Young People's Choir of New York City. Additionally, Arts are embedded in the academic curriculum. For example: Children illustrate their writing, build models for science and social studies, they compose maps and create self portraits. Children also learn songs that are tied to the curriculum. The last interdisciplinary unit is communication, where in students produce and perform in a school-wide play.We also have a designated Arts committee made up of parents and faculty who are charged with finding and writing grants and partnerships to enhance our Arts curriculum.

PS./I.S. 66 offers a comprehensive arts program that aligns with the New York City Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts and the Common Core Standards. Formative and summative assessment tools are used by the teachers to analyze student achievement. Students in kindergarten through grade three are immersed in the Music and the Brain program, where they learn keyboarding, notation and introduction to music theory. There are two choruses: grade four/five and middle school. After school enrichment programs include individualized piano lessons, wind band rehearsal, and rock band instruction using "Little Kids Rock" materials. School wide visual arts displays highlight student work. Our goal is to provide exposure to the arts in the elementary grades and develop a comprehensive sequential arts program for middle school focusing on 2-D and 3-D design. We currently have 2 full time fine arts and 2 full time music teachers. Our after school program offers various arts and other activities. Classroom teachers also include art in their curriculum. Students have gone on wonderful trips in every grade that include the arts. Art teachers and music teachers collaborate with each other for shows, concerts, and exhibits. Students have been accepted into art shows and music students perform at nursing homes as part of community outreach.Art and music teachers collaborate with classroom teachers to provide cross-curricular enrichment to deepen students' learning experience.
Q45_1: Every middle school student receives mandatory instruction in music and art.

Q44_1: Our arts program includes two to three weekly hours of visual arts and dance for 6th, 7th, and 8th grade students. Our visual arts curriculum includes painting, drawing, writing and arts research. Our visual arts students will host an arts night exhibition in which their original works will be highlighted. Our culminating arts event will be a talent show. For the 2017-2018 year our goal is to expand the program.

PS 114 is committed to providing a comprehensive arts in education program in alignment with the blueprint for teaching and learning in the arts. Our students are engaged in a variety of enrichment activities that foster creative expression and addresses the academic and social needs of our student population. Lower elementary engage in creative music and movement activities as well as keyboard instruction. Upper elementary participate in vocal, percussion, recorder and modern band programs. Teachers work collaboratively to produce grade level curriculum based performances such as short plays and holiday shows. We continue to maintain our long standing partnerships with cultural organizations to enrich our arts programming. To celebrate the arts, we conduct annual school-wide holiday shows, music recitals, theatre productions, and multicultural dance festivals to provide opportunities for all students to participate in and experience the performing arts.

P.S. 115 provides Arts instruction in two arts disciplines: Dance and Music utilizing certified Arts staff. We participate in and provide professional development in each art form across curriculum areas that support the Common Core Standards. Students participate in Art, Glee, Recorder, Dance, and Musical Theater clubs. We have regular school wide performances by our students, with collaborative showcases in the winter and spring. All classrooms across grades produce assembly programs that showcase student talent and highlight grade level curriculum. All classes attend events throughout the city with a variety of cultural organizations. Our Art students go out into the community and participate in a wide range of performances and competitions. Grades Pre K- 2 have a Spring Dance Festival and the entire school has a Spring Carnival in June. Grade 5 is highlighted with a Talent Show prior to graduation. This year Grades 3/4 are having their own Talent Show.  
  STEAM and STREAM classes have been added to our school  highlighting the use of arts within content areas. Both programs had their own STEAM/STREAM Fair.  P.S. 115 also participated in the District 18 Arts Fair in May.
 There are regular parent workshops that showcase the arts as well as interactive workshops between students and their families.This year we had a Saturday Family Drumming Residency.

Teaching and exposing our students to various art disciplines at P.S. 135 continue to be a strong focus. Providing opportunities for the students to participate in performing arts and fine arts programs allow the students to hone their skills.The rhythmic and lovely melody of the P.S. 135 band and chorus ricochet along the hallway. P. S. 135 was the proud recipient of a dance studio from the Department of Education's Office of the Arts and Special Projects. All of our students have an opportunity to showcase their talents through our Holiday and Black History Month Assembly programs, monthly performances, talent show concert, and multicultural performances for their peers and family members during the school year. Also the performances provide our entire population with the opportunity to enjoy music, dance, and art. Along with our dance troupe, band and chorus, teachers collaborate on the holiday presentation for hospitals and senior citizens centers. Students' artwork is displayed throughout the hallways.

The P.S. 208K school community greatly values its school’s arts programs. These programs are inclusive of parents, teachers, students and our local partners. After earning a parent engagement grant our school community had the opportunity to partner with The Brooklyn Arts Council. Students’ exposure to the arts is a critical dimension to their creative and academic development. When students are provided with an opportunity to explore these arts disciplines, they are engaged and encouraged to work more conscientiously in other academic areas. Our students are given the opportunity to explore music, dance, visual arts and theater. Consequently, students express their ideas in positive and creative ways. It is our goal to continue to provide high quality arts education to our students.

My arts program is composed of music and visual art.  My students are playing the guitar and violin to enhance their critical thinking skills.  Students are exposed to visual art in the classroom.  Students are studying and engaged in different genres.  The music and visual art program is designed to have students display their talent in concerts and in their student portfolios.  Students conduct a self-assessment and a peer assessment on their knowledge.

PS 219 music and visual arts students continue to enjoy putting on the numerous class and grade performances that comprise our monthly assembly programs.  Throughout the school year they showcase their abilities to sing, dance, act and memorize extensive play scripts. They also benefit from a diverse and challenging curriculum that is informed by the Common Core Learning Standards and the New York City Department of Education Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts. This includes specialized coursework that connects music and the visual arts to the other academic learning strands (Math, ELA, Science, Social Studies, etc.) Students in Pre-Kindergarten through Grade 5 receive weekly instruction in the visual arts and music. Through differentiated instruction, the curriculum addresses the needs of our ENL's and SWD's. The visual arts and music programs present standards-based, rigorous and creative approaches to these disciplines. The visual arts program culminates in our yearly Art Show. The arts program delves deeply into the common core subjects while giving students in Grades Pre-K through Fifth the latitude to demonstrate learning over time in varied dimensions. The music and visual arts program motivates students to go beyond the walls of the classroom and to take advantage of the rich resources available across New York City in museums, concerts, and performance spaces.

The Langston Hughes School is an elementary school that works to provide students with access to the arts. We have accomplished this goal through the use of staff resources and the services offered by Ifetayo Cultural Arts Academy and Arts Connection. 

Ifetayo Cultural Arts Academy has given our students exposure to the cultural arts disciplines of West Africa and America. This year our students have received instruction in African dance and visual arts. Ifetayo Cultural Arts Academy has helped our students experience elements of the arts that they may not normally experience. 

Arts Connection provided our students in grades three through five with violin instruction.  Third grade students' musical aptitude is assessed.  Violin students are selected from the pool of students who demonstrate musical aptitude. The fourth and fifth grade students are returning students from the year before.

Our certified music teacher is a knowledgeable educator who regularly participates in professional development to enhance her craft. While new to teaching dance in school, our dance teacher is a seasoned educator.  She is currently exploring the steps needed to receive certification in dance instruction. Our dance teacher also attended professional development sessions regularly.  

Under their guidance, students have had the opportunity to create, practice and share their artistry a minimum of two times per year in our annual Winter and Spring Music and Dance Festival.

Over the last 16 years, P.S. 235 - Janice Marie Knight School has developed an arts program that supports and enhances the overall curriculum. The arts programs span across the grades and include all students. Our visual arts and dance teachers organize performances and exhibitions throughout the year. In addition, they continue to work closely with the Project Arts Community Based Contributors such as National Dance Institute, Theater for a New Audience, and Symphony Space.

Q46_2: Visual Arts Teacher and Arts Coordinator

Q44_1: It is our goal to provide a quality arts education to all of our students. To support the arts, we have classroom space dedicated to two visual arts and one music program, each supported by a full time teacher. We were also able to support our artist-in-residency programs with long term spaces devoted to multiple art forms. Our school auditorium has state of the art sound, lighting and video equipment. Students in grades K-5 have an opportunity to extend their curriculum with an assembly performance during the school year. We have had theater and music residencies to bring expanded opportunities to as many students as funding allows.

P.S. 268's art program is designed to support our students' creative ways of thinking  and provides them with numerous opportunities to express themselves artistically. We continuously strive to make sure that our instructional art program is aligned with the  Common Core art standards and grade benchmarks as outlined in the Blue Print for visual arts.

The majority of Arts Programs rovided for our students happen thhrough our ater school partnership.  During the after school hours, students are engaged in Dance, Step, Voice and Theater.  In addition, Studio In a School provides Visual Arts instruction to all of our pre-k and kindergarten classes on a weekly basis.

This school participates in the Brooklyn Ballet stepping up program.  The program provided instructions to all second grade students for six weeks. In addition, the program provides and after-school program for twenty students ranging from grade three to grade five. Instructions is provided in both ballet and hip hop.  The program meet two times per week. Twenty-two, two hours per day sessions.

The Meyer Levin Performing Arts Center is a Borough-Wide in-school and after-school arts program, staffed by certified professionals, who offer Meyer Levin students the opportunity to study disciplines of the arts that include Dance, Drama, Instrumental Music, Steel Band, Vocal Music, and Art. Performance schedules include winter concerts, Black history, spring concerts, and a major production involving a collaboration of the arts. Major productions have included “Barnum” (with students training for 6 weeks at the Big Apple Circus), “Hello, Dolly!,” “My One and Only,” “The Wiz,” “Guys and Doll,s” “Good News!,” “Once On This Island,” “My Fair Lady,” “42nd Street,” and “The Tap Dance Kid.” In addition to the in-school performances, groups have performed for the Mayor at City Hall and Gracie Mansion, for the Borough President at Brooklyn Borough Hall, Senior Citizen groups, and various Manhattan locations for the holidays like Lehman Brothers, the Woolworth Building, and the Daily News.

The arts program at The Science and Medicine Middle School 366 consists of a combination of in-house and external services to students. All seventh grade students take visual arts classes every day with a certified arts teacher. All eighth graders take dance class under the tutelage of a certified dance instructor. Our students are involved in dance after school, as well as a vocal ensemble that performs at events such as awards night and commencement. Eighth grade students attended arts-related field trips to see the film Hidden Figures and the musical The Wiz. The sixth graders were treated to Black History musical concert performed by McDonald's Voices of Black History. Finally, the dance teacher produced and directed a Black History dance exhibition show.
