Brooklyn Theatre Arts High School is a vibrant comprehensive four year college preparatory high school with a focus in theatre arts. All students take a theatre elective course during their education at BTAHS and are exposed to high quality arts programming, trips and experiences. 

Additionaly, BTA students can continue in a CTE Drama theatre track and become eligible for WBL theatre internships (Junior and Senior level) and are eligible to earn a Chancellor's Endorsed Diploma in Theatre upon successful completion of a 10 credit course sequence, senior project and sitting for the Comprehensive Examination in Theatre. 

BTA has a partnership with Roundabout Theatre Company and strong connections with The Park Avenue Armory, Second Stage Theatre, TDF and Broadway Bridges.

Our goal is to offer arts classes to our students in order to fulfill their graduation requirements. It is also our goal to provide our students exposure to the arts, thereby allowing them to discover their talents. Over the last few years, several of our students have had their work displayed at various art galleries throughout the city and nominated for prestigious honors. As an inquiry based school, we are fully committed to the idea that building connections between interest and academic rigor through the arts is a tool to propel our students to become greater critical thinkers. In addition, we will also continue to reach out to community based organizations to develop and maintain partnerships to bring more opportunities to our students in the arts.
Students at B.B.A. conduct various visual arts portfoliors that is shared with the entire community at parent teacher meetings.

Q30_6: ArtsConnection, Jacob Burns Film Center, Brooklyn Historical Society, and Commonweal
Q44_1: The East Flatbush Community Research School is committed to providing students with authentic learning experiences. Our current arts program offers every student two full years of instruction music appreciation and performance. All of our students are enrolled in our expanded day program which offers our students classes in the following areas: Step Dance, Steel Pan, School Musical Production, Visual Arts, Culinary Art, Music Production, Journalism and Newspaper Design, Robotics design, and Coding. At the East Flatbush Community Research School, students take a survey three times throughout the school year. This survey allows students to express what their interests are and what types of extra-curricular programming they would like to receive.

The Middle School for Art and Philosophy provides multiple pathways to arts learning including school day arts instruction and extensive after school arts programs including music, dance, drama, and chorus. Our unique Friday schedule provides students with the opportunity to engage in the arts from 12-2:30 pm. During the regular school day, our visual arts teacher utilizes our school's concept based curriculum and instructional model to help students make interdisciplinary connections across classrooms. Teaching artists in residence from Urban Arts Partnership through the 21st Century Grant have infused visual arts into our day program giving us and The Cultural After School Adventures programs (CASA) provide Elders Share the Arts (ESTA) who use history, and culture by using the power of the arts to transmit their stories and life experiences to benefit and support students' critical thinking and literacy skills. instrumental music and song writing, and creative dance programs. Our Sports and Arts program regularly tailors its offerings to student interest including drama, multiple forms of dance and visual arts.

In addition to stand alone visual arts class we have focused upon integrating the arts into our core content areas.  In ELA and science teachers are working to integrate the arts in a manner relevant to the content to support multiple entry points as well as student engagement.  Students are enrolled in clubs that cover a wide range of enrichment programs, such as the following: advanced art, music, film, glee club, podcasting, and many more.

During the 2016-2017 school year, students participated in choice art elective courses which included dance, african drumming and visual arts. At the beginning of the schoolyear, students completed opportunity to complete an art elective choice form to rank their art  preferences.  Students were placed in specific art sections based off of their preference choices. 90% of the students were granted their 1st preference, 7% were placed in theier 2nd choice and 3% in their 3rd choice.

The IAM school arts program is embedded into their advertising and media classes. As students move through the sequence of study at IAM, they are exposed to different aspects of the arts. Students work at producing digital art and have been exposed to digital design, digital animation and traditional graphic design. We continue our partnership with Opening Act which began in 2015 and through this program our students have performed in venues in Manhattan including performing on the Today Show.

The Cultural Academy for the Arts & Sciences offers students visual arts, opportunities for theater and the spoken word, music, and the culinary arts. New this year is a full culinary arts program headed by a practicing chef. Our student culinary team is involved in planning and catering for all school events. In addition to project-based learning classes in visual art, digital photography, and careers in the arts, we continue to build cultural literacy into the school day by exposing students to theater, music, and dance performances at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Our students and faculty participate in talent shows that feature individual talent at least once a year. Students attend gallery exhibits and enter visual arts competitions. This year they participated in the Ezra Jack Keats Bookmaking competition, Scholastic Art Awards, and P.S. Art, and are exhibiting work through the Brooklyn Borough Visual Arts Festival and the Diversity Lens Project. Students' works are displayed at the The Tweed Court House and other Department of Education venues. Our school continues to emphasize arts in service learning through our various partnerships. Once again we focused on theater and specifically Shakespeare and the spoken word. Our students participated in a variety of residencies and performances celebrating Shakespeare at the Brooklyn Academy of Music and beyond, including the spoken word in the form of poetry slams and storytelling through The Moth.

We offer an integrated approach to the arts through visual art literacy. Instruction and curriculum is developed by our certified art teacher so that art is integrated to deepen students' understanding and provide multiple forms of expression in the classroom through literacy. The goals for The Arts Education Program are as follows: Provide all students with an inquiry-based, student-centered, and constructivist approach to art expression learning; provide all students with arts-integrated lessons allowing for greater connections between the school's mission and our community service program; equip teachers with creative arts-based pedagogical techniques to meet the holistic needs of students, and align the program with DOE Blue Print for the Art. In addition, we develop partnerships between teaching artists from Brooklyn Academy of Music (BAM) and faculty in the English department to build a culture of teaching and learning so students can develop their spoken word skills.

Our goal is to provide our students with an enriching arts program. We incorporate technology in our arts classes on a daily basis. Students will be exposed to both the theory and practical application of the arts.

We are a small school with one dedicated visual arts teacher, who conducts 5 classes per day to provide an opportunity for artistic experiences to our students.  During the past 2 years in addition to our visual arts classes we have expanded our program to include such electives as Graphic Arts, Drawing, and Painting. Our visual arts teacher has focused on art history and has incorporated field trips to local museums into his art curriculum.  Next year we intend to incorporate art into our computer science classes and robotics classes.

Education in the Arts supports intellectual and educational development along with personal and social development. Education in the Arts provides each learner with diverse opportunities and lenses, to explore and build self-awareness, self-acceptance, self-reliance and-accountability. Education in the Arts helps improve skills in: teambuilding, communication, critical thinking, problem solving and decision making, interpreting oral, written and visual language, reading and writing, overall school achievement, and also, preparation for life-long-learning in and out of school.  

Throughout the Arts program, student artists make real world connections and create art that communicates something. In creating a real-world connection, you are embedding multimedia in a rich context in which students will learn and practice skills, gather and present information, and solve problems. Students connect to the real world through their project topics; the topics themselves involve some expression of students' lives and identities. Students can connect through authentic interactions with people and institutions within and outside school.  Students make meaning and find purpose by making real-world connections. Students connect through creation.

In the Art room we explore various mediums and styles in the form of drawing, painting, collage, sculpture and photography.

The outcomes for this class are
Acting Like an Artist
Self Reflection & Sketchbook Entries
Experimenting with Media 
Perspective
Symbolism 
Drawing From Observation
Color Theory
Art History and Master Studies
Critiques and Feedback
Portraiture
Unit 1: Drawing from Observation
Overview: This unit focuses on drawing from life.  Students learn to translate visual information to a two-dimensional format.  There will be an emphasis on planning in that students will learn how to create thumbnail sketches and compositional frames.   Additionally, students will explore value and space.  Finally, students will create an extended time observation based drawing that ties together the skills from this unit.
Students will create an image in color that combines at least two different styles of art, one of which should have historical significance.  The students will begin by researching a predetermined list of Artists provided to them in the form of a handout.  The final project can be mix artist styles in one or more of the following ways: New school combined with old school artists, an old master work of art combined with a modern affect,  a famous work of art combined with a current political/media event,  a master work of art combined with a cartoon, video game, etc.  This unit will explore color theory and serve as a culmination of all of the skills learned.
The additional classes offered through DTE, dance, spoken word poetry and drumming provide students enrichment and internship through artists in residency programs.

Our school is participating in the Arts Matter program. We have been fortunate to share a Visual Arts teacher with another NYC middle school. Our seventh and eighth grade students are receiving visual arts for two periods each week.

At PS13K, we believe in the arts. We provide piano instruction to students through our partnership and grant with the Lang Lang Foundation's "Keys of Inspiration" program. We offer Visual Art instruction and Dance Instruction through partnerships with various CBO's. The Karate Team, Step Team and Ensemble are other entities where students can showcase their talents in the arts. Monthly Assemblies are held with a focus around the Social Studies and Cloud 9 curriculum. During this time, students dance, sing, act and incorporate spoken word.

The arts program at P.S. 65 has provided instruction aligned to the New York State Learning Standards for the Arts. This has included the following disciplines: visual arts, music, and theater arts. Our drama program is provided through an in-house after-school program. Our visual arts and music programs are provided through certified teachers on staff within the discipline.

Cypress Hills Community School (PS/IS 89) is proud to offer a range of arts experiences to all students pre-K-8th grade. Our two in-house teachers (one visual arts and one music) provide students with a well-rounded education in the visual arts and music, including looking at art work, art making, choral and instrumental music. 2016-2017 marks our 15th year partnership with Young Audiences New York. Through this partnership, students from K-5 engage in a 12 week artist residency. Middle school students participate in residencies through HOUSE courses. In these residencies, teachers and artists partner with each other to provide students with opportunities in dance, film, music and theater. Our parents also have the opportunities to engage in arts through these residencies. We continue to be part of a band program through the Brooklyn Queens Conservatory of Music. Furthermore, we continue to build art's partnerships with other organizations such as Philharmonic's Young People Concert which provide 75 of our fifth-eighth grade students arts field trips. Through our expanded education program after-school students PreK-8 select art, music and dance as majors twice a week.

P.S. 108K's school community has always supported a comprehensive, enriching arts program that encompasses all disciplines of The Arts: visual, music, dance, and theater. It is our philosophy that through The Arts, children develop a variety of channels to express themselves. P.S. 108K is committed to providing a positive learning environment which integrates the creative abilities of children into academic curriculum. In order to reach our academic goals, we integrate The Arts into all curriculum areas to provide an education that stimulates our students. For the 2016-17 SY, the arts teacher were given the opportunity to attend a yearlong series professional development with the DOE to incorporate formative assessment strategies giving students an opportunity to reflect and modify their work. Through The Arts program we provide, our students learn how to be creative, work cooperatively, stay focused and believe in their talents strengthening their self-esteem. Our goal is for our children to self-reflect on their choice of art forms. Our students explain and evaluate their work based on the standards and in alignment with the Common Core State Standards. Each child creates a visual arts portfolio that reflects a culmination of his/her best work. We will continue to equip our students with the creative and critical thinking skills that are vital for success in the innovative environment of the future.

P.S. 149 The Danny Kaye continues to provide students with high quality arts programs aligned to NYC Blueprints and a Common Core Standards based curriculum. Students are offered extended   activities such as, Visual Arts, Art Club, Dance with Hope, Educational Alchemy Theatre, Steel band, Chorus, Guitar Club, The Little Kids Rock modern band and Keyboard Club.  Several of these clubs are led by professionals in the field, while others are facilitated by passionate and talented staff members. Many of these programs are offered as part of our existing day residency programs, while others are after-school or Saturday programs.  Our annual assemblies, concerts and arts festival connect school, families and community in sharing the appreciation of the arts. We have maintained our long standing relationship with key cultural arts organizations such as, Neighborhood Music and Arts and Yaffa Cultural Arts annually as well as forming new bonds. Our Out of School Time (OST)  community based organization, Gary Klinsky, hosts an annual arts extravaganza for aspiring artists for our PS 149 school community members.

Q42_R1_C1: Circus Education Specialist - National Circus Project
Q44_1: Our goal is to continue to grow our students creativity, and love of the arts through our art program and our fantastic art teachers.

P.S. 159K is devoted to the philosophy that the arts are a mandatory exploration for the full social, emotional, and academic development of children.  Celebrations focus on the careers embedded within arts products and the peer collabrative efforts of staff and students.  Through experienced house staff, guest artists, and grant supports, all chldren have a chance to explore all areas of the arts.  Auditorium programs, trips, grade presentations, and fairs honor the work of each child and teacher.  Scaffolding is always provided for ELL, Special Ed. and shy artists through peer assists, individual conferencing or instruction and inter grade monitors.  Historical implications, artist of history, and social studies connections are honored within class and specialist's lessons.  We are all involved, all honored and all learning the world of the arts.
The arts program that began this school year consisted of visual arts, photography, modeling/etiquette, musical theatre.

This school year PS 202 has planned a plethora of school based and school led arts programs such as oratorical contests, spring music and dance festivals and other events where the community to celebrate the artistic achievements of our students. In addition, we have art residencies in photography, steel pan and chorus. We endeavor to continue to cultivate these programs and increase the number of opportunities for students to engage in the arts.

Here at PS 213, we are confident that if we can provide a strong academic environment for our students, coupled with an array of supporting programs, such as, the Art and Dance programs that we are holistically equipping them for success. It is our view that students should be exposed to art portfolios and dance performances to introduce them to self-discipline, creative ways of expression and placing a high emphasis on self-effort, team collaboration and school enthusiasm. We have heard many positive comments and enthusiastic discussions amongst our parents and community members relatable to our school arts and our performances. We want to continue with our programs and hopefully to extend to other programs of expressions.

For the 2016-2017 school year, we maintained the full-time Musical Theater teacher and Piano instruction was also provided to the 4th graders, as per the Lang Lang Foundation grant. This year we continued our Chorus for 3rd, 4th and 5th grade students. Our partnership with Music for Many allowed us to provide our Grade 3 students with a dance residency. For the 2016-2017 school year we added a Creative Movement cluster position and were able to provide a yoga residency for Grade 4. Students engaged in activities that encourage communication, observation, replication and creation of music, dance and movement. Our Musical Theater teacher continued to work with the arts cluster teachers on alignment of curricula to the Blueprints for the Arts, CCLS and Danielson's Framework. This year we received two generous grants, Arts for ELLs which provided Bollywood Dancing for Grade 5 and the Inside Broadway theater grant for Grade 2. Contingent upon funding for 2017-18 and proven successful, we plan to provide the same programs next year for our students.

P.S. 224's theme this year was continued focus on character building.  Many of the arts projects were centered around core virtues and team building skills as well as peer mediation.   The residencies supported the vision with culminating arts activities that brought the student experiences to life. The students were able to create comic books and sculptures that reflected on life long learning experiences.  The projects were then shared with the school community for public viewing.

P.S. 290 has ongoing art related school-based initiatives. Our goals are to continue our arts programs and create opportunities for additional arts education in all curricular areas to support Common Core State Standards. The school's arts programs will include but will not be limited to the following: *Project based, theme based, and performance oriented instruction. *Arts education in the core curriculum. *Infusing content based skills into arts education. *Lessons/Objectives or topics that will enable students to meet or exceed grade level and developmentally appropriate benchmarks in the arts. Art making, literacy, academic connections, community and cultural resources, and career and life-long learning into the curriculum. *School based art exhibit. *Partnerships with established arts organizations will continue with emphasis on pushing art into the classrooms and broadening programs to integrate academics and the arts.

At JHS 292 we have licensed Visual Arts and Music teachers who teachers 6th to 8th grade students of all levels, including English Language Learners and Students With Disabilities. We pride ourselves on educating the whole child, and we feel that the Arts provides our students with the opportunity to gain self confidence in their own abilities, which they transfer into the classroom. This is especially true for our students with disabilities. Our students take pride in their performances and in their work. Our dedicated teachers prepare their students from the 6th grade, for auditions in schools for performing arts such as LaGuardia High School.

At the Fresh Creek School we believe in educating the whole child. At P.S. 345 we are dedicated to providing all of our students with quality Arts Education. 
Our Visual Arts program continues to provide our students in Grades Pre-Kindergarten through Grade Five, with rich Common Core and Blue Prints aligned instruction.
Another large part of our school's Art program can be contributed to the phenomenal cultural organizations, such as Inside Broadway, Shadow Box Theater and The Brooklyn Public Library, that we have been fortunate enough to partner with this school year.  In addition, we infuse Arts education through exciting field trips, in-school performances, and residency programs which directly connect to our curriculum and expose our students to new learning experiences.  One such program was The Green Golly Project, which taught our students in Grades Two and Three about classical music and imaginative storytelling.
Also, this year we were thrilled to be the recipient of two spectacular grants which we applied for. The CASA  Grant awarded our school with a fantastic Theater Residency program with Inside Broadway.  Through this program students from Grades Three through Five learned original songs, script and dance as part of their rendition of "Cats."  We were also awarded a Parent Engagement Arts grant through Shadow Box Theater, where parents and their children learned about Puppetry Arts and created their own puppets which were featured in a culminating showcase.  Both programs truly enriched our school community and inspired our students to develop their artistic talents.
Q45_1:
Each year we strive to expand upon the amount of Arts education our students receive.  We reach out to cultural organizations, write grants and research arts opportunities that will enrich the lives of our students and enhance our school's Art program. 
We continually seek to acquire staff members who can support us in building and diversifying our school's Art program to include more Arts instruction within our school day. Some of the programs we hope to implement in the 2017-2018 school year include a Reader's Theater Program for our early elementary grades, a School Band for students in Grades Three to Five, and a Glee Club for students in Grade Two to Five.  
It is our hope that a greater emphasis will be placed on allocating funds to support such programming goals within our school and assist us in providing a broader variety of Arts based classes for our deserving students.

Q44_1: Arts at our school is blossoming.  This year we have sprouted in school programming in addition to our after school programming.  Students across all grade levels are actively participating in the Young Voices, Big Sounds program.  Students receive vocal and keyboarding lessons and showcase their work through different outlets.  In school we also offer visual arts for students to express their passions with a connection to the school garden.  Students also engage in dance and theater opportunities both in school and through performances attended.  We are continuing to grow our Arts program at Brooklyn Gardens Elementary School.

Q33_6: Theater Development Fund, BACA and Society for Educational Arts, Primary Stages
Q44_1: Students at Maxwell CTE High School are given their two terms of required arts credits, ideally in the ninth grade. The art curriculum strives to incorporate interdisciplinary themes, art history and a wide range of studio materials and techniques. Higher level arts-based classes are offered in specialized areas such as fashion illustration, textile design, color theory, typography, photography, web design, mixed media and desktop publishing. Both studio and computer based graphic design courses are taken in sequential order. Currently, students can also fulfill the arts credit by taking music. We offer guitar, chorus, music appreciation, instrumental techniques, and keyboard/piano. We have an established keyboard lab. Students have the chance to work collaboratively with their peers in the music room for performance ensembles. It is our hope that in the near future, students will elect to pursue careers in the arts.  The art/music teachers attempt to tap into the students' creativity to strengthen their problem solving skills. Maxwell has participated in the annual SING competition for the past two years.  Students have the opportunity to dance, sing, write, set design, be in the chorus, act, stage/lighting/sound crew.  The annual SING competition has become a highlight of the school year where students can showcase their talents.

The following programs are offered to our students: 
Dance - Grades Pre-k through Grade 5 
Music - Grades Pre-k through Grade 5 including Music and the Brain (K and 1)and keyboarding 
Drama - Pre K through 5 instruction by the classroom teacher
Art - Pre-k through grade 5

The arts have the ability to impact our young people tremendously; besides providing an avenue for students to develop their creativity, the arts possess the power to discipline, empower, and excite our young people. The arts create a feeling of joy and provide many opportunities for students to develop and build their self-image and self-esteem. Currently, our students receive arts instruction in the visual arts, theatre and dance. I.S. 364 utilizes tax levy funds as well as a 21st Century Community Learning Center grant funding to support many of the arts initiatives in our building. In order to facilitate arts instruction, we have augmented our collection of library materials and books. Since PD plays a key role in the academic success of the students, we will continue to offer PD through our affiliation with various Arts organizations.

Q37_4: School Community Nights, parents participate with students in various arts activities
Q44_1:
The Arts, which at AFYW include Music, Theatre, and Visual Arts, help to foster students’ self-expression in a safe and caring environment. Our programs help students to solve problems, think critically, engage each other creatively, and feel a sense of accomplishment as individuals and as part of a community.

AFYW offers a rich variety of artistic experiences. Students are encouraged to expand their understanding of the arts through music, theater, and/or studiol art. Students develop creativity and innovation, personal style, observational skills and an awareness of multiple perspectives.

In the Visual Arts, students are guided through a program that balances the development of technical skills and ingenuity. Art is offered to students in grades 8-12. Students use a variety of materials to create drawings, paintings, sculptures, and digital designs. 

The Music program encourages students to develop a love and appreciation of music. Music is offered in grades 6-12. Students learn to read music and play instruments. Students participate in the school band where they learn to perform in front of audiences. 

The Theater program encourages students to find their voices. Through instruction and direct experience, students acquire the tools of stagecraft, the confidence to create plays and skits, set designs, and develop acting skills.

Q42_R1_C1: Learning through an Expanded Arts Program
Q44_1: At SCCS, we believe children, with access to the arts as a fundamental part of their education, will grow into critical, creative, and compassionate thinkers, and successful leaders of the 21st Century. SCCS integrates the arts into instruction and learning across the curriculum. Our arts-based courses offerings have included theater, Voice-over Recording, Art and Literacy, and our official arts partnerships include BRIC Contemporary Arts and the Shubert Foundation. In addition to formal artist residencies, visiting artists run lunch-time and after-school sessions, and co-plan arts integration units with our academic teachers in content classrooms. Artists collaborate with teachers daily to provide direct instruction to students, utilizing our auditorium and art studio.  Student work is displayed in school wide talent shows and exhibitions, and in galleries citywide in conjunction with our partnerships. In addition, we currently have one full time Art teacher and one full time music teacher on staff that work closely with our student population.

The goal of FDA VIII's Arts program is to immerse scholars in cultural experiences through dance, visual arts, drama, and music to
develop life-long arts appreciation and knowledge. Additionally, our programs are designed to nurture our scholars talents, while exposing
them to a plethora of art forms that will provide them choices for art education and careers beyond FDA VIII. For the first time here at FDA VIII, we are offering Audio Engineering.

We have expanded our arts program to include a Recording Studio where students develop the skills of mastering, create beats, create lyrics for beats,write creative lyrics and develop performance skills.
A music class is in place where students learn the art of singing as a choir.
Our students are engaged a film production class. Students develop the skills of filmmaking and editing.

Sequence in Performing Arts Freshman Year: Introduction to the performing arts. Students will receive a formal introduction to one of our arts disciplines (dance, drama, vocal music and instrumental music), after an initial audition and placement process. Students will select a major in one of these four areas at the end of the freshman year. Sophomore Year: intermediate dance, drama, vocal or instrumental music. Students will begin their sequence of study in the major they selected at the end of 9th grade. Junior year: advanced dance, drama, vocal music or instrumental music. Students will continue their studies in their chosen major. Senior year: Advanced Studio in Dance, Advanced Drama, Advanced Vocal Music, and Advanced Instrumental Music. Students in the advanced studio will be engaged in development of professional portfolios and the creation of original pieces.

Creative Arts lays the groundwork for continued exploration in the arts. Students are introduced to the Elements and Principles of art through a variety of projects. The course is divided into four units of studio art) Drawing, Painting, Printmaking and Sculpture). Throughout the course students will be engaged in studio practice, reflection and critique.

Due to declining enrollment and the resulting reduced funding, we had to excess our Visual Arts Teacher and we currently rely on our STEAM program to execute art services to our students.  We are planning to fund a Music teacher for 2017-2018, to supplement our existing program.
Q45_1: Transit Tech in a Career and Technical Education school in which students are programmed for 13 additional credits to the 44 credits State mandated requirement, which leaves limited room for electives.  Thus, we have sought to embed art into our educational program.

Q44_1: In the Graphic Arts course, students learn several basic elements of art and design, and put them to work through daily challenges. This course introduces students to graphic design as a problem-solving process, in which designers use art to communicate specific ideas. Students  employ a variety of traditional arts materials to create thumbnails and drafts of designs; provide students with a fun foundation in the practice of design brainstorming; develop trial and error skills, and work through ideas before employing software techniques. The goal is to reinforce the notion that graphic design starts with an idea (or a “solution”), and that mastery of various software comes second.

We currently offer visual arts to our students as an elective which is credited. We have a theatre program which is co-sponsored by Henry street settlement, a full time digital photography program as elective and part-time music program.

The foundation of our social/emotional program is Choice Theory. The two needs we recognize as being essential for productive adolescent development are a sense of belonging and power or respect. These needs are fulfilled when students join clubs and develop competencies in the arts. We provide students with the opportunity to hone their knowledge and skills of fine arts and instrumental music. Also, our Media department offers video production provided by Urban Wall Street, which allows students to share their voice in a dynamic way. We collaborate with CAMBA to provide opportunities for students to learn the skills of choreography and dance, as well as audio/visual competencies.

Vista Academy in collaboration with St. John's University, Kids Kreative Kollective and SamSmith LLC provides various arts programs to its students. Students are enrolled in their program of choice. Student-generated work products are proudly displayed in the hallways and classrooms of the school building. Parents and families attend and celebrate culminating activities and performances at the school. Students attend off-site arts exhibitions and functions to extend their in-school arts engagement and learning.
We have a part time Dance and part time Theater teacher. 8th grade students take half a year of both arts discipline.

At School of the Future Brooklyn students are exposed to the performance arts in theater, dance and music.  We believe that all students have talents, and are able to use the performance arts to support their self-expression, literacy, and build self-confidence.  Students are able to perform for their school communities, and for wider audiences across the city.  We believe that the arts give all students the opportunity to discover who they are in the world and develop into well-rounded individuals.
Q45_1: Students come to our school having limited exposure to the arts.  Our student population is almost 100% free and reduced lunch, and the majority of our students come to sixth grade 3-4 years below grade level.  We believe that participating in the arts gives students opportunity to be successful within the school day, to connect with each other in a new way, and to build self-esteem.  We see our students develop new skills and talents, and this helps them connect with school in new ways.

Q42_R1_C1: Learning through an Expanded Arts Program
Q44_1:
Our music program teaches our students elements of a song, and music composition. Students have the opportunity to learn to play musical instruments (keyboards and drums) in a band setting, sing and rap. This program enables our students to conduct a full performance, including instruments and vocals with a focus on contemporary music.

Students have an opportunity to participate in theater with in house teachers.  Students have performed Disney plays.  Second and third grade students study theater to develop characters and build cultural awareness.
Q45_1: ENYESE provides arts education to all including SWD and ESL students.  Students were introduced to behavioral management through the arts in the form of theater training.  Every student has the opportunity to be performer in the House Band.  Grades are chosen to perform at monthly assemblies.

Q44_1: At East New York Middle School of Excellence our goal is to expose our students to the arts in order to build awareness of themselves and their culture. All students receive the opportunity to be apart of our yearly musical theater program. We are collaborating this year with our SCO Family Dynamics. We offer jazz through Jazz at Lincoln Center, in which we have visiting artists who offer workshops on the history of jazz music throughout the school year and most of our field trips are arts based in which our students are given the opportunity to attend all types of arts performances and events. For example, over the past two years, students have been afforded the opportunity to see operas at the Metropolitan Opera (Lincoln Center). They have seen about 4 performances this year alone and we also attend BAM frequently for a variety of different arts events throughout the year. Additionally, our full-time music teacher engages our students with all forms of music throughout the year from African drumming to pop music. The students perform about 2 variety shows a year.
Q45_1: Even though we do not have teaching artists who are integrated into our day school, our after school program offers a wealth of arts for most of our students. They have dance, step, band, and vocal.

Q44_1: School for Classics offers students a variety of elective classes in Theater, Theater Design, Film Study and Playwriting.  All entering students take Introduction to Theater and Theater Design.  The School for Classics Drama Club produces an annual play.  A fall and spring Talent Show provides students with opportunities to perform.  In addition to the Drama Club, the SFC Choir (which also meets after school) performs at school events.  Field trips to Queens Theatre, Lincoln Center, and the Metropolitan Museum of Art supplement the Theater curriculum.  Once or twice a year, SFC hosts an Arts organization for a school-wide performance. (Past examples include Jazz at Lincoln Center and the Martha Graham Company.)  SFC has partnered with a wide range of Arts organizations in the past to support its Theater program.  In the 2016-17 year, teaching artists from People's Theatre Project and CUNY-CAT supported the Theatre and ELA teachers in select classes and after-school programs.

Highland Park Community School is a 6-8 middle school established in 2014. We are a project-based S.T.E.A.M. school where the arts play a pivotal role in our curriculum and programs. Each grade has a social justice project theme and the Arts, as in every other content area, connects to that theme. Our 6th grade theme is Food Justice, 7th grade is Environmental Activism and 8th grade is Innovation.  We currently serve 305 students so our classes are small and students get individual attention.  We are a Title I schools and use grants, partnerships and fundraising to fund many of our trips to art galleries and museums. Students take a Visual Arts and Theater class each year. The Arts are incorporated into inter-disciplinary projects through all content areas. Students use various programs and technologies to create mixed or multi-media projects. Teaching artists provide music, theater and photography instruction. A glee club and talent show provide opportunities to showcase their talent. Through after-school programming students have voice, dance and theater.  8th graders work with local architects for an architecture elective and students have had a music production elective. The strengthening of their art skills will assist them in their coding classes and their final project. Students use art to bring awareness and voice to the community on issues that are important to them.
Q45_1:
98% of our students are from minority backgrounds, 16% are ELLs and 20% are SWD.
This is our 3rd year and the first year we are full matriculated as a 6-8 school.
As a STEAM-focused school we want to have a strong arts program, specifically through inter-disciplinary connections to STEM.
For our ELLs especially we have seen the benefit of the arts in language acquisition and understanding varying content areas.

Q44_1:
This school year we added Theater and an additional music teacher to our Arts department. We are in the midst of expanding our program to ensure all students have the opportunity to engage in all 4 Arts genre. The intention is to hire a dance teacher for the 2107-18 school year. 
We are working with Jessica Englehart and Pascal from Office of the Arts to create a progressive and comprehensive Arts program for the grade bands. Grades K-2 will receive music (beginning a chorus) and visual art. Grades 3-5 will be introduced to instruments (preferably string and/or band). Grades 6-8 will have the opportunity to choose among the Arts based on interest. 
The goal is for all our students in grades K-8 to be provided the opportunity to a comprehensive Arts program.

The Mapleton School is committed to educational growth in the area of the arts. We will continue to develop in the arts discipline through professional development and increasing the use of technology. Public School 48 provides students with the opportunity to showcase their learning of the arts disciplines through the winter and spring performances. Students also create and perform original music, small skits and dances at community and school events. The Columbus Day Parade,Have A Heart, Musical Memories and Dancing Classrooms are other activites that enhance the students' creativity.

IS 62 is comprised of 3 academies, a 6th Grade Exploratory Academy, The Academy for Performing & Visual Arts and The Law & Community Service Academy. ARTs instruction is infused throughout the building, with a prominent presence in the Academy of Performing & Visual Arts. IS 62 offers Visual Arts, Band, Keyboard, Dance & Chorus programs in ARTs specific rooms, including a state of the art dance studio, a fully stocked art room, a band room with a heavy presence of brass and woodwind instruments and a keyboard room with 16 hi-tech keyboards and 3 technology labs. Our school auditorium has been updated with a new sound system, has audio/visual technology access and a baby grand piano. Students in 6th grade participate in a rotation of the ARTs & a Chorus program. Students in the 7th grade are screened & matched with a major ARTs class for the year. Students in the 8th grade continue with that major ARTs class for a 2nd year and, in addition, pick up a second ARTs class as a minor. Each program adheres to the NYC Blueprint for the Arts & the New York State Common Core Learning Standards. It is & has always been our hope that our students have exposure to a variety of cultural activities, experiences and events that provide enrichment and assist in the development and growth of that student, holistically. It is our mission that each student gain the inspiration needed to foster their 

individual creative interests as they become young men and women, through the exposure and mastery of both the arts and academics at IS 62.

PS 69 is proud to be named The Vincent D. Grippo School in honor of the late superintendenet of Community District 20. In addition to a rigorous academic education, PS69 provides a highly rigorous arts environment. All students experience deep and challenging curriculua in visual arts, music, dance and theatre programming which is provided by skilled professionals. All curriculua is developed in alignment with the Blueprints for the Arts, Common Core Standards and Danielson's framework. Additionally, PS 69 is pioneering the development and use of formative assessments in the visual arts. Chancellor Carman Farina has designated PS69 for the third consecutive year as a Showcase School for Integrating the Arts for Student Success. Visiting educators learned how to naturally infuse literacy in the arts, saw systems and structures that bring arts programming to all students and understood how to use the arts to bolster early language acquisition.  Our Visual Arts Teacher, Angela Fremont, is recognized citywide as a facilitator for professional development, and Arts Mondays.  Her art studio serves as a laboratory and resource to support the professional growth of colleagues throughout the city.

P.S. 102 has an exemplary arts program that owes its success to the huge support it receives from administration, staff, parents, and cultural art organizations. The art program includes visual art, theater, international dance, STEAM, instrumental and choral music. These programs are aligned with NYC DOE Blue Print for Teaching and Learning in the Arts, CCLS and grade appropriate curriculums. P.S. 102 proudly presents year round events that evidence student attainment of benchmarks in all of the art disciplines. Our PTA Art Gala, Opera Production, Chorus Performances, Violin Recital, Spring Fair, STEAM Showcase, Band concerts, Talent Show and International Celebration are a testimony to the rich array of arts experiences provided to our students. P.S. 102’s art team believes that the arts are an integral part of any successful school environment and support academic achievement. We remain committed to keeping a thriving arts environment aimed at the highest level of creative achievement.

P.S./I.S. 104, The School for Civic Leadership and Responsibility, provides an education which includes integration of the Arts into students' daily instructional program. Additionally, Arts education is provided by two full-time Arts teachers, one in Visual Arts and one in Vocal Music.  Students are also provided instruction utilizing basic percussion instruments, recorders, keyboards and guitars.We were selected through a grant for selected students to receive Clarinet instruction and Visual Arts, Cartooning in an after school program for the 2016-2017 school year.  We were also the recipient  of a residency providing a selected grade instruction through dance, music and theater leading to a culminating performance.

P.S. 105 has a strong commitment to arts education and recognizes its potential to enrich every aspect of teaching and learning. Our goals, strategies, and major initiatives center on supplying all of the student population with instruction in visual arts, music, dance and theater using the New York City Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts, which is aligned to the Common Core State Standards. All students actively engage in the processes that constitute creation, performance, and participation in the arts. They respond to and analyze the arts with an understanding of the cultural dimensions and contributions of all arts disciplines. The arts instruction is implemented using a comprehensive and sequential standards-based approach, targeting the benchmarks in the blueprints. This allows students to be art makers, have literacy in the arts, make connections, be aware of community and cultural resources and develop into lifelong learners of the arts.
Q45_1: In our school of English Language Learners, the Arts support the acquisition of the English language.  In addition, the Arts help special needs students build confidence and express themselves creatively which leads them to succeed.

Q44_1: Through music, dance and visual arts, P.S.112 engages students in learning across the Blueprint for the Arts strands. P.S. 112 supports the arts through our strong visual art, music and dance programs. We have many strong collaborations with arts organizations that provide our students with additional exposure and experiences in the arts. All students in our school receive weekly instruction in both art and music. Additionally, our upper grade students receive ballroom dance instruction.We strive to provide a sequential learning experience that builds a stong foundation for students. The arts are alive and well at P.S.112!

Our school offers a sequencial visual arts, dance, music, and theater program throughout the year. The students participate in hands on activities in visual arts and learn about different artists and the history of art. Our music program involves vocal and general music. Our theater program uses dramatic arts to reinforce and to enhance literacy skills. Dance is also a part of our program which teaches ours students choregraphic movement based on various styles of dance  for various performances and for our annual dance festival. Our second and third grade chorus performs for the school community and local senior citizens centers. Many school trips are arts related. Dance and theater are integrated in assembly programs and other content areas.

At P.S. 160, 80% of our students speak a language other than English at home, and 68% of our students are English language learners. The arts give our students a voice to express themselves. We have full-time teachers in visual arts, music, and drama, and part-time teachers in violin and dance. Our students enjoy arts residencies in music, dance, and theater. Our school has rich after-school programs that provide instruction in the arts. Several include: Art Club, Drama Club, Dance Club, Chinese Dance Club, Craft Club and Jewelry Making club. Our goal is to provide quality arts education to all students in our school. We also have many daytime, evening and Saturday workshops, festivals and assemblies to expose and engage our students and their families in all art forms. At P.S. 160 we believe in educating the whole child, so we are a great supporter of the arts. We also believe in nurturing the gifted, talented and enthusiastic. Our hope is to continue to grow our arts programs. At P.S. 160, there is something for every student.

Fostering our students’ creativity and talent is a part of P.S./I.S. 163's mission statement and a major component of our students' education. 

In addition to regularly scheduled music classes, our school has a chorus, a guitar club, a band, and an orchestra. The students who are members of these groups, as well as many others, participate in and perform in our Winter Concert and our Spring Arts Festival. Our Dance program exposes students to various types of dance, classical and contemporary, and presents them with the opportunity to express themselves through movement. Our Visual Arts program provides students in grades K-8 a well-rounded visual arts experience that covers both art history and hands on art projects. 

At P.S./I.S. 163, the arts are an integral part of student learning, as they help students to make connections between subjects and gain a sense of pride and accomplishment by recognizing their creative talents and potential.

The arts program is aligned with the NYC Blueprints for the Arts. The music program serves grades PK-5 with a combination of general music, vocal, and recorder instruction. The extended day program serves a group of band students two to three times a week depending on whether they are in the beginning or advanced band. All band members are provided with instrumental lessons once a week during the school day and all advanced band members attend practice each day during recess. The band performs at school events, concerts and graduation as well as at outside events like the Brooklyn Borough Arts Festival & the District 20 Arts Fair. The visual arts program serves PK-5 students. Classroom teachers integrate art instruction into their curriculum daily. This year our Prekindergarten and Kindergarten G & T class partnered with Studio in a School for an Arts Residency.  In addition, our grade 2 students participated in a Dance Residency with Rioult. Rioult’s DanceREACH program introduces students to the art of modern dance.

P.S. 170 The Ralph A. Fabrizio School’s 1,079 student population is a diversified group of American students and a large immigrant population from different Asian, Middle Eastern and South American Countries. Due to such diversity in religious beliefs, gender identity, culture and racial ethnicity, we have a responsibility to develop our students not only academically but socially, emotionally, culturally and artistically.  Principal Wu feels so strongly about the ARTS that he has 3 certified and licensed teachers one in fine arts,one in vocal and one in music.   PS 170 integrates the NYC Blueprint for the ARTS and aligns ARTS CCLS into all content areas.  We offer many programs to our K-5 students in all of the arts disciplines.  Programs offered include:  Violin instruction, Music and the Brain, recorder instruction, chorus, band,visual arts and ENL Theatre Arts.  Students perform at monthly PTA meetings and annual Winter and Spring concerts. Our 7th Annual Cultural Festival was a celebration of dance, music and songs from Chinese, Latino, Arabic,and American,cultures.  Visual Arts students participate in local and city-wide competitions such as the Halloween Window Painting contest, Sustainability Calendar Contest and the Respect for All Contest which we were honored for in 2017. The students in our K-5 English as a New Language students continue to write, produce and perform original dramatic plays. At PS 170 we are deeply committed to education and fostering a lifelong love and appreciation of the arts.

The PS 176 arts program offers a comprehensive approach in music, dance and visual arts. The music program offers a traditional band, instrumental music, violin and cello string ensemble as well as chorus. Many students also learn how to play the recorder by fifth grade. The success of our music program can be witnessed during our various concerts performed throughout the year. Our visual arts program encompasses various media and can be seen displayed throughout the building and in murals on the walls. Our annual art show displays student artwork in a gallery style and is planned and coordinated by our very own talented art students. All student artwork can now be viewed in an online art gallery, Artsonia, all year long! As for dance, we have an amazing Creative Movement program which teaches the students various disciplines in dance. There are specialized Art, Music and Dance clubs held throughout the school day. PS 176 parents and students look forward to our many amazing performances and galleries throughout the year!

The Visual Arts program provides instruction to students in Pre K through grade five according to the Blueprint for the Arts. We provide residencies in dance and music instruction; extend learning beyond the classroom with museum visits,theater performances, and other venues that expose students to a life-long appreciation of the arts. PS 179 provides opportunities for parent engagement in the arts through student performances and annual art exhibit. PS 179 offers Chorus; Music Memory.After school programs include Art Club, Violin and Recorder instruction and Brooklyn Children's Theater after school program.
Q45_1: PS 179 is a recipient of the Continuum Grant for Dance, and the ELL'S and SWD grant for Theater and Music. With our high ELL population, both these art forms have been a unique way for students to increase their language skills and explore new art forms. Our goal is to provide students with multiple opportunities to experience and appreciate the arts.

Q44_1: PS/IS 180, The SEEALL Academy is dedicated to strengthening and expanding the arts learning experience for all of our students. We strive to offer many diverse arts opportunities to our students, tapping into the talents and unique abilities of our entire staff, not just our certified arts teachers. We continue to expand our arts department via hiring, enrichment, and after school activities.

Our present goals focus on implementing our visual arts and theatre program. We strive to bring awareness of art and theatre history to all our students as well as strengthening cross-curriculum connections. Our Visual Arts Program stresses the use of multi-media techniques using a hands on approach with successful results. Several school-wide presentations throughout the year showcase the children's' artwork. The use of journals reinforce the art curriculum
through writing.  Our Theater teacher focuses on connecting the mind, body, voice, and movement into the daily curriculum.  Our theater program brings children to new heights, ultimately making them more comfortable on stage and in front of an audience.  We display our talents and strengths through performance and presentations.  We are continuing to see positive feedback from our students in terms of 
self-confidence and experiential learning. In addition our school continues to provide the 5th graders with a 20 week Ballroom Dancing program.

This year we have been fortunate enough to offer students in all grades the benefit of performing arts and visual arts instruction as part of their school schedule. We also offer a period per week of "show choir" where students learn theater-related pieces to perform at a culminating event at the end of the year. There is also an art committee that works with the Visual Arts teacher. Students have performed at school concerts and assemblies both during the school day and evening and included parental involvement. Through a partnership with the NIA ExpandED, students were able to put on a performance of The Little Mermaid and performed at the Borough Arts Festival. . Along with after-school arts teacher, students created sets and props for the production. Also through ExpandED, students were invited to see Aladdin on Broadway.

The arts program within IS 187 allows for students to become fully immersed within all aspects of the arts. The arts programs includes and not limited to band, chorus, visual arts graphic arts and theatre. Students have the ability to take part in our after school program in which they experience, drama, set-design, graphic arts as well as engage in various field trips related to the arts.

Our arts program follows the New York City blueprint which is grounded in the national and New York State learning strands. These strands guide teachers in addressing specific learning goals for students. They also provide the guidelines for offering a diverse visual art, dance and musical experience. The visual arts program is structured around the Art Making strand of the blueprint. Our artists are given the opportunity to work in different media, including painting, drawing, collage,sculpture and printmaking. Our music program provides our students with many opportunities to express themselves through music. Students in grade 4-8 have the opportunity to participate in the school band or chorus program

P.S 200's mission is to achieve excellence in all areas of the curriculum. In addition, data is used for analyzing student achievement and focusing instruction. In the disciples of Music and Visual Arts all students participate in a curriculum that reflects "The Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts" goals. Teachers are receiving professional development for Formative Assessment, Art Mondays, Common Core Standards, and Danielson Framework Evaluation Criteria. Enrichment programs for the arts include a STEAM curriculum which helps students in 3rd, 4th, and 5th grades integrate technology, science, social studies and art.

Drama: to create a school-wide production incorporating all aspects of theatre including acting, lighting, sound, directing, choreographing and set design. To explore Shakespearean drama on each grade level, incorporating instructional components into the annual Shakespeare Festival. Music: to develop and expand students' vocal and instrumental technique through daily study of scales, technical exercises, vocal warm-ups, and short compositions that facilitate improvement of tone quality, tuning/intonation, rhythmic precision and general concentration. Art: to use differentiation to enhance all projects of art within the Blueprints for the Arts and to incorporate the Common Core Standards using the Universal Design to reflect Blueprints for the Arts

At PS 204, we strive to engage our students in all aspects of the arts: visual arts, dance, theater, and music.  Students in grades K-5 have the opportunity to broaden their skills in our visual arts program where our arts teachers utilize The Blueprints for Teaching and Learning the Arts.  These teachers engage students in various visual arts projects providing them ongoing opportunities to partake in self and peer assessment aligned to the standards.  We have three full-time certified music teachers who provide music instruction to students in grades K-5.  Our kindergarten students perform in an annual Gift Sharing performance.  Our 1st and 2nd grade students are provided the opportunity to perform, with their classes, for their parents, highlighting all they have learned over the course of the school year.  Our 3rd graders learn the recorder and take part in a culminating performance and our 4th graders study various Broadway musicals (Inside Broadway) and perform acts from each of them for our student body and parents. In addition, our 4th and 5th grade students have an opportunity to play in our school band and perform in neighborhood parades. Our 5th grade students can also join our school's chorus and perform at various concerts (along with the band). All students in grades PreK-5 learn different styles of dance and perform in a school wide dance festival held annually each Spring, and our fifth grade students receive instruction by Dancing Classrooms in various styles of ballroom dancing.

The 2016-2017 school year proved to be one that the arts department continues to burgeon. The PS 205 community, on a year-by-year basis, offers a myriad of opportunities for students to become engaged in various art disciplines.

Our program seeks and achieves in building community ties through such events as our Colombus Day Parade (where our band performed), and shaping our program into one that embraces culture and diversity through our outside cultural organizations. Our art department succeeded in sending students to the Borough-Wide Arts Festival. Additionally, the music department has continued it’s increase in NYSSMA participation, continued involvement in the Music Memory competition, and Carnegie Hall’s “Linked In” program. We held our yearly winter and spring concerts for band, chorus, and orchestra, and organized our 2nd annual NYSSMA Recital for Family Arts Night, (featuring our orchestra, piano, and band students). 

Our goal of continued expansion and the ameliorating of our arts program through innovative and creative means (during school hours and our numerous after school programs), succeeds in providing our students with the opportunities and tools they need as they progress on to middle-school and beyond

We use the Blueprint for the Arts, and offer arts to all our students. One addition to our Arts program that we are proud of is the expansion of our Dramatic Arts Instruction. We have also increased our outreach to Cultural Organizations in order to enrich students understanding and appreciation of the arts disciplines.  We have nearly 33% English Language Learners. The arts is also a way of engaging our ELL students and motivating them to improve their use of the English language. Through the arts, we celebrate diversity in our school with cultural performances. In addition, the school runs a comprehensive architecture program for 7th graders. With the help of Mr. Ronald Miller, architect and director of Planning Design Construction for Maimonides Medical Center, classes use a life like request for proposals to design a building by preparing floor plans, elevation plans, axonometric drawings and a scale model. Ten final teams are chosen to represent the school of design Expo, a special day at the center for Architecture in Manhattan where the teams present their designs to a panel of professional architects.  Our school presents an annual festival of the Arts allowing students to showcase what they have learned through dramatic performances, musical concerts and exhibition of student art.  Parents of performing and exhibiting students are invited to attend.  Finally, we have also increased our after school and summer instruction in the Arts.

JHS227 is immersed in the arts for the years 2017-18, Edward B. Shallow has - A school band - - A school orchestra - A String Band- A school vocal/chorus - A digital photography class - dance (Zumba) incorpotrated into physical education curriculum - theatre in the form of Inside Broadway and Theatre Moves. In addition segments in Arts dedicated to Disney Art, Graphing, Drafting and Civil Engineering.

P.S./I.S. 229K serves children in Pre-K through Grade 8. VISUAL ARTS students are empowered with experiences that challenge, build knowledge, and skills in the use of the various tools, techniques and intellectual methods of creating art. Early childhood students learn about the elements of MUSIC that include singing, instruments, and movement, incorporating the Kodaly and other methodologies. Upper grades have an opportunity to join the school band, string orchestra, jazz ensemble, and chorus. Middle school enrichment includes dance and dramatic readings. The THEATRE@229K provides an opportunity to participate in performance, set design, stage crew and lighting--meeting on Saturdays and as after-school programs. Our goal is to provide a sequentially standards-based arts education building an appreciation of various cultures, connections to other disciplines, participation in NYC cultural institutions and making known the varied available careers in the arts.

We are always looking for ways to improve our Arts programs. Students in the Photography program identify and research trends in photography that make them adaptable to the shifts in the professional industry. We also created a Media program. Students use professional video equipment and learn how to broadcast live events.  After assessing students to see who had an interest in choral music or in playing an instrument, we created two additional classes in our schedule.  We now have a Chorus class and a Band class.  Our Theater program is in its third year. Our students will be performing a third musical at the end of May. This year, we had our very first Winter Festival.  Our Theater classes performed along with the newly established Band and Chorus. We also created a Set Design class in the spring of this year.  The students are creating, designing, building and painting the scenery for our spring musical. Our Arts department has established a partnership with BSAG, Brooklyn Streetcar Artists Group. Through this organization, Arts students have the opportunity to exhibit their art in a local gallery space. We will continue to use student portfolio assessments, sketchbooks, projects and our literacy initiative in the arts classes as a way of assessing knowledge and skills. We have attended professional development this year that addresses how to make our instruction more aligned. We will continue to build on what we have established and hopefully add more productive programs as we move forward.
Q46_2: Assistant Principal, English and the Arts

Q44_1: The arts are part of our name, part of our vision and mission. All of our students receive exposure to a broad range of arts experiences fully integrated into our school curriculum and culture. We partner with cultural organizations to supplement the skills and specialties of our full time faculty. We make strategic decisions to hire staff with a strong passion for and expertise in the arts. Classroom teachers are integral to the success of our arts program as they bring their own passion and arts experiences to the classroom setting. We are confident that this integrated approach allows children to explore and express their creativity across a wide variety of genre. We incorporate two periods per week of Studio Time into our schedule. During Studio Time students have an opportunity to participate in self-selected activities for a twelve week period. These activities include musical theater, ballroom dancing, ceramics, arts and crafts and a variety of other creative endeavors. We are home to a resident adult theater company. These actors work with our students and perform classical theater for them. Our students learn both the performance aspects and technical aspects of the arts, and they have assumed full responsibility for lighting, sound and stage management for our productions. We look forward to watching our children continue to grow and develop as artists.

Q42_R1_C1: BRIC Arts Media Bklyn Inc.Brooklyn Information & Culture ROTUNDA
Q44_1: Art education is essential for a child’s perception and understanding of our world. Opportunities for creative outlets allow students to interpret their perceptions through different art forms. Art education teaches students to respect and appreciate their own interpretations and those of others. We develop basic skills and encourage awareness of and appreciation for different cultural perspectives, intellectual growth and creative self-expression. Our school’s commitment to arts education is essential for every student's development as well-rounded, creative and productive citizens in the global world. Goals: Students will • develop literacy skills and make connections to content knowledge in other disciplines through arts • develop an appreciation for art and confidence in creative self-expression • have an awareness of global cultures and an exposure to the diversity of art • develop an appropriate level of artistic proficiency in a variety of artistic media
Q45_1: We Provide an after school enrichment Arts program in partnership with BRICS and the TADA, using school funding. For TADA, we received the SWDELL Arts grant. We are hoping to receive it once again for the 2017-2018 school year in order to continue providing the theater to our students.

Q44_1: Having now graduated 3 Academy of Art & Design Cohorts, we have a chance to reflect on our practices as we prepare students for college. One strength is in building their level of technical skill, evidenced by the growth seen in observational drawings from within each student’s personal portfolio. All Art Majors are required to maintain an average of 80 or above. We have instituted a probationary program where a letter is sent home to parents when students need help based on their mid term report cards. We have increased the number of field trips to engage our art students in History, English and Science through the lens of art making. Changes made in the Academy of Art & Design Program are being carried over into the general art classes as well. Our contest participation went up by 40% and in each case, our students placed in the competition or were recognized. Going forward we plan to engage the student body by offering in-house exhibition opportunities and reorganizing our annual art show to become a juried event. We will set our sights on fundraising, marketing and community outreach/service in 2017-18.

A rich arts program with a strong studio and performance component is essential to our students' academic growth. Our studio arts curriculum emphasizes self-reflection and social commentary and includes basic studio art, mixed media, fashion, and design. Our students learn to work in a variety of media including pencil, charcoal, water color, collage, pastel, linoleum and ink print. Students display their work in exhibitions. Courses that provide students with art-technology experience in our newly renovated computer labs include digital photography, graphic design and yearbook. Performance-based courses include chorus, keyboards, drama workshop and musical theater. Student performances take place every year in our newly renovated, state-of-the-art auditorium/theater, where we also screen full-length feature films. We have a long-standing collaboration with BAM and the TDF Open Doors Program and the New York Theater Workshop. Students visit museums and theaters including MOMA, The Met, BAM and the Brooklyn Historical Society. This year, students in our art classes have worked with Thrive Collective, and designed and painted a large scale mural at the entrance of the school reflecting the themes of diversity and community.

Fort Hamilton High School is fortunate to offer a vast array of arts classes. Our visual arts courses include, but are not limited to, creative art, calligraphy, ceramics, drawing, painting, portfolio development and advanced placement studio art. We have an excellent theater department that produces two fully staged shows annually. The last two musical productions were the 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee and In The Heights. Fort Hamilton High School’s music program is a competitive program that travels and competes across the country. We have consistently received the highest grades at adjudication festivals. Our performing arts program requires an audition and is listed in the H.S. Directory. Seats are limited, but audition pending, talented students from all over New York City can be admitted to our school and be part of our music program, theater program or Joffrey Ballet Dance Academy. Honors level courses are available if students qualify. Students who qualify will take honors level academic classes.

Q42_R1_C1: BRIC Arts Media Bklyn Inc.Brooklyn Information & Culture ROTUNDA
Q44_1: PS 503 strives to students with experiences that will support their education and enhance their lives. With over 1,100 students, 59% being English Language Learners and 97% of the student population are eligible for free lunch the school faces many challenges.  It is our belief that the arts are a basic and integral part of a high quality education. It is also our belief that every student, regardless of background or economic status, is entitled to this level of education. Every student in our school is provided with arts education as a standard part of our school schedule. Collaboration between teachers and across domains creates a multi-layered, cross-disciplinary program that enables the students to appreciate the interconnectedness of subjects. Science and social studies integration has imbued our arts instruction with a cultural relevance alongside opportunities for experimentation with art forms and techniques.

FDR offers classes in disciplines including theatre, music, visual arts and film. Students can choose to sample various electives or major in a sequence. Yearly, FDR produces a play, musical, multicultural festival, talent show, and several concerts. Our school is involved with residency partnerships with the best cultural and arts organizations in New York, such as the TDF and Roundabout. Our art rooms include a ceramic studio and photography and computer art labs with state-of-the-art equipment for film and digital photography/restoration. Our music program has a concert band and guitar ensemble. The theatre department offers two tracks, performance or technical. FDR is starting a four year sequence which will end in a specialized arts-endorsed diploma. We are beginning work on a screened program. With its strong multicultural population, our Literacy Arts program helps ELL students improve language skills through artistic expression. Our goal in to instill a love and appreciation for the arts.

At P.S. 506, assemblies are held monthly and full-length performances are done each winter and spring. Assemblies include, but are not limited to, full-length violin concerts and musicals, themed songs, dances, and skits, and student-created videos that integrate various holidays, historical events, classroom subjects, and leadership principles. Enrichment arts clubs are available to students who show interest in a certain discipline. Arts appreciation is spread through events such as our outdoor dance festival and our violin program’s annual visit to a local hospital as well as our chorus program's visit to a local nursing home. Visual art contests are held throughout the year to showcase our students’ work. We are in partnership with Disney Theatrics and the full-length Disney musical, The Lion King Kids, will be shared with our school and community through performances in June. Our students will also be performing at our District Arts Festival in May. Students attend arts-based field trips throughout the year as well. The arts are used to develop literacy through the use of word walls, group discussion, and technology. Arts teachers are given the opportunity to inquire with each other to align curricula and share best practices. All arts programs are aligned with the Blueprint for the Arts. The arts are infused in every classroom and the existence of the arts is truly evident throughout the building through the use of TV screens in the halls highlighting our monthly assemblies as well as artwork displayed on each floor.

PS 682 - is a Schoolwide Enrichment Model school. We conduct three nine week cycles of enrichment clusters ranging in areas from film-making, sports, horticulture, etc...based on student interests. TADA! for our K-5 students - students dance, sing, and act during the 20 week partnership. Dancing Classrooms for our 4th and 5th grade students, one cycle of ballroom dance lessons twice a week. We have one full-time music teacher trained in Music and the Brain. The 3-5 students have learned the recorder and our 4th and 5th grade students participate in band. We have a full-time art teacher, for art K-5. We continued Art History for grades 4 and 5. Also we have Town Hall in grades K-3, a Dance partnership. We have continued an after-school program that focuses on theater arts, visual arts, athletics, and computers. We are also a TC school that incorporates Art in ELA.

The Arts Program at KECSS is designed for self-directed students who are interested in creating their own arts-related course of study. KECSS' Enrichment Clusters allow students to pursue their diverse interests each year. Art forms in which students participated during the 2016-2017 school year include visual art, writing, drama, dance and music. 
7th grade students had visual art taught 4 hours a week by a certified visual arts teacher. Our teacher delivered a program according to the Statewide Strategic Plan for the Arts which included  planning and implementation to support the advancement and adoption of the New York State P-12 Dance, Music, Theater, Visual and Media Arts Learning Standards.  Three (3) of our field trips included a Broadway Musical, a Shakespearean play and a one woman show.  Our 10th grade participated on a field trip to The National Museum of the American Indian.   The Classic Stage Company lead a workshop at our school presented to our 11th and 12th graders. Our tenth grade students take college level Art History and our early college students were taken to a theater production.

The goal of PS 748 is to integrate visual and performing arts into the curriculum by using an interdisciplinary approach. We are fortunate to have both a full time music and art teacher. Both teachers work cooperatively with classroom teachers to integrate arts instruction into curriculum maps and create standards based lessons.
