At PS 748, we incorporate the Schoolwide Enrichment Model where students get their choice of arts classes including theatre, sculpting, dance, and music. In addition,students in grades 4 and 5 participate in Academies where the Arts are also explored. Students change their selection throughout the year to gain exposure to various disciplines. The Brooklyn School for Global Scholars also believes in building strong relationships with parents. We have an annual winter concert and dance festival each year. We also have a chorus that meets once a week. We hope to continue to build on our arts curriculum in the upcoming year.

District 20 Pre K Centers offer instruction in movement and music appreciation, dramatic play and visual arts aligned with the Pre K Quality Standards and founded on the principals of the Pre K Foundation for the Common Core. All children are exposed to a variety of the Arts to instill a love of learning through discovery and exploration which in turn stimulates individual creativity.
Q46_2: District Director of Early Childhood Education

Q44_1: P.S. 971 continues to provide an educationally enriched arts. In our dance, visual arts, music and theatre programs, students are able to express their individual creativity while further deepening the connection between performing, visual and musical arts. In addition, to further reinforce the students' understanding of arts, Brooklyn Conservatory of Music returned this year. As a result, this musical program helps students explore musical enrichment through hands-on participation in musical instruments, cultural songs and rhythmic applications. PS 971 students also enjoy in-house performances through Lincoln Center, where they are instructed about the history and evolution of Jazz. In addition, students have opportunities to experience art in technology with our partnerships in Robotics and Coding. Building upon last years success, the coding and robotics program has expanded to include an after school component. PS 971 students explore primary sources that include art artifacts for study and reflection. As a whole, while following the Blue Print for the Arts Standards, students are able to explore the connection with the arts throughout their daily content areas programs.

The Arts Program at P.S.90 offers a vibrant interdisciplinary approach to learning through our music and visual arts classes. All students receive instruction in the Visual Arts from either the school's licensed Art teacher or the Artist in Residence.   Students  participate in Borough wide and citywide contests and have the opportunity to have their work publicly displayed. This year, a Kindergarten student made it to the semi-finalist round of the P.S. Art competition. We also had a second grade student's artwork displayed at the Brooklyn Borough Arts Festival. We also entered artwork into the DOE School Wellness contest and were delighted to find out that a fourth grade student from our school won, his artwork will be displayed on calendars and other forms of school communication to promote school wellness.
       All students experience a vocal and instrumental music program which includes recorder, violin, keyboard and a complete Orff  orchestra. These programs culminate in two concerts and various assemblies throughout the school year. Our school also participates in the " Little Kids Rock" music program which uses "modern band" instruments. We also have several Arts residencies in place.
        Looking ahead we are excited to have been designated as a Magnet School with a focus on Environmental Studies and Community Wellness. We will incorporate the Arts into other disciplines through STEAM (science, technology, engineering, art, math ) and a project based learning approach.

PS/IS 95 is a Pre-K to 8th grade school. We believe in educating the whole child through rigorous academic programs and arts instruction that enriches the lives of our students. We offer dance, music, art, and drama, facilitated by experienced staff members who frequently attends professional development. The arts allow students to expand their academic horizons through a knowledge of cultural appreciation and enlarge their understanding of the world. In our efforts to prepare our students for college and career, the arts program has also been aligned with our social studies curriculum and the Common Core state standards. Our goals for our arts program are to allow our student population to appreciate the diverse cultural heritages inherent in our school, and to help create a respectful and tolerant learning community. We have also sought opportunities through a 21st century grant funding to bring dance, chorus, and visual arts to our school to service all of our students in grades 4-8. In addition we applied for and received a CASA grant for additional visual arts instruction through the Brooklyn Arts Council. Through this program the students have left a legacy for future students by the paintings of murals throughout our school building. We have also engaged parents in the arts by inviting them to workshops that culminated in the painting of murals that are displayed in our multi-purpose room.

The arts program at Public School 97 provides its students with channels for self-expression and opportunities to enhance self-esteem, all while fostering an appreciation for the arts and encouraging students to become life-long learners. Our goal is to expose all students to situations and experiences which allow them to explore various techniques in all areas of the arts because we strongly believe that exposure to the arts increases students' inquiry skills, observational skills, problem-solving skills and critical thinking skills. As an all inclusive school, we embrace our multicultural multilingual PS 97 community and allow opportunities for our students to learn about world cultures, become world citizens and passionate leaders. Through the arts education, we celebrate the voices and cultures of our students, our families, our staff, and our community. At PS 97, every student receives art education through art teachers, teaching artists, and art clubs. Many of our students continue their art education at Mark Twain Middle school for Gifted and Talented.
Q45_1: In addition to the art teachers and teaching artists, we offer arts during Friday clubs (word art, painting, arts and crafts, dance, choir, karaoke, violin, dance, etc)

Q44_1: The Bay Academy continues to provide rigorous instruction to the arts program and incorporate literacy and critical thinking in all lessons. The Bay Academy offers talent areas in all three grades such as visual art, vocal music, winds, strings, drama and dance. There are many opportunities after school for students to participate in an arts program. The performing arts classrooms are enriched with ELA expeditionary learning protocols and through observations the performing arts teachers have mastered and balanced the use of creativity and meaningful discussion. The students learn about their craft through non-fiction research, writing projects and performance based assessment.The Bay Academy once again has been the recipients of many elected official based contests such as Respect For All, Assemblyman Cymbrowitz' Holocaust Memorial, as well as Senator Savino's Project Boost and The Ezra Jack Keats Book Making Contest.

The goal of PS99 is to raise achievement levels for all students in PreK-8 through the integration of a rigorous standards based arts program. We incorporate the NYC Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the the Arts into all curricula areas. Students will develop the skills needed to meet or exceed benchmarks. Students perform in plays and choral presentations in school and at charitable organizations. The community at large is invited and encouraged to be involved. All of our 7th and 8th Grade students meet the required number of instructional hours needed for Graduation in the Arts.

P.S. 100, The Magnet School of Media Arts & Communication believes the arts are an effective medium for forging students, faculty, and families into a school-wide community. We achieve this goal through dance and musical performances, art exhibitions, and partnerships with American Ballroom Theatre and the Jewish Association of Services for the Aging. Moreover, our arts specialists work collaboratively with classroom teachers to produce class plays, integrating theatre arts into our curricula. Each of our arts disciplines is aligned with the Common Core State Standards and the NYC Blueprints for Teaching and Learning in the Arts. Through participation and exposure to the arts, our students are able to develop a self-confidence and sense of self, which supports our vision that at P.S. 100, every child has a voice.

Q37_4: Participating in arts workshops/programs with students
Q44_1: We have a strong commitment to the arts and believe in giving our children the best well-rounded education that includes a strong arts program as part of their curriculum and exposure for tapping into the various earning styles in which students learn best and celebrate their multiple intelligences. The addition of a full-time music teacher, new after-school programs including filmmaking, and parent/student arts workshops, has enhanced student learning and experiences once again this year. This year we've launched the Leader In Me Program which focuses on the 7 Habits of Highly Effective People into our student curriculum as well as after-school residencies. Through the arts, our children learn how to express their unique identities, while simultaneously developing habits of mind that will help them succeed anywhere, from the playground to the workplace. The survey does not reflect our 5th grade teacher led enrichment programs, our 4th grade collaborative arts event, our annual early childhood Dance Festival, choral performances and Talent Show.

We seek to provide our students with opportunities to tap into their individual creative abilities. Our visual arts curriculum is a materials rich experience that includes drawing, painting, printmaking, and 3D sculpture. In our music program, students learn to read music, play the recorder, drums, guitar and keyboards. Through partnerships with cultural institutions and residencies, our program exposes students to a variety of arts disciplines. Our teachers integrate and align our arts program with the New York State Common Core Curriculum and prepare our students for college and career readiness. We strive to ensure that our students take full advantage of NYC's cultural offerings by affording them the opportunity to visit a variety of cultural institutions

Q42_R1_C1: Learning through an Expanded Arts Program
Q42_R1_C10: ELL and SWD grant is over
Q44_1: P.S. 128 continues to provide an enriching and diverse arts program for all students.  We have 2 full-time arts teachers as well as partnerships with various arts organizations.  Not only do we continue to follow the NYC Blueprint for the Arts Instruction, but we have integrated these expectations into our content areas, aligning our units of study with the Common Core Learning Standards. All students receive arts experiences in visual arts, music, dance and theater.  Our classroom teachers also collaborate with arts teachers and supplement the program with grade showcases that are interdisciplinary, and build on student interests and talents. We also integrate the arts in our after school program.  We believe that all teachers are teachers of the arts. Arts education allows students to be creative and expressive as we educate the whole child and prepare him/her to become future leaders.

The children at P.S. 153 share a love for the arts. P.S. 153 currently has a full-time Theater,dance and music program. In addition it has a part-time visual arts program. The theater program allows the childern from grades K-5 to learn improv, play theater games, playwrite and have an opportunity to perform on each grade level. In addition the children have opportunity to perform in the lip-sync, karoke, dance festival and Talent show. The dance program introduces grades kindergarten through 5th grade to the various elements of dance. students are taught dance through body, effort/dynamics, space and relationship. Grades pre- K-2 have the opportunity to have music and visual art.The goal is to help motivate and enhance children's admiration for the arts. Children are exposed to the arts during school trips. It's our continued goal to motivate and reinforce the arts.

This year, our arts program expanded to include two (2) full-time Visual Arts Teachers, one for grades PK-2 and another for grades 3-5. Our young musicians continue to excel with our instrumental band programs (Cadet Band and Concert Band), as well as Chorus and Recorder Band. School leadership has made arts education a priority for our school and continues to focus on providing a quality education in the arts for all of our students.

Q42_R1_C1: BRIC Arts Media Bklyn Inc.Brooklyn Information & Culture ROTUNDA
Q44_1: The Michael E. Berdy School for the Arts proudly integrates all art forms into our curriculum. It is our goal to expose the student population to the arts and promote awareness and love for the arts. We have a dance and visual arts educator on staff; these teachers also facilitate in-house professional development for all of our staff. Our dance program is extensive and focuses on various techniques of dance in our state-of-the-art dance studio. The visual arts studio program covers all media and explorations in visual art, focusing on a variety of artists and art disciplines, including sculpture and printmaking. Culminating performances are collaboratively created with the dance and art coordinators.

PS 199 believes the arts provide opportunities for all children to express themselves and develop multiple intelligences and talents. By integrating the arts into other curricula areas, the arts provide a vehicle for developing literacy and critical thinking skills. Our school provides these opportunities to our students both within the school day and in after school programs. Through our assembly program, students are exposed to various performance arts and perform in plays and concerts.

Q42_R1_C2: Federation of Italian American Organizations of Brooklyn
Q44_1: We have provided choral music for our Kgn grade. Visual Arts will be provided to our 1st and 2nd grade children by the Visual Arts cluster.  Every classroom teacher in grades K to 5th grade will provide instruction in either dance/visual arts and theater arts.Grades K to 5 will be required to perform one assembly program a year. In grades 6,7 and 8 the English Language Arts teacher for each grade will work collaboratively with the other content area teachers on the grade to produce two plays in a school year.  The plays can include music and dance as well.

Our school places a very high priority on the quality of the arts imparted to our children. The administration supports every effort to create and maintain the rich and nurturing environment for the arts to blossom. P.S. 212 offers a musical theater program for all grades that includes acting, directing, and design. We offer a Literacy through Dance program and dance clubs for grades 3 and 4. This year, we have introduced a glee, chorus and cheer club.  We also hosted an after school art club which was attended by over 30 students.   We have an annual Costume Parade and Dance Festival for the lower grades; a winter concert for all grade levels; a 5th grade musical theater production directed by the theater and dance teacher and complimented by the work of the art club.  We hosted a spring show titled " Through the Years" and hosted individual grade assemblies.  Our school participates in the Ezra Jack Keats Book Making Competition and our art clubs in grades grades 3, 4 and 5 submit artwork for different contests. Student art pieces are celebrated in a grade level art family fun event. This year, our student art work was selected for the borough arts fair and also to be displayed as part of the Metropolitan Museum of Art showcase.  Our cheerleaders  competed and placed third and were recognized for their spirit!

Q42_R1_C2: National Museum of the American Indian
Q44_1: The goal of P.S. 215's art program is to provide a comprehensive and sequential standards-based art education to all students k-5.

Arts education helps students discover their inner talents. It brings out the best in each student, expands their horizons and helps them discover unknown talents and hobbies within themselves. Students who receive art instruction perform on a higher level academically. Providing arts education is not a luxury; it is a necessity. We have provided more arts residencies this year including theater.

At PS/IS 226, the students participate in the arts during the school day, in after school programs and at special performances. Our music program includes general and instrumental classes.  Our instrumental program showcases different grade levels on recorder, violin, guitar, keyboard, xylephone, and concert bands.  Our visual students’ art work is displayed throughout the school using different mediums and in large scale murals.  We have every class perform a class play, which includes singing and dancing on stage for their peers, family members and the school community. The students perform winter and spring musical concerts on both the elementary and middle school grade levels to demonstrate student achievement in the arts. Selected students in grades 5-8 take part in Broadway Junior after school theater program provided through Music Theater International.  In addition, our students place their talents on full display with our talent show. Our goal is to give every student an opportunity to experience, make connections, and become literate in each of the arts disciplines during their time as a student at PS/IS 226.

The Arts Magnet Program at David A. Boody is a three year sequential program that encompasses strings, winds, dance, theatre, visual art and digital art. Students are immersed in comprehensive arts experiences that include arts making, arts literacy, making connections and performing. The program is aligned with the Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts and prepares students for High School. During this year, we introduced STEAM within our school community.

PS 238 is a small K-8 school located in Midwood, Brooklyn. The arts programming consists of a full-time certified visual arts teacher, a music teacher/ drama teacher, and a dance teacher. Student in the elementary grades have an opportunity to experience dance, chorus, drama, and visual arts at least one period a week if not more. Students in the middle school have visual arts twice a week. Sixth graders have chorus. In addition, the middle school offers drum, dance, and guitar talent which meets twice a week. The school takes students out of the building to visit Museums that are integrated with their social studies, science, and ELA curriculum. This year students went to the Brooklyn Museum, Rubin Museum, Snug Harbor, Brooklyn Historical Society, and Brooklyn Navy Yard. In addition they took trips to see the cityscape where they drew from observation at the Brooklyn Bridge Park and Coney Island. The school also brought in several arts partnerships this year including Studio In A School and The Brooklyn Public Library. The students at PS 238 are growing artistically. This year three students made the semi-finalist for and one of the three made the final PS ART show. In addition three students are represented in the Brooklyn Borough Arts festival. For the upcoming year, the school is looking to further strengthen the arts department by developing more arts partnerships in the music and dance disciplines as well continuing to develop the community involvement in the arts.
Q45_1: This is a small school that has a very large ELL population. The school services the direct neighborhood of Midwood Brooklyn, but also many of the students come from neighboring Coney Island. The school also has a very large special education department with ICT as well as ID and 12/1 special education classes. Many of the students receive special pull out services.

Q44_1: Mark Twain IS 239 For the Gifted and Talented is an arts-centered school that uses the arts to enhance education across the curriculum. In alignment with the Common Core Standards and the New York City Arts Curriculum Guides (The Blueprints for the Arts), Mark Twain offers comprehensive programs in the four art forms. Screened three-year sequences are offered in Dance; Music (strings, vocal, and winds); Theater; and in the Visual Arts (fine arts and media). Emphasis is placed on literacy in the arts, and cultural/historical connections with related curricula. Students enrolled in a three-year sequence receive intensive instruction throughout their time at Mark Twain, and all students meet or exceed the New York State arts requirements to qualify for graduation in the eighth grade. It is Mark Twain's goal to enable every child to perform at their optimum level in the core curriculum, as well as to participate and appreciate the arts in pursuit of a well-rounded, holistic education.

By June of 2018, students and staff will demonstrate an increased awareness of the arts. Participation in school and class concerts /performances, parent/student workshops and meeting grade appropriate benchmarks in the literacy of the arts strand as measured by The Blueprints for Teaching and Learning in the Arts. Demonstration of mastery will be evidenced both within and beyond the classroom.

Q42_R1_C1: Learning through an Expanded Arts Program
Q44_1: Our arts curriculum at I.S.281 Joseph B. Cavallaro is an integral part of a solid educational foundation that builds upon prior arts knowledge and experience and addresses the needs of all learners. We offer a wide range of experiences in dance,music, media, technology and visual arts, wherein students develop the physical, aesthetic and critical thinking skills that enable them to see and respond to the world. Students will experience various disciplines to expand their knowledge and skill and help them to make personal connections with our school and the world around them. Technology and the Fine Arts are infused into curriculum studies throughout our school community. Our staff plan units of study that allow students to experience the arts through a variety of mediums. Ultimately, we seek to nurture an appreciation of the arts within all of our children.

Our goal at the Surfside School is to inspire well-rounded children who have been elevated to a higher level. We believe that by exposing our children to the arts, we provide a positive learning experience that will have lifelong impact. The Surfside School has been recognized, citywide, for its excellence in the arts. In addition to our premier seaside location, we are home to a state of the art dance studio, museum, art studio, well appointed auditorium and two technology labs. Our students are exposed to a myriad of enriching experiences including fine art, ballroom dance, modern, west african and jazz instruction, theater, chorus, violin study, photography and media arts. Our students enjoy frequent opportunities to explore and celebrate their talents. Grade five students participate in Talent Academies aligned to their art discipline of choice. Annually, the dance and music presentations represent the culmination of student enrichment across the various arts disciplines. We believe such experiences allow P.S. 329 students to become empowered, inspired and elevated to their highest level of achievement!

All students at IHSL receive three full years of arts instruction, including visual arts and media arts in the 9th/10th grades as well as multi-media music arts in the 12th grade. All students will have access to additional arts offerings (singing, dance, film/media, photography) through our elective program. Also, the arts program at IHSL has designed innovative, interdisciplinary curricula for ELLs. Additionally, extensive outreach is done to partnership organizations to provide additional opportunities to students, based on need and interest.

We are a small school, but intend to offer new programs to students. These will include guest speakers, continue clubs, school-wide projects and art competitions across grades. We will continue to develop arts exhibits, highlighting the best that our students can create. We will continue with our talent show as well. We also implemented several ceramics classes to engage diverse learners in the various functions of creating pottery and sculpture. Next school year we will starting a 3D printing program.

This year, we continued to expand our music program to included advanced piano. Students will be able to concentrate in music appreciation. This year, we included a small visual arts program for students during the day. We have included a coding class that is a pre-requisite to compliment our growing computer science program.  The in residency program provided a cohort of 9th grade students an opportunity to express their artistic talents in visual arts. We hope to expand this program if the funding is provided.

The Arts at Murrow provide students entering our communication arts program a wide choice of introductory classes in vocal and instrumental music, visual arts, dance, animation and theater. Many students go beyond the NY State required arts credits and choose to broaden their arts education with a substantial sequence of study through higher level elective classes in the arts. Students who discover a talent and interest in the arts can pursue more rigorous studies in one of our screened arts programs: Music, Art and Theater Institutes. Institute students participate in enriching classes, ensembles and experiences unique to our school and remarkable in both depth and scope. In addition, each Institute prepares students to take a comprehensive citywide exam which, in passing, offers the distinction of a Chancellor's Endorsed Arts Diploma. Beyond high school, many Institute students are well-prepared to continue their arts education in many prestigious university and conservatory programs. We try an improve on all of our courses every year in order to stay as current as possible. This year we have added Music Technology to our repertoire.
Q45_1: Murrow is one of the most diverse buildings in this city. We have students from every corner of Brooklyn, from every walk of life and from every culture and background. We try and accommodate every single student by bringing out the best in them through their talents and abilities.

Q44_1:
John Dewey High School continues to offer an expansive array of courses, including ceramics, computer graphics, drawing, painting, photography, dance, and theater production.
We offer AP Art History, as we continue to increase the number of AP courses for all students.
This year, we did a production of "In The Heights", the famous play written by Lin-Manuel Miranda, who more recently, wrote "Hamilton".  We also received a grant and participated in SING for the first time.
Our Dance program continues to grow, and we intend on growing the program.
We now offer the Arts Endorsement for graduation.  This is a challenging, but prestigious achievement that the New York City Department of Education now offers.
Our Arts Academy will be entering its second year, and we look forward to increasing its capacity and offerings.

Q37_4: chaperoning on arts and culture related excursions
Q44_1: At LIFE Academy for Film and Music we offer a multi year sequence in film and visual literacy as well as a revolving track in music production in support of our school’s mission L.I.F.E. (Literacy Integrated in Film Education). Film is used as a catalyst across the curriculum to engage diverse learners and levels by introducing students to various media tools to unlock and express their creativity. Multiple modalities deepen and focus literacy skills on Common Core parameters of Position, Evidence, and Analysis encompassing peer review, critique, ownership, and decision making through inquiry, hands on projects. In support of our arts program, we continue to have utilize cultural resources from Teen Nights at the Whitney Museum to the Met. Students participate in Master Classes with “I Will Graduate” & “Get Reel,” sponsored by ABC/Disney. Further, we continue to partner with  The Museum of the Moving Image as a foundation for the moving image curriculum. In the Fall of 2016, students attended Teen Design and other college fairs to help them prepare their portfolios and skills needed in their forthcoming applications. For the third consecutive year, our students have had their visual art work adjudicated and accepted into the Brooklyn Borough Arts Fair. Additionally, our students participate in Y Plan to promote debate, citizenship, and presentation skills. Further, many of our young female students are working with Liberty Partnerships to cultivate their talents and prepare them for college and life beyond.
Q45_1: As we have enrolled numerous ENL students in the past few months, we aim to broaden the visual literacy through the arts and music program to engage all learners through a wider, more universal lens.

Q33_6: Bridging Arts and Education Together and Stoked
Q44_1: Leaders has a full-time visual Arts teacher.  She teaches a 9th grade arts class that all students take and an advanced class that students may elect to take.  We also offer a dance and photography elective throughout the year.  We offer an after school guitar program and an after school Beat Makers program.  Our goals for next year are to enhance the quality of all of these programs and to demonstrate the student achievements through more public art and photography shows and more dance recitals.  It is also a goal to inspire more students to participate in the after school guitar and Beat Makers programs.  We also hope to have more performances for the students in these programs.

The Marine Park Junior High Band Program has enjoyed many years of excellence. Located in Marine Park Brooklyn, students begin their musical day at 7:00 A.M. and often finish late in the evening. Students are taught their instruments from scratch in the 6th grade, and by 8th grade have several opportunities to thrive as young musicians. Marine Park's Band Program is comprised of beginner band, a symphonic band, two jazz ensembles (audition only), a marching band, and chorus. The symphonic band, jazz ensemble, jazz band and chorus have earned Gold and Gold with Distinction ratings at NYSSMA Festivals for the last seventeen years. Our Drama students are involved with two major productions each year. Our credits include Brighton Beach Memoirs, Lost in Yonkers, The Miracle Worker, Cinderella, Bye Bye Birdie, Little Shop of Horrors, Guys and Dolls, Fame Jr., To Kill A Mockingbird, Outsiders, Thoroughly Modern Millie, The Giver, and The Little Mermaid Jr.

Grady High School has worked diligently over the past several years to increase the arts opportunities available for students. As a CTE school, only required art and
music were offered. While students are still only required to take two terms of study in the arts, the certified arts teacher provides instruction in a number of different type of art forms in her classes.
It is our consistent goal to enhance our students’ arts experiences through integration of courses that give them the opportunity to develop their own artistic identities while expanding their knowledge of cultural arts.

We offer a basic art program via our iLearn Platform that allows at-risk students of not graduating the possibility to fulfill the state mandated graduation requirement. Through other classes that are offered we provide students other opportunities to explore and engage in the arts via museums, school talent showcases, and plays. We have also been fortunate to receive a grant for an arts program to combat violence.
Q45_1: We serve an overage/under-credited population of students who typically have very little time to increase academic skills,pass regent exams, attain credits and graduate before either aging out or going to work full time.

Q44_1: Shell Bank students enjoy Violin through Midori and Friends grant.  Elective classes include Music history, and Chorus.

Instruction in the arts is a top priority at P.S. 52, and to that end, our arts department—which consists of a licensed visual arts, theater, dance and music teacher—and our classroom teachers, work collaboratively throughout the year to plan and develop curricula that addresses arts instruction in visual arts, music, theater, and dance. We produce musical theater, dramatic performances, concerts, dance performances, and visual arts and the moving image exhibitions throughout the year for the school and the community. The arts department also works collaboratively throughout the year with educational and cultural arts organizations to secure arts grants, arrange field trips and provide artist residencies for our school. Classroom teachers incorporate the arts into all areas of their curriculum and exhibit artwork on a regular basis, and artists and composers are studied in each grade as part of the arts curriculum. P.S. 52 is committed to delivering a high quality, interdisciplinary arts education for all of our students.

P.S 109 is servicing grades 3-8 in Visual Arts. This year P.S 109 provided the students with instruction in painting, drawing, pastel art, mixed-media and sculpture. Cross-curriculum information was incorporated into each visual art lesson, and each unit plan was tied to a specific artist and art period. ART CLUB was offered every day during lunch in order to facilitate the students with High school portfolio preparation, and the development of personal art interest exploration. As a result two students got into the specialized art high schools of their choice. Students were provided with differentiated visual and physical materials in order to reach their diverse learning styles. Students work was exhibited in the Annual District 22 art show. Additionally, students were entered into the Annual Brooklyn MLK arts competition where two of of them won first and second place.
P.S 109 is currently working with an art partnership called "Studio in a School" students are exploring pottery making and clay sculpture design from a teaching artist.  With the skills gained through this partnership, next year we would like  to incorporate more clay sculpture making into the art curriculum at P.S 109. Additionally, we would like to incorporate more technology and digital visual art based lessons into our program.

PS 119 is committed to developing the whole child with a focus on the arts. Students are given art and music instruction from PreK through grade 5. A magnet school, each year students study diverse cultures with a culminating Expo demonstrating student learning and achievement.  An important part of the school culture is to expose our children to global traditions while promoting peace on earth.   Art is seen as a tool for creative expression as well as a pathway for language development and behavior modification.  Our arts partners work in concert with the arts educators and classroom teachers to provide the most coherent scaffolding of lessons for making meaning through the arts.  Students annually visit performances through out the year at Brooklyn College including dance, theater and storytelling. It is through this far reaching arts approach that we believe children are motivated to enjoy learning across the curriculum as they evolve into their best selves.

At P.S. 134 we strive to incorporate all aspects of the arts instruction into the curriculum. Our goal is to create a climate of appreciation and learning of all art forms by our students. We do this by exposing the students to various arts instruction from Kindergarten through Grade 5. We also do this by showcasing the accomplishments of all students in the arts. The students receive instruction in the arts from certified teachers who use the Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts to provide developmentally appropriate lessons. These teachers also differentiate instruction for the students to accelerate the learning of all students.

For over 12 years, our arts program has shown consistent growth. Our PreK classes have music, movement, and visual art with both a classroom teacher and certified arts teachers. All K-2nd grade classes have general music and keyboarding with Music and the Brain. 3rd-5th grade classes have singing, percussion, and recorder with another certified music teacher. All students have dance with certified dance teachers, and 5th Grade has line dancing in physical education. All students receive visual arts from cultural organizations. K-2nd grades have theater with their classroom teachers. A few dozen students have Music Therapy. We have violin for 30 1st and 2nd graders, and 15 students participate in Bell Choir. 20 students in every grade participate in dance clubs. Sixty 4th and 5th graders use band instruments from the VH1 Grant. 50 4th and 5th graders share guitars from Little Kids Rock. Throughout the year, we receive several instrument and visual arts donations from the community. Studio in a School provides several parent workshops. Several years ago, the Arts Space grant provided risers, stage lights, and microphones. Next year, we hope to have a theatre residency for all students and a certified visual art teacher for K-2nd grades. Every child has several opportunities to perform in both dance and music concerts throughout year culminating in a Fine Arts Night with an art walk at the end of the year, as well as several Stepping Up Ceremonies. We continue to enrich the whole child.
Q45_1: We are a Title 1 school with 74.4% of our population receiving free lunch.  Culturally, we are an incredibly diverse school with a 40.47% Hispanic population, 17.71% Asian, 27.29% Black, 10.81% White, 1% Native American, and 2.5% biracial.  16.3% of our students have IEP's.  18.95% of our students are ELLs, and the majority of the rest are FELL's.  All students are offered all arts opportunities both during and after school regardless of their needs and cultural backgrounds, and all departments work together to ensure the education of the whole child.

Q44_1: P.S.152's goal is to ensure that instruction in the arts is an integral component of our academic program. Students in our Early Childhood Annex receive specialized instruction in visual arts, reader's theater and music. Students in grades 2-5 are provided with specialized instruction in visual arts, theater, music and dance. P.S.152's students in grades 2-5 participate in a school chorus, and upper grade students have the opportunity to be part of our African Drum Ensemble. Students participate in shows and dance recitals several times a year.They attend off site plays and view films in class. The final production of the year is our Spring Fling, which highlights student artistic endeavors (dance, music, and visual art) throughout all grades.

P.S. 193 offers Kinesthetic Arts, Music and Theater programs, exposing Pre-K thru grade 5 students to a variety of art experiences.  Students are enriched in the arts through cultural arts organizations by attending dance, music, theater and art exhibits in the community.  We plan on increasing our family engagement by offering more family night opportunities.

A previous Federal Magnet Grant enabled PS 194 to establish our arts program. Although we are no longer funded by the grant, our arts teachers and classroom teachers work collaboratively to provide arts instruction to support units of study aligned with the CCSS & the NYC Blueprint for the Arts. With knowledge gained from prior residencies (Covenant Ballet Theatre of Brooklyn, Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, Making Books Sing, Education in Dance, Brooklyn Philharmonic and Midori & Friends) our teachers continue to use the arts as a vehicle to enhance the classroom curriculum and produce grade performances which include dance,music/singing,speaking & acting. We have continued our connection with Covenant Ballet Theatre and Midori and Friends as well as making new connections with NY City Center, Music for Many & Ballet Tech. We are continuing our Composer/Artist of the Month program in which the students are exposed to facts and musical excerpts each morning & we hope to include Dancer of the Month next year. Also, our certified arts teachers are utilizing specially equipped spaces such as the dance studio, art room & auditorium. This year we continued our music periods in which each grade meets together for instruction and the majority of our classes are receiving dance instruction as well. Our students can also participate in the arts by joining our after-school arts related clubs and through the Midori & Friends violin program. The arts are and will continue to be an integral part of PS 194.

Q37_4: Funding an after school visual arts program
Q44_1: P.S. 195 is extremely proud of the arts programs we have developed at our school. We have a visual arts teacher who serves all grade levels. Her program incorporates artist studies and rich interdisciplinary connections to our social studies curriculum. A certified dance teacher provides instruction to all students in the history of dance, choreography, and technique. We have several art exhibits and dance performances throughout the year.
Q45_1: As a non-Title I school, we have limited funding to expand our Arts program.  We rely on the generosity of Councilman Deutsch for our CASA program after school.  Additionally, as a non-Title I school, we are not eligible to apply for many grants for the Arts.

Q44_1: This year we have a full time dance teacher who services fourteen  classes. We also have a full time theater teacher who services twelve classes. In addition, we were able to bring Marquis Studio to our school.This program is funded by a federal Magnet grant.  Marquis Studio provides music lessons, visual arts and theater to our students. In addition, Band for Today is providing keyboarding/piano lessons for some of our students. We have plans to expand our arts program next year with the grants we received. We will be working with other outside art specialists to incorporate more arts in our curriculum.

The Arts Program at PS/IS 206 includes two certified visual arts teachers, two certified music teachers, one certified drama teacher and one certified dance teacher. In the 2017-18 school year, PS/IS 206 will be adding an additional visual arts teacher to the Arts department. The elementary music program at P.S. 206 is a sequenced program that addresses musical feeling, concepts, music literacy, cultural context, and performance. The middle school program includes General Music building a foundation of music which includes:  the instruments of the orchestra, traditional notation, tablature, Western and World Music History, musical theater and the Little Kids Rock Modern Band Program. Performances are done throughout the school year. The Dance program at P.S./I.S. 206 is a creative based program focused on the Elements of Dance and techniques such as Ballet, Modern, Jazz, Hip-Hop, and cultural dance forms. Through the Blueprint for the Arts in Dance, we study various choreographers, and the history of each dance form. Students are creative choreographers through the art of dance-making including a partnership with Alvin Ailey. The PS 206 theatre program is designed to introduce students to theatre as an art for and means of communication, engage their creativity in developing original performance material, and build their skills as theatre artists and lifelong learners. The Visual Arts Program at is aligned with the NYC Blueprint for Arts and students explore drawing, painting, sculpture paper-mache, printmaking, and collage.

Our goal is to make our students college and career ready, in all subject areas, including the arts. Our students participate in rigorous arts curricula which support the Common Core Learning Standards/College and Career Readiness program, in addition to the Blueprint based units of study, and lessons which connect the arts to the common core subjects. Being a former i3 Arts Achieve school, we focus on formative and summative assessment which works to empower students to reflect to directly enhance their experience and performance in the arts, and to connect them to a multitude of resources. Therefore, we believe there to be a significant correlation of arts achievement on improved English Language Arts performance. It is our firm belief that this holistic approach to learning will yield students who are well-rounded, with the ability to incorporate the arts seamlessly into their daily lives and/or to make educated college and career choices rooted in the education they receive at PS 207.
Q45_1:
The Fillmore Academy (the middle school portion of our K-8 school) features a very strong visual arts and music program. The visual arts offers a screened Portfolio Development/Advanced Visual Arts class. Students create portfolios which enable them to audition for specialized high schools. Our school holds a yearly gallery exhibit. 
We have just completed a 5 year, visual arts i3 Arts Achieve Federal Grant school for the Visual Arts.
We have also a participated in a music, Juilliard Grant school. This program enables practicing musicians to visit with individual classes, as well as provide interactive performances for the students in grades 5-8. The music program offers a screened instrumental ensemble which includes a specialized Jazz Band. Our music program also offers a chorus for both upper elementary and middle school. Both the choral and band groups present two shows yearly, as well as specialized performances for school wide and local community events. Many of these students, in both the visual arts and music programs, go on to attend specialized Arts High Schools.

Q44_1: PS 217's goal is to provide all students with sequential instruction in the arts so they meet benchmarks in the arts blueprints. Students experience instruction in visual arts, music/movement and theater/dance. They receive additional instruction through residencies and our extensive after-school program, offering 30 arts related classes providing 24-48 additional hours of arts instruction to over 400 K-5 students. Fourth and fifth graders choose an area in the arts they wish to focus on and experience in-depth instruction in our Magnet Masters program by participating in one or two of twenty-four different clubs. Instruction takes place during an extended last period on Fridays adding thirty hours of arts instruction for these students. Our licensed librarian integrates the arts into her program with book related lessons that include art, theater and music, using methods such as puppetry, collage, movement and finger play.

Classroom and out of classroom teachers engage students in arts instruction in alignment with the Blueprint for the Arts. Our students participate in visual arts activities such as painting, drawing, collage, and sculpture. Students learn about famous artists through read aloud, research and class discussions. Classroom teachers creatively connect drama and literacy by designing lessons where the children act out stories and put on plays. In addition, students engage in activities such as performing dance routines and drama skits for the students and parents of P.S. 222 to enjoy. Music and expressive movement are integrated into various curricula areas throughout the day. Teachers work collaboratively to produce grade level performances such as songfests and holiday shows. Every year our students participate in competitions where they can design books, posters, or create songs for the particular topic of the competition. We support our students’ talents and creativity by encouraging them to participate in a variety of contests.
Q45_1: Please note that the classroom teachers integrate the arts to ensure that all students receive the required number of Arts instruction.

Q44_1: The arts program at Cunningham engages students in a comprehensive study of both performing and visual arts. Our objective is to enhance our students' understanding, appreciation and performance. Throughout our program, students are actively engaged in creation and performance in the arts through a variety of classes. Our goal is to expose students to music, dance, theater, painting, ceramics, digital photography, film media, textile design, and to enhance their understanding and appreciation of those arts. We encourage them to respond critically to a variety of works, connecting the individual work to other works and to other aspects of human endeavor and thought. Through interdisciplinary lessons, field trips, and visits from various arts organizations, our students develop an understanding of the personal and cultural forces that shape artistic communication and how the arts in turn shape the diverse cultures of the past and present society.

PS 236 is committed in providing students with excellent Art education and looks for creative ways to incorporate all aspects of Art into our curriculum. This year we have continued with our Art Classroom Instruction. We also have incorporated enrichment programs offered to students during the school day which include fine art, music, yoga, and drama. Music and Dance residencies were once again presented to the students as well as the STEAM program which spanned all aspects of the arts and blended this with our curriculum. The Parents' Association has supplemented many of our activities so that we can continue to thrive on a limited budget.

Andries Hudde Junior High School is committed to providing an arts education to all our students. We have classes in visual arts, string orchestra and brass band. Each of these offerings has a dedicated room and is taught by teachers licensed in the specific areas. Our instrumental music classes perform at graduation and award ceremonies. Selected students perform with the District 22 Honors Band.  The students’ art work is displayed for parent teacher conferences and the District 22 Art fair. Our Title III Immigrant Grant provided us with three evenings of painting for our parents. This evening was facilitated by our visual arts teacher.  In addition to our school offerings, we work closely with Puppetry in Practice. They provide residencies for our sixth, seventh and eighth grade classes. The sixth-grade classes did a project using Stop Motion Animation based on Science Fiction articles. The seventh- grade classes completed projects using Claymation to display three dimensional models of the Solar System. The eighth- grade classes created shadow puppets to represent the story of The Hidden Figures.  We will continue this partnership next year and enhance it with an editing component.  We will also increase residencies and in school performances for the school year 2017-2018.

Our school become a part of the  USDOE Magnet Program and our school has chosen Arts and Sciences as their focus. As such, our school has benefited from adequate funding of arts programs. This has enabled our school to support arts residencies in the performing and visual arts. This has ensured that all of our students benefit from a full arts program including Music, Dance and Theater. Our students continue to work with the Brooklyn Arts Council on puppetry and Mexican Dance. However our students also participated African Dance with the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Through Marquis Studio's students have begun to learn the joys of percussion music and attended a performance of STOMP. Our visual artist have been accepted again in both the Brooklyn Borough Art Show as well as PS Art. We look forward to having PS 245 School of Arts and Sciences become a beacon for the arts.
Q45_1: We received a Magnet Grant to support our arts program this year.

Q42_R1_C2: Bureau of Lectures and concerts African drum and dance
Q44_1: The Arts programs at the Paerdergat P.S. 251 School are continuously making strides to not only meet, but exceed the expectations as set forth in the Blueprints for the Arts and in through the integration of the Common Core Standards. In this endeavor we have identified areas in which we intend to enhance our arts programs. 1.Additional Arts Dance Program 2. Alignment of out of classroom arts content specialist curriculum with the CCS for Social Studies   3.	Increased family involvement in the school’s arts activities, resulting in advocacy for the school’s arts programs and support for their children’s arts learning. • Music, theater and dance concerts and performances. •	Parent workshops in integrating arts in the home setting. •	Art shows, Parent/ student arts and craft night. 4.	Develop student awareness of artistic options through the strategic use of technology and digital media. •	Lunch clubs for the arts • Professional development seminars for staff as to support use of technology in learning. Through the implementation of these focuses, our arts program will take a huge leap into using technology creatively, enhancing participation from the family and community as well as cultivating rigorous and meaningful arts experiences while fostering college and career readiness.

Q37_4: Parents raised funds to ensure that students in Grades K-5 received visual art instruction.t
Q44_1: We have established a solid relationship with Studio In a School and are in our eighth year of partnership. Our resident artist works diligently with every student in grades K-5. We have very strong parental involvement which is imperative to the success of the program. Studio offers professional development for classroom teachers and has implemented special projects to "expand the frame" linking art with other content areas. We are considered a "STEAM" school. Students'artwork has been displayed in such venues as The Asia Society,The Brooklyn Historical Society, Museum of the City of New York, and The Metropolitan Museum of Art. Fifth grade students were assigned a special project to create banners for Studio's 40th Anniversary Gala which were then displayed at the Seagram's Building Plaza in Manhattan. We have been awarded a Cultural After School Adventures grant through our local councilman. Through this grant, permanent artwork will be displayed for all to enjoy. Our Art Exposition is our culminating event and takes place in the middle of June for students, staff, and parents. Students in our chorus, Pre-K, and Kindergarten classes have performed several holiday shows for our student body and parents alike. All classroom teachers have participated in the NaliniKids program which encourages nurturing the whole child including physical, emotional, and character development. We have been awarded a Solar One grant which fosters a "green" environment. Six third-grade students participated in Ballet Tech's beginner's program.

Q37_4: Fundraising, accompanying classes on museum trips
Q44_1: Our visual arts program, based on the Blueprint for Visual Arts, includes experiences in all media, extended art periods, museum trips, quality sketchbooks/journals, thoughtful written reflections, formative assessments and the use of an art room Smart Board that brings the art of the world right into our classroom. Students' work is displayed around the school and in the community, often winning awards. Two visual art teachers assure every student weekly visual arts experiences in an integrated, scaffolded program. Older students have double art periods.Our music program's junior and senior chorus perform in two major concerts and for District 22 events. All students seen by our music specialist learn music notation, recognition, and choral instruction. Pulled out 4th & 5th Grade students belong to the Flute Club.  Our new dance studio gives student dancers the chance to explore creative movement and learn dance notation. Ballet barres and mirrors enhance students' experience. Dance curriculum is based on the Laban Movement Analysis system. All dance students discuss and write about dance as well as observe and critique each others work. Themes include animals, motif notation, patterns, and storytelling.  Dance Club participants choreograph creative dances. Dance students perform two major concerts during the year and at special events. Free tickets to the American Ballet Theater are given to dance students.

"An education without the arts is an education that handicaps rather than enables.”  Here at PS 269, we believe that educating our students with the arts culture is essential to their development. It allows them to be creative and supports learning across the curriculum.

The P.S. 277 arts program encompasses a range of all arts disciplines. Each child in the school prepares and participates in a theater assembly program which includes instruction in theater, visual arts, dance and music, culminating in a final performance. Pre-Kindergarten prepares and participates in several small performances which include the Lunar New Year and Mother's Day. In the 2016-2017 school year a cluster position for theater arts was incorporated into the program.  Visual arts is provided to our students through parent-funded cultural arts organizations. All students participate in visual arts instruction that is integrated into literacy, math, social studies and science. Our goal is to increase arts instruction in all arts disciplines for all students. In addition, we share a partnership with Marquis Studios through Parents Association funds and a partnership with the Brooklyn Arts Council through Council Funds. These partnerships afford us the opportunity to provide additional arts instruction for all of our students.

It is the goal of P.S. 312 to provide an arts education program that enhances the appreciation of the arts, while integrating curriculum based content areas and embedding the Common Core State Standards. We work towards meeting the Standards for the Arts by involving staff, parents, professional artists, arts organizations, cultural institutions and other community resources. We recognize the importance of the positive impact of the arts on the healthy development of students, both intellectually and socially. Integration of arts education can effectively engage students in all areas of study, helping to raise student achievement, as well as develop students' creative abilities to foster aesthetic appreciation. In addition to our standard arts program , we provide an intense weekly study in enrichment clusters for selected students in chorus, band, theater and visual arts, all of which culminate in a project or performance for a targeted audience.

Public School 315 is widely recognized as a school where the successful integration of arts education , academics and quality teaching are lifting student achievement. P.S. 315 has built an exemplary curriculum that emphasizes both arts integration and sequential skills-based instruction in dance, music, visual arts and theater. Literacy, social studies, computer graphics and science all have art components taught by classroom teachers and academic clusters. The arts specialists all integrate literacy, social studies and science disciplines into their curriculum. The efforts of the teachers are reinforced by partnerships with a team of preeminent cultural institutions. It is the school’s philosophy that through the emergence of the arts, students will make valuable contributions to the community.
Q45_1: This year we were at a detriment regarding our Arts Programs. Our auditorium has been off limits from January through the present. It is the process of being repaired. We are a shared campus and did not have access to a large space as we had to share the gymnasium for the lunch periods as well as the gym periods for both schools. Our Arts Program will hopefully make a comeback for the 2017-18 school year.

Q44_1: P.S. 326 has a wonderful arts program that exposes our students to all different kinds of art mediums, famous artists and their unique styles. We believe that learning through the arts helps prepare children for life. We strive to develop the childrens' imaginations, foster their skills and teach concepts important for self- expression. Students discover and explore elements of art and principals of design in art works and in their surroundings. Many concepts are tied to classroom units of study. Students are given opportunities to examine works of art, learn about the artist and their particular style of creating these works. Students experiment with all kinds of mediums and materials and create beautiful works of art that are displayed throughout our school. Our program allows students to develop essential knowledge and skills they will use throughout their lives.

The East Flatbush Primary School has a full time music teacher. Our music teacher follows the research based program "Music in the Brain", where students learn to play the keyboard.

First and Second grade students have the opportunity to audition for the school chorus and perform for their peers, parents and community members. 
 All students have the opportunity to play the violin.

Every student sixth through eighth grade was given the opportunity to take Art classes in the 2016-17 academic year.  Every child receives 2 periods of Art instruction per week.  Students receive further Art instruction/enrichment through our School Wide Enrichment Program.  Additionally interested students, as well as students who show special aptitude in Art and are interested in pursuing Arts education in High School are selected to be part of the school's Art Club.
Q45_1: None at this time.

Q44_1: Midwood High School strives to offer students hands-on experiences to develop their talents in art, music, media, and theater. Students are offered both in-school and out of school experiences to broaden their knowledge of art and music. We offer Music Production, Graphics Arts and Media Arts including sound recording and editing classes to our Media CTE students to make students aware of career possibilities in film, television, and entertainment. We have a television studio and students can enter their film work in citywide and national film festivals.  We have two new Mac Labs for Graphic Arts.   We place students in internships at museums and art galleries. We offer band and chorus experiences and earned Silver Medals for our Symphony and Choral groups and a Gold Medal for our Wind Ensemble at the 2016 NYSSMA contest. We have an annual SING that is student-created and run. The spring production exposes students to live theater. All students have the possibility to create portfolios for colleges and are accepted into any art or music class during their free periods to work on their art or participate in a music ensemble. Our SWD and ELL students participated in an in-school and afterschool Art workshop this year. Our advanced students painted a mural on the bridge over the Long Island Railroad cut on Nostrand Avenue through Groundswell.  Our Councilman provided another grant to paint the other side of the bridge this year.
Q45_1: We are focusing on Band.   We will give away our string inventory to make storage room for more horns.  We have Pratt Scholars and Parson Scholars who have been given four year scholarships to those institutions.

Q44_1: Thanks to a very generous grant from our local Council person we have a very strong collaboration with Roundabout Theater. Students in ELL, English and Special Education have visiting artist working with them in their classrooms. Roundabout Theater is also working with our spring musical (costumes, sets, lighting and all parts of the performance) and worked with SING. Our music program has grown to include strings and orchestra. We have more sections of ceramics this year thanks to the hiring of a trained ceramics teacher.
We offer Painting and Ceramics Arts courses.
Q45_1: We are a STEM-themed school.

Q44_1: Corona Arts and Sciences Academy aims to provide an Arts educational experience for our students that is both rich in content and practice while being accessible for all students. In our third year, we have moved to a new facility equipped with two Visual Arts studio spaces, a Band room, as well as a fully functioning Dance space, and a multi-purpose Gymatorium with a curtained stage, lighting, and sound system.  We have continued to work to expand upon our inaugural curriculum, fostering student voice and creativity through the implementation of lessons geared around Arts history, theory, and practice. This year, we continued our sequential Arts program in which students are allowed to take an Arts sequence, focusing on content that both interests the student and promotes personal student mastery. We also introduced our students to instrumental music in the form of a formal Band course. In the coming 2017-18 school year, our hope is to expand to include a Dance program for our students that will be added to our sequential/rotational Arts program.  Our goal is to promote the importance of the Arts in the well-rounded students’ pedagogy, and the positive life-skills acquired in such courses that can be used across the curriculum and outside of the school setting.

We are very proud of our arts program. With the inclusion of our Early College arts courses as well as our Shakespeare electives, our students are receiving a well rounded arts education. Our students have the opportunity to showcase their talents in art and music. Our arts programs allow students to reflect on their abilities and express themselves in ways that no other academic subject can.
Q45_1: Brooklyn College Academy is an Early College High School with two sites in Brooklyn. Our main site is located at our Main Site at Coney Island Avenue which houses our 9th and 10th grades. Our site in James Hall at Brooklyn College houses our 11th and 12th grade students. We serve predominantly African-American students and our Hispanic and Asian populations are growing. Our arts courses include band, World Ensemble, visual arts, a Shakespeare performance elective (in collaboration with the NYC Student Shakespeare Festival/CUNY CAT) and an Early College Music History course sponsored by Brooklyn College. This year The CUNY CAT team also did two half day workshops for nine of our classes which was sponsored by NY City Councilman Jumaane Williams.

Q44_1:
The Visual Arts and Music programs at Origins High School develops a young artist's technical abilities and personal vision through the study of a variety of traditional and contemporary media. Creative problem solving, critical thinking and a broad range of experiences build the foundation for deeper understanding, advanced learning, and innovation within the various media. 

All students take Digital Literacy and Art Foundations during their freshman year. Students will learn how to use technology resources to aid them in organization, projects, formatting documents, and self expression. Programs include Google Suite (Docs, Slides), Prezi, GIF file animation, Weebly websites, Pixton comics, and GarageBand. In Art Foundations, students are exposed to a wide variety of techniques and skills which will be developed through a series of planned projects in 2-dimensional mediums such as collage, drawing, painting, graphic design, photography and animation. 

Sophomores, juniors and seniors are able to choose from the following courses: Instrumental Music, Guitar, Drawing, Sculpture, Ceramics, both Darkroom and Digital Photography, Graphic Design, Animation and Mixed-Media Sculpture. In addition to these offerings, we will be adding on a theater elective in the coming year.

We are a Transfer school that offers Music classes that teach performance, critiquing, composing, and analyzing music to students of varying musical aptitude and achievement levels. Further, we also offer Visual Art classes that are aligned to the NY State and NYC Blueprint for the Arts. Students plan, revise, display and present their work using the formal language of the visual arts

Q37_4: Participating in Family Arts Events with their chidren
Q44_1:
Our young artists enjoy rich art history lessons through "Master of the Month.  Each month we learn about a famous artist and explore different art techniques.  Children engage in creative hands-on art activities which allow them the freedom to express themselves though painting, drawing, collage and sculpture.  For the second year, we received arts grants to include a 10 week in-class puppet theater program through Puppetry in Practice.  We have offered additional workshops for families to participate with their children in puppet-making activities.  At one of our centers, we have also collaborated with Studio in a Classroom to support the teachers in enriching the arts program for their students.  
Our Music and Movement program offers children an opportunity to express themselves through rhythmic music and movement, echo or count the beat, singing and dramatic or imaginary movement in which children lead the group.
Q45_1:
Our program provides education to 240 pre-kindergarten children at 3 locations. Our students represent diverse backgrounds and needs.  Over 65 percent of our students are learning English in addition to the family's native language spoken in their homes.  We have 22 languages in addition to English spoken by our student. Approximately 22 percent of our students also receive additional services to support their learning needs.  
The arts are critical in enabling our diverse student body learn to communicate their thoughts.

Q44_1: All of our sixth grade students have two to five periods of fine arts electives (band, string orchestra, chorus, visual arts) per week, offered by five full time music/visual arts teachers. Seventh grade students have arts electives two to three periods a week. Select sixth grade classes also study the arts and culture of the Silk Road (Silk Road Connect) during their ELA or social studies classes. Sixth through eighth grade students have the opportunity to study the arts during our period nine extended day program, as well as in our comprehensive after school program sponsored by the Child Center of NY. Arts. Offerings in the after school program include dance, musical theater, chamber orchestra, jazz band and art portfolio.  Students also participate in school day arts residencies (dance and visual arts) with Arts Connection. This school year we have received a grant from ArtsSpace to update one art classroom and to create another one. This will greatly enhance our visual arts programming and also facilitate the traveling time for the teachers in between the two classroom. It is our goal to offer our students a comprehensive, sequential, and rigorous fine arts curriculum which fosters an appreciation for the arts, as well as developing the necessary skills for placement in high school art programs, and expanding future career choices.

Our school community has continued to support the arts programs. We are providing the students with a culturally rich academic experience. We offer programs in the arts both during school hours and in after school enrichment. Students are able to prepare for auditions and portfolio presentations for specialized high school admissions. Students are taught music, dance, and visual art as part of the school curriculum. Instrumental, choral music, dance and art are taught in morning, and after school programs. Students may learn ballet, tap, Hip Hop, jazz, Step, African, Indian Folk Dancing, and creative movement as part of their class curriculum or as an enrichment program. Our music program consists of morning and afternoon small group instrumental lessons and pull out multi-grade enrichment including: drum kit, woodwinds,guitar,keyboard, brass and rock band ensemble. Our Visual Arts curriculum includes mask making, watercolor painting, clay projects, paper-mache, and bookmaking. Our after school program helps students explore stage decoration, portfolio preparation, and individual strengths and creativity  Our school has collaborative performances showcasing student achievement.

At PS 150 we strive to make the arts an integral part of the school's culture and students' learning experience. As this year we did not have our typical dance cluster, we sought to build partnerships and residencies with cultural based organizations.  Because the partnerships were formed in the Fall, it took awhile to get what was intended to be year long residencies started.  Next year the residencies will begin earlier in the fall. This year, as in the past, PS 150 partnered with the Brooklyn Arts Council. This year our partnership was a residency for grade 4 scholars.  These scholars performed for the school community and for a local Senior Care Center. We also began a residency program with Mark Morris Dance Group.  This residency served scholars in grades 1, 2 and 5.   Students involved in the Brooklyn Arts program worked with Elders Share the Arts in producing a theater production. These scholars performed for the school community.   This year Imani House After school program offered African Dance, Steal Pan, Drama, and djembe drumming.

The art program at PS/IS 155 helps to broaden the students understanding of various cultures past and present. This is achieved through the study of art history and the exploration and use of various techniques and materials. This helps students to become well-rounded individuals who are better equipped to tackle high school and be more prepared for college and career readiness.

PS/IS 284 Arts Programming continued to expand during the 2016-2017 school year as a designated community school and as a 2nd year Turnaround Arts grant school. In addition to visual arts instruction for graders Pre - K - 5, grades 5 - 7 received music and theater classes. Some of the arts organizations to work with our students include: Mark Morris Dance, BRIC, Reelworks, We Make Noise,  ArtsConnection, and Materials for the Arts.  After school Brooklyn Community Services provided dance and visual arts experiences for our K - 5th grade and  Sports and Arts After School kept middle school artistically engaged  with graphic design and dance. This year we successfully produced  our first Disney musical- Lion King., Jr.,

Q37_4: help with our Broadway Theater Production and help setting up an art show in the community
Q43_10: checklists, exit slips, glow and grow and critiques
Q44_1: PS/IS 323 is a team of actively engaged and dedicated staff members, whose goal it is to provide an appropriate and authentic learning environment for each student in all subjects. Exposing our students to the arts is a priority at PS/IS 323. Our students experience musical theater, dance and the visual arts. We strive to meet each child’s individual needs in a challenging and encouraging environment, developing their full potential and personal expressions.
Q45_1:
We have a FABULOUS performing arts period, once a week for TWO CONSECUTIVE periods (90 minute block) for grades 4-8. The students choose which arts discipline they would like to experience for that year. 
Wednesday grades 4-6
Thursdays grades 7 and 8

We are also a Cool Culture Pass School. Our pre-k-2 students have family passes to attend all the cultural institutions in NYC. They have passports that are stamped by their teacher to illustrate the ones they have experienced throughout the year.

Q44_1: The arts program at the Dr. Rose B. English school encompasses music, dance, theater, visual arts, and media arts. Our goal is to ensure that all of our scholars explore and develop their creative talents. As a result of our arts program, scholars are exposed to various cultures, music, and orchestra instruments. Arts education at the Dr. Rose B. English school helps to propel and prepare our scholars for 21st century college studies and careers.

Arts education continues to be a part of the everyday experiences of students at I.S. 392. We are a school that believes that through the arts our students are able to learn and grow academically. Our students are provided a well rounded education that includes a balance of academics and arts both during the day and after school. We continue to provide the same emphasis on arts as we did last year through our residencies for ceramics, and poetry writing resident artists who work with our children and teachers. This year we provided theater classes twice a week to most of our 6th, 7th,  and 8th graders. Our visual arts teacher this year worked with a resident artist to provide ceramics classes to 6th graders. The ceramics instruction was integrated into the social studies curriculum on ancient civilizations. Students at I.S. 392 this year had the opportunity to audition for a role in our Broadway Jr. Production of Beauty and the Beast It is our second year with this program, and our students and staff have been working hard and put together an outstanding show that will once again be attended by other schools in our district as well as our superintendent and other guest. During last year's and this years performance preparation, our students have been able to sharpen their skills in vocal music, dance,  theater, acting, visual art, and sound and light technology. This program has shown our students how all of the arts disciplines come together for one amazing performance.

2016-2017 In PS 401 Arts was successful within the classroom using the grant Music and the Brian. Students from K-2 focused on preparing for their piano recitals and have become comfortable critiquing themselves and each other. Singing was also a priority this year. Exposing students to all types of music and building curriculum around their likes and needs. Goals for next year would be scheduling and collaboration.
Q45_1: PS 401 students are very far behind academically which forces music and the arts to be pushed back and not a priority in the school.

Q44_1: Our current arts program consists of full time dance and visual arts programs and a part time music program. All children have dance and visual arts twice a week and lower level has music 1-2 times per week. All units are aligned with the NYC Blueprint. Teachers collaborate on 3 school wide performances. Partnerships with organizations such as Mark Morris provided supplemental instruction for dance and visual arts this year.

Our arts program includes visual arts focused on drawing techniques and a visual media arts/design. Students can join our dance class and   visual arts after school through counseling in schools. We also have an in residence arts counselor. Students present their work via bi annual events with an art display and dance/talent show. We have drum line classes with monthly performances inside and outside of school.

FDA VII offered drama this year and introduced spoken word and script writing.  Students wrote and performed "alternative" productions of plays in class and performed one major play for the community -at -large.  Additionally, the culminating drama program is SING a competition among grade levels which incorporate script writing, digital media and drama.  The theme for our SING launch is Fairytales.

It is our belief that an arts program is an absolute necessity for providing students with room for self-expression, creativity and intellectual sagacity.
