Dance: students on all grades receive dance instruction on a regular scheduled basis.
Theatre: In partnership with Broadway Junior, students have learned best practices and have successfully brought their third play to stage.
Technology: Our arts program was implemented to integrate technology (with the use of digital cameras, lighting equipment, and other accessories), to enhance output and to give students an experience in video production.
Sports and Arts: Students work with the Sports and Arts and Beacon programs to be further exposed to other aspects of the arts - music, African drumming, steps, graphic design, fashion design and modeling, and chess.
Trips: Students attend art-focused trips to the theatre, art exhibits, and concerts to expose them to a wide variety of artistic options and expression.  Thereby they will gain relevant information and find their niche in the art world!
Brooklyn Democracy Academy provides students the opportunity to participate in music, theatre, and fashion design classes throughout the school year.

This year, our school implemented a music program (The D.R.E.A.M. Factory) that was funded through the Department of Youth Development and Community Development.  It provided our students the opportunity to utilize their talents in the music and hip hop industry.  The students were able express their talents

Our students participate in lunch groups and after school workshops facilitated by Dance Theater Etcetera. These programs are born from our shared belief that creativity is the key to engaging and inspiring our young people. Students work with a teaching artist to find their voice and creativity unlocking their hidden talents. Students develop their critical thinking skills connecting their ideas, values and experiences to the greater world around them. Students have the opportunity to enjoy the academic learning process in a dynamic and fun way.

BEES is a small middle school. As such, we use a variety of means to incorporate the arts into our programming. This year we partnered with ArtsConnection for 3 separate in school artist residencies. We hosted ArtsConnection teaching artists in Dance, Visual Arts and Drumming/Percussion. All students participate in the residencies. In addition, BEES has committed to have every student experience a live performance each month. This year we partnered with Community Works to attend performances at the Apollo Theater and Aaron Davis Hall @ City College each month.  Additionally, we are a New Victory Theater partner school.  This means BEES students attend a performance once per month at New Victory on 42nd Street.

We offer dance or visual arts to all middle school students. In addition, we offer music to grades 6 and 7 students during the spring semester. Students have the opportunity to learn keyboarding, guitar and prepare vocals for our art showcase. At the high school level, students can elect to enter the Arts Centered Program in 10th grade. They remain in this program from grade 10-12. During these years they take classes in visual arts and dance as well as having outside opportunities to perform and explore additional art experiences. All high school students, who do not enter the Arts Centered Program, take a minimum of one year of visual arts or dance. We offer music as an elective for students based on their interest level.  We offer Spoken Word workshops as a unit within English Language Arts and a Spoken Word Dance Elective. We hope to continue to grow the program for ACP and non-ACP students. We are also trying to continue and/or grow partnerships.

Q30_6: MTI/Schubert Broadway Jr. - iTheatrics via Grant Funding (Awarded in 2016-2017)
Q44_1: The Fine and Performing Arts Department's Vision is for students to be open-minded,to think critically,and to explore in an environment that fosters a community of learners, with a focus on problem-solving skills, collaborative thinking and develop a life-long appreciation of the Arts. Our vision connects to the broader scope of the goal of our school community: to talk like scholars, write like experts, think like innovators and live like leaders. Our school offers arts education in all of the four arts areas: dance, drama, music, and visual arts. In addition, we house a culinary arts program and technology course that routinely integrates film. The diverse Fine and Performing Arts Department at our large middle school (over 1850 students) allows all of our students the ability to experience the arts. Since 2014, we have sought to provide a depth of study in a different art form each year, while all of our special education classes receive culinary arts. In addition, we are thrilled to have our first MTI/Schubert Broadway Jr. School Musical Fame, Jr. this spring! Moving forward into the 2017-2018 school year, the Fine and Performing Arts Department will be engaging in studies of student assessment in the arts, aligning best practices and further defining our collective instructional approach as both a cohesive teacher team and those who instill a love for the arts in our students.

At P.S. 7Q, it is our goal to provide our students with an enriching, comprehensive arts education. Our certified visual arts teacher meets with many students on a weekly basis and uses the NYC Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts as a framework for the development of lessons. We have again increased family involvement in the arts by inviting families to participate in arts-related experiences with their children such as visual arts contests, parades,art festivals, mask making and written communication regarding community based arts opportunities. The hallways of P.S. 7Q are decorated with authentic, standards-based beautiful artwork created by the students. We strive to involve our students in all arts disciplines and believe that the arts are an essential component of a comprehensive education.

At PS 12Q, we recognize that our role as a school should go beyond the traditional ways of teaching and that students need more than academic subjects. Our teachers are encouraged to expand their students' imaginations by experiencing the excitement of class trips. Music and art, we believe, should be integrated into our curricula. Many of our 4th through 5th grade students are members of our school band and our 5th graders learn the importance of working as a team while participating in our school's chorus. All of our 3rd graders learn how to play the recorder. Our school's art teacher enhances our academic curriculum by designing art projects that empower our students the opportunity to view the world from different perspectives, in addition to advancing our students' creativity. Established partnerships with Symphony Space and TADA! Youth Theater enable us also to broaden the arts education provided to our students.

Our goal is to continue to instill an appreciation of the fine and performing arts. PS13Q uses the Blueprint for the Visual Arts in planning our art curriculum and decorating the walls and bulletin boards throughout the school year. Students' writing about their artwork also accompanies the art.  Students in grades 3, 4, and 5 participate in band or chorus. Our band and chorus demonstrate their musical skills during the Winter and Spring Concerts. Students' visual artwork is displayed throughout the school year for parents, students, and staff members to enjoy. We have also had two parent paint afternoon sessions and evening parent paint nights. 
ESL and bilingual students in grades 4 and 5 participated in the third of three years with the DELLTA Arts Connection. Students performed original plays for each other, and for the third grade ESL students as well. The New York City Ballet and Ballet Hispanico partnered with our school this year to provide programs where students participated in dance. The students also attended a trip to Lincoln Center.  Queens Museum also partnered with our students to provide arts classes and lessons. Students also enjoyed dance, theater, and music from class trips. We also partnered with Inside Broadway this year and students performed CATS on stage in our school auditorium for the parent and other fourth grade classes to see.  Performers from Broadway also came and performed Land that I Love in our school auditorium. 
Our theater teacher prepared the students to perform Peter Pan at PS 13Q.

PS 14 The Fairview School has an amazing music program, bolstering large junior and senior bands, junior and senior violin orchestras, guitar lessons for classes of students, and 3rd, 4th, and 5th grade chorus. Grand musical performances are held at the school in the fall and the spring. Our choir performs annually at the Corona Tree Lighting Ceremony, at Queens Museum art openings, and at our Leadership Events. In May 2017, our students even performed at Carnegie Hall!

Our visual arts program is growing as well, serving 660 students. Second graders show their work at Queens Museum, as do the CASA students in grades 3, 4, and 5. Additionally, all 1782 students show at least one piece of visual art at our May Leadership Event when our school is transformed into an art gallery. 

We started our theater program 2 years ago, and our students are begin celebrated at the Queens Borough Arts Fair for the second year in a row. The purpose for bringing in theater classes was to support all students, with a focus on Special Education and ELL students, in engaging in purposeful conversational English. The program has grown far beyond our expectations as our very talented theater teachers are bringing out the best in our very talented students. 

Dance is next. In the fall of 2017, we are bringing in a dance residency to begin to build out the fourth pillar of our arts program. Additionally, in the spring of 2018, we will  perform our first true musical as a student body. Look forward to beautiful work from our students in 2017-18!

Public School 16, Queens, strives to align its curriculum with the NYC Blueprint for the Arts, implement school-wide enrichment and accelerate learning for each student in music, visual arts, dance and theater. Our school strives to enrich the curriculum through morning arts programs, day school arts programming, monthly field trips, residencies and implementation of enrichment clusters in the arts during the day and in an after-school rotating program. Our school hopes to sustain partnerships with cultural organizations in the arts including the Museum of Modern Art, Queens Museum, Artworks, Carnegie Hall, Julliard School, Dancing Classrooms, Queens Botanical Garden, NY Historical Society, Martha Graham Dance Ensemble and Carlota Santana Dance Company. Our school will continue to seek and forge new alliances to further enhance arts programming.

Q37_4: participation in the grant-funded PS 19Q Family Choir
Q44_1:
PS 19Q is committed to providing our students with quality arts instruction, expanding our partnerships with cultural arts organizations to enhance our curriculum.  Thanks to these partnerships, our students receive direct instruction from teaching artists in Visual Arts, Theatre, Music and Dance.  Additinally, teachers receive professional development to support the alignment of arts instruction into literacy.  
In addition, to our certified Visual Arts and Music teachers, we have continued our partnerships with the ArtsConnection, the 92nd Street Y, the New York Philharmonic Partnerships Program, and the TownHall Foundation.  Our students also enjoy from a variety of arts-related field trips, taking advantage of New York City's rich cultural institutions like the Metropolitan Museum, the Cooper Hewitt Design Museum and Museum of Modern Art to name a few.  In the 2016-2017 school year we expanded our arts curriculum, providing dance residencies in Hip-Hop to 1st graders and Ballet to 2nd graders.
PS 19Q maximizes resources to bring quality arts programming in-school and after-school.  Our after-school programs include:  a Flamenco dance residency with Flamenco Vivo Carlota Santana, Purfek Academy's Music Engineering program, and the Afro-Latin Jazz Alliance's instrumental music program.  Our Saturday arts programs include iPhone Photography and an Arts and Crafts program through NYCares. Thanks to Parent Engagement grant from the NYCDOE, we partnered with Corona Youth Music Project to begin the PS 19Q Family Choir.

I.S. 125Q offers an enriched and comprehensive Unified Arts curriculum to all of its students. We have dedicated classrooms and studios for dance, orchestra, band, visual arts, chorus and theater. All seven Unified Arts teachers are licensed and teach full time programs in their subject.  Teachers attend professional development sessions in the building as well as those offered by the DOE. All Unified Arts teachers collaborate on a weekly basis and hold arts workshops together with the students each term.   
Students are given the opportunity to select specific classes in the arts and are able to continue that course work from grade 6-8. Students may switch course work with the approval of their teacher, parents and department supervisor. Students in the Arts maintain learning goals that are created and maintained through individual conferencing between teacher and student.  All students taking dance, chorus, theater, band and orchestra are given the opportunity to perform in front of the school community on three separate evenings. These performances take place in December and May.  Students may audition for the annual school musical which is performed in May.

Q45_1: P.S. 28 provides students from diverse backgrounds and abilities with a comprehensive arts program. Our goal is to expose students to theater, music, dance and visual arts to support the development of their artistic and creative minds. Music comes alive with students singing and performing in winter, spring and summer concerts. Classroom teachers provide opportunities for students to participate in dance in their classrooms. Puppetry in Practice provides students with an art/theater experience. Pre- kindergarten and Kindergarten students create puppets that come alive to tell a story. Second grade students participate in a Stop Motion Animation residency where they explore "communities". First Grade students participate in an art residency with a "Tiffany" glass focus showing students a connection between the past and the present. Puppetry in Practice provides parent workshops on how art can be a medium to support literacy. In addition to a full visual arts program, we hold an annual art show where students' work has been showcased at the Queens Borough Arts Festival and the Metropolitan Museum of Art. In addition to our arts residencies and certified arts teachers, classroom teachers provide many opportunities for our young students to use their imagination and creativity to explore the arts in all subject areas.

Q44_1: In the 2016-17 school year, PS/IS 49 has enriched our arts program.  We have added drama for our 6th grade students.  We also have an after school drama club for 6th, 7th and 8th grade students.  We held our annual spring music and arts festival which exhibited our students' talents as well as our annual holiday concert. We also received a CASA grant through City Council Member Crowley's office which allowed students the opportunity to work with artists from Studio in a School after school.  We partnered with the New York Historical Society and Studio in a School.  After school programs were offered to ENL students as well as 7th and 8th grade students to work on their portfolios for high school.

P.S. 58Q strives to provide all students with the chance to participate in visual arts, music, theater, and dance programs in compliance with the 186+ hours of arts instruction required per year for grades 1-3 and 93+ hours required for grades 4-6. Students in grade pre-K through 6 received music and visual arts instruction on a weekly basis from both full-time school-based arts teachers and their classroom teachers, who further enhanced their classes’ arts curriculum through dance and drama lessons. Students presented their culminating projects in visual arts, music, dance, and drama for their parents in our Museum of Student Arts showcase in June and on bulletin boards throughout the year. Our auditorium was the site of seven concerts that highlighted our music students' work, along with music and visual arts-themed assemblies promoting principles of student empowerment as outlined in Stephen Covey’s “The Leader In Me” program. P.S. 58 follows the Music and the Brain program, which incorporates music history and keyboard use as a tool for reading music. For P.S. 58's foreign language program in Italian, students celebrated Italy’s heritage by singing traditional songs, creating colorful Carnevale masks, and attending plays based on Italian culture.

Our school has offered a complete performing/fine arts program, which includes Theater, Music (Band and Strings), Visual Art, Film, and Dance for the past seven years. Students rank their top three choices for in-school arts options and are matched to a desired arts group. Our Sixth, Seventh and Eighth grade programs in the arts are a full-year sequenced class that allows our students to grow in their chosen arts discipline. In addition to having semester performances that showcase content skills, as expressed in the Blue Print for the Arts, we also incorporate performances that revolve around culture and school spirit. Our arts curriculum is aligned to the Common Core standards and explores the arts through ELA, Math, Social Studies, and Science. In the last two years, we have partnered with several arts organizations to provide our students connections to artists and art work throughout the scholastic year.  We also offer our students multiple performance opportunities outside of the classroom through school musicals, dance teams, music, film, and art clubs.
Q45_1: IS61Q, Leonardo Da Vinci, is working towards having a three-year sequential program for our Visual and Performing Arts department. Our students are talented and we hope to provide them with the proper training to be competitive in order to gain admittance into performing arts and visual arts high schools. In accordance with adapting the leader in me initiative to our arts department, our students coordinate with one another to create individual student lead projects that are showcased during a special leadership day performance for a second year. Our arts department expects this initiative to evolve into a culture that is professional in nature and compassionate in taking in students who want to expand their own horizons.

Q44_1: Elm Tree Elementary School provides our students with diverse backgrounds a culturally representative arts program. All of our students receive visual arts instruction from a certified art teacher. As students learn about the many cultures they comprise, they are introduced to a variety of art materials and modalities and are encouraged to use their imagination when creating artwork. The students' artwork is celebrated by the school community during our evening Dual Language Celebration. Elm Tree Elementary School is an All Star Move-to-Improve school! All of our staff members have been trained and certified in Move-to-Improve, which is a series of activities and dance movements that are incorporated into the classroom each week. Our Kindergarten families are members of a school subsidized Cool Culture program allowing families free access to art museums throughout New York City. Moving forward, as Elm Tree grows we are committed to having a full time music teacher join our school community.

At PS 68 we strive to educate the whole child. Our goal is to equip our students with the ability to express themselves, to enhance their lives and to appreciate the arts as a vital component of their learning. We continue to maintain an enthusiastic music and performing arts tradition which is showcased in our weekly assembly programs as well as our annual Talent Show and Dance Festival. The MUSIC and THE BRAIN program is taught to all Kindergarten and First grade students through piano keyboard classes. This year we added the Second grade to our MUSIC and The BRAIN piano program. We offer an "Early Bird" Chorus program for 3rd, 4th and 5th graders. We continued our partnership with ARTS CONNECTION . This year we, also, obtained a residency with Studio in a School to work with all students from First Grade through Fifth Grade. Each cycle of Studio in a School culminates in a school art celebration and exhibit. Enrichment classes are offered in all grades, such as: Music Appreciation, Drama, Photography, Painting, Dance History, Cake Decorating and Collage.

At IS 73 we agree that the Arts are extremely important in our students' growth. Our goals are to not only give our students what is required by New York State but also to give them what they need to succeed in our ever changing society. Our belief is that Arts education enhances the intellectual and emotional lives of children by stimulating their imagination, improving communication skills, including analysis and critical thinking and strengthening visual literacy. It promotes emotional IQ and builds character; encouraging multicultural awareness and acceptance. It instills self-discipline, inspires respect for craftsmanship and gives families an opportunity to share, explore, and celebrate ideas and feelings that children may not be able to put into words. In 2016, our teachers began implementing our Arts Elements Curriculum allowing 6th grade students to circulate through each of the available Arts disciplines including, Visual Arts, Music, Dance and Drama. Students received instruction in each course for one Semester. We placed 7th and 8th grade students in a class aligned to their area of interest as determined by the Student Arts Survey. Students will continue to be able to pursue their area of interest for 7th and 8th grade Arts instruction. We believe that our interest-based Arts program will inspire students and allow them to creatively express their ideas leading to increased student performance and achievement.

We brought back traditional Art program by hiring a new Art teacher that also works as part of the ELT. There have been multiple trips to Arts High Schools and Arts exhibits. In addition we offer monthly Assemblies with Provider Arts Horizons for all students in our school. Multiple residencies from Arts Horizons and LEAP. With our ELT Grant, students have been offered 2 hours a day four days a week various arts enrichment programs of their choice. Students involved in these programs have displayed their artwork and various other projects in a culminating gallery exhibition and performance. Parents are always invited and welcomed to support these events.

Our goal is to provide students with an extensive exposure to as many arts experiences as possible. Besides our Visual Arts and Dance programs currently in our school - we have daily and monthly arts celebrations. We continue our daily "Village News" musical announcements - The children choose a meaningful song and have "Words of Wisdom" for it - They lead the announcements of the morning.We start each day with a song, smile and reminder to "treat people the way we want to be treated". We continue to add several school wide celebrations - Rocktober Fest was repeated this year where the children were introduced to many genres of music and created a dance to one. We also had a school wide art exhibit where the children were encouraged to choose their favorite work of art to be displayed. There continues to be school wide celebratory concerts and dancing in our Gym.

Learning Through Art (LTA) is an artist residency program which cultivates students' 21st Century learning skills (creativity, innovation, critical thinking, problem solving, collaboration and communication), by designing sustained, process-oriented art projects that support learning across the curriculum. The program sends experienced teaching artists into New York City public schools, where they collaborate with classroom teachers to develop and facilitate art projects integrated with the school curriculum. During the 20 week in-school residencies, participating students examine, discuss, and create works of art. Students participate in three visits to the Guggenheim Museum throughout the course of the residency. These visits support the residencies, as students are immersed in an environment rich with the works of world famous artists where they will engage in art inquiry, offering new insights into art and challenging students to think critically about art and ideas. PS 88 also was awarded the Disney Grant. This allows us to partner with Disney artists in working towards putting on a Spring Production of "Aladdin". Students will perform the production in the school for students and family members. Additionally, council member Crowley awarded P.S. 88 with the “CASA” (Cultural After School Adventures) grant for our 4th grade students. Lastly, P.S. 88 hired a certified art teacher who is responsible for developing students' appreciation of the arts through various experiences.

Q37_4: Family art time during parent engagement
Q44_1: P.S. 89's art program strives to enrich our students through the arts. Our goal is to help children learn to express themselves in varied ways which may include creating art, talking about art, sharing their unique abilities and potentially develop a lifelong awareness and participation in the arts. Through sensitive adult guidance, children are aided in mastering pivotal moves in the artistic process, the creation of ideas for personal expression, the discovery of visual qualities to express ideas and feelings, and the use of media to convey an expressive intent. A strong sense of pride is created in our students through our continued concentration on the cultural diversity of our student population. Through the varied art mediums, students are taught about their cultures by learning native songs and dances as well as art history.

Our Goals for the coming school year are to continue to integrate the arts curriculum into our common core curriculum.  We will continue to encourage teachers to take field trips to the various cultural institutions that the city has to offer. This will help enrich our curriculum and instructional programs.  We will continue to work with our current cultural organization, Arts Connection, which will enhance student learning through the art of puppetry. This year we brought the art of music to our Pre-K students. We hope that we can extend this in the upcoming school year.

At I.S. 93 we offer a two day a week, full year talent program. We offer 6th, 7th, and 8th grades the opportunity to take a three year sequence in Visual Art, Drama, and Music or if so chosen they may take different classes each year including the aforementioned courses as well as LEGO Robotics, STEM, and Stock Market. Our school and teachers facilitate arts related activities in most disciplines. Our clubs and classes perform several theatrical productions, and many concerts each year as well as an annual Art exhibit. The school provides opportunities for students and families to engage in trips, after-school and weekend activities, like visiting museums our great city has to offer. We look forward to continuously making our art program bigger and stronger as we have proven to do so in recent years.

Our goal as a school is to continue to have certified arts teachers servicing all of our students in the arts, while aligning curriculum to the Blueprint for the Arts, the New York State Standards, and the Common Core Curriculum. We hope to provide an arts program that will enrich and enhance learning across the disciplines. We will continue to devote designated rooms for our arts teachers. In the past five years we have also implemented an after school theater program and our school has put on a large scale musical theater production every year. For the past three years we have had a school wide Art Expo where we showcased artwork from third through eighth grade.  Each year we continue to put on a Winter Concert showcasing the talents of our talented Chorus and band, as well as a "Battle of the Bands" run by our middle school music teacher in an after school program. IN addition this year we will be adding a talent show for grade five through eight. Our arts teachers enter students into multiple contests (and have winners). Some of these competitions include the Queens Borough Art Fair, P.S. Art, the UFT Raw Materials contest,and the Little Kids Rock 2016 Songwriting competition. This year we implemented STEAM in K-2, and our science teachers incorporated art into their curriculum. We added a dance teacher and theater teacher, who are classroom teachers,  to work with younger grades part time.

At PS 110Q we value the arts. In our fifth year, a full time music teacher continues to work with our children. Throughout the year the teacher has been using the Orff Schulwerk approach to teaching music through imitation, experimentation, and personal expression. Children receive music instructiion 1-2 times per week; they put on two concerts during the school year. To compliment our music program, the CASA program has provided after-school music programs throughout the year for students across grade levels. In addition to music, Marquis Studio has provided our students across grades with additional after-school circus arts and theatre programs. We are also working with an in-house resident artist from Studio in a School over the course of five years to provide visual arts to all of our students. There will be an exhibition at the middle and end of the year for the students, staff and parents. Our artist in residence also provides professional development to our teachers to help them further integrate arts into the curriculum.

PS/IS 119 offers a variety of performing arts to our students. We presently have a number of orchestras, multiple level bands, guitar ensemble, Music on the Brain for our elementary students, chorus, chamber winds, and visual arts for the majority of our students. The Arts program is designed to connect with the other content areas and to meet National Standards for the Arts and the NYC Blueprint for the Arts. Parents and the community can enjoy our vast amounts of shows and performances throughout the year.

The arts program is aligned with the New York State literacy standards as well as the Blueprint for Teaching & Learning in New York State. Students work with a wide range strategies to create traditional and contemporary works of art in a creative setting. Projects are completed in units, where students build upon prior learned skills in Art, Music, and Theater.

P.S 143Q is dedicated to immersing each and every child in the arts. Our certified visual arts, music and dance teachers along with our drama teacher meet weekly with many students and use the NYC Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts as a framework for the development of lessons. Our arts clubs, including Glee Club, Dance Club, Music Club, Drama Club, and Spoken Word Club, encourage our students to explore and share their talents. Our strong partnerships with arts organizations support our vision for the arts. The community gathers to see student performances, which include venues at our own school and at Carnegie Hall. We are continuing to grow our arts program and are committed to supporting our students by providing them with an enriching, comprehensive arts education.

Developing awareness and appreciation of the arts for all students continues to be a fundamental goal of our school. Each year, students in most grades receive an arts residency through various outside agencies. It is our goal to increase the number of students receiving arts instruction, either in classrooms or with an arts cluster teacher. Recognizing that every child has interests and talents, we have instituted a dance classroom for our sixth grade students as well as two other classes. Our fifth grade ballroom dance program continues to be a favorite with our teachers and students. In addition, we have partnered with an outside organization to provide subsidized music lessons for students in grades 4,5 and 6. We will continue to seek support from outside organizations to enhance our arts programs.  Through Arts Connection we have been able provide varied arts instruction for our students, including an after school creative movement class.

For the 2016-2017 school year, P.S. 199Q has had arts partnerships with New York City Ballet, Creative Music Programs, and New York City Children's Theatre. Our partnership with New York City Ballet provided a dance residency for twenty first through fifth grade classes. Creative Music Programs provided arts residencies for eight classes, focusing on music. This school year we continued our partnership with New York City Children's Theater (Making Books Sing)for twelve first through fifth grade classes and culminated with a class share performance. Classes were able to participate in theatrical performances provided by New York City Children's Theater and dance (ballet) performances by NYC Ballet. Funding supports direct services to students, planning and/or professional development for school staff, materials and supplies, curriculum resources, arts and cultural services, performances, admissions to performances, etc. Our goal is to continue these arts partnerships for the 2017-2018 school year.

At P.S. 229, we value arts in education. Throughout the school day, all children are immersed in a plethora of education in all of the arts disciplines. We currently have two visual arts teachers and a music/drama teacher. In addition, our regular classroom teachers implement the arts in education throughout the day. Teachers in our building are constantly embarking on innovative projects in the arts such as reader's theater, songs and dances, visual arts projects, and field trips to museums, films, and shows. Outside organizations play an important role in educating our children in the arts as well. We participate in Ballroom Dancing, Midori Instrumental Music, The BRIDGES Puppetry program, and Ballet Tech. Through these programs we are able to provide the students at 229 with valuable arts experiences. All children at P.S. 229 leave our school with a solid foundation in the arts.

We serve newcomer immigrant students with a huge range of languages. Our school engages students in project based learning and mastery-based grading to assess student learning. The International High School for Health Sciences visual arts program offers visual arts courses for 9th and 10th grade students in a variety of mediums, including painting, drawing, origami, collaborative art making, photography, printmaking and illustration. Eleventh grade students are currently enrolled in a theatre/drama class. Our program focuses on incorporating visual art making skills and literacy skills to allow students to answer essential questions that develop higher order thinking skills and literacy skills. 

This year, 9th and 10th students engaged in a variety of units focused on identity-beginning with a project producing mandalas representing community members to their current project on empathy where students create masks representing the internal and external dimensions of personhood of cancer survivors.

The 11th grade team continued their work with a visiting teaching artist who helped to use a drama curriculum to introduce theatrical concepts, allow students to write and perform scenes and role play practical post high school circumstances, such as interviewing skills.  The instructional team additionally worked with a film production trainer to incorporate animated videos into a unit on immigration experiences for their US History curriculum.

P.S. 239 has a comprehensive visual arts and music program. Our music teacher works with a variety of grades, as well as a 4th and 5th grade chorus. Our School Chorus participated in a cross-school choral performance in December and have performed for parents and students during and after school. Our visual arts teacher also works across grades and displays student work around the school for all to enjoy. Our technology teacher works with our students on the development of graphic arts skills. Both 4th and 5th grade students participate in Theater and Art Clubs.  Our Theater club will be performing an end of year show to be shared with the student and parent communities.  This year, our school community has brought back monthly assemblies to further develop "theater" skills.  Students worked on set development, music and dance performance, as well as writing.  Our 5th grade students worked along with The Big Green Theater to develop plays, including music and sets around environmental issues.  Third grade students attended Ballet Tech.  Our arts team has created and compiled lessons based on the benchmarks found in the NYC Blueprints for the Arts. Classroom teachers use the lessons to provide our students with Readers Theater and Dance experiences from around the world. All of our students have an opportunity to experience and enjoy the arts.

Our arts program strives to challenge students to think critically and creatively in the visual arts. Students are knowledgeable about a variety of art materials as they investigate the relationship between the visual arts and social, political, historical and personal issues. Students keep a portfolio of their work culminating in a year end self-reflection. Students partake in independent field trips to museums and galleries to support classroom learning. This year, Photography has been added as an elective. The goals of photography students are to develop visual and technical skills to express a personal point of view using digital cameras.

At A.C.E. Academy for Scholars (PS 290Q) scholars receive the following art offerings: Visual Art, Performing Arts and Arts and Sciences. These courses are supported by the Blueprint for the Arts. Scholars perform in music, dance, and theater. In all subjects, our scholars’ learning is enhanced by field trips, interdisciplinary projects, service learning activities, and professional experiences Visual Arts takes a holistic approach to developing the whole artist where scholars experience exposure to Art History and the technical skills to develop their artistic talents. Performing Arts incorporates Music, Dance, and Theatre where scholars have the opportunity to develop each discipline in a unique way. Scholars participate in two whole-school performances annually as well as one grade-level performance annually. The Arts and Sciences course at the A.C.E. Academy for Scholars (PS 290Q) is a unique class modeled after similar ideals of a liberal arts college education. Scholars engage in a wide range of discovery and critical thinking activities, while simultaneously transferring their literacy and numeracy skills. We linked the common process and inquiry skills of the Arts and Sciences and developed a course that allows scholars to create, discover, explore, and express. The Arts and Sciences course at A.C.E. Academy for Scholars is supported by the Blueprint for Visual Arts, created by the New York City Department of Education, driving the Arts component.

Pan American International HS has a performance based arts program.  It offers classes in voice and diction, dramatic performance, music theory, theatre production, playwriting, chorus, and music composition.  Our after school Arts program includes professional training in dance and musical theatre.  Every year, students do a Winter and Spring Showcase that include music, theatre, and dance.  Every year the school produces a Broadway Musical.

The Arts program at Bard High School Early College Queens is designed to foster and lay the groundwork for a life-long engagement with the arts for all our students. Our faculty of active professionals, who have established relationships with major art organizations in New York City, offer students a well-rounded introduction to the appreciation and creation of visual and performing art. We offer a sequence of courses in music, theater, and visual art in which students build their skills in performance and in the creation of visual and aural compositions.
Q45_1: At Bard High School Early College Queens students complete 9th and 10th grade, including participation in an arts course each semester, then all students enter college on our campus.  Students take a program of college courses, including more advanced work in the Arts, during their final two years, culminating in both the high school diploma and AA degree from Bard College.  Our school is in a shared building, but it is well-equipped for the Arts, since it was originally designed as an Arts high school.

Q44_1: Learners and Leaders has a robust arts program. Students work with experts including DOE certified arts teachers and others with high levels of knowledge and skill in working with students to ensure a high-quality and well rounded experience with arts. Art has a very important role in our lives here at Learners and Leaders. Students participate in a wide variety of art forms. They have the opportunity to learn about and explore in important concepts in music, visual arts, dance and technology.

Students generally study two dimensional art media including drawing, painting and collage. They broaden their creative horizons, expand their English vocabulary and knowledge of art history while practicing a variety of techniques and styles. Since all of our students are English language learners we place a heavy emphasis on English language development in all of our content area and non-content area courses. Students are required to turn in written critiques/reflections at the end of each unit. They learn to function with other young artists in a vibrant, supportive workshop environment while also learning to work independently in pursuit of an individual sense of expression. All students moving from our 9th/10th grade junior Institute to our 11th/12th grade senior Institute must present a creative portfolio project before a committee as one of their six graduation portfolio requirements.
Q45_1: The International High School at LaGuardia Community College is a multicultural alternative high school for recent arrivals servicing the needs of students with varying degrees of limited English proficiency.  Our mission is to enable each of our students to develop the linguistic, cognitive and cultural skills necessary for success in high school, college and beyond.  The International High School gives priority to students of limited English language proficiency who have been in the United States for four years or less at the time of application.  All of our students enter as English language learners.  Our students come from over 49 countries and speak 36 languages.  All teachers provide English and native language development through the content area instructional program.

Q44_1:
Visual Arts - The goal of our visual arts program is to teach students the elements of art and the principles of design. Students are encouraged to analyze masterworks, their work, the work of their peers and discuss the elements of art. Curriculum units are focused on line, shape, form, texture, and value. There is a school wide art show that takes place in the Spring.

Dance - The goal of our dance program is to encourage self expression and creativity through dance performance and dance making. Through dance technique and creative activities, our curriculum teaches students important skills for both dance and life including problem solving, self discipline, and spatial awareness. Dance enrichment programs are offered after school throughout the school year.. Finally, students have the opportunity to showcase their dancing in various assemblies and performances throughout the year

Music - Students at PS 330Q are given the opportunity to learn about the many different aspects of music through performance. Kindergarten and first grade students learn a large repertoire of songs, games, and dances. Students in this age range master skills such as singing, listening and keeping a steady beat. Second graders learn about different styles and cultures in music through the Carnegie Hall Musical Explorers program. Third graders are provided the opportunity to learn the recorder through the Carnegie Hall Link Up curriculum. Fourth and fifth graders learn to play a variety of different band instruments.

As our school is growing, we continue to develop our arts programming. Our partnership with Education Through Music (ETM) continued with a full-time certified music teacher teaching classes to all of our students. Students performed in two choral concerts. Two students also participated in the NYSSMA solo vocal festival. Next year, our ETM certified music teacher will join our school faculty and ETM will continue to support the school with professional development and programming. All students also participated in art classes with our full-time certified art teacher. Their work was displayed in two school-based art shows. Two of our students had their work selected to be displayed in borough-wide and city-wide art shows. We continue to integrate theater and dance into classroom instruction. We anticipate hiring a certified theater or dance teacher for the 2017-18 school year. Students also attended dance, music and theater performances in school and in venues around the city.

Newtown has continued to expand its programs. We have added a visual arts teacher and will offer more choices in our arts sequence. We offer College Now classes in Drawing,Painting and Music Appreciation. We are looking into offering classes in AP Art as well. Our students prepare portfolios for college and career readiness in the arts. Students are familiar with the NYS Standards & NYC Blue Print for the Arts. Students are exposed to various art forms, tools & techniques to produce artworks and perform. Students develop observational skills and how to develop and argue an opinion when comparing & contrasting their artwork and the work of others which fulfills Common Core Standards. Students are introduced to professions in the "Arts" and are encouraged to develop their goals towards artistic careers. NHS has arts exhibits, concerts and plays within the school. Visual art students have exhibited at many outside exhibits and guitar students perform often at community venues and the choir. We have received grant money to expanded after school enrichment clubs which range from arts and crafts, films, dancing , and art club studio time to name a few. We have an annual "sidewalk art day" and this year we had a "Fall into the Arts" event where the art students made scarecrows of all kinds that were displayed outside for the community. We have offered "Paint night" that is open to students staff and parents. This years play in May is "Alice in Wonderland" and we also host a Spanish Drama Play.

Grover Cleveland High School continues to offers a rigorous and engaging arts curriculum aligned with the Common Core Standards and focused on College and Career Readiness. Students in the Academy of the Arts choose a pathway to a concentration in fine arts, commercial arts, music, or drama. Additionally, the Arts Department is partnered with core curricula subjects to infused literacy via the Literacy Design Collaborative in conjunction with High Schools That Work. All pathways seek to engage students in art making, performance, portfolio building, and technology. Students in all Small Learning Communities will experience foundational courses in art and music.

Our school has a full time art and music teacher. All high school classes receive instruction at our music studio and the art classroom.  In addition, students can enroll in LaGuardia Community College Arts classes which include visual arts, theater, dance, voice and instrument instruction. We are a small school which traditionally serves a high risk population.  Our students have the ability to stay a 5th year to earn an Associate's degree and/or earn college credits.  Approximately 115-120 students enroll in all areas of the arts as well as other college classes.

The High School for Arts and Business has a highly developed Art program that has ten credit art sequences for both Fine Arts and Graphic Arts. These sequences culminate in a Chancellor's Endorsed Advanced Regents Diploma. We are also developing a Career and Technical Education Sequence for the arts program. The course offerings are: Studio Art, Foundational Drawing, 3-D Design, Computer Graphics, Digital Filmmaking, Digital Photography, Advanced Painting, Studio Arts, and Commercial Design. There are also college level and Advanced Placement courses in Art History ,Photography and Digital Photography (Articulated Agreement with Queensborough Community College). Our program offers internships from the Center for Arts Education, Queensboro Museum, Groundswell Inc., Oratorio Society , Metropolitan Museum of Art and Queens Museum. Students participate in Arts Workshops at Cooper Union, Fashion Institute of Technology, The International Photography Museum, The Arts Director Club, Arts Connection and Art Students League. Last year we had an exhibit at the Queenboro Museum. Most of our Art students have completed our ten credit sequence and have attained the Chancellors Endorsed Arts Diploma. The Music department offers a Beginning and Advanced Band, Beginning and Advanced Chorus as well as Music Theory. Our school has a full concert band set up featuring woodwind, brass and percussion instruments. Students are performing and attaining NYSSMA certification. Our school also has a dance studio and several dance performances.

The arts program at Robert F. Wagner Jr. Secondary School for Arts and Technology includes arts-based experiences for students between 6th and 12th grades. There is consistent arts instruction (music and fine arts) for all middle school grades and art is offered both as a standard course and as elective courses for students throughout their high school years. Included in this offering is a course of fine arts classes, music classes, and theater arts classes. Each year, arts classes display their work around the building, utilize our gallery space for viewings, and celebrate their work with presentations and exhibitions. Our music classes and club have performed both for the student body and our parent association. Our theater arts class puts on two full-length productions each year, one play and one musical production. Students at Wagner have the opportunity to exceed the minimum required credits for graduation in the arts.

The Goal of the Maspeth High School Fine and Performing Arts Program is to support the school's Mission of Truth, Goodness, and Beauty with High Quality Performing Arts Class Offerings. All students at Maspeth take four years of an Art Form from one of Five Disciplines: Theater, Dance, String Orchestra, Choral, or Visual Art. Class work includes rigorous Arts Making Course offerings and synthesis with Common Core Standards. Students qualify for the Advanced Arts Diploma after completing coursework. Students may participate in after school Arts Clubs and Programming including Ballet, Theater Productions, Orchestra, Choral Concerts, and Visual Art Gallery's. Additionally, Maspeth Arts Department provides Cultural Partnering opportunities with organizations such as Carnegie Hall, The Metropolitan Opera, and Theater Development Fund in support of classroom instruction.

The general arts education program at Queens Vocational consists of project-based learning activities that focus on the five visual arts benchmarks. These benchmarks are: Art Making, Literacy in the Visual Arts, Making Connections through Visual Arts, Community & Cultural Resources, and Careers & Life-long Learning in the Visual Arts. This program allows students to acquire the credits required of all New York City students to graduate from high school. In addition, Queens Vocational has two four-year Career and Technical Education (CTE) programs. These two programs are graphic arts and cosmetology. Graphic arts focuses on preparing students for work in computer graphics. Students develop a visual/design vocabulary, create designs through the use of different media and processes, and engage in design creation and criticism. This program teaches students how to use Adobe Photoshop, Illustrator, InDesign and Acrobat.

Our school has an exciting Arts Program that focuses on introducing students to the keyboard, creating and editing audio and video and using computer based programs to develop uniquely designed drawings. All of our students take a Music course and an Art course.
Q45_1: Our school is a Career and Technical Education public high school in the City of New York that trains all of our students to be FAA certified aircraft technicians. Prospective students have to selectively apply for our school and we screen students based on their seventh grade academic record.
Q46_2: AP Pupil Personnel Services and Music

Q44_1: Our full-time arts teacher provides students with curriculum and instruction that address a range of media and arts concepts. The teacher leads students in a range of outside-of-school trips and internal projects and exhibits which celebrate their work. This year, we expanded our arts programming to include podcasting, theater and music study and production in English classes, French Cinema in our language classes, and guest spoken-word performances during our all-school "town halls."

Q42_R1_C1: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
Q44_1:
Each and every year The 51st Avenue Academy increasingly immersed in the arts.  Our Theatre and Arts program has proven to be extremely fruitful. Students in the 4th and 5th grade have won contests enabling them to get their artwork exhibited at museums such as The Metropolitan Museum of Art, The Queen's Museum and more. Our Engaging theatre program, equips our students to express themselves and learn life's core lessons.

Our school scope is to expose our students to the arts in order for them to find ways of expressing their feelings through integrating all the core subjects. Our school environment is such that all the arts are integrated, including a program after school entitled, Arts and Literacy. The arts engage students in a variety of modalities that enable them to achieve personal and corporate goals in music, visual art, dance, theater, and more. Our students have been exposed to many forms of art that aid in their achievement in core subjects such as literacy, math, social studies, science, and social skills. Thus far, our students have had the privilege of going on many class trips to museums, musical forums, theater and dance institutions which have expanded their experiences and personal vision. The art program at P.S. 877 has exposed students to many art forms, thus enabling them to grow in their personal, physical, mental, emotional and artistic development. Our vibrant arts curriculum plays a large part in our students becoming productive members of society and the global community surrounding them.

The foundation of P.S. 20's arts program is to provide quality arts instruction, assess students in the arts, build teacher capacity in arts instruction, develop partnerships with arts organizations and promote parental involvement in arts education.

P.S. 21 provides a well rounded arts program for all students. Weekly assembly periods are led by teachers who prepare the students for grade wide performances. Our third grade students participate in a comprehensive recorder program where they learn to read music as well as play the instrument. This program gives the students a basic music background before they choose an instrument for our fourth/fifth grade band program. Our arts department has collaborated to produce several showcases throughout the school year, including our school's first musical. Art exhibits are on display throughout the school building. During cycles of enrichment classes, students in grades 1-5 have an opportunity to choose from a wide variety of arts classes throughout the year. Each year our dedication to the arts is further developed through a variety of cultural affiliations. This year we are proud of our partnerships with Ballet Tech, Carnegie Hall, Lincoln Center and Little Kids Rock. All of our arts events are celebrated either grade or school wide in order to give our families the opportunity to celebrate their children's accomplishments.

The PS22 community believes that the Arts are integral to successful learning. Three full time Arts teachers (Music, Visual Art, & Drama), provide our students with a variety of arts experiences. To ensure that every student is involved in the arts, they are scheduled for music, visual arts, and drama a minimum of once every seven days. This seven day cycle allows for the over 800 students to engage in the arts regularly. This year we have had the opportunity to bring in many performers for our students. Assembly programs that have allowed the students to interact with the performers. We also work with a cultural organization within our community to provide our students with Dance. The students in our school perform in a Fall and Spring music and dance concert. There is also an end of the year talent show and drama club performance. All classes are encouraged to organize class trips to the many cultural organizations the city has to offer as additional enrichment for the arts. For the coming school year, we will be looking into partnering with an additional organization for an Arts Partnership Grant. We hope to continue to make the arts an important part of our students lives.

Our goal is to integrate the arts disciplines and Blueprint with the Common Core State Standards in all core content curriculum areas. This will be measured by student performances, projects, journal entries, observations and lesson planning. Our students will explore, be actively engaged in, and will respond critically to the visual, expressive, creative and fine arts. Our classroom teachers design, plan, and implement curriculum using the arts as a vehicle of expression and support to content area work. Our teachers will include working with various media and techniques in the visual arts: Reader's Theater, storytelling and oral presentations, singing through the grades, and creative movement and rhythm for early childhood. Class trips to museums, concerts and theater presentations will be conducted to extend the partnerships with cultural organizations to provide our students the opportunities for scaffolded learning from dynamic teaching artists in music and singing. This year we are also working with the residency: Theatre Moves which works with all of our Kindergarten and 3rd grade students. In addition, we are the recipient of a CASA grant so that our 2nd and 3rd grade students participate in theater activities after-school. We also partner with Brooklyn Conservatory of Music, Create! and ESTA for instruction in music, dance and theater.   Early exposure and integration of the arts into our curriculum will expand our youngest learners' knowledge and enable our children to become more successful in the future

Q37_4: Parents come in to help create scenery for productions.
Q44_1: PS 29's goals for the arts for the year 2016-2017 focused on ensuring that all students had a variety of oppportunities to experience the different aspects of the Arts throughout the year. Teachers immersed themselves in professional learning and practice around growth specifically in the area of assessment. Through the use of rubrics, checklists, the collection of observational data and analysis teachers and students reflected on what was learned and created next steps to enhance their teaching practices and performances. This year teachers have utilized technology such as video tapping to encourage and support their students to be reflective of their practice and identify areas of strength and next step through various evaluation tools. As well, teachers have been expanding the use of technology to include using the i-Pads for research and animation purposes. These skills are then put into action through live performances. Each child in grades 2-5 put on a production that intergrates theatre, music, dance and art. Twice a year there is an Arts Showcase where teachers collaborate for an evening of the Arts. In collaboration with the PTA every third grade student recieved their own individual recorder. After mastering the skills on how to identify notes, correct fingering and song patterns the third grade students then put on a recorder concert for their families. All fourth and fifth grade students also have the opportunities to try out for our PS 29 Chorus and Dance Company. These groups perform in different
Q45_1: capacities throughout the year. As well, the arts teachers invite our parents into the building for workshops around the Arts, to assist in creating scenary for productions and to participate in performances.  To further extend our In-School Arts program we have welcomed in outside organizations to work with our students. These organizations include; dancing classrooms, QTELL, Poppenhusen and Ballet Tech. As well, PS 29 works to make meaningful outside connections for our students and this year had the opportunity to take the fourth grade classes to see Phantom of the Opera on Broadway. Lastly, PS 29 has been granted a new dance studio, and an upcoming project to enhance and upgrade our Auditorium sound and lighting systems. Looking forward into the 2017-2018 school year we are motivated to continue strengthing our Arts practices within our building. We are striving to cultivate a learning environment where all students have the opportunity to express themselves in whatever aspect of the Arts resignates with them. We will continue to deepen our work around using various resources and technology to enhance our work and make meaningful connections with our students.

Q44_1: We recognize that the study of art enriches students' learning and enriches their lives. Our program enhances students' abilities to express themselves creatively by offering opportunities to participate in a comprehensive integrated arts education. This includes experiences in school, as well as experiences in the community and New York City in general. Our program enables our children to reach the NYS learning standards in the arts. The goals of the program are that children are actively engaged in creating, performing and participating in the arts, make use of available materials and resources, respond thoughtfully to a variety of works, and understand the cultural contributions of the arts

PS 79Q serves 1,086 pre-kindergarten through grade 5 students. We have a vast in-house arts program which includes three full time performing arts specialists, one each in dance, music, and theater, plus one visual arts certified specialist. In addition to classroom arts instruction, students are provided with instruction from Cultural Arts Organizations. Dancing Classrooms offers our fifth and fourth graders a residency in ballroom dancing. The Metropolitan Opera Guild at Lincoln Center offers our third and second graders a residency in Urban Voices. Marquis Studio offers our kindergarten and first grade students a residency in drumming and mask making. In addition our fifth grade students participated in a residency through Lincoln Center in investigating patterns and printmaking.

We provide a child-centered arts enriched environment for every student. We partner with arts organizations and cultural institutions. Our arts program includes the visual arts, vocal and instrumental music, dance, and theater/drama. In our Art Studio students use their imagination and problem-solving skills. They learn about famous artists, different art media, colors, value, line, texture, and composition. Children learn to play the electronic keyboard. Parents are invited to school-wide multicultural events, recitals, holiday performances, publishing celebrations, etc., and are active participants in our community 'art-reach' events. Our Glee Clubs are the centerpiece of our musical program. Weekly assembly programs highlight the drama, dancing, singing, and visual arts skills of each class. Student dancers perform at many events. Music in the Air, a tradition for over 40 years, is a community event. It is a 4-night event where every student performs.

PS 120 has an Instrumental Music Program as well as instruction from a licensed visual arts teacher. Students in grades P-K and K also receive music and arts instruction four times a week. Grade three students learn how to play the recorder and present a culminating concert in June. Various classes in grades four and five are part of our school band and perform in June for their families. PS 120 students take part in a variety of art residencies. We have storytelling, Indian Dance, Inside Broadway, Making Books Sing and the NY Philharmonic. Teaching artists work with all of our children in grades Pre-k through 5. These residencies end with a celebration that our parents are invited to. We are proud that every single student is exposed to the arts. Many of our children have grown socially and emotionally through these programs. In addition, the arts have increased our students' language acquisition as well as supported their writing skills. We hope to continue these successes.

P.S. 129 has always been, and continues to be, an advocate for the arts.  Over the past several years we have added a full time drama teacher so that we now have all arts disciplines in our school. Our goal is to hire more full time arts teachers to service our students, but we continue to struggle to find the money to support this effort.  
We plan to continue our very successful relationship with Dancing Classrooms.  The program has become an integral part of the fifth grade experience.
It is our hope that we will be able to expand our arts offerings next year.

Q43_10: Teachers collaborated with instructors and worked alongside students There was no direct rubric/assessment associated with this
Q44_1: We believe that instruction in the arts is essential in providing a well-rounded curriculum for our students. Since children learn in different ways, it is essential to support their learning styles and intelligences using various methods. We have found that the arts can make the difference between a child's success or failure in school. Our goal continues to expose our young learners to multiple forms of art so they may experiment and find those that interest them. We continue to expand on these experiences for our young learners and look forward to growing this initiative by  partnering with more organizations and providing our students with more enrichment program opportunities.

Our aim at P.S. 163 is to develop students academically, artistically and socially so that they leave this school as independent, cooperative, responsible and creative children with a lifelong interest in the arts. Our visual arts program benefits students in many ways. Beyond the tremendous value of learning artistic expression, they learn to visualize and complete creative projects. Through our arts education residencies, which include Indian Dance, Luann Adams Story Telling, and the Inside Broadway Theater Company, the students are making connections between visual art concepts and other curriculum areas. Our Indian dance residency taught the students the traditions and culture of South Asia. Through our story telling residency, our students were exposed to folktales and fables through a theatrical approach. Inside Broadway allowed the students to feel the background experience of preparing for a Broadway play. Each of these residencies also included performances that families attended to reinforce the love of the arts at home. We believe that this exposure will prepare our students to purse goals in arts education and allow them to be well rounded citizens that will contribute to the life and well being of society as a whole.

PS/MS 164 offers all inclusive opportunities in arts education. We offer established programs in visual arts, theater, dance, moving image/video arts. Additionally, this school year we were again able to offer vocal music to our students. All students receive a comprehensive arts education which begins in pre-kindergarten and continues through eighth grade. We are committed to the philosophy that the arts provide vehicles for strengthening basic skills, heightening language development, academic motivation and achievement. The arts allow a wide range of students the opportunity to experience success and develop a feeling of self worth.

The goal of arts instruction at PS 165Q is to engage every student in expressive arts-making activities. Our accelerated arts programs provide numerous opportunities for students to achieve artistic excellence. Curricula in dance, vocal music, visual art, band and string orchestra are based upon the Common Core State Standards and are aligned with the NYC Blueprints for the Arts, Pre-K-12. All students in Grades K- 5 receive arts instruction, as well as opportunities to participate in formal and informal performances. Music, Dance, and Visual Art are differentiated, according to their respective learners in a variety of class settings, including ASD Nest, Integrated Co-teaching, Self-Contained Special Education, General Education, and Gifted and Talented. Music, Visual Art and Dance programs offer sequential multi-year instruction for all students, as well as an accelerated performance program for students in the PS 165Q Gifted and Talented Program. The school community's strong tradition of a dedicated commitment to the arts and supportive family involvement nurtures the education of the whole child.

The P.S. 184Q arts program includes visual arts for all students in grades PreK-5 and dance for all students in grades K-5. This year we continued our Dancing Classrooms Ballroom Dance residency for our fifth grade students and they loved learning how to rumba, tango, swing dance and more! Grades K-4 students reaped the benefits of a City Center Artist in Residency dance program. Students learned about the basics of movement and space and were given the opportunity to work together to create their own dances using various parts of the curriculum as inspiration. All students in grades PreK-5 also received weekly visual arts instruction aligned to the Blueprint for the Arts. Projects are designed to build on student interests and skill level. All of our students are provided with opportunities to share their artistic pieces with the community on a regular basis. We believe that the academic performance and overall success of our students is enhanced by the presence of the arts. The dance, music, and art instruction is tied to content area learning, thus reinforcing academic knowledge. It also enhances both fine and gross motor skills and coordination. It also builds a sense of confidence and provides students with knowledge specific to the art forms.
Q45_1: Being a small school with a small budget, we are fortunate that some of our arts funding can be fulfilled through our PTA and fundraising throughout the year.

Q44_1: Daniel Carter Beard Junior High School 189 has a comprehensive arts education program that provides students with opportunities to employ literacy in visual art, music, and theater that are aligned with the New York State Learning Standards. Students actively participate in skills-based instruction in the arts and develop connections between the arts and the core curriculum. Within the arts program, students receive direct instruction in visual arts, choral music, and theater, including musical theater. Students are also exposed to instruction in the arts through residencies provided by local cultural organizations. Our goal is to continue the comprehensive art program allowing students to further develop their skills in visual arts, vocal music, and in theater based projects, including musical theater.

Students at PS 193 have the opportunity to experience the arts in a variety of settings. The art and music program afford children the freedom to explore various media supported with classroom instruction. Through our partnership with City Center, our students participated in a dance residency based on the work of Alvin Ailey. This residency culminates in shared sessions to which parents are invited. NYC Children's Theater allow children to explore children's literature and create their own dramatic play. Students participate in singing, dancing, and theater with Inside Broadway which is funded by City Council.  The culminating performance will be shared with the entire school.  Selected grades participate in Enrichment Clubs of their choice involving the arts.  PS 193 has received several grants that have enriched our school community.

Q37_4: Chaperones to arts events outside of school
Q44_1: JHS 194 offers arts education to every one of our 1100 students. Arts offerings include dance and an after-school dance team, instrumental music (concert and jazz bands), fine art, drama, film & media, photography, and debate/public speaking. All students are given an opportunity to select an art form and pursue it for a calendar year; in grade six, students have two choices per year. For instrumental music, students are encouraged to participate for a three year program, each year building on the skills of the previous year. Twice yearly, students have an opportunity to showcase their work through film festivals, dance shows, theater productions, art galleries, and concerts. This year we have partnered with arts organizations including Flushing Town Hall, Jazz @Lincoln Center, City Center, and Magic Box Productions that provide additional enrichment for our students. Our belief is that our diversified arts program promotes engagement and enhances the rigorous learning for all our students.

We have continued to provide arts instruction in a variety of ways. This was our second year in the Middle School Arts Matter grant. Middle school students engaged in Music instruction throughout the year. We also aimed to program Visual Arts in a manner that allowed for a class to have multiple Art classes per week, rather than just once per week. Along with Music and Art, our students have Drama, in which they learn about acting, improvisation, and stagecraft. In order to supplement arts education, we partnered with Together in Dance. They engaged in long-term cultural movement residencies with grades 2 and 3 and musical theater residencies with grades 4 and 5. Through support from our local Council Member, we were also able to offer violin instruction to students in grade 4 after school with Midori & Friends, and several students participated in a ten-week dance program at Queens Performing Arts Center. For the first time, we programmed two semesters of enrichment electives for middle school students. Several enrichment themes are arts-based, including: storytelling, photography and media, developing an art portfolio in preparation for applying to high school, film study, and comedic improvisation. Students in grades 6-8 are assigned one of their top enrichment choices each semester. We have now begun our transition to becoming a magnet school with the theme of global studies and leadership. Thematic arts education will characterize much of our curriculum and we will expand our arts partnerships to support our students.

Kappa Vi offers a comprehensive arts program which focuses in the dramatic arts and instrumental music. All cadets receive both of the these classes, biannually, for their three years at Kappa Vi. We believe in sequential, experiential learning. Students, or cadets, are encouraged by their teachers to engage themselves throughout this curriculum to ensure for a well-rounded education and aid to core-curriculum classes. 

Drama at Kappa Vi focuses on specific areas. These areas are: creating original student compositions, creating parodies/satires, folklore play-ons, as well as analyzing how art imitates life. Students participate in a large production at the end of each semester where all of these art-forms are highlighted. For all three years, students are broken into groups, where they create and  perform on a daily basis.  

Instrumental music at Kappa Vi allows for students to actively participate in a concert band setting. In the 6th grade, students have the choice of picking their own instrument, learning the responsibilities that pertain, and the responsibility of mastering the basics. With these understandings, students participate in musical units revolving around both conflict, love, and motivation. One of the most important aspects of this sequence is how interdisciplinary instruction aids in both musical instruction/learning, as well as their core classes of ELA, Math, Science and Social Studies. Students of all grades perform at the end of semester concert to show the growth they have made in these areas.
Q45_1: Kappa Vi is a preparatory middle school which focuses on preparing students for high school, college, and the future. While being a Title-One school, Kappa Vi doesn’t spare any expense in providing worthwhile resources for its students. Instrumentally, Kappa Vi has acquired most of their instruments by donation. With this being said, administration and the teachers, make it the highest priority that every student has an instrument to actively participate. This year, students will be enhancing their dramatic performances with body microphones to amplify their great work. Much of the arts education at Kappa is experiential. As previously noted, Kappa infuses interdisciplinary content in all classrooms. In partnership with the workshop model, students/cadets experience consistency and rigor throughout their school day.

Q44_1: Every student in PS 201 is provided access to performing arts. Through creative and strategic use of resources the school has one full time certified music teacher, and one full time certified dance teacher. Every student is afforded the opportunity to learn keyboarding, create art and learn via dancing and movement. Through collaboration between PS 201 and the Music and the Brain grant student learn music literacy and appreciate through piano keyboard.  American Ballroom Dancing Company further develops music and dance appreciation for students in fourth grade, completing twenty sessions of ballroom dancing that culminate with an assembly for the community and a group of 4th graders attending a local competition. PS 201 has a collaboration with a CBO the Chinese Advantage.  PS 201 offers students additional after school programs to enrich students: Lion King World, and Sing Me A Story.  PreKindergarten classroom have collaborated with a visiting artist from Materials for the Arts.

Our goal is to provide students with a meaningful and well-rounded arts based curriculum. Each student participates in a production which is presented to family. This insures that all students have an opportunity to dance and perform for an audience. We have a full time visual arts teacher who implements lessons that integrate various content areas.
