We have a full time Music teacher who services every class in the school.  We have a grade 4 chorus, a grade 5 chorus and a school band who meet with her weekly. Students in grade 3 learn about and play bucket drumming and in grades 4-5 they learn how to play recorders. For a sixth year we have our CCAST (Cadwallader Colden After School Theater) program. This program allows us to perform a annual musical theater production. This year we performed The Jungle Book Kids. Approximately 80 students (performers, art/set design and stage crew) were provided with a 20 week after school program and are involved in this full scale production which was presented to family, friends and the community in the spring. This performance assists us in sustaining the CCAST program for the following year. This year 30 of our grade two students participated in a CASA grant sponsored by our Councilman's office.  The students met for 20 2.5 hour sessions with a resident from Flushing Town hall and learned Chinese Dance.  The program will culminate with a performance in June.  
We will continue to utilize all available resources for a continued comprehensive arts education program.

Arts instruction in theater, music and/or art, are provided by both classroom teachers and by the art and music teachers. Students also receive arts experiences by participating in events at Queens College, Lincoln Center, The Guggenheim and The Metropolitan Museums of Art, and Ballet Tech and more. We also host Ballroom Dancing for select grades! We are especially excited about continuing the K-8 music and instrumental programs, including adding creating a full time music position for middle school Band. We have begun to expand our instrumental and choral programs, including a new beginner Band/Orchestra with small group lesson instruction for grades 4-6, choral ensemble opportunities for the same grade levels, and Little Kids Rock modern band instruction for students from elementary to lower middle school. In grades 7 and 8, Band is a full time subject. Music at PS/MS 219 is inclusive and differentiated for our student population in opportunities, instruments and ensembles. The addition of an elementary school Visual Art teacher ensures that every student in grades Pre-K to 8 receives arts instruction weekly.  We are also proud of our Early Childhood Program where we seamlessly integrate literacy into visual arts, drama, music and movement. Throughout the school, we incorporate movement into everyday academic activities through Move to Improve and Activity Works. For the 2017-2018 school year, we would like to expand our ensemble curricula and bring more performance opportunities for our students in and outside of school.
Q45_1: Part of our school's philosophy of education is social justice and positive behavior supports. Our programming reflects that. The school wide program shows two disciplines of arts for every homeroom, in every week of the school year. We are a Nest and Horizon school.

Q44_1: We strongly believe students involved in the arts make gains in math, reading, cognitive ability, critical thinking, and verbal skills. Our school's theme is "The Arts", therefore careful attention is given to planning lessons and projects to ensure that our magnet theme continues to flourish. We are fortunate to offer our students both performing and visual arts classes during the school day as well as an extensive after-school talent enrichment program

Veritas Academy is a high school which opened in September of 2013. We are a small school which is committed to finding the gifts and talents of all school in keeping with our Renzulli Schoolwide Enrichment Model. Veritas has on staff 1 full-time music and, as of this school year, 1 full-time visual arts teacher. We offer students various music courses as well as arts electives in Latin Dance and Film Study. Veritas also offers an extracurricular modern dance club. We look forward to expanding our arts course offerings in the future.

QHSLS is a small high school committed to providing opportunities in the arts for our students. We currently offer a theater class to 9th graders and visual arts to 10th and 11th graders. 12th graders can elect into an advanced visual arts or theater class. In addition, we have a weekly after school Music Club, Photography Club and Improv Club.

P.S.242 actively engages students in creating art in all media and exploring the expressive arts in musical theater, dance, and the visual arts. We make school-based connections by reading aloud to our young students about artists and their lives, discussing art as lifelong learners, and integrating the arts into all curricula areas.  We provide students with cultural and historical background through monthly on- and off-site professional performances and trips to museums and cultural institutions. Our strong and ongoing partnership with musical theater teaching artist Alastair King provides students and teachers with the opportunity to develop as musical theater artists and performers culminating in a gala musical theatre production on each grade each year. In addition our partnership with Studio-In-A-School provides rich opportunities for students and staff to create and display in the visual arts through their work with on-site teaching artists culminating in grade level art shows for families twice each year. Our collaboration with Cultural After School Adventures (CASA) provides enrichment through a grant funded after school arts program for our grade two students which culminates with a professional exhibition of student artwork at The Godwin-Ternbach Museum at Queens College CUNY.  In these ways we support students, families, and staff members in appreciating the arts and living artistic lives!

TALES continues to integrate the arts into all curriculum areas in the school. Specifically, TALES is viewing the arts as a way to enrich the language acquisition process for its many English language learner students. The school has partnered with Music for Many to provide enhanced music instruction for its Pre-K students, as well as to provide professional development for classroom teachers. Music is used on a daily basis in every classroom as an important instructional tool for the school's young learners. We also have an ESL teacher who teaches language through the mode of music. In addition, we contracted with Studio in a School this year to provide visual arts instruction to our Kindergarten, 1st and 2nd grade students. We also began a relationship with Private Picasso for 3rd grade this year. TALES hopes to continue offering specialized arts instruction in order to provide students with a rich, child-centered curriculum that promotes language development and a love for the arts.

The arts program at The Robert F. Kennedy Magnet School of Community Studies includes a general and vocal music program for all of our students. Our school has a show choir and a recorder ensemble that performs both in school and "on the road". Students have the opportunity to take class and grade trips that expose them to music, dance and theater. In addition, 8th graders have an opportunity to take a visual arts course.

Queens School of Inquiry is a 6-12 Early College Initiative School. All middle school students receive instruction in art,music, and theater. Students learn the basics in drawing, painting, art history and art criticism in 6th and 7th grade. In music, all students gain basic knowledge in reading and composing music and all students learn to play the recorder and violin/viola in 6th and 7th grade. In theater, all 8th grade students take the Introduction to Musical Theatre course. When students enter high school, every freshman student is scheduled for Acting I & II. Opportunities are extended to students who wish to enroll in advanced level drama courses, college art courses and/or high school art/music electives. Outside of the school day, QSI offers MS Musical, art club and SING!. The mission of the Queen's School of Inquiry Arts Department is to foster a passion and dedication for the Visual, Musical, and Theatrical Arts. We want our students to become collaborative creators of culture and change through the various artistic disciplines while exploring their identity. Beginning in 6th grade and continuing until 12th grade, students are exposed to many aspects of the arts including: acting, analysis, criticism, dance, design, directing, music, playwriting, history, research, and visual arts. The QSI Arts Department is expanding in the 2017-2018 school year. Our current 10th grade students will have the ability to receive an advanced arts diploma designated in theater if they fulfill 10 credits in theater related coursework.

Arts are an integral part of our students' educational experience at the Flushing International HS. All of our students take classes in visual arts, media arts, and drama in each of their four years at FIHS. Students also have multiple opportunities to perform and share their work with members of the larger school community.

Q42_R1_C1: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
Q44_1: P.S./I.S. 499 continues to cultivate an intensive arts education program involving the entire school community. The visual arts teacher follows a curriculum as detailed by the Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts. Planned lessons are thematic and rigorous, as well as standard and content based. Students are encouraged to appreciate and understand how art can become a vehicle for expressing ideas, exploring new experiences and igniting the imagination. Supplementing our art program is our partnership with Lincoln Center. We are a Lincoln Center Education Focus School and as such we boost the study and appreciation for various art forms: visual arts and dance. We infuse aesthetic education philosophies and methodologies throughout our curriculum. Queens College supports our involvement with LCE and our music program.

East-West has full-time dance, music and art teachers. Students will be introduced to the elements of music programs, beginning guitar instruction, web based instruction and listening assignments. Our dance course will address the five strands of the Dance Blueprint; Dance Making, Developing Dance Literacy, Making Connections, Working with Community and Cultural Resources and Exploring Careers and Lifelong Learning. The art department will have students working with many projects, exploring various artists and learning various art techniques. The goal is that by the end of the school year every student will love the arts and mature into a creative individual.

Q45_1: We have hired an visual art teacher for 2017-2018 through the ATR incentive.

Q44_1: Flushing High School has a robust and growing arts program in three major arts disciplines: music, visual art, and theater. Students may enroll in a variety of arts classes. Modern band students learn popular music through keyboard, percussion, and guitar, culminating in two major performances. Piano classes are tailored to student ability, which means beginners can learn simple rhythms and advanced students can tackle complex pieces for performance. Choral students learn and perform classical and contemporary pieces while being introduced to music theory. Visual arts students engage in drawing, painting, digital media, and multimedia. Theater students learn acting, playwriting, design, and directing by producing both published and self-written works.
Q45_1: There is a great need for supplies and resources to support ELL and special education students.  It would also be useful to access a FAMIS vendor list so that art teachers know where they can order specialty supplies for their studios.

Q44_1: At Townsend Harris High School at Queens College, creative and performing arts are central to the humanities mission. All students are encouraged to explore artistic interests and talents. Our goals in the Fine Arts Department are to empower students as they begin to define themselves artistically; to expose them to a wide range of new techniques and media; to challenge them to strengthen artistic techniques and critical thinking skills and to make the arts relevant both as a future career and as personal enrichment. The department sponsors a variety of extra-curricular activities and enables students to learn from practicing artists and to earn college credit through our partnership with Queens College.

Q45_1: The school is presently seeking an Arts organization to partner with.

Q44_1:
Robert F. Kennedy Community High School offers students a variety of fine arts experiences including: Studio Art, Advanced Drawing and Painting, Digital Photography, Computer Assisted Design and Digital Animation. In addition, we have a long history of working with the Theater Development Fund which provides our English classes with an artist in residence and live theater experiences. This year, we participated in EduHam, the program that involves NYC public high school students with creating their own performances based on "Hamilton" and then presenting these on stage at the Richard Rogers theater before attending the musical itself. 
In the 2017-2018 school year, we plan to offer AP Studio Art for the first time.

The Susan B. Anthony Academy Arts Program provides vigorous arts learning in visual arts, instrumental music, general music, chorus, dance and digital art through photography and technology. Students are given opportunities to participate in various performances and attend trips to art institutions and exhibits during the school year. Our school’s vision is to provide a quality arts program which follows the New York City Blueprint for the Arts and alignment to the Common Core State Standards. Teacher teams share best practices and incorporate storytelling, history, and technology through the different arts forums.  Teachers in the arts department collaborate with their colleagues from other departments to make the arts disciplines an integral and visible part of our school culture.

We continue to find it a challenge to provide our students with a richer arts experience during their short stay of 18 to 24 months with us. Budgetary constraints and limited opportunities to obtain grants have made it difficult for us to enrich our program.  Despite these barriers, through the use of our full-time art position, we have managed to work with our students to meet NYS Arts graduation requirements during the school year.
Q45_1: We are a small, ungraded, Transfer High School with an enrollment of 200 students using 9 classrooms and housed in a renovated parochial school building. Our student population consists of 38% Blacks, 37% Hispanics, 11% Whites, and 12% Asians. 79% of our students are overage/under-credited.

Q44_1: PS98Q provides varied art form instruction to all students. Music is the primary art form students receive throughout the year, spanning instruction from general music to reading music, playing instruments (recorder,guitar,keyboard)and culminating in a 5th grade seminar on music history and the science of music. Kindergarten through third grade students learn stage presence & performance as part of music class and participate in an annual Spring Concert. A chorus, selected by audition,rehearses weekly and performs a culminating concert in the Spring. In addition, our 4th and 5th grades were introduced to Ballroom Dancing this year. PTA funding supplements Arts programming that includes theater performances, Midori workshops & concerts, and a visual arts residency. A CASA grant has allowed the school to offer a partnerhsip with Midori & Friends with after school programming in drumming and vocal training. Students who paticipate in the after school workshops perform in concerts with the artists. This year, PS98 began offering an after school program that includes instruction in visual art, theater and music for students interested in going beyond what is offered during the school day. A school-wide vocabulary enrichment initiative has been enhanced by original songs written to incorporate themed "words of the month". The Arts instruction at PS 98 is integrated with other curricular areas such as literacy, social studies, science, math and technology.

The arts program at P.S.18 is driven by thoughtful, robust and sequential instruction guided by the NYC Department of Education Blueprint for the Arts. Using backwards planning and inquiry-based lessons, creative exploration and expression, students create art to make social, cultural and academic connections to engage in learning beyond the classroom. Students at P.S. 18 are encouraged to share in each others diversity, celebrate their individuality, and become life-long learners and visual interpreters. We strive to make the arts an integral part of providing a well-rounded education to all our students.

PS. 26 continues to grow our Arts Program in many ways. We continue to promote art through creative means of theater, visual arts, music, and digital programs. We have increased the number of Promethean boards to support our Arts program. This allows our teachers to use technological means to support the facilitation of specific art lessons. Our teachers continue to search for innovative ways to expand our students’ creativity, expression, and artistic abilities. The most important aspect of PS 26 is providing our students the tools to assist one another in their artistic endeavors.

PS 31 is a school that is dedicated to providing an enriching arts program to its students. Our music program includes a full time music teacher. We perform Winter and Spring Concerts. We employ a full-time visual arts teacher who works with each class on incorporating a variety of mediums into student art. We also have a Winter and Spring Art Show. PS 31 also consists of an outstanding drama club which meets after school from January through June culminating in a final performance for our community at large in June. Our fifth graders are part of a ballroom dance arts residency in which the culminating activity is a performance for their parents. Twelve students are chosen to take part in the Colors of the Rainbow ballroom dance competition against other schools around the city.

Our school's vocal music program encourages students to participate in an interactive learning experience that promotes self-expression. Students develop an understanding and appreciation of music literacy which supports and enhances the Common Core State Standards. Our music program is defined by students' innate and natural ability as well as interest. We believe that all students not only benefit from a quality music program, but that it also enhances their daily learning encounters. Students enjoy the benefits of a vocal music program that promotes musicality, theory, and performance. Students in kindergarten through fifth grade learn through units of study aligned to the NYC Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in Music.

At PS 46Q, we value the importance of the arts for all of our students. We offer a multifaceted and comprehensive set of experiences in the arts through their integration in all subject areas. The school is decorated with student created art masterpieces. The performing arts are highlighted by the winter and spring concerts. Choral instruction is provided to all students in both lower and upper grades. Children receive a variety of instrumental music instruction with band instruments including piano, string instruments, keyboarding, percussion electric guital and acoustic guitar. Additionally, all third grade students receive recorder instruction. Dance instruction is given to all 5th graders and is also offered to the rest of our student population through various whole class and pull-out activities. Musical Theater is offered to all the students at PS 46Q and each class puts on a musical theater production. Additionally, we seek to provide our teachers with professional development during our arts cycles with teaching artists.
We offer a variety of studio art and music programming to challenge our students.  We look for opportunities for our students to authentically engage with the public as artists.

We feel that a school without its musicians, actors, singers, artists, and story tellers is a school without a voice. Thus, our vibrant arts are a reflection of our school culture - engaging, diversified, and with a strong student voice where students help to drive their own learning. One of the most celebrated school events is the performance of an annual musical. It is a culminating event where the entire community enjoys an evening at the theater supporting our students and the Arts at MS67Q.

Nathaniel Hawthorne Middle School 74 provides rigorous arts learning in all four arts forums. As part of our individualized approach, during the 2016-2017 school year, our students were provided with individual choice. The students could choose from instrumental music, vocal music, graphic art & design, studio art, theatre, or the moving image. We continue to provide additional arts learning through our collaborations with World Dance Theatre (Cultural Dance Project), Arts Horizons, Jose Limon Dance Company, Jazz at Lincoln Center, and the New York Historical Society. Our Dance program was part of Arts Achieve over a six-year period. The Arts Achieve work created a foundation for our teachers and students to learn how to use peer and self-assessment to drive instruction. Our teacher team has shared these best practices, and this approach has been shared across the arts department. Two of our arts teachers were facilitators this year during "Arts Monday" professional development, and three of our other arts teachers participated in these professional development opportunities. Their work and research focused on utilizing different types of formative assessment in order to guide instruction. These conversations were a continuation of the Arts Achieve work that was started in our Dance program.

The arts program is designed to teach students creativity and introduce as well as continue to expose the children to a variety of art materials corresponding to the New York City Art Standards and The Blueprint for the Visual and Musical Arts. Each grade has its own curriculum and challenging projects that often relate to what they are learning with the classroom teacher. The children are exposed to many different techniques in Art and Music. In addition, there is an emphasis on formative assessments (both peer and self) as well as summative assessments where the children have time to reflect on their projects.

At The James J. Ambrose School we believe that instruction in the arts is essential in providing a well-rounded curriculum for our students.   It is important to include opportunities for students to grow their abilities in other areas such as dance, music, performing, and visual arts.  Providing students with other avenues to excel is critical, as it allows students to experiment and find new interests and allows them to showcase their talents in many different ways. Our goal is to continuously provide multiple opportunities for students to engage in these areas.  We hope that this exposure leads to a lifelong love and appreciation for learning about the arts.

At the Curious Young Learners Pre-K center, we believe curiosity leads the children down new paths. At the cornerstone of our school is our arts program. Children are naturally creative and derive much pleasure from involvement in the arts. They learn a host of skills and acquire tremendous self-esteem when given varied opportunities to create. Because we consider art such an integral part of our program, our children are provided with open-ended opportunities to create. Our children use a wide array of art media including acrylic, finger, and water paints, pastels, crayons, and markers. In addition, children are given the opportunity to express themselves through drawings, sculptures, models, and paintings. 
We celebrate our children’s creativity by prominently and artfully displaying their work throughout our preschool sweet. Because we believe the artistic process to be even more valuable than the final product, we accompany each work with a transcription of the child’s thoughts about the piece along with pictures of the process.
The children participate with increasing interest and enjoyment in a variety of music activities including listening to music, singing songs, performing finger plays and experimenting with various musical instruments. We encourage the children by creating sounds using traditional instruments like bells, drums, and recorders. In addition, the children use some non-traditional instruments that we make out of tin cans, oatmeal boxes and cardboard containers. Singing songs, making up silly and rhym
Q45_1: We are a Pre-K center and serve 4 and 5 year old children.

Q44_1: Our overall goal is to incorporate visual arts, music and dance into everyday learning and provide all students with opportunities to participate in a variety of arts activities. This is accomplished through dedicated periods of instruction provided by our classroom and visual arts teachers, programs involving cultural organizations, artist residencies and field trips. Our philosophy is that the arts are essential to building critical thinking skills, creative and effective problem solving, effective communication and teamwork. For these reasons, instruction and appreciation for the arts are infused in all areas of the curriculum by teachers and support personnel. Art is a universal language and our goal is for each member of our school community to realize the importance of the arts in the development of a well balanced educational program and lifelong learning.

Our arts program is an integral part of achieving our school's mission to prepare students to exhibit their competence as critical thinkers and creative individuals. Our learners will take responsibility and ownership of their learning to successfully contribute as a productive member of society. Without the arts in our school, we would not be able to help develop the whole child. We have incorporated interdisciplinary projects which help our students to excel in school and beyond. Many of our students go on to showcasing their talents in various venues. Throughout the school year our students perform or have their works displayed in places such as Queens College, The Metropolitan Museum of Art, American Ballet Theatre Company, as well as the Little Neck/Douglaston Memorial Day Parade just to name a few places. The collaboration provided by in-residence teaching artists allow the students to learn additional information and provide experiences that they might not have in another school. Many of our students have a passion for the arts and want to continue their journey in high school, many of which are accepted into specialized high schools based on their performance in the arts. The arts at Marie Curie help provide students a place for their creative side to come alive. We were pleased to continue providing our students with choices in the following art programs: dance, vocal, orchestra, and visual art and look forward to offering as many experiences with the arts as we can in the future.

The students at PS 159Q are exposed to all areas of the arts- theater, music, dance and visual arts, with their classroom teachers each day. In between class changes, teachers incorporate "Go Noodle" activities which involve song and dance routines. Students have performed the dances they learned for the families and students during the school day and at evening PTA meetings. During routine activities, teachers incorporate song to manage student behavior and transition between activities. In addition to the activities that classroom teachers incorporate in their instruction, we have a full-time licensed visual arts teacher who provides instruction in the arts about artists, time periods of art movements and connections between the content areas and the art work students are learning. Students in grade 4 & 5 participate in a specialized Art Club, where students create art portfolios. Our full-time music teacher has designed a program that teaches students about song, reading sheet music, and to play instruments including the keyboard, drums, guitar, electric guitar, and recorder. We have a chorus & band program that performs a concert each year. Each class in our school goes on a minimum of 3 class trips per year. Of those trips, classes visit museums and theatrical performances. This school year we received a CASA grant and worked with CUNY Creative Arts program to provide theater instruction to our 1st & 2nd graders.  In addition, our PTA has provided our students with enriching assembly programs.

We are grateful to the PTA and council representatives who monetarily support a great number of our arts programs with visual arts/theatre in Grades K-4 in conjunction with the Early Stages Program and Grade 5 with the Ballroom Dancing program. The Ballroom Dancing residency takes place in the Fall for the 5th graders with a culminating day/evening performance for students and parents. These programs help with our efforts to promote building upon multiple intelligences for all our students, which is the essence of our mission statement

Q42_R1_C1: Learning through an Expanded Arts Program
Q44_1: Irwin Altman Middle School 172 is committed to providing our students with a quality arts education and assuring that we are following our mission to "make this school the educational center of this community" which is culturally and artistically diverse. The Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts has provided a guide for our curriculum development in visual arts, vocal and instrumental music and theatre production; similarly in Digital Film/ Computer Coding we have followed the Common Core 6-8 Literacy in Science and Technology Subjects Standards to supplement our curriculum focused on Computer Science for All and computer fluency for creating digital media products.

We have three major goals in developing the arts at our school. We plan to continue to train classroom teachers to incorporate more arts learning into the content areas. We intend to continue to increase students' awareness and appreciation of the arts. We also intend to increase parent involvement and increase outside partnerships in the arts.

Q37_4: Parent engagement workshops designed for deepening understanding of  the arts and working with their children
Q44_1:
PS/IS 178Q offers arts programs in the following areas: Music,Visual Arts, Moving Image (Digital Media/Technology) and Dance. Additionally, we are partners with the prestigious Young People's Chorus of New York City, offering a choral program for students in grades 3-8. We have a successful fifth grade ballroom dance program in partnership with Dancing Classrooms. We have a long standing partnership with the Jewish Museum made possible through CASA and our local Congressman. We also have partnered with Arts Matters in order to provide a robust curriculum of music instruction for all our students across grades K-8.

This year our students have bridged learning across grades and disciplines and created workshops and presentations for the community in our efforts to expand programming and highlight the arts by creating new learning experiences for all.  We utilized digital portfolios in the arts and piloted digital assessment software to incorporate 21st century technology for college and career readiness. We have received multiple grants made possible through arts teacher initiatives to continue to support the need to update our studio spaces.  Our graduating students have gained acceptance into specialized high schools such as LaGuardia, Stuyvesant, Bronx Science, Brooklyn Tech, Queens High School for the Sciences at York College and Townsend Harris.

At PS 186Q, we follow a balanced arts program that aligns with the Blueprint for the Arts. Our visual arts program introduces mentor artists and studies their work to teach elements of art and principles of design. Students are exposed to various media and interdisciplinary approaches. Examples of student work are displayed throughout the school building all year long. Our music program provides all students with "Core Music" classes, as well as opportunities for high-interest students to participate in in enrichment groups including chorus, guitar, and percussion ensembles. Through singing, playing instruments, movement, listening to music, performance, and various other activities, instruction is aimed at building music literacy and expressive skills that will aid them in becoming better musicians and consumers of music. Through theater activities, students learn the value of literary, oral and cultural traditions. They learn to express themselves, develop empathy for their own and other's situations and greater self- confidence.

By June 2017, pre-K-5 students will have connected the arts to personal experience, community and society through developing dance, music, visual arts, and theater literacy as measured by the New York City Blueprint for the Arts – Teaching and Learning in the Theater benchmarks

Each class receives vocal, music and art instruction during the week and after school by our certified teachers.Talented grade 3-5 students are in the chorus and present three concerts per year. Students audition, practice and perform each year in our Mayflower Idol show . Every class produces an art, musical or dance production celebrating historical events, cultural events, curriculum units, holiday celebrations or book reviews. Using after school PTA and parent funding, our staff offers various art programs in dance, computer graphics, CODE, arts and crafts and many others. Students and parents look forward to many annual events where the children perform: Thanksgiving Day, Grandparent's Day, International Day, Chinese Festival, Colonial/Historical Fair, Carnival Dance Show, Mayflower Idol and our spring and winter concerts. This year Senator Avella provided state funding for a City Center Flamenco Dance Program during the school day for 12 weeks including a trip to see the show and a parent evening Dance workshop. Hopefully we will receive additional funding to continue to work with outside cultural organizations. We would love to be more involved in the arts but lack the funding to provide more dance, music or visual arts to every child.

Q37_4: participating in family engagement arts activities and events
Q44_1:
Goals: To provide instruction to all students in dance, music, theater and visual arts. To continue integration of the arts into subject curriculum through a variety of initiatives. To provide enrichment opportunities through clubs that support college and career readiness. E.g. Broadcast Journalism Team, Audio/Visual Team. To provide information for students and families about arts opportunities available locally and throughout NYC. To create community connections through the arts. E.g.; student performances at local senior centers. To expose students to a variety of arts experiences. Our school based programs include: DANCE: •Collaborate with music and theater teachers on choreography for class plays in grades 3, 4 and 5 •Dance Club in grades 4 & 5 •Preparation of children in all grades for school wide celebrations. MUSIC: Vocal and Instrumental •Grades K-5 served •Grades 4&5 classes rework known songs for class plays •Recorder in grades 2 & 3 •chorus• band •accordion band •winter and spring concerts •All students prepared for performances in school-wide presentations. THEATER:•All grades served • Grades 4 & 5 classroom teachers work with theater and music specialists to create an original 40 minute musical play• Other grades receive theater arts skills instruction • Produce full-length Drama Club musical. VISUAL ARTS: •All grades 3-5 classes create their own scenery for class plays.
GOAL: to connect families with their child's education through ongoing opportunities in the arts that support student achievement.

With a very limited budget our school has had to make critical decisions in order to keep the arts a vital part of our students' education. We have on staff an art teacher to work with the students in all classes, Pre-Kindergarten - Grade 5. Two student art shows were produced in the fall and spring. Our entire school community is involved in our International Fair which includes ethnic performances performed by the students. All classes K-5 participate in two 6-10 week cycles of the School wide Enrichment Cluster initiative. Every classroom teacher incorporates arts education into their classroom instruction. All K-5 students receive weekly music instruction from our music teacher. We were able to hire our current music teacher through our partnership with the organization Education Through Music which affords students an enriching experience with music. Students performed two concerts for the school community to showcase their music instruction and talents.

We are a community based middle school. All 6th graders go through a full arts instruction assessment in visual, choral, and instrumental, and dance arts. They are assessed for talent and based on that assessment, students and parents are invited to participate in tracked arts talent for 7th and 8th grade. Art talent students are groomed to create arts portfolios in their specific discipline in preparation for auditions in NYC specialized arts programs in high school. Many of our art talent students are chosen to attend prestigious arts schools such as LaGuardia and Frank Sinatra. Others continue with the arts in their local or chosen high schools. Some form of the arts is available for 7th and 8th graders outside of the talent track. Those students are prevue to dance, chorus, music, digital graphic arts, and visual art.

PS 221 prides itself on arts education. Our programs include visual arts, musical, and dance instruction. Our music program includes singing, performing, Orff, recorder, guitar, ukulele, and drums. We perform in school concerts and community outreach. Our 4th grade performs a holiday concert, 3rd grade a recorder concert, & 2nd grade Earth friendly songs at our Science Fair. This year we performed for the Queensboro president’s office during the winter holidays. We also have group of fifth graders in our North Hills Harmonics. Our visual arts program includes 5th grade sketchbooks, art history, and a partnership with Deepdale Cares. This year’s community project created artwork for our school atrium and their coop community. Together students and Deepdale Cares seniors worked painted terracotta pots, stepping stones, and birdhouses. We also have ‘Artify It!’, an art enrichment program. Our students participate in the Square 1 visual arts project. Our dance program includes Dancing Classrooms and our annual Dance Festival. Our theatre experiences included Circus Arts, Marathon Playhouse, Queens Theater, LeAP, and the Queens Museum. Our visual arts experiences included the MET. This year’s residencies programs were Journeys into American Indian Territory and the Art Works Project with visits to the MET. In-house, our annual Renaissance program incorporates a wide variety of enrichment experiences in the arts, such as dance, theater, visual arts, and music. We hold an annual talent show, Family Art Night and an Open Mic event.

Our students are engaged in the arts from pre-kindergarten to grade 8. Students are given a variety of opportunities within multiple art disciplines as well. We believe that the arts are an essential part of the learning environment and academics. Here at PS/IS 266, all constituencies support student learning, exposure to arts and culture.

Btech High school currently offers two art courses. One is studio art, which heavily focuses on the traditional methods and mediums to create art. This course implements art history and many of the artistic movements throughout history. The second course, is called digital art, which focuses on more modern media, such as 3-d modeling, graphic design, product design, prototyping,and Fashion design. The purpose of both courses is to foster creativity within the students and provide career and marketing skills to help them develop business models.

Our Music Department offers a diversified program to meet the needs and interests of each of our students. Students have the opportunity to be members of the following performing groups: Junior Chorus, Senior Chorus, Beginning Band, Intermediate Band, Advanced Band, Beginning Orchestra, and Advanced Orchestra. In addition, there are courses in Guitar, and Music Appreciation. Students perform at concerts throughout the year as well as participating in several field trips.notate music, perform in an ensemble, and understand music in relation to history and culture. Develop instructional strategies to ensure that each student reaches their full potential while developing a lifelong appreciation for the Arts.
Performing Arts Program- Students study ballet, modern, and jazz techniques along with choreography. Students also have the opportunity to explore additional forms of dance by attending live performances and participating in school productions. Theatre and Film: The primary goal of this course is to enhance students’ understanding of the art of film.  Students will study and become familiar with filmmaking terminology and film history.  Through the screening of various films and film clips in class, students will analyze techniques and critique the work of a broad range of directors.  All aspects of cinematography will be explored including editing, lighting, camera use, mise-en-scene and production choices.

Q43_10: Student presentations of projects and course knowledge.
Q44_1:
The school currently offers a course titled Raising Social Awareness Through Art as a mixed grade class. In the course, students examine both health and social issues from current events and create art to bring these issues to the public. Incorporating videos, comics, brochures, board games, street art, along with classical art skills such as drawing from observation students will work together to develop artworks both alone and with peers. This year we have begun to offer a foundational course in music and music theory

In addition, the school offers avenues for the study of art through English, Science, Social Studies and Mathematics classes at each grade level. Artistic expression is available to students through a variety of clubs, including art, photography, and a dance team. As the school grows we plan to increase our arts programming via after school activities.

Our current arts program consists of dance, theater, fine arts, graphic and visual arts, and vocal and orchestral/band performance. Our goals are to sustain a diverse and challenging sequence of courses which will culminate with our Arts Festival and the Regents for our Dance Academy students. This enables our students to participate in authentic arts experiences both in and out of school. We are looking to offer a three year sequence in graphic arts.  Our students have many opportunities to perform both in an out of school in dance, instrumental and vocal music.
Q46_2: Assistant Principal Art, Music, Dance, Technology, PE & Health

Q44_1: Martin Van Buren has a dynamic Arts Program which offers many electives and sequences in music and visual arts. The Music Department offers sequences in Piano, Band, Chorus and Musical Theater.  Senior students are offered Music Production and Composition.  In Visual Arts we offer a Fine Arts sequence as well as sequences in Fashion, Cartooning and Animation, Graphic Arts, Advertising and Web Design, 3-D Design and Architecture.  We have a chapter of the Tri-M Musical Society and participate in the Grammy Foundation Training Camp each year. Drumline Club and Visual Arts clubs are offered after school. This was our second year offering SING musical competition with great success. We are proud to say that we have successfully helped our students enter into excellent college arts programs including the Fashion Institute of Technology, Parsons, C W Post, Cooper Union, The Arts Institute, Nassau Community Fashion Program,and Queens college Music program.
Q45_1: We are focusing on integrating the arts with technology and connecting our classes to possible careers in the arts.

Q44_1: Bayside High School's music and art programs are congruent with the Bayside mission to graduate students possessing awareness and core competencies needed for success in the employment arena and institutions of higher learning. Both programs provide student-centered, skill-intensive, real-world experience in students’ areas of interest. Rooted in developing core technical skills, our programs also familiarize students with industry-standard equipment and software. Lastly, we introduce students to careers in their chosen art form, as well as expectations of the job market, with special attention to arts careers. We have applied for NYS CTE approval for both our screened Art and Music Programs and are shifting from traditional Arts program models toward arts focused CTE programs. Accordingly, we actively align our Digital Art & Design Program and our Music Performance & Production Program to meet industry expectations. Both programs culminate in industry-endorsed technical assessment.

Students in PreK-5, receive music and visual arts 1-2 times a week. Students in 6-8, receive music and visual art once a week.

Students in the middle school are granted the opportunity of participating in a theatrical production through the Broadway Jr. MTI grant.

PS 45Q provides arts education to students through the strategic partnering of our school based educators with New York City cultural organization. Classroom and Enrichment teachers work closely and receive professional development from Studio In A School, National Dance Institute and Dancing Classrooms. Students in Grades PreK - 6 receive direct instructional from training teaching artists in music, dance and the visual arts.

Our practical vision for arts instruction emcompasses inspiring students, building confidence, and deepening critical thinking skills through the arts. This should include not only history and appreciation but a hands-on component which allows for experiential learning. Our goal would be to maximize our students' creative potential.

Our arts program is based on The Blueprint for the Arts and the Core Curriculum Learning Standards. Visual arts, music and movement, as well as theater are integrated into our curriculum maps. Parents are invited to attend a Kindergarten dance performance in the spring and a Grade 1 musical performance at the end of the school year. Parents  have an opportunity to learn more about the visual arts program through workshops led by our visual arts teacher, and  through visual arts exhibits.
Q45_1: We are a Pre-K to Grade 1 school. The visual arts teacher works in all three grades.  Our students are exposed to music and dance through classroom activities, in-classroom consultancies, as well as after-school activities (to the extent that the budget allows).

Q44_1:
Here at MS 53, we educate the whole child. Our performing arts program introduces students to historical and language based content while allowing them to explore their sense of self. Our program impacts our students' cognitive growth by increasing cultural awareness, problem solving abilities, recognition of visual language, and higher order thinking skills. Every Wednesday, for approximately two hours, our students participate in one of the following performing arts programs: Drumline, Martial Arts, Dance, Step, Visual Arts, Music, Capoeira, and Steel Pan. 

One of our most esteemed programs, Life Changing Music (LCM), is a program that allows students to explore their creativity through songwriting as well as music and video production. As featured on the Fox 5 News' "Influential New Yorkers" segment, we take pride in our students and staff having produced several CD's and music videos, including "SWAGGER," "53-Swag," and Motivate" featuring Dres of Black Sheep. The LCM program has dramatically increased self esteem and collaboration among students as they express themselves through positive musical messages.  

Additionally, our Urban Arts partnership offers rigorous residency programs in a wide range of art forms, taught by expert teaching artists. All programs use a project based approach for students to develop pre-professional skills and key vocabulary while producing high quality, original artworks. Students also develop an increased awareness of career opportunities in the arts.

PS 64Q has established an art education program that supports and enhances student learning. Our art education programs span across all grades and are inclusive of all students. Arts education at PS 64Q integrates the learning of other disciplines-Social Studies, Science and English Language Arts. Higher order thinking skills such as planning and preparation for artistic expression/representation, critique, analysis, questioning, discussion and reflection are embedded throughout our art education program. Our visual arts and music teachers prepare our students to present showcases of their work throughout the year. We’ve established partnerships with outside organizations to further promote art education and to present additional learning opportunities for our students. Our partnerships with Carnegie Hall Weill Music Institute, Young People’s Chorus of NYC, Disney Musicals in Schools and Marquis Art Studio have allowed our students to perform at Carnegie Hall, The Apollo Theater,  Manhattan Symphony Space Theatre, 92nd Street Y and The New Amsterdam Theatre. These partnerships have been valuable in supporting our school in sustaining our art education programs so that we are able to provide our students with enriched educational experiences.

The goal of the PS 56Q arts program is to engage students in an integrated arts experience to enhance children's understanding of the world around them. Through a combination of school-level instruction and cultural partnerships, we will continue to provide children with a rich and meaningful arts educational experience.

Q42_R1_C1: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
Q44_1: Students worked hard this year on achieving our school goals of improving questioning techniques and establishing a culture for arts learning. We have been able to develop questioning techniques for students to gain a deeper understanding of art works and question each other's points of view and thinking. These questions have enabled them to think critically about art which is helping them to become lifelong learners of art. We have established a culture for arts learning which is demonstrated by the children connecting art into real things encountered in real life as well as global issues beyond their background.

Q33_6: Studio in a school, Lincoln center Ballet
Q37_4: Studio in a school Parent workshops
Q44_1: At P.S. 62, a Magnet School for Computer Science and Innovation, we encourage our students to be Makers of Apps and Arts. We ensure that all 950+ students participate in dance, music, theater and visual arts classes during their years at PS 62. Innovation is integrated across all disciplines and classroom Maker Spaces incorporate concepts with design. This year two classroom teachers were Astor Fellows and their classes worked with the Metropolitan Museum on a year long partnership. Third and fourth grade students learn to play guitar or violin with the Music teacher who partners with Lincoln Center. During these classes, they are exposed to a wide variety of arts across a variety of genres and cultures. Our dancers practice creative movements, develop motor skills, focus on specific styles of dance and explore a variety of ways to create and manipulate their own movement. Our arts programs provide opportunities for students to become literate in art, make social, cultural and historical connections, become lifelong learners and advocates for the arts. Additionally, our third, fourth and fifth grades are given the opportunity to participate in an arts club (dance, visual arts, chorus). This year we were awarded a Midori grant in which 40 students were instructed in guitar.  We celebrate the arts throughout the year through shows, exhibits and classroom presentations attended by the whole school community. These performances and presentations are recorded and uploaded to our school website and our Facebook page for viewing.

Arts programs are a priority at PS63Q. Over the past several years, our arts programs have remained steadfast, despite a difficult economic environment. We have established strong partnerships with many arts organizations such as Carnegie Hall, American Ballroom Theater (Dancing Classrooms), Music & The Brain and Little Kids Rock. Our current performance groups include chorus, modern band, concert band and violin. We also feature original artwork by students in our school productions, as well as in outside exhibitions whenever possible. Last year we had winners in the following art exhibition/contests: NYSATA Legislative exhibit in Albany, NY, PS Art winner in Met museum exhibit, Queens Arts Festival winner at Queens Museum of Art exhibit, Ezra Jack Keats bookmaking contest Citywide winner in Elementary School category. This year we also won a grant for a music/theater residency to support our English Language Learners. In the future, we would like to increase student access to programs involving the theater arts and provide professional development that will enable classroom teachers to incorporate more arts-based ideas into their curriculum.

Q42_R1_C1: Learning through an Expanded Arts Program
Q44_1: PS 66 Queens will implement diverse integrated arts programs through a variety of instructional and cultural initiatives for all students. Our goal is to incorporate the arts across all curricula areas. Using the curriculum, we integrate music, dance, theater, and art into thematic units where students are offered hands-on opportunities to discover the world. Using residencies and trips, we expose students to theater, drama, dance and music. The students participate in school-based arts festivals during the year.

This year, the P.S. 90 Arts Department has expanded to include a Dance component.  In addition to enriching our students educational experience with Visual Arts and Theater, we now provide our students with another creative outlet through Dance. The addition of our dance program is helping to propel our entire school towards our central focus of student achievement across all subject areas. 
    The goal of our arts program is to provide students with opportunities to demonstrate their multiple intelligences.  By doing this, we are providing students with the opportunity to flourish in varied ways, both in the classroom for their peers and teachers, as well as during performances for parents and the community.  We have had Visual Arts Exhibitions, Musical Theater performances, Puppet Theater performances, and Dance performance  that span multiple genres of cultural dance. 
     It is our belief that by exposing our students to the performing arts, we will increase their literacy skills and develop their confidence. Our staff as a whole feels that the benefits of our arts program are tangible in the classroom and culture of our school.  We expect to see the continued growth of not only our students, but of ourselves as professionals.

Public school 96 Queens is an elementary school with 310 students from grade  pre-kindergarten through grade 5. We use an interdisciplinary approach to infuse the four major disciplines for our student population. The Visual Art, Drama, Dance and Music have been incorporated into our Units of Studies. Our Visual Arts Curriculum focuses on the various art forms and is aligned with the Blue Prints for the Arts. Our students study various composers. Our diverse population has afforded us the opportunity to study various cultural dances during our annual Dance Festival. 
Visual Arts residency has been made possible for past two years through funding from a private donor to secure a residency with Studio In A School. The program provides comprehensive, media and strands rich, sequential visual art instruction to all K-5 students. Each grade receives weekly art instruction in a range of media, designed specifically for PS 96Q, in alignment with the New York City Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Visual Arts and Common Core. Classes are instructed in collaboration with the classroom teachers and a professional studio visual artist. The program equips students with multiple opportunities to develop the ability to work from observation, memory, and the imagination, to plan, reflect, revise, and to collaborate, to develop ideas from multiple sources and synthesize their ideas to create original works of art that are personally relevant. 
Our goal is to continue to increase our students’ exposure to the Arts.

I connected serval units with the science teacher as well as classroom teacher. The dance teacher and  I worked together connecting vocabulary/movement in art. A large percent of my lessons were student choice and project based and I allowed more time for students to view/redo /share time. In the back of my room I had several art centers that students were allowed to go to to explore and create when they were finished with their work and I also had art centers in the early grades.This worked out well, and was usually done when the main idea/objective was learned.
My school is a wonderful school and I feel fully supported by the administration!!!!
I love coming to work!
Q45_1:
My school has a large percent of english language learners. We have both dance and art which works out nice since we both work well together. I use song/movement/poems/theatre in my art lessons and try to provide each class with a trip.
We both plan with the teachers to not only enhance their program but to give it greater understanding and learning experience for the students.

Q44_1: We continue to maintain our arts program at PS 100, which consists of three major components that cycle three times a year covering all of our classes in music, visual arts and drama/theatre. An additional component offers instrumental music instruction and chorus. The students in our instrumental program play recorder, clarinet, saxophone and percussions. The children have competed at NYSMA, performed at Carnegie Hall.

Public School 104 in Far Rockaway, Queens arts program teaches visual arts education to students in grades pre-kindergarten through fifth grade. Grades pre-kindergarten through second grade work towards benchmark 2 in the New York City Blueprint for the Arts by engaging in storytelling, combining their observations and imagination into art making. Grades third through fifth make thoughtful inquiries and capture details about life, recreating those details in art making and exploration working towards benchmark 5 in the New York City Blueprint for the Arts. With each art lesson students are exposed to the life and works of artists from the past and present around the world assisting students in making historical and cultural connections. The life and works of artists teach and inspire students about the many career possibilities available in the arts. Students explore and manipulate a variety of art mediums using the elements and principles of design through 2-dimensional and 3-dimensional art works. Through assessment and critique students read, write and reflect upon art making reinforcing literacy skills. When writing assessments in the arts students support findings with evidence. In addition, students work independently and in teams honing skills and increasing enjoyment and appreciation of the arts.

The arts program runs with two music teachers and one visual arts teacher. The program serves students from PK to 8th grade. Depending upon the classes, students receive art education one to two times a week in both disciplines. The arts program follows the NYC Blue Print Benchmarks for the Visual Arts and Music, making interdisciplinary connections with the Social Studies and Science curriculum. Lessons are planned incorporating Common Core Standards for Math and ELA. . Outside the school workshops, music and visual art teachers participate in various professional development workshops related to their own discipline. The school also offers one period per cycle, for an art and chorus and band that runs in 2 semesters for grades 7 and 8

All students at P.S. 106Q will receive music instruction at least once a week throughout the school year, and grades 3 through 5 will receive music at least once a week. That will meet the New York State learning standards in the arts as measured by monthly bulletin board displays, unit tests in the arts, written responses , musical performances and art displays. Music and Science cluster teacher will work together with classroom teachers to enhance the core knowledge curriculum through the Music and Science. Students will attend local performances in Music and museums and have the opportunity to not only create melodies and perform in recitals and concerts, but will also learn to play the recorder. Students will also have the opportunity to participate in a winter concert, the Black History Month Show, and the Say No To Violence Assembly. 5th graders will participate in a graduation show/assembly. Through Music in Schools, staff members will participate in professional development training in-house. The music teacher will have both in-house professional opportunties and mentorship as well as District 27 Arts professional development.

The arts program at the Metropolitan Expeditionary Learning School (MELS) is comprised of year-long courses in instrumental music (orchestral and rock instruments), and visual arts for all students in 6th and 7th grade. Beginning in 8th grade, students may also elect vocal music and all courses continue in sequence to the AP level. Central to the arts at MELS is an emphasis on the relationship between the arts and world, characterized by the full integration of the arts into the school’s interdisciplinary, community-action oriented curriculum. In 2016-2017, students participated in a gallery exhibition, the annual fall arts "Coffeehouse Showcase", Battle of the Bands competition, and an Elementary School Orchestra Tour. Additionally, MELS offers after school programs in rap crew, art portfolio, and jazz ensemble.

PS 108 is proud of our ability to provide each child in the school with an opportunity to explore and experience the arts. Our art teachers are diligent about displaying student artwork so our hallways serve as a gallery showcasing our children's current artistic achievements. Our dance teachers coordinate performances amongst all grades exhibiting students' hard work to entertain fellow pupils, staff and parents. We have supportive parents who continuously participate in school events. This year we were able to hire two full time music teachers and we were able to have a music afterschool program. We are continuously exploring other avenues which may provide a multitude of invaluable experiences.

Goals For Arts Education: - Students will expand their awareness of the influence the arts have had on the world throughout history. - Students will be able to make connections in the arts to other areas of instruction. - Students will receive a well-rounded education in the arts.

the arts have been considered to be a link to higher-level thinking.  We offer instrumental music in grades K-8; starting with K-2 being introduced to reading and playing keyboards via the "Music and the Brain" program...seguing into the 3rd grade with flutophones and graduating in grades 4-8 with the playing of playing concert band instruments...leading to musical groups as the Concert Band (4-8), the Marching Band (4-8) and the Jazz Band (6-8).  An additional musical group would be our Glee Club (4-8).

Visual arts instruction is given to a majority of the school.

The visual arts program at PS/MS 124 follows the Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in Visual Arts, created by New York City Department of Education's Office of Arts and Special Projects. Through the five activity strands that compose the Blueprint, students are offered a comprehensive and multifaceted set of visual arts-related experiences. Formative assessment is utilized in the arts classroom to support students and improve performance. Middle School students applying to screened visual arts programs in high schools will participate in portfolio to prepare for auditions. PS/MS 124 will continue to enter art competitions such as the Queens Borough Arts Festival, Ezra Keats Bookmaking Contest, and PS Art. In the graphic arts at PS/MS 124, students are encouraged to develop an interest in the field of graphic design. They develop their digital manipulation skills by creating a complex piece of artwork using Adobe Photoshop Elements in order to create the most appealing, up to date designs. The program enables students to create, edit, organize and share images with the use of a computer. In addition, the dance/creative movement at PS/MS 124 emphasizes building a foundation of the dynamics of movement with the incorporation of spatial awareness, use of effort, shapes, and relationships between the dancers. As students move to the middle school level there is the opportunity to work collaboratively with their peers in dance making aligning the learning process with the blueprint in dance.

At MS 137, we strive to educate the whole child. MS 137 has continued to make arts education a priority. In order to accomplish this, we realize that a well-rounded education in the arts is a critical component in preparing our students to enter the professional community. Students are exposed to career-building skills in the arts-related fields and gain an appreciation of art as a means of expression. By infusing the arts with technology, we provide students with an arts curriculum that is challenging as well as rigorous. Students are supported to apply knowledge and skills learned in the arts to make connections to the world around them. Our Arts curriculum supports goal setting, prioritizing, and strengthening interpersonal skills by working collaboratively with peers, and working independently. We put great emphasis on literacy in the arts and these skills support interdisciplinary units of study. This year, we were fortunate to have two of our students selected to participate in the Queens Boro Arts Fair, as well as another student as a semi-finalist for PS Art. We were also partnered with Theater for a New Audience Residency. Theater residents worked with our students to create plays. At the culmination of the residency, professional actors brought the students plays to life by acting out what they wrote and created. For the first time we had the extreme pleasure of being the host school for NYSSMA. Our school has previously been rated Gold in both our Instrumental Band and Chorus for the borough of Queens.

Our school community is dedicated to the arts as it benefits our students emotionally, socially, and physically. The Arts programs develop childrens' creative minds and technical abilities. Through Our Visual Arts Program students explore various media such as painting, drawing, printmaking, collage, and 2D/graphic design. They develop an understanding of the Elements of Art and the Principles of Design, as well as deepen their expressive and critical skills. Choral and Instrumental Music allow students to develop critical insights, engage in music learning and making within the school community, and become lifelong learners in and advocates for music. Our Dance Program teaches students to become literate in dance, connect creatively to the other arts and disciplines, technology and health; engage in dance learning within the school community, and become lifelong learners in and advocates for dance. The Green Magnet Production Company teaches students to create sustainable lives. They work to beautify our school, reduce our carbon footprint, and look at global and social issues. Our Technology and Moving Image Program teaches students digital citizenship and awareness of their digital footprint. Students learn to engage in this digital age. Performing students participate in two large scale productions each year that showcase their talents and skills. Many of our students go on to Arts high schools, but every student becomes thoughtful and engaged participants in the Arts throughout their lives.

PS 146 is proud to offer classes in the arts to 100% of our students in the forms of dance, music, theater, and the visual arts. We have art-based performances throughout the year and take our students on trips to experience art forms in music, drama, and dance. We participate in citywide art contests offered by the Office of Health and Wellness, NYC Sustainability Council (Energy Saving), and Earth Day celebrations. Our students artwork is displayed throughout the school. We hold an annual Dance Festival in which our K-4 students participate and multi-grade students put on  yearly musicals under the guidance of our theater teacher. We believe the arts is an integral piece in the mosaic of each student's well-rounded education.

At P.S. 155Q, the arts program utilizes the five strands of The Blueprint For Teaching and Learning in the Arts, that is aligned with the Common Core Learning Standards, as a guide for integrating the arts into the core curriculum. The school's visual and musical arts curriculums provide a variety of modalities for creativity, student learning, and success. Differentiated, and scaffolded instruction is evidenced in student performances, portfolios, and completed work projects. We will continue to improve student achievement in the arts, through the development and implementation of balanced art assessments (formative and summative) that are aligned to high student content and "Blueprint" based academic achievement standards.

P.S./M.S. 183Q is committed to providing our students with an art enriched program. All grades and classes conduct an assembly which focuses on a theme for the month. Students participate in talent shows, Christmas show and Black history month performances. They perform plays, sing songs and create their own dances. We encourage teachers and staff member to incorporate the arts throughout all subject areas, such as drawings and music. We have the Enact program that works with our grades 1-4 students on drama. The Thrive program works with our middle school students through visual arts and music and our third grade students participates in dance with Ballroom Basix.
Q45_1: We only have one visual arts teacher available to teach our students in Pr-K through 8th grade.

Q44_1: The mission of Robert H. Goddard MS 202 is to provide our students with a comprehensive education with a particular emphasis on the fine arts so they able to view the world though a holistic lens and be well prepared to meet the challenges of college and career as motivated, socially conscious and inspired individuals. Our long term goal is to continuously enhance the Arts curriculum by providing instruction, which is aligned to Common Core Learning Standards and the Blueprint for the Arts. Additionally, our goal is also to enrich our students' lives by exposing them to the Arts and having them develop a profound and life long appreciation for the arts. This will enable our students to express themselves freely in different creative ways, and thus allow them to develop and showcase their own personal talent.

Throughout the 2016-2017 school year, the visual and performing arts program were guided by the Blue Print for Learning.  The goal of each program was to meet the benchmarks of the Second, Fifth and Eighth Grade students including becoming familiar with visual and musical concepts, art and music history and the elements and principles of fine art and music. In addition, students were offered opportunities in Chorus Club, Band Club and Rock Band.  Theatre Club collaborated with the music and the art program to enrich performances throughout the school year.  We strive to support the Core Standards between the arts and the academic subjects to all of our students.

Public School 273 serves Pre-K - Grade 5 students. We believe that providing visual arts and music education is integral to addressing the needs of the whole child. Our visual arts program serves all of our students and is integrated and sequential. In Pre-K through Grade 5, our visual arts instruction increases children's awareness of their physical environment, extends and develops the use of the senses and encourages inventive thinking. Our visual arts program supports individual interpretation of ideas and feelings while providing opportunities for experimentation in a variety of media, such as painting, drawing, printmaking, collage, sculpture, applied design and technology. Our art teacher nurtures our children's curiosity by encouraging our students to explore and express their individual interpretations of artwork. In Grades Pre-K – 4, our music teacher implements differentiated instruction and builds upon the strengths and challenges of multi-cultural, multi-lingual, and multi-racial groups of students. She teaches instrumental music to grades K-2 (including keyboarding in collaboration with the Music and the Brain program). This year, we received a grant from the Carnegie Hall Weill Music Institute Link Up Program to provide great musical experiences for our Grade 3 students utilizing recorders. Our music teacher has also established a specialized school chorus consisting of Grades 4-5 students.

Q44_1: This year we created a Visual and Performing Arts Academy and hired two music teachers. Yearly we plan on building this program. Our vocal music teacher has provided the students with a well rounded appreciation for the arts.  She has taught the students how to read music and use this information to enhance their knowledge in the field. Our instrumental music teacher has also began to teach the students how to read music.  He has began to teach the students how to play the guitar.  Students have requested to play the bucket drums.  They are working on beats and rhythm.  Students in our visual arts program work with various art mediums.  We had two students who have their art work displayed in buildings.  Students in our ACES program will present their theater production to the school community.  They have participated in a district Dance Festival with other schools.

At MS210 we have 5 Career Academies. This is our first year as career academies and we are looking to build yearly. There are 5 different career academies; Academy of Graphic Arts and Computer Science (AGACS); Academy of Visual and Performing Arts (AVPA); Academy of Health Professions (AHP), Academy of Law and Humanities (ALH) and Academy of Engineering and Architecture (AEA).  Each career academy focuses on career development courses that are unique to them.  Within the Academy of Visual and Performing Arts students learn Studio Art, Theatre, Instrumental Band and Vocal Music.

Next year we are looking to secure a partnership with a college and/or private arts programs to increase the exposure of the arts to our students.

Q44_1: Here at P.S. 223,our full-time visual arts teacher and full-time music teacher have continued a rigorous approach to arts instruction that is aligned with the NYC Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts. Arts instruction at our school continued to pursue diverse approaches to the content being taught through various media and repertoire.  Student artwork was displayed within the school and was featured at our parent/teacher conferences. The chorus continued to engage parents and the school community with their performances. A group of students also attended  dance and music related field trips with our music teacher.  The theme of our Dance Festival this year focuses on the music of Motown. Cultural organizations like Community Works, Studio-in-a-School and Ballet Tech have delivered additional instruction in music,dance and visual arts. Our music and visual arts teachers attended Arts Mondays PD throughout the school year. Our Pre-K teachers also attended extensive workshops through Studio-in-a-School.

Our arts  program includes the following: two full time art teachers and one full time music teacher.
