Q44_1: Our arts program follows NYS Learning Standards for the Arts and the NYC Blueprint for the Arts. We provide a balanced arts program which is incorporated in our curriculum program. Our goal is exposure to all various forms of the arts, creating unique opportunities and experiences to all of our students. In our arts program, we support literacy by writing about art and dance concepts.

Our Arts program follows NYS Learning Standards for the Arts and the NYC Blueprint for the Arts. Students are exploring at least five different art-making disciplines in each grade starting from Kindergarten through 5th grade and study several different instruments in music classes. We ensure that our students reach two visual arts benchmarks working on 4 -6 week unit based projects. By the end of 2nd grade, they demonstrate knowledge of a variety of art materials and tools and create original work. By the end of 5th grade, our students work on sequential projects and extend knowledge of art media. We are also integrating art and music with other disciplines and collaborate with classroom teachers on special projects. In our Arts program we support literacy by writing about art and music concepts and interpreting and analyzing works of art. An important component of Art program is regular visits to art museums, music concerts, dance and theater performances, where students experience original works of art and understand their significance within the context of diverse cultures. We also offer several programs for parental involvement in the arts through numerous art workshops and music events.

VOYAGES SOuth High School has created a project based art program tailored to our over aged and undercredited young adults. A true collaboration between our Art and Construction teachers, the Construction Arts Program incorporates a wide range of artistic mediums including sculpture, architecture, carpentry, modeling, paint, ink and brush, wood working, and other non traditional elements. Students build various projects throughout each trimester ranging from habitat models, Tim Burtom exhibitions, murals, 3D Houses, Lego sculpture, and models.
Q45_1: We are a NYC Transfer High School co-located in the August Martin Campus. Our students are over aged and undercredited ranging in age from at least 16-21 years old. Programming is based on an accelerated credit accumulation model. Each student enters our school with differing levels of credit attainment from their previous high school. Students receive a NYS Regents Diploma at the end of two years if they attend and pass all the state and school requirements.

Q44_1: We have a visual arts program that is offered to both middle and high school students. The teacher creates interdisciplinary projects with core subject teachers. In addition, we have choral music, keyboarding, rock 'n roll group as well as a concert and marching band. Our choral music teacher works with the Metropolitan Opera Guild Urban Voices Program. Our students are not only offered their required arts program, but also an additional choice of elective in dance, chorus, band and visual arts.  Electives takes place three times a week.

At NYCAD - PS 306Q, we believe that a well-rounded education begins with integrating the arts into the curriculum. All students benefit from the opportunity to learn about and experience the arts. Arts education helps bolster a child’s attitude towards school and in turn makes for a more positive school environment. Next year, we will continue to offer arts education through theater and the visual arts.

Q42_R1_C1: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
Q44_1: We currently offer visual and digital arts to all our students as well as theater and dance. We also offer AP Studio Art in Drawing for our advanced art students who want to pursue college and career in the arts. Every year, we host an art exhibit where our students showcase their artwork to the school community, including parents. We also have art clubs including yearbook that meet every week after school. Students have the opportunity to engage in theater production twice a semester as well as take dance electives for physical education.

EPIC High School south is a relatively new school and in our third year of existence. As such, we have limited resources including diversity in art offerings. We currently offer visual art as an elective to all students.  Art is currently being taught by a substitute teacher.  We intend on hiring a full time visual art teacher for the 2017-2018 school year.  
This school year our students participated in the Think It Up program offered by the Entertainment Industry Foundation.  Our students were able to compete in an art competition where they won and was awarded $1000 which was used to purchase art supplies for our school. 
For the next school year, we hope with a resident art teacher our art program will expand to include a greater variety of art celebration events, as well as more rigorous art experience for our students.

WAVE Prep is committed to demonstrating WAVE (Worldliness, Accountability, Virtuousness, Excellence) and preparing scholars for college and careers. To support scholars in developing as worldly and virtuous individuals, all scholars engage in a rigorous interdisciplinary curriculum that integrates various forms of art across all content areas. Scholars embrace dance, visual arts and music, and utilize their artistic abilities to demonstrate their knowledge and understanding of academic areas.

We have a strong founding music and visual arts program.

Our goal is to provide all students in our school with exposure to the arts.  As we grow our goal is to add more arts (ie. instrumental music, theater, etc) to our curriculum to expose our elementary students to a diverse art program.
Q45_1: Our school is in it's third year.  We currently have PK-2nd grade.  As our school grows, so will our arts program.

Q44_1: Our school uses both performing and visual arts as a bridge between content and understanding. Classroom teachers design their standards based (Common Core) curriculum maps with the arts integrated within. All arts based teachers design their arts based curriculum maps with ELA, Math, Science and Social Studies standards integrated within. School based art teachers include Visual Art, Dance, Music, STEAM, and Theater. We offer art based residencies through Creative Arts Team, Disney Theatrical, The Guggenheim Museum, NYC Ballet, Little Kids Rock and Center for Architecture. We also use the Schoolwide Enrichment Model on Fridays for 2 periods where students get to choose what cluster they want to study. We do two cycles of enrichment. Cycle 1 and cycle 2 lasts 15 weeks each. We also have art enrichment after school programs/clubs in dance, art, band, 3D printing, chess, basketball, soccer, and theater.

Waterside works to integrate our progressive visual arts curriculum into each scholar's educational experience. We believe that visual arts are a critical and essential part of the education of every young person and we work to provide all scholars with high-quality, studio art experiences fitting to their individual stages of development and background. Studio visual arts courses at WSL include drawing, watercolor, manga art, portraiture, photography and painting. Scholars research and emulate various artists and styles over he course of three years. They are encouraged to ask questions with each and every project they create.

Village Academy has continued to strive to integrate the arts into subject areas as well as providing each student with visual arts, music, theatre and dance, multiple times a week. Our students continue to participate in recording their own media arts and developing their own original music. Students participate in poetry slams, direct and produce videos, and perform in annual concerts. Currently the students work with Entertainers4Education Alliance, Life Changing Music, and the YMCA. Teachers also support our arts initiatives by providing weekly arts and literacy based electives and attending professional development related to the arts.  As a small school we continue to need the support of grants for funding to expose all our students to different forms of arts education where they can continue to express themselves through the arts.

Q43_10: solo performances, art exhibitions, gallery showings, presentations, ensembles and blogs
Q44_1: Scholars' Academy stays committed to enhancing the effectiveness and scope of existing programs and continues to to embrace the numerous technological advances that are offered in our society, through our stream webcasts, links to student made films, concerts and performances as well as exploring virtual art studios and installations.  Our school makes art in the 21st century accessible to all and prepares our art students for success in college and careers.  Writing and discussions continue to infiltrate the arts in a profound manner and will continue to be a focus of the visual and performing arts department.

Studio Art provides an introduction to art through a multi-media experience. Students learn and apply the elements and principles of design to produce creative projects.  Students are exposed to multiple disciplines such as drawing from observation, creating a painting using color theory, use of different medium through collage and the fabrication of a sculpture.
 
Jewelry Design provides a hands on approach to the creation of jewelry using basic techniques, cold connections and hand tools. Students are shown simple techniques and create functional jewelry.  The students create design sketches, fabricate bracelets, rings, pendants and earrings and keep written reflections on each work they create. 

After School Art is an introduction to the design and fabrication of tile mosaics. The students will create 3 mosaics for our school hallways. They will create original designs and hang the mosaics themselves. 

The music program at Rockaway Park High School for Environmental Sustainability focuses on developing student musicianship utilizing popular music.  Students learn traditional music notation, however, emphasis is placed on the development of their auditory senses.  Students learn to rely on their ears when making a variety of musical decisions.  We offer a two-part guitar course with the added option of learning other modern band instruments (keyboard, bass guitar, or drums).  In addition, we’ve also created a modern band program for those students who wish to continue, develop, and explore their musicianship.

1. To provides opportunities for student to be challenged in various genre of art, dance, music and visual arts, where they learn the content, skill, techniques and processes.  

2. To create a safe and risk free environment where student can appreciate and enjoy the arts as well as express themselves through a variety of artistic medium. 

3. To develop students ability to understand how time, culture and society influence art as well as make interdisciplinary connections.
Q45_1: Rockaway Collegiate High School is a small school serving approximately 390 students from primarily economically disadvantaged communities.  About 75% of our students qualify for free lunch and 85% qualify for free or reduced lunch.  56% of our student body are males and most of our student population is comprised of blacks and Hispanics.  We are a community school that offers many services to our students and their families to support the student’s social emotional development as well as meet their academic needs.  Our students are extremely creative and talented and would benefit from a culturally rich arts program.  They are also fortunate to have a committed and dedicated staff that work collectively to understand their needs and meet their demands on a daily basis.

Q44_1: The John Adams HS arts program offers students a broad perspective of the arts and deepens their understanding of the opportunities for art-related careers through exposure to art history, contemporary artists and artwork, and music and drama. This program attempts to enable students to realize and achieve their full potential in art. Lessons consist of lectures, demonstrations, slide presentations, studio activities, assigned research and group assessments

Studio Art is a one year course which introduces students to the Elements of Art and Principles of Design while developing drawing skills and painting techniques. All 10th grade students are programmed for Studio Art Class that meets four times per week. During this time students will experiment with a variety of media and begin to develop student’s individual style and creative problem solving skills. Students will also demonstrate their ability to respond, to analyze, and to interpret their own artwork and the work of others through discussions, critiques, and peer/self reflections. 
College Now Visual Art program offers qualified high school students the opportunity to take AP Studio Art course for college-credit. The 11th and 12th grade students have met the following requirements to determine they were “College Ready. This year the College Now Visual Art ran for a full year in which students received 6 college credits.  This class is taken during 0 period and meets 5 days a week.  Students were introduced to the practice and articulation of elements of drawing and painting.  At the end of this year students spent the last month on their Concentration Topic in which they took all the knowledge they have learned and created a series of paintings based on one theme which they will present to their peers and staff.

Our school along with the band and art program, has added the Arts in Education Program (I Will Graduate) to our arts program. This program provides instruction in different types of dance, chorus, karate, steel pan, journalism and drumline.

Currently our school's Art Teacher has creatively designed a curriculum that is linked to our school's Social Studies themes.  From Merengue to Nigerian Hip Hop, her classes are exposed to the various music from around the world.  Our students are engrossed in cultural dances and explore their creativity through dynamic visual art projects.

Currently our scholars partner with a visual arts teacher to create and design art that are aligned to social studies and science standards using strategies from BLUEPRINTS for visual arts.
Classroom teachers also engage scholars in activities during the instructional day that provide opportunities for them to be creative with the use multi-media tools.

Q44_1: At the present time PS50 has a visual arts, drama and music program. We have received a Casa Grant that provides direct art instruction to students in the area of music, visual arts and dance. We have established a relationship with Dancing Classrooms to provide Ballroom Dancing to our 5th grade students. We have also established a relationship with Marquis Studio to provide Latin Dances to our 1st grade studets and Bollywood Dances to our 3rd grade students.  Our primary goal is to promote academic excellence and cultural awareness through a strong arts program. It is our vision to challenge all of our students academically and creatively. Our focus is to mesh our students’ cultural knowledge and background into our arts program; thus allowing our students to develop positive attitudes towards self, others, and the community. Additionally, we would like to increase our association with cultural arts organization and bring in more dance and music. Our Principal, Rina Manjarrez, is committed to supporting the teaching of the arts.

PS 54Q continues its ongoing partnership with LEAP and Creative Arts Team-CUNY and anticipates a new partnership with Arts Horizons and Midori for the upcoming school year.  This year we were able to fund an F-Status Art Teacher who provided instruction to all 24 classrooms and we were able to support multiple projects through Material For The Arts and some monies from the school's budget. Teacher Cohorts regularly attend MFTA workshops and the school integrates art across content areas thorugh interdisciplinary units.  Music and movement is infused throughout our Physical Education program; classroom activities; monthly assemblies and concerts.PTA Executive Board and Parent Volunteers continue to support our Movie Nights; Assemblies and performances.  We try to enlist all the in-house talents of our diverse staff and each morning children are welcomed to classical renditions by one of our paraprofessionals on the piano. Student Council regularly consults with the broader student constituency and we continue the  tradition of "An Afternoon of Art" each Friday. Councilwoman Koslowitz has generously continued to support our partnership with CAE and we look forward to the same in the upcoming school year.  We have a Grant Team who are working on securing a Parent Engagement opportunity with Arts Horizons and we are hopeful to be able to broaden the scope of our partnership with this CBO to include all 23 projected K-5 classes.We are constantly seeking additional partners to cultivate these opportunities for our children.

By the end of the school year 2015-2016, all of the students will graduate with the following: - A minimum of 2 consecutive semesters in the fine arts or performing arts. - Attend at least 1 excursion related to their performing arts elective. - Attend at least 1 musical performances - Perform at least 1 times outside of school. - Perform a minimum of 3 times inside of school (concerts/ assemblies). Students will be afforded the opportunity to participate in multiple arts activities before and after school, including but not limited to: - Alvin Ailey Ballet and Lincoln Jazz Center - k (after School Program) - Broadway Junior (Seussical Jr 2016-2017)- End of year Arts Concert and Gallery Exhibit.

Every year, PS 86 strives to improve our arts programming. Our music teacher is a certified music professional who is trained and knowledgeable in instrumental, chorus, and overall in creating musical scores with the students. Our lessons are interdisciplinary and with our ongoing curriculum writing, this enables us to improve our shows and assemblies, while supporting the arts. We currently have two Art teachers who service the students with visual arts in the classroom. The Theatre Arts teacher encompasses the arts, theatre, and literacy.The students are not the only ones learning and growing. Our parent involvement has increased with each passing year through the arts and craft sessions provided by the school. We encourage parents to participate in arts/crafts, tutorials, museum trips, and live day and evening performances. Our annual Art Day is the culminating event preceded by a month long study of a famous artist. Our multicultural fashion show in February, depicts the fashion, art, dance moves, and music of a particular country from around the world. Our music teacher has immersed our students with learning the piano and the guitar for 4th and 5th grades. Our poetry club performs in a poetry performance which includes and culminates in a student-based, student created, movie, filmed and edited by our PE teacher. Our 5th grade chorus performs at The National Choral Festival each year for the past four years. Overall, the students have the opportunity to become inspired while becoming lifelong learners through the arts.

Q44_1: For the 2017/2018 school year, PS99 plans to continue to teach, support and experience all four art forms according to the NYS Standards for the Arts, The NYC Blueprint, while emphasizing the Common Core. The Arts are integrated into every area of the curriculum. Continued planning, conferencing and reporting by teachers at professional development meetings (e.g. grade conferences, literacy meetings, technology summits) will be continued and encouraged. Support for the Arts will be in evidence with our cultural partnerships and our parent involvement programs in the Arts. Student work, assemblies, exhibitions, dramatization fairs and trips are integral to educating the whole child at PS99. Community connections are also emphasized through newsletters, bulletins and invitations to our school-wide cultural events. Our assessments will be ongoing, collaborative and directed toward enhanced student learning in the Arts.

Over the years our school has established professional collaborations with outside organizations. These collaborations provide academic and recreational enrichment for our students and support for our staff and support our instructional goals. Currently, we are partnered with: Queens College, Hunter College, Jazz Standard, Little Orchestra Society, American Ballroom Dancing, NY Pops. We have done fund-raising with and for: Penny Harvest, City Harvest, and St. Jude’s Hospital. Our Parents' Association has provided several Arts residencies for students in grades K - 6 to enrich the curriculum.

The visual arts teachers in our school provide our students with an extensive art education that is aligned with the Common Core Standards, NYS Art Standards and the Blueprint for the Arts. The culminating projects are displayed throughout the school building and semi-annually at the Superintendent's office. Some of our students artwork has been entered into and been selected as semi-finalists and finalists in borough-wide/city-wide art competitions. Classroom teachers also support the arts and make connections to the arts within their curriculum. They welcome artist residencies into their classrooms and aid in arts activities/performances. In addition to our daily art program/artist residencies, our school provides several arts related after school programs. These programs allow students to display artwork and scenery and participate in dramatic performances.

We have a dance program with a full time dance teacher. We also have a visual arts program with a part time visual arts teacher. Our Arts program goals are to ensure that exceptional works of art are created and performed, in order to provide more opportunities for participation in arts experiences and to guarantee that arts education is a part of all our students' learning experiences. We have a dance, yoga and art club that meets after school. A brand new dance studio was built in our school this year, dedicated to our dance program. We have many art residencies, including grants from the city for ELL/SWD students.

We are committed to high standards in arts education. The Arts help children learn creativity ,confidence, self-expression, thinking skills, and a joy for learning. We provide arts education by following the NYCDOE Blueprint Arts Benchmarks. Our glee club performed in 2 concerts. K students presented a choral concert. Grade 1 students performed circus arts. Grade 2 participated in Dancing on Broadway. Grade 3 participated in Hip Hop. Grade 4 learned recorders and participated in an Architecture Residency. Grade 5 studied ballroom dancing and participated in a Musical Spectacular. Grade 4 and 5 students competed in Music Memory. Our International Festival celebrated the diversity of our school through the performing arts. The Ezra Jack Keats Competition motivated our students to write and illustrate children's books. Our Art teacher created projects with the students. The technology teacher embedded visual arts with technology content. One visit to our school speaks for itself.

In the 2016-2017 schoolyear we have provided all students in grades  Pre- Kindergarten to Grade Five  with many opportunities in the Arts. We make sure that all of our students received a class in Visual Arts, Music which includes  singing songs, playing instruments such as the Recorders and the Drums and doing a variety of dances like Tap, Jazz and African. In our arts class the students are exposed to various eras in art. The students are encourage to learn the different styles of artists such as Vincent Van Gogh and Leonardo De Vinci. Students learn about the different art styles during a specific era, and what type of art skills that the artist of the given era focused on. The students then take the style and implement it into a painting. Students are also encouraged to write about their art and use academic vocabulary to enrich their writing pieces.
In the Music program the students are learning how to play the Recorder and the  Drums. The students have put on several perfo throughout the school year such as Black History Month, and Holiday shows which teaches about different cultures.
We continue to work with Marquise Studio. During the session with Marquis Studio, the students using Technology to create Architecture Figures such as home and building.
Our goal for next year 2017-2018 is to expand our Arts Program. We look to user arts in science , and social studies through having our student complete project based learning activities. We also would like to hire a Dance instructor, and expand the instrumental program.

We are a school that services students from grades Pre-Kindergarten to Fifth. We are excited because the demographics of our school has gone from one cultural environment to a multicultural environment. We plan to expand our arts program to focus on many multicultural events, such as International Day. We also want the students to be able to explain  the differences and similarities between each cultural.
We want each student to graduate with a sense of respect for different cultures.

Q44_1: At P.S. 160 all students are engaged in a diverse set of experiences in the arts. Students create and conduct their own investigations, analyze data and draw conclusions. Culminating activities mirror productions in theater, dance, architecture, engineering and music. The students are given many opportunities to showcase their artistic talents. With the Visual Arts Specialist the children have designed and implemented a museum in the cafeteria that features visual arts projects created by the students of P.S. 160. With the music specialist students in grades 1-2 learn to play the piano with a culminating recital at the end of second grade. Students in grade 3 learn to play the recorder while students in grades 4-5 learn the ukulele through individualized programs that encourage peer instruction. The dance specialist works with all grades introducing multicultural dance styles.  Ongoing relationships with skilled artists and musicians enable students to become artistic and independent critical thinkers. The Magnet Program, through collaborations with organizations such as the Turtle Bay Music School, Dancing Classrooms, Midori, Alvin Ailey’s Arts in Education and Community Programs, taps the rich resources in New York City to bring in-depth experiences that are not available elsewhere. Arts instruction at P.S. 160 is delivered through discrete classes conducted by musicians, dancers and licensed teachers who are specialists in the arts. At the same time, the arts are integrated into thematic units across the curriculum.

The NYS CCLS has changed the way we think about instruction. We now expect students to think critically and develop a deeper understanding of complex topics. Students develop a keener appreciation for unfamiliar topics. Teachers infuse the arts into their instruction, making the subjects more relevant. Through this modality, the children more readily develop an appreciation of abstract concepts and extend their understanding of those previously mastered. With this in mind, we have adjusted our curriculum to include singing, dancing, performing, and the visual arts. Our students have the opportunity to incorporate the arts into other subjects, making topics come alive. They become active learners, ready to engage in activities that supports higher order learning. They also cultivate an interest in unfamiliar concepts. They build background knowledge and develop intellectual curiosity. NYC is a treasure for art enthusiasts. Our students venture off school grounds to watch dance and choral presentations.

P.S. 182 continued its Project Quest initiative this school year. Students received intense interdisciplinary instruction through art investigation and exploration in the areas of visual arts, music, dance, and theater. Instruction is led by professional artists and classroom teachers and is bundled into extended learning time. This year, 160 third, fourth, and fifth grade classes participated in Quest.

We currently have a full arts program including Dance, Chorus, Band, Drama and Visual Art.  Our students participate in the community at local stores during the holidays, local senior centers, St. Mary's children's hospital, NYSMA and have sang our National Anthem at CitiField.  Our student created art work is displayed in District 28 office as well as local libraries.  Many of our students audition for and are accepted to Specialized Arts High Schools including Frank Sinatra and LaGuardia.

We relate art and music to all curriculum areas to align with the new common core learning standards. It is important for students to have an in depth understanding of the formal elements of design which will be used in each project they work on. Students will learn to understand new ways of expressing themselves through various cultures and techniques. Most important, the children should develop a sense of achievement. Achievement instills confidence which raises self esteem.

We encourage our teachers to take their students to visit museums and cultural events throughout the year.  We welcome the Jazz and Lincoln Center to come and perform for our students.  We also welcome outside sources such as Ballet Tech to work with our students who enjoy dancing and are eager to continue dancing.  Our school fosters an environment where art is displayed throughout our building.

The Academy for Excellence through the Arts provides all students, Pre-K through 3rd grade, with a comprehensive visual and performing arts program. Wingspan Arts provides an in-house visual arts residency and all students, Pre-K through 3rd grade, participate. Second and third grade students participate in Literacy through Art and Music and, as a culminating event, students and parents participate and perform in a 1920s living museum event. Students participated in a 12 week residency program with the NY Pops and 92nd Street Y.

Queens Gateway to Health Sciences Secondary School is a screened school with the emphasis on health careers and the sciences. There is a full-time art teacher on staff who provides art instruction to students who are required to complete courses in art necessary for graduation.

We offer basic Studio Arts for the required art credit. We also offer a Graphic Design class to students who have passed Studio Arts. This 
class doubles as a yearbook production class and an advanced art class. Students learn design skills using Adobe Photoshop and Adobe Illustrator to create graphic design projects, and how to create dynamic layouts. These skills enhance our yearbook production.

It is our goal to expose our students to at least three art forms in their academic careers. Currently, we have programs in visual arts, media arts, music, dance and theater. There are additional opportunities through joint programs with the other schools in our building, with an emphasis on performance. Each term, we have performances which showcase our students' accomplishments in the areas of visual arts, media arts, music, dance, theater or musical theater.

Jamaica Children's School is committed to arts education. Every student has visual art twice weekly and music every week. Children have the opportunity to explore a variety of art mediums including painting and sculpture. They learn about different artists each month and analyze their work.  

In music, children learn about instruments, musicians, and cultural music from around the world. They explore a variety of instruments and learn new songs. Children perform several times a year for their peers and families. 

Additionally, all students participate in a weekly Community Meeting. During this time, children participate in dance and theater connected to our core values.  As we continue to grow and add new grades to our school, we look forward to developing a full performing arts program.

HALA is an arts-themed school that integrates arts into all academic classes, and provides a rich variety of arts themed curriculum additionally both during and after school. Students select visual arts, music, or creative writing and are provided with arts instruction every day as 9th and 10th graders. 10th and 11th grade students also select into arts-themed advisories.
Students also participate in extra-curricular arts instruction, including HALA NOW, and after-school arts collective run in collaboration with Queens Museum of Art. In addition Lincoln Center provides the Learning English and Drama program to ELL Students. Students also participate in Drama Club, Mural Club and Dance Club.
Students at HALA have the opportunity to earn a Chancellor's Endorsed Diploma with Distinction in the Arts.

We focus on music in the form of Introduction to Music and Music History classes. These are required for all students. Additionally, we have ensemble classes based on student interest. For example, we have Rock Band Ensemble, Jazz Band Ensemble and String Ensemble. Students in each of the ensemble classes perform in semester culminating concerts. Additioally, we provide students with photography classes and 3D modeling. This year, we introduced a visual arts class that includes sculpting, drawing and photography through a partnership with Abrons Art Program.

During the 2016-2017 school year, our school provided 6th, 7th and 8th  grade students with a purposeful art education. Students were provided with a full time NYS licensed art teacher and a part-time NYS licensed music teacher. Each student took a visual arts class over the course of this school year. 8th grade students were provided with music or visual arts for a full year.Students also had the opportunity to participate in our Broadway Junior program. This allowed students to gain insight and experience within theater. Overall, we hope to continue to grow our arts program in the 2017-2018 school year. We will continue to participate in the Broadway Junior program as well.

Q42_R1_C1: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
Q44_1: Our teachers collaboratively plan and infuse arts into our curriculum. Our students are encouraged to attend more museums and cultural events. Our teachers chaperone students on trips to the museums. We are a performance based performance assessment school, and our students create and develop projects for formative assessments throughout the year.

Public School 349 currently serves students in Pre-Kindergarten, Kindergarten, 1st grade and 2nd grade.  Providing music and visual arts is an important part of our curriculum. Our music program, in collaboration with “Music in Brain”, is inspired by scientific and neurological research linking music and cognitive development. Music has a significant effect on the way our brains develop and function. When children receive sequential music instruction, it can impact their proficiency in language, reading, math and cognition. Our visual arts instruction increases children's awareness of their physical environment, extends and develops the use of the senses and encourages inventive thinking. This year, we will continue to add other art disciplines to our programs in collaboration with a residency program.

The school now has 4 school bands: 3 concert bands (beginner, intermediate, and advanced) and a jazz band. The bands competed in the Six Flags New England Music in the Parks Competition.  Students were also exposed to the arts through the Improvisation theater class and the photography class. The computer class is related to the arts through its web design component. Students also have the opportunity to participate in the school's cultural show which includes performances in dance, spoken word, vocal music, and instrumental music.
Q45_1: The school has a math and science focus with many math/science electives. The arts are therefore limited because of scheduling constraints.

Q44_1: Choir I and Choir II Course Description This beginning course is designed for students experiencing their first vocal/choral class. This level emphasizes fundamental vocal development, music literacy, and the introduction to ensemble singing. The four learning strands found throughout the curriculum require performance, musical knowledge, creativity/improvisation, and musical connections at a fundamental level. Opportunities are provided for students to explore ways in which the content of the various disciplines, within and outside the arts are interrelated with those of music. Unit/Length SEMESTERS 1 and 2, 2 Credits, UA1, 2 Learner Outcomes based on Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts: Music Indicators/ Essential Questions Standards based Skills/Concepts Formative/Summative Assessment 1st Nine Weeks What is correct posture and why is it important? How do you produce proper diction? How does a song change without accompaniment? When is adjusting intonation important? How do you improve blend and balance within an ensemble? Why are forms of musical expression important when singing a song? What gestures does a conductor use to create the appropriate expressions and meaning of a song? Why is movement important when warming up the voice? Why is it important to listen to various styles and genres of music? What are important components of a choral score? How are emotions expressed from the composer on a sheet of music? Vocal Skills Techniques Analyzing Pre-Test Singing

The arts program fully embraces STEM to STEAM as our model. The objective of the STEAM movement is to transform research policy to place Art and Design at the center of STEM and encourage integration of Art and Design across all subject areas. This goal is achieved through project based learning throughout the arts program which is integrated with the curriculum of all students grades Pre K - through 5.The arts program also includes dance and chorus to further expand the arts as a foundation in our student learning. Finally,our strong partnership with the arts agency, Marquis Studios, supports student engagement in many forms of visual and performing arts, including but not limited to architecture, puppetry, and music.
Q45_1: As a showcase school the halls and classrooms are rich with art work completed by our talented students. In addition, our annual performances include choral and dance entertainment provided by the chorus and dance teachers.

Q44_1: Forest Hills High School’s Academy of Vocal and Instrumental Music and Drama Academy provide students with rigorous conservatory style training and a challenging academic program. The Academy of Vocal and Instrumental Music provides intensive choral instruction and intensive instruction on all band and orchestral instruments covering music theory, composition and history. Instrumental Music students participate in Jazz Band, Beginning Band, Intermediate Band, Symphonic Concert Band, Beginning Strings, Intermediate Strings, Symphonic Orchestra, Beginning Percussion and Advanced Percussion Ensemble. Vocal Music students participate in Vocal Training, Women's Chorus and Concert Choir. Students perform in the Winter Concert and Spring Arts Festival. Drama Academy provides students the opportunity to study the dramatic arts through a rigorous and specialized program involving acting, directing, play writing, film making and play productions. The Fall and Spring Play Pro theater productions showcase the arts talents of FHHS students.

The arts mission at Hillcrest is to provide every student a robust arts education modeled on New York State requirements and NYC’s Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts. The courses offered allow students to participate at all levels, from introductory to advanced, and in a variety of mediums such as strings, orchestra, chorus, drum line, fine art, media arts, theater and art history. The school also offers consecutive arts programs in Music, Theater and Visual Art through the Media, Arts and Music or Theater Small Learning Communities. Performing opportunities include two Festivals of the Arts, a full production musical and Senior and Junior theater productions at the school. Students also enter citywide visual and performing arts contests as part of the school’s enrichment activities and local community outreach includes sending performing groups to other schools, as well as hosting.

All students take art and music for a ½ year each. Dance is offered in the physical education department. Chorus is offered as a club. The art sequence includes required courses in drawing and painting techniques, color theory, and design principles. Students choose from 3 pathways: Commercial Art, Graphic Communications, and Web Design. Commercial Art students use traditional art media and computer applications, prepare portfolios, take the industry standards-based Skills USA exam, and earn 6 credits from Queensborough Community College. Graphic Communications focuses on the creative use of computer applications, digital photography, and commercial printing, while Web Design focuses on designing for the web, including both hand coding and computer applications. Students take Adobe certification examinations at the end of these sequences. All visual art students have the opportunity to apply for internships and work-based learning opportunities and receive CTE endorsements on their diplomas.

PS 35 provides a rigorous, sequential arts program that is based on the NYC Blueprint for the Arts. The interdisciplinary units are utilized to strengthen self-awareness, higher thinking skills, creative problem-solving, and means of self-expression. Students of PS 35 contribute successfully to city- and borough-wide arts competition. In addition, PS 35 offers an advanced music program, participation in the school band, ballroom dancing, and trips to various cultural organizations.

Classroom teachers provide arts instruction in their classroom by doing school assemblies and presentations such as Singsation and dance festival. Scholars have been exposed to the visual arts by doing project based assignments. P.S. 36 had the opportunity to partner with this school year with the New York City Ballet. The Third Grade scholars learned the art form of ballet with infused literacy components through the company's Nutcracker Project. Scholars in Kindergarten and First Grade learned basic art skills such as using lines to make self-portraits and the use of clay to make designs. Students in Grade 4 and 5 participate in clubs. there are scholars who are in a dance or music.  Grade 4 continues to do ballroom dancing with Dancing Classrooms. A group of 10 scholars in Grade 5 participates in a photography club after-school program facilitated by The Project Photo Organization. A group of 25 scholars in Grades 3 and 4 participate in an arts after-school program facilitated by Jamaica Arts Center for Learning.

PS37Q, The Cynthia Jenkins School, makes the Arts a priority to ensure that students have a nurturing and diverse learning experience. A teacher of visual arts provides instruction to all students in addition to the instruction of classroom teachers who integrate the arts to include dance, music and theater.  The implementation of various art clubs provide enrichment to selected students in grades 3 to 5. Field trips and assemblies are used to integrate all 4 forms of the arts into the learning experience of students. The Blueprint for Teaching and Learning the Arts is used to guide the implementation of the PS37Q art instructional program. An interdisciplinary approach to teaching the arts focuses on literacy with social studies connections, self expression and talent development.  Students are encouraged to use the arts to understand historical context and study cultural diversity. Students utilize artistic expression and their imagination to practice their skills as speakers, listeners, writers, designers, visual artists, actors, singers, dancers, researchers, critics and collaborators. Parents are invited to participate in art workshops and museum trips. Students' artwork is prominently displayed in hallways and classrooms to celebrate their talents and learning.

Arts education is vitally important to the full development of children. Providing instruction in the arts has many benefits . Arts education can help to improve the student's overall academic performance, as well as help to develop the skills that are needed for the 21st century, such as critical thinking, creative problem solving, effective communication, teamwork and more. The arts provide an avenue that allows children to express themselves creatively and lift their self esteem. Our goal is to help students become more knowledgeable in the four arts disciplines (visual arts, music, dance, and theater. In the four arts disciplines, students use their imagination make decisions, problem solve, and work together in groups cooperatively .They have hands on learning and make social ,cultural and historical connections. Students learn how to reflect ,analyze and evaluate their own, and their classmates work. These skills are then incorporated in the content areas and the lives of our students.

Q42_R1_C1: Learning through an Expanded Arts Program
Q44_1: It is the goal of our school to add onto our arts program. We are looking for resources and funding to incorporate dance, music, visual arts and theater.

• To develop a literacy-based art experience aligned with the Arts Blueprints • Develop art skills, explore various techniques incorporating the principles and elements of art • To develop critical thinking through art critiques • To develop an extensive vocabulary art base • Develop organizational skills • To further refine learned skills and develop new techniques and strategies • The music program in PS 95 Q is aligned to The Blueprint for the Arts • The goals of the music program this year was to 1) introduce musical concepts such as rhythm, melody and harmony to as many students 2) to have students engaged in practicing and applying the musical concepts by clapping, tapping or singing.

This school year we were successful in offering our students all three electives, dance, music, visual arts.  We also received a grant which allowed us to have theater by Centre Stage/Queens Theatre In the Park as an after-school program.  We hope that we will get more funding for the arts so we can also have clubs for the various art forms.

Q37_4: Attended Parent Workshops in the Arts
Q42_R1_C1: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
Q44_1:
This year PS/IS116Q provided students with 2 major art programs. We have a full-time Visual Arts teacher with a classroom as a dedicated art space where students in Grades K-8 received regular instruction in the Visual Arts. Lessons are congruent with the Visual Arts Blueprint. Our Art teacher has been attending monthly Arts Mondays professional development via the Office of Arts and Special Projects, Queens South to learn the latest practices in formative assessment in the Arts. Student work has been entered into various contests and exhibition opportunities, through which our students have had the experience of seeing their work on display in a larger community setting.
Our school continues its partnership with Lincoln Center to provide students with engagement in the arts via residencies with teaching artists at our school in music, drama/theater, dance and visual arts. Students see professional performances at Lincoln Center as well as at our school where families are also invited to attend Family Events. 
This year's instruction is culminating in a joint effort between our art teacher and Lincoln Center to showcase student work at the school with an evening exhibit of student work along with dinner, workshops and a live concert provided by Lincoln Center. We expect both of these venues for artistic expression and engagement to continue next year.
Q45_1: The arts are essential for engaging students at school. Budgets need to be increased for consumables in an art program, as well as monies provided to improve staffing for implementing existing programs.

Q44_1: Public School 131 has a strong commitment to arts education and it offers many opportunities for its students to experience different arts disciplines. Our arts faculty is fully State certified and provides rich and creative standards based instruction as well as articulating and integrating the arts into classroom instruction in conjunction with the CCLS. This year our students participated in many assemblies as well as performances outside of the school and outreach activities with other area organizations. PS 131 provided additional arts groups such as the Abigail Adams Children’s Chorus. These experiences allowed our children to be 'creators', have literacy in the arts, make connections with other disciplines, be aware of their community and cultural resources, develop cooperation and appreciation for the talents of different artists and grow into lifelong learners of the arts.

PS 135's art program includes instruction in visual arts, drama, dance and music. The arts are integrated into the students day through cluster programs as well as classroom teacher led instruction. Teachers   integrate the arts with other subject areas such as ELA, Social Studies and Science to provide students with learning opportunities that engage all their learning styles. We feel that it is important to expose our students to the world of the creative arts to engage them in learning an help them become a more well rounded individual in life.

Q42_R1_C1: Learning through an Expanded Arts Program

Q44_1:
PS/MS 147Q The Ronald McNair School, provides students with an outlet of expression through the arts.  Our visual arts teacher provides instruction to students in Grades Pre-K through 5 and conducts an art club for students in Grades 3-8.  Our classroom teachers also integrate visual arts throughout units of study.  The Blueprint for Teaching and Learning the Arts is used to guide the implementation of the art instructional program in our school community.
Our theater teacher provides our students in Grade 5-8 instruction in theater and set design.  Our interdisciplinary approach to teaching the arts focus on literacy and social studies.  Students are encouraged to use the arts to understand historical context and study cultural diversity.  
Music instruction is provided to our students in Grades 6-8.  Keyboard and guitar is taught throughout the school year.  Students also have an opportunity to audition for the band.  The band includes drums, wood wind and brass instruments.  Our middle school band performs at various school and community events.  Students’ artistic talents are celebrated during assembly programs, theater productions, art displays, and district events.

The programs that were hosted this school year, did not require in-house certified staff. The funds were not available to have residencies. Through a grant given by our local Councilman, we were able to host the DIVAS for Social Justice program which is Digital, Interactive, Visual Arts in Sciences. Our classroom teachers incorporated arts in their curriculum. The music cluster teacher( K-5) teaches music appreciation and has students she works with for chorus. In addition, students visited Carnegie Hall twice this school year and as a collective we incorporated theater and art clubs on Friday afternoons.  Our goal is to expand our arts program to include dance, more drama, and continued photography.

The ultimate goal of our school arts program is to provide all students an increased understanding of art history. Students will learn to compare diverse art forms and develop a respect for the arts. In addition students will discover, develop and enhance their personal abilities.

The Linden-Renaissance Middle School offers a rich foundation in the Arts supported by Black Spectrum Theater. All students enrolled in our school are required to study visual arts, drama, theater, video/music recording, dance and music. This year our sixth graders focused on video production in our state -of -the Arts recording studio. The students perform live for their friends, family and community four times a year. We have an after school instrumental band, dance team, cartooning/animation and theater production provided by certified arts teachers.

This year P.S. 195 was awarded a STEM Magnet grant which will focus on multi-media arts. currently, with the help of LAMP, 5th grade students are producing a video presentation which highlights the many wonderful opportunities that will be available from animation and music to robotics. At PS 195, we are always committed to offering students a well balanced education in the arts. Early childhood students receive general music classes by a licensed music teacher. We also provide Wind Band, Violin, Little Kids Rock Band, Chorus and Step Dancing. All of our groups participate in performances throughout the school year.

We currently have a full time licensed music teacher. Every class receives music instruction at least once a week in the music studio. All students participate in three annually themed arts assemblies. 
Students also engage in trips that are centered around the arts.

At Excelsior Preparatory High School we believe that a rich arts program with a strong studio and performance component is essential to the academic growth of our students. One of our goals is to provide each student with a great overall art experience. All Bands are proud to play at our school's various assemblies, concerts and contests throughout the year. Our Band has also played in concert along with the Five Towns College Concert Band. We are very excited to see the growth of the arts over the last few years, and will continue to strive for growth. Currently we offer Studio and Media Arts courses, Concert Band, and Advanced Band. We hope to incorporate AP Studio Art courses in the future.

he arts are an integral part of PS/IS 268's curriculum. We strive to fully realize the goals and objectives of the Blueprint for the Arts and enrich the academic program. We meaningfully integrate the arts into all curriculum areas to enhance learning. Students in 4th and 7th grade have had the opportunity to participate in CAE's Arts Engage Initiative. This program uses drama to support the Social Studies curriculum. CAE's Runaway Arts program incorporates visual arts with 8th grade Social Studies. Students have had their artwork showcased at the Queens Borough Art Show. Students in grades 3 through 8 had the opportunity to be part of the AMP UP NYC and Little Kids Rock Modern Band program. Dance students had the opportunity to perform at Queens Borough Art Show. Students in grades 7 and 8 are provided with opportunities to specialize in one art form. They are supported in creating portfolios and preparing for auditions if they are interested in attending a specialized art school.

The Gordon Parks School for Inquisitive Minds continues to inspire and encourage excellence. Students in grades K-3 received instruction in at least two separate arts disciplines. Students in grades 4-8 were given the opportunity to select their preferred arts discipline. Beginning in the 2016-17 school year we are very excited to offer middle school students the option of choosing an arts major and minor discipline. This not only enables us to better meet NYSED requirements regarding middle school arts instruction but has the added benefit of empowering us to offer students the possibility of 9 years of continuous progressive instruction in their preferred arts discipline.

The Preparatory Academy for Writers offers Theatre Arts and Audio/Video Production classes to both high school and middle school students. An Audio club, a Production club and an acting group are open to all students. Additionally, we have talent shows twice a year. This year, we introduced a moving image/video production program which allows students to collaboratively create short films and participate in all aspects of the production process from pre-production planning to post-production editing. Student Films are screened and shared out with the school as part of a showcase.

Our school is a Career & Technical Education School with a focus on Information Technology and Finance. Our Arts courses are technology based. We offer Graphic Design, Web Design and the Adobe Photoshop certification. We also provide arts opportunities through clubs and after school. Those programs are supported by The Future Project a not for profit CBO we work with.

Our art teachers annually propose art elective courses to our student body and sections open based on student interest. To date we've taught digital media, digital photo, graphic design, drawing, mixed media, chorus, origami, film, theatre arts, and three dimensional sculpture. We are constantly expanding our elective course offerings.

Our students participate in the arts in multiple ways both in and out of school through collaborations with outside organizations as well as museums and other cultural centers. Our students have enjoyed

During the first quarter of school, sixth grade students are introduced to the following art forms: Dance, Music, and Visual Arts. During this time, the Arts Department faculty holds internal auditions in which students gain admission into one art studio for the duration of their time at school (6th, 7th and 8th grade). Sixth grade students participate in their studio three times a week. Seventh classes are held four times a week, and 8th grade students attend studio 5 times a week. The arts department holds two festivals each year, which include a combination of 6-8th grade students in each art form.

P.S. 360Q currently has a full time licensed music teacher. Every class receives music twice a week. Students are currently receiving keyboard instruction.  All students participate in assemblies throughout the school year.  

We also have a full time art teacher. All students receive art instruction in the art studio twice a week. Art projects/student work are displayed throughout the school.  

The arts programs at P.S. 360 are aligned to the  NYC DOE Blueprint for the Arts.

At Mathematics, Science Research and Technology high school, the arts program has been integrated into the CORE curriculum. Teachers are planning integrated lessons with the art teacher. The Social Studies Department works with the art teacher to teach students the art work of different eras such as Medieval, Renaissance and modern times. Students are learning about artists like Pietro Lorenzetti, Michelangelo, Leonardo da Vinci, Vincent Van Gogh, Francisco De Goya and Pablo Picasso. Students are exposed to different forms of arts such as dancing, music, and theater. They visit the American Museum of Natural History, Brooklyn Museum, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Museum of Modern art (MOMA) and other institutions such as Brooklyn Academy of Music, Carnegie, Repertorio (Latino Theater) and Manhattan Theater Club. The school has created partnerships with these organizations and has had artists visit classrooms to discuss their art work. Students make connections with the socio-cultural and historical significance of theater. This year, Mathematics, Science Research and Technology High School's goals are to

 • Integrate arts into all content areas.
 • Create partnerships with various arts organizations to enrich the culture of our students.

 Mathematics, Science Research and Technology High School provides students the opportunity to earn more than one credit in visual arts. Students are able to express themselves through the arts and build skills and knowledge in a variety of forms. Arts enrich our learning community.

Q37_4: Attended parent workshops (hands on & informational sessions)
Q44_1: One of our goals for the art programs at P.S. 2Q is to create opportunities for students to recognize the social, cultural, and historical significance of art, and connect the arts to other disciplines. In order to do this, students must be taught to refine their observation, problem–solving skills, develop a more extensive visual vocabulary, read and write about art to reinforce literacy skills and interpret the arts through discussion. This is achieved through a differentiated and multi-sensory approach to learning. Not only do our classroom teachers teach various art forms throughout the year in content areas, we are also fortunate enough to have community-based arts partnerships as well. Another goal at P.S. 2Q is to continue the current partnerships, to expand the programs offered to include more students, and to add more variety to the programs offered. We were very grateful to provide multiple programs to our students this year, including visual arts instruction, dance, music, and dramatic arts. Through these partnerships we hope to offer students exposure to a variety of art forms and media through weekly sessions with resident artists, field trips and school art projects. Finally, we strive for our students to become lifelong learners and advocates for the arts.

I.S. 10Q, provides the student with a full theater program that instructs the students in the various aspects of theater production; i.e., stage management, costume design, props, scenic design and acting. The visual art classes provide the students with exploring the areas of two dimensional drawing, sculpting, and drafting. In the Chorus class, the students are able to explore the world of music by learning how to read sheet music, and perform using only the strength and tone of their voices. With the addition of guitar classes, our music classes have gained strength and popularity among the students.

Our goal is to use the NYC DOE Blueprint as a guide to reinforce the arts and its cultural significance in their every day lives. Students are exposed to different artistic styles within the fine arts as well as within the folk art traditions. Students are intellectually engaged during arts instruction while mastering art making techniques. Teachers assess their students, and give them feedback and next steps, while the assessments help plan for further instruction. Students are motivated to make meaningful connections to other content areas and their lives beyond the classroom.

At P.S. 17 we believe that the arts are essential to a child's academic and social-emotional development. Our arts teachers' schedules provide children with opportunities to participate in band, keyboarding, recorder lessons, visual arts, and theater performances. Our arts partners include: 
•Alvin Ailey 
•Music and the Brain 
•Community Word
•Studio in a School 
•NY Cares 
•CASA Flushing Town Hall 
•Carnegie Hall
•Disney Musicals in Schools

Q43_10: peer assessments using checklists recorded on video
Q44_1: At PS 69Q, “The School of Cultural & Performing Arts”, the arts are alive and thriving. Our students are engaged in a variety of multiple arts and enrichment activities that reflect our diverse and multicultural school community. Grants from our arts partner City Lore Inc. brought residencies in songwriting, Indo-Caribbean dance, music and visual arts to our students while a CASA grant afforded them musical theater and theater trips. Little Kids Rock provided a music grant enabling student participation in programs before and after school in addition to instruction already offered to 150 students in guitar, violin and wind instruments in Grades 3, 4 and 5. Our award winning choral program continues to flourish, receiving top ratings at NYSSMA festivals. Our Artist in Residence programs continue to bring direct arts instruction to all our students while focusing on our magnet theme of Asia this year and Africa next year.  Multiple celebrations and performances featuring these residency and musical programs are held during the school year. We are a SEM school engaging in multiple enrichment opportunities through directed magnet or interest-based enrichment clusters in Grade 2, 4 & 5 while early childhood students receive arts instruction in our EaGLE program. We will continue our rich, successful cultural arts partnerships with City Lore, JALC, Pandora, Little Kids Rock, Dancing Classrooms, Inside Broadway and Joyce Theater. Our goal at PS 69Q is to provide comprehensive, rich arts experiences that educate the whole student.
Q45_1: At P.S. 69Q, we strive for an instructionally focused learning environment emphasizing our multicultural and diverse background of 1,048 students who have 24 different home languages and cultures. We are "The School of Cultural and Performing Arts" and endeavor to offer as many arts experiences to our students as possible. We believe that the arts play a vital role in the development of our students not just academically but in their social and emotional growth as well. All students are encouraged to be meaningfully and thoughtfully engaged in academic, artistic, collaborative and socially conscious tasks where every student is accepted and honored for their accomplishments, potential and individuality.  We annually rotate our magnet theme between Asia, Africa and the Americas, integrating these themes throughout our arts curriculum, residency programs, cultural events, multiple school music celebrations and performances while making connections to our students own varied unique cultural experiences. We embrace all opportunities to collaborate with a variety of arts partners that are brought into our school through federal and state grants, the public sector, NYC DOE approved arts partners and the families of our students.

Q44_1: The elementary art program in P.S.70Q provides activities in drawing, painting, art history, sculpture, printmaking and crafts. The program is sequentially developed on disciplined based art education and is aligned with the New York City Blueprint For Teaching and Learning in Visual Arts and Common Core Standards. Art concepts are taught through activities based on the elements of design: line, shape, form, texture, space, color and value. Art instruction lends itself to integrating with other subject areas. The purposes of these activities are to help students develop awareness of, and appreciation for, the skills in communicating through art, and a feeling of pride and satisfaction in their work. Multicultural art activities are infused into the curriculum. Art in the elementary school gives students the opportunity to develop an interest in art appreciation and to develop critical and creative thinking skills. The music program at P.S.70Q, which also follows the standards, provides an opportunity for all students to receive a comprehensive performance-based music education. Through the study of a wide range of music literature students can become intelligent consumers, producers, and/or creators of music. The high level of motivation required for performance courses is an invaluable asset to educational growth. School performances contribute to developing a sense of responsibility in students.

While we strive to maximize critical-thinking skills and rigorous academic learning tasks, we equally prioritize access to the Arts.  This year, in addition to instrumental music classes during the day, we created a before-school violin sectional for Kindergartners, a recorder sectional for 3rd-graders, and a wind and percussion ensemble for 4th- and 5th-graders.  We also hired a certified visual arts teacher who services classes across all grades (PK-5), and has turned our school's main lobby into a revolving art gallery.  Additionally, we began our first-ever afterschool theater program this spring and will be staging "The Lion King" in June.  We were fortunate to offer our students the "Arts for All" and "Enact" music and theater residency programs again this year, and we received a grant to offer 4th- and 5th-grade students a 12-week, direct-instruction dance residency through Alvin Ailey.  We will continue searching for grants and other means to bring in more and more music, visual arts, theater and dance programs.

Our goal this year has been to continue to educate the whole child and help build well rounded students. Collections of student work show the students' growth as learners. We continue to align our arts programs with the core curriculum and the standards from the Blueprint for Learning the Arts so that we establish an alignment of arts disciplines with academic disciplines. We are also maintaining our partnerships with Music and the Brain, Little Kids Rock, and Studio in a School to help develop higher level cognitive abilities within our students. Through the arts, students develop a balance in a variety of subjects. Our aim is to create students who are better able to express their creativity and be successful in life.

All of our students participated in visual arts through our STEAM Art/Media program. Elements of dance and drama along with music are all incorporated into all of our Arts classes. Our Pre-K classes explored the voice and keeping beat through movement and responsive listening. Our Kindergarten classes continued from Pre-k with an expansion of song and dance repertoire. Grades one and two followed the Weill Music Institute’s “Musical Explorers” curriculum. Grade three followed the Weill Music Institute’s “LinkUp!: program. Grades 4 four and five - also followed the Weill Music Institute’s “LinkUp! program. In addition our Grade five students participated in a band program.

At P.S. 85 students are engaged in music, theater, visual arts and dance instruction. Students in grades 1-5 are engaged in a weekly enrichment that includes arts programming as well. In addition, classroom teachers incorporate art into daily instruction.

Our goal is to continue to incorporate art into other subject areas, such as social studies and science. We encourage creativity in all students. We received a STEAM Grant to help further incorporate art into our curriculum.  The focus will be Engineering, Architecture and the Arts.  
We also provide musical instruction that is branching out to all subject areas, initiated by our two talented music teachers. Music is also valued in our ESL program. One bilingual teacher utilizes a piano in his classroom to further vocabulary instruction. 
Our after school program includes morning instruction to band and chorus members. The Arts and Literacy program provides theater (including video), dance, art and music.

Community School 111Q scholars receive dance instruction in our school dance studio which was constructed in 2006 with funding from the NY City Council. Dance residencies are provided by cultural institutions and community arts foundations such as Alvin Ailey. Visual arts instruction is provided by a full time art teacher to all grades PreK-8. Art activities are based on the NYC Blueprint for the Arts and New York State Standards for Visual Arts. Students participate in citywide contests and school exhibitions, such as our Annual Student Art Festival held in June. As a Community School we have a number of partnerships with arts and media institutions such as Studio In A School, The Museum of the Moving Image, and Lincoln Center Education. Funding for Alvin Ailey is provided by City Council member Jimmy Van Bramer. With the addition of our music program this year, scholars in grades 6-8 have been introduced to modern band instruments through hands on learning. Elementary scholars also have weekly music instruction. Art and Music lunch time clubs also are implemented weekly.

Q30_6: ‘Education: Discovering the Promise of Reality’  Exhibit
Q44_1: Our goals are: •To support the academic development of our students through an integrated, comprehensive arts curriculum. •To increase students' content knowledge through the various art forms. •To boost students’ self confidence through participation in the arts. •To gain knowledge of different types of mediums in the Visual Arts, using these for greater self-expression. •To teach students to express their thinking using body movement and language.

PS 122 believes the arts are an integral component of a child’s education. The arts complement academics in literacy, mathematics, technology, and all other content areas. All students at PS 122 are provided with arts education in various art forms. The arts help develop the whole child and nurture their talents and interests. In grades 4-8, students have the option to participate in Band or Chorus. Our middle school has a talent show to showcase talent in the arts. In addition, students participate in a club of their choice, including dance, music, and fine arts. Parents are partners in the arts and participate in art education workshops and events. Families are invited to attend school concerts, events, Family Night, Hobby Night, Dance Festival, Culture Night, and art trips. Students and families are given free passes to the Noguchi Museum in Long Island City. Students who participate in American Ballroom Theater in fifth grade are given an opportunity to continue dance instruction in Manhattan for a nominal fee. An event was sponsored for cultural organizations to introduce their programs and encourage family participation. Free passes to museums were given to families who attended the workshop. The school participates in Donors Choose and Materials for the Arts in order to obtain materials for art education. Many of our graduating 8th graders with talents and interest in the arts are accepted by specialized arts high schools.

This year at The Albert Shanker School for Visual and Performing Art we continued to offer a robust arts program including visual arts, chorus, core music, drama, musical theater, and dance. As we do each year, in 2016-2017 we had three performances: a winter concert, a collaborative spring musical, performances at graduation along with a talent show and multicultural festival. This year we partnered with community based organizations such as Alvin Ailey, Inside Broadway, Socrates Sculpture Park and The Community Word Project in order to grow and realize our commitment to the arts .Over the course of their three years of study, students receive instruction in each of these disciplines working not only toward proficiency in basic skills but in a meaning making process helping to build life-long learners who are critical, introspective thinkers. Looking forward to the 2017-2018 school year, we are looking to continue to support and grow our art department with partnerships and grants.

P.S./I.S. 127 provides music and visual arts programs to all students from grades Pre-K - 8. This year we were also fortunate enough to welcome several artistic residencies into our building to provide additional enrichment opportunities.  These partnerships included Flamenco Vivo Carlota Santana, Studio Arts, Jazz at Lincoln Center, and Disney Musicals in Schools!  What is so special about these enrichment opportunities is that students across all of the educational settings that we have in the building are afforded the opportunity to be exposed to and interact with the arts!

School budgets are shrinking across the city, but at Steinway Intermediate School 141, we make every attempt to keep the arts a top priority in our students' education. Our music classes include music theory, music history, piano choral music programs. Our art teachers bring the joy of visual and computer arts to all our students. As educators, we understand that our students all have individual strengths and talents. It is our goal to always ensure that these strengths and talents are shared and celebrated. As part of our ongoing effort to showcase our students' talents, we have incorporated several stage performances into our school year such as Sounds of the Season, Poetry Slam, Spring Arts Showcase, Broadway Jr. Musical, Man in the Mirror: Respect for All Showcase and the Multicultural Dance Festival. Additionally, computer art allows our students to be creative using technology. As a result of our students' contributions, the arts program is flourishing within our school community and continues to be celebrated and appreciated.

Q30_6: professional film/video companies, unions, and individuals
Q44_1: Every year in New York City, the television and film production industry generates over $5 billion and supports over 100,000 jobs. In 2007, a team of industry professionals and educators, encouraged by the New York Production Alliance (NYPA), an industry advocacy organization, began to define how the production industry and public education could collaborate to support a small and rigorous Career and Technical Education (CTE) school. The result was the Academy for Careers in Television and Film (TvF), which opened its doors to its first freshman class in September 2008. Now located on the waterfront at the new Hunter’s Point Campus in Queens, TvF serves over 540 NYC students in grades 9 through 12. As a CTE high school, all of TvF’s students simultaneously participate in a rigorous academic program while receiving serious professional instruction. In order to ensure that all graduates are prepared for the workplace, TvF is committed to providing our students with the opportunity to work alongside industry professionals in authentic work experiences. To date, our school has provided internships to over 160 of our students in film/video organizations such as WNET, Panavision, KAS Stage Lighting, Gotham Sound, Silvercup Studios, Timberlake Studios, Cinemaworld Studios, Eclectic Props, Eastern Effect, Contesta Rock Hair, Navasync, Bronx Docs, Alien Dawn Productions, and The Good Wife.

The students participate in the New Victory Theatre program and The Moving Image film production. The students attend multiple functions related to the arts via school trips. Broadway shows, Medieval Times, etc

It is our goal to continue to expose our students to as many areas of the arts as possible. Currently, we have a visual arts, theater and music program which focuses on arts appreciation! We have a parntership with Studio in A School where students are exposed to visual arts through a residency program throughout the school year.

The arts programs at P.S. 149 continues to grow and evolve with each school year. Current programs offered include: Music and the Brain, music appreciation, band, recorder, chorus, visual arts and lunch clubs in the arts. The CUNY Creative Arts Team offers enriching literacy based activities incorporating elements of drama to motivate our youngest of learners. Our goal has been to utilize all tools available through targeted professional development and current educational research studies (personal and published), carefully aligning instruction to the Common Core State Standards while infusing the arts to enrich learning experiences for students in K-5. We encourage community involvement by providing special events throughout the year to all stakeholders (parents, students and teachers).

The mission of PS 150Q is to provide our students with instruction and hands-on learning activities in all the art disciplines, such as music, theater, visual art, and dance.  We believe that by tapping into our students’ creative and artistic abilities, it will allow them to be critical thinkers and life-long learners.
