Q45_1: Our students receive art instruction in music, dance, art and drama.  Students are able to audition and participate in band and chorus, and it is done within the school day.  There is an afterschool select chorus. There is a winter and spring concert. The fifth graders each year put together an amazing play. In May, we have a big art show to demonstrate all the students pieces.  All presentations are well attended by the parents.

Q44_1: The Mary D. Carter school continues to build upon its arts program.  In addition to the established music program, this year marks the first full year of a visual arts program.  Drawing upon classroom teachers and the resources of artistic organizations, students are given access to a critical aspect of a worldly education. The school intends to maintain their established dedication to the arts and will continue to offer the same and/or similar programs to current and future students.

Arts education strengthens our goal for children given the benefits it provides in fostering academic achievement. At P.S. 152 the arts are weaved into each daily instructional experience. We provide our students with in-house arts instruction consisting in music, theater, and visual arts provided by licensed teachers on staff and artists in residence from arts organizations. Residencies include 10-week cycles provided via our partnership with Marquis Studios to children in K through 5 and a second collaboration with Dancing Classrooms offered to our fifth graders. Arts instruction includes movement and expressive theater for all of our students. Additionally, the following Arts programs are provided: Percussion to Grade 3, Islamic Arts studies to Grades 4; Visual Arts (Origami) to Grade 4; Photography and Ballroom Dancing to Grade 5. The arts will continue to be the forum to build emotional maturity, physical development, and social awareness.

P.S. 166Q has aligned the curriculum to the CCLS. Teachers design lessons that meet the needs of their students. The students work on project-based activities that allow them to explore and discover. This year our students had the opportunity to participate in cultural performances, visit museums, exhibit art and engage in daily fitness breaks to promote wellness. Our music teacher has organized performances and concerts for all of our students. Our music room has keyboards, guitars and a drum set where the children can learn to read and play music. Teachers have incorporated the arts in their classrooms using a multidisciplinary approach. Outside supporters from our community are always invited to be part of the students learning experiences. Our first graders participated in the Literature at Play program from the New York City Children's Theater and they had the opportunity to bring books to life. The fourth grade children learned how to ballroom dance. Long Island City YMCA created dance routines for our whole school during lunch time recess.

Q30_6: MATB, Little Kids Rock, Theatre Crash Course
Q33_6: Flushing Town Hall, Turtle Bay, NY Pops, CUNY Creative Arts
Q44_1: As a Magnet School of the Arts, it is incumbent upon us to incorporate the arts into our core academic areas.  We presently incorporate the arts into all of our Social Studies and Literacy units.  We have also begun infusing the arts into our Math units.  We have a full time art teacher and a full time music teacher.  Students also participate in artist residencies and in school concerts and shows.
Q45_1: At P.S. 171, our classroom teachers have worked diligently to incorporate the arts into their classroom teaching of multiple subjects.  Music, visual arts and movement are all utilized in order to capitalize on different student learning styles.

Q44_1: Students at PS 212 are exposed to the arts on a daily basis.  Children express their creativity through different art forms.  Trips are planned throughout the school year to guarantee children get to experience  different cultural activities.  Students participate in the arts through residency programs both during and after the school day.  Exposure to the arts increases a child's academic performance and opens the world to them.

Our comprehensive arts program focuses on music, dance, visual arts, and theater instruction. We have a licensed music and theater teachers, and a physical education teacher who integrates dance into her instruction. Classroom teachers incorporate the arts into content area study. Our arts partners include Studio In A School and Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater in order to provide our students multiple opportunities to develop their skill sets in the fine arts.

Students at the Louis Armstrong Middle School are given a number of opportunities to participate in the music and art departments. In the 5th grade, all students learn the recorder;sing folk songs from around the world, often celebrating the student’s ancestral heritage, and apply movement to their music making. 6th graders have a number of options that prepare them for continued study in 7th and 8th grade. In general music, students continue using the mallet percussion and drums while learning basic music theory and solfege.In the ensembles: chorus, band and orchestra, students learn how to read music and learn to apply musical notation to a number of genres from the Baroque era to popular music throughout the years. It is the mission of the music department to teach students to be life-long learners. Much emphasis includes working towards preparing students for performing arts high schools to become career and ready in any subject area. In our Art classes, we enable students to use a variety of processes to stimulate creative products, manipulatives, and self-determined learning and making. Students explore all different means of mediums while putting together portfolios for specialized high schools. Art classes are actively engaged in using self and peer assessment to promote growth and revision within their projects. Art students adhere to the blueprints while exploring contemporary movements in the Art world today. Self-contained classes enjoy differentiated Art experiences. All students celebrate yearly in the Art show

PS 228's Comprehensive Arts Program includes an integrated Arts Curriculum for students in Grades pre-k-2. Students benefit from daily opportunities to participate in visual art, theater, dance and music experiences. Artist and Composer of the Month programs develop students' cultural literacy. 2016-2017 Artist in residence partnerships maximized creative arts experiences for all of our students and enhanced the Standards-based PS 228 Arts Curriculum.

Our arts programs consists of a three year sequence for our students. These arts disciplines include: band, chorus, guitar, and visual arts. Our goal is to design coherent curriculum and instruction which incorporates the Common Core Standards, Civics in the Community and the Blue Prints for the Arts.

P.S. 234 The School of Performing Arts and Technology continuously supports the Arts. All students are given the opportunity to showcase their talents and be celebrated. P.S. 234 employs licensed teachers in all Arts disciplines; Visual Arts, Dance, Music, Theater. The school's hallways continue to be a museum of student displays and artwork. All students and teachers participate in concerts, visual art fairs, dance and theater performances several times a month. In addition, all classroom educators teach music, visual arts, dance and theater. Our active PTA also volunteers and continuously contributes to P.S. 234's Art Programs. We have also continued our partnerships with Inside Broadway, Alvin Ailey, NYC Ballet, Ballet Tech, Creative Arts Team and City Harvest. Our goal is to continue to increase our Arts Program in 2016-2017.
Q45_1: P.S. 234 - The School of Performing Arts and Technology is a barrier-free school, in which our arts programming is fully inclusive of all of our students.

Q44_1:
I.S.235,The Academy for New Americans is a unique school designed to serve newcomer students in grades 6-8. Students partake in a variety of projects that allow them to acquire English language skills through the arts. Teachers infuse the arts into their lessons by providing students with opportunities to develop their innate talents through class projects and group assignments. 
This year various cultural groups {City Lore, C.A.S.A., 21st Century Leadership, Center for Arts Education (Historic Hudson Valley)] provided arts instruction (which included visual art, theatre, dance, music).  We also had an F-status art teacher who taught visual art to 70% of our students. All art projects were displayed in an Art exhibit held at the school.  The students' art creation created in conjunction with a City Lore artist will be exhibited in the City Lore Art Gallery through the summer. Students also contributed to the New York Historical Society's permanent art installation "We the People" which was created with donated shoelaces from students from around the city. Students wrote and produced a play with C.A.S.A., that was performed at Queens Theater in the Park.
Q45_1: Since our school services newly arrived immigrant students, the number of students enrolled is small.  Consequently, due to budget constraints, we are unable to provide an arts teacher.  Through Arts grants from the DOE, specifically for Ells, and resources provided by cultural institutions we have been able to provide art to the majority of the students.

Q44_1: Energy Tech High School expanding its existing arts program in the 2016-2017 school year, affording students the opportunity to take Studio Art I, visual arts electives, Theater I, and theater electives.  We are currently preparing to add digital arts and new media technology in the coming year.  In addition to formal classroom experiences, Energy Tech continues to offer supplemental theater programming both in the English Language Arts coursework and after school through the New York City Shakespeare Festival and the CUNY Creative Arts Team.  We have also expanded our after-school offerings to include improv comedy through Upright Citizens Brigade, and have offered a number of in-school and after-school Broadway show trips through a variety of school partnerships.

This year, the Academy for Environmental Leadership offered an AP studio art (drawing - a combination of drawing, painting, printing, all based around marks made by hand on paper/canvas/etc) course for selected seniors. AP students researched topics of interest and examples of art and artists who dealt with those topics, and produced artists' statements for their finished pieces and portfolios. Unfortunately, one period a day for one year was not enough time for students this year to develop the 24 portfolio-quality pieces necessary for application for the AP Studio Art exam.   Three sections of introductory studio art classes (11th Graders and students recovering missing arts credits) produced artwork in a variety of materials and artistic discipline.  Programming for the 2017-18 year is being worked on now to move intro art to 10th grade, so that AP could take place over two school years and students could produce enough artwork to self-curate a strong portfolio and earn college credit.  Various ways of discussing and assessing work were introduced to students in all classes, and projects involve student writing and current-event topics to engage understanding of the world and self.

P.S. 280Q believes that the arts are a fundamental aspect of education that provides an environment where students can develop their potential as individuals in personal, social, and educational contexts. Through arts education, students are given the opportunity to creatively express themselves, to acquire critical thinking skills, to explore materials, to develop new ways of seeing and interpreting the world, and to learn about their artistic and cultural heritage through artistic means. At P.S. 280Q, we offer visual arts education, music education, and technology. Students are given a variety of opportunities to express themselves creatively.

The arts programming at our school has shifted some. The 6th and 7th grade students are exposed to music, art and drama.  These subjects are taught by certified arts teachers before they move on to high school.  8th grade students do not have room for an arts elective currently.  There is a strong elective culture at school where non-certified arts teachers teach classes in film, photography and creative writing to all grades. There is a strong dance culture at the school that is provided by a non-certified dance teacher. The high school students are exposed to arts education through electives. They are offered a choice, and most students are given a course they are interested in. Some examples of these courses are:  The History of Cinema, Stand-Up Comedy, Musical Theater, Advanced Scene Study, Chorus, Slam Poetry, Filmmaking Costume Design, Eco-Friendly Fashion Show and Multicultural Dance Club. There is still a great need for staffing to be able to provide all students with a full "Arts Sequence" but we are doing the very best we can with what we have.
Q45_1: TYLWS of Astoria supports the arts even when funding is scarce.  It is a place where students will have multiple opportunities to engage in various art making activities.  We still have plenty of room to grow and expand our arts programming.

Q44_1:
Sixth grade students spend half a school year in visual art and half of the year in music. At the end of their sixth grade year, these students choose to pursue either visual art or music for their 7th and 8th grade years.

 In addition to regularly scheduled music classes, supplemental sectional instruction time is provided for all music students on a weekly rotating basis. Beyond the school day, our spirit band plays at school sporting events and during open houses.

Along with regularly scheduled visual art classes, our school offers a visual art portfolio development class for students who intend to apply to visual arts high schools. This class is offered three times per week. 

Similarly, students who intend to apply to performing arts high schools have the option to take a monologue course, also offered three times per week. Theater is also offered after school through the yearly Broadway Junior musical performances.

The Principal and the faculty at Long Island City High School take pride in providing students with creative course sequences in visual arts and music. While most courses are available to all students, some are focused exclusively on students in Academy of Humanities and Urban Culture SLC. Long Island City High School has a long history of partnerships with various cultural institutions of New York City such as The Metropolitan Opera, Noguchi Museum, ABT, Repertorio Espanol, Socrates Sculpture Park, and Orpheus Chamber Orchestra. Long Island City High School is also one of the five locations for The Metropolitan Opera HD Live in Schools program. The school offers classes in band, string orchestra, chorus, guitar, music history and music theory. Visual art classes include AP Studio Art (Drawing; 2-D, 3-D), Computer Graphics, Architectural Design, Mixed Media, Costume and Stage design. Students have an opportunity to graduate with the Chancellor's Endorsed Diploma in the Arts.

Q45_1: Our school is competing its third year since inception and our growth trajectory has made it very difficult to hire a full time certified arts teacher, to date.  As the new principal of Q300, it has been a top priority to remedy that situation for the upcoming school year.

Q44_1:
School-wide Performance Outcomes

Critical thinking skills: Evidenced by the ability to read and analyze rigorous texts across content areas

Creativity in problem solving: Evidenced by the performance level on project-based learning tasks

Communication skills: Evidenced by the quality of oral and written presentations



General Arts Performance Outcomes

Critical thinking skills: Evidenced by the ability to interpret and analyze works of art

Creativity in problem solving: Evidenced by the ability to create original works of art through the intentional application of emerging artistic skills and concepts

Communication skills: Evidenced by the ability to present works of art (e.g., in gallery exhibitions or musical performances) and justify artistic decisions orally and in writing


Music Performance Outcomes

Critical thinking skills: P.S. 361Q musicians listen thoughtfully and analytically to the music they encounter in their daily lives--whether at school, at home, or in their communities. P.S. 361Q musicians utilize their emerging mastery of musical concepts to interpret other musicians’ work.

Creativity in problem solving: P.S. 361Q musicians use their emerging mastery of musical concepts to compose music that expresses a variety of ideas and emotions.

Communication skills: P.S. 361Q musicians demonstrate the expressive qualities of music through musical performances. P.S. 361Q musicians use oral and written language to explain their musical decisions.

New York City Department of Education Pre-K Centers have a unique learning environment dedicated exclusively to pre-K students and led and operated by NYCDOE staff. Pre-K Centers are located either in existing district school buildings or standalone new NYCDOE sites. D30 Pre-K Centers serve 300 students.
Art cluster teachers integrate the arts to the units of study. Through the arts, students use their five senses to explore collage, paint and clay. Students have the opportunity to observe, listen, wonder, create, express ideas, and speak with others - foundation skills for reading and writing. This year, the students had the opportunity to know Frida Kahlo, Pablo Picasso, Henry Matisse, Eric Carle, Mary Cassatt, and I.M.Pei. The arts allows students to learn about the artist's life, culture, and appreciate art. 
The music teacher also integrates music to the units of study. The chorus curriculum is focused on teaching students to understand and appreciate music. Students are exposed to various styles. They may sing folk songs, nursery rhymes, and holiday favorites. Songs help teach basic skills concepts as well as social skills.

During the 2016-17 school year, Bryant’s Arts Program has continued to make significant strides in advancing and expanding its programs and offerings. Our music department faculty increased to three full-time teachers, while our theatre department increased to two full-time teachers. We currently have two full-time dance teachers and four full-time visual artists (including two graphic designers). Both our Dance Company and Theater Company were accepted to perform at the annual Queens Arts Festival, while our visual arts program will have pieces displayed. This year, we took 150 students to see HAMILTON the Broadway musical and participated in their student performances. We have taken additional Bryant students to see three other Broadway shows through out the school year. In February, our Bryant Shakespeare monologue winner moved on to the ESU semi-finals in NYC. Our choir has performed outside in distinct community centers. The Jazz band was awarded silver meal from the 2016 NYSSMA performance. Students also participated in the solo NYSSMA festival for performance adjudication. We stage two theater productions, four music concerts/performances (jazz band, concert band, rock band, concert choir & show choir) a multi-cultural festival, an art installation show and one dance company recital. We end our year with a celebratory cabaret event. For the 2017- 2018 school year, our emphasis will continue to focus on creating a CTE theater program and preparing students for an advance arts certificate.

Frank Sinatra School of the Arts offers a pre-conservatory course of study in six art forms: dance, fine art, vocal music, instrumental music, drama and film and media. We are housed in a new state of the art building with an 800 seat concert hall, two black box theaters and discipline based rehearsal spaces including art studios, an art gallery and a film sound stage. Our students are involved with many of the outstanding arts and cultural institutions that make up the artistic community of New York City.

The arts program presently consists of band, music history, jazz history, studio art, elements of video, and video production. The goal of the arts program this school year was to encourage students to participate in performing ensembles such as band and participate in NYSSMA Contest events. Students who participate in drama club perform at a Shakespeare festival. Students in the visual arts program display their works around the school and at various locations in the local community. The video production program and web development programs are part of the school's CTE program.

The arts program at Newcomers High School provides newly arrived immigrant students, who are all English language learners, with instruction that supports their transition into a new school setting. We have developed an arts program that builds literacy skills, which is essential for our students. We tap into the vast array of cultural resources that make New York City the art center of the world and teach students about various art forms in the fields of music, dance, theatre, and the visual arts through arts partnerships that support our instructional programs, exposing our students to the rich cultural and artistic scene of New York City. Students have the opportunity for advanced study in a particular dance, studio art, music, media production and media analysis. When possible, interdisciplinary links to subjects such as math, science, English, social studies and multimedia technologies are encouraged and established.

The Academy offers the following programs in the Arts: Studio Art, College Now Art History, Painting, Playwriting, Acting, Digital Media, Opera Appreciation and 20th Century Expression Through the Arts course. In addition we actively seek to integrate the arts into all the curriculum areas. The Theater for a New Audience work with ninth grade ESL classes while ninth grade History students participate in the "Runaway Arts" program through the Center for Arts Education. Tenth grade English students participate in interdisciplinary film screenings bridging ELA and history.  Eleventh grade English teachers collaborate with the Museum of Modern Art connecting the written word to a variety of artistic mediums through the theme of identity. Twelfth grade students are offered opportunity to become part of the Center for Arts Education Career Development Program and intern in the arts. Meanwhile the entire student body is provided with artistic and cultural opportunities such as multiple trips to the Metropolitan Opera the Metropolitan Museum and other NYC art museums.  This year, for the first time, students took part in the Upright Citizens Brigade/NYCDOE Teen Improv Festival in celebration of the Improvisational Theatre Club's 20th anniversary.  For the past 19 years, the Academy has sent a delegation of students to the New York State Theatre Education Association's student conference.

The International Baccalaureate Diploma Program- Group 6 Visual Arts. The aims of the visual arts course at both the Higher Level and Standard Level are to enable students to: 1. Investigate past, present and emerging forms of visual arts, 2. Engage in producing, appreciating and evaluating visual art, 3. Develop an understanding of visual arts from a local, national and international perspectives, 4. Build confidence in responding visually and creatively to personal and cultural experiences, 5. Develop skills in, and sensitivity to, the creation of works that reflect active and individual involvement, and  6. Take responsibility for the direction of their learning through the acquisition of effective working practices.

This year we received about $25,000 in grant money to support our arts programs which was an essential component of our arts instruction. Parent involvement is key in keeping the arts alive by contributing their knowledge, time, and funding to support the arts in the classroom. All students received music instruction throughout the year with the assistance of the PTA. Our school wide enrichment model allows students to spend time learning about and creating various art projects from jewelry making, dance, photography, and drama. This program culminates with a performance and exhibition to the school community. Our after school enrichment programs supported further instruction through the arts. Programs such as drama, visual arts, and dance were offered to all students. Our students' artwork was selected to be featured not only in the Borough Arts Festival but at the Snug Harbor Children's Museum as well. An Artist Walkway/Gallery is dedicated to showcasing student artwork throughout the school year. In addition to the walkway, our school building celebrates students' artwork on all bulletin boards, hallways, stairways, and the auditorium. At P.S. 1 our goal is to continue an arts-rich education, exposing students to more arts learning through dance, music, performance and visual arts.  Through the hands on training and learning teachers engaged in with the residencies, we are working towards building capacity within our school to provide our students with ongoing instruction in the arts.

This school year we offered dance, movement, music and visual arts to our students. We believe performing arts and visual arts are essential in a students education. Our goal is to enhance socialization, academic achievement and boost self-esteem. The arts department is aligned with the Common Core Standards as well as the Blue Prints for the Arts. Students are exposed to different dance forms, line dance, yoga, cultural dance, ballroom and role play in dance and movement. In visual arts, students learn about famous artists and how to use their techniques. In collaboration with several arts residency programs, students have the opportunity to gain valuable skills in music, dance, theater and art literacy while learning to work together as a team and gaining experience in performing live in front of an audience. Students use their voice and instruments during music and have the opportunity to perform at Carnegie Hall. We offer many opportunities to be involved during school and after school in our arts programs. We have performances during the school day as well as in the evenings. The arts department allows students to use creativity, imagination and collaboration to increase confidence, focus and perseverance in each discipline

It is our long-term goal to fully integrate the arts into our curriculum so that we can provide all students with arts instruction in all arts disciplines over the course of their elementary education. This year we added two performance arts clusters to our  two visual arts cluster teachers.  These teachers served all students in grades K-5. In addition, through the generosity of our PTA and grant funding, we were able to provide Dancing Classrooms for our grade 5 students.  Students in grades 1-5 participated in grant funded arts residencies including drama, visual arts, and dance.  We were able to use school funding to provide a visual arts residency for our Pre-K and Kindergarten students.  For the 2017-2018 school year, we will continue with our Performing Arts and Visual Arts clusters.  Through these classes students will receive instruction in drama, dance, visual arts, and music. This We also hope to fund residencies for each grade as we did this year.

This year all students in grades 3-5 received band instruction provided by a DOE certified teacher. All students in grades 4 and 5 received ballroom dancing instruction from Dancing Classrooms. All students in grades 2-3 received Hip Hop dance instruction from Sundog Theatre. All students in the entire school (grades K-5) received theater arts instruction from our full-time certified theater teacher. Our goal is to continue to use formative assessment strategies and research to further enhance our theater arts instruction and to support our school wide mission of making self-assessment capable learners. We also plan to continue our school-wide enrichment program to offer more arts opportunities to our students. We will continue to expand our arts instruction as we find it invaluable to the development of our students.

Each year, we continue to expand the program to a greater sequence for theater and/or open more space to students who study music. This year we were fortunate to be able to expand even more with a grant for visual arts with  a resident artist who was absolutely fantastic! This allowed an even greater number of visual artists to participate in contests for drawing, sketching, and photography under the tutelage of their club advisor; currently the visual art program is an after school club, but we have a great deal of talent in our school and would like to introduce the visual arts as a complete school curriculum. We are creative in utilizing our television studio and by allowing students hands on experience when filming productions put on by students. Core subject teachers continue to work with our TV studio teachers to have student presentations filmed and streamed throughout the building on the hallway televisions so that we can better reach the student body with messages and spirited information. We continue to bring students to the opera, the ballet and Broadway to enhance their relationships with the arts, although budget does limit us. Each year we try to grow in new directions a bit more, taking full advantage of New York City and its cultural offerings.

PS 6 is a haven for creative exploration; we encourage the development of each student through the multi-faceted "Five Strands of Learning" from the Blueprint for the Arts.  As we are geographically remote from many cultural institutions, our school-based programming is of vital importance.  During the 2016-2017 school year, we ensured that all four arts disciplines were represented through cluster programming or artists-in-residence.  Grants, via the City Council CASA program and NYCDOE ELL/SWD funding, enabled us to accomplish the aforementioned. 
Assemblies and field trips continued to serve as vital components of our artistic character.  Literacy and Social Studies were often infused throughout our arts curricula, thus ensuring thematic, academically relevant ties to classroom instruction.   We are exceedingly proud of the strides that our arts department has made, and anticipate further expansion in years to come.
Q45_1: Please note that the data recorded in STARS does not reflect the entirety of our arts programming.  For example, third grade does not currently receive music instruction as a cluster period.  However, students participate in the Link Up program in conjunction with Carnegie Hall, whereby they enjoy intensive orchestral music education and learn to play the recorder.  They also participate in a community-oriented Flag Day ceremony which fuses theater, dance, and music - and is the centerpiece of our civic education as PS 6.  The aforementioned is done during the music teacher's administrative period, or when the classroom teachers have availability and is not termed as "music" within the tracking database.  Where programming does not suit our creative/compliance needs, we accommodate accordingly.   In that vein, the dance teacher has instituted a Dance Company.  Children engage in choreography/performance for festivals and events throughout the school year.  Similarly, the visual arts teacher has formed a stagecraft club; students create set pieces for the numerous productions that we stage at PS 6.  We are pleased to offer our students an extensive artistic menu to reflect their diverse interests and capabilities.

Q44_1: IS7 is committed to providing our students with quality art education, while offering advanced levels of programs that connect to cultural organization that share in our goal of each student reaching their potential within the arts. The IS7 programs have continued to expand dramatically throughout recent years. Combining the efforts of our theater, dance, visual art, and glee programs. We are able to produce school wide production in each specific art competency that allows us to reach our goal of maximizing each students individual talents. In addition, we have implemented after school programs such as the United Activities Unlimited and the Multi- Cultural Group that provide another opportunity for students to showcase their individual creativity. In partnership with Marquis Studios through the Art Continuum Grant which offers additional student exposure to the arts. The Marquis Studio residents focus on technical artistic development through the Garage Band Program as well as film production. Our goal is for each student to explore his or her creative interests in a a coherent and enriching environment.

Q42_R1_C1: Learning through an Expanded Arts Program
Q44_1: P.S. 8 offers all areas of the arts both during the school day and in the after-school programs (pending funding). Included are art and music classes, classroom theater programs, band, chorus, and dance. The students also participated in programs and contests held throughout the year where the arts were integrated. The Energy Efficiency Calendar Contest and social studies projects are just a few. The after-school enrichment program offers a variety of classes, such as scrap booking, Center Stage Performers, Fitnessgram, Little Picasso's, Music to My Ears, and Glee Club. The NY Public Library and LEAP have also enriched the arts to the students in our school. This year we received a Baby Grand Piano from Donor's Choose and an artist painted piano from SING for Hope.  Students participated in the dedication of the painted piano with the artist and volunteers.

At PS 9, Naples Street Elementary School, students, staff and families will work collaboratively to create meaningful opportunities for all members. Through strong partnerships with community organizations, students will be provided with cultural and artistic curriculum related experiences to enhance the literacy curriculum. PS 9 is committed to building a strong arts program that, at full capacity, includes dedicated dance, drama, music and visual arts programs. These programs will offer students at various levels with different learning styles access to content based curriculum in an exciting way.

P721X: The Stephen D McSweeney School has, over the past several years, demonstrated an expanded commitment to the arts.  This year we created a new Arts Department school wide across our various campuses. Our first theatrical production was Romeo and Juliet.  While most of the performers came from our main site there were dancers from our Monroe site and the beautiful masks for the party scene were created by students at our 368 site. Bronx Net filmed the production along with several student photographers and videographers, expanding the film production program we began last year. Students were involved in every aspect of the production from sets, props, costume design, stage management, and lighting - in addition to those in front of the camera. We are currently in production on our second play West Side Story. We received a $2,500 Arts and Family Engagement Grant that provided a 6 week collaboration with Flamenco Vivo which allowed us to introduce parents and families to the incredible dance/ music program their young adults have enjoyed these past two years. This is in addition to the rich instructional program offered by our own talented arts teacher in the areas of music, dance/theater, film, and the visual arts. Two of our students had artwork exhibited and another performed a piano solo in the performance showcase in the Bronx Borough Arts Festival. Our band will be performing at the District 75 Festival for the Arts. We had had numerous performances/showcases to celebrate the accomplishments of our students.

P.S 10R, the Fort Hill Collaborative focuses on the arts as related to S.T.E.A.M (Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts and Mathematics). Students engage in hands on learning through the engineering process of creating, designing and developing. We have partnered with Salvadori, Solar One, Common Threads and Captain Planet to further our student learning and teacher's professional development around the area of S.T.E.A.M. 

We have added a part time music cluster this year to service our second graders. Students are learning how to read music and play the recorder.

For the 2016/2017 school year, Public School 11 offered a full-time visual arts and theater program for all students. Visual arts, music, and theater continued to be infused within the general curriculum. After school programs, such as the Newspaper Club and dance, were offered and teachers planned field trips that focused on the arts. Special assemblies and nightly performances took place including "European Explorers," "Pirates of Grammar Island," "Incredible Westward Movement," "13 Colonies," "Friendly Neighborhood Helpers," Veteran's Day, Holiday Extravaganza, Ecology Day, Dance Fete and Annual Fright Fest.

The arts soar at P.S. 13! Adhering to the NY Art Standards in Visual Arts, our student participate in grade appropriate activities, such as, chalk drawings (Gr. 1), working with pastels (Gr. 2), and sketching with charcoal (Gr. 4). Grade 5's visual arts curriculum offers units in photography. Student work is displayed throughout the lobby for all to enjoy. All students take part in two units of dance. Each unit culminates in a performance for parents. Our Readers' Theater classes stress fluency while learning skills, such as, puppetry, pantomime, and commercial making. Funding from grants and our City Council Member afforded us opportunities to offer 3 enrichment programs: "The Environmental Art Project", facilitated by Universal Temple of the Arts, guided students through the process of transforming recyclables into art; partnered with the Alice Austen House, two 10-week After School Cultural Adventures (CASA) in photography were accorded to interested 3rd and 4th grade students; and, a Parents as Arts Partners grant through The Center for Arts Education had parents and children dancing for 5 sessions. We received the rights to perform "The Lion King Kids" through a Disney Musicals in Schools grant.  This production contained all theatrical elements, including costuming, lighting,choreography, and scenery design. The program concluded with a Student Share where our students had the opportunity to perform on a Broadway stage. We culminate our school year with a morning of dance and song during our annual Dance Fete.

During the 2016-2017 school year, P.S.16 has continued to increase arts instruction to meet the arts standards. Students are participating in visual arts, dance, music and theater. During the school day we have an existing 25 period music program in grades 2 and 3 where students learn to play the recorder.  We've also added a five day, 25 periods Visual Arts Program. The second grade has participated in a 15 week, one hour, a week, theater program provided by Sundog. We have also continued our 15 week after school arts program as part of the Violence and Prevention Grant on Friday afternoons for two hours.  In grades K-5 ENL students were targeted for a theater program provided by IlluminArt during a 15 week program.  4th and 5th Grade SWD's were also targeted for an after school visual arts program 2 days a week.  We have partnered with Arts Connection and have residencies in drums, Hip-Hop Story Telling, and Hip-Hop dance.  In May, all of our students will be performing and participating during Arts Week.

We have two full time art teachers (music and visual arts). In addition to the teachers, we have a residency with 2 cultural organization (Universal Temple of the Arts & Studio in a School) to integrate the arts into the curriculum. P.S. 18 makes sure that we follow the Blueprint for the Arts. Teachers are also responsible for participating in school-wide assemblies, and grade assemblies. Examples of school wide assemblies are Hispanic Heritage, Holidays Around the World, and Black History. Grade assemblies vary according to the curriculum in each grade. The arts are an integral part of P.S. 18's curriculum.

P.S. 19 understands the value of the arts in educating the whole child. We strive to secure creative methods to  provide our students with rich art experiences and opportunities to create while learning. As a culturally diverse school, respect and understanding for other cultures is made more tangible through the relationship we have built with various cultural organizations. Arts educators from these organizations work closely with classroom teachers to connect the arts to the core subjects in a meaningful way. Our students are offered additional arts opportunities through field trips and assembly productions assembled by their peers. We are proud of the after school theater program we have developed with the assistance of Disney Musicals in Schools which allows 75 students musical theater training, culminating in a performance for our community. Our ELL students participated in the ELLA Program which provides direct instruction in theater, music, dance, and visual arts on Saturday mornings. As a school committed to the arts, we work to provide instruction and experiences in the arts in many different ways.

P.S.20 provides all students with the opportunity to engage in visual arts, dance, music and theater during and after school despite fiscal challenges and space shortage. We continue to seek sources of funding through grant writing. It is our belief that arts tap into children's strengths and different learning modalities, enhancing learning across all curriculum areas and providing opportunities for enrichment. The arts also provide an opportunity for parents to experience and share in their children's learning. Our visual arts cluster services all grades and the year ends with a culminating art fair. Our theater and movement clusters service all grades, and students perform in class and at school wide assemblies throughout the year. When funding is available, residencies in the arts are provided by vendors. Students attend performances and visit museums and cultural institutions throughout the city.

This year we are extremely proud to continue our work with MTI (Musical Theatre International). The students were excited and worked hard work to perform the play, Annie Kids. Each production includes visual arts, music, drama, and singing. Utilizing grant funds from NFL Play 60, the school is continuing its Wellness and anti-bullying themes and partners with NYCArtsCypher to implement and create a comic book club reflecting the school's PBIS core values, anti-bullying theme and healthy habits. In May, we continue our traditional May Fete Dance where all classes perform and the 5th grade dances the tradition May Pole and Drill as a Salute to America. Through grant funds awarded by Staten Island Arts (Art Brings Change Grant); a local graphic designer collaborates and with our visual arts teacher to learn about art as career.  The third grade art students design and create t-shirts to celebrate PBIS and the school community in art class.

P.S. 23 has been fortunate to expand our band program to include music instruction for 2nd, 3rd, 4th, and 5th graders with the assistance of PTA Gifts to the school. In addition to this, we now have a full time Arts teacher who is teaching Social studies through Visual Arts. Our SS/Art teacher provides instruction to grades Pre-K through 5 and infuses both the New York City DOE Social Studies Scope and Sequence and Blueprint for the Arts.  We are also continuing our partnership with Richmondtown Historical Society through a Casa Grant. This grant provides students on all grade levels to participate in a an arts based program with a historical twist.

At Intermediate School 24 the Arts Program includes, on all grade levels: Visual Arts, Performing Arts, Instrument Music (Band), Music Appreciation, Graphic Arts, Computer Technology, and our Media program.  Students enjoy a hands-on experience with culminating activities that offer opportunity to exhibit the skills they have acquired as they reach each benchmark of the New York City Department of Education “Blueprint For Teaching And Learning In the Arts”.   When visiting our school you will find that we have been successful in reaching our past goals in transforming public space (halls, cafeteria, school yard walls, classroom doors) into lasting pieces of student artwork.  Both the interior and exterior walls are used as student canvases as individual art work is permanently fixed on the walls throughout the campus.  

As part of our goal to maintain our arts education programs we will implement in September 2017 individualized programming for the incoming 6th grade.  Over the next three years individual student programming will expand to include all 6th, 7th and 8th grade students.  This will provide stronger possibilities of students being placed in an arts education program that best fits their interests.  In addition we will continue to collaborate with various education organizations to help us strengthen our  art curriculum.

Q42_R1_C10: our school must be selected for the program
Q44_1: All teachers integrate the arts into all curriculum areas. All grades are involved with inquiry based instruction. Arts instruction is an integral part of the curriculum for all grade levels. This year we actively sought, and were awarded grant funds, and leveraged school funds, to enable us to provide a full art and music program for all students. Students in grades 3, 4 and 5 participated in chorus and drama programs.Grade 2 also participated in chorus. They put on five full performances for the entire school. Students in kindergarten and first grade participated in an art program that exposed them to various artistic mediums which mimicked famous artists. For example, they created sculptures and paintings. They participated in an arts exhibit where they displayed their work they had created throughout the program.

IS27 is committed to provide its students with a multi faceted arts experience. We do this through the study of instrumental music, vocal music, theatre and visual arts. We engage in a multi disciplinary approach, including the Common Core Learning Standards, in all our arts lessons. We require all of our arts students to participate in writing assignments that align themselves with the English Common Core standards. Throughout the school year, students are involved in various arts activities that include composition, music history, musical theatre, choreography, creation, analysis, and performance.

The students at P.S. 46 enthusiastically participate in the arts. All of our students receive visual arts instruction that culminates with a school wide show.  Our band program continues, with a pull out  program for 4th and 5th graders led by a dedicated volunteer instructor.  The band is always eager to participate in assemblies and finish up the year with a concert.  The classroom teachers add dance, music, and theater instruction.  We have theater productions on each grade level and a dance festival in June.  The parents enjoy attending their children's art activities.  Again ,this year, we received a grant that enabled us to team up with the Staten Island Museum to provide an after school visual arts experience to some of our students.

Q30_6: Music and the Brain, Americas Young Voices
Q44_1: Each grade experiences the arts as part of a progressive curriculum that transfers easily from grade to grade. For Kindergarten and first grade we have the BAM program (Believe, Achieve, Motivate). Each year the students learn music, movement, and art within the context of an accessible theme such as Living Healthy. In the BAM program children are exposed, sometimes for the first time, to different genres of music, group singing, and other musical activities. They participate in visual arts experiences related to their theme of study. In the second and third grade the classroom teachers continue to relate the visual arts to other curriculum areas and explore songs and music related to topics they are studying. Students also begin participating in school plays that reinforce music, visual arts, and introduce choreographed group dance. Third grade students learn to read music while playing the recorder.  In the Fourth and Fifth grades, children choose an academy that they work with for the remainder of their time at school. Students in the band or chorus showcase their talents by performing at a variety of events such as Barnes & Noble, the Groundhog Day Ceremony at the Staten Island Zoo, Staten Island Welcomes our Heroes, Make Music New York, American Young Voices and other performances throughout the year.

P.S. 30 has an arts department that includes visual arts and music. All programs service grades pre-K through 5, general and special education, and follow the NYC Blueprint for the Arts. Connections are made to all subjects, especially literacy, social studies and math as well as learning about the history of each discipline. Our visual arts department has a fully equipped arts studio. Children create drawings, paintings, prints, and sculptures while also learning art history. The year culminates with two in-school art shows and a display of student artwork at the Staten Island Conference House Art Expo. Individual students/classes are also selected to participate in various contests through the year. The music department includes instruction in band, jazz band, rock bank, recorder and songflute as well as Music Memory and, rhythm and movement. Students play individually and as an ensemble and learn to critique as well as assess self and peer performances. Students learn to connect sounds and symbols and the year culminates with performances.

Students at PS 31 are encouraged to explore the arts through classroom instruction as well as attendance at concerts, dance and theater performances and visits to cultural institutions. Through our partnerships with community organizations, we are able to bring the expertise of practicing artists and performers to our school. Most classes are instructed by a visual arts teacher at least once per week. Student art work is regularly displayed in the school building and classes and parents are invited to take "gallery walks" to view the completed pieces. Art instruction is integrated in the core curriculum. Students respond to the book of the month through visual arts on a school-wide basis. Through our arts partners with grant funding, we have been able to connect our writing curriculum with drama instruction and provide our teachers with professional development in drama, visual arts and music.Our goal is to provide standards-based arts instruction to all students while nourishing their talents and creating a lifelong appreciation for the arts.

At PS 35, our goal is to afford our children with opportunities to activate their imaginations. Through the implementation of observations, tactile learning and self expression, our students create hands-on art projects which stimulate thoughtful inquiry and careful perception. It is our priority at PS 35 to instill a love and appreciation of the arts in every student
Q45_1: Due to continued space constraints in the building, our greenhouse serves as a music room . With no dedicated auditorium, performances are staged in our all-purpose room that houses our lunchroom as well as space where physical education conducted.

Q44_1: PS 36 has an extraordinary comprehensive arts program. Our four licensed arts specialists share their knowledge and passion through small group and individualized lessons. Our band/music director conducts two bands in addition to teaching the general music curriculum. The theater arts teacher directs two theater companies as well as teaching the general theater curriculum: physical/vocal expression, playwriting, puppetry, mask making. Our dance teacher works in a fully equipped dance studio and teaches different forms of dance as well as choreographic elements and the study of human anatomy. The visual arts teacher works in all different media, stressing problem solving. We have an "Arts Academy" for grades 4 and 5 that allows students to specialize in an art form. The third graders benefit from a continuing partnership with Learning Leaders that culminates in a visit to the Brooklyn Museum.

Our certified visual arts teacher provides visual arts for all of our students and is an artist by nature who also acts as a District Arts PD Facilitator. Our school has transformed into a museum-like gallery exhibiting a plethora of visual arts and multi media projects throughout our corridors and adorning our walls all produced by students. Some examples of the variety of art work include but are not limited to: clay, collage, paper mache, stitchery, water color, sculpture, puppetry, print, documentary photography, etc. All of our Visual Art teacher's work, as well as our art resident's, is aligned to the Blueprint For the Arts and is aligned to our curriculum across all content areas. Although we only have one visual arts teacher, we ensure that our students are provided with every opportunity to explore other art forms such as photography, technology, dance, and theater through experiences with on-site and off site cultural organizations. We further immerse our students in real world experiences by aligning a variety of field trips to the arts.
Q45_1: Our school is a school which heavily relies on grants for the integration of other art forms.  We are underbudgeted and without grants cannot afford to bring in residencies.  Our Salsa Dance/Zumba and theater enrichment groups  programs  take place after school through a CASA grant

Q44_1: "Public School 39: Bridging Leadership with Success" motivates academic achievement for the students, instills in them a sense of school pride and encourages them to become lifelong achievers and contributors to their community. Public School 39’s mission is to embrace the needs of the whole child. We are a diverse group of learners whose members include children, families, school staff and the community. Cooperatively we strive to build a strong foundation for all. Our journey begins by creating a safe and caring environment promoting mutual respect. We provide multiple opportunities for our students to excel. Through the arts students have the opportunity to express themselves creatively. Our special events invite families to join us on our journey and see their children shine. We embrace the arts as a bridge that connects social, emotional and academic excellence in preparation for meeting the challenges of the 21st Century.
Q45_1: PS 39 is a Leader-in-Me Lighthouse school that infuses Stephen Covey's 7 Habits of Effective People within our curriculum.  We believe students need the opportunity to utilize the arts to express their leadership skills and abilities.

Q44_1: At PS 41 we provide our students with quality arts instruction. Our art program for grades Pre-K to 5 will continue to be taught by our full-time certified visual arts teacher. She will instruct our children in all art mediums, organize our two annual Art Expos and art gallery, and coordinate participation in notable art contests such as PS Art, the Ezra Jack Keats Bookmaking contest and the Boroughwide Arts Festival. Our music program will continue to be taught by a full-time certified music teacher and includes the following instruction: the pre-corder, recorder, general music, chorus, and 4th and 5th grade bands. A concert of soloists and duets was given, along with 2 band concerts which included a performance by our 3rd grade chorus. Our classroom teachers also work with students to present live performances for student and parent assemblies.

As we continue our focus of increasing the Arts within our instructional program, our School Leadership, PTA and faculty have been engaged in grant writing to help support and sustain the Arts. For the 2016 - 2017 school year, we have already retained grant support for electric pianos for our music/band program as well as retained grant money for technology / audio equipment for our theater program. The P.S. 42 Leadership, PTA and faculty is committed to sustaining the Arts as well as continue to leverage community recourses to continue growing and enhancing our program.

A featured aspect of P.S.44R's arts program was through visual arts which was provided by Sundog Theatre, Marquis Studio and Studio in a School with accompanying professional development for the participating teachers. These programs focused on improving literacy skills for our students (mostly with Individual Education Plans) through theatre. All classroom teachers ensure visual arts are an embedded component in their literacy programs. Most classrooms participate in multiple performances involving dance, music and visual arts. We have a large student body involved in chorus. Also, this year we incorporated S.T.E.A.M. for Pre K - 5th grade for our Black History Month featuring the first three African American women who worked for N.A.S.A. from the movie "Hidden Figures." The program allowed the students to incorporate initiatives that created critical thinkers, increased science literacy, encouraged student exploration of visual arts, theater, music, dance, architecture, and puppetry. In the future, P.S.44R will continue to develop a passion for creative learning in each and every child allowing students to reach their fullest potential.  Also, we will continue to cultivate school-wide initiatives around the arts education.

Q37_4: after school workshops,  parent engagement time
Q44_1: The Arts curriculum at P.S. 45 is aligned with the NYC DOE Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts and the NYS Arts standards. In addition, rigorous arts instruction supports common core standards. The students have the opportunity to participate in annual performances in school as well as in the community. They also have the opportunity to work with other students from mentoring schools in the community, as well as teaching artists and cultural organizations in order to create products and performances, collaboratively. The arts are integrated in other subject areas, such as: literacy, science, mathematics and social studies.

The Arts Curriculum at PS/IS 48 is aligned with the NYC Department Of Education Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts and the NYS Arts Standards. Through partnerships with a variety of community organizations, students will be provided with cultural and artistic experiences to enhance the literacy curriculum. PS/IS 48 is committed to a strong arts experience for all of our K-8 students.

P.S. 50 provides instruction in visual arts, chorus, and music to the entire student population as part of our regular academic program.  Each class attends 1 period per week of music and art.  Both programs showcase student work through performances and a culminating artwork exhibit.  

In addition to our regular program, P.S. 50 has partnerships with two arts-based cultural organizations.  Students in grades 3-5 participate in a long standing partnership with the NY Philharmonic.  Teaching artists provide direct instruction on a weekly basis with an emphasis on recorders and musical composition.  In addition, students attend two in-school concerts as well as one out of school concert at Lincoln Center.  The students perform their own compositions at a culminating performance.  NY Philharmonic also provides professional development for classroom teachers. 

Students in grades K-2 participate in a dance program with teaching artist(s) from Sundog Theater.  This program runs throughout the Spring students are showcased at a final performance.

Additional arts programs offered are based on student interest.  These additional programs include:

Band (Grades 3, 4, 5; 120 students)
Jazz Band (Grade 5; 15 students)
Violin (Grades 2, 3, 4, 5; 60 students)
After School Chorus 
Talent Show (Grades 4 & 5; 40 students)
Storytelling Festival (Grades 3-5; 15 students)
Cultural/Art-related trips (vary by grade/class)
District 31 Borough Arts Showcase (55 students)

The arts are celebrated and valued at P.S. 52, where we are committed to providing quality arts instruction in all arts disciplines. We recognize the importance of family involvement and have provided our families with P.S. 52’s grade specific chorus performances, student performances of theater productions, band concerts, recorder concerts & Ballroom Dance Finale. We offer additional arts opportunities in our after school programs as well which is sponsored by NIA. Our teachers use the arts to connect to their curriculum in order to make learning more meaningful. Our administration supports the students, teachers, and arts residencies in enriching and extending student learning through the arts.

Arts Education is an important component in the educational program of each of our students at P.S. 53. This year we have a part-time music and band teacher, visual arts teacher, in addition to a social studies cluster teacher who incorporates art into the curriculum for grades Pre-k- 2. Our music teacher provides violin instruction to our 4th grade Gifted and Talented students and also provides music to our Pre-k and kindergarten students. Our 4th and 5th grade students have the opportunity to participate in band and put on numerous performances for our students and their families throughout the school year. This year our music teacher has also delivered instruction to our 3rd grade students in musical theater. 
    This year we have continued our partnership with Dancing Classrooms who provides ballroom dancing to our 5th grade students and we have also continued a partnership with SunDog Theater who provides theater arts to our 2nd grade students.Classroom teachers  utilize various programs which infuse arts into curriculum areas which provides diverse opportunities for our students to learn through the arts.

Q37_4: Music lessons during parent engagement time
Q44_1: P.S.54 is a Pre-K through 5 school which is dedicated to providing school wide arts programs which enable our students to express themselves through music, visual arts and theater. Our school includes extracurricular areas in these areas as well. All of our art classes provide opportunities for active participation. The Visual Arts program follows the NYC DOE blueprint for Teaching and Learning in Visual Arts. Final products are published on Artsonia, which is an online Art Museum. P.S. 54’s music program serves grades Pre-Kindergarten through Fifth Grade. Grades Pre-K and K receive Music and Movement which includes movement activities, small percussion and singing. Grades 1, 2, and 3 receive either recorder class, vocal class, or keyboard class depending on scheduling and location. Grades 4 and 5 are Modern Band guitar classes.Students in grades Pre K through 2 are working towards mastering the Benchmarks for Theater by activating and using their imaginations and exploring the use of the actor’s tools – body, voice and imagination. Using literacy as their source, students participate in group, partner and individual activities which include dramatic play, storytelling, puppetry, music, and dance. All activities are embedded in the ELA CCSS for the appropriate grade level. Students in grades 3 through 5 are working towards mastering the Benchmarks for Theater for Grade 5. Students exercise and refine the actor’s instrument—the body, voice and mind—through ongoing exploration of the physical, vocal, characterization.

Our goal is to allow every student access to each art discipline, and give them the foundation to explore their interests and strengths. The early childhood classes engage in music appreciation instruction with a certified music teacher. Each teacher in the early childhood grades integrate visual arts across the curriculum. Our drama program services students on every grade level. Each child performs at one grade assembly. Our second grade students receive recorder instruction in music. Our third graders have chorus and a small group is selected to participate in a violin program. Fourth grade students are selected for violin or band and perform twice a year. In addition, they perform in drama. Our fifth grade participates in ballroom dance with "Dancing Classrooms," and drama. Students are selected for band and violin. There is a part time visual arts program that services some classes at each grade level. We also offer visual arts, and drama in our after school program.

We were able to establish a Fifth Grade Dance Club, as well as continue our Theater Club and Art Club.  We created an inclusive environment in all of our arts classes, where our Special Needs students were able to thrive and flourish.  Special accommodations were made for children with physical and emotional disabilities, including choreography in shows to highlight their strengths and work around their limitations.  This year we held a Halloween Dance Festival for Grades 3, 4, and 5 outside for parents after our March of Dimes Walk-A-Thon in October.  We had 4 successful Holiday musical theater and dance performance shows for children in grades K-5.  The Fifth Grade Theater and Dance Clubs created and performed a "Respect For All Week" choral, dance, and drama performance assembly for the entire school.  In addition, children in grades K-5 participated in our 2nd Annual Dance Festival, which took place in our school yard in April.  Each grade from K-5 performed their own Spring musical theater concert.  We had culminating Stepping Up performances for children in grades Pre-K, K, and 5.  Visual Arts components were included in all of these performances, including scenery, posters, costumes, etc.  The Visual Arts classes worked on various contest entries throughout the year, as well as participated in a Spring Art Show.

P.S. 57 introduced a dance teacher this year full time and a music program for all grades K through 5th grade. We partnered with Education through Music to ensure that all of our students had music in their weekly program throughout the entire year and that we had a certified music teacher on staff. We also continued this school year working with Illuminart through a grant with Staten Island Foundation.  Illuminart is a non-profit organization whose goal is to empower students of all ages with the ability to portray and develop solutions for the complex challenges they'll confront through the power of theater. The teaching artists worked with all our 3rd grade classes, to write an original play and performed it. They also worked with a select group of 3,4, & 5th grade students after school in the same type of format. There was also two 10-week artist residencies  servicing 8 classes total provide by Puppetry in Practice. We look forward to becoming a Community School in the coming year. Hopefully this will allow more resources to be dedicated to the  Arts and our students.

P.S.58's art program strives to achieve fidelity to the mandated Blueprints for the Arts. We provide learning opportunities across all grade levels to all children in theater, music, visual arts and dance .We believe that learning through the arts is a valuable and necessary part of students' education. Our goal is to continue to provide these opportunities through two full time visual arts teachers as well a 1 full time music/theater teacher. These teachers serve the entire school community. In addition, through other sources, we provide, in conjunction with community based organizations, residencies in theater to all grade 2 classes. Culminating performances through the school year celebrate student achievement with the school community. At the end of May, each school year, we celebrate the Arts with an Evening of the Arts Performance showcasing the students' achievements in music and dance. In addition to the performances, our building displays our students' visual art work done through out the year to showcase our commitment to the arts.

P.S. 60 embraces the Arts and the proof is in our commitment to instructional practice. We have 2 licensed Visual Arts instructors, 1 licensed Music instructor and 1 licensed Dance instructor. Arts educators meet on a weekly basis to discuss and plan during professional development sessions. Visual Arts students follow the NYC Blue Print for the Arts so arts skills can scaffold each year. Students use sketchbooks/journals to track their progress. Smartboard technology and document cameras enrich art viewing. Art work is posted on Artsonia, a virtual student art museum. All 900 students take part in the yearly school based art show. Our music students play guitar and vocalize simultaneously. They play a wide variety of music ranging from cultural folk songs to modern day pop music. The music program is outfitted with two complete sets of ¾ sized classic guitars. Students who need smaller guitars are provided a ½ size version. Students have the opportunity to accompany their group performance with percussion, electric bass and electric guitar. We have an advanced chorus group that sings challenging music while dancing. We added a new Dance Studio which has wooden floors, mirrors and balance bar.Our dance program offers students the opportunity to build their technical and expressive skills and develop their artistry. All classes receive a structured dance experience which helps students develop physical, cognitive and social skills. All of our Arts programs reinforce our commitment to the arts and allow creativity to blossom.

William A. Morris Intermediate School 61, a designated Magnet School of the Arts in New York City, is a thriving middle school with a teaching and administrative staff committed to nurturing and encouraging the artistic potential of all of our students in grades six through eight. We continue as a School of Arts and Letters through Museum Studies as designated by our previous Federal Magnet Grant through the US Department of Education. We are proud of our reputation as a school which both infuses and enriches arts education for our students during their time at our school. We continue to develop young musicians, singers, actors, dancers, visual artists, and filmmakers, while cultivating a lifelong love of the arts in all of the young men and women who attend our school. Our school continues to teach and encourage immersion in the many different arts disciplines as indicated by the NYC Department of Education Blueprint for the Arts. All of our students benefit from the many different tenets for success in the Arts and those who are in the three-year immersion disciplines for the arts areas i.e.. Band, Orchestra, Choir, Drama, Dance, Visual Arts, Photo & Film Journalism, receive an unparalleled experience at The middle school level.

Students in grades Pre-K through Grade 1 received visual arts and dance instruction each week by a cluster teacher. The curriculum is aligned to the CCLS as well as the Blueprint for the Arts. During this time students were made aware of the standards, were given opportunities to self-assess, peer-assess and create goals so that they can take ownership of their learning. Students also received visual arts, dance and theater instruction in the classroom.
This year we partnered with Marquis Studio and all students took part in a Visual Arts and Theater Residency. During the Visual Arts Residency students learned about different artists and different art forms. The students learned how to create a monoprint, how to combine primary colors to make secondary colors and how to construct a collage.  At the conclusion of the session, the students had an opportunity for reflection and were able to view their peer's work through an Art's Share. During the Theater Residency students learned how to use their voices and body expressively in order to perform in front of an audience, how to work with peers and how to imitate and create basic emotions. Students then had an opportunity to perform for an audience.
This year our Pre-K sites participated in the NYC Pre-K Create track and learned how to incorporate the visual arts, dance, theater, and music into their ongoing instruction to promote student learning in multiple PKFCC domains. Through PD we learned new ways to design classroom learning centers so that art activities are integrated.

The Gaynor McCown EL High School values the influence that arts education has on the other core academic subjects. Our visual arts teacher provides arts instruction to beginners as well as advanced students. Students also performed in our Talent Show and The Little Mermaid. We are also the only Staten Island school to participate in TDF's Open Doors Theater Scholarship Program, where 8 students are selected to work with a mentor/theater professional and see 6 Broadway performances throughout the year.

PS 65 infuses arts into the curriculum, thereby enhancing their educational experiences. Students have many different learning styles, and the "arts" provide multiple media in which students may acquire the skills and knowledge that they need to be successful in their academic as well as social/emotional careers. Teachers receive ongoing and sustained professional development from professional artists so that they may learn how to successfully and effectively incorporate each of the art strands into each academic area. Daily you will observe our teachers having students perform, act out, sing, dance, and represent their learning in various art forms. Monthly assemblies, as well as classroom-based performances, are an integral part of the school year. Students have multiple opportunities to display their talents, strengths and abilities and feel good about themselves. Our community is embedded in the belief that all students will be successful if we build on their strengths.

This year Studio in a School covered four different art categories:  collage, tempera paint, wood construction and clay sculpture.  The kindergarten students were exposed to these genres once a week for 50 minutes.  Initially the facilitator (artist) engaged in a whole class lesson, then pulled a small group to work on the art.  The classroom teacher would then take small groups during the week to reproduce a product defined by the artist.  All students were able to produce an art piece in each of the genres.
Our technology rich school environment provides the tools necessary to create a cutting edge Graphic Design program.

Our goal for the 2016-2017 school year is to incorporate Success Criteria into each Art discipline at the school. The students will take "ownership" of what a high rigor art/music project consists of. The students will create the Success Criteria with the teacher/facilitator outlining all the necessary expectations needed to be implemented to achieve proficiency on a rigorous task.

The Police Officer Rocco Laurie Intermediate School 72 is an ethnically diverse middle school located in Staten Island, NY with a population total of 1,321 students. We have a growing fine Arts program that offers instrumental music, vocal music, general music and dance. Students are offered a 3-year sequence in music (band and chorus) that follows a curriculum aligned with the NYC Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts. With the addition of our dance classes being such a success, we have also implemented a dance team which has performed at several school events, outside dance competition, and the Borough Arts Festival at the St. George Theater.
Q45_1:
We are a title 1 school in which 61% of our student population receives free or reduced lunch.  
We run our tracked band and chorus class parallel so we are able to service 2 classes worth of students at a time between band and chorus with student choice permitted.

Q44_1: Our arts program is dedicated to the Visual Arts, Dance, Music and Theater. Each program is a 3-year sequence and is a comprehensive application of each specific discipline. Our performing arts program offers Major Band A & B, Chorus, Drama, Dance, Video & Stage Production. The collaborative effort allows our students to reach their potential in each area and provides them with multiple venues in order to perform their talents. Holiday shows, concerts, musicals and extra-curricular functions allow our students to showcase their talent. Many of our student audition for schools such as LaGuardia and have achieved high levels of success in their secondary and collegiate careers. The Visual Arts includes Digital Arts & Design, Fine Arts and Graphic Arts & Print Production. Fine Arts allows our students to express their talents using media such as watercolors, pastels, oils and charcoal to generate beautiful pieces of art that adorn our building. The Digital Arts program affords our students with the opportunity to utilize current software applications to generate a wide variety of projects of student interpretations of design. Graphic Design and Print allows our students to work on the design and application of logos and other media displays. Our program is supported by an extremely talented and gifted staff who lend their expertise to our developing artists. The talents of our students are showcased each year in our annual "Night of the Arts" where the entire Paulo community celebrates the success of our gifted students.

Q42_R1_C1: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts
Q44_1: The units of study we implemented this year aligns perfectly with the Common Core Learning Standards as well as the Blueprint for the Visual Arts. We have expanded our Arts partnerships to now include theater, music, dance and the visual arts. Our previous residencies with the New York Philharmonic, Sundog, Alice Austin House and Marquis Studios, has opened the doors to the resources that are an integral part of the development of young artists. We have continued with the NY Philharmonic, and added numerous Community School partners that include Lincoln Center, Staten Island Children's Museum, as well as the Staten Island Zoo. We have continued with Steven Covey's 7 Habits, and have incorporated the Leader in Me in our assembly performances. This year we have our second arts culminating event, an Art Expo, to coincide with our Leadership Day. In our community school, we collaborate to create activities that ensure family participation. We are excited about our work in helping to design our new playground with the Parks Department. Our objective is to closely listen to the needs and concerns of the school community so as to enhance the ownership of the work we do here at PS 78. Our partnerships and programming in the arts ensures that every student and family experience all that New York City has to offer.

The Michael J. Petrides School is a seamless Pre Kindergarten through 
12th grade school, committed to providing a learning environment that 
nurtures the whole child;mind, body, and spirit. Teachers, parents, administrators, and support staff collaborate to provide an education 
that celebrates the diversity of our students and recognizes the individuality and creativity of each child. 

We are proud of our comprehensive arts program which inspires interest and encourages students to develop their talents in dance,
