music, theater, and art.

New Dorp High School’s mission is to provide an environment that enables all students to grow academically, intellectually, socially, emotionally, and culturally. We are divided into eight Smaller Learning Communities, one of which is dedicated to "The Arts." The Academy of Fine & Dramatic Arts (AFADA) supports a complete academic program and includes dedicated staff and space to students who major in fine and performing arts. With the CEP goal of reaching 80% graduation rate, data indicates that students who complete their arts sequence, are more likely to graduate on time.Therefore, AFADA inquiry work has focused on ways to improve student outcomes in sequence completion. There are four sequences of electives offered in AFADA:dance, drama, art and music, which include lessons aligned to the Common Core and Hochman designed writing exercises, as well as collaboration with dedicated staff to support interdisciplinary activities.Students experience a scaffolded sequence of courses for each of the four concentrations. Each contain beginner, intermediate and advanced classes along with options such as stagecraft, film, photo art, art history, portfolio, chorus, band, piano and guitar.Throughout the year, students are afforded a cadre of opportunities outside the classroom. Moving forward, we used our school survey to create new, more rigorous coursework designed to engage students and foster student participation in extracurricular activities.These include an exploratory program freshmen year,costume design and AP Drawing.

Curtis High School is a comprehensive high school located on the north shore of Staten Island near the Staten Island Ferry. Curtis High School provides arts instruction in the 4 major art forms of dance, theatre, music and visual art. Curtis offers a sequence in Graphic Design and Fine Arts ; Jazz band, Concert Band, Orchestra, Guitar Ensemble, and Chorus. Dance programs are offered in Modern, Ballet, Survey and Choreography. Dance, Art and Theatre all offer International Baccalaureate classes. All students at Curtis High School can pursue a sequence in the arts no matter what Small Learning Community they belong to.

Tottenville HS offers a myriad of arts courses to every grade 9-12 student. In Fine Arts: fashion, computer art, television, multi-dimensional design, analog & digital photography, advertising, drawing , painting, architecture, technical & computer assisted drawing lab, Adobe web design, graphic design, art portfolio, core art, art history. Performing Arts: symphonic, concert, intermediate, jazz & beginning band; symphony, intermediate & beginning orchestra; Vocal training, mixed & concert choir. We offer a competitive marching band that competes and performs throughout the metropolitan area and Walt Disney World, beginning and advanced guitar & piano labs; music theory, core music, music history and extensive after school chamber ensemble opportunities. We are also the only Staten Island High School to offer a Chancellor's endorsed Arts Diploma in Visual Arts and Music. Every arts student in our large, 4,000+ school is important. They become integral members of smaller learning communities, creating a family-type experience. Parent support and great rapport between teacher and students create an enriching and rigorous learning and creative atmosphere.

The Wagner Arts program has a wide array of courses and specialized teachers within each discipline. The music program has performed to critical acclaim throughout New York City and the country at various festivals, competitions and public venues. This April, the music department swept top honors in all instrumental categories at theFestival Disney Competition in orlando, FL. Music courses include multi-leveled ensembles in chorus, band, and guitar. The Theatrical Arts institute is a four-year sequential program, which includes courses in acting, directing, stage design, musical theatre, and playwriting. In addition to class work, students are engaged in a number of full-scale productions each year including musicals and dramatic plays. The visual arts program has opportunities for students to study art through a number of media including painting, drawing, graphic design, and photography. Students regularly contribute artwork for galleries and national competitions each year. The new addition of our Dance Learning Center allows us to offer multi leveled courses to students interested in pursuing serious study in Ballet, Jazz, Tap, and Modern.
Q46_2: Assistant Principal, Performing and Visual Arts

Q44_1: By 6/18,100% of students will receive and engage in a comprehensive art, music, dance and/or dramatic performance education and will demonstrate common core standards skills as measured by the NYC Blueprint for the Arts. This includes visual art and/or performance arts. K-8 schedules in rotation blocks allows students to receive this education. Students will incorporate learning into stage and school performances for parents/community. Intermediate students will be programmed into a track of art, band, chorus/drama dependent upon interest/talent. To supplement in house performing arts instruction, we formed a partnership with the CASA where students have the opportunity to participate in theatre and dance. Even though we have no residency this year our teachers have been trained through past residencies to teach dance to our students.As a culmination all students will display their talents through various performances and/or art exhibits, which will be documented and assessed and will be open to family/community partners.

Q42_R1_C2: Alley Park Queens fesrival of Cultures
Q44_1:
P.S./I.S. 45K provides students with the opportunity to learn to play musical instruments, act on stage, sing in a chorus and engage in hands-on arts projects.  Funds are set aside to enable all students to participate in cultural activities, such as field trips to the theater, visits to art galleries and engage with on-site artistic consultants.  

We have purchased keyboards and percussions to enhance the musical capabilities of our students during the school day.  Teachers of the arts continue to be provided with professional development training throughout the school year, which enhances their knowledge and our arts programs.  Music in the Brain, the early childhood keyboard program, for the seventh year has engaged our students in learning literature through song and play.   

There is a strong family involvement component in which the parents participate in cultural activities and engage in a variety of musical and artistic experiences.  

Our goal for the school year is to differentiate the arts learning for students of all grades. The Middle School Arts partnership has been extremely beneficial to our 6th-8th grade students.  During Elective periods on Friday, students engage in chorus and dance.  In preparation for high school, 8th grade students have an opportunity to build art portfolios with a visual arts focus.

he Mayda Cortiella Elementary School envisions all students in our  Music program to be accountable for benchmarks as stated in the Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts. These goals are integrated into the overall vision and mission statement of our school and provide each student with a balanced education within each grades curriculum. Our goals next year are to build on more  balanced, project based curriculum that includes a band for our fifth grade students. We will continue with our chorus and have our Winter and Spring concerts which allow all students to participate and parents to enjoy.

This collegiality of administrators and teachers helps create a unified environment within P.S.75. The outcome of our efforts produces a stimulating learning environment of vibrant, multi-talented, high performing students.
We have a full time music teacher and a full time visual arts teacher

During the 2016-17 school year, PS 145 has a collaborative residency with  Studio in a School that has been on-going for the last four years. The artist in residence provides visual arts instruction to the majority of the students in the school throughout the year. Students have shown growth in their artistic techniques in a variety of media such as sculpture, collage, painting and animation. Students' culminating projects show their in depth thinking and understanding of artistic creativity.
This year, we received funding to institute an afterschool dance and theater program in collaboration with the Brooklyn Arts Council. This program supports and highlights our multi-cultural appreciation for our students and families.

We currently have two certified arts teachers on staff one in music and one in dance. All students receive an hour of each art form a week and some classes receive additional arts instruction. In addition, a select group of students are part of a band and choir facilitated by the music teacher. Students are highly engaged and involved in the annual performances put on by the music and dance programs. This year PS86 had two in school residencies a dance residency with Movement Research and a visual arts residency with The Center for Arts Education. PS86 also had two after-school residencies a theater residency with Inside Broadway and a visual arts residency with Studio in a School. Our school is committed to exposing our students, parents, and community to different art forms and experiences.
Q45_1: Through grants, reduced ticket costs, and free arts programming we are able to provide our students with such an array of rich art experiences. Due to reduced funding we were unable to continue working with some of our past art residencies and were unable to attend performances whose ticket costs were to high.

Q44_1:
At P.S. 106 we currently offer Music, Art, and Visual Arts in grades Pre-K through 5th.  Each student at our school is given the opportunity to partake in our Arts Program. Our goal is to instill in our students a deep appreciation of the arts. In addition, our students are offered the opportunity to participate in After School Arts activities.  Through the after school program, the students receive a rich array of disciplines which include dance, mural design, and video productions.  

For School Year 2017-2018, we will be offering dance as one of our day school cluster program.  We are looking forward to enriching our arts program.

In 2015 - 2016 PS 116 made a commitment to expand our arts program and we continued that work this school year.  We have two licensed art teachers in both visual arts and music who have attended professional development to increase their knowledge in these areas in order to fully incorporate and embed the arts into our curriculum.  Our goal of becoming a school of the arts, is partially based on the fact that a strong art curriculum combined with content area subjects, enhances and improves student learning and in some cases has even helped in closing learning gaps; especially for English Language Learners  and Students with disabilities.  This year we have dedicated space in our building to accommodate an art room and a music room housed with equipment such as instruments, smartboards, computers, and an abundance of art supplies. We also use the Blueprints for the arts to guide our instruction and educate our art teachers who meet with other teachers across disciplines and grades to create interdisciplinary lessons.  Our art teachers also continually attend professional development opportunities to expand their knowledge and continue their learning.  A new initiative this year is the creation of a grant team who meet weekly to seek out grants and opportunities to provide funding for our arts program. We have obtained a grant to create a new-state of the art visual arts room and construction will begin this summer.

This will be our second year with our music teacher who in continuing the school day instrumental music program. For K-2nd grades, the students have learned keyboard, and the students in grades 3-5 have learned guitar and songwriting. New this year we have commenced a music club program.  In the visual arts program, this year's students enjoyed the arts club, trips to MOMA and The Metropolitan Museum of Art, and participated in various art contests, such as AJK Bookmaking Contest, Water Contest, Respect Contest, and others. Their artwork was displayed locally, citywide, and at the Brooklyn Borough Arts Festival. Our students' artwork is published on the internet website Artsonia, which is an online gallery where families can view their child's artwork at home. We've decorated our school with murals at the entrance of the school, and on the second floor. Next year we're planning to extend our murals to the staircases.

This year we commenced a violin and hip-hop dance afterschool program for students in first, second and third grades and a theater afterschool program for students in third, fourth and fifth grades. These 30-week afterschool programs were made possible through our partnership with the Bronx Arts Ensemble.
Q45_1: Our school is located in the Bushwick Section of Brooklyn servicing a total of 350 students in grades Pre-Kindergarten through fifth.  Of our student population, approximately 25% of our students are classified as English language learners (ELLs), approximately, 23% of our students are classified as students with disabilities (SWD), approximately 255 of our students are living in temporary housing, and 100% of our students are entitled to free lunch (title 1 funds.)

Q44_1: IS 162 has a visual arts program incorporated in the school day. Graphic/Computer art is offered during the school day through a residency program. Chorus, Music, Theatre, and Dance are offered after school through a residency program. We showcase our students' work in the arts through assembly programs and evening performances. This year we have added a theatre production in the spring.

Visual arts program designed to help students understand the power of art to inspire, creative expression, innovative thinking and problem solving. Through art education students will be able to: • Make connections between visual art concepts and other curriculum areas. • Appreciate and recognize the influence of art beyond the school setting. • Learn to value, understand, and use the creative processes. • Use a variety of art media and techniques to create works of art. • Interpret and respond to artwork using visual arts vocabulary. • Communicate ideas and personal expressions through artwork. • Understand characteristics of visual form from a variety of cultures and historical times • Develop problem solving skills and innovative thinking.

P.S./I.S. 384 has always offered our students a chance to explore a wide variety of techniques and mediums in the visual arts.This has included drawing,painting,ceramics and creating large scale mosaics.
      The school also provides a keyboard lab and "Music and the Brain" for our younger students. Our middle school students have been offered guitar instruction during our advisory program and through the after school program, SASF. This after school program has also provided a dance program for our older students, while our younger fourth graders, have been given a chance to work with the Alvin Ailey dance company.  Alvin Ailey provided a two month residency program  during regular school hours. 
      In addition to music, dance and  art, drama has been provided to our middle school students, through the Department of Education's" ARTS MATTER program. The ARTS MATTER program will continue into its second year for the 2017-2018 school year.
  Lastly, For the 2017-2018  school year, we plan to continue with our visual arts program, and music for the lower grades.

The 2016-17 arts program at P.S. 274 incorporated music, visual arts, dance and theater instruction for students in pre-k through fifth grade.  Our school values creativity, imagination, self expression and the ability to apply knowledge across content areas.  Students need these skills more than ever as they prepare for higher education and the work force.  Our school cultivates these skills through arts instruction.  PS274 collaborated with Brooklyn Academy of Music, New Victory Theater and TADA to include music, dance and theater to enrich our curriculum for students in grades Kindergarten through Five. The Music and the Brain program offers our students in K and 1 the tools to learn to read music through classroom keyboard lessons.  Students in Kindergarten and 2nd grade created and performed short musicals based on famous works of literature. In addition, VTS is implemented throughout our building to support our love for visual arts through rich discussion. All classes visit our art studio where the art teacher introduces different artists and their techniques, many times blending in themes that support the units of study in the classrooms. Student art work was celebrated at a school wide art exhibition.  Our after school program offered a modern band program to students in grades 4 and 5.  All students at PS274 have had the opportunity to participate and perform during school wide events with their classes throughout the year. PS274 takes pride in providing a well rounded education in the arts to all students.

A.t I.S, 291K, students receive in grades 6-8 Visual Arts as required by the State and National Standards.  Students are introduced to paintings and drawings.  This exposure facilitate students to exposure to the elements of arts.  Students are also exposed to Dancing, Vocal Music, Instruments (Drumming).
Q45_1:
Presently we have a Century 21 Grant in which the students participate in multiple activities.  Students receive the following:
Martial Arts, Vocal Music, (FYREZONE), Drum Line and Entrepreneurship.
Students in grades 6-8 participate in the above activities.

Our school is located in the Bushwick Section of Brooklyn and access to arts resources are limited. We strive to offer some after school opportunities for our students to engage in dance, visual arts, and theatre.

Q44_1: IS 347 is fully committed to the arts. We have a full-time Visual Arts Teacher and Dance Teacher. We currently have a Humanities team which conducts interdisciplinary planning and execution of lessons for our 8th grade through Visual Arts, Dance, ELA, SS and Foreign Language. We hope to build on the gains and performance made by this teacher team to infuse both Math and Science as well. The 347 Principal and Assistant Principal responsible for the Arts will continue to participate in the Shubert Leadership Series for the Arts. We currently have residencies and partnerships with prestigious organizations such as the Center for Arts Education and the Urban Arts Partnership.

Q42_R1_C1: Learning through an Expanded Arts Program
Q44_1: The goal is to create a visual arts program that is aligned to the academic standards outlined by New York State and the Blueprint for the arts. Programs, such as the LEAP program, will be offered during extended learning time to support additional arts learning. Additionally, we have added two 3D printers to provide students with the opportunity to engage in digital arts, and fabricate their designs.

Our arts program goals for the 2015-2016 academic year were met. Pedagogues teaching the arts participated in professional development so they could begin to align their arts instruction to the Common Core Learning Standards. Workshops were provided to improve teachers' abilities in Instructional Technology as an arts medium. PS 376 will continue to provide students with rich and varied experiences in the arts during the 2016-2017 academic school year during the school day and in after school programs. We will continue to provide professional development and conduct frequent observations with meaningful feedback to ensure our arts instruction is aligned to the Common Core State Learning Standards and the Blueprint for the Arts. We will continue to offer pedagogues teaching the arts professional development in Instructional Technology so they continue to incorporate 21st Century skills in their instruction. We will continue our partnership with Brooklyn Arts Council, Studio In The School and the Sports and Arts Foundation to provide students with additional experiences in visual arts, theatre and dance.

Q37_4: PTA Title I parent engagement workshop
Q44_1: We currently offer Arts education in the discipline of Music to our middle school students in grades 6-8. We also have a 1 day per week after school program that includes singing and dancing and is open to all grade levels. The PTA also organized a student dance team that has performed for students and families.We have a bucket drum ensemble that has performed during school assembly programs. Although we were unable to provide our elementary students with arts education this year, they have participated in school assembly programs that featured music and dance performances.
Q45_1:
Our students enjoy and appreciate all forms of art!!

Unfortunately, due to budgetary circumstances we are not able to fund the arts at our school to the extent that are students deserve.

The Arts program at Philippa Schyuler Middle School for the Gifted & Talented has been one of our prized jewels for many years! This versatile program offers students the opportunity to study a variety of disciplines. From Modern and Urban dance to Steel Pan and Concert Band, our students are immersed in learning activities that afford them the chance to express themselves and showcase their many talents in a multitude of ways. This year, one of our school's goals has been to continue to enrich and expand the Performing & Visual Arts program within our school community. 

Given this focus, we have boosted our level of performance, and expanded both of our annual winter and spring concerts to encompass more diversity and theatrical elements. We also put together an elaborate production of the theatrical play, Antigone, with full cast and crew! We have also expanded on our International Day celebrations to include more performance opportunities that highlight a variety of cultures. In addition, we have created partnerships with local Arts Educational programs to prepare our students with the foundational skills needed to succeed in these realms. Through these comprehensive programs, students learn valuable, life-long skills that are necessary to working in large and diverse groups. Additionally, they broaden the scope of our school community, allowing for teachers, students and parents to come together and acknowledge the hard work and diligence found within our Performing and Visual Arts Program.

Q44_1:
At EBC we believe it is essential to provide artistic expression for students of color. We have a state of the art media studio, instrumental music course, vocal training, theatre program, and we infuse the student's culture into all that we do.

We have received over $20,000 in funding this year, we are in the process of creating a school website, and we hire students as part time staff to support our efforts around the arts.

The visual arts curriculum is divided into two sections. Artist Studies and Design. In A.S. students learn basic art theory, art making techniques based on contemporary art influences, and learn how to see with an artist's lens using art making materials. In Design students explore fashion design, industrial design, advertisement and architecture. Student develop a sense of team building and learn the basic skills of public speaking and the consumer approach to the art market. Students are also introduced to Art History and build on their knowledge of writing and global history as a support tool for their upcoming regents.AP Studio Art Drawing is offered to our excelling  artists in 11th and 12th grades with the emphasis on portfolio development and college readiness.

We use CBO's such as Tribeca and Scenarios to provide teaching artists for students to engage in film making and editing. We also have a partnership with Opening ACT to ensure students have opportunities around performing especially in theater. We have a History of Dance class that operates five day a week in conjunction with a West African Drumming Class taught by a contracted vendor of the DOE. We plan to partner with a middle school to have a licensed Art Teacher two to three days a week. Also, we will utilize the AP Art program with a school on campus in order to have students have advanced art.

Q42_R1_C1: Learning through an Expanded Arts Program
Q44_1: Our partnership with LEAP has been incredible- students enjoy our Resident instructors in learning about Visual Art, Dance, Theater and Music. Coordination among our staff with these Resident artists has allowed for a wonderful multi-year experience where students have grown in their artistic expression. We will continue to use LEAP as our partner to have our students learn and express themselves in creative ways both in the classroom and in public performances.

The staff and teachers at Bushwick Leaders’ High School for Academic Excellence wish to provide an arts program with the following goals: • Expose students to the world of theater, visual arts, music and dance. • Provide students with the knowledge and understanding about art resources and programs available in the NYC area: this includes all museums and theaters. • Help students to become critical thinkers regarding the art to which they are exposed. • Use the arts as a way to make connections to the content being studied in ELA, math, social studies and science classes, as aligned to the Common Core Standards. • Use the arts to help students gain a sense of history. • Help students to experience art as more than a place to express themselves. • Support students in increasing self esteem. • Support students in utilizing theater techniques to support their work in content area classes and in the work place.

We have a digital art program at the school focused on teaching students Adobe Suite. The program includes animation and special effects training and skill-building to allow for alternative options for college or art schools. We plan on bringing in more professional artists into the classroom and greater links with technology. We intend to enhance connections with potential art schools, colleges and universities. and to promote and explore careers in the arts and arts and media internships.

The school has strived aggressively to intensify its Arts Instructional Program. Our goals would be 
- to increase the and expand its partnership with external the Arts Cultural Organizations to provide professional learning for classroom teachers and non-certified teachers of Arts
- to attract, recruit and retain certified Arts Teachers in all the sub disciplines to help establish a more comprehensive Arts Program
- to explore and gather appropriate funding to facilitate this Initiative
Our future Arts program would be expanded  to include more opportunity in theater, photography and films for all of our students; with an intensification of our VisualArts, Music and Dance Instructional Hours
Q45_1: School Community PS 4 K is a Special Education School with 366 students from Grade PreK through Grade 5. The school population comprises of 62.02 % Black, 25.68% Hispanic, 4.91 % White, 4.37% Asian, and 3.02 % others. Our Special Education PreK- Grade 5 student body includes 16.7 % ENL students , and 83.3% Special Education Students. The following populations of students with Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD), and other varying behavioral and developmental impairments represent: 6:1:1 ; 12:1:1 ; and 8:1:1. Boys account for 72.40% of the students enrolled, and girls account for 27.59%, representing a ratio of about 3:1. The average attendance rate for the school year 2015-2016 was 89.30%. We pursue a rigorous CCLS-alighned Curriculum Map driven by the 3-E Instructional Model within a Center -based Interdisciplinary Learning Approach for all student to meet lifelong learning and independence

Q44_1: The arts are an integral part of P53K's teaching and learning. In addition to students having classes in art and music programmed into their daily schedules, arts activities are integrated with instruction in academic core subjects by making use of the Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts, the NYS Learning Standards and the Common Core Standards. Many of our students are nonverbal and the arts are a means by which to enhance their learning opportunities and enrich their lives. Learning through the arts contributes to the academic, social and personal development of each student as well as supporting the progress of their IEP goals. By incorporating the arts in academics, P53K effectively accommodates individual learning differences within a flexible learning environment allowing students to perform according to their cognitive and physical abilities, consequently motivating our students to learn. We have continued our residency with Marquis Studios with a focus on Mask Making.Students crafted masks with a variety of materials such as paper, wire, plaster and foil to create wearable three-dimensional works.  They focused on expressions and exaggeration as well as color, and pattern. We were awarded the Disney Grant allowing our students to see a show Aladdin on Broadway, backstage and talk to the cast. Most excitingly they will perform the Lion King on stage!! We continue to be part of the Ezra Jack Keats bookmaking workshop and visit various museums throughout the boro.

P77K is a District 75 school serving students on the autism spectrum from Kindergarten through their graduation at age 21. We believe that the arts play a key role in learning and give our students, both verbal and nonverbal communicators, a way to express themselves creatively. P77K has a strong visual arts program, in which students learn skills in drawing, painting, printmaking, sculpture, digital media and animation.  Students are also exposed to art in their community through participation in programs at MoMA, Brooklyn Art Museum, and Cooper Hewitt Smithsonian Design Museum. Each year, we highlight their work and invite families to share in their accomplishments in school and local art exhibitions and an annual student film festival. Our students have also had work selected for the international VSA exhibition at the Kennedy Center in Washington D.C., PS Arts at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Times Square Coalition for the Arts, Brooklyn Borough Arts Festival, and have been awarded the city and district awards in the Ezra Jack Keats Bookmaking Competition. In the performing arts we have a lively music program in which our students study a wide variety of musical genres and explore playing different instruments. We have partnered with cultural organizations including BAM, Music for Many, and Marquis Studios to provide further exploration of music, as well as dance and theatre to give our students the opportunity to express themselves through movement, build peer interactions, and strengthen fine and gross motor skills.

Serving 100% of students with disabilities, we find that participation in various art forms, including visual and performing arts, and music allow our students to be successful. We tap into a talent that is generally not seen in other academic areas. Therefore, we hope to build upon our performing arts program through dance and music, and also expand our offerings to our students with autism. This year, we have added stepping to our offerings. We hope to continue bringing new opportunities to our students.

Our arts instruction is linked to the social studies curriculum, and it is supported by classroom and/or cluster teachers at the site. Students have opportunities throughout the school day to interact with peers and explore skills through different artistic media. Students then have the opportunity to describe their artwork through writing. Sharing these ideas has helped to open up students and explore new interests, which can help facilitate more meaningful core content instruction through the incorporation of these interests. This further promotes student voice and increases self confidence. In addition, students have used the arts to develop gross and fine motor skills through the incorporation of arts activities, which allow them greater exposure to motivating movement and exercise.

Q37_4: Following the class progress on Artsonia website
Q44_1: PS 231, in District 75, offers a rigorous arts education program with a full range of creative arts for our student body. Student engagement in music, dance, drama, and the visual arts is designed to develop creative thinking, problem solving, and social competence in support of student IEP goals and personal growth. Instructional plans are aligned with common core standards and the Blueprint for the Arts with special attention to cross-curricula connections, and school wide CEP goals. Arts lessons build on prior knowledge and are designed to demonstrate growth over time. Each arts teacher provides hands on experiential learning in large and small groups with a range of differentiated supports to facilitate student success across a varied population of student ages, needs, and abilities. The arts program at 231 includes multisensory experiences guided by teachers and artists in residence that are linked to cultural, historical, and social contexts. Arts exploration provides our students with opportunities to increase personal and community awareness and to develop peer-to-peer interaction. Through out the year parents are invited to engage with students during various special events designed to enrich student life and nurture a lifelong enjoyment of the arts. Events may include Student performances, student art exhibitions and visits to a variety of cultural institutions.

P368K continues to offer visual arts to every student in our program. The arts program spans across grades and supports all students in both alternate and standardized assessments. Additionally, our annual Winterfest and Black History Concert is well attended by parents and the entire school community. Each class selects a seasonal performance, song, dance, poem, reading, skit etc. to perform to the school community. In the spring of each year, our art teachers organize the annual Spring Variety show, where students across all grades participate and exhibit their talents.   
For the 2016-17 school year we were excited to hire both music and dance teachers, who has been a great asset to our school community by enriching and cultivating our students talents. 
Through usage of song, instruments, and technology(interactive whiteboard, laptop, music interface)our students have strived creating their own songs and music.  In addition our music teacher has written grants that has enhanced our musical program with new equipment such as keyboards, guitars, speakers, etc.  
At the high school level the dance teacher has provided our students on the autism spectrum with the opportunity to express themselves through different styles of dance and movement such as African Rhythms, Jazz, and Caribbean.

The students at P373K have the opportunity to participate in visual, theater, music, dance, and film/media arts in varied settings within and outside of the school environment. They have the opportunity to visit local cultural organizations, museums & galleries, assemblies, lectures, educational films, and hands-on learning experiences within our community. Our school has built a well-rounded arts program that continues to grow and has been largely documented by the students themselves and showcased on the student-built and maintained school website. Also, since the inception of our musical theater program 3 years ago, students have taken on increasingly challenging projects; this year we will be presenting "GREASE". The students are creating the artwork and set design for this performance, participating in chorus, dance, film, and acting. Some students have even taken on direction, production, stage management, lighting and sound, and costume design. Our school arts program continues to evolve yearly, as nearly all classroom teachers are collaborating to incorporate different arts disciplines into their classrooms to support their curricula and our young adults' creative strengths.
Q45_1: P373K/Brooklyn TransitionCenter is a school that serves High School Special needs students.

Q44_1: P369 feels that the Arts are integral part of a student's education. We provide all our students exposure to dance, music, musical instruments, art, and various field trips based on the arts.

Arts education is infused throughout the curriculum in all grades. The techniques students utilize, and the knowledge they acquire are gained through various multi-media projects in visual arts, music, drama and dance classes. This knowledge has helped them grow in ELA, math, science and social studies courses.

Our school services a range of students. Our students have severe learning and emotional challenges. Our program also services students with autism. Arts education allows the students to learn and explore through a different means. By infusing arts into the every day curriculum, we see students excel and shine. Many are extremely motivated to participate in out arts programs and engaged for extended periods of time. We currently have a fine arts and a music program at our school. Although these are our dedicated arts programs, all classroom teachers use arts education as part of their every day instruction. This year we have continued with our school beautification project and added additional murals into our community.

Q37_4: Hosting school wide events and funding arts partnerships.
Q44_1: The goal of our program is to engage children in discovery and expression through the arts. Arts instruction at PS 372 supports children's ability to learn by providing several entry points to their studies, including visual/spatial, kinesthetic, mathematical, intra and inter-personal modalities. Based on National, State and City Standards, and aligned with the Common Core Learning Standards, our arts programs include instruction in art making, art literacy, critique and analysis, and the study of the arts in history and culture. Arts education at The Children's school often integrates with learning in other disciplines including social studies, science and English language arts. In all units of instruction there is an emphasis on higher order thinking skills. We believe that the arts education enhances our ability to think critically, since the very act of creativity depends the students' ability to solve problems of expression and representation.
Q45_1: The Children's School, PS 372, has two sites. Housed at IS113, our program for Children with Autism serves over 50 children in self-contained, 6:1:1 classes. At our main site on Carroll Street our ICT program serves 450 children. Here, each class is comprised of 15-18 children in general education, and 8-10 children with special needs. Our special needs population includes children with ADD, ADHD, ASD, hearing impairment, visual impairment, Down's Syndrome, various learning disabilities, and children with emotional disabilities.

Q44_1: The arts program at P396K continues to grow from year to year. Presently we have four full time teachers assigned to the arts program, Dance, Music, Theatre and Visual Arts. We also partner with the Brooklyn Conservatory of Music to provide music every Friday to our students.  As well as, instruction in dance and music provided by several cultural organizations such as Flamenco Vivo, Paul Taylor and teaching artists from BAM.  School staff work with parents to make sure that each child has the opportunity to participate fully in our art program. Along with our monthly shows and exhibits,  we continue with our Saturday Family Program. This provides a great opportunity for students, parents and staff to come together and engage in scaffolding arts activities. Classroom teachers and the art teachers work collaboratively to provide our students with field trips to museums and provide other experiences to support their curricular learning with arts exposure to arts and theatre. We work diligently to use our art funding and supplement with PA funds and other school monies to provide opportunities through cultural arts organizations.
Q45_1: Our students serve students with many challenges. At present our student population consist of 12;1:4, 6:1:1 and 12:1:1 special needs populations. We strive to ensure that every student performs to the best of his or her level of independence to prepare for life as an adult. This includes rigorous functional academics including art, reading, writing, math and employment skills. We also teach our students communication skills and daily living skills.

Q37_4: Attending District Arts Events, Attending Brooklyn Borough Arts Exhibits
Q44_1: Arts instruction at 721K are as follows: music, dance, visual art, are provided by full-time arts teachers. Theater/performance arts are provided through arts workshops. Non-arts teachers use theater, music and visual arts to enhance instruction on a regular basis.  We have expanded our use of cultural providers to enhance student access to all arts forms. Strong connections to The Met Museum have been established and we hoping to continue our partnership with them next year. 721K provided regular field trips to the public art on view on the subway lines in our community.  We are working to fully integrate all art forms into our school's sequence and expand in-house professional developing programming in art instruction. 721K offers students and their families an opportunity to view films or participate in a dance at our Family Nights throughout the school year. This year we have also expanded our family programming to include paint nights as well.

We at BSCD explore and embrace a variety of art forms and programs that are proven useful to our student population. Our program is unique because it supports our students social and emotional learning and incorporates practical skill building. A well staffed and supportive team of professionals working collaboratively accomplishes this. Students are prepared not only on a social and emotional level, but can graduate from the school with practical, job related skills and experience. With the expansion of our student population to include students with autism and the addition of another physical site, we have utilized the arts as a means of communication and personal expression.  Our goal is to stress the importance of academics, job skills, and competitive employment. For this, we facilitate specific programs that are aligned with the common core learning standards and follow the Blueprint for the Arts.
Q45_1: This year we opened our new site, Aveyron Academy at the Canarsie Educational Campus.  Our students are predominantly students on the autism spectrum.  Classroom teachers and speech teachers use the arts as motivation, introduction, and baseline writing.

Q44_1: P771K is a District 75 special education school across multiple eight sites. The school as a whole participates in arts through literacy and the teachers work closely with classroom teachers to create a curriculum based on units of study. P771K has also participated in the Marquis Studios program where outside teachers come and work with the students in visual arts as well as music at one site.  The goal of the P771K art program is to provide the students with resources and hands-on experience  that will help foster their love and understanding of the arts.  This goal will hopefully lead the students to discover a lifelong enjoyment and appreciation of the arts.  Through these experiences, P771K hopes to provide an environment that will help the students develop skills that will improve their educational, social and emotional goals as well as to enhance their skill set.

Our instructional goals include: to increase student skills for exploring movement, music and visual art processes; to increase music/sound production skills using age/interest/ability appropriate experiences; to support positive behaviors through increased multi-modality communication/expressive skills; to increase academic achievement through arts activities with strong connections to CCLS concepts/skills; and to increase opportunities for positive social interactions with peers.  Our professional goals include: to increase staff content knowledge and improve skills for aligning CCLS concepts/skills to interactive arts experiences that are engaging/relevant/meaningful to our students; to create/provide opportunities for students to access wide-ranging arts experiences with increased independence; and to expand strategies that support communication, socialization and positive behaviors.
Our arts partners implement strategies well matched to students' diverse abilities, preferences and ages.  They provide students with engaging and interactive opportunities to experience, replicate and enjoy a variety of arts skills and techniques. Students are demonstrating gains in sensory skills that positively impact communication, socialization and behaviors.

The Connie Lekas School provides many opportunities for rich arts experiences to our students. In addition to full-time music and visual arts teachers, we have extensive arts residencies with cultural partners in dance, music, visual art and theater. We have an accomplished choral ensemble, visual arts showcases and seasonal Family Arts Day celebrations each year. This year we were able to offer a Family Engagement art program on weekends. We appreciate the value of arts education as a way for our students to achieve their full potential.

P35M is an elementary through high school with students from Kindergarten through grade 12. P35M is dedicated to academic excellence. P35M offers students multifaceted arts experiences in an environment organized to provide opportunities and supports appropriate to student abilities. Teachers implement the Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts Curriculum and The New York State Arts Standards by aligning arts instruction with the Common Core Learning Standards. Assessment is made on individual achievement related to each student’s stage of growth and development. An arts integration model engages students in various arts activities linked to literacy in the arts, making arts connections to other academic areas, utilizing community cultural resources, acquiring knowledge of arts careers and encouraging students to regard arts as a means of expression and a source of lifelong enjoyment. The art program enables each student to develop positive attitudes toward self, others and the environment through creative experiences. Problem solving and creative learning encourage the student to relate visual knowledge to other core subjects and to respond with originality, appreciation, flexibility and imagination.

Dr. Horan/P79M’s collaboration with Harlem Studio Museum continues to grow and every effort is being made to sustain and build upon this partnership. The benefits to our students' are indescribable. Once again, Harlem Studio Museum has generously donated their space to host our 2nd Annual Laser Painting Art Exhibit. Our Laser Painting Program is a collaboration between District 75 and Marquis Studio. Our resident artist, Deborah Dawson, works with students who are multiply handicapped to create works of Art that are inspiring. Our students' achievement have surpassed our expectations. Their work has been showcased in il Café Latte in Harlem. Another student’s work is being showcased in the Ultralight Art Exhibition in North Carolina.

P94M The Spectrum School is the District 75 School of Visual and Performing Arts. Residencies with ArtsConnection and Marquis Studios build on instruction provided by 23 school-based arts specialists across eight sites, engaging K-12 students with special needs in dedicated arts programming for more than 50% of the school week. In class instruction and residencies, students creatively access core content curricula in ELA, math, social studies and science through the arts. Our nationally-recognized musical theater program, STAARS (Sequential Teaching in Arts, Action Research and Scholarship), based in arts education research, grounded in the NYC BLUEPRINTS FOR THE ARTS, and NYS Arts Standards, is a sequential arts curriculum through which children learn the social/emotional and communication skills, paired with the academics they need to succeed in school and daily life. Our instruction is continually revised based on monthly data collected and reviewed by each of our 23 dedicated arts specialists.

721M is a District 75 Alternative Assessment school that services middle through high school students with intellectual, behavioral, emotional, social, and physical challenges and disabilities. The school's mission and vision is to provide a smooth transition from school to life in the community and the best post-secondary outcomes for all. Our school stresses the acquisition of basic, functional skills that students generalize in all settings to help them become more independent learners and thinkers. Our teachers incorporate multi-media and visual arts in their instruction, and many of our students' culminating projects integrate the arts. Student involvement in the arts not only enriches their lives, but also supports their academic and social development. During this past year, we have successfully provided our students with arts instruction through our visual arts program, Latin Drumming through Title III and Theater with Project Arts. Families are engaged in culminating events that include student performance as well as audience participation. Parents and students were involved in weekend programs to various arts institions.
Q45_1:
Many of our students participate in work site placement/programs in the community and are away for the school much of the school day.

Our student population is 100% special needs.

Q44_1: P.169 M enables its students to explore the arts through different forms and materials. This year we improved upon our music and dance program to enable our students to express more of the strengths that we know they have inside themselves. Through developing their artistic skills we believe this will also activate and improve their self esteem and academic skills.

At P226M, we strive to maintain programming in the arts that is sequential, expands the skill base and knowledge of our students, and aligns to the Common Core Learning Standards. We expect students to increase their physical and intellectual proficiency in the arts as they engage in a variety of motivating, hands-on curricular experiences. P226M's goals in the arts include: 1. To develop critical thinking skills by drawing images of in-class creations, paired with writing about the experience 2. To develop and learn about the arts by visiting/ viewing art in museums, galleries and theatre 3. To develop an interest in art-making, theatre, dance and music 4. To participate in art lessons through self-critique 5. To interact with the arts to promote higher order thinking skills by making connections to other subject areas 6. To self-evaluate and evaluate peer work 7. To critique special works of art with the use of a rubric to understand criteria to grow student's art knowledge-base.

Q37_4: Family Arts Workshops conducted by Arts Horizons
Q44_1: Our goal is to expose students to the arts and encourage life-long learning.  Through visits from our arts partners, students are introduced to and develop an understanding of how the arts reflect diverse cultures of the past and present - through music, movement and visual arts such as painting, sculpture, printmaking and collage.  Our collaboration with the arts' organizations has led to an important kind of thinking which transfers to all areas for our students. These multisensory means of engagement are aligned with CCLS and the NYC Blueprint for the Arts. The arts have positively contributed to the social emotional and academic areas in each classroom. Thus, our students have exhibited increased respect for personal space, taking turns, listening and responding appropriately. Our visual arts units exemplify collaborative teamwork among students.  The residencies have made a strong impact on our students by increasing peer to peer respect, building vocabulary and confidence to express themselves in a safe environment. In addition, through dance and rhythm, our students worked through impulse control, sequencing skills, following directions and socialization.  The multisensory nature of the arts is vital to our students most of whom are in psychiatric crisis. We believe in the expressive, creative and therapeutic benefits of engaging through the arts.
Q45_1: Our students are hospitalized for medical, rehab or psychiatric reasons.  Our student population is transient and changes on a daily basis.  Therefore, it is important to mention that the numbers reflect a snapshot of students, but does not truly reflect the attendance for a full school year.  In addition, we do not have students for a full day in many sites so we must integrate the arts into other content areas to address all standards in a short amount of time.  We greatly value the arts and appreciate what the Arts Counts budget affords for our very special students.  Although, capturing growth and data is a challenge for a transient group of students, we see first- hand the power and magic of the arts

Q44_1: Home Instruction Schools is an interim program serving over 3000 students per year who receive instruction until they are ready to return to their school of affiliation. Art and music is taught as a requirement for high school students. Art and music is also used for all of our Alternate Assessment students to develop gross and fine motor skills and is used to differentiate student learning. The arts program is also infused into the curriculum for elementary and middle school students to help enhance their learning in other academic areas.

The arts at 751M provides students with opportunities to learn about music, visual arts, and film as forms of personal and cultural expression. Students work with classroom teachers to connect the arts to their core content classes, as well as to explore how they relate to career readiness. Our school has a long-standing relationship with community organization, Best Buddies, IncludeNYC, Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, Zumba and several arts related trips, which allows the school to collaborate with the community and effectively exposes students to the arts across disciplines. Students also participate in community-based arts field trips in each discipline.

P811M offers students multifaceted arts experiences in an environment that is organized to provide opportunities and supports that are
appropriate to student abilities. An arts integration model engages students in various arts activities linked to literacy in the arts, making arts connections to other academic areas, utilizing community cultural resources, acquiring knowledge of arts careers, and encouraging students to regard arts as a means of expression and a source of lifelong enjoyment. Our goals include supporting differentiated instruction in the arts through the development of curriculum and professional development for teachers of visual art, music, dance and theater. We support and follow the guidelines of the Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in the Arts, prek-12, which outlines what students should know and be able to do in the arts at benchmark grade levels.
Q45_1:
P811M, The Mickey Mantle School is a District 75 school consisting of one main site and five off sites. In total, we proudly serve 350-400 students with severe disabilities grades Pre-K-8. P811M students are categorized as having multiple disabilities, autism, emotional/behavioral difficulties and/or severe language and communication disorders.
By looking at the whole child, The Mickey Mantle School focuses on social-emotional growth and works to provide strategies to internalize positive behavior. Universal systems are implemented as well as targeted interventions as part of our Positive Behavior Intervention Supports program. P811M maintains excellent communication with parents integrating a wider range of information being passed between home and school in the form of newsletters, workshops and daily communication tools.

Q42_R1_C1: Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center
Q44_1: While following the NYC Blueprint for the Arts curriculum, our goal is to provide a meaningful arts program to all students with disabilities. We strive to achieve this by being committed to the arts by staffing all our sites with full time arts teachers. We also work with a variety of arts organizations to provide professional development for our arts teachers, as well as exposure to the arts for our students, in our culturally rich community. Our students are also exposed to the arts through visits to theaters, museums and concert halls. Additionally, we provide performances on and off site in order to present the student's hard work to their parents and guardians. There is also a great deal of collaboration between the arts teachers and the classroom teachers across all sites.

P009Q is a multi-site, multi-grade organization that serves 649 emotionally disturbed and multiply disabled students at seven school sites. We have dedicated seven staff positions to design and implement literacy, poetry, play writing, video production, editing, costume/set design and visual arts. We have established a model of arts education that is infused across curriculum areas and have involved all school personnel including related service providers in every discipline to insure the sustainability of our model.

P 23 Q is a multi-site organization serving students in grades K-12 from all five boroughs. At P 23 Q it is our belief that an effective arts program contributes to the emotional and educational well-being of the whole child. Our goal is to provide a basic foundation and appreciation of the arts and to have this foundation support other areas of instructional learning throughout the school day. Through the arts we are able to reinforce content areas through hands on project based learning, increase self-esteem, develop social skills, and improve team building while addressing the students' individual needs with regard to their various learning styles. Visual arts, theater and music are offered to our students throughout the year. Students grades K-12 participate in Little Kids Rock, a nationwide program which uses innovative music education approaches to involve students in creating music. Students learn guitar, bass, keyboards, and drums while playing contemporary and classic popular music. We piloted the Broadway Bridges Program which aims to get students to attend Broadway shows at discounted prices. We also participated in the NYCDOE’s Digital Theatre Program. Through the Office of Arts and Special Project’s partnership with C&T Theatre in England, students used theatre techniques to explore contemporary issues and shared their work with students from around NYC and the world. High school students earn credits for music and art that fulfill requirements for graduation.

The P. 75 Q School Community provides fine arts as a part of the curriculum established by the New York State Department of Education (NYSDOE). Our fine arts teachers follow the prescribed curriculum set forth by the New York State Department of Education. Additionally, fine arts teachers have participated in professional development provided by the Department of Education at the Central level or in conjunction with District 75's professional development calendar and through outside arts organizations to improve the quality of their teaching. The school supplements arts instruction through Project Arts Funding, as well as, monies drafted from the school budget. Art residencies and supplies are funded through both sources. The P.75Q Community is committed to exposing our students to multiple artistic endeavors to provide a complete educational experience.

Our school community understands the importance and the benefits of a full range of arts programming incorporated into our curriculum. The arts in the curriculum have an enormous impact on the core subjects. In addition, the arts also provide activities that develop focus, problem solving, prolonged attention, mastery, self esteem, decision making, observation and experimentation to name a few. The student gains ownership of the activity which translates to motivation. Learning begins with desire and the arts create desire. P177Q will continue to expose all of our students to a variety of disciplines in the arts for maximum learning potential. We continue to strive to expose our students to a variety of art experiences that will enable our students to grow and expand their potentials through different genres. All art programs have a definite impact on the "whole child" and enables them to be successful in all subject areas due to the wide range of skills that they are exposed to during the arts. The arts provide an environment of success without stress. This is so important for our students to reach their goals. Next year, we plan to expand out arts curriculum by adding a Social Skills through Drama full time teaching position.
Q45_1: Our main site of approximately 50 classes is a self contained, District 75 school serving students with Autism Spectrum Disorders, as well as those with Intellectual and Emotional Disabilities. These students are all Alternate Assessment. In addition, we have an off site of our youngest students, with similar disabilities including Multiple Handicapped students. We also have two Inclusion sites with three classes who receive art and music classes with their general education peers.  It is important to our whole organization that all our students receive instruction in all aspects of the arts.

Q44_1: We strive to provide a rich and varied arts program to our diverse population.  We are limited by inadequate space but we do our best to expose our children to all the arts and have them see themselves as capable or producing and enjoying the arts.  We know that the arts are an important part of a person's life and that the arts enrich a person's whole life. Our students are life-long learners.
Q45_1: We have a varied population of emotionally disturbed, cognitively delayed, autistic and hearing impaired children.  It is a challenge to help them all feel successful and challenged.  The arts can offer many of our children an outlet for creativity, frustration and communication.

Q44_1: P233Q serves students with special needs (autism, physical disabilities, emotional and cognitive challenges). Through the arts, students engage in interesting and meaningful activities that are aligned to the learning standards and IEP goals. The year long curriculum serves to expose students to theater, music, dance, visual arts, and poetry. With each unit module, students have opportunity to expand their understanding of the arts reflected in scheduled performances and/or culminating projects. At the start of the school year, students take an interest inventory to identify individual student interests and talents. As a result of these personal inventories, students have been selected to participate in the school band, dance team, step team, art club, and culinary club. To extend learning across content areas, the arts are infused into core subjects. This year, the school had special assemblies to include performances by Young Audiences. P233Q now has a theater group and Step Team. The students participate in the Queens Borough and District 75 Arts Festivals. As several P233Q classes are housed in a community High school, several students have been provided with the opportunity to participate in an after school theater program.

255Q's ARTS Program supports the school's focus on a multi-sensory approach to learning.Teachers of the ARTS provide instruction in their disciplines with emphasis on teaching targets related to developing skills. These "teaching targets" are developed through the use of school-wide assessments. Additionally, teachers of the ARTS, in collaboration with classroom teachers, select student IEP goals for which they take data and monitor student progress thus supporting on-going collaboration with the classroom teachers. This process advances a collective responsibility for implementation of the IEP as a comprehensive plan.

256Q is a conglomerate of 6 sites spread over 40 miles. Our population ranges from 6:1:1,8:1:1,12:1:1 and general education students. We serve students from pre-K through High School. With limited resources, we cover our 6 sites by programming art, theater and music into our school day. Our Middle/High School programs have attended On/Off Broadway Shows & Sporting events through MVP(Most Valuable Kids),and CEA(Creative Arts Education).256Q believes that exposure to the Arts enhances instruction, encourages students to work cooperatively, develops fine/gross motor skills and paves the road for a variety of expression. The Arts can open doors to Global Communities all over the world.
This year was our 2nd year in receiving a $15,000 ELLS Grant; we had 2 resident artists from Art Connections who worked with our High School Programs in the Creation of Hallway and Entranceway 3-D Murals for (2) of our sites.

Beyond Tutoring provided a "You are Your Decisions" 3 day workshop for 3 sites.

We have employed Marquis Studios and Mass Transit to conduct Professional Development on Chancellors Conference Day; between these (2) vendors, all of our teachers across all sites will be addressed.
 
Lincoln Center provided free shows for a variety of school classes.
School Trips and admission prices for; Museum and Gold Vault, Bronx Zoo, Photoville, Cradle of Aviation, Tolerance Museum, Love Heals Professional Development, College Trips etc.
Q45_1:
Due to budgetary restraints, reaching out to neighboring resources enhance all of our programs. Some examples of this are;

United we ohm; a not-for profit who provides yoga training for those in need.

Neighborhood Community Officers-4 session initiative with the 100th  Precinct which culminated in a Field Trip to the Police Academy.

Beautiful Me - a female empowerment story of survival

LGBT Network provided guest speakers/resources for weekly meetings.

RISE-Rockaway Institute for Sustainable Environment

From the Fires:Voices From the Holocaust

Breezy Motorcycle Run

Lead to Free - a Sustainable Gardening program

Nassau County Library Association - provides school performances and resources to our Syosset site.

We have held school/class Celebrations for Poetry Slams, Multi-cultural Luncheons, Body Systems presentation, Debate Class, Social Studies Fair etc.
We have 6 teachers who are solely dedicated to providing Arts Classes

Q44_1: The Arts and Music programs for all the 277Q sites are based off the Blueprint for Teaching and Learning in Visual Arts. Instructional targets are based off the 5 strands of art and music from the Blueprint. Students are provided the opportunity to explore different periods, artists, mediums, and techniques in art and music. The Arts and Music program is aligned with our ongoing English Language Arts and Social Studies curriculum. 277Q implements culminating activities in the areas of art and music. Musical performances and art exhibits are ongoing through out the year to celebrate student achievement in the arts.

The John F. Kennedy Jr. School provides services to approximately 490 students with a range of educational, social and physical needs. We have created a program which incorporates the arts in order to maximize our students’ progress towards independence, integration and productivity. Our program incorporates music, dance, visual arts and the performing arts. Our music program provides students with the opportunity to expand their musical abilities and work collaboratively in a chorus. Through dance, motor and movement issues are addressed. We have visual arts and photography programs that allow our students to express themselves creatively. Annual theater productions and holiday shows give students the chance to demonstrate their theatrical talents. Lastly, we offer concerts and cultural events both during and after school hours that foster an appreciation of the arts for our students and their families.

The goals of the Arts program at the Queens Transition Center are to: a) Integrate arts education into the programming of all alternate and standardized assessment students and bridge the arts into the content areas. b) Collaborate and create a series of culminating projects/activities aligned with the common core standards and transition goals of all our students. c) Foster positive peer interactions to build communication and help increase tolerance of diverse individuals. For the 2016-2017 school year we strived to integrate the Capacity Framework with the arts to provide better opportunities for college and career readiness and other post secondary outcomes

The arts education program at P.811Q is multi-faceted. In multi-media classes students used digital cameras to edit and print out photos. Students learned how to edit the school's yearbook; delete old photos and upload the digital pictures of new graduates. Students in all grades received visual art instruction and learned new concepts, with hands-on art making and self expression. Students received Dance/Music and held several performances throughout the year. Students' work was exhibited at the schools' annual Gallery Walk and at District 75 Office. Students' Art work was also exhibited at the Queens Museum of Art. Queens Museum of Art held a residency program at 3 of our sites. At the QHST site, students received art instruction in scrapbooking, technology (including photography and video) dance, music and art. Students learned how to layout digital pictures for the school newspaper. Students were also offered the opportunity to join various school clubs: Glee, dance, music and girls club. The arts education goal for our school is to provide the students the resources and tools to enable them to explore and enjoy the various forms of art.
Q45_1: Alternate Assessment District 75 School serving students in Grades K-12+.  Special Education teachers are needed to teach all the arts in order to best adapt work for our students. Our Alternate Assessment ratios are 12:1:1, 8:1:1, 6:1:1 and 12:1:4 in Grades K-12+

Q44_1: This year we Worked with Arts Horizon. Arts Horizon supplied excellent music/dance field trips for our elementary and middle schools and our High School received the artist in residency programs. We are grateful our students were able to participate and learn from such professionals. Vital components of the arts are put into practice at P993 on a consistent and daily basis. From listening skills to eye hand coordination, to peer interaction in dance and theater, students are actively engaged in best practices. The arts are an active component of the core curriculum; from poetry to Math in Music. The arts engage students by allowing them to describe and evaluate their works of art. That is why we at P.993Q cherish our connection with various arts related activities, performances, etc.

Q42_R1_C1: Learning through an Expanded Arts Program
Q44_1: Art Goals - Students will be assigned various projects over the course of the year, exploring and mastering multiple media and learning the required skills to accomplish the set tasks. Students will learn and apply various themes, concepts and symbols to communicate ideas through art. Students will use the knowledge and skills gained from previous projects and apply them to the following ones. The student will use problem solving skills, perseverance, effort and patience when approaching each task. Students will complete all assigned work within the time frame.
Q45_1: We provide education for students with special needs including students on the autism spectrum and students that have been identified as emotionally disturbed.

Q44_1: Our classroom teachers incorporate the arts into their curriculum and provide a multi-sensory approach to teaching our special needs students. This approach lends itself to using the arts as an important teaching tool. Our Licensed Arts Teacher, provides opportunities for her students to shine, by teaching them how to use their creativity and talents to create works of art that are showcased each year, at various art showcases around the city. Our staff brings many talents to our school, and Theatre Production is a talent that some of our staff members possess. Our first production, Snow White, was a wonderfully enjoyable experience for our talented students! There will be more to come! We are also fortunate enough to be a pARTnership school with Marquis Studios. Our students benefit each year from quality arts instruction, in music, the visual arts, and dance. Our staff and students have formed long term relationships with many master teaching artists from Marquis Studios, who have provided opportunities for both students, through programming, and parents, through parent/child workshops, to embrace the arts and cultivate the talents of our students! The Teaching Artist Training Institute, which is in its 8th year, with financial support from Marquis Studios, has provided the opportunity for teaching artists to learn from Marquis Master teaching artists, to come to our school to learn about effective methods of working with students on the Autism Spectrum as well as students with other developmental disabilities. .

PS168X is a district 75 school serving standardized and alternate assessment students from Pre Kindergarten to High School at 7 different sites. The arts program at each site is unique, tailored to the students’ ages and abilities, and planned independently by the arts teachers available at each site. Our High School students receive arts instruction from the host schools teachers. All of our arts teachers are full time and include 5 Music teachers and 4 Visual Arts teachers. Most of our arts teachers travel with carts and push into classrooms, as we do not have dedicated arts classrooms. Instruction is aligned with the NYC Blueprints for their discipline and supports the CCLS and IEP goals of their students. Classes are differentiated according to interest, age and ability. Each site holds an end of year performance/celebration in shared auditoriums, where students perform for their peers and family members.

It continues to be our goal at P373R to provide a comprehensive arts curriculum within the frameworks of Danielson and the Blueprints for Teaching and Learning in the Arts, and aligned with Core Curriculum Learning Standards. Through the arts, we seek to address the varied learning modalities of our special needs students, both standardized and alternate assessment. Recognizing the power of the arts to support our students' emotional and social growth, as well as academic growth, we will continue to support Emotional Literacy in our school in and through the various arts disciplines. To this end, we continuously work to expand upon our programs, to partner with cultural organizations, whenever possible, and to elevate the rigor of our arts instruction through cohorts and professional development. With an aggressive approach to grant writing, we have been able to supplement our existing programs and bring in partner organizations.
Q45_1: Our school is located in one main site and 4 co-located sites.  We have dated and limited space, which with the exception of one designated art room, is shared not only among any and all art disciplines, but also used for meetings, conferences, social studies and science fairs, PTA functions and testing.  We are in desperate need of space for our students and stage time scheduled for our students.  Co-locations do not freely share space and our Main site is very small and not always available.

Q44_1:
This year our school continued to work with Lincoln Center Education (LCE) and we became one of ten LCE's focus schools throughout NYC. We conducted active research to study the impact of integrating arts instruction with the Lincoln Center Education's capacities (for imaginative thinking) on our students with severe special needs. We have been sharing our findings with the school community at large, as well as with Lincoln Center Education, and other Focus Schools. We funded this work with Project ARTS money, and a NYCDOE Arts & Family Engagement grant.  
We also are a Year-2 School recipient of Shubert Foundation's funds to help support our production of "Peter Pan Jr." at our school's main site.
Q45_1:
P721R is a District 75 school with a main site and 6 annexes.  At all our inclusion sites, we are proud to say that our students are included and succeed in general education classes.  We are part of general education choral and musical shows.  Our visual arts projects are exhibited alongside the general education populations.
At our main site, we have our own school choir.  We entertain audiences at various community events.  We incorporate the arts int the core curricula to make learning more attainable.  We have our students attend various cultural institutions on and off Staten Island.  We find that our parents are strong advocates for the arts.  As a school, we are assertive proposal writers for additional arts funding.

Q44_1:
The Lewis and Clark school’s art program serves grades 6th through 12th with an emphasis on experimentation in the middle grades and a concentration on the principles of design in the latter years. The entire program teaches the elements of art. The program, which encompasses a rigorous academic program, the arts, community service, experiential education, and social emotional development, is based on the recognition that middle and high school students are at a most complicated developmental stage. 

We have partnered with Marquis Studios arts‐in¬‐education services and Daniel’s Music Foundation to offer students with additional arts residency programs. These residency programs offer students a unique opportunity to work with professional artists and experience the arts right in their classrooms.  These in school residencies have been intended to work very closely with the classroom teachers to enhance current curriculum through the use the arts.  Participation in arts residency programs reinforce skills in reading comprehension, following directions, public speaking, critical thinking, conflict resolution, team building, concentration, memorization, character development, and problem solving. Participation in any creative process provides youth with a better understanding of their peers, their communities and the world as a whole.

Q37_4: Cooked traditional meals for a cultural celebration
Q44_1: P17X is a District 75 school serving students with disabilities and diverse learners with an emphasis on connecting arts learning between our elementary and middle school sites through Arts Partnership Grant Programs.  Our arts partnerships with Inside Broadway,  Flamenco Vivo and New Victory Theatre continue to enhance Blueprint based arts programming, increase parental engagement and increase our NYSED hours to meet our special needs students in all arts disciplines.
