We have a history of winning arts competitions including PS Art, the Ezra Jack Keats Bookmaking competition, All Kids Can Create National Exhibit, All You Can Be by former Yankee Curtis Granderson, and the Bronx Borough Arts Festival.

PS 176X is a district 75 program serving students with Autism Spectrum Disorder and other special needs. Through the art mediums such as music, modern dance, hip hop, yoga, ballet, musical theater, band, chorus and visual arts, students enhance their language, self direction, social skills, reading and life skills as well as performance skills. 

Aside from projects based in literacy, the school has developed several performing arts groups such as a school chorus, keyboard, three drum lines and a dance troupe. We continue to work with the "EASE" organization through professional development and online services. This year, the school received the Shubert Arts Grant for theater workshops involving students and their families. Our school participates in a district sponsored yoga program entitled Get Ready to Learn. 176x participates in District 75 arts events. Students participate in monthly assemblies during which they perform or attend performances that help facilitate a positive school culture for students, parents and staff. 

The school has a collaboration with the Disney Organization, where Disney drama educators work with students and staff so that the students may perform the show, "The Jungle Book." The entire school community was involved with The Jungle Book production in some capacity. The arts provide a pathway to learning that connects the common core learning standards and the NYCDOE Blueprints for the Arts as well as parent engagement.
Q45_1:
The school was highlighted in "Arts In Schools" magazine in October, where they highlighted the school's work centered around the arts.  

Art teacher, Faye Moses was selected for the Very Special Arts calendar, in which her student's work was celebrated. 

New this year, the school welcomed our school therapy dog, Izzy. Izzy is a two year beagle and is instrumental in social communication and expression.

Q44_1: The P186x arts program utilizes the NYCDOE Blueprint for the arts curriculum framework. Our students engage in project-based learning activities in the visual arts, as well as cooperative team activities in the movement and theater arts. During the 2016/2017 school year P186X integrated dance and movement into the curriculum by creating a dance/movement position for our Alternate Assessment students. In the 2017/2018 school year, the school plans to develop and schedule an "Advanced Art" class for those identified 8th grade students whose goal is to apply to an "art specialized" High School and future careers in a general education setting.
Q45_1: P186X is a District 75/Citywide Special Education school located in the Bronx, southeast of Crotona Park. There are a total of 69 classes throughout the P186X organization. The main site has a total of 46 classes, grades K-8, which consists of: thirteen Standardized Assessment 8:1:1 classes, fourteen Standardized Assessment 12:1:1 classes, six Alternate Assessment 12:1:4 classes, six Alternate Assessment 12:1:1 classes, two Alternate Assessment 8:1:1 classes, and five Alternate Assessment 6:1:1 classes. In addition to the main building there are five annexes which are: P186X@PS306X which consists of 16 Alternate Assessment classes, grades K-8: four 12:1:4 classes, eight 12:1:1 classes, two 12:1:1 bilingual classes (one Transitional Bilingual Education (TBE) and one Dual Language Program (DLP), and two 8:1:1 classes. The P186X@PS140X annex consists of four Standardized Assessment 12:1:1 classes, grades K-5. P186X@New York State Psychiatric Institute has one adolescent High School class. P186X@Bronx Studio High School and P186X@ PS140X each have one inclusion class. Our vision is for all students to be engaged and excel in Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts, and Mathematics (STEAM), academics and social skills to be prepared for college and careers. Our mission is to provide students with the necessary tools to transition into a Least Restrictive Environment (LRE) by providing them with access to learning through representation, action/expression, and engagement.

Q44_1: Our art program continues to be robust. P188X integrates the arts into our curriculum following the Blueprint for the Arts. We strive to meet the needs of our diverse student population. We have two theater classes at two sites, art/literacy at two sites, and visual arts at three of our sites. p188X has dance movement class at two of our sites and continues to explore arts integration. We continue to strive to meet the diverse needs of our students through the arts internally and externally with the help of cultural programs, public performances and art exhibits. We partner with Marquis Art Studio annually and MOMA to support out students' learning.  We were the recipient of A Studio in Arts grant for our Pre-K program.  Arts Connection has partner with us to support dance and creative expression with our ENL population. Annually our H.S. program attends the Ballet as a unit at Columbia and the Orchestra of St. Luke's.  Our teachers participate in EASE professional development along with district based professional development. We participate in Materials for the Arts program where teachers receive art materials. Our High School inclusion program is partnered with an arts CBO. We were published in the 2016-2017 VSA calendar.  We received honors from the NYCDOE for our arts education program and the Bronx Museum of Art.  Our students enjoy and excel in the arts.  P188x values Art Education and will continue to strive for artistic excellence in all areas!

Our goal is to provide arts instruction that is appropriate, individualized and thoughtfully designed to address the strengths and needs of all students at P352X. The arts are an integral part of instruction at P352X and are embedded within the curriculum across all subject areas. Teachers of the arts work with classroom teachers and related service providers to support students in improving socialization skills through real world, cross-curricular and collaborative experiences. Students participate in a wide range of authentic art experiences to broaden their understanding of various art forms and related careers. Students can be found creating original works of art, performing traditional song or dance and experimenting with media to create an iMovie. During the 2016-2017 school year, P352X has continued its participation in Disney Musicals in Schools. This experience has supported the development of a sustainable musical-theatre program within our school, thereby strengthening our school’s arts program. Students and staff gained exposure to the many benefits of musical theatre, including the development of self-confidence, collaborative skills, speaking and reading skills, and creativity. To extend art education beyond the classroom, we take advantage of every opportunity to expose our students to the vast cultural resources that NYC has to offer and we value the partnerships we’ve formed with our community.

P469X The Bronx School for Continuous Learners opened in September 2014. In both 2014-2015 and 2015-2016, we were the recipient of the Arts for ELLs and SWD grants, providing us with a total of $30,000 to fund arts-related residencies. This year we were ineligible to re-apply since we received it two years in a row, but found arts residencies to incorporate into our after school programming and monthly culminating activities. We also enhanced the arts within our programming by introducing both Performing Arts and Movement/Dance into our repertoire of teaching and learning for the 2016-2017. Next year, we plan on enhancing and expanding the arts opportunities for our students as a K-6 school in the 2017-2018 school year.

For school year 2016-2017 we decided to use our funding to supply two of our visual arts teachers with technology tools, e.g. Smartboards. This will allow students the opportunity to visualize individual steps to guide them through any projects they are creating, whether a collage, still life, city scene, etc.

The Jeffrey M. Rapport School for Career Development has continued to provide a diverse art curriculum for its students. The visual arts program includes coursework in: Illustration, painting, color theory, sculpting, and art history. We also often collaborate with the wood shop teacher, who has students paint pictures on various wood designs. Student work is showcased during parent-teacher conferences and will be shown during our annual Family Fair Day as well.
